description: shrub 1-4 (-7.5) m high,  obconic and commonly spindly. bark grey. branchlets minutely appressed-puberulous, the hairs often embedded in resin, the ridges  resinous-crenulated. phyllodes mostly obliquely elliptic or narrowly elliptic, 4-12 (-16) cm long, 10-30 (-40) mm wide, rigid, acute to obtuse, minutely  velvety with hairs not visible to unaided eye, pale bluish green or milky pale green, multistriate, with minor veins numerous (7-9 per mm) and not anastomosing, with 3 or more prominent veins confluent near base. spikes 2-6 (-7) cm long, orange or golden. peduncles 1-3 mm long, densely puberulous. flowers 5-merous, resinous; calyx 0.9-1.2 mm long, dissected for ¢‚¬¦¢‚¬¢-½ its length, puberulous; corolla 1.8-2.2 mm long, dissected for circa ½ its length, glabrous; ovary puberulous. pods linear, almost straight-sided, often curved,  compressed-terete, 4-13 cm long, crustaceous, pubescent to  glabrous, resinous, longitudinally furrowed. seeds longitudinal, narrowly oblong to oblong-elliptic, 3-6 mm long, dark brown; pleurogram with yellowish halo; areole  open, depressed, olive-brown. the plate labelled 'acacia acradenia ' by f.j.von mueller, iconography of australian species of acacia and cognate genera dec. 11 [pl. 4] (1888), is a mixture of two species; figs 1-8 represent acacia acradenia and 9-13 acacia umbellata. these two species are frequently confused, although acacia acradenia has longer corollas, longer pods, spikes (only rarely with a rudimentary shoot between them) borne in pairs in the phyllode axils, and appressed-puberulous-pubescent branchlets, peduncles, rachises and part or most of phyllodes. a specimen from the mckinley range, south australia, (viz. 1876, sutherland, nsw), which is much further south than all other records, suggests a possible outlier population or doubtful record that requires further investigation. grows in skeletal sandy soils and red earths, on laterite, sandstone or calcrete, on rocky hillsides or in gorges, often along creeks with eucalypts and spinifex. a relatively short-lived species that is killed by hot summer fires; it regenerates from seed and may form localised colonies in areas following disturbance (bruce maslin, pers. comm., june 2012). flowers all year. details of aboriginal use of acacia acradenia are given by latz, book_source 85 (1995). the seeds have been utilised for food (kenneally et al. 1996: 128). ;
original_text: Shrub 1-4 (-7.5) m high,  obconic and commonly spindly. Bark grey. Branchlets minutely appressed-puberulous, the hairs often embedded in resin, the ridges  resinous-crenulated. Phyllodes mostly obliquely elliptic or narrowly elliptic, 4-12 (-16) cm long, 10-30 (-40) mm wide, rigid, acute to obtuse, minutely  velvety with hairs not visible to unaided eye, pale bluish green or milky pale green, multistriate, with minor veins numerous (7-9 per mm) and not anastomosing, with 3 or more prominent veins confluent near base. Spikes 2-6 (-7) cm long, orange or golden. Peduncles 1-3 mm long, densely puberulous. Flowers 5-merous, resinous; calyx 0.9-1.2 mm long, dissected for ¢‚¬¦¢‚¬¢-½ its length, puberulous; corolla 1.8-2.2 mm long, dissected for c. ½ its length, glabrous; ovary puberulous. Pods linear, almost straight-sided, often curved,  compressed-terete, 4-13 cm long, crustaceous, pubescent to  glabrous, resinous, longitudinally furrowed. Seeds longitudinal, narrowly oblong to oblong-elliptic, 3-6 mm long, dark brown; pleurogram with yellowish halo; areole  open, depressed, olive-brown. The plate labelled 'Acacia acradenia ' by F.J.H. von Mueller, Iconography of Australian Species of Acacia and Cognate Genera dec. 11 [pl. 4] (1888), is a mixture of two species; figs 1-8 represent Acacia acradenia and 9-13 Acacia umbellata. These two species are frequently confused, although Acacia acradenia has longer corollas, longer pods, spikes (only rarely with a rudimentary shoot between them) borne in pairs in the phyllode axils, and appressed-puberulous-pubescent branchlets, peduncles, rachises and part or most of phyllodes. A specimen from the McKinley Range, South Australia, (viz. 1876, Sutherland, NSW), which is much further south than all other records, suggests a possible outlier population or doubtful record that requires further investigation. Grows in skeletal sandy soils and red earths, on laterite, sandstone or calcrete, on rocky hillsides or in gorges, often along creeks with eucalypts and spinifex. A relatively short-lived species that is killed by hot summer fires; it regenerates from seed and may form localised colonies in areas following disturbance (Bruce Maslin, pers. comm., June 2012). Flowers all year. Details of Aboriginal use of Acacia acradenia are given by P. Latz, Bushfires & Bushtucker 85 (1995). The seeds have been utilised for food (Kenneally et al. 1996: 128).

simplified_phrase: in some places, regenerates from seed after fire
fire: in some places it regenerates prolifically from seed following fire (b.maslin, pers.
description: compact shrub, crowns smoky grey or blue to grey-green or blue-green. branchlets densely velvety-tomentose with white patent or slightly retrorse hairs. phyllodes usually 6-10 per whorl and (1.5-) 2-5 (-7) mm long, pubescent with slightly curved hairs. peduncles (3-) 6-18 mm long, indumentum similar to branchlets. bracteoles setose in upper half. calyx lobes and corolla lobes hispid, with hairs 0.2-0.4 mm long. the variety has been generally confused with acacia lycopodiifolia which it resembles in indumentum and habit. the arrangement of the seeds in the pod, the lack of setae on the phyllodes, and the fewer phyllodes per whorl distinguish the two taxa. a specimen labelled port darwin, [northern territory], forrest (mel) apparently has an incorrect locality. a collection from abydos-woodstock reserve in the pilbara, western australia, k.tinley 3274 (perth), has unusually short hairs on its branchlets and phyllodes, and atypically short peduncles (3-4 mm long). another pilbara plant (r.chinnock 9705, perth, from the mid-slope of mt meharry) is unusual in having up to 15 phyllodes per whorl which are longer than normal (10-12 mm) (b.maslin, pers. comm.). occasionally hybridises with acacia spondylophylla in the pilbara region, western australia. this very attractive variety has horticultural potential as a ground cover, especially for rockery plantings. in some places it regenerates prolifically from seed following fire (b.maslin, pers. comm.). grows in sand (commonly lateritic) and in shallow rocky soil. flowers mostly april-september. ;
original_text: Compact shrub, crowns smoky grey or blue to grey-green or blue-green. Branchlets densely velvety-tomentose with white patent or slightly retrorse hairs. Phyllodes usually 6-10 per whorl and (1.5-) 2-5 (-7) mm long, pubescent with slightly curved hairs. Peduncles (3-) 6-18 mm long, indumentum similar to branchlets. Bracteoles setose in upper half. Calyx lobes and corolla lobes hispid, with hairs 0.2-0.4 mm long. The variety has been generally confused with Acacia lycopodiifolia which it resembles in indumentum and habit. The arrangement of the seeds in the pod, the lack of setae on the phyllodes, and the fewer phyllodes per whorl distinguish the two taxa. A specimen labelled Port Darwin, [Northern Territory], A. Forrest (MEL) apparently has an incorrect locality. A collection from Abydos-Woodstock Reserve in the Pilbara, Western Australia, K.L. Tinley 3274 (PERTH), has unusually short hairs on its branchlets and phyllodes, and atypically short peduncles (3-4 mm long). Another Pilbara plant (R.J. Chinnock 9705, PERTH, from the mid-slope of Mt Meharry) is unusual in having up to 15 phyllodes per whorl which are longer than normal (10-12 mm) (B.R. Maslin, pers. comm.). Occasionally hybridises with Acacia spondylophylla in the Pilbara region, Western Australia. This very attractive variety has horticultural potential as a ground cover, especially for rockery plantings. In some places it regenerates prolifically from seed following fire (B.R. Maslin, pers. comm.). Grows in sand (commonly lateritic) and in shallow rocky soil. Flowers mostly April-September.

fire: moderately fast-growing but relatively short-lived species that regenerates from seed following fire or other disturbance and can form rather dense, localised thickets, especially where water is not limiting (b.maslin, pers. details of fire impacts on, and aboriginal use of, adsurgens are given by latz, book_source 86 (1995).
description: spreading, multi-stemmed shrub mostly 1-4 m high. bark grey to reddish brown, mostly smooth but sometimes rough and somewhat fibrous at base of main stems on oldest plants. branchlets angular to flattened towards apices, light brown or reddish, glabrous. phyllodes linear, straight or upwardly curved, flat, (8-) 10-18 (-20) cm long, (1-) 2-4.5 (-8) mm wide, coriaceous, usually pale yellowish green or milky green when dry, glabrous; longitudinal veins numerous with central vein more pronounced than the others; minor veins obscure and c. 8-10 per mm; gland 1, basal, swollen, to 3 mm above pulvinus. peduncles 5-15 mm long, often about as long as the spikes. spikes 0.8-2.5 cm long, densely flowered, yellow. flowers 5-merous; calyx 0.8-1.25 mm long (exceeding ½ length of corolla), dissected by less than 10%, with densely scurfy viscid lobes and midrib commonly evident; corolla 1.2-1.8 mm long, dissected to circa one third its length, glabrous; ovary glabrous or apex very finely tomentose. pods linear, slightly raised over and constricted between seeds, straight or slightly curved, 3.5-12 cm long, 2-3.5 mm wide, firmly chartaceous to thinly crustaceous, light brown. seeds longitudinal, narrowly oblong to oblong-elliptic, dorsiventrally flattened, 3-4.5 mm long, dark brown to blackish; areole small, open with u-shaped pleurogram, paler than rest of seed; aril rather large, convoluted and bright yellow. a specimen from the gibson desert, western australia, has atypically wide phyllodes (a.george 15658, bri, perth). acacia adsurgens is most closely related to tenuissima (with which it is sometimes sympatric) that is most readily distinguished by having slender, terete phyllodes. a. adsurgens is superficially similar to linear phyllode forms of sibirica from the pilbara, western australia, which are distinguished by generally shorter phyllodes (mostly 40-90 mm long) that are uniformly finely veined (the midvein not more pronounced than the rest), less densely flowered spikes (with smaller flowers and calyx shorter relative to the corolla) that are commonly about twice as long as the peduncles, and broader pods. it is also related to the pilbara endemic acacia sp. jimblebar (van leeuwen 1342). a. adsurgens possibly hybridises with rhodophloia in the central hamersley range, western australia. (b.maslin, pers. comm.). grows in reddish sandy and gravelly soils, on flat plains and hillsides, commonly in spinifex grassland communities, sometimes with eucalypts. moderately fast-growing but relatively short-lived species that regenerates from seed following fire or other disturbance and can form rather dense, localised thickets, especially where water is not limiting (b.maslin, pers. comm.). details of ecology, utilisation, etc. of acacia adsurgens are given in l.a.thomson & hall, australian acacias leaflet no. 22, csiro division of forestry & forest products (1989) and j.doran et al., in j.doran & j.turnbull (eds), australian trees and shrubs: species for land rehabilitation and farm planting in the tropics (1997). details of fire impacts on, and aboriginal use of, adsurgens are given by latz, book_source 86 (1995). flowers may-september, sometimes as early as february. ;
original_text: Spreading, multi-stemmed shrub mostly 1-4 m high. Bark grey to reddish brown, mostly smooth but sometimes rough and somewhat fibrous at base of main stems on oldest plants. Branchlets angular to flattened towards apices, light brown or reddish, glabrous. Phyllodes linear, straight or upwardly curved, flat, (8-) 10-18 (-20) cm long, (1-) 2-4.5 (-8) mm wide, coriaceous, usually pale yellowish green or milky green when dry, glabrous; longitudinal veins numerous with central vein more pronounced than the others; minor veins obscure and c. 8-10 per mm; gland 1, basal, swollen, to 3 mm above pulvinus. Peduncles 5-15 mm long, often about as long as the spikes. Spikes 0.8-2.5 cm long, densely flowered, yellow. Flowers 5-merous; calyx 0.8-1.25 mm long (exceeding ½ length of corolla), dissected by less than 10%, with densely scurfy viscid lobes and midrib commonly evident; corolla 1.2-1.8 mm long, dissected to c. one third its length, glabrous; ovary glabrous or apex very finely tomentose. Pods linear, slightly raised over and constricted between seeds, straight or slightly curved, 3.5-12 cm long, 2-3.5 mm wide, firmly chartaceous to thinly crustaceous, light brown. Seeds longitudinal, narrowly oblong to oblong-elliptic, dorsiventrally flattened, 3-4.5 mm long, dark brown to blackish; areole small, open with U-shaped pleurogram, paler than rest of seed; aril rather large, convoluted and bright yellow. A specimen from the Gibson Desert, Western Australia, has atypically wide phyllodes (A.S. George 15658, BRI, PERTH). Acacia adsurgens is most closely related to A. tenuissima (with which it is sometimes sympatric) that is most readily distinguished by having slender, terete phyllodes. A. adsurgens is superficially similar to linear phyllode forms of A. sibirica from the Pilbara, Western Australia, which are distinguished by generally shorter phyllodes (mostly 40-90 mm long) that are uniformly finely veined (the midvein not more pronounced than the rest), less densely flowered spikes (with smaller flowers and calyx shorter relative to the corolla) that are commonly about twice as long as the peduncles, and broader pods. It is also related to the Pilbara endemic Acacia sp. Jimblebar (S. van Leeuwen 1342). A. adsurgens possibly hybridises with A. rhodophloia in the central Hamersley Range, Western Australia. (B.R. Maslin, pers. comm.). Grows in reddish sandy and gravelly soils, on flat plains and hillsides, commonly in spinifex grassland communities, sometimes with eucalypts. Moderately fast-growing but relatively short-lived species that regenerates from seed following fire or other disturbance and can form rather dense, localised thickets, especially where water is not limiting (B.R. Maslin, pers. comm.). Details of ecology, utilisation, etc. of Acacia adsurgens are given in L.A.J. Thomson & N. Hall, Australian Acacias Leaflet no. 22, CSIRO Division of Forestry & Forest Products (1989) and J.C. Doran et al., in J.C. Doran & J.W. Turnbull (eds), Australian Trees and Shrubs: Species for Land Rehabilitation and Farm Planting in the Tropics (1997). Details of fire impacts on, and Aboriginal use of, A. adsurgens are given by P. Latz, Bushfires & Bushtucker 86 (1995). Flowers May-September, sometimes as early as February.

fire: fire-sensitive plant. details of the aboriginal use of this fire-sensitive rare plant are given by latz, book_source 86 (1995).
description: shrub or small tree, 1.5-7 m high. bark splitting longitudinally or fibrous, grey to black. branchlets angular or flattened, soon becoming terete, pale yellow or light brown, glabrous. phyllodes linear, flat, 11-24.5 (-27) cm long, 4-10 mm wide, tapered toward apex and base, with apex drawn out into an elongate slender blunt tip, coriaceous, with subprominent midvein and 8-11 minor non-anastomosing veins per mm; gland 1, very inconspicuous, basal, 1-3 mm above pulvinus. spikes single or paired on axillary shoots that sometimes become leafy, 2-5 cm long, densely flowered, yellow. flowers 5-merous; calyx 1-1.25 mm long, dissected to 1/10-¢‚¬¦¢‚¬¢, basally, villous, with orange-brown scurf on lobes; corolla 1.3-1.6 mm long, dissected to one third-½, glabrous; ovary densely villous. pods linear, slightly constricted between and strongly raised over seeds, 5.5-11 cm long, 2-3 mm wide, with margins n, coriaceous, dark brown, glabrous. seeds longitudinal, narrowly oblong to broadly elliptic, dorsiventrally flattened, 3-4 mm long, dark brown; areole small, surrounded by pale u-shaped pleurogram; funicle folded and thickened into cupular aril. allied to acacia undoolyana. usually in sandy soils, often on dunes, or in gravelly soils, with spinifex. details of the ecology of acacia ammobia are given in j.turnbull (ed.), multipurpose australian trees and shrubs 94-95 (1986) and j.doran et al., in j.doran & j.turnbull (eds), australian trees and shrubs: species for land rehabilitation and farm planting in the tropics 104-105 (1997). fire-sensitive plant. flowers august-october. details of the aboriginal use of this fire-sensitive rare plant are given by latz, book_source 86 (1995). ;
original_text: Shrub or small tree, 1.5-7 m high. Bark splitting longitudinally or fibrous, grey to black. Branchlets angular or flattened, soon becoming terete, pale yellow or light brown, glabrous. Phyllodes linear, flat, 11-24.5 (-27) cm long, 4-10 mm wide, tapered toward apex and base, with apex drawn out into an elongate slender blunt tip, coriaceous, with subprominent midvein and 8-11 minor non-anastomosing veins per mm; gland 1, very inconspicuous, basal, 1-3 mm above pulvinus. Spikes single or paired on axillary shoots that sometimes become leafy, 2-5 cm long, densely flowered, yellow. Flowers 5-merous; calyx 1-1.25 mm long, dissected to 1/10-¢‚¬¦¢‚¬¢, basally, villous, with orange-brown scurf on lobes; corolla 1.3-1.6 mm long, dissected to one third-½, glabrous; ovary densely villous. Pods linear, slightly constricted between and strongly raised over seeds, 5.5-11 cm long, 2-3 mm wide, with margins nerve-like, coriaceous, dark brown, glabrous. Seeds longitudinal, narrowly oblong to broadly elliptic, dorsiventrally flattened, 3-4 mm long, dark brown; areole small, surrounded by pale U-shaped pleurogram; funicle folded and thickened into cupular aril. Allied to Acacia undoolyana. Usually in sandy soils, often on dunes, or in gravelly soils, with spinifex. Details of the ecology of Acacia ammobia are given in J.W. Turnbull (ed.), Multipurpose Australian Trees and Shrubs 94-95 (1986) and J.C. Doran et al., in J.C. Doran & J.W. Turnbull (eds), Australian Trees and Shrubs: Species for Land Rehabilitation and Farm Planting in the Tropics 104-105 (1997). Fire-sensitive plant. Flowers August-October. Details of the aboriginal use of this fire-sensitive rare plant are given by P. Latz, Bushfires & Bushtucker 86 (1995).

simplified_phrase: resprouts from base of stem after fire
fire: this species regenerates from the base of its stem following fire.
description: shrubby tree to 7 m high. bark corky, deeply furrowed. branchlets terete, finely ribbed, glabrous. phyllodes inequilaterally obovate-elliptic to subflabellate, obliquely falcate, 4-7 (-9) cm long, 2-5 (-6) cm wide, obtuse to bluntly acute, coriaceous, green or subglaucous, glabrous, with (3-) 5-7 (-8) main longitudinal veins, openly reticulate between. inflorescences elongated terminal or axillary racemes or panicles; raceme axes glabrous; peduncles 2-5 mm long, glabrous; heads 2-2.5 mm diam., 4-7-flowered, cream. flowers 5-merous; sepals minute, free. pods  moniliform, raised over seeds and variably constricted between them, almost straight to strongly curved and often variably twisted, to 28 cm long, 1-2 cm wide, crustaceous to woody. seeds longitudinal, broadly elliptic to circular, 9.5-14 mm long, dull, brown; areole strongly depressed, paler; funicle thickened, exarillate. a well marked species with corky bark, unusual shaped phyllodes that are reminiscent of the outline of a duck's head, minute flowers in few-flowered, cream heads, large pods, and exarillate, nearly circular, compressed seeds with the areole strongly depressed. often grows on red dunes or in saline depressions. this species regenerates from the base of its stem following fire. flowers may-june. ;
original_text: Shrubby tree to 7 m high. Bark corky, deeply furrowed. Branchlets terete, finely ribbed, glabrous. Phyllodes inequilaterally obovate-elliptic to subflabellate, obliquely falcate, 4-7 (-9) cm long, 2-5 (-6) cm wide, obtuse to bluntly acute, coriaceous, green or subglaucous, glabrous, with (3-) 5-7 (-8) main longitudinal veins, openly reticulate between. Inflorescences elongated terminal or axillary racemes or panicles; raceme axes glabrous; peduncles 2-5 mm long, glabrous; heads 2-2.5 mm diam., 4-7-flowered, cream. Flowers 5-merous; sepals minute, free. Pods  moniliform, raised over seeds and variably constricted between them, almost straight to strongly curved and often variably twisted, to 28 cm long, 1-2 cm wide, crustaceous to woody. Seeds longitudinal, broadly elliptic to circular, 9.5-14 mm long, dull, brown; areole strongly depressed, paler; funicle thickened, exarillate. A well marked species with corky bark, unusual shaped phyllodes that are reminiscent of the outline of a duck's head, minute flowers in few-flowered, cream heads, large pods, and exarillate, nearly circular, compressed seeds with the areole strongly depressed. Often grows on red dunes or in saline depressions. This species regenerates from the base of its stem following fire. Flowers May-June.

simplified_phrase: killed by fire; regenerates from seed
fire: usually killed by fire but regenerates profusely from seed.
description: fastigiate, multi-stemmed shrub 1.5-4 m high. bark grey, longitudinally fissured towards base of mature stems otherwise smooth. branchlets angular, often flexuose, pale yellowish orange or red-brown, glabrous. phyllodes linear, or very narrowly elliptic, straight or slightly falcate, (4.5-) 6-18 cm long, (2-) 3-10 (-13) mm wide, coriaceous, somewhat shiny, bright olive-green, glabrous, with 1-3 subprominent yellowish main veins; minor inconspicuous veins 3 or 4 per mm, with rare anastamoses; marginal vein discrete and yellowish; glands inconspicuous, 2 or 3, marginal. spikes 2.5-4.5 cm long, golden; peduncles 5-15 (-25) mm long. flowers 5-merous; calyx 0.5-0.8 mm long, dissected to one third, glabrous or slightly tomentose; corolla 1.5-1.8 mm long, dissected to ½ its length, glabrous; ovary tomentose. pods narrowly oblong or cultrate, tapered at both ends with apex  hooked, slightly indented or straight-sided, 6-11.5 cm long, often erect, crustaceous to subwoody, obliquely reticulate, brown to dark brown, glabrous, resinous, dehiscing elastically (valves recurved following dehiscence); seed-partitions well marked; marginal vein thick. seeds oblique, broadly oblong to  oblong-elliptic or  ovate, 6-7 mm long, brownish black; pleurogram fine, with yellowish halo (outer band pitted); areole open, depressed. in the pilbara, western australia, this species commonly hybridises with acacia stellaticeps (see sphaerostachya) and rarely with citrinoviridis, arida and orthocarpa. plants described by b.maslin, nuytsia 4: 405-407 (1983), as ancistrocarpa x trachycarpa are now referable to trachycarpa x tumida var pilbarensis. grows usually in mallee-spinifex communities and in stony spinifex grasslands, and in shrub-steppes and along watercourses, in deep red sands and skeletal soils on lateritic plains. usually killed by fire but regenerates profusely from seed. used extensively in land rehabilitation in the pilbara because it produces large quantities of seed that is easy to collect, its preference for disturbed sites and its rapid growth rate (b.maslin, pers. comm.). further details of its ecology, utilisation, etc. are given in j.turnbull (ed.), multipurpose australian trees and shrubs 98-99 (1986). details of aboriginal use are given by latz, book_source 87 (1995) and b.maslin & van leeuwen, wattles of the pilbara 8 (2008). flowers late february-july. ;
original_text: Fastigiate, multi-stemmed shrub 1.5-4 m high. Bark grey, longitudinally fissured towards base of mature stems otherwise smooth. Branchlets angular, often flexuose, pale yellowish orange or red-brown, glabrous. Phyllodes linear, or very narrowly elliptic, straight or slightly falcate, (4.5-) 6-18 cm long, (2-) 3-10 (-13) mm wide, coriaceous, somewhat shiny, bright olive-green, glabrous, with 1-3 subprominent yellowish main veins; minor inconspicuous veins 3 or 4 per mm, with rare anastamoses; marginal vein discrete and yellowish; glands inconspicuous, 2 or 3, marginal. Spikes 2.5-4.5 cm long, golden; peduncles 5-15 (-25) mm long. Flowers 5-merous; calyx 0.5-0.8 mm long, dissected to one third, glabrous or slightly tomentose; corolla 1.5-1.8 mm long, dissected to ½ its length, glabrous; ovary tomentose. Pods narrowly oblong or cultrate, tapered at both ends with apex  hooked, slightly indented or straight-sided, 6-11.5 cm long, often erect, crustaceous to subwoody, obliquely reticulate, brown to dark brown, glabrous, resinous, dehiscing elastically (valves recurved following dehiscence); seed-partitions well marked; marginal vein thick. Seeds oblique, broadly oblong to  oblong-elliptic or  ovate, 6-7 mm long, brownish black; pleurogram fine, with yellowish halo (outer band pitted); areole open, depressed. In the Pilbara, Western Australia, this species commonly hybridises with Acacia stellaticeps (see A. sphaerostachya) and rarely with A. citrinoviridis, A. arida and A. orthocarpa. Plants described by B.R. Maslin, Nuytsia 4: 405-407 (1983), as A. ancistrocarpa x trachycarpa are now referable to A. trachycarpa x tumida var. pilbarensis. Grows usually in mallee-spinifex communities and in stony spinifex grasslands, and in shrub-steppes and along watercourses, in deep red sands and skeletal soils on lateritic plains. Usually killed by fire but regenerates profusely from seed. Used extensively in land rehabilitation in the Pilbara because it produces large quantities of seed that is easy to collect, its preference for disturbed sites and its rapid growth rate (B.R. Maslin, pers. comm.). Further details of its ecology, utilisation, etc. are given in J.W. Turnbull (ed.), Multipurpose Australian Trees and Shrubs 98-99 (1986). Details of Aboriginal use are given by P. Latz, Bushfires & Bushtucker 87 (1995) and B.R. Maslin & S. van Leeuwen, Wattles of the Pilbara 8 (2008). Flowers late February-July.

simplified_phrase: resprouts from basal rootstock after fire; spreads vegetatively via underground runners
fire: in the pilbara region, western australia, arida is generally a low, multi-stemmed shrub with a dense crown and appears to spread vegetatively by subterranean runners and regenerates from a basal root stock following fire. acacia orthocarpa on the other hand is commonly a taller, single or few-stemmed plant with an open wispy crown and is normally killed by fire, regenerating from seed.
description: obconic, multi-stemmed, glabrous shrub 0.5-2 (-3) m high; crown dense, with soft, delicate foliage. branchlets light brown but reddish brown or yellowish at extremities, often with a thin waxy finely cracked resinous coating, obscurely ribbed. phyllodes linear to narrowly oblong or linear-oblanceolate, erect, flat, straight, (2-) 2.5-6 (-8) cm long, 1-4 (-6) mm wide, coriaceous, puncticulate by evident (x10 mag.) stomata, light green (at least when young) to distinctly subglaucous or grey-green, with a sweet fragrant smell when young; veinless or with an obscure central vein, occasionally with 1 or 2 less prominent additional longitudinal veins; gland 1, inconspicuous, 0.2-2 mm above pulvinus. spikes 1-2.4 cm long, golden. flowers 5-merous; calyx gamosepalous, dissected to ¼-¢‚¬¦¥¡ of length. pods erect, linear-oblanceolate, terete to flat or quadrangular, (3-) 4-6.5 (-8) cm long, woody, obscurely longitudinally striate, resinous, opening elastically from apex (dehisced valves shallowly to strongly recurved); margins inconspicuous; seed partitions distinct but narrow. seeds retained in pods following dehiscence, oblique and seated in distinct chambers, narrowly oblong-elliptic, 4.5-7 mm long, brownish black; funicle-aril narrowly turbinate. acacia arida is very closely related to orthocarpa which is most readily, and perhaps arbitrarily, distinguished by its terete to subterete phyllodes: the relationship between these two species requires further study. a specimen collected by lazarides 6392 (canb, nsw), 19.2 km nnw of elgie cliffs station, kimberleys, is intermediate between the two. in the pilbara region, western australia, arida is generally a low, multi-stemmed shrub with a dense crown and appears to spread vegetatively by subterranean runners and regenerates from a basal root stock following fire. acacia orthocarpa on the other hand is commonly a taller, single or few-stemmed plant with an open wispy crown and is normally killed by fire, regenerating from seed. acacia arida probably also has affinities to arrecta. some specimens of citriodora had previously been confused with arida (see p.kodela & b.maslin, nuytsia 27: 99-102 (2016). a possible hybrid between arida and stellaticeps has been collected in the roebourne-wickham area of western australia (glennon 196, perth). a rare hybrid between arida and ancistrocarpa has been recorded from near roebourne (b.maslin 8629, perth). grows in red sandy loam or coarse, gravelly, skeletal sand on laterite or sandstone, in low, open eucalypt forest. flowers (often sporadically) february-november, main flush may-august. ;
original_text: Obconic, multi-stemmed, glabrous shrub 0.5-2 (-3) m high; crown dense, with soft, delicate foliage. Branchlets light brown but reddish brown or yellowish at extremities, often with a thin waxy finely cracked resinous coating, obscurely ribbed. Phyllodes linear to narrowly oblong or linear-oblanceolate, erect, flat, straight, (2-) 2.5-6 (-8) cm long, 1-4 (-6) mm wide, coriaceous, puncticulate by evident (x10 mag.) stomata, light green (at least when young) to distinctly subglaucous or grey-green, with a sweet fragrant smell when young; veinless or with an obscure central vein, occasionally with 1 or 2 less prominent additional longitudinal veins; gland 1, inconspicuous, 0.2-2 mm above pulvinus. Spikes 1-2.4 cm long, golden. Flowers 5-merous; calyx gamosepalous, dissected to ¼-¢‚¬¦…¡ of length. Pods erect, linear-oblanceolate, terete to flat or quadrangular, (3-) 4-6.5 (-8) cm long, woody, obscurely longitudinally striate, resinous, opening elastically from apex (dehisced valves shallowly to strongly recurved); margins inconspicuous; seed partitions distinct but narrow. Seeds retained in pods following dehiscence, oblique and seated in distinct chambers, narrowly oblong-elliptic, 4.5-7 mm long, brownish black; funicle-aril narrowly turbinate. Acacia arida is very closely related to A. orthocarpa which is most readily, and perhaps arbitrarily, distinguished by its terete to subterete phyllodes: the relationship between these two species requires further study. A specimen collected by M. Lazarides 6392 (CANB, NSW), 19.2 km NNW of Elgie Cliffs Station, Kimberleys, is intermediate between the two. In the Pilbara region, Western Australia, A. arida is generally a low, multi-stemmed shrub with a dense crown and appears to spread vegetatively by subterranean runners and regenerates from a basal root stock following fire. Acacia orthocarpa on the other hand is commonly a taller, single or few-stemmed plant with an open wispy crown and is normally killed by fire, regenerating from seed. Acacia arida probably also has affinities to A. arrecta. Some specimens of A. citriodora had previously been confused with A. arida (see P.G. Kodela & B.R. Maslin, Nuytsia 27: 99-102 (2016). A possible hybrid between A. arida and A. stellaticeps has been collected in the Roebourne-Wickham area of Western Australia (K. Glennon 196, PERTH). A rare hybrid between A. arida and A. ancistrocarpa has been recorded from near Roebourne (B.R. Maslin 8629, PERTH). Grows in red sandy loam or coarse, gravelly, skeletal sand on laterite or sandstone, in low, open eucalypt forest. Flowers (often sporadically) February-November, main flush May-August.

simplified_phrase: killed by fire; resprouts from base of trunk after fire
fire: acacia ayersiana is generally killed by fire but can regenerate from the base of the trunk.
description: rounded or obconic, multi-stemmed shrub 3-6 m tall, and about the same in diam., sometimes a single-stemmed tree 7-12 m tall. branchlets with dense white appressed pubescence between red-brown ribs; ribs sometimes with a thin veneer of translucent resin; new shoots not or scarcely resinous (except for margins of young phyllodes), usually densely sericeous with hairs normally pale yellow. phyllodes narrowly elliptic to lanceolate, straight but often shallowly recurved at apex or occasionally over entire length, (3-) 5-8 (-10) cm long, (4-) 7-12 (-18) mm wide, acute to acuminate, commonly silvery light grey-green ageing dull green, longitudinal nerves numerous with 3-6 nerves slightly more pronounced than the rest (best observed on young phyllodes); marginal nerve discrete and resinous, light brown to red-brown but often ageing dull yellow. inflorescences single in axils; peduncles 3-6 (-8) mm long; spikes (10-) 15-35 mm long. flowers 5-merous; sepals ¼-one third length of corolla, free or shortly united at base; corolla 1.3-1.7 (-2) mm long. pods shortly stipitate, oblong, 1-4 cm long, 10-14 (-17) mm wide including wings 1-2 mm wide, chartaceous, brown, reticulately nerved, glabrous or minutely appressed-pubescent, dehiscent. seeds transverse to oblique, oblong, 5-6 mm long, 2.5-3 mm wide; aril small, terminal, oblique, pileate, white. a variable species in need of critical study, see b.maslin & j.reid, nuytsia 22(4): 181-190 (2012), for discussion. typical ayersiana has rather large phyllodes (mostly 50-80 x 7-12 mm), the new shoots are not resinous (except for margin of young phyllodes) and are densely sericeous by normally pale yellow hairs that obscure the underlying nervation, and the pods are 10-14 (-17) mm wide. plants with short phyllodes (normally 35-50 mm long) and often narrow pods (6-10 mm wide) are most common in western australia from wiluna east to the gibson desert (e g b.maslin 5658, perth). a morphologically variable, narrow-phyllode variant (4-6 mm wide) is scattered throughout the range of the species; some of these plants have falcate phyllodes and/or new shoots that are moderately resinous, dark reddish brown and often striate with appressed white hairs between the rather obvious nerves (e g d.albrecht 11399, nt, perth). a member of the 'aneura group' (mulga) most closely related to aneura which has narrower phyllodes that lack a discrete, resinous marginal nerve. these two species putatively hybridise in western australia in the pilbara region, gibson desert and central ranges (east of warburton) where they can form complex populations containing individuals that appear to vary continuously between the presumed parents; see b.maslin & j.reid (2012) for discussion. representative specimen: gibson desert, w.a., 67 km sse of clutterbuck hills, w.a., s.hopper 2906b (perth). putative hybrids between ayersiana and incurvaneura also occur in the pilbara (e g m.trudgen 17615) and in a few other places where the putative parents co-occur. short phyllode forms of ayersiana can resemble long phyllode forms of mulganeura which are most readily distinguished by the thick, opaque (not translucent) resin on their branchlet ribs; these two species putatively hybridise in the pilbara region. specimens of the narrow-phyllode variant with falcate phyllodes are sometimes difficult to distinguish from the narrow-phyllode variant of caesaneura (see caesaneura for discussion). usually grows in sandy soils, often in swales of dunes. acacia ayersiana is generally killed by fire but can regenerate from the base of the trunk. indigenous peoples of the pilbara used the timber from this species to make digging sticks, clubs and other tools. flowers recorded february, april-june. ;
original_text: Rounded or obconic, multi-stemmed shrub 3-6 m tall, and about the same in diam., sometimes a single-stemmed tree 7-12 m tall. Branchlets with dense white appressed pubescence between red-brown ribs; ribs sometimes with a thin veneer of translucent resin; new shoots not or scarcely resinous (except for margins of young phyllodes), usually densely sericeous with hairs normally pale yellow. Phyllodes narrowly elliptic to lanceolate, straight but often shallowly recurved at apex or occasionally over entire length, (3-) 5-8 (-10) cm long, (4-) 7-12 (-18) mm wide, acute to acuminate, commonly silvery light grey-green ageing dull green, longitudinal nerves numerous with 3-6 nerves slightly more pronounced than the rest (best observed on young phyllodes); marginal nerve discrete and resinous, light brown to red-brown but often ageing dull yellow. Inflorescences single in axils; peduncles 3-6 (-8) mm long; spikes (10-) 15-35 mm long. Flowers 5-merous; sepals ¼-one third length of corolla, free or shortly united at base; corolla 1.3-1.7 (-2) mm long. Pods shortly stipitate, oblong, 1-4 cm long, 10-14 (-17) mm wide including wings 1-2 mm wide, chartaceous, brown, reticulately nerved, glabrous or minutely appressed-pubescent, dehiscent. Seeds transverse to oblique, oblong, 5-6 mm long, 2.5-3 mm wide; aril small, terminal, oblique, pileate, white. A variable species in need of critical study, see B.R. Maslin & J.E. Reid, Nuytsia 22(4): 181-190 (2012), for discussion. Typical A. ayersiana has rather large phyllodes (mostly 50-80 x 7-12 mm), the new shoots are not resinous (except for margin of young phyllodes) and are densely sericeous by normally pale yellow hairs that obscure the underlying nervation, and the pods are 10-14 (-17) mm wide. Plants with short phyllodes (normally 35-50 mm long) and often narrow pods (6-10 mm wide) are most common in Western Australia from Wiluna east to the Gibson Desert (e.g. B.R. Maslin 5658, PERTH). A morphologically variable, narrow-phyllode variant (4-6 mm wide) is scattered throughout the range of the species; some of these plants have falcate phyllodes and/or new shoots that are moderately resinous, dark reddish brown and often striate with appressed white hairs between the rather obvious nerves (e.g. D.E. Albrecht 11399, NT, PERTH). A member of the 'A. aneura group' (Mulga) most closely related to A. aneura which has narrower phyllodes that lack a discrete, resinous marginal nerve. These two species putatively hybridise in Western Australia in the Pilbara region, Gibson Desert and Central Ranges (east of Warburton) where they can form complex populations containing individuals that appear to vary continuously between the presumed parents; see B.R. Maslin & J.E. Reid (2012) for discussion. Representative specimen: Gibson Desert, W.A., 67 km SSE of Clutterbuck Hills, W.A., S.D. Hopper 2906B (PERTH). Putative hybrids between A. ayersiana and A. incurvaneura also occur in the Pilbara (e.g. M.E. Trudgen 17615) and in a few other places where the putative parents co-occur. Short phyllode forms of A. ayersiana can resemble long phyllode forms of A. mulganeura which are most readily distinguished by the thick, opaque (not translucent) resin on their branchlet ribs; these two species putatively hybridise in the Pilbara region. Specimens of the narrow-phyllode variant with falcate phyllodes are sometimes difficult to distinguish from the narrow-phyllode variant of A. caesaneura (see A. caesaneura for discussion). Usually grows in sandy soils, often in swales of dunes. Acacia ayersiana is generally killed by fire but can regenerate from the base of the trunk. Indigenous peoples of the Pilbara used the timber from this species to make digging sticks, clubs and other tools. Flowers recorded February, April-June.

simplified_phrase: killed by fire; regenerates from seed; fire avoidance in shallow sand over sandstone; fire avoidance near creeks in fire-protected areas
fire: grows in shallow sand over sandstone, often near creeks in fire-protected areas, in low shrubland, often with triodia. the species is killed by fire and regenerates from seed.
description: glabrous shrub 1-2.5 m high. branchlets bearing scars where phyllodes have fallen. stipules mostly caducous, inconspicuous, 0.2-0.3 mm long. phyllodes crowded, patent, triangular to oblong-triangular with broad, sessile, truncate base, 1.5-3 mm long, 1-3 mm wide, terminated by conspicuous, upwardly inflected, setose mucro 0.5-2 mm long; longitudinal veins indistinct, 3-7 per face; gland absent or inconspicuous. inflorescences simple, 1 per axil; peduncles 4-7 mm long, resinous, ebracteate at  base; heads globular, 30-40-flowered, light golden; bracteoles circa 2 mm long, acuminate and slightly exserted in buds. flowers 5-merous; sepals free, narrowly linear. pods narrowly linear, 3-6 cm long, 2-3 mm wide, firmly chartaceous to thinly coriaceous, resinous, dark red-brown, finely longitudinally veined. seeds longitudinal, oblong, 3-4 mm long, shiny, black; aril terminal and white. a distinctive species with no obvious close relatives; possibly distantly related to members of the 'acacia deltoidea' group which differ most obviously in differently shaped, pungent phyllodes. see m.lewington & b.maslin, nuytsia 19(1): 66-67 (2009), for discussion. grows in shallow sand over sandstone, often near creeks in fire-protected areas, in low shrubland, often with triodia. the species is killed by fire and regenerates from seed. there are few collections available to determine flowering and fruiting periods. collections from january bear flowers and fruits. ;
original_text: Glabrous shrub 1-2.5 m high. Branchlets bearing scars where phyllodes have fallen. Stipules mostly caducous, inconspicuous, 0.2-0.3 mm long. Phyllodes crowded, patent, triangular to oblong-triangular with broad, sessile, truncate base, 1.5-3 mm long, 1-3 mm wide, terminated by conspicuous, upwardly inflected, setose mucro 0.5-2 mm long; longitudinal veins indistinct, 3-7 per face; gland absent or inconspicuous. Inflorescences simple, 1 per axil; peduncles 4-7 mm long, resinous, ebracteate at  base; heads globular, 30-40-flowered, light golden; bracteoles c. 2 mm long, acuminate and slightly exserted in buds. Flowers 5-merous; sepals free, narrowly linear. Pods narrowly linear, 3-6 cm long, 2-3 mm wide, firmly chartaceous to thinly coriaceous, resinous, dark red-brown, finely longitudinally veined. Seeds longitudinal, oblong, 3-4 mm long, shiny, black; aril terminal and white. A distinctive species with no obvious close relatives; possibly distantly related to members of the 'Acacia deltoidea' group which differ most obviously in differently shaped, pungent phyllodes. See M.A. Lewington & B.R. Maslin, Nuytsia 19(1): 66-67 (2009), for discussion. Grows in shallow sand over sandstone, often near creeks in fire-protected areas, in low shrubland, often with Triodia. The species is killed by fire and regenerates from seed. There are few collections available to determine flowering and fruiting periods. Collections from January bear flowers and fruits.

simplified_phrase: killed by fire; regenerates from seed
fire: it is generally killed by fire and regenerates from seed although under very cool burn conditions large plants may regenerate from root stock close to the base of the parent plant.
description: shrub normally 1-3 m high, rarely prostrate, usually dense and glabrous. bark smooth and light grey to medium grey. branchlets often slightly pruinose. phyllodes variable, usually narrowly elliptic to oblong-elliptic or obovate, usually 2-5 cm long and 6-25 mm wide with l: w ratio = 2-5, with incurved to straight mucro, thin to subfleshy, green or glaucous, usually 2¢€š¬¢‚¬Ëœveined per face; glands commonly 3, with lowermost prominent and 2-12 mm above pulvinus, and distal glands smaller with one commonly adjacent to mucro. inflorescences 6- or 7-headed racemes, mostly growing out with subsequent inflorescences simple; raceme axes 2-4 cm long; peduncles (10-) 15-35 (-45) mm long; heads globular, subdense, normally 16-23-flowered, deep golden; buds bright green. flowers 5-merous; sepals united into a  truncate calyx. pods erect and submoniliform (breaking readily at constrictions between seeds), to 8 cm long, 5-8 (-10) mm wide, firmly crustaceous to subwoody, light brown. seeds longitudinal, oblong-elliptic, 4-6 mm long, glossy, dark brown; aril red or orange. a.chapman & b.maslin, nuytsia 8(2): 249-283 (1992), define and discuss the informal 'acacia bivenosa group' which comprises the following 12 species: ampliceps, bivenosa, cupularis, a. didyma, ligulata, rostellifera, salicina, sclerosperma, startii, telmica, a. tysonii and xanthina. in the pilbara region of western australia bivenosa hybridises with ampliceps and sclerosperma subsp sclerosperma. as discussed by a.chapman & b.maslin, nuytsia 8(2): 249-283 (1992), a. bivenosa is a variable species, especially with respect to growth form and phyllode morphology. the phyllodes are often distinctly 2-veined, but on plants with very narrow phyllodes and on many plants from northern territory and queensland, the second vein can be reduced and obscure or even absent. in northwestern western australia a number of variants are recognised: plants from the hamersley range and on islands of the dampier archipelago have generally narrower than normal (mostly 5-12 mm wide with l: w ratio = 3-8), narrowly elliptic to oblanceolate phyllodes (e g between tom price and the wittenoom-nanutarra road, b.maslin 4667, perth); plants from airlie island and thevenard island have atypically long (normally 4-9 cm), 1- or 2-veined phyllodes (e g long 165, perth); at dampier and in the tom price-newman area a variant with a distinctive weeping habit is common (e g burrup peninsula, n of dampier, b.maslin 4740, bri, perth). the sympatric occurrence of plants with green phyllodes and those with glaucous phyllodes is not unusual and has no taxonomic significance. occasional plants from western australia, northern territory and queensland have puberulous branchlets and raceme axes. bentham's concept of bivenosa included xanthina (drummond 1: 283, preiss 928) and didyma (dirk hartog island, [a.] cunningham [330]), according to a.chapman & b.maslin, nuytsia 8(2): 249-283 (1992). however, bivenosa is readily distinguished from these two more southerly distributed species by the more elongate phyllodes of xanthina and wider pods of a. didyma. acacia bivenosa is often sympatric with startii. it is closely related to and sometimes difficult to distinguish from ligulata (possibly due to hybridisation), particularly in south-central northern territory where they are partially sympatric. grows in a variety of soils, including coastal sand, and on rocky hillsides and gullies, in shrubland, open shrubland and open woodland, often associated with spinifex. in the pilbara acacia bivenosa is used extensively in land rehabilitation. it is generally killed by fire and regenerates from seed although under very cool burn conditions large plants may regenerate from root stock close to the base of the parent plant. acacia bivenosa can be heavily grazed by livestock, especially at the seedling stage. the immature pods attract red-winged parrots that extract the seeds (kenneally et al. 1996: 129). flowers may-october. indigenous people obtained edible grubs from the roots. ;
original_text: Shrub normally 1-3 m high, rarely prostrate, usually dense and glabrous. Bark smooth and light grey to medium grey. Branchlets often slightly pruinose. Phyllodes variable, usually narrowly elliptic to oblong-elliptic or obovate, usually 2-5 cm long and 6-25 mm wide with l: w ratio = 2-5, with incurved to straight mucro, thin to subfleshy, green or glaucous, usually 2¢€š¬¢‚¬Ëœveined per face; glands commonly 3, with lowermost prominent and 2-12 mm above pulvinus, and distal glands smaller with one commonly adjacent to mucro. Inflorescences 6- or 7-headed racemes, mostly growing out with subsequent inflorescences simple; raceme axes 2-4 cm long; peduncles (10-) 15-35 (-45) mm long; heads globular, subdense, normally 16-23-flowered, deep golden; buds bright green. Flowers 5-merous; sepals united into a  truncate calyx. Pods erect and submoniliform (breaking readily at constrictions between seeds), to 8 cm long, 5-8 (-10) mm wide, firmly crustaceous to subwoody, light brown. Seeds longitudinal, oblong-elliptic, 4-6 mm long, glossy, dark brown; aril red or orange. A.R. Chapman & B.R. Maslin, Nuytsia 8(2): 249-283 (1992), define and discuss the informal 'Acacia bivenosa group' which comprises the following 12 species: A. ampliceps, A. bivenosa, A. cupularis, A. didyma, A. ligulata, A. rostellifera, A. salicina, A. sclerosperma, A. startii, A. telmica, A. tysonii and A. xanthina. In the Pilbara region of Western Australia A. bivenosa hybridises with A. ampliceps and A. sclerosperma subsp. sclerosperma. As discussed by A.R. Chapman & B.R. Maslin, Nuytsia 8(2): 249-283 (1992), A. bivenosa is a variable species, especially with respect to growth form and phyllode morphology. The phyllodes are often distinctly 2-veined, but on plants with very narrow phyllodes and on many plants from Northern Territory and Queensland, the second vein can be reduced and obscure or even absent. In northwestern Western Australia a number of variants are recognised: plants from the Hamersley Range and on islands of the Dampier Archipelago have generally narrower than normal (mostly 5-12 mm wide with l: w ratio = 3-8), narrowly elliptic to oblanceolate phyllodes (e.g. between Tom Price and the Wittenoom-Nanutarra road, B.R. Maslin 4667, PERTH); plants from Airlie Island and Thevenard Island have atypically long (normally 4-9 cm), 1- or 2-veined phyllodes (e.g. V. Long 165, PERTH); at Dampier and in the Tom Price-Newman area a variant with a distinctive weeping habit is common (e.g. Burrup Peninsula, N of Dampier, B.R. Maslin 4740, BRI, PERTH). The sympatric occurrence of plants with green phyllodes and those with glaucous phyllodes is not unusual and has no taxonomic significance. Occasional plants from Western Australia, Northern Territory and Queensland have puberulous branchlets and raceme axes. G. Bentham's concept of A. bivenosa included A. xanthina (Drummond 1: 283, Preiss 928) and A. didyma (Dirk Hartog Island, [A.] Cunningham [330]), according to A.R. Chapman & B.R. Maslin, Nuytsia 8(2): 249-283 (1992). However, A. bivenosa is readily distinguished from these two more southerly distributed species by the more elongate phyllodes of A. xanthina and wider pods of A. didyma. Acacia bivenosa is often sympatric with A. startii. It is closely related to and sometimes difficult to distinguish from A. ligulata (possibly due to hybridisation), particularly in south-central Northern Territory where they are partially sympatric. Grows in a variety of soils, including coastal sand, and on rocky hillsides and gullies, in shrubland, open shrubland and open woodland, often associated with spinifex. In the Pilbara Acacia bivenosa is used extensively in land rehabilitation. It is generally killed by fire and regenerates from seed although under very cool burn conditions large plants may regenerate from root stock close to the base of the parent plant. Acacia bivenosa can be heavily grazed by livestock, especially at the seedling stage. The immature pods attract Red-winged Parrots that extract the seeds (Kenneally et al. 1996: 129). Flowers May-October. Indigenous people obtained edible grubs from the roots.

Phyllodes variable, usually narrowly elliptic to oblong-elliptic or obovate, usually 2-5 cm long and 6-25 mm wide with l: w ratio = 2-5, with incurved to straight mucro, thin to subfleshy, green or glaucous, usually 2¢€š¬¢‚¬Ëœveined per face; glands commonly 3, with lowermost prominent and 2-12 mm above pulvinus, and distal glands smaller with one commonly adjacent to mucro. Pods erect and submoniliform (breaking readily at constrictions between seeds), to 8 cm long, 5-8 (-10) mm wide, firmly crustaceous to subwoody, light brown. Seeds longitudinal, oblong-elliptic, 4-6 mm long, glossy, dark brown; aril red or orange. A.R. Chapman & B.R. Maslin, Nuytsia 8(2): 249-283 (1992), define and discuss the informal 'Acacia bivenosa group' which comprises the following 12 species: A. ampliceps, A. bivenosa, A. cupularis, A. didyma, A. ligulata, A. rostellifera, A. salicina, A. sclerosperma, A. startii, A. telmica, A. tysonii and A. xanthina. In the Pilbara region of Western Australia A. bivenosa hybridises with A. ampliceps and A. sclerosperma subsp. sclerosperma. As discussed by A.R. Chapman & B.R. Maslin, Nuytsia 8(2): 249-283 (1992), A. bivenosa is a variable species, especially with respect to growth form and phyllode morphology. The phyllodes are often distinctly 2-veined, but on plants with very narrow phyllodes and on many plants from Northern Territory and Queensland, the second vein can be reduced and obscure or even absent. In northwestern Western Australia a number of variants are recognised: plants from the Hamersley Range and on islands of the Dampier Archipelago have generally narrower than normal (mostly 5-12 mm wide with l: w ratio = 3-8), narrowly elliptic to oblanceolate phyllodes (e.g. between Tom Price and the Wittenoom-Nanutarra road, B.R. Maslin 4667, PERTH); plants from Airlie Island and Thevenard Island have atypically long (normally 4-9 cm), 1- or 2-veined phyllodes (e.g. V. Long 165, PERTH); at Dampier and in the Tom Price-Newman area a variant with a distinctive weeping habit is common (e.g. Burrup Peninsula, N of Dampier, B.R. Maslin 4740, BRI, PERTH). The sympatric occurrence of plants with green phyllodes and those with glaucous phyllodes is not unusual and has no taxonomic significance. Occasional plants from Western Australia, Northern Territory and Queensland have puberulous branchlets and raceme axes. G. Bentham's concept of A. bivenosa included A. xanthina (Drummond 1: 283, Preiss 928) and A. didyma (Dirk Hartog Island, [A.] Cunningham [330]), according to A.R. Chapman & B.R. Maslin, Nuytsia 8(2): 249-283 (1992). However, A. bivenosa is readily distinguished from these two more southerly distributed species by the more elongate phyllodes of A. xanthina and wider pods of A. didyma. Acacia bivenosa is often sympatric with A. startii. It is closely related to and sometimes difficult to distinguish from A. ligulata (possibly due to hybridisation), particularly in south-central Northern Territory where they are partially sympatric. Grows in a variety of soils, including coastal sand, and on rocky hillsides and gullies, in shrubland, open shrubland and open woodland, often associated with spinifex. In the Pilbara Acacia bivenosa is used extensively in land rehabilitation. It is generally killed by fire and regenerates from seed although under very cool burn conditions large plants may regenerate from root stock close to the base of the parent plant. Acacia bivenosa can be heavily grazed by livestock, especially at the seedling stage. The immature pods attract Red-winged Parrots that extract the seeds (Kenneally et al. 1996: 129). Flowers May-October. Indigenous people obtained edible grubs from the roots.

fire: generally killed under hot fire conditions. however, lightly scorched plants or those burnt under cool fire conditions resprout from the crown, along main stems and branches or from the trunk just below ground level.
description: tree to 8 (-10) m tall; trunk not fluted. new shoots not resinous, densely sericeous by silvery white or pale yellow hairs. peduncles 2-7 mm long; spikes 8-15 mm long. pods 4-6 (-8) mm wide. perhaps conspecific with the typical subspecies which occurs in queensland and northern territory, but subsp catenulata seemingly grows to a taller plant and has deeply fluted trunks, according to pedley, austrobaileya 1: 145 (1978), and sometimes has resinous new shoots that are never yellow-hairy. this subspecies may resemble acacia subcontorta with which it is sometimes sympatric. a putative hybrid between aneura and catenulata subsp occidentalis occurs between newman and jiggalong, western australia. grows on hardpan flats or gently undulating terrain along diffuse watercourses or colluvial fans, sometimes extending to dry low rocky hills or ridges. grows in (sometimes stony) shallow, red-brown sandy loam, clay-loam, deep red loamy duplex soils or self-mulching cracking clays in open to moderately closed low woodlands of eucalyptus victrix and/or with mulga ('acacia aneura group' of species). it often forms dense populations. generally killed under hot fire conditions. however, lightly scorched plants or those burnt under cool fire conditions resprout from the crown, along main stems and branches or from the trunk just below ground level. few fertile specimens are available to accurately determine the phenology. it appears to flower in response to rainfall between december and june, but not all plants in given populations produce flowers during this period. ;
original_text: Tree to 8 (-10) m tall; trunk not fluted. New shoots not resinous, densely sericeous by silvery white or pale yellow hairs. Peduncles 2-7 mm long; spikes 8-15 mm long. Pods 4-6 (-8) mm wide. Perhaps conspecific with the typical subspecies which occurs in Queensland and Northern Territory, but subsp. catenulata seemingly grows to a taller plant and has deeply fluted trunks, according to L. Pedley, Austrobaileya 1: 145 (1978), and sometimes has resinous new shoots that are never yellow-hairy. This subspecies may resemble Acacia subcontorta with which it is sometimes sympatric. A putative hybrid between A. aneura and A. catenulata subsp. occidentalis occurs between Newman and Jiggalong, Western Australia. Grows on hardpan flats or gently undulating terrain along diffuse watercourses or colluvial fans, sometimes extending to dry low rocky hills or ridges. Grows in (sometimes stony) shallow, red-brown sandy loam, clay-loam, deep red loamy duplex soils or self-mulching cracking clays in open to moderately closed low woodlands of Eucalyptus victrix and/or with Mulga ('Acacia aneura group' of species). It often forms dense populations. Generally killed under hot fire conditions. However, lightly scorched plants or those burnt under cool fire conditions resprout from the crown, along main stems and branches or from the trunk just below ground level. Few fertile specimens are available to accurately determine the phenology. It appears to flower in response to rainfall between December and June, but not all plants in given populations produce flowers during this period.

simplified_phrase: resprouts from base of stem or epicormically after cool fires
fire: generally killed under hot fire conditions. however, lightly scorched plants or those burnt under cool fire conditions resprout from the crown, along main stems and branches or from the trunk just below ground level.

fire: dense regrowth populations often develop in disturbed sites such as road verges, gravel pits and burnt areas.
description: spreading shrub 2-4 m high; occasionally a tree to 9 m high. new shoots sericeous; hairs pale yellow-brown, soon ageing silvery. branchlets acutely angled, silvery-sericeous. phyllodes normally obliquely narrowly elliptic, ‚straight but commonly shallowly recurved at apices, mostly ascending to erect, 7-23 (-25) mm long, 10-45 (-55) mm wide, with  mucro, silvery green, grey-green or bluish, sericeous but indumentum sparse on oldest phyllodes; main veins 3 or 4 per face, some confluent and ‚contiguous with the lower margin at base; minor veins forming an obvious longitudinally orientated reticulum; gland absent from apex of phyllodes. inflorescences rudimentary 2-headed racemes with axes to 0.5 mm long; peduncles (2-) 3-5 (-10) mm long, appressed-puberulous to sericeous, with indumentum sometimes sparse; spikes 3-7 cm long, golden. flowers 5-merous; sepals united; petals hairy. pods openly and strongly curved (var colei) or tightly coiled (var ileocarpa), with dehisced valves somewhat twisted, entangled and persisting as conspicuous clumps following dehiscence, 3.5-4 mm wide, thinly coriaceous-crustaceous, glabrous or subglabrous. seeds longitudinal, normally oblong, 3-4 mm long, glossy, very dark brown to black; aril bright yellow. when the sticky unripe pods are moistened and rubbed between palms they produce a greenish lather that removes dirt and cleans hands, hence the sometimes used common name, soap wattle (kenneally et al. 1996: 130). dense regrowth populations often develop in disturbed sites such as road verges, gravel pits and burnt areas. details on the habitat and ecology of acacia‚ colei are provided by‚ j.doran et al., in j.doran & j.turnbull (eds), australian trees and shrubs: species for land rehabilitation and farm planting in the tropics 128-131‚ (1997). flowers may-september. see kenneally et al. (1996:‚ 130). ;
original_text: Spreading shrub 2-4 m high; occasionally a tree to 9 m high. New shoots sericeous; hairs pale yellow-brown, soon ageing silvery. Branchlets acutely angled, silvery-sericeous. Phyllodes normally obliquely narrowly elliptic, ‚straight but commonly shallowly recurved at apices, mostly ascending to erect, 7-23 (-25) mm long, 10-45 (-55) mm wide, with knob-like mucro, silvery green, grey-green or bluish, sericeous but indumentum sparse on oldest phyllodes; main veins 3 or 4 per face, some confluent and ‚contiguous with the lower margin at base; minor veins forming an obvious longitudinally orientated reticulum; gland absent from apex of phyllodes. Inflorescences rudimentary 2-headed racemes with axes to 0.5 mm long; peduncles (2-) 3-5 (-10) mm long, appressed-puberulous to sericeous, with indumentum sometimes sparse; spikes 3-7 cm long, golden. Flowers 5-merous; sepals united; petals hairy. Pods openly and strongly curved (var. colei) or tightly coiled (var. ileocarpa), with dehisced valves somewhat twisted, entangled and persisting as conspicuous clumps following dehiscence, 3.5-4 mm wide, thinly coriaceous-crustaceous, glabrous or subglabrous. Seeds longitudinal, normally oblong, 3-4 mm long, glossy, very dark brown to black; aril bright yellow. When the sticky unripe pods are moistened and rubbed between palms they produce a greenish lather that removes dirt and cleans hands, hence the sometimes used common name, Soap Wattle (Kenneally et al. 1996: 130). Dense regrowth populations often develop in disturbed sites such as road verges, gravel pits and burnt areas. Details on the habitat and ecology of Acacia‚ colei are provided by‚ J.C. Doran et al., in J.C. Doran & J.W. Turnbull (eds), Australian Trees and Shrubs: Species for Land Rehabilitation and Farm Planting in the Tropics 128-131‚ (1997). Flowers May-September. See Kenneally et al. (1996:‚ 130).

fire: regenerates from seed after fire (sometimes pure stands of seedlings);
description: shrub or tree to 5 m high; branches arching downwards. branchlets flexuose, flattened, narrowly winged, glabrous. phyllodes often patent, narrowly elliptic, mostly 5-10 (-12.5) cm long and 10-30 (-45) mm wide, obtuse to subacute, thinly coriaceous, glabrous, with 7-9 prominent distant main veins and openly reticulate in between; pulvinus 2-3 mm long. inflorescences 4-8 per axil in axillary fascicle or sometimes fascicles racemose on axis to 30 mm long; peduncles 8-12 mm long, glabrous; heads globular, 6 mm diam., 35-45 (-60)-flowered, bright yellow. flowers 5-merous; sepals free to ½-united. pods linear, rounded over seeds alternately on each side and shallowly to moderately constricted between them, to 15 cm long, 6-10 mm wide, thinly coriaceous-crustaceous, wrinkled reticulately over seeds, glabrous. seeds longitudinal, subglobular, 4-5 mm long, dull, dark brown; funicle encircling seed. the markedly flattened branchlets and seeds with an encircling funicle serve to relate acacia complanata to homaloclada; these characters distinguish these species from related taxa such as simsii and multisiliqua (which have narrower phyllodes). acacia complanata is also similar to fleckeri. grows in sand, gravel and loam, usually over sandstone, in dry sclerophyll forest and heath. regenerates from seed after fire (sometimes pure stands of seedlings); also regrows from rootstock (lithgow 1997: 39). flowers circa november-march. ;
original_text: Shrub or tree to 5 m high; branches arching downwards. Branchlets flexuose, flattened, narrowly winged, glabrous. Phyllodes often patent, narrowly elliptic, mostly 5-10 (-12.5) cm long and 10-30 (-45) mm wide, obtuse to subacute, thinly coriaceous, glabrous, with 7-9 prominent distant main veins and openly reticulate in between; pulvinus 2-3 mm long. Inflorescences 4-8 per axil in axillary fascicle or sometimes fascicles racemose on axis to 30 mm long; peduncles 8-12 mm long, glabrous; heads globular, 6 mm diam., 35-45 (-60)-flowered, bright yellow. Flowers 5-merous; sepals free to ½-united. Pods linear, rounded over seeds alternately on each side and shallowly to moderately constricted between them, to 15 cm long, 6-10 mm wide, thinly coriaceous-crustaceous, wrinkled reticulately over seeds, glabrous. Seeds longitudinal, subglobular, 4-5 mm long, dull, dark brown; funicle encircling seed. The markedly flattened branchlets and seeds with an encircling funicle serve to relate Acacia complanata to A. homaloclada; these characters distinguish these species from related taxa such as A. simsii and A. multisiliqua (which have narrower phyllodes). Acacia complanata is also similar to A. fleckeri. Grows in sand, gravel and loam, usually over sandstone, in dry sclerophyll forest and heath. Regenerates from seed after fire (sometimes pure stands of seedlings); also regrows from rootstock (Lithgow 1997: 39). Flowers c. November-March.

fire: fire ecology is discussed by bell & elliott (2013).
description: tree to 10 m high. bark smooth, grey, with base later corrugated and blackish. branchlets terete with 4-6 ridges circa 0.2 mm high, and with numerous lenticels, glabrous. young foliage-tips blackish brown, almost glabrous. leaves green; petiole 0.7-4.7 cm long, glabrous or with sparse minute white hairs, with a gland just below lowest pinnae to median; rachis 1.5-6 cm long, with 1 (rarely 2) gland(s) at base of pinnae; interjugary glands absent; pinnae 2-6 pairs, 3-7.8 cm long; pinnules 14-30 pairs, often arranged alternately except towards apex, linear, (2-) 4-9 (-13.5) mm long, 0.25-0.4 mm wide, with 1 central nerve,  glabrous, acute. inflorescences mainly in axillary or terminal false-panicles. peduncles 1-4 mm long, glabrous. heads 12-26-flowered, golden. pods straight, mostly straight-sided to barely constricted between seeds, 3-8 cm long, 5-7 mm wide, subcoriaceous (young), light brown to black, glabrous. allied to acacia decurrens which has prominently winged sharp ridges on branchlets, and wider and more closely spaced pinnules. grows in woodland on the basalt summit and rocky slopes; dominant or co-dominant with eucalyptus moluccana and albens. psyllid species associated with acacia dangarensis are discussed by powell et al. (2012). fire ecology is discussed by bell & elliott (2013). flowers recorded august-september; fruits october, december. ;
original_text: Tree to 10 m high. Bark smooth, grey, with base later corrugated and blackish. Branchlets terete with 4-6 ridges c. 0.2 mm high, and with numerous lenticels, glabrous. Young foliage-tips blackish brown, almost glabrous. Leaves green; petiole 0.7-4.7 cm long, glabrous or with sparse minute white hairs, with a gland just below lowest pinnae to median; rachis 1.5-6 cm long, with 1 (rarely 2) gland(s) at base of pinnae; interjugary glands absent; pinnae 2-6 pairs, 3-7.8 cm long; pinnules 14-30 pairs, often arranged alternately except towards apex, linear, (2-) 4-9 (-13.5) mm long, 0.25-0.4 mm wide, with 1 central nerve,  glabrous, acute. Inflorescences mainly in axillary or terminal false-panicles. Peduncles 1-4 mm long, glabrous. Heads 12-26-flowered, golden. Pods straight, mostly straight-sided to barely constricted between seeds, 3-8 cm long, 5-7 mm wide, subcoriaceous (young), light brown to black, glabrous. Allied to Acacia decurrens which has prominently winged sharp ridges on branchlets, and wider and more closely spaced pinnules. Grows in woodland on the basalt summit and rocky slopes; dominant or co-dominant with Eucalyptus moluccana and E. albens. Psyllid species associated with Acacia dangarensis are discussed by Powell et al. (2012). Fire ecology is discussed by Bell & Elliott (2013). Flowers recorded August-September; fruits October, December.

fire: information on habitat, population dynamics, fire ecology, conservation, etc.
description: shrub 1-2.5 high, clonal. branchlets normally pendulous, short-hispid, sparsely to moderately glandular. phyllodes obliquely broad elliptic to circular, margins often undulate 2.7-9.5 mm long, 2.1-8.4 mm wide, mucronate, resinous, with stalked, gland-tipped hairs densest on margins and veins and scattered on surface; 1- or 2-veined per face with the second vein often not prominent; gland 0.4-1.2 mm above pulvinus. inflorescences simple, 1 per axil; peduncles 2.5-9 mm long, hispidulous or appressed to subappressed puberulous, basal bract persistent; heads globular, 12-22-flowered, golden. flowers 5-merous; sepals united. pods oblong, slightly curved, 0.7-3 cm long, 1.7-3.8 mm wide, with gland-tipped hairs. seeds not seen. population genetic studies using isozyme techniques show that populations of this species are clonal, reproducing almost exclusively by root suckering, however all but two populations are genetically different. the species is seemingly a shy seeder as all pods observed to date have been without seed. see bartolome et al., australian systematic botany 15: 465-475 (2002), for further discussion. the gland-tipped hairs on the phyllodes are distinctive and are absent from its closest relative, glandulicarpa which occurs further west and differs also in having non-pendulous branchlets, glabrous peduncles and generally broader pods. comprehensive information concerning this species, including a morphometric analysis involving some presumed close relatives, is provided in bartolome et al., australian systematic botany 15: 465-475 (2002). grows in subalpine, high-elevated environments in open forest and woodland. information on habitat, population dynamics, fire ecology, conservation, etc. is provided by bartolome et al., australian systematic botany 15: 465-475 (2002). flowers recorded october. ;
original_text: Shrub 1-2.5 high, clonal. Branchlets normally pendulous, short-hispid, sparsely to moderately glandular. Phyllodes obliquely broad elliptic to circular, margins often undulate 2.7-9.5 mm long, 2.1-8.4 mm wide, mucronate, resinous, with stalked, gland-tipped hairs densest on margins and veins and scattered on surface; 1- or 2-veined per face with the second vein often not prominent; gland 0.4-1.2 mm above pulvinus. Inflorescences simple, 1 per axil; peduncles 2.5-9 mm long, hispidulous or appressed to subappressed puberulous, basal bract persistent; heads globular, 12-22-flowered, golden. Flowers 5-merous; sepals united. Pods oblong, slightly curved, 0.7-3 cm long, 1.7-3.8 mm wide, with gland-tipped hairs. Seeds not seen. Population genetic studies using isozyme techniques show that populations of this species are clonal, reproducing almost exclusively by root suckering, however all but two populations are genetically different. The species is seemingly a shy seeder as all pods observed to date have been without seed. See M. Bartolome et al., Australian Systematic Botany 15: 465-475 (2002), for further discussion. The gland-tipped hairs on the phyllodes are distinctive and are absent from its closest relative, A. glandulicarpa which occurs further west and differs also in having non-pendulous branchlets, glabrous peduncles and generally broader pods. Comprehensive information concerning this species, including a morphometric analysis involving some presumed close relatives, is provided in M. Bartolome et al., Australian Systematic Botany 15: 465-475 (2002). Grows in subalpine, high-elevated environments in open forest and woodland. Information on habitat, population dynamics, fire ecology, conservation, etc. is provided by M. Bartolome et al., Australian Systematic Botany 15: 465-475 (2002). Flowers recorded October.

fire: acacia dealbata is often an early coloniser after fire.
description: bushy shrub or spreading tree to 30 m high. bark smooth, grey, brown or dark brown, deeply corrugated when old. branchlets slightly angular with ridges, densely puberulous, usually pruinose. young foliage-tips white, cream-coloured to golden, velvety-tomentose. leaves herbaceous, usually bluish grey or silvery and glaucous; petiole to 1.5 cm long, slightly ridged, with apical gland; rachis 1-12 (-17) cm long, with one orbicular light to dark brown tomentellose jugary gland at each pair of pinnae; interjugary glands absent; pinnae 6-30 pairs, 0.5-5.5 cm long; pinnules 10-68 pairs, narrowly oblong to linear, 0.7-6 mm long, 0.4-0.8 (-1) mm wide,  glabrous or puberulous on upper surface, silvery-puberulous below, obtuse or truncate. inflorescences in axillary racemes, or mostly terminal or axillary false-panicles; axes often zig-zagged. peduncles 2-10 mm long, hairy. heads globular, 13-42-flowered. pods often slightly constricted between some or all seeds, 2-11.5 cm long, 6-14 mm wide, subcoriaceous, blue or purplish, pruinose. acacia dealbata has previously been confused with the subspecies of leucoclada; it also occasionally hybridises with baileyana. there are 2 subspecies. pinnae mostly 1.5-5.5 cm long; leaves mostly 5-12 cm long or more; pinnules 1.5-6 mm long; heads 22-42-flowered; tree to 30 m high, occasionally a shrub ............ subsp dealbata pinnae 0.5-2.5 (-3) cm long; leaves mostly 1.5-8.5 cm long; pinnules mostly 0.7-4 mm long; heads 13-34-flowered; shrub or tree to 5 (rarely 10) m high ................... subsp subalpina intermediates occur between the subspecies; see p.kodela & m.tindale, telopea 9(2): 319-322 (2001), for discussion. grows mostly in open or tall open forest or woodland, at high altitudes often in low vegetation in subalpine areas, and in deep gullies and on swamp margins. potential pollen vectors for acacia dealbata within its natural range in tasmania are investigated by griffin et al. (2020). they found several bird species fed on the flower heads and foraged for small invertebrates inhabiting the blossoms. in the process, pollen adheres to their feathers and is likely to be transferred to other genets as the birds moved. see griffin et al. (2020) also for discussion on insect and wind pollination findings in the study. acacia dealbata is often an early coloniser after fire. acacia dealbata is a weed in parts of australia and is an invasive species in many ecosystems worldwide (see bibliography and references therein). it outcompetes plant communities through direct competition, changes in microhabitat and soil properties under the canopy, and the release of allelopathic compounds (lorenzo et al. 2017). ;
original_text: Bushy shrub or spreading tree to 30 m high. Bark smooth, grey, brown or dark brown, deeply corrugated when old. Branchlets slightly angular with ridges, densely puberulous, usually pruinose. Young foliage-tips white, cream-coloured to golden, velvety-tomentose. Leaves herbaceous, usually bluish grey or silvery and glaucous; petiole to 1.5 cm long, slightly ridged, with apical gland; rachis 1-12 (-17) cm long, with one orbicular light to dark brown tomentellose jugary gland at each pair of pinnae; interjugary glands absent; pinnae 6-30 pairs, 0.5-5.5 cm long; pinnules 10-68 pairs, narrowly oblong to linear, 0.7-6 mm long, 0.4-0.8 (-1) mm wide,  glabrous or puberulous on upper surface, silvery-puberulous below, obtuse or truncate. Inflorescences in axillary racemes, or mostly terminal or axillary false-panicles; axes often zig-zagged. Peduncles 2-10 mm long, hairy. Heads globular, 13-42-flowered. Pods often slightly constricted between some or all seeds, 2-11.5 cm long, 6-14 mm wide, subcoriaceous, blue or purplish, pruinose. Acacia dealbata has previously been confused with the subspecies of A. leucoclada; it also occasionally hybridises with A. baileyana. There are 2 subspecies. Pinnae mostly 1.5-5.5 cm long; leaves mostly 5-12 cm long or more; pinnules 1.5-6 mm long; heads 22-42-flowered; tree to 30 m high, occasionally a shrub ............ subsp. dealbata Pinnae 0.5-2.5 (-3) cm long; leaves mostly 1.5-8.5 cm long; pinnules mostly 0.7-4 mm long; heads 13-34-flowered; shrub or tree to 5 (rarely 10) m high ................... subsp. subalpina Intermediates occur between the subspecies; see P.G. Kodela & M.D. Tindale, Telopea 9(2): 319-322 (2001), for discussion. Grows mostly in open or tall open forest or woodland, at high altitudes often in low vegetation in subalpine areas, and in deep gullies and on swamp margins. Potential pollen vectors for Acacia dealbata within its natural range in Tasmania are investigated by Griffin et al. (2020). They found several bird species fed on the flower heads and foraged for small invertebrates inhabiting the blossoms. In the process, pollen adheres to their feathers and is likely to be transferred to other genets as the birds moved. See Griffin et al. (2020) also for discussion on insect and wind pollination findings in the study. Acacia dealbata is often an early coloniser after fire. Acacia dealbata is a weed in parts of Australia and is an invasive species in many ecosystems worldwide (see bibliography and references therein). It outcompetes plant communities through direct competition, changes in microhabitat and soil properties under the canopy, and the release of allelopathic compounds (Lorenzo et al. 2017).
