fire: can form thickets, and resprouts from a lignotuber after fire (beasley 2009: 48).
description: shrub normally 1-3 m high. branchlets ribbed, glabrous or sometimes appressed-puberulous, hairs rarely patent. phyllodes on raised stem-projections, often patent, oblanceolate to narrowly oblanceolate, narrowly elliptic or linear, (1.5-) 2-6 cm long, usually 3.5-10 mm wide, narrowed at base, obtuse to acute, grey-green to glaucous, usually glabrous, 1-veined per face; lateral veins obscure or absent; glands 1 or 2, with lowermost normally 5-15 mm above pulvinus. inflorescences prolific racemes in upper axils; raceme axes usually 2-6 cm long, appressed-puberulous with white or golden hairs; peduncles 3-6 (-9) mm long, usually appressed-puberulous, with hairs golden but sometimes white in fruit; heads globular, 15-30-flowered, golden. flowers 5¢€š¬¢‚¬Ëœmerous; sepals united. pods to 11 cm long, 4-9 mm wide, firmly chartaceous to thinly coriaceous, sometimes pruinose, glabrous. seeds longitudinal, oblong, 4-6 mm long, shiny, black; funicle-aril ½-¾ length of seed. a somewhat variable species but generally recognised by its relatively short, commonly oblanceolate phyllodes and long racemes with often light golden, normally appressed hairs on their axes and peduncles. the glands are small and normally slightly exserted, the lowermost usually being situated 5-15 mm above the pulvinus and sometimes connected to the midrib by a fine oblique nerve. the phyllode margin is commonly slightly indented at the gland. racemes occasionally reach 12 cm long (e g 9 km from chinchilla on the burnett hwy, queensland, hando 18, perth). pedley, austrobaileya 1: 296 (1980), noted a low spreading habit variant with narrow phyllodes (to 3 mm wide) from the inglewood district, queensland (e g t.mcdonald 362, bri). plants with linear, very narrow phyllodes, commonly 1-2 mm wide, occur in the hunter river area, new south wales (e g b.maslin 5920, mexu, nsw, perth). these are multistemmed shrubs to circa 1.2 m high and are confined to areas of shaly clay. these entities were treated as decora (narrow phyllode variant) in b.maslin (coordinator), wattle acacias of australia cd-rom (2001). acacia caleyi was treated as a distinct species by b.maslin, flora of australia 11a: 305 (2001), but it is now considered best treated as a variant within decora. plants referred to this entity are found near griffith, new south wales, and are characterised primarily by the spreading, often curved or crisped hairs on their branchlets, phyllodes, raceme axes and often peduncles. elsewhere in decora the raceme axes and peduncles have straight, closely appressed hairs; the phyllodes and branchlets are normally glabrous but if hairs are present (mainly victorian populations) they are closely appressed. acacia decora sometimes resembles buxifolia which is distinguished especially by its normally glabrous raceme axes and peduncles. sometimes sympatric with acacia polifolia in queensland, which is distinguished by its appressed-puberulous branchlets and generally longer, appressed-puberulous phyllodes. in the field these two species may be confused with deuteroneura. the habit of hamiltoniana may resemble that of decora. putative hybrids with vestita and another with conferta are noted under those species. commonly grows on rocky ridges or outcrops, in eucalyptus communities, sometimes as pure stands. can form thickets, and resprouts from a lignotuber after fire (beasley 2009: 48). flowers chiefly april-october. ;
original_text: Shrub normally 1-3 m high. Branchlets ribbed, glabrous or sometimes appressed-puberulous, hairs rarely patent. Phyllodes on raised stem-projections, often patent, oblanceolate to narrowly oblanceolate, narrowly elliptic or linear, (1.5-) 2-6 cm long, usually 3.5-10 mm wide, narrowed at base, obtuse to acute, grey-green to glaucous, usually glabrous, 1-veined per face; lateral veins obscure or absent; glands 1 or 2, with lowermost normally 5-15 mm above pulvinus. Inflorescences prolific racemes in upper axils; raceme axes usually 2-6 cm long, appressed-puberulous with white or golden hairs; peduncles 3-6 (-9) mm long, usually appressed-puberulous, with hairs golden but sometimes white in fruit; heads globular, 15-30-flowered, golden. Flowers 5¢€š¬¢‚¬Ëœmerous; sepals united. Pods to 11 cm long, 4-9 mm wide, firmly chartaceous to thinly coriaceous, sometimes pruinose, glabrous. Seeds longitudinal, oblong, 4-6 mm long, shiny, black; funicle-aril ½-¾ length of seed. A somewhat variable species but generally recognised by its relatively short, commonly oblanceolate phyllodes and long racemes with often light golden, normally appressed hairs on their axes and peduncles. The glands are small and normally slightly exserted, the lowermost usually being situated 5-15 mm above the pulvinus and sometimes connected to the midrib by a fine oblique nerve. The phyllode margin is commonly slightly indented at the gland. Racemes occasionally reach 12 cm long (e.g. 9 km from Chinchilla on the Burnett Hwy, Queensland, V. Hando 18, PERTH). L. Pedley, Austrobaileya 1: 296 (1980), noted a low spreading habit variant with narrow phyllodes (to 3 mm wide) from the Inglewood district, Queensland (e.g. T.J. McDonald 362, BRI). Plants with linear, very narrow phyllodes, commonly 1-2 mm wide, occur in the Hunter River area, New South Wales (e.g. B.R. Maslin 5920, MEXU, NSW, PERTH). These are multistemmed shrubs to c. 1.2 m high and are confined to areas of shaly clay. These entities were treated as A. decora (narrow phyllode variant) in B.R. Maslin (coordinator), WATTLE Acacias of Australia CD-ROM (2001). Acacia caleyi was treated as a distinct species by B.R. Maslin, Flora of Australia 11A: 305 (2001), but it is now considered best treated as a variant within A. decora. Plants referred to this entity are found near Griffith, New South Wales, and are characterised primarily by the spreading, often curved or crisped hairs on their branchlets, phyllodes, raceme axes and often peduncles. Elsewhere in A. decora the raceme axes and peduncles have straight, closely appressed hairs; the phyllodes and branchlets are normally glabrous but if hairs are present (mainly Victorian populations) they are closely appressed. Acacia decora sometimes resembles A. buxifolia which is distinguished especially by its normally glabrous raceme axes and peduncles. Sometimes sympatric with Acacia polifolia in Queensland, which is distinguished by its appressed-puberulous branchlets and generally longer, appressed-puberulous phyllodes. In the field these two species may be confused with A. deuteroneura. The habit of A. hamiltoniana may resemble that of A. decora. Putative hybrids with A. vestita and another with A. conferta are noted under those species. Commonly grows on rocky ridges or outcrops, in Eucalyptus communities, sometimes as pure stands. Can form thickets, and resprouts from a lignotuber after fire (Beasley 2009: 48). Flowers chiefly April-October.

simplified_phrase: regenerates from seed after fire and resprouts from basal rootstock after fire
fire: acacia dictyophleba regenerates from seed after fire and also resprouts vigorously from the root stock.
description: shrub 1-4 m high, glabrous and resinous. branchlets often sparsely tuberculate. phyllodes oblanceolate, (4-) 5-8.5 cm long, (9-) 10-25 (-28) mm wide, l: w = 3-7 (-11), obtuse, mucronulate, thickly coriaceous, smooth or asperulate by small tubercles on nerves, dark green but soon aging grey-green or an attractive blue-grey, with resin sometimes drying white (especially over veins); prominent longitudinal veins 2 or 3, with secondary veins forming a coarse, open reticulum; basal gland prominent, elongate, 1-3 mm long, with an obscure smaller gland at base of the minute apical point. inflorescences simple, 1-3 per axil; peduncles 10-25 (-50) mm long, ebracteate at base; heads globular or obloid, 9-13 mm diam. when dry, densely 40-60-flowered, golden. flowers 5-merous; sepals united almost to their apices. pods stipitate, narrowly oblong, flat, raised over seeds alternately on each side, to 9 cm long, 1-1.6 cm wide, firmly chartaceous, often vernicose. seeds transverse, circa 4 mm long, arillate. some plants from the northern gibson desert and the little sandy desert, western australia, are unusual and may represent a distinct taxon. they are spindly, single-stemmed shrubs 3-6 m high with 2¢€š¬¢‚¬Ëœveined, rather large phyllodes (mostly 4-6 x 1-1.5 cm), similar to those found on a. dictyophleba. however, the phyllodes are not thickly coriaceous or coarsely veined like that species and, furthermore, their heads are only 6-8 mm diam. when dry (smaller than those of dictyophleba, but within the range of melleodora). principally on account of their distinctive growth habit, these plants were included by b.maslin, flora of central australia 132 (1981) under jensenii (e g 4.8 km w of well 23, canning stock route, n of lake disappointment, b.maslin 2275, canb, perth), but their 2-veined phyllodes distinguishes them from that species. these spindly plants are favoured by aboriginal people for making spears. grows mainly in deep red or red-brown siliceous sand, on dunes or interdunal areas; sometimes found in shallow stony soils. acacia dictyophleba regenerates from seed after fire and also resprouts vigorously from the root stock. flowers march-september, the main flowering flush may-early july. the aboriginal use of acacia dictyophleba in central australia is discussed by latz, book_source 96 (1995), but it is probable that most of the information contained in this account refers to melleodora. ;
original_text: Shrub 1-4 m high, glabrous and resinous. Branchlets often sparsely tuberculate. Phyllodes oblanceolate, (4-) 5-8.5 cm long, (9-) 10-25 (-28) mm wide, l: w = 3-7 (-11), obtuse, mucronulate, thickly coriaceous, smooth or asperulate by small tubercles on nerves, dark green but soon aging grey-green or an attractive blue-grey, with resin sometimes drying white (especially over veins); prominent longitudinal veins 2 or 3, with secondary veins forming a coarse, open reticulum; basal gland prominent, elongate, 1-3 mm long, with an obscure smaller gland at base of the minute apical point. Inflorescences simple, 1-3 per axil; peduncles 10-25 (-50) mm long, ebracteate at base; heads globular or obloid, 9-13 mm diam. when dry, densely 40-60-flowered, golden. Flowers 5-merous; sepals united almost to their apices. Pods stipitate, narrowly oblong, flat, raised over seeds alternately on each side, to 9 cm long, 1-1.6 cm wide, firmly chartaceous, often vernicose. Seeds transverse, c. 4 mm long, arillate. Some plants from the northern Gibson Desert and the Little Sandy Desert, Western Australia, are unusual and may represent a distinct taxon. They are spindly, single-stemmed shrubs 3-6 m high with 2¢€š¬¢‚¬Ëœveined, rather large phyllodes (mostly 4-6 x 1-1.5 cm), similar to those found on A. dictyophleba. However, the phyllodes are not thickly coriaceous or coarsely veined like that species and, furthermore, their heads are only 6-8 mm diam. when dry (smaller than those of A. dictyophleba, but within the range of A. melleodora). Principally on account of their distinctive growth habit, these plants were included by B.R. Maslin, Flora of Central Australia 132 (1981) under A. jensenii (e.g. 4.8 km W of Well 23, Canning Stock Route, N of Lake Disappointment, B.R. Maslin 2275, CANB, PERTH), but their 2-veined phyllodes distinguishes them from that species. These spindly plants are favoured by Aboriginal people for making spears. Grows mainly in deep red or red-brown siliceous sand, on dunes or interdunal areas; sometimes found in shallow stony soils. Acacia dictyophleba regenerates from seed after fire and also resprouts vigorously from the root stock. Flowers March-September, the main flowering flush May-early July. The Aboriginal use of Acacia dictyophleba in central Australia is discussed by P. Latz, Bushfires & Bushtucker 96 (1995), but it is probable that most of the information contained in this account refers to A. melleodora.

fire: reshoots from the roots following fire.
description: shrub or tree to 10 m high, single-stemmed. bark corrugated, dark greyish brown to black on trunk. branchlets angular towards apices, yellow-brown to red-brown, glabrous,  resinous. phyllodes linear, flat, mostly straight to slightly curved, 7-20 cm long, 2-8 (-10) mm wide, with recurved or oblique apices, coriaceous, glabrous, with 1 prominent and usually 2 subprominent main veins continuous to base; minor veins 7-10 per mm, parallel, rarely anastomosing; glands mostly 1, rudimentary, basal. inflorescences short racemes 2-15 mm long; spikes (1.5-) 2-3.5 cm long, golden. flowers mostly 5-merous; calyx 0.7-1.1 mm long, dissected to ¢‚¬¦¢€ž¢-¼ of length, densely pubescent; corolla 1.2-2.1 mm long, dissected to ¼-½ of length, glabrous; ovary  pubescent or glabrous. pods linear, slightly moniliform, 5-10 cm long,  coriaceous, longitudinally wrinkled, glabrous. seeds longitudinal, elliptic-oblong, 3-5 mm long, black; pleurogram without halo; areole open.  grows in open woodland or open forest in skeletal rocky soils, often on ridges or hillsides and on flat or undulating land, with mallee eucalypts in red earths. reshoots from the roots following fire. information on the biological and ecological features of this species is given in b.maslin and m.mcdonald, acaciasearch: evaluation of acacia as a woody crop option for southern australia, rirdc publication no. 30/017, 80-83 (2004). flowers late august-late september in the north and mid-september-november in the south. ;
original_text: Shrub or tree to 10 m high, single-stemmed. Bark corrugated, dark greyish brown to black on trunk. Branchlets angular towards apices, yellow-brown to red-brown, glabrous,  resinous. Phyllodes linear, flat, mostly straight to slightly curved, 7-20 cm long, 2-8 (-10) mm wide, with recurved or oblique apices, coriaceous, glabrous, with 1 prominent and usually 2 subprominent main veins continuous to base; minor veins 7-10 per mm, parallel, rarely anastomosing; glands mostly 1, rudimentary, basal. Inflorescences short racemes 2-15 mm long; spikes (1.5-) 2-3.5 cm long, golden. Flowers mostly 5-merous; calyx 0.7-1.1 mm long, dissected to ¢‚¬¦¢€ž¢-¼ of length, densely pubescent; corolla 1.2-2.1 mm long, dissected to ¼-½ of length, glabrous; ovary  pubescent or glabrous. Pods linear, slightly moniliform, 5-10 cm long,  coriaceous, longitudinally wrinkled, glabrous. Seeds longitudinal, elliptic-oblong, 3-5 mm long, black; pleurogram without halo; areole open.  Grows in open woodland or open forest in skeletal rocky soils, often on ridges or hillsides and on flat or undulating land, with mallee eucalypts in red earths. Reshoots from the roots following fire. Information on the biological and ecological features of this species is given in B.R. Maslin and M.W. McDonald, AcaciaSearch: Evaluation of Acacia as a woody crop option for southern Australia, RIRDC Publication No. 30/017, 80-83 (2004). Flowers late August-late September in the north and mid-September-November in the south.

simplified_phrase: resprouts from root suckers after fire
fire: n.burbidge & gray, flora of the australian capital territory 202 (1970), report falciformis in the australian capital territory as forming thickets by root suckers following fire or disturbance.
description: shrub or tree to 12 m high, sometimes taller. branchlets glabrous. phyllodes  pendulous, usually falcate and 10-22 cm long, 1.5-3 cm wide, narrowed at base, grey-green to glaucescent, glabrous, with prominent midrib, finely penninerved; gland 5-30 mm above pulvinus; margin indented at gland which is connected to midrib by a fine oblique vein. inflorescences 5-18-headed racemes, sometimes in terminal panicles; raceme axes 2-10 cm long, usually yellow appressed-puberulous at least near apices; peduncles 4-10 mm long, usually yellow appressed-puberulous; heads globular, 20-30-flowered, creamy yellow. flowers 5-merous; sepals united. pods mostly 5-13 cm long and 15-25 mm wide, thinly coriaceous, slightly pruinose, glabrous. seeds longitudinal, oblong to  elliptic, 5.5-7 mm long, slightly shiny, black; funicle thickly filiform, often folded below seed, dark reddish brown; aril clavate. a few specimens from northern new south wales (e g gloucester buckets, gibraltar ra.) have oblanceolate,  straight, shorter than normal phyllodes 6-8 cm long (e g r.coveny s.n., nsw167394). acacia falciformis is usually distinguished from related species with large, falcately recurved phyllodes and broad pods, by its yellow appressed-puberulous raceme axes and peduncles (hairs occasionally white or absent; mabellae has similar indumentum but with  spreading hairs), and phyllodes with their adaxial margin shallowly indented at the gland which is situated 5-30 mm above the pulvinus and connected to the midrib by a fine oblique nerve. the variant from glasshouse mountains, queensland, referred to by pedley, austrobaileya 1: 267 (1980), is probably within the normal range of variation for the species. however, many specimens from further n in queensland are unusual in having the gland located 0-5 mm above the pulvinus and seemingly lacking the oblique nerve to the midrib. these can be confused with falcata which is distinguished by its peduncles 3-4 mm long, heads 15-20-flowered, sepals  free, pods 5-8 mm wide and funicles completely encircling the seeds. patterns of variation within these queensland populations require further study. past confusion between falciformis and penninervis is discussed by j.maiden, forest flora of new south wales 3: 69-77 (1907), and summarised by pedley, austrobaileya 1: 269 (1980). acacia obliquinervia was also formerly confounded with falciformis. phyllodes are sometimes  mottled pinkish purple upon drying and may resemble those of rubida, a species readily distinguished by its commonly persistent juvenile foliage, peduncles normally 2-4 mm long, heads light golden and 10-20-flowered, pods 5-8 mm wide and funicles completely encircling the seeds. acacia falciformis appears to hybridise with bancroftiorum in the leichhardt district, queensland. n.burbidge & gray, flora of the australian capital territory 202 (1970), report falciformis in the australian capital territory as forming thickets by root suckers following fire or disturbance. grows in clay loam in sclerophyll forest or woodland. ;
original_text: Shrub or tree to 12 m high, sometimes taller. Branchlets glabrous. Phyllodes  pendulous, usually falcate and 10-22 cm long, 1.5-3 cm wide, narrowed at base, grey-green to glaucescent, glabrous, with prominent midrib, finely penninerved; gland 5-30 mm above pulvinus; margin indented at gland which is connected to midrib by a fine oblique vein. Inflorescences 5-18-headed racemes, sometimes in terminal panicles; raceme axes 2-10 cm long, usually yellow appressed-puberulous at least near apices; peduncles 4-10 mm long, usually yellow appressed-puberulous; heads globular, 20-30-flowered, creamy yellow. Flowers 5-merous; sepals united. Pods mostly 5-13 cm long and 15-25 mm wide, thinly coriaceous, slightly pruinose, glabrous. Seeds longitudinal, oblong to  elliptic, 5.5-7 mm long, slightly shiny, black; funicle thickly filiform, often folded below seed, dark reddish brown; aril clavate. A few specimens from northern New South Wales (e.g. Gloucester Buckets, Gibraltar Ra.) have oblanceolate,  straight, shorter than normal phyllodes 6-8 cm long (e.g. R.G. Coveny s.n., NSW167394). Acacia falciformis is usually distinguished from related species with large, falcately recurved phyllodes and broad pods, by its yellow appressed-puberulous raceme axes and peduncles (hairs occasionally white or absent; A. mabellae has similar indumentum but with  spreading hairs), and phyllodes with their adaxial margin shallowly indented at the gland which is situated 5-30 mm above the pulvinus and connected to the midrib by a fine oblique nerve. The variant from Glasshouse Mountains, Queensland, referred to by L. Pedley, Austrobaileya 1: 267 (1980), is probably within the normal range of variation for the species. However, many specimens from further N in Queensland are unusual in having the gland located 0-5 mm above the pulvinus and seemingly lacking the oblique nerve to the midrib. These can be confused with A. falcata which is distinguished by its peduncles 3-4 mm long, heads 15-20-flowered, sepals  free, pods 5-8 mm wide and funicles completely encircling the seeds. Patterns of variation within these Queensland populations require further study. Past confusion between A. falciformis and A. penninervis is discussed by J.H. Maiden, Forest Flora of New South Wales 3: 69-77 (1907), and summarised by L. Pedley, Austrobaileya 1: 269 (1980). Acacia obliquinervia was also formerly confounded with A. falciformis. Phyllodes are sometimes  mottled pinkish purple upon drying and may resemble those of A. rubida, a species readily distinguished by its commonly persistent juvenile foliage, peduncles normally 2-4 mm long, heads light golden and 10-20-flowered, pods 5-8 mm wide and funicles completely encircling the seeds. Acacia falciformis appears to hybridise with A. bancroftiorum in the Leichhardt District, Queensland. N.T. Burbidge & M. Gray, Flora of the Australian Capital Territory 202 (1970), report A. falciformis in the Australian Capital Territory as forming thickets by root suckers following fire or disturbance. Grows in clay loam in sclerophyll forest or woodland.

fire: they regenerate from seed following fire or other disturbance and may form dense roadside populations.
description: shrub 1.5-3 m high, obconic with spreading,  open crowns. bark smooth, orange or grey. branchlets slender, terete except angled at extremities, minutely and densely white-hairy. phyllodes wide-spreading to ascending, narrowly elliptic to oblanceolate, straight and dimidiate to shallowly or moderately falcate, 8-12 cm long, 10-15 mm wide, narrowed at base, green or bluish green; finely multistriate with 2 subcentral veins more evident than the rest and sometimes confluent with one another near base; minor veins closely parallel, sometimes anastomosing; pulvinus distinct, 4-5 mm long, orange (fresh). inflorescences simple, 2 per axil; peduncles 7-12 mm long, sub-stout, glabrous or minutely hairy; spikes 2-4 (-4.5) cm long, 5-6 mm diam., dense, light golden. flowers 5-merous; calyx ½-¢‚¬¦¢‚¬€ length of corolla, very shortly divided; petals circa 1.5 mm long. pods prolific, linear, rounded over and slightly constricted between seeds, 7-9 cm long, 3-4 mm wide, firmly chartaceous to very thinly crustaceous, brown,  glabrous to minutely appressed-hairy. seeds longitudinal, oblong to oblong-elliptic, 3.5-4 mm long, dark brown; aril white. most closely related to the more northerly and widespread species acacia gonoclada which differs in having stouter, acutely angled branchlets, often shallowly incurved (never recurved) phyllodes and generally shorter peduncles, spikes and pods. it is superficially similar to elachantha which has densely silver- or yellow-hairy new shoots, 3 prominent phyllode veins with widely spaced anastomosing minor veins and seeds with yellow arils, and hamersleyensis which has subglaucous to glaucous phyllodes, often larger spikes and broader, hairy pods with oblique seeds. grows in areas under-laid by sedimentary rocks and appears to favour water-gaining sites. plants flower from an early age; they regenerate from seed following fire or other disturbance and may form dense roadside populations. flowers april-june. ;
original_text: Shrub 1.5-3 m high, obconic with spreading,  open crowns. Bark smooth, orange or grey. Branchlets slender, terete except angled at extremities, minutely and densely white-hairy. Phyllodes wide-spreading to ascending, narrowly elliptic to oblanceolate, straight and dimidiate to shallowly or moderately falcate, 8-12 cm long, 10-15 mm wide, narrowed at base, green or bluish green; finely multistriate with 2 subcentral veins more evident than the rest and sometimes confluent with one another near base; minor veins closely parallel, sometimes anastomosing; pulvinus distinct, 4-5 mm long, orange (fresh). Inflorescences simple, 2 per axil; peduncles 7-12 mm long, sub-stout, glabrous or minutely hairy; spikes 2-4 (-4.5) cm long, 5-6 mm diam., dense, light golden. Flowers 5-merous; calyx ½-¢‚¬¦¢‚¬€ length of corolla, very shortly divided; petals c. 1.5 mm long. Pods prolific, linear, rounded over and slightly constricted between seeds, 7-9 cm long, 3-4 mm wide, firmly chartaceous to very thinly crustaceous, brown,  glabrous to minutely appressed-hairy. Seeds longitudinal, oblong to oblong-elliptic, 3.5-4 mm long, dark brown; aril white. Most closely related to the more northerly and widespread species Acacia gonoclada which differs in having stouter, acutely angled branchlets, often shallowly incurved (never recurved) phyllodes and generally shorter peduncles, spikes and pods. It is superficially similar to A. elachantha which has densely silver- or yellow-hairy new shoots, 3 prominent phyllode veins with widely spaced anastomosing minor veins and seeds with yellow arils, and A. hamersleyensis which has subglaucous to glaucous phyllodes, often larger spikes and broader, hairy pods with oblique seeds. Grows in areas under-laid by sedimentary rocks and appears to favour water-gaining sites. Plants flower from an early age; they regenerate from seed following fire or other disturbance and may form dense roadside populations. Flowers April-June.

simplified_phrase: resprouts after fire and regenerates from seed after fire; soil-stored seedbank
fire: acacia gordonii has been observed to both resprout and regenerate from seed after fire (has a soil-stored seedbank) (steve douglas, pers.
description: erect or spreading, often straggling shrub 0.5-1.5 m high, sometimes to 2 m. branchlets densely pubescent. phyllodes  spirally arranged to subverticillate and on prominent stem-projections, crowded, ascending to erect, straight but slightly recurved at apex, subterete to flat, 8-15 mm long, 0.7-1 mm wide, obliquely and excentrically mucronate apex, cuneate to obtuse base, green, sometimes asperulate, finely puberulous with  antrorse and often tubercle-based hairs, finely longitudinally rugose when dry; veins not evident; pulvinus hairy. inflorescences simple, 1 per axil; peduncles 8-15 mm long, stout, densely pubescent, ebracteate at base; heads globular, (12-) 20-25 (-34)-flowered, bright deep golden. flowers 5-merous; sepals circa ½-¾-united, glabrous or sparely hairy; petals glabrous. pods oblong to narrowly oblong, flat,  straight-sided but sometimes constricted between some seeds, to 5.5 cm long, 9-15 mm wide, firmly chartaceous, blackish, glabrous, dehiscing unilaterally. seeds transverse, elliptic, 3-4 mm long, arillate. related to the more northerly acacia brunioides which is recognised by its thinner, usually shorter, glabrous phyllodes with frequently only slightly upturned mucros. also related to the more northerly distributed beadleana and is sometimes confused with baueri subsp aspera which grows in the blue mountains but which is readily distinguished by its shorter peduncles, fewer-flowered heads, smaller pods and longitudinal seeds. grows in sand on sandstone in heath and dry sclerophyll forest, often amongst rock platforms on sandstone outcrops. acacia gordonii has been observed to both resprout and regenerate from seed after fire (has a soil-stored seedbank) (steve douglas, pers. comm., october 2019). see also benson & mcdougall (1996: 709) and bell (2008: 340). powell et al. (2012) describes a specialist psyllid species (psyllidae: acizzia sp.) on gordonii (the host) when it is in flower. august-september. ;
original_text: Erect or spreading, often straggling shrub 0.5-1.5 m high, sometimes to 2 m. Branchlets densely pubescent. Phyllodes  spirally arranged to subverticillate and on prominent stem-projections, crowded, ascending to erect, straight but slightly recurved at apex, subterete to flat, 8-15 mm long, 0.7-1 mm wide, obliquely and excentrically mucronate apex, cuneate to obtuse base, green, sometimes asperulate, finely puberulous with  antrorse and often tubercle-based hairs, finely longitudinally rugose when dry; veins not evident; pulvinus hairy. Inflorescences simple, 1 per axil; peduncles 8-15 mm long, stout, densely pubescent, ebracteate at base; heads globular, (12-) 20-25 (-34)-flowered, bright deep golden. Flowers 5-merous; sepals c. ½-¾-united, glabrous or sparely hairy; petals glabrous. Pods oblong to narrowly oblong, flat,  straight-sided but sometimes constricted between some seeds, to 5.5 cm long, 9-15 mm wide, firmly chartaceous, blackish, glabrous, dehiscing unilaterally. Seeds transverse, elliptic, 3-4 mm long, arillate. Related to the more northerly Acacia brunioides which is recognised by its thinner, usually shorter, glabrous phyllodes with frequently only slightly upturned mucros. Also related to the more northerly distributed A. beadleana and is sometimes confused with A. baueri subsp. aspera which grows in the Blue Mountains but which is readily distinguished by its shorter peduncles, fewer-flowered heads, smaller pods and longitudinal seeds. Grows in sand on sandstone in heath and dry sclerophyll forest, often amongst rock platforms on sandstone outcrops. Acacia gordonii has been observed to both resprout and regenerate from seed after fire (has a soil-stored seedbank) (Steve Douglas, pers. comm., October 2019). See also Benson & McDougall (1996: 709) and Bell (2008: 340). Powell et al. (2012) describes a specialist psyllid species (Psyllidae: Acizzia sp.) on A. gordonii (the host) when it is in flower. August-September.

fire: regenerates well from seed after fire (lithgow 1997: 43).
description: resinous shrub to 2 m high. branchlets finely ribbed below insertion of phyllodes; indumentum mostly of short scattered glandular hairs. phyllodes crowded, sometimes subverticillate, erect, straight but slightly recurved at apex, probably subterete when fresh,  depressed-triquetrous when dry, 6-18 mm long, circa 0.4 mm wide, excentrically mucronulate, with two indistinct longitudinally grooves when dry, asperulous-tuberculate; veins not evident; gland minute, near middle of phyllode, often absent. inflorescences simple, 1 per axil; peduncles mostly 6-10 mm long, asperulous-tuberculate; heads globular, circa 30-flowered, bright yellow, viscid. flowers 5-merous; sepals united to about the middle. pods narrowly oblong, to 4 cm long, 3-4 mm wide, with prominent raised cartilaginous excrescences on valves. seeds longitudinal, oblong, circa 4 mm long; aril clavate. acacia handonis is related to the 'johnsonii group' but can be readily distinguished by the distinctive pods with prominent excrescences on their valves. this character helps relate the species to glutinosissima and rossei from western australia; sedifolia (also western australia) seems not far removed from this group even though its pods do not have prominent excrescences. the phyllodes of handonis are superficially similar to those of brunioides subsp granitica . grows in lateritic soil with grey sand or clayey silt with ironstone gravel, in gently undulating country, often on stony ridges, in eucalypt woodland and open forest. regenerates well from seed after fire (lithgow 1997: 43). flowers mainly july-september. ;
original_text: Resinous shrub to 2 m high. Branchlets finely ribbed below insertion of phyllodes; indumentum mostly of short scattered glandular hairs. Phyllodes crowded, sometimes subverticillate, erect, straight but slightly recurved at apex, probably subterete when fresh,  depressed-triquetrous when dry, 6-18 mm long, c. 0.4 mm wide, excentrically mucronulate, with two indistinct longitudinally grooves when dry, asperulous-tuberculate; veins not evident; gland minute, near middle of phyllode, often absent. Inflorescences simple, 1 per axil; peduncles mostly 6-10 mm long, asperulous-tuberculate; heads globular, c. 30-flowered, bright yellow, viscid. Flowers 5-merous; sepals united to about the middle. Pods narrowly oblong, to 4 cm long, 3-4 mm wide, with prominent raised cartilaginous excrescences on valves. Seeds longitudinal, oblong, c. 4 mm long; aril clavate. Acacia handonis is related to the 'A. johnsonii group' but can be readily distinguished by the distinctive pods with prominent excrescences on their valves. This character helps relate the species to A. glutinosissima and A. rossei from Western Australia; A. sedifolia (also Western Australia) seems not far removed from this group even though its pods do not have prominent excrescences. The phyllodes of A. handonis are superficially similar to those of A. brunioides subsp. granitica . Grows in lateritic soil with grey sand or clayey silt with ironstone gravel, in gently undulating country, often on stony ridges, in eucalypt woodland and open forest. Regenerates well from seed after fire (Lithgow 1997: 43). Flowers mainly July-September.

simplified_phrase: regenerates from seed after fire and resprouts from base and/or epicormically
fire: "very fire tolerant and rapidly regenerates from seed and resprouts from the base and/or develops epicormic growth following fire" (b.maslin et al., wattles of the pilbara 2010).
description: somewhat gnarled glabrous tree 2-4 m tall, sometimes to 8 m. bark thick, corky. branchlets normally pruinose. stipules spinose, sometimes only bases persisting. phyllodes inequilaterally ovate to elliptic or obovate, sometimes obliquely orbicular, normally 2-5 cm long and 1.5-3.5 cm wide, variably undulate, normally acute to acuminate, pungent, coriaceous, normally grey-green, glabrous; midrib prominent and excentric; lateral nerves forming a close, normally prominent reticulum. inflorescences terminal or axillary racemes; raceme axes 5-18 cm long and (together with the peduncles) purple-red and often pruinose; peduncles mostly twinned and 1-2 cm long; heads globular, circa 30-flowered, golden; buds dark purple-red. flowers 5-merous; sepals free, sometimes shortly united. pods curved to openly 1½-coiled, to 11 cm long, 7-10 mm wide, firmly chartaceous to thinly coriaceous, pruinose. seeds longitudinal, oblong to orbicular, 4.5-6 mm long, dull, brown, encircled by funicle. formerly confused with acacia pyrifolia which has non-corky bark, symmetrically elliptic to orbicular or obovate phyllodes with central midribs and lateral nerves forming a less prominent reticulum, pale-coloured peduncles, raceme axes and flower buds, and short funicles which do not encircle the seeds. phyllodes and inflorescences are often similar to those of marramamba . grows in sand or sandy loam, often on rocky hills, in tall shrubland with spinifex ground cover. "very fire tolerant and rapidly regenerates from seed and resprouts from the base and/or develops epicormic growth following fire" (b.maslin et al., wattles of the pilbara 2010). inaequilatera is a comparatively short-lived species, lasting less than 10 years, according to a.a. mitchell & d.wilcox, arid shrubland plants of western australia 2nd edn: 478 (1994). flowers may-august. seeds (green or mature) eaten by aboriginal people. ;
original_text: Somewhat gnarled glabrous tree 2-4 m tall, sometimes to 8 m. Bark thick, corky. Branchlets normally pruinose. Stipules spinose, sometimes only bases persisting. Phyllodes inequilaterally ovate to elliptic or obovate, sometimes obliquely orbicular, normally 2-5 cm long and 1.5-3.5 cm wide, variably undulate, normally acute to acuminate, pungent, coriaceous, normally grey-green, glabrous; midrib prominent and excentric; lateral nerves forming a close, normally prominent reticulum. Inflorescences terminal or axillary racemes; raceme axes 5-18 cm long and (together with the peduncles) purple-red and often pruinose; peduncles mostly twinned and 1-2 cm long; heads globular, c. 30-flowered, golden; buds dark purple-red. Flowers 5-merous; sepals free, sometimes shortly united. Pods curved to openly 1½-coiled, to 11 cm long, 7-10 mm wide, firmly chartaceous to thinly coriaceous, pruinose. Seeds longitudinal, oblong to orbicular, 4.5-6 mm long, dull, brown, encircled by funicle. Formerly confused with Acacia pyrifolia which has non-corky bark, symmetrically elliptic to orbicular or obovate phyllodes with central midribs and lateral nerves forming a less prominent reticulum, pale-coloured peduncles, raceme axes and flower buds, and short funicles which do not encircle the seeds. Phyllodes and inflorescences are often similar to those of A. marramamba . Grows in sand or sandy loam, often on rocky hills, in tall shrubland with spinifex ground cover. "Very fire tolerant and rapidly regenerates from seed and resprouts from the base and/or develops epicormic growth following fire" (B.R. Maslin et al., Wattles of the Pilbara 2010). A. inaequilatera is a comparatively short-lived species, lasting less than 10 years, according to A.A. Mitchell & D.G. Wilcox, Arid shrubland Plants of Western Australia 2nd edn: 478 (1994). Flowers May-August. Seeds (green or mature) eaten by Aboriginal people.

fire: details on fire tolerance of kempeana are given by latz, book_source 102 (1995).
description: shrub or tree to 5 m high, spreading. bark furrowed, usually grey or brown. branchlets terete except at apices, grey or brownish, slightly scurfy, glabrous. phyllodes narrowly elliptic to very narrowly elliptic, sometimes oblanceolate to narrowly oblanceolate, flat, straight or very slightly curved, 3-7.5 (-9) cm long, 4-15 (-25) mm wide, with obtuse and often mucronulate apices, coriaceous, grey- or blue-green, glabrous, resinous when young, very finely multistriate, non-anastomosing, sometimes with 1-3 veins slightly more prominent; gland basal. peduncles 5-12 mm long, glabrous. spikes 1 or 2 per upper axil, 1-2.5 cm long, dense, bright golden. flowers 5-merous; calyx cupular, dissected to one third of length, hairy mostly at base; corolla 1.3-2 mm long, 2-2.5 times as long as calyx. pods oblong to narrowly oblong, flat, 2-7 cm long, 1-1.6 (-2) cm wide, chartaceous, finely transversely reticulate, glabrous, often slightly resinous. seeds transverse to slightly oblique. this species is closely allied to acacia stowardii [sibirica]and duriuscula. it is also related to aprepta. since publication of the flora of australia (2001) the australian plant census recognises acacia sibirica (placed in synonymy with kempeana in the flora of australia ) as an accepted species. acacia kempeana remains as an accepted name. widely distributed in arid areas, where it occurs usually on stony hillsides or in coarse textured alluvial soils; often abundant in mulga woodlands on red sandy loam plains. details on fire tolerance of kempeana are given by latz, book_source 102 (1995). probably flowers whenever temperature and soil moisture are high. fruiting mainly august-november. aboriginal people obtained witchetty grubs from the roots, as well as the bush providing edible gum and seed (urban, wildflowers and plants of central australia 84, 1990). details on aboriginal use of kempeana are given in latz (1995, 1999, 2018). ;
original_text: Shrub or tree to 5 m high, spreading. Bark furrowed, usually grey or brown. Branchlets terete except at apices, grey or brownish, slightly scurfy, glabrous. Phyllodes narrowly elliptic to very narrowly elliptic, sometimes oblanceolate to narrowly oblanceolate, flat, straight or very slightly curved, 3-7.5 (-9) cm long, 4-15 (-25) mm wide, with obtuse and often mucronulate apices, coriaceous, grey- or blue-green, glabrous, resinous when young, very finely multistriate, non-anastomosing, sometimes with 1-3 veins slightly more prominent; gland basal. Peduncles 5-12 mm long, glabrous. Spikes 1 or 2 per upper axil, 1-2.5 cm long, dense, bright golden. Flowers 5-merous; calyx cupular, dissected to one third of length, hairy mostly at base; corolla 1.3-2 mm long, 2-2.5 times as long as calyx. Pods oblong to narrowly oblong, flat, 2-7 cm long, 1-1.6 (-2) cm wide, chartaceous, finely transversely reticulate, glabrous, often slightly resinous. Seeds transverse to slightly oblique. This species is closely allied to Acacia stowardii [A. sibirica]and A. duriuscula. It is also related to A. aprepta. Since publication of the Flora of Australia (2001) the Australian Plant Census recognises Acacia sibirica (placed in synonymy with A. kempeana in the Flora of Australia ) as an accepted species. Acacia kempeana remains as an accepted name. Widely distributed in arid areas, where it occurs usually on stony hillsides or in coarse textured alluvial soils; often abundant in mulga woodlands on red sandy loam plains. Details on fire tolerance of A. kempeana are given by P. Latz, Bushfires & Bushtucker 102 (1995). Probably flowers whenever temperature and soil moisture are high. Fruiting mainly August-November. Aboriginal people obtained witchetty grubs from the roots, as well as the bush providing edible gum and seed (A. Urban, Wildflowers and Plants of Central Australia 84, 1990). Details on Aboriginal use of A. kempeana are given in Latz (1995, 1999, 2018).

fire: one specimen from kybeyan range has atypically sparsely hairy branchlets (e g wadbilliga fire trail between tuross river and bumberry creek, r.coveny 6604 et al., a n.v., b n.v., bri n.v., canb, e n.v., k n.v., l n.v., mel, nsw, p n.v., rsa n.v., tns n.v., uc n.v., us n.v., z n.v.).
description: dense shrub 1-2.5 m high. branchlets tomentulose to densely appressed-puberulous. phyllodes occasionally deflexed, slightly asymmetric, oblong-elliptic to narrowly elliptic or lanceolate, 1-5 cm long, 3-6 mm wide, grey-green to glaucous, glabrous or sometimes sparsely appressed-puberulous, 1-veined per face; lateral veins obscure or absent; gland not prominent, 1-15 mm above pulvinus. inflorescences 4-10-headed racemes; raceme axes 1-4 cm long, usually densely hairy; peduncles 1-3 mm long, usually densely appressed-hairy; heads globular, subdensely 8-15-flowered, bright golden; bracteoles widely ovate to subcircular, dark brown to black. flowers 5-merous; sepals united, brown; petals 1-veined; ovary glabrous. pods stipitate, oblong to narrowly oblong, raised over seeds along midline, to 6 cm long, 1-2 cm wide, firmly chartaceous, blackish, slightly to moderately pruinose, glabrous. seeds mostly transverse to oblique, elliptic to widely elliptic, circa 4 mm long, 3.5 mm wide, arillate. a marked variation in phyllode length in this species indicates the need for further studies to ascertain whether it, as circumscribed here, comprises more than one taxon. on specimens from new south wales (including the type of acacia kybeanensis and oreades) the phyllodes are normally 1-3 cm long, whereas in victoria they are mostly 2.5-5 cm long. the long phyllode variants may resemble kettlewelliae but are most readily distinguished by their terete, densely hairy branchlets, densely hairy peduncles and raceme axes, and less prominent glands which are not, or scarcely, swollen within the lamina of the phyllode. deflexed phyllodes, which occasionally occur in the long phyllode variant, are sometimes also seen in boormanii. one specimen from kybeyan range has atypically sparsely hairy branchlets (e g wadbilliga fire trail between tuross river and bumberry creek, r.coveny 6604 et al., a n.v., b n.v., bri n.v., canb, e n.v., k n.v., l n.v., mel, nsw, p n.v., rsa n.v., tns n.v., uc n.v., us n.v., z n.v.). it appears to approach the short phyllode forms of kettlewelliae but is distinguished by the presence of an indumentum and less prominent gland. it is possible that this variant is part of a hybrid swarm between kybeanensis and kettlewelliae: both putative parents occur in the kybeyan range. usually grows in eucalyptus woodland or forest on rocky slopes, commonly at circa 1000 m alt. ;
original_text: Dense shrub 1-2.5 m high. Branchlets tomentulose to densely appressed-puberulous. Phyllodes occasionally deflexed, slightly asymmetric, oblong-elliptic to narrowly elliptic or lanceolate, 1-5 cm long, 3-6 mm wide, grey-green to glaucous, glabrous or sometimes sparsely appressed-puberulous, 1-veined per face; lateral veins obscure or absent; gland not prominent, 1-15 mm above pulvinus. Inflorescences 4-10-headed racemes; raceme axes 1-4 cm long, usually densely hairy; peduncles 1-3 mm long, usually densely appressed-hairy; heads globular, subdensely 8-15-flowered, bright golden; bracteoles widely ovate to subcircular, dark brown to black. Flowers 5-merous; sepals united, brown; petals 1-veined; ovary glabrous. Pods stipitate, oblong to narrowly oblong, raised over seeds along midline, to 6 cm long, 1-2 cm wide, firmly chartaceous, blackish, slightly to moderately pruinose, glabrous. Seeds mostly transverse to oblique, elliptic to widely elliptic, c. 4 mm long, 3.5 mm wide, arillate. A marked variation in phyllode length in this species indicates the need for further studies to ascertain whether it, as circumscribed here, comprises more than one taxon. On specimens from New South Wales (including the type of Acacia kybeanensis and A. oreades) the phyllodes are normally 1-3 cm long, whereas in Victoria they are mostly 2.5-5 cm long. The long phyllode variants may resemble A. kettlewelliae but are most readily distinguished by their terete, densely hairy branchlets, densely hairy peduncles and raceme axes, and less prominent glands which are not, or scarcely, swollen within the lamina of the phyllode. Deflexed phyllodes, which occasionally occur in the long phyllode variant, are sometimes also seen in A. boormanii. One specimen from Kybeyan Range has atypically sparsely hairy branchlets (e.g. Wadbilliga fire trail between Tuross River and Bumberry Creek, R.G. Coveny 6604 et al., A n.v., B n.v., BRI n.v., CANB, E n.v., K n.v., L n.v., MEL, NSW, P n.v., RSA n.v., TNS n.v., UC n.v., US n.v., Z n.v.). It appears to approach the short phyllode forms of A. kettlewelliae but is distinguished by the presence of an indumentum and less prominent gland. It is possible that this variant is part of a hybrid swarm between A. kybeanensis and A. kettlewelliae: both putative parents occur in the Kybeyan Range. Usually grows in Eucalyptus woodland or forest on rocky slopes, commonly at c. 1000 m alt.

simplified_phrase: fire avoidance around sandstone pavements in fire-protected areas
fire: in the west kimberley, acacia lentiginea appears to be restricted to the higher rainfall zone, and grows around sandstone pavements in fire-protected sites (r.barrett, pers.
description: shrub to 3.5 m high, erect, spreading, glabrous, resinous. branchlets terete, obscurely ribbed, minutely puncticulate. phyllodes narrowly elliptic, shallowly falcately recurved, 7-10 cm long, 7-10 mm wide, thin, drying brownish, sparsely tuberculate, with numerous subdistant veins; veins 3-6, slightly more pronounced than the intervening venules; anastomoses few or absent; gland 1-2 mm above pulvinus, slightly swollen within lamina; pulvinus circa 1 mm long. inflorescences simple; peduncles 2-3 mm long; spikes 1.5-3 cm long, narrow, pale yellow to ?cream-coloured. flowers 5-merous; sepals free. pods and seeds not seen (see below), recorded as narrow-linear in circagardner 1369. at the time of compiling the flora of australia (maslin 2001) acacia lentiginea was known only from the type and the cunningham specimen cited above. this led maslin (2001: 218) to state "it is curious that a. lentiginea is so poorly known, especially given the considerable collecting that has occurred in the prince regent river area in recent years" and "it is therefore assumed that the species is rare and has very specific habitat requirements". since then, there have been several new collections and observations, and these confirm the rarity of the species. more recent collections of a. lentiginea in the west kimberley indicate a. lentiginea grows in rare habitats in the region (see habitat notes above) which would contribute to the plant being rarely collected (r.barrett, pers. comm., october 2018). if the pods which are described in the protologue of acacia lentiginea in fact belong to this species then they are probably very similar to those of tenuispica. acacia tenuispica differs most obviously from lentiginea in its ribbed, angled branchlets and its shorter, straight phyllodes. in gardner's field book the flowers of lentiginea are described as cream-coloured, and in m.bennett 1833 recorded as pale yellow; in tenuispica the spikes are golden. acacia lentigenea is similar to plectocarpa subsp plectocarpa which is recognised by its hairy ovary and calyx, and transversely wrinkled pulvinus 2-3 mm long (smooth and circa 1 mm long in lentiginea). acacia lentiginea is perhaps related to kimberleyensis. recorded growing between sandstone boulders near a creek, and on a sandstone pavement. in the west kimberley, acacia lentiginea appears to be restricted to the higher rainfall zone, and grows around sandstone pavements in fire-protected sites (r.barrett, pers. comm., october 2018). flowers recorded january, may-june. ;
original_text: Shrub to 3.5 m high, erect, spreading, glabrous, resinous. Branchlets terete, obscurely ribbed, minutely puncticulate. Phyllodes narrowly elliptic, shallowly falcately recurved, 7-10 cm long, 7-10 mm wide, thin, drying brownish, sparsely tuberculate, with numerous subdistant veins; veins 3-6, slightly more pronounced than the intervening venules; anastomoses few or absent; gland 1-2 mm above pulvinus, slightly swollen within lamina; pulvinus c. 1 mm long. Inflorescences simple; peduncles 2-3 mm long; spikes 1.5-3 cm long, narrow, pale yellow to ?cream-coloured. Flowers 5-merous; sepals free. Pods and seeds not seen (see below), recorded as narrow-linear in C.A. Gardner 1369. At the time of compiling the Flora of Australia (Maslin 2001) Acacia lentiginea was known only from the type and the Cunningham specimen cited above. This led Maslin (2001: 218) to state "it is curious that A. lentiginea is so poorly known, especially given the considerable collecting that has occurred in the Prince Regent River area in recent years" and "it is therefore assumed that the species is rare and has very specific habitat requirements". Since then, there have been several new collections and observations, and these confirm the rarity of the species. More recent collections of A. lentiginea in the West Kimberley indicate A. lentiginea grows in rare habitats in the region (see habitat notes above) which would contribute to the plant being rarely collected (R.L. Barrett, pers. comm., October 2018). If the pods which are described in the protologue of Acacia lentiginea in fact belong to this species then they are probably very similar to those of A. tenuispica. Acacia tenuispica differs most obviously from A. lentiginea in its ribbed, angled branchlets and its shorter, straight phyllodes. In Gardner's field book the flowers of A. lentiginea are described as cream-coloured, and in M.D. Bennett 1833 recorded as pale yellow; in A. tenuispica the spikes are golden. Acacia lentigenea is similar to A. plectocarpa subsp. plectocarpa which is recognised by its hairy ovary and calyx, and transversely wrinkled pulvinus 2-3 mm long (smooth and c. 1 mm long in A. lentiginea). Acacia lentiginea is perhaps related to A. kimberleyensis. Recorded growing between sandstone boulders near a creek, and on a sandstone pavement. In the West Kimberley, Acacia lentiginea appears to be restricted to the higher rainfall zone, and grows around sandstone pavements in fire-protected sites (R.L. Barrett, pers. comm., October 2018). Flowers recorded January, May-June.

fire: details of fire tolerance are given by latz, book_source 106 (1995).
description: shrub to 6 m tall, multi-stemmed, spreading, resinous, often viscid. bark 'minni ritchi' type, red-brown. branchlets angular; ridges fawn, appressed-hairy; interstices green, glabrous, lenticellate. stipules triangular, 0.5-2 mm long, persistent. phyllodes linear-obovate, oblique, flat, 1-5 cm long, 1.2-5 (-7) mm wide, with a short apical point, coriaceous, with conspicuous stomata, glabrous or appressed-hairy on nerves and margins, with 2-5 conspicuous raised longitudinal nerves (all confluent and inconspicuous just below apex), with anastomosing nerves obscure on broad phyllodes; gland 1, basal. spikes 0.7-3.7 cm long, golden. flowers 5-merous; calyx 0.3-0.8 mm long, dissected for ½ their length or almost to base, glabrous; corolla 0.9-1.6 mm long, dissected for one third-½ their length, often papillous; ovary hairy. pods slightly or variably more constricted between seeds or straight-sided, straight to strongly curved, flat, 2-10 cm long, 6-9 (-12) mm wide, thinly coriaceous to firmly chartaceous, obliquely reticulate, viscid; margins thick and yellowish. seeds oblique, 4.2-5 mm long, black; areole closed, depressed, surrounded by a conspicuous pale halo. the following specimens are probable lysiphloia x monticola intergrades: sisters plateau, circa 96 km due se of derby, w.a., b.maslin 2671 (mel); 'highland plain', n.t., henry 231 (nsw). acacia monticola is one of the species bridging sections plurinerves and juliflorae. acacia lysiphloia is very closely allied to and rather doubtfully distinct from a chisholmii which may usually be distinguished by the two raised nerves of the narrower phyllodes.  grows in sandy or gravelly soils, often on laterite, on plains or hillsides, frequently along streams, in open mixed eucalypt and acacia woodland, low scrub or spinifex grassland. details on the ecology of acacia lysiphloia are given in l.a.thomson & hall, australian acacias no. 24, csiro division of forestry & forest products (1989). details of fire tolerance are given by latz, book_source 106 (1995). flowers april-september. details of aboriginal use of acacia lysiphloia are given by latz, book_source 106 (1995). ;
original_text: Shrub to 6 m tall, multi-stemmed, spreading, resinous, often viscid. Bark 'Minni Ritchi' type, red-brown. Branchlets angular; ridges fawn, appressed-hairy; interstices green, glabrous, lenticellate. Stipules triangular, 0.5-2 mm long, persistent. Phyllodes linear-obovate, oblique, flat, 1-5 cm long, 1.2-5 (-7) mm wide, with a short apical point, coriaceous, with conspicuous stomata, glabrous or appressed-hairy on nerves and margins, with 2-5 conspicuous raised longitudinal nerves (all confluent and inconspicuous just below apex), with anastomosing nerves obscure on broad phyllodes; gland 1, basal. Spikes 0.7-3.7 cm long, golden. Flowers 5-merous; calyx 0.3-0.8 mm long, dissected for ½ their length or almost to base, glabrous; corolla 0.9-1.6 mm long, dissected for one third-½ their length, often papillous; ovary hairy. Pods slightly or variably more constricted between seeds or straight-sided, straight to strongly curved, flat, 2-10 cm long, 6-9 (-12) mm wide, thinly coriaceous to firmly chartaceous, obliquely reticulate, viscid; margins thick and yellowish. Seeds oblique, 4.2-5 mm long, black; areole closed, depressed, surrounded by a conspicuous pale halo. The following specimens are probable A. lysiphloia x A. monticola intergrades: Sisters Plateau, c. 96 km due SE of Derby, W.A., B.R. Maslin 2671 (MEL); 'Highland Plain', N.T., Henry 231 (NSW). Acacia monticola is one of the species bridging sections Plurinerves and Juliflorae. Acacia lysiphloia is very closely allied to and rather doubtfully distinct from A chisholmii which may usually be distinguished by the two raised nerves of the narrower phyllodes.  Grows in sandy or gravelly soils, often on laterite, on plains or hillsides, frequently along streams, in open mixed eucalypt and Acacia woodland, low scrub or spinifex grassland. Details on the ecology of Acacia lysiphloia are given in L.A.J. Thomson & N. Hall, Australian Acacias no. 24, CSIRO Division of Forestry & Forest Products (1989). Details of fire tolerance are given by P. Latz, Bushfires & Bushtucker 106 (1995). Flowers April-September. Details of Aboriginal use of Acacia lysiphloia are given by P. Latz, Bushfires & Bushtucker 106 (1995).

fire: acacia maitlandii regenerates from a woody root-stock following cool fire but is killed by hot fire.
description: openly branched, erect, normally rather straggly shrub 1-4 m high, becoming rather bushy in well-watered sites. branchlets red to brown, lenticellular, glabrous, resinous-viscid, scarred where phyllodes have fallen. stipules 0.5-1.5 mm long, erect, often enveloped in resin. phyllodes patent to inclined, variable, asymmetrically narrowly elliptic to oblong-elliptic or oblong-obovate, (6-) 7-25 (-30) mm long, (1.5-) 2-4 (-5) mm wide with l: w ratio = 3-10, pungent with a slender cusp, rigid, green, glabrous; midrib prominent, rarely with an obscure second vein, lateral veins obscure or absent; pulvinus 0.5 mm long, yellow. inflorescences simple, 1 per axil; peduncles 1-2 (-2.5) cm long (often exceeding the phyllodes), glabrous; heads globular, circa 9 mm diam. (fresh), densely 50-90-flowered, golden. flowers mostly 5-merous; sepals free, linear-spathulate. pods rounded over and slightly constricted between seeds, 2-7.5 cm long, (3-) 4-5 (-10) mm wide, firmly chartaceous, glabrous, somewhat viscid when young. seeds longitudinal, elliptic to ovate, 3.5-4.5 mm long, dark brown, slightly mottled, cream on periphery and bordering pleurogram, exarillate. acacia maitlandii is related to acacia minutissima, subtiliformis and walkeri; its exarillate seeds and pungent phyllodes suggest affinities with the 'pyrifolia' and 'murrayana' groups. it superficially resembles siculiformis. the species is rather variable in phyllode shape and size. a specimen with atypically broad pods (about 10 mm wide) is recorded for the carnarvon range, western australia (hancock 3, perth). grows in red sand on plains or dunes, or sometimes on rocky slopes, often in mulga scrub, spinifex country or eucalypt open woodland. acacia maitlandii regenerates from a woody root-stock following cool fire but is killed by hot fire. flowers may-september. notes on aboriginal use of acacia maitlandii in central australia are provided by latz, book_source 107 (1995). ;
original_text: Openly branched, erect, normally rather straggly shrub 1-4 m high, becoming rather bushy in well-watered sites. Branchlets red to brown, lenticellular, glabrous, resinous-viscid, scarred where phyllodes have fallen. Stipules 0.5-1.5 mm long, erect, often enveloped in resin. Phyllodes patent to inclined, variable, asymmetrically narrowly elliptic to oblong-elliptic or oblong-obovate, (6-) 7-25 (-30) mm long, (1.5-) 2-4 (-5) mm wide with l: w ratio = 3-10, pungent with a slender cusp, rigid, green, glabrous; midrib prominent, rarely with an obscure second vein, lateral veins obscure or absent; pulvinus 0.5 mm long, yellow. Inflorescences simple, 1 per axil; peduncles 1-2 (-2.5) cm long (often exceeding the phyllodes), glabrous; heads globular, c. 9 mm diam. (fresh), densely 50-90-flowered, golden. Flowers mostly 5-merous; sepals free, linear-spathulate. Pods rounded over and slightly constricted between seeds, 2-7.5 cm long, (3-) 4-5 (-10) mm wide, firmly chartaceous, glabrous, somewhat viscid when young. Seeds longitudinal, elliptic to ovate, 3.5-4.5 mm long, dark brown, slightly mottled, cream on periphery and bordering pleurogram, exarillate. Acacia maitlandii is related to Acacia minutissima, A. subtiliformis and A. walkeri; its exarillate seeds and pungent phyllodes suggest affinities with the 'A. pyrifolia' and 'A. murrayana' groups. It superficially resembles A. siculiformis. The species is rather variable in phyllode shape and size. A specimen with atypically broad pods (about 10 mm wide) is recorded for the Carnarvon Range, Western Australia (M. Hancock 3, PERTH). Grows in red sand on plains or dunes, or sometimes on rocky slopes, often in mulga scrub, spinifex country or eucalypt open woodland. Acacia maitlandii regenerates from a woody root-stock following cool fire but is killed by hot fire. Flowers May-September. Notes on Aboriginal use of Acacia maitlandii in central Australia are provided by P. Latz, Bushfires & Bushtucker 107 (1995).
