original_text: Shrub or tree 2-5 m high, sometimes to 9 m. Branchlets often pruinose, glabrous, sometimes hairy. Stipules spinose, commonly only bases persisting at mature nodes, 2-12 mm long. Phyllodes variable, linear to narrowly oblong, lanceolate or narrowly elliptic, straight or incurved, (1.4-) 2-5 (-10) cm long, 2-8 mm wide, l: w = 2-13 (-25), green to grey-green or glaucous, usually glabrous; midrib prominent; lateral veins usually obscure; gland basal, obscure or prominent. Inflorescences normally racemose but peduncles sometimes subtended by a secondary phyllode; raceme axes 1-10 cm long, slender; peduncles mostly twinned, 6-18 mm long, slender, glabrous, sometimes hairy; heads prolific, globular, 15-30-flowered, creamy white to pale lemon-yellow. Flowers 5-merous; sepals free, narrowly spathulate. Pods narrowly oblong, to 8 cm long, 9-16 mm wide, chartaceous, glabrous. Seeds transverse, globose, 4-6 mm long, brown, mottled blackish; funicle short, thick, scarcely arillate. A variable species. Acacia victoriae subsp. arida and subsp. fasciaria are recognised in some herbaria but are provisionally not recognised here because further study is need to better characterise them and to confirm their taxonomic status. Variation in subsp. arida is discussed by B.R. Maslin, Flora of Australia 11A: 377 (2001), and in that place subsp. fasciaria is represented by long-phyllode individuals cited for the Kimberley region (Western Australia) and Queensland. The taxonomy of the 'A. victoriae group' is discussed in B.R. Maslin, Nuytsia 8: 285-309 (1992) where the above-mentioned subspecies are shown in figs 7K and 7B respectively. In the absence of flowers Acacia victoriae may be confused with A. synchronicia, or when phyllodes are long and linear, with A. alexandri; A. glaucocaesia may ultimately be better placed within A. victoriae. Acacia victoriae is distinguished from A. murrayana by its commonly shorter phyllodes which lack apical glands, spinose stipules, twinned peduncles and mottled seeds. The 'Acacia victoriae group' appears closely related to the 'Acacia pyrifolia group'. Arid and subtropical areas in a variety of habitats but commonly in clay or loam on alluvial flats, and (especially plants identified as subsp. arida) in sand. The ecology of the species is discussed in J.W. Turnbull (ed.), Multipurpose Australian Trees and Shrubs 210-213 (1986), B.R. Maslin & M.W. McDonald, AcaciaSearch: Evaluation of Acacia as a woody crop option for southern Australia, RIRDC Publication No. 30/017, 222-226 (2004) and D.J. Boland et al., Forest Trees of Australia 5th edn, 188-189 (2006). Flowers (July-) August-October (-December). Aboriginal language names and uses of Acacia victoriae in the Northern Territory are included in FloraNT at http://eflora.nt.gov.au/factsheet?id=3576 The plant has been used for food (green pods, mature seeds, gum), spears, weapons, implements, firewood, fish-poisons and traps, shade and shelter (O'Connell et al. 1983, Latz 1995, Maslin et al. 1998).

simplified_phrase: germination is likely stimulated by fire
fire: the germination of soil-stored seed of acacia wollarensis is likely to be stimulated by fire.
description: tree 12-20 m high. bark smooth, greyish, becoming rough, furrowed and brown with age. branchlets terete with broad rounded ridges, densely villous with spreading white hairs (smaller hairs 0.3-0.5 mm long forming a continuous indumentum, with scattered emergent longer hairs 0.7-1.0 mm long). leaves obovate in outline, pale light green on new growth, mid-green when mature, sessile; petiole 0.2-0.4 cm long, densely villous; rachis 5.3-9.5 cm long, prominently and narrowly-ridged above, densely villous with spreading white hairs circa 1 mm long; jugary glands prominently raised, circular to broadly elliptic, 0.6-1 mm diam., at base of upper 1-4 pairs of pinnae and occasionally on lower 1 or 2 pairs; pinnae 10-14 (-16) pairs, 13-61 mm long, lowermost pairs shorter than others, near-uppermost pairs the longest; pinnules 6-26 pairs, oblong-subulate, 3-6 mm long, 1-1.7 mm wide, dark green above, paler green below, setose with scattered white bristles to 0.5 mm on upper side, confined to margins and midvein below, margin recurved, apex obtuse to subacute. inflorescences in terminal and axillary racemes and panicles. peduncles 4.5-6.5 mm long, white appressed-pubescent. heads globose, circa 24-31-flowered, circa 4-6 mm diam. (when dry), golden yellow. pods straight to slightly curved, moniliform, margin moderately and  regularly constricted between seeds, distinctly raised over seeds, 9-13.5 cm long, 7-9 mm wide, coriaceous, green becoming light to dark brown at maturity, with fine raised and reticulate lateral veins, scattered white setose with hairs to 0.6 mm long. grows in sheltered gullies or on mid to lower slopes, at the interface of triassic narrabeen sandstones and permian claystones and shales. sometimes forms a dense sub-canopy below eucalyptus punctata and sparsifolia. for more details see bell & driscoll (2017). the germination of soil-stored seed of acacia wollarensis is likely to be stimulated by fire. details on the ecology, habitat, population size and conservation status of a. wollarensis is provided by bell & driscoll (2017). flowers recorded in september; pods with mature seed collected december-january. ;
original_text: Tree 12-20 m high. Bark smooth, greyish, becoming rough, furrowed and brown with age. Branchlets terete with broad rounded ridges, densely villous with spreading white hairs (smaller hairs 0.3-0.5 mm long forming a continuous indumentum, with scattered emergent longer hairs 0.7-1.0 mm long). Leaves obovate in outline, pale light green on new growth, mid-green when mature, sessile; petiole 0.2-0.4 cm long, densely villous; rachis 5.3-9.5 cm long, prominently and narrowly-ridged above, densely villous with spreading white hairs c. 1 mm long; jugary glands prominently raised, circular to broadly elliptic, 0.6-1 mm diam., at base of upper 1-4 pairs of pinnae and occasionally on lower 1 or 2 pairs; pinnae 10-14 (-16) pairs, 13-61 mm long, lowermost pairs shorter than others, near-uppermost pairs the longest; pinnules 6-26 pairs, oblong-subulate, 3-6 mm long, 1-1.7 mm wide, dark green above, paler green below, setose with scattered white bristles to 0.5 mm on upper side, confined to margins and midvein below, margin recurved, apex obtuse to subacute. Inflorescences in terminal and axillary racemes and panicles. Peduncles 4.5-6.5 mm long, white appressed-pubescent. Heads globose, c. 24-31-flowered, c. 4-6 mm diam. (when dry), golden yellow. Pods straight to slightly curved, moniliform, margin moderately and  regularly constricted between seeds, distinctly raised over seeds, 9-13.5 cm long, 7-9 mm wide, coriaceous, green becoming light to dark brown at maturity, with fine raised and reticulate lateral veins, scattered white setose with hairs to 0.6 mm long. Grows in sheltered gullies or on mid to lower slopes, at the interface of Triassic Narrabeen sandstones and Permian claystones and shales. Sometimes forms a dense sub-canopy below Eucalyptus punctata and E. sparsifolia. For more details see Bell & Driscoll (2017). The germination of soil-stored seed of Acacia wollarensis is likely to be stimulated by fire. Details on the ecology, habitat, population size and conservation status of A. wollarensis is provided by Bell & Driscoll (2017). Flowers recorded in September; pods with mature seed collected December-January.

simplified_phrase: coppices from base and resprouts epicormically after cool fires
fire: "a slow-growing, long-lived plant that regenerates from seed and apparently does not produce root suckers. it does, however, have moderate coppicing ability when cut or damaged (e g by cool fire) at ground level; it will also reshoot from the terminal branches following cool fires. the plants are readily killed by hot, or even moderately hot, fires." b.maslin et al., wattles of the pilbara (2010).
description: shrub or tree 3-7 m high, often gnarled, bushy, main branches often rather contorted and widely spreading. branchlets glabrous or sparingly appressed-puberulous. phyllodes ascending, elliptic or ligulate, tapering to acute or acuminate apex and long-attenuate base, straight to slightly curved, 5-12.5 cm long, 3.5-16 mm wide, rigid, glaucous, sericeous, glabrescent, with numerous very obscure closely parallel veins; central vein sometimes slightly raised. inflorescences rudimentary 1- or 2-headed racemes with axes circa 0.2 mm long, often growing out; peduncles 7.5-15 mm long, appressed-puberulous; spikes 2.5-5.5 cm long, 5-7 mm diam., loosely flowered, light golden; receptacle appressed-hairy. flowers mostly 5-merous; sepals 1/4-1/3 length of petals, united, often golden-puberulous. pods pendent, linear, raised over and sometimes constricted between seeds, straight to slightly curved, 8-20 cm long, 7-18 mm wide, crustaceous-woody, irregularly coarsely reticulate, glabrous, shining. seeds longitudinal, broadly elliptic, 6-10 mm long, peripherally crested, dull, brown; aril/funicle fleshy. superficially similar to the flat phyllode variant of acacia intorta; and to eremaea (sect. plurinerve). perhaps related to hamersleyensis which is most readily distinguished by its more obvious phyllode nerves, denser spikes, more deeply divided, white-villous calyx and pilose pods. grows on sometimes subsaline clay flats, stony plains and hills, in acacia shrubland and low woodland, dominating in localised areas. "a slow-growing, long-lived plant that regenerates from seed and apparently does not produce root suckers. it does, however, have moderate coppicing ability when cut or damaged (e g by cool fire) at ground level; it will also reshoot from the terminal branches following cool fires. the plants are readily killed by hot, or even moderately hot, fires." b.maslin et al., wattles of the pilbara (2010). further details of ecology, utilisation, etc. of xiphophylla are given in j.turnbull (ed.), multipurpose australian trees and shrubs 214-215 (1986), b.maslin et al., wattles of the pilbara (2010) and references therein. flowers quickly and opportunistically in response to rain. flowering specimens have been collected in january, march-may and august-september. indigenous peoples of the pilbara used xiphophylla in a number of ways; see b.maslin et al., wattles of the pilbara (2010) for details. ;
original_text: Shrub or tree 3-7 m high, often gnarled, bushy, main branches often rather contorted and widely spreading. Branchlets glabrous or sparingly appressed-puberulous. Phyllodes ascending, elliptic or ligulate, tapering to acute or acuminate apex and long-attenuate base, straight to slightly curved, 5-12.5 cm long, 3.5-16 mm wide, rigid, glaucous, sericeous, glabrescent, with numerous very obscure closely parallel veins; central vein sometimes slightly raised. Inflorescences rudimentary 1- or 2-headed racemes with axes c. 0.2 mm long, often growing out; peduncles 7.5-15 mm long, appressed-puberulous; spikes 2.5-5.5 cm long, 5-7 mm diam., loosely flowered, light golden; receptacle appressed-hairy. Flowers mostly 5-merous; sepals 1/4-1/3 length of petals, united, often golden-puberulous. Pods pendent, linear, raised over and sometimes constricted between seeds, straight to slightly curved, 8-20 cm long, 7-18 mm wide, crustaceous-woody, irregularly coarsely reticulate, glabrous, shining. Seeds longitudinal, broadly elliptic, 6-10 mm long, peripherally crested, dull, brown; aril/funicle fleshy. Superficially similar to the flat phyllode variant of Acacia intorta; and to A. eremaea (sect. Plurinerve). Perhaps related to A. hamersleyensis which is most readily distinguished by its more obvious phyllode nerves, denser spikes, more deeply divided, white-villous calyx and pilose pods. Grows on sometimes subsaline clay flats, stony plains and hills, in Acacia shrubland and low woodland, dominating in localised areas. "A slow-growing, long-lived plant that regenerates from seed and apparently does not produce root suckers. It does, however, have moderate coppicing ability when cut or damaged (e.g. by cool fire) at ground level; it will also reshoot from the terminal branches following cool fires. The plants are readily killed by hot, or even moderately hot, fires." B.R. Maslin et al., Wattles of the Pilbara (2010). Further details of ecology, utilisation, etc. of A. xiphophylla are given in J.W. Turnbull (ed.), Multipurpose Australian Trees and Shrubs 214-215 (1986), B.R. Maslin et al., Wattles of the Pilbara (2010) and references therein. Flowers quickly and opportunistically in response to rain. Flowering specimens have been collected in January, March-May and August-September. Indigenous peoples of the Pilbara used A. xiphophylla in a number of ways; see B.R. Maslin et al., Wattles of the Pilbara (2010) for details.

simplified_phrase: killed by moderate to hot fires; regenerates from seed after fire
fire: "a slow-growing, long-lived plant that regenerates from seed and apparently does not produce root suckers. it does, however, have moderate coppicing ability when cut or damaged (e g by cool fire) at ground level; it will also reshoot from the terminal branches following cool fires. the plants are readily killed by hot, or even moderately hot, fires." b.maslin et al., wattles of the pilbara (2010).

fire: recorded from cleared and mown firebreak on edge of wet sclerophyll forest, weedy eucalypt woodland, roadsides.
description: wide-crowned, shrub or deciduous tree to circa 7 m high; andromonoecious. leaves: lamina palmately 5 (7-11)-lobed, 5-10 cm long and wide, nearly truncate at base, virtually glabrous, usually with a tuft of short hairs near the attachment of the petiole; lobes typically divided to within circa 1 cm of petiole, occasionally completely divided, margins irregularly serrate; petiole 15-35 mm long. flowers in short, semi-pendent, terminal racemes to circa 4 cm long, appearing with or before leaves; pedicels slender, 3-6 mm long; sepals narrowly obovate, circa 3 mm long, purplish red; petals broadly obovate, shorter than sepals, pale yellowish or tinged pink; nectary disc annular; stamens 8, circa 4 mm long in male flowers, shorter in female flowers, inserted within disc; ovary glabrous. samaras circa 1.5 cm long, the seed compartment broadly ellipsoid, circa 4 mm long, wings spreading at an obtuse angle.  recorded from cleared and mown firebreak on edge of wet sclerophyll forest, weedy eucalypt woodland, roadsides. ;
original_text: Wide-crowned, shrub or deciduous tree to c. 7 m high; andromonoecious. Leaves: lamina palmately 5 (7-11)-lobed, 5-10 cm long and wide, nearly truncate at base, virtually glabrous, usually with a tuft of short hairs near the attachment of the petiole; lobes typically divided to within c. 1 cm of petiole, occasionally completely divided, margins irregularly serrate; petiole 15-35 mm long. Flowers in short, semi-pendent, terminal racemes to c. 4 cm long, appearing with or before leaves; pedicels slender, 3-6 mm long; sepals narrowly obovate, c. 3 mm long, purplish red; petals broadly obovate, shorter than sepals, pale yellowish or tinged pink; nectary disc annular; stamens 8, c. 4 mm long in male flowers, shorter in female flowers, inserted within disc; ovary glabrous. Samaras c. 1.5 cm long, the seed compartment broadly ellipsoid, c. 4 mm long, wings spreading at an obtuse angle.  Recorded from cleared and mown firebreak on edge of wet sclerophyll forest, weedy eucalypt woodland, roadsides.

simplified_phrase: inconclusive genus-level observation; inhibited by hot summer fires, taking years to recover and flower
fire: most acianthus species are inhibited by hot summer fires, taking years to recover and flower.
description: deciduous, terrestrial orchids forming spreading, clonal colonies that are sometimes dense and often have a low proportion of plants flowering. leaf single, held horizontally above ground-level on a fleshy stalk, heart-shaped, under-surface purplish red (sometimes green). racemes erect, multiflowered; peduncle longer than rachis, fleshy. flowers resupinate, small, pinkish, greenish or purplish, resembling tiny insects. sepals free, larger than petals; apex with thin cylindrical osmophore (club). dorsal sepal larger than lateral sepals; cucullate over column, or spreading. lateral sepals porrect beneath labellum. petals free, small, spreading or reflexed against ovary. labellum attached by base to column base. labellum lamina unlobed, porrect, base with shallow b area, margin finely toothed. callus dominating labellum: large, fleshy with central channel and two prostrate, to glands at base. column curved, slender, wingless. anther with 8 pollinia in two pairs of four, each unit of four attached to viscidium.  these orchids grow in sheltered areas of moist to wet forest and heathland in freely draining soil; often under cover of shrubs and bracken. dormant tubers survive through late spring and summer and sprout in autumn to winter; the plants flowering autumn, winter and spring. leaves increase in size after emergence and also after flowering. buds and flowers often abort after hot or dry conditions. the parent tuber dies after a single growing season. replacement tubers are produced annually, and vegetative reproduction is by daughter tubers on stolonoid roots. most acianthus species are inhibited by hot summer fires, taking years to recover and flower. autumn and winter burns can have a disastrous impact on the survival of these orchids and their pollinators. nectar, which is produced from labellum glands, gathers in labellum basin and along callus channel. pollination is by small gnats in families mycetophilidae and sciaridae that are attracted to the nectar (jones 1974, kuiter 2013, kuiter & findlater-smith 2017). both sexes feed on the nectar, but pollination is mainly achieved by the larger females. natural hybridisation is very rare in the genus. acianthus exiguus is self-pollinating, and self-pollinating variants of acianthus caudatus are known. ;
original_text: Deciduous, terrestrial orchids forming spreading, clonal colonies that are sometimes dense and often have a low proportion of plants flowering. Leaf single, held horizontally above ground-level on a fleshy stalk, heart-shaped, under-surface purplish red (sometimes green). Racemes erect, multiflowered; peduncle longer than rachis, fleshy. Flowers resupinate, small, pinkish, greenish or purplish, resembling tiny insects. Sepals free, larger than petals; apex with thin cylindrical osmophore (club). Dorsal sepal larger than lateral sepals; cucullate over column, or spreading. Lateral sepals porrect beneath labellum. Petals free, small, spreading or reflexed against ovary. Labellum attached by base to column base. Labellum lamina unlobed, porrect, base with shallow basin-like area, margin finely toothed. Callus dominating labellum: large, fleshy with central channel and two prostrate, tonsil-like glands at base. Column curved, slender, wingless. Anther with 8 pollinia in two pairs of four, each unit of four attached to viscidium.  These orchids grow in sheltered areas of moist to wet forest and heathland in freely draining soil; often under cover of shrubs and bracken. Dormant tubers survive through late spring and summer and sprout in autumn to winter; the plants flowering autumn, winter and spring. Leaves increase in size after emergence and also after flowering. Buds and flowers often abort after hot or dry conditions. The parent tuber dies after a single growing season. Replacement tubers are produced annually, and vegetative reproduction is by daughter tubers on stolonoid roots. Most Acianthus species are inhibited by hot summer fires, taking years to recover and flower. Autumn and winter burns can have a disastrous impact on the survival of these orchids and their pollinators. Nectar, which is produced from labellum glands, gathers in labellum basin and along callus channel. Pollination is by small gnats in families Mycetophilidae and Sciaridae that are attracted to the nectar (Jones 1974, Kuiter 2013, Kuiter & Findlater-Smith 2017). Both sexes feed on the nectar, but pollination is mainly achieved by the larger females. Natural hybridisation is very rare in the genus. Acianthus exiguus is self-pollinating, and self-pollinating variants of Acianthus caudatus are known.

fire: flowering is enhanced by bushfires.
description: plants forming sparse to dense and often extensive vegetative colonies. leaf heart-shaped, 10-30 x 5-20 mm, dark green above, purple beneath, held 10-30 mm above soil level on a fleshy stalk. flower stem 50-250 mm long, dark brown, 1-9-flowered. flowers circa 40 x 4 mm, dark reddish purple (rarely green), strongly odorous. dorsal sepal and lateral sepals broadest near base (1-1.5 mm wide) then long and th; dorsal sepal 35-40 mm long; lateral sepals 15-20 mm long. petals narrowly ovate, circa 4 x 1 mm, spreading or reflexed. labellum wedge-shaped when flattened, broadest near base then tapered to an acuminate apex, 5-6 x 3.5-4.5 mm, concave in basal third with incurved margins, apex flat, densely papillate, curved downwards or recurved. callus consisting of a narrow central longitudinal channel flanked by papillae, with two erect basal glands circa 1 mm long. flowers have a strong smell that is noticeable on warm days; described by some as a rotten smell, by others as warm, musky, or like a wet dog. widespread and common from the coast to the mountains in small to extensive colonies; growing among shrubs and bracken on slopes and flats in coastal scrub, heathland and heathy forest in freely draining sands; and in open forest and woodland in clay loams. colonises exotic pine plantations in sw vic. and s.an unusual, autumn-flowering (april-may) population occurs at 900 m elevation in washpool national park, northern n.s.(lachlan copeland, pers. comm.). flowering is enhanced by bushfires. cross-pollinated by male and female fungus gnats (family mycetophilidae) (jones 1974) but self-pollinated populations also occur. flowers april-october. ;
original_text: Plants forming sparse to dense and often extensive vegetative colonies. Leaf heart-shaped, 10-30 x 5-20 mm, dark green above, purple beneath, held 10-30 mm above soil level on a fleshy stalk. Flower stem 50-250 mm long, dark brown, 1-9-flowered. Flowers c. 40 x 4 mm, dark reddish purple (rarely green), strongly odorous. Dorsal sepal and lateral sepals broadest near base (1-1.5 mm wide) then long and thread-like; dorsal sepal 35-40 mm long; lateral sepals 15-20 mm long. Petals narrowly ovate, c. 4 x 1 mm, spreading or reflexed. Labellum wedge-shaped when flattened, broadest near base then tapered to an acuminate apex, 5-6 x 3.5-4.5 mm, concave in basal third with incurved margins, apex flat, densely papillate, curved downwards or recurved. Callus consisting of a narrow central longitudinal channel flanked by papillae, with two erect basal glands c. 1 mm long. Flowers have a strong smell that is noticeable on warm days; described by some as a rotten smell, by others as warm, musky, or like a wet dog. Widespread and common from the coast to the mountains in small to extensive colonies; growing among shrubs and bracken on slopes and flats in coastal scrub, heathland and heathy forest in freely draining sands; and in open forest and woodland in clay loams. Colonises exotic pine plantations in SW Vic. and S.A. An unusual, autumn-flowering (April-May) population occurs at 900 m elevation in Washpool National Park, northern N.S.W. (Lachlan Copeland, pers. comm.). Flowering is enhanced by bushfires. Cross-pollinated by male and female fungus gnats (family Mycetophilidae) (Jones 1974) but self-pollinated populations also occur. Flowers April-October.

fire: flowering is sometimes increased following a summer fire.
description: leaf cordate, 12-32 x 10-30 mm, dark green above, purplish or green beneath. flower stem 30-180 mm long, pinkish, 1-18-flowered. flowers 8-12 mm long, often crowded, translucent green or pinkish with a green to reddish labellum and callus. dorsal sepal obovate, 6-8.5 x 2-5 mm, held away from column, tip terete, 1-2.5 mm long. lateral sepals 6-8 x 0.8 mm, parallel or crossed; clubs terete, 1-2 mm long. petals 2.5-3 x 1 mm, reflexed against ovary. labellum cordate when flattened, 4-4.5 x 2-3 mm, margins recurved, not toothed. callus fleshy, papillate near apex; glands circa 0.8 mm long, comma-shaped. colonies with green or reddish flowers are sometimes seen. widespread and common from the coast to the ranges; growing on slopes, flats, ridges and among rocks in a wide range of relatively dry to wet, forested and heathy habitats including coastal scrub, littoral rainforest, heath, mallee shrubland, tea-tree thickets, open forest and woodland in freely draining sands, clay loams and loams. colonies can be extensive, but usually with a low proportion of flowering plants. flowering is sometimes increased following a summer fire. flowers march-august. ;
original_text: Leaf cordate, 12-32 x 10-30 mm, dark green above, purplish or green beneath. Flower stem 30-180 mm long, pinkish, 1-18-flowered. Flowers 8-12 mm long, often crowded, translucent green or pinkish with a green to reddish labellum and callus. Dorsal sepal obovate, 6-8.5 x 2-5 mm, held away from column, tip terete, 1-2.5 mm long. Lateral sepals 6-8 x 0.8 mm, parallel or crossed; clubs terete, 1-2 mm long. Petals 2.5-3 x 1 mm, reflexed against ovary. Labellum cordate when flattened, 4-4.5 x 2-3 mm, margins recurved, not toothed. Callus fleshy, papillate near apex; glands c. 0.8 mm long, comma-shaped. Colonies with green or reddish flowers are sometimes seen. Widespread and common from the coast to the ranges; growing on slopes, flats, ridges and among rocks in a wide range of relatively dry to wet, forested and heathy habitats including coastal scrub, littoral rainforest, heath, mallee shrubland, tea-tree thickets, open forest and woodland in freely draining sands, clay loams and loams. Colonies can be extensive, but usually with a low proportion of flowering plants. Flowering is sometimes increased following a summer fire. Flowers March-August.

fire: all species regenerate after fire by resprouting, some also show regeneration by seed (meney et al.
description: herbs, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial; male plants with fertile and vegetative culms; female plants with vegetative culms and with spikelets terminating short stout subterranean stems. rhizomes long, slender, glabrous, covered with glossy scales. culms mostly widely separated on the rhizomes, glabrous or pubescent, striate, with short flattened lateral branches or terete and repeatedly branched; aerial stems all vegetative in females; the lowest internode similar to upper internodes or elongated and slender. sheaths persistent, appressed, mucronate. male spikelets solitary and terminal on culm branches, or many pedunculate spikelets in a slender inflorescence taller than the vegetative culms; with several or many flowers and often several sterile glumes. female spikelets solitary, sessile on the rhizomes, so that the flowers and fruits are largely below ground, with only the long style, stigmas and tips of cataphylls above ground level; mostly 1-flowered, rarely 2-flowered, with many surrounding glossy bracts and a dense ring of long hairs between the bracts and tepals. flowers with 6 hyaline tepals. male flowers with 2 keeled outer tepals; stamens 3; anthers exserted. female flowers with 1-locular ovary; style united in lower part but with 3 long red or purple stigmatic branches. fruit a large (10-15 mm long), globular or obconical glossy nut, maturing below ground level. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2 or 3 layers of short peg-cells; chlorenchyma continuous in the lower part of the basal internode, interrupted by girders in the upper part of the basal internode, with elongated peg-cells and pillar cells in the upper culm branches; central ground tissue sclerenchymatous; central cavity absent. the male spikelets and flowers, and the culm anatomy (except the base of the lowest internode), resemble those of chordifex but the female spikelets and flowers are highly distinctive, although rarely observed. the difference between floriferous and vegetative male culms is most apparent in alexgeorgea ganopoda. culm anatomy: peg-cells are pali chlorenchyma cells with peg-like outgrowths; pillar-cells are elongated cells extending from the parenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma (cutler 1969). plants are commonly infected with smut fungus (tolyposporium restionum) and infected male plants produce galled spikelets with enlarged pistillodes that resemble capsules but are indehiscent (sieler et al. 1999). those of alexgeorgea nitens were wrongly described (nees 1846: 59) as female spikelets. well-drained sites in mesic and seasonally dry regions; in sandy soils. wind-pollinated. all species regenerate after fire by resprouting, some also show regeneration by seed (meney et al. 1990a, b). roots strongly sand-binding; apogeotrophic roots also present in alexgeorgea ganopoda. ;
original_text: Herbs, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial; male plants with fertile and vegetative culms; female plants with vegetative culms and with spikelets terminating short stout subterranean stems. Rhizomes long, slender, glabrous, covered with glossy scales. Culms mostly widely separated on the rhizomes, glabrous or pubescent, striate, with short flattened lateral branches or terete and repeatedly branched; aerial stems all vegetative in females; the lowest internode similar to upper internodes or elongated and slender. Sheaths persistent, appressed, mucronate. Male spikelets solitary and terminal on culm branches, or many pedunculate spikelets in a slender inflorescence taller than the vegetative culms; with several or many flowers and often several sterile glumes. Female spikelets solitary, sessile on the rhizomes, so that the flowers and fruits are largely below ground, with only the long style, stigmas and tips of cataphylls above ground level; mostly 1-flowered, rarely 2-flowered, with many surrounding glossy bracts and a dense ring of long hairs between the bracts and tepals. Flowers with 6 hyaline tepals. Male flowers with 2 keeled outer tepals; stamens 3; anthers exserted. Female flowers with 1-locular ovary; style united in lower part but with 3 long red or purple stigmatic branches. Fruit a large (10-15 mm long), globular or obconical glossy nut, maturing below ground level. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2 or 3 layers of short peg-cells; chlorenchyma continuous in the lower part of the basal internode, interrupted by girders in the upper part of the basal internode, with elongated peg-cells and pillar cells in the upper culm branches; central ground tissue sclerenchymatous; central cavity absent. The male spikelets and flowers, and the culm anatomy (except the base of the lowest internode), resemble those of Chordifex but the female spikelets and flowers are highly distinctive, although rarely observed. The difference between floriferous and vegetative male culms is most apparent in Alexgeorgea ganopoda. Culm anatomy: peg-cells are palisade-like chlorenchyma cells with peg-like outgrowths; pillar-cells are elongated cells extending from the parenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma (Cutler 1969). Plants are commonly infected with smut fungus (Tolyposporium restionum) and infected male plants produce galled spikelets with enlarged pistillodes that resemble capsules but are indehiscent (Sieler et al. 1999). Those of Alexgeorgea nitens were wrongly described (Nees 1846: 59) as female spikelets. Well-drained sites in mesic and seasonally dry regions; in sandy soils. Wind-pollinated. All species regenerate after fire by resprouting, some also show regeneration by seed (Meney et al. 1990a, b). Roots strongly sand-binding; apogeotrophic roots also present in Alexgeorgea ganopoda.

fire: regenerates after fire by resprouting.
description: herb, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial; males with similar fertile and vegetative culms; females with vegetative culms but spikelets subterranean. rhizome to 40 cm long or more, 1-4 mm diam.; scales glossy dark brown to chestnut, lanceolate, usually shortly fimbriate. culms dimorphic; vegetative culms much-branched, 10-50 cm high, to 2 mm diam. at base, circa 0.5 mm diam. towards apex, terete to compressed, striate, glabrous, green to yellow-green; internodes numerous, to circa 4 cm long; floriferous culms few on male plants, mostly unbranched below the inflorescence, erect, 30-50 cm long, 1.0-1.5 mm diam. at mid-culm, terete to compressed, striate, glabrous, with several internodes each to circa 10 cm long. sheaths 1-2 cm long, appressed, light brown to straw-coloured; apex acute with a 1-2 mm long blunt lamina; sheaths on branches circa 2-5 mm long, appressed, green to light brown, glabrous, apex obtuse to acute with a blunt lamina circa 1 mm long. male spikelets in a narrow inflorescence 20-35 cm long; original_text: Herb, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial; males with similar fertile and vegetative culms; females with vegetative culms but spikelets subterranean. Rhizome to 40 cm long or more, 1-4 mm diam.; scales glossy dark brown to chestnut, lanceolate, usually shortly fimbriate. Culms dimorphic; vegetative culms much-branched, 10-50 cm high, to 2 mm diam. at base, c. 0.5 mm diam. towards apex, terete to compressed, striate, glabrous, green to yellow-green; internodes numerous, to c. 4 cm long; floriferous culms few on male plants, mostly unbranched below the inflorescence, erect, 30-50 cm long, 1.0-1.5 mm diam. at mid-culm, terete to compressed, striate, glabrous, with several internodes each to c. 10 cm long. Sheaths 1-2 cm long, appressed, light brown to straw-coloured; apex acute with a 1-2 mm long blunt lamina; sheaths on branches c. 2-5 mm long, appressed, green to light brown, glabrous, apex obtuse to acute with a blunt lamina c. 1 mm long. Male spikelets in a narrow inflorescence 20-35 cm long; terminal on filiform pedicels to 2 cm long, ovoid, c. 5 mm long, c. 3 mm wide. Male glumes c. 15-20, all fertile, ovate to rhomboid, concave, straw-coloured, glabrous, 1.7-2.7 mm long; apex acuminate; mucro 0.5-0.7 mm long. Female spikelets solitary, sessile on short subterranean branches, with only the long style, stigmas, and tips of cataphylls above ground; fruit maturing below ground. Male flowers: tepals 1.5-2.0 mm long, oblanceolate, thin, pale, hyaline; inner tepals mucronate; filaments 2.5-3.1 mm long; anthers c. 1.2 mm long. Female flowers enclosed by glossy, brown bracts; between bracts and tepals are dense, long (5-10 mm), coarse ginger-brown hairs; tepals hyaline, narrowly deltoid, acute; style emergent, basally connate with 3 stigmatic branches. Fruit globular, dark brown or black, 10-11 mm diam. Female spikelets with at least 2 flowers observed (pers. comm. E. Sandiford). Heath and sandplain or openings in Eucalyptus marginata - Corymbia calophylla forest. Regenerates after fire by resprouting. Extensive areas at some sites, 5-15 m across, are either male or female and are thought to be single clones. Roots strongly sand-binding; dimorphic; deeply penetrating roots and apogeotrophic roots present. Flowers spring, summer; November-January, April (Hollister & Thiele 2014).

fire: regenerates after fire by resprouting.
description: herb, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial; males with similar fertile and vegetative culms; females with aerial vegetative culms but spikelets subterranean. rhizome to 40 cm long or more, 1-3 mm diam.; scales scarious, glossy, shortly ciliate, chestnut-coloured. cataphylls to 8 cm long, glossy-brown. culms usually spaced up to 30 cm apart on rhizome, 10-30 cm long, erect, slender, 0.5-1.3 mm diam., + terete, smooth to rugose or striate, brown, pilose with short white hairs; the first internode (2.5-) 7-15 cm long; much branched above the first internode; upper branches 1.0-1.5 mm diam., terete to compressed, flexuose or curled, striate, glabrous, grey- to yellow-green; internodes numerous, 0.5-2.0 mm long; barren branches terminating in a minute mucro. sheaths appressed, 3-8 mm long, rigid, red-brown, becoming brown; apex obtuse to truncate with a minute lamina 0.2-0.7 (-5.0) mm long. male spikelets on short, flexuose branches; the spikelets solitary and terminal or axillary, ovoid, 3.5-6 mm long, 1-3 mm wide. male glumes circa 3 sterile lower and 6-13 fertile upper, lanceolate, (1.3-) 1.8-2.2 mm long; mucro (0.6-) 1.6-2.5 mm long; the apical margins fringed with very short white hairs. female spikelets solitary, sessile on short subterranean branches, largely below ground; only the style, stigmas, and tips of cataphylls above ground level; fruit maturing below ground. male flowers: tepals brown, 1.6-2.0 mm long; filaments 1.9-2.7 mm long, stout; anthers circa 0.9-1.4 mm long. female flower enclosed by numerous glossy bracts; bracts 2-80 mm long; long inner bracts convolute around the emergent style; tepals oblong-lanceolate, 15-20 mm long; between bracts and tepals are dense, silky, long (8-12 mm) white hairs. fruit circa 15 mm long, circa 8 mm diam., conical, glossy-black, striate. seed smooth, brown, globose or pyriform, circa 10 mm long. plants are commonly infected by smut fungus and male plants produce galled, smut-affected spikelets 5-8 mm long, 4-7 mm wide, with the pistillodes developed into indehiscent, brown-black, conical to obpyriform structures circa 4 mm long and resembling a 2- or 3-locular capsule, the locules filled with black smut spores. these galled spikelets were wrongly described as female spikelets in the species protologue. the type of alexgeorgea nitens (preiss 1696) is part of the type material of the fungus tolyposporium restionum (sieler et al. 1999). heath and open woodland, in sandy soil. regenerates after fire by resprouting. roots strongly sand-binding. flowers autumn (meney et al. 1990); april-june (hollister & thiele 2014). phenology of growth has been studied (meney et al. 1990). ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial; males with similar fertile and vegetative culms; females with aerial vegetative culms but spikelets subterranean. Rhizome to 40 cm long or more, 1-3 mm diam.; scales scarious, glossy, shortly ciliate, chestnut-coloured. Cataphylls to 8 cm long, glossy-brown. Culms usually spaced up to 30 cm apart on rhizome, 10-30 cm long, erect, slender, 0.5-1.3 mm diam., + terete, smooth to rugose or striate, brown, pilose with short white hairs; the first internode (2.5-) 7-15 cm long; much branched above the first internode; upper branches 1.0-1.5 mm diam., terete to compressed, flexuose or curled, striate, glabrous, grey- to yellow-green; internodes numerous, 0.5-2.0 mm long; barren branches terminating in a minute mucro. Sheaths appressed, 3-8 mm long, rigid, red-brown, becoming brown; apex obtuse to truncate with a minute lamina 0.2-0.7 (-5.0) mm long. Male spikelets on short, flexuose branches; the spikelets solitary and terminal or axillary, ovoid, 3.5-6 mm long, 1-3 mm wide. Male glumes c. 3 sterile lower and 6-13 fertile upper, lanceolate, (1.3-) 1.8-2.2 mm long; mucro (0.6-) 1.6-2.5 mm long; the apical margins fringed with very short white hairs. Female spikelets solitary, sessile on short subterranean branches, largely below ground; only the style, stigmas, and tips of cataphylls above ground level; fruit maturing below ground. Male flowers: tepals brown, 1.6-2.0 mm long; filaments 1.9-2.7 mm long, stout; anthers c. 0.9-1.4 mm long. Female flower enclosed by numerous glossy bracts; bracts 2-80 mm long; long inner bracts convolute around the emergent style; tepals oblong-lanceolate, 15-20 mm long; between bracts and tepals are dense, silky, long (8-12 mm) white hairs. Fruit c. 15 mm long, c. 8 mm diam., conical, glossy-black, striate. Seed smooth, brown, globose or pyriform, c. 10 mm long. Plants are commonly infected by smut fungus and male plants produce galled, smut-affected spikelets 5-8 mm long, 4-7 mm wide, with the pistillodes developed into indehiscent, brown-black, conical to obpyriform structures c. 4 mm long and resembling a 2- or 3-locular capsule, the locules filled with black smut spores. These galled spikelets were wrongly described as female spikelets in the species protologue. The type of Alexgeorgea nitens (Preiss 1696) is part of the type material of the fungus Tolyposporium restionum (Sieler et al. 1999). Heath and open woodland, in sandy soil. Regenerates after fire by resprouting. Roots strongly sand-binding. Flowers autumn (Meney et al. 1990); April-June (Hollister & Thiele 2014). Phenology of growth has been studied (Meney et al. 1990).

description: herb, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial; males with similar fertile and vegetative culms; females with aerial vegetative culms but spikelets subterranean. rhizome to 30 cm long, 0.5-2.0 mm diam.; branched above the 1st internode; branches 1.5-2.0 mm diam., erect or curved, compressed to subterete with a longitudinal furrow, striate, glabrous, green; branchlets 1-4 cm long, 1.5-2 mm wide, often several arising from each culm sheath axil, not repeatedly branched, often prominently mucronate; the mucro 1-4 mm long. sheaths appressed, 5-12 mm long, rigid, brown, acute to less often truncate, with a short erect lamina, fringed with white hairs circa 1 mm long. male spikelets solitary, terminal, ovoid, 6-12 mm long, 4-9 mm wide; glumes circa 8 sterile lower and to 50 fertile upper, lanceolate, 2.5-3.0 mm long, mucronate. female spikelets solitary, sessile on rhizome branches. male flowers: tepals brown-hyaline, 2.5-2.7 mm long; filaments 3.0-3.2 mm long, slender; anthers 1.0-1.2 mm long. female flowers with only the style, stigmas and cataphyll tips above ground; fruit maturing below ground; flower enclosed by numerous glossy, pale or chestnut bracts 1-8 cm long; between bracts and tepals are dense, silky, long (8-10 mm) white hairs. female flowers: tepals 6, hyaline, oblong-lanceolate; apex acute, fimbriate, 3-10 mm long; ovary 1-locular but 3-angular, brown; style emergent, 8-11 cm long, basally terete for 4-7 cm; branches 3, 4-6 cm long, mostly exerted from the enclosing bracts. fruit obpyriform, brown or black, circa 15 mm long, circa 9 mm diam. plants are commonly infected by tolyposporium restionum smut fungus and male plants produce galled, smut-affected spikelets (sieler et al. 1999). kwongan vegetation; original_text: Herb, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial; males with similar fertile and vegetative culms; females with aerial vegetative culms but spikelets subterranean. Rhizome to 30 cm long, 0.5-2.0 mm diam.; scales lanceolate, scarious, pale to chestnut, shortly ciliate. Cataphylls to 6 cm long, glossy, pale to chestnut, lanceolate, apex with white hairs. Culms 8-30 cm long, usually spaced to 15 cm; basal internode 4-12 cm long, erect, slender, 0.7-1.1 mm diam., terete, smooth to rugose or striate, tomentose or pilose with short white hairs; branched above the 1st internode; branches 1.5-2.0 mm diam., erect or curved, compressed to subterete with a longitudinal furrow, striate, glabrous, green; branchlets 1-4 cm long, 1.5-2 mm wide, often several arising from each culm sheath axil, not repeatedly branched, often prominently mucronate; the mucro 1-4 mm long. Sheaths appressed, 5-12 mm long, rigid, brown, acute to less often truncate, with a short erect lamina, fringed with white hairs c. 1 mm long. Male spikelets solitary, terminal, ovoid, 6-12 mm long, 4-9 mm wide; glumes c. 8 sterile lower and to 50 fertile upper, lanceolate, 2.5-3.0 mm long, mucronate. Female spikelets solitary, sessile on rhizome branches. Male flowers: tepals brown-hyaline, 2.5-2.7 mm long; filaments 3.0-3.2 mm long, slender; anthers 1.0-1.2 mm long. Female flowers with only the style, stigmas and cataphyll tips above ground; fruit maturing below ground; flower enclosed by numerous glossy, pale or chestnut bracts 1-8 cm long; between bracts and tepals are dense, silky, long (8-10 mm) white hairs. Female flowers: tepals 6, hyaline, oblong-lanceolate; apex acute, fimbriate, 3-10 mm long; ovary 1-locular but 3-angular, brown; style emergent, 8-11 cm long, basally terete for 4-7 cm; branches 3, 4-6 cm long, mostly exerted from the enclosing bracts. Fruit obpyriform, brown or black, c. 15 mm long, c. 9 mm diam. Plants are commonly infected by Tolyposporium restionum smut fungus and male plants produce galled, smut-affected spikelets (Sieler et al. 1999). Kwongan vegetation; heath and woodland, in deep sand. Regenerates by resprouting or seed after fire. Stems turn yellow during drought, regreening after rain (George 2002). Roots strongly sand-binding. fire: an important pioneer species able to withstand fairly intense fires (wightman & andrews 1989: 20).

original_text: Perennial tufted herb, 0.7-1.5 m high; rhizome thick, 10-22 mm diam., sometimes pseudobulbous; roots sand-binding; plants clonal, 0.3-1 m across; caudex present; old leaf sheaths covering the caudex, not breaking apart into fibres with age, pale brown to reddish brown. Culms stout, erect, leafy, with 4-7 nodes, obtusely trigonous, 2.5-7 mm diam., somewhat ribbed, usually scabrous but otherwise glabrous, base enlarged. Leaves basal and cauline, numerous, reducing in size up the culm, ultimately bract-like; phyllotaxy loosely spirotristichous, sheath scabrous, especially on upper leaves, loose around culm, 20-28 (-38) mm long, not broader than the leaf lamina, upper margin with short, thick, brownish hairs, ligule absent; lower leaf lamina (150-) 220-460 mm long, 5-15 mm wide, lamina  linear, flat or usually folded, margins and prominent midrib scabrous, apex gradually attenuate. Inflorescence open, panicle-like, narrow, 120-750 mm long, 20-45 mm wide; with 7-14 nodes, bracts leaf-like, exceeding the spikelet clusters; branches spreading, with (1-) 3-12 spikelets on peduncles 7-16 mm long, arising in each bract axil; spikelet prophyll absent. Spikelets brown, very narrowly ovate, 12-22 mm long, with 10-14 glumes, finely and very shortly hairy, only top-most 2-4 fertile, all bisexual, basal glumes 3-6 mm long; fertile glumes 11-20 m long, glabrescent, acute, becoming acuminate; rachilla compact and not or scarcely sinuous in fruiting spikelets. Perianth absent. Stamens 3; anther connective 6-11 mm long, linear to subulate; anthers pale yellow, 7-10 mm long, with a glabrous apical appendage 1.0-1.5 mm long. Style 16-22 mm long, trifid; base 8-12 mm long, slightly enlarged so continuous with the nutlet, branches 8-10 mm long, hairy. Nutlet sessile, subovoid but base contracted, 3.2-3.8 mm long, 1.8-2.2 mm diam., with three white ribs that broaden towards the apex; embryo not examined. Photosynthetic pathway inferred from anatomy to be C3 (Fitzgerald NSW 4337; Salasoo 4017; Bruhl & Wilson 2007). 1C = 0.39 pg (Barrett RLB 7785; Bureƒ€¦¡ et al. 2013).  Occurs close to the coast on sandplains, consolidated sand dunes and limestone in Banksia and jarrah-marri woodland, occasionally extending inland along rivers. Ammothryon grandiflorum is persistent in the landscape due to its clonal growth, with individuals tracked for over 30 years in Kings Park, Perth, and observed to resprout very quickly post-fire (Baird 1977). Flowers recorded (March-) April-July; fruit recorded July-October.

fire: resprouts after fire.
description: herb, evergreen, dioecious, perennial, caespitose, forming small tufts or large dense tussocks to 30 cm across. leaves basal, linear, 25-75 cm long; sheathing base 5-13 cm long, red-brown to blackish; lamina subterete or laterally compressed, 0.5-1.5 mm wide dorsiventrally, acuminate. culms semi-terete to compressed, (24-)35-77 cm long, 1-1.5 mm wide, smooth or slightly scaberulous. inflorescences 3-10 cm long, with short erect branches; floral bracts 2, very broad deltoid, 1.3-2.5 mm long; males with 20-80 flowers; females with 8-35 flowers; flowers very shortly pedicellate. spathes subtending inflorescence caducous, linear-lanceolate, 5-14 cm long, circa 0.8 cm broad, reddish brown, scarious, sheathing below but equitant towards the apex. upper bracts broad cuneate, membranous, 2-3 mm long. male flowers: tepals 6, narrow-lanceolate, rigid, keeled, reddish brown, acute to acuminate; outer tepals 6.8-8 mm long; inner tepals 5-7.5 mm long; filaments (1.7-)2.5-3(-4) mm long; anthers 3-3.3 mm long. female flowers: tepals 6; outer tepals narrow-deltoid, acute, keeled, 3.8-4 mm long; inner tepals narrow ovate, obtuse, 2.5-3 mm long; style branches equalling tepals, recurved. capsule 2-2.6 mm long, 1-2 mm broad. seeds colliculate. appears to hybridise with anarthria humilis, or there may be a taxon, not yet described, with some similarities to gracilis and to humilis. dna studies and morphology suggest that gracilis, as generally recognised, may consist of two or three taxa (fominchev & sokoloff, pers. comm.) heath in sand in dry and seasonally damp sites. resprouts after fire. flowers in spring. ;
original_text: Herb, evergreen, dioecious, perennial, caespitose, forming small tufts or large dense tussocks to 30 cm across. Leaves basal, linear, 25-75 cm long; sheathing base 5-13 cm long, red-brown to blackish; lamina subterete or laterally compressed, 0.5-1.5 mm wide dorsiventrally, acuminate. Culms semi-terete to compressed, (24-)35-77 cm long, 1-1.5 mm wide, smooth or slightly scaberulous. Inflorescences 3-10 cm long, with short erect branches; floral bracts 2, very broad deltoid, 1.3-2.5 mm long; males with 20-80 flowers; females with 8-35 flowers; flowers very shortly pedicellate. Spathes subtending inflorescence caducous, linear-lanceolate, 5-14 cm long, c. 0.8 cm broad, reddish brown, scarious, sheathing below but equitant towards the apex. Upper bracts broad cuneate, membranous, 2-3 mm long. Male flowers: tepals 6, narrow-lanceolate, rigid, keeled, reddish brown, acute to acuminate; outer tepals 6.8-8 mm long; inner tepals 5-7.5 mm long; filaments (1.7-)2.5-3(-4) mm long; anthers 3-3.3 mm long. Female flowers: tepals 6; outer tepals narrow-deltoid, acute, keeled, 3.8-4 mm long; inner tepals narrow ovate, obtuse, 2.5-3 mm long; style branches equalling tepals, recurved. Capsule 2-2.6 mm long, 1-2 mm broad. Seeds colliculate. Appears to hybridise with Anarthria humilis, or there may be a taxon, not yet described, with some similarities to A. gracilis and to A. humilis. DNA studies and morphology suggest that A. gracilis, as generally recognised, may consist of two or three taxa (Fominchev & Sokoloff, pers. comm.) Heath in sand in dry and seasonally damp sites. Resprouts after fire. Flowers in spring.

fire: regenerates after fire by resprouting.
description: herb, evergreen, dioecious, perennial, caespitose, forming small tufts to large tussocks 40 cm across. rhizomes very short, erect or ascending. leaves basal, 8-20 cm long; sheathing base 1.8-5 cm long, reddish brown; lamina subterete or laterally compressed, 0.5-1 mm dorsiventrally, apex acuminate and recurved. flowering stems compressed, 9-30 cm long, 0.5-1 mm wide, often curved. inflorescences slender, 1-3.5 cm long with short erect branches and 3-25 flowers; floral bracts 1 or usually 2, deltoid or broad ovate-deltoid, 0.5-2 mm long, acute or obtuse, margins hyaline. spathes subtending inflorescence caducous, narrow-deltoid, 3.5-5.5 mm long, reddish brown, subulate, incurved at the tip. male flowers: pedicellate; tepals 6, narrow-lanceolate, keeled, yellow-brown, scarious with membranous margins, acute or acuminate; outer tepals longer, 4.8-7.5 mm long; inner tepals 4.5-6.0 mm long; filaments 1.5-2.0 mm long; anthers 3-4 mm long. female flowers: very shortly pedicellate; tepals 6, more rigid than males; outer tepals 3.2-5 mm long; inner tepals 2.7-3.2 mm long; style branches equalling outer tepals, recurved. capsule 2-2.5 mm long and broad. appears to hybridise with anarthria humilis, or there may be a taxon, not yet described, with some similarities to gracilis and to humilis. well-drained sites in heath and mallee in sand or sandy loam over laterite. regenerates after fire by resprouting. flowers in spring. ;
original_text: Herb, evergreen, dioecious, perennial, caespitose, forming small tufts to large tussocks 40 cm across. Rhizomes very short, erect or ascending. Leaves basal, 8-20 cm long; sheathing base 1.8-5 cm long, reddish brown; lamina subterete or laterally compressed, 0.5-1 mm dorsiventrally, apex acuminate and recurved. Flowering stems compressed, 9-30 cm long, 0.5-1 mm wide, often curved. Inflorescences slender, 1-3.5 cm long with short erect branches and 3-25 flowers; floral bracts 1 or usually 2, deltoid or broad ovate-deltoid, 0.5-2 mm long, acute or obtuse, margins hyaline. Spathes subtending inflorescence caducous, narrow-deltoid, 3.5-5.5 mm long, reddish brown, subulate, incurved at the tip. Male flowers: pedicellate; tepals 6, narrow-lanceolate, keeled, yellow-brown, scarious with membranous margins, acute or acuminate; outer tepals longer, 4.8-7.5 mm long; inner tepals 4.5-6.0 mm long; filaments 1.5-2.0 mm long; anthers 3-4 mm long. Female flowers: very shortly pedicellate; tepals 6, more rigid than males; outer tepals 3.2-5 mm long; inner tepals 2.7-3.2 mm long; style branches equalling outer tepals, recurved. Capsule 2-2.5 mm long and broad. Appears to hybridise with Anarthria humilis, or there may be a taxon, not yet described, with some similarities to A. gracilis and to A. humilis. Well-drained sites in heath and mallee in sand or sandy loam over laterite. Regenerates after fire by resprouting. Flowers in spring.

description: herb, evergreen, dioecious, perennial, forming large dense clumps to 1 m across. rhizome horizontal or ascending, short, stout, to 6 cm long, 3-8 mm diam., covered by the fibrous remains of weathered leaf bases and imbricate scales. leaves linear, 35-65 cm long; sheathing base 4-14 cm long, reddish brown when young, becoming dark brown; lamina thick, rigid, grey-green, the margins smooth. flowering stems erect, compressed 20-105 cm long, 1.5-5 mm wide, the margins smooth. inflorescences erect, 5.5-10 cm long with up to 200 subsessile flowers crowded on short erect branches. spathes subtending the inflorescence and major inflorescence branches caducous, linear, 5.5-6.3 cm long, circa 0.5 cm broad, keeled, herbaceous-scarious, green tinged reddish brown, with a short equitant lamina, 2-6 mm long. upper bracts persistent, broad deltoid, reddish brown, membranous, acute. male flowers: tepals 6, oblong-lanceolate, reddish brown, scarious-membranous, flat, obtuse to acuminate; outer tepals slightly shorter than inner, 2.5-3 mm long; inner tepals 3-3.5 mm long; filaments 2.2-3 mm long; anthers exserted, 2.5-3 mm long. female flowers: tepals 6; inner and outer tepals equal in length, 2.2-2.5 mm long, remaining scarious in fruiting stage; style branches 3, stout, exceeding tepals, strongly recurved. capsule circa 2.5 mm long and broad. male plants are much less common than females at some sites. moist heaths, depressions or swamps in peaty sand. regenerates after fire by resprouting. flowers spring and autumn. ;

description: herb, evergreen, dioecious, perennial, plants often resembling loose 'cushions' of much-branched stems and leaves, flat on the ground or raised to 6 cm above ground level on the stem and/or slender vertical stilt-roots; older plants sometimes dying in the centre and forming spreading rings to 30 cm across. stems ascending or erect, 5-15 cm long, covered with imbricate bases of crowded leaves, bearing peduncles and usually adventitious stilt-roots. leaves linear, 3-12 cm long, flexible or rigid; base reddish with a scarious margin; lamina terete, 0.5-1 mm diam., coarsely striate, not scabrid, acute. peduncles terete, 1.5-4.5 cm long, 0.4-0.5 mm diam., not scabrid. inflorescences of 2-5 subsessile flowers; floral bracts (1-) 2, deltoid or broad deltoid, 0.7-2.1 mm long. spathes subtending the inflorescence usually persistent, subulate or narrow deltoid, 5-8 mm long, scarious, acuminate. upper bracts deltoid, membranous, 1-3 mm long. male flowers: tepals 6, ovate to lanceolate, 3.5-4.5 mm long, outer tepals slightly longer than inner, light-brown, scarious, keeled, sub-acute to acuminate, margins membranous; filaments 3.2-3.8 mm long; anthers 1.4-2.8 mm long. female flowers: tepals 6, 2.6-3 mm long; style branches exceeding tepals, strongly recurved. capsule 1.7-2.3 mm long, circa 2 mm broad. seeds with a pattern of large flat lobed cells. plants in the north of the range mostly have longer, more flexible leaves and fewer stilt-roots than those in the south. sclerophyllous mallee and heath in clayey sand, in mostly dry climatic areas. regenerates after fire by seed. flowers in spring. ;

description: similar to anigozanthos bicolor but diminutive in all respects and the flowers not falcate, relatively broad for their length. leaves 3-12 cm long, 1-3 mm wide. scape 5-20 cm tall. perianth 20-30 mm long, 3.2-5.2 mm wide at narrowest point above middle; lobes 3.5-5.5 mm long. anthers 1.4-2.3 mm long; filaments 2-3.5 mm long. style 20-30 mm long. seeds 0.5-1.5 mm long, grey-brown. the smallest of the kangaroo paws. rarely seen because it appears in profusion only the first year following fire and rapidly declines in subsequent years. although close to anigozanthos bicolor and regarded by some as conspecific with it, there are sufficient morphological and genetic differences to justify specific rank - see s.d.hopper, austral. bot. 28: 659-680 (1980). confused with bicolor var minor until now (see below). no major geographical variants. hybridises frequently with humilis , rarely with rufus . grows in winter-wet pink sand along ephemeral creeklines and in depressions in foothills in low open woodland and scrub of melaleuca , lambertia inermis and nuytsia floribunda . flowers sept.-oct. ;

Perianth 20-30 mm long, 3.2-5.2 mm wide at narrowest point above middle; lobes 3.5-5.5 mm long. Anthers 1.4-2.3 mm long; filaments 2-3.5 mm long. Style 20-30 mm long. Seeds 0.5-1.5 mm long, grey-brown. The smallest of the kangaroo paws. Rarely seen because it appears in profusion only the first year following fire and rapidly declines in subsequent years. Although close to Anigozanthos bicolor and regarded by some as conspecific with it, there are sufficient morphological and genetic differences to justify specific rank - see S.D.Hopper, Austral. J. Bot. 28: 659-680 (1980). Confused with A. bicolor var. minor until now (see below). No major geographical variants. Hybridises frequently with A. humilis , rarely with A. rufus . Grows in winter-wet pink sand along ephemeral creeklines and in depressions in foothills in low open woodland and scrub of Melaleuca , Lambertia inermis and Nuytsia floribunda . Flowers Sept.-Oct.

simplified_phrase: rare species seen in abundance only after fire
fire: a relatively rare species seen in abundance only after fire.
description: leaves flat, falcate, to 12 cm long, 3-10 mm wide, bluish green. scape 10-20 cm tall, straight. floral hairs red except on perianth, which may be yellow, yellow-red or green-red. perianth somewhat falcate with margins downcurved well beyond tube, 25-45 mm long, 10-16 mm wide at insertion of outer filaments; lobes fully recurved, 4-8 mm long. stamens triseriate; anthers 1.6-3.5 mm long; filaments 1.3-3.5 mm long. style 15-45 mm long. seeds 0.5-1 mm long, black. a relatively rare species seen in abundance only after fire. the reflexed perianth lobes, two-coloured flowers, blue-green leaves and relatively later flowering distinguish it from nearby anigozanthos humilis . possibly of hybrid origin, derived from a stabilised backcross of humilis xmanglesii . hybridises freely with humilis , occasionally with manglesii . occurs in sandy depressions and winter-wet slopes in undulating plateau terrain, usually in low heath. flowers aug.-sept. ;
original_text: Leaves flat, falcate, to 12 cm long, 3-10 mm wide, bluish green. Scape 10-20 cm tall, straight. Floral hairs red except on perianth, which may be yellow, yellow-red or green-red. Perianth somewhat falcate with margins downcurved well beyond tube, 25-45 mm long, 10-16 mm wide at insertion of outer filaments; lobes fully recurved, 4-8 mm long. Stamens triseriate; anthers 1.6-3.5 mm long; filaments 1.3-3.5 mm long. Style 15-45 mm long. Seeds 0.5-1 mm long, black. A relatively rare species seen in abundance only after fire. The reflexed perianth lobes, two-coloured flowers, blue-green leaves and relatively later flowering distinguish it from nearby Anigozanthos humilis . Possibly of hybrid origin, derived from a stabilised backcross of A. humilis xmanglesii . Hybridises freely with A. humilis , occasionally with A. manglesii . Occurs in sandy depressions and winter-wet slopes in undulating plateau terrain, usually in low heath. Flowers Aug.-Sept.

simplified_phrase: rare species seen in abundance only after fire or disturbance
fire: a relatively rare species seen in abundance only after fire or disturbance.
description: leaves broadly keeled and conduplicate for most of length, 5-15 cm long, 2-15 mm wide. scape 15-30 cm tall. floral hairs dull red to cream. perianth straight, 40-55 mm long; outer lobes 12-18 mm long; central lobes 10-16 mm long. anthers 2.5-4 mm long; outer filaments curved inwards, 6-10 mm long; central filaments straight, 5-7.5 mm long. style 38-50 mm long. seeds 0.8-1.5 mm long. a relatively rare species seen in abundance only after fire or disturbance. no morphological variants are known. hybridises freely with anigozanthos humilis . occurs in well-drained sand on slopes and plains in mallee heath, often with eucalyptus tetragona and lambertia inermis as conspicuous emergents. flowers mainly sept.-oct. ;

description: leaves 10-25 cm long, 1-5 mm wide. scape 20-70 cm tall, covered in reddish plumose hairs, more dense above. floral hairs red on pedicel, ovary and lower perianth, yellow beyond. perianth straight, 50-60 mm long; lobes 14-22 mm long. anthers 3-4 mm long; outer filaments 8-15 mm long, curved towards centre of perianth; central filaments 6-12 mm long. style 50-63 mm long. seeds 1.2-2.2 mm long. a most distinctive species, easily recogised by its large  flowers on top of a once-forked stem. very constant throughout its range. shows the nearest relationship to macropidia fuliginosa of any species of anigozanthos . a single collection of a rare natural hybrid with flavidus has been made (a.m.ashby 3108 , ad, mel). probably a relict species. occurs in grey sand on gentle slopes in eucalyptus staeri and casuarina fraseriana low open woodland. flowers best after fire, oct.-nov. ;
original_text: Leaves 10-25 cm long, 1-5 mm wide. Scape 20-70 cm tall, covered in reddish plumose hairs, more dense above. Floral hairs red on pedicel, ovary and lower perianth, yellow beyond. Perianth straight, 50-60 mm long; lobes 14-22 mm long. Anthers 3-4 mm long; outer filaments 8-15 mm long, curved towards centre of perianth; central filaments 6-12 mm long. Style 50-63 mm long. Seeds 1.2-2.2 mm long. A most distinctive species, easily recogised by its large claw-like flowers on top of a once-forked stem. Very constant throughout its range. Shows the nearest relationship to Macropidia fuliginosa of any species of Anigozanthos . A single collection of a rare natural hybrid with A. flavidus has been made (A.M.Ashby 3108 , AD, MEL). Probably a relict species. Occurs in grey sand on gentle slopes in Eucalyptus staeri and Casuarina fraseriana low open woodland. Flowers best after fire, Oct.-Nov.

fire: all species are able to resprout following fire; however, anthelepis paludosa has a relatively shallow, fibrous root system (vs deeper, rhizomatous roots), and may be killed by hot fires.
description: erect small to robust perennials (sometimes short-lived or annual), forming dense tussocks, with or without rhizomes. culms not noded or 1 (2)-noded, slender, rigid, smooth, usually sulcate when dried. leaves all basal and spirally arranged, or sometimes 1 or 2 cauline at nodes, with a well-developed blade, mapania-type pseudopetiole absent, oreobolus-type pseudopetiole present (obscure to obvious; figure 2 in barrett et al. 2019); blade flat to channelled above, scaberulous or glabrous on the margins; sheath equitant or not; ligule absent. lowest inflorescence bract erect, similar to the leaves, shorter to slightly longer than the inflorescence, upper bracts decreasing in length and often becoming g, lamina linear. inflorescence compound, paniculiform or subracemose, rather diffuse to dense, with several internodes, consisting of 2-10 distant fascicles of branches in the bract axils; branches 1-4 at each node, unequal, exserted from the sheath, rigid, flexuous, compressed, scaberulous or glabrous on the margins. spikelets subsessile or pedicellate, in clusters of 2-24, usually 1-flowered, the rachis not elongated or flexuous. glumes (floral bracts) 4-7, acute or mucronate, obscurely distichous, glabrous unless with sparse, minute prickle hairs along midrib; basal 2 or more glumes sterile; upper glume with a bisexual flower. hypogynous bristles (3-) 6, linear to lanceolate, margins with dense to scattered, short, white, antrorse, ciliate or ciliate-plumose hairs, persistent on the nutlet. stamens 3; filaments glabrous; anthers twisted when dry. style 3-fid, slender, of similar thickness throughout or slightly swollen at the base, deciduous. nutlet narrow-ellipsoid to obovoid, with 3 whitish ribs, slightly reticulate-rugulose at 40 x magnification, papillate or shortly hispidulous (glabrous in clarksonii) at the apex, otherwise glabrous. photosynthetic pathway inferred from anatomy to be c3.  primarily grows in tropical wetland habitats, with anthelepis paludosa extending south in eastern australia to the limit of regular summer rainfall. all species are able to resprout following fire; however, anthelepis paludosa has a relatively shallow, fibrous root system (vs deeper, rhizomatous roots), and may be killed by hot fires. ;
original_text: Erect small to robust perennials (sometimes short-lived or annual), forming dense tussocks, with or without rhizomes. Culms not noded or 1 (2)-noded, slender, rigid, smooth, usually sulcate when dried. Leaves all basal and spirally arranged, or sometimes 1 or 2 cauline at nodes, with a well-developed blade, Mapania-type pseudopetiole absent, Oreobolus-type pseudopetiole present (obscure to obvious; fig. 2 in Barrett et al. 2019); blade flat to channelled above, scaberulous or glabrous on the margins; sheath equitant or not; ligule absent. Lowest inflorescence bract erect, similar to the leaves, shorter to slightly longer than the inflorescence, upper bracts decreasing in length and often becoming glume-like, lamina linear. Inflorescence compound, paniculiform or subracemose, rather diffuse to dense, with several internodes, consisting of 2-10 distant fascicles of branches in the bract axils; branches 1-4 at each node, unequal, exserted from the sheath, rigid, flexuous, compressed, scaberulous or glabrous on the margins. Spikelets subsessile or pedicellate, in clusters of 2-24, usually 1-flowered, the rachis not elongated or flexuous. Glumes (floral bracts) 4-7, acute or mucronate, obscurely distichous, glabrous unless with sparse, minute prickle hairs along midrib; basal 2 or more glumes sterile; upper glume with a bisexual flower. Hypogynous bristles (3-) 6, linear to lanceolate, margins with dense to scattered, short, white, antrorse, ciliate or ciliate-plumose hairs, persistent on the nutlet. Stamens 3; filaments glabrous; anthers twisted when dry. Style 3-fid, slender, of similar thickness throughout or slightly swollen at the base, deciduous. Nutlet narrow-ellipsoid to obovoid, with 3 whitish ribs, slightly reticulate-rugulose at 40 x magnification, papillate or shortly hispidulous (glabrous in A. clarksonii) at the apex, otherwise glabrous. Photosynthetic pathway inferred from anatomy to be C3.  Primarily grows in tropical wetland habitats, with Anthelepis paludosa extending south in eastern Australia to the limit of regular summer rainfall. All species are able to resprout following fire; however, Anthelepis paludosa has a relatively shallow, fibrous root system (vs deeper, rhizomatous roots), and may be killed by hot fires.

fire: this species has often been interpreted as an annual because the stems and leaves are quite soft, and it lacks a well-defined rhizome, but it has also been observed to resprout after fire and with the previous year's dead growth still present;
description: erect slender annual to short-lived perennial, forming dense tussocks, with very short rhizome. culms not noded or 1 (2)-noded below inflorescence, slender, flexible, terete throughout, striate when dried, smooth, 12-65 cm high, 0.7-1.1 mm diam. leaves mostly basal, sometimes 1 (2) per culm cauline, with well developed blade, 3.5-12 cm long, shorter than the culms; blade  flat above, semi-circular below, rigid, striate below, glabrous on the margins, 0.4-1.7 mm wide; sheath not equitant, scarcely dilated at the base, yellowish brown to reddish brown, striate, shiny, with firm, brown margins, tightly clasping the culm; junction of sheath and blade apparently lacking a ligule. lowest inflorescence bract erect, similar to the leaves, usually shorter than the inflorescence, 2.7-9 cm long, sometimes breaking off after anthesis, upper bracts decreasing in length, reduced to a linear lamina, not spreading; sheath, 2.5-17 mm long, brown, lamina linear. inflorescence interrupted, paniculiform, erect, rather diffuse, narrow, 6-42 cm long, with several internodes, consisting of 5-9 distant fascicles of branches in the bract axils; primary branches solitary, unequal, 2-13 cm long, well exserted from the sheath, slender, flexuous, compressed, glabrous on the margins; secondary branches 1-6, 1.5-3.2 cm long. spikelets shortly pedicellate, in clusters of (1-) 3 (-4), 4-6 mm long, 1.1-1.5 mm wide, narrow-ovate, compressed, 1- or 2 (-3)-flowered, pale brown; pedicels 3-18 mm long; the rachis not elongated or flexuous. glumes 4-8, 1.4-5.6 mm long, narrow-ovate, acute, mucronate, obscurely distichous, membranous, straw-coloured with reddish patches, keel often green, shiny, white to translucent on the margins, glabrous, veinless; basal two glumes 1.4-2.0 mm long, sterile; next glumes 2.3-5.6 mm long, upper-most glume smaller, with a bisexual flower, 1 (or 2) glumes below with a male fertile flower. hypogynous bristles 6, linear, 0.3-0.8 mm long, shorter than nutlet, margins with scattered, white, short, antrorse ciliate hairs, falling with the nutlet. stamens 3; filaments 3.8-4.2 mm long, glabrous; anthers yellow, aging red, linear, 1.6-2.8 mm long, ~0.2 mm wide, twisted when dry, apiculum narrowly triangular, to 0.2 mm long. style 3-fid, 3.8-5.1 mm long, branching for ¢‚¬¦--½ of its length, slender, of similar thickness throughout, not swollen at the base, dark brown at maturity, deciduous. nutlet trigonous, ovoid to obovoid, with 3 fine, whitish ribs, reticulate at 40x magnification, shortly hispidulous in the upper one third-½, glabrescent below, green to reddish to brown when immature, dull, blackish brown at maturity, 1.0-1.3 mm long, 0.6-0.8 mm in diam. grows in damp places in heath in sandy soils, often over sandstone, and in coastal swamps. this species has often been interpreted as an annual because the stems and leaves are quite soft, and it lacks a well-defined rhizome, but it has also been observed to resprout after fire and with the previous year's dead growth still present; so, it is here interpreted as an annual to short-lived perennial. flowering recorded for february-may; fruiting recorded for june-september. ;
original_text: Erect slender annual to short-lived perennial, forming dense tussocks, with very short rhizome. Culms not noded or 1 (2)-noded below inflorescence, slender, flexible, terete throughout, striate when dried, smooth, 12-65 cm high, 0.7-1.1 mm diam. Leaves mostly basal, sometimes 1 (2) per culm cauline, with well developed blade, 3.5-12 cm long, shorter than the culms; blade  flat above, semi-circular below, rigid, striate below, glabrous on the margins, 0.4-1.7 mm wide; sheath not equitant, scarcely dilated at the base, yellowish brown to reddish brown, striate, shiny, with firm, brown margins, tightly clasping the culm; junction of sheath and blade apparently lacking a ligule. Lowest inflorescence bract erect, similar to the leaves, usually shorter than the inflorescence, 2.7-9 cm long, sometimes breaking off after anthesis, upper bracts decreasing in length, reduced to a linear lamina, not spreading; sheath, 2.5-17 mm long, brown, lamina linear. Inflorescence interrupted, paniculiform, erect, rather diffuse, narrow, 6-42 cm long, with several internodes, consisting of 5-9 distant fascicles of branches in the bract axils; primary branches solitary, unequal, 2-13 cm long, well exserted from the sheath, slender, flexuous, compressed, glabrous on the margins; secondary branches 1-6, 1.5-3.2 cm long. Spikelets shortly pedicellate, in clusters of (1-) 3 (-4), 4-6 mm long, 1.1-1.5 mm wide, narrow-ovate, compressed, 1- or 2 (-3)-flowered, pale brown; pedicels 3-18 mm long; the rachis not elongated or flexuous. Glumes 4-8, 1.4-5.6 mm long, narrow-ovate, acute, mucronate, obscurely distichous, membranous, straw-coloured with reddish patches, keel often green, shiny, white to translucent on the margins, glabrous, veinless; basal two glumes 1.4-2.0 mm long, sterile; next glumes 2.3-5.6 mm long, upper-most glume smaller, with a bisexual flower, 1 (or 2) glumes below with a male fertile flower. Hypogynous bristles 6, linear, 0.3-0.8 mm long, shorter than nutlet, margins with scattered, white, short, antrorse ciliate hairs, falling with the nutlet. Stamens 3; filaments 3.8-4.2 mm long, glabrous; anthers yellow, aging red, linear, 1.6-2.8 mm long, ~0.2 mm wide, twisted when dry, apiculum narrowly triangular, to 0.2 mm long. Style 3-fid, 3.8-5.1 mm long, branching for ¢‚¬¦--½ of its length, slender, of similar thickness throughout, not swollen at the base, dark brown at maturity, deciduous. Nutlet trigonous, ovoid to obovoid, with 3 fine, whitish ribs, reticulate at 40x magnification, shortly hispidulous in the upper one third-½, glabrescent below, green to reddish to brown when immature, dull, blackish brown at maturity, 1.0-1.3 mm long, 0.6-0.8 mm in diam. Grows in damp places in heath in sandy soils, often over sandstone, and in coastal swamps. This species has often been interpreted as an annual because the stems and leaves are quite soft, and it lacks a well-defined rhizome, but it has also been observed to resprout after fire and with the previous year's dead growth still present; so, it is here interpreted as an annual to short-lived perennial. Flowering recorded for February-May; fruiting recorded for June-September.

fire: a colonising species common after fire or disturbance.
description: erect shrub to 2.7 m high with 1 or 2 stems, the branches often tinged with purple, branches and leaves glabrous, rarely with scattered glandular hairs; seedlings with prickles on stems. leaves obovate to narrowly obovate-elliptic, occasionally spathulate or elliptic, sessile or almost so, 15-80 mm long, 7-35 mm wide, thick and fleshy, entire, or the juvenile leaves dentate. inflorescence pan, leafless except at base; pedicels 3-8 mm long. calyx 4-8 mm long. corolla 12-27 mm long, bright yellow, the striations purple to maroon; tube often tinged with purple outside; lobes linear, 6-18 mm long, 3-6 mm wide. stamens 4-10 mm long. capsule narrowly ovoid-ellipsoid, acute to apiculate, 11-21 mm long. seeds 48-114 in all, 1.4-1.9 mm long.   fruit sometimes malformed due to galling, but only in subsp ilicifolia. it can be difficult to distinguish between ilicifolia and littorea, and they are sometimes misidentified in the literature (see notes in illustration citations in subsp ilicifolia and littorea).in the account of littorea by dixon (2011: 86-87), the flowers depicted for the species appear to actually be ilicifolia subsp ilicifolia, and the capsule is consistent for that taxon. see also diagnostic features above. grows in calcareous sand, mostly in coastal situations; a colonising species common after fire or disturbance. flowers and fruits much of the year, as determined by the time of germination and establishment following a disturbance event. ;
original_text: Erect shrub to 2.7 m high with 1 or 2 stems, the branches often tinged with purple, branches and leaves glabrous, rarely with scattered glandular hairs; seedlings with prickles on stems. Leaves obovate to narrowly obovate-elliptic, occasionally spathulate or elliptic, sessile or almost so, 15-80 mm long, 7-35 mm wide, thick and fleshy, entire, or the juvenile leaves dentate. Inflorescence panicle-like, leafless except at base; pedicels 3-8 mm long. Calyx 4-8 mm long. Corolla 12-27 mm long, bright yellow, the striations purple to maroon; tube often tinged with purple outside; lobes linear, 6-18 mm long, 3-6 mm wide. Stamens 4-10 mm long. Capsule narrowly ovoid-ellipsoid, acute to apiculate, 11-21 mm long. Seeds 48-114 in all, 1.4-1.9 mm long.   Fruit sometimes malformed due to galling, but only in subsp. ilicifolia. It can be difficult to distinguish between A. ilicifolia and A. littorea, and they are sometimes misidentified in the literature (see notes in Illustration citations in subsp. ilicifolia and A. littorea).In the account of A. littorea by Dixon (2011: 86-87), the flowers depicted for the species appear to actually be A. ilicifolia subsp. ilicifolia, and the capsule is consistent for that taxon. See also Diagnostic Features above. Grows in calcareous sand, mostly in coastal situations; a colonising species common after fire or disturbance. Flowers and fruits much of the year, as determined by the time of germination and establishment following a disturbance event.
