description: shrub to 2 m tall, usually taller than wide, without lignotuber. stems tomentose. leaves: petiole 1.5-2 mm long; lamina narrowly linear, commonly 1.5-3 cm long, 1-1.3 mm wide, obtuse to acute; upper surface pubescent, glabrescent. inflorescence 3-5 cm long; involucral bracts 3-4 mm long, tomentose. flowers golden brown to pale brown; styles cream. perianth 22-25 mm long including limb of 4 mm, hirsute outside and inside. pistil hooked, 25-29 mm long, glabrous; pollen presenter narrow, 1 mm long. old flowers persistent. follicles up to 65, narrowly elliptic, 12-20 mm long, 4-9 mm high, 4-7 mm wide, smooth, hirsute. seed obovate, 19-23 mm long; seed body oblong, 10-13 mm long, 2-3 mm wide, smooth. killed by fire and regenerates from seed; follicles usually opening with fire. in the late bud stage the inflorescence assumes a shortly cylindrical aspect. related to leptophylla which has longer leaves and larger flowers, and the inflorescence rounded through all stages. in deep grey sandy loam, often wet in winter, in scrub, occasionally in low woodland. flowers may-aug. ;
original_text: Shrub to 2 m tall, usually taller than wide, without lignotuber. Stems tomentose. Leaves: petiole 1.5-2 mm long; lamina narrowly linear, commonly 1.5-3 cm long, 1-1.3 mm wide, obtuse to acute; upper surface pubescent, glabrescent. Inflorescence 3-5 cm long; involucral bracts 3-4 mm long, tomentose. Flowers golden brown to pale brown; styles cream. Perianth 22-25 mm long including limb of 4 mm, hirsute outside and inside. Pistil hooked, 25-29 mm long, glabrous; pollen presenter narrow, 1 mm long. Old flowers persistent. Follicles up to 65, narrowly elliptic, 12-20 mm long, 4-9 mm high, 4-7 mm wide, smooth, hirsute. Seed obovate, 19-23 mm long; seed body oblong, 10-13 mm long, 2-3 mm wide, smooth. Killed by fire and regenerates from seed; follicles usually opening with fire. In the late bud stage the inflorescence assumes a shortly cylindrical aspect. Related to B. leptophylla which has longer leaves and larger flowers, and the inflorescence rounded through all stages. In deep grey sandy loam, often wet in winter, in scrub, occasionally in low woodland. Flowers May-Aug.

fire: shrub or small tree to 4 m tall, with stout trunk, often of irregular form, fire-tolerant. fire-tolerant, sprouting by epicormic shoots. follicles opening with fire.
description: shrub or small tree to 4 m tall, with stout trunk, often of irregular form, fire-tolerant. bark tessellated or rugose, grey. leaves alternate but crowded near branchlet tips; petiole 2-5 mm long; lamina narrowly linear, 5-13 cm long, 1-1.5 mm wide, entire except an obtuse tooth each side of apex; margins revolute; upper surface hirsute, glabrescent; lower surface woolly. inflorescence 7-15 cm long; involucral bracts closely tomentose, soon falling. flowers golden, drying dark red-brown; style bright yellow. perianth 23-26 mm long including limb of 2.5 mm, appressed-pubescent outside, glabrous inside. pistil hooked, 32-37 mm long, glabrous; pollen presenter ovoid, 1 mm long. old flowers soon falling. follicles up to 35, prominent, elliptic, 15-28 mm long, 8-16 mm high, 8-14 mm wide, slightly rugose, glabrous. seed obovate, 23-28 mm long; seed body obovate, 11-17 mm long, 9-12 mm wide, rugose. fire-tolerant, sprouting by epicormic shoots. follicles opening with fire. no close relatives. thiele & ladiges (1996) considered this misplaced in ser. spicigerae and transferred it to ser. abietinae but the latter is here restricted to those taxa with entire leaves and spherical inflorescences. in rocky, lateritic soil, sometimes at breakaway edges, in shrubland. flowers late mar.-july. ;
original_text: Shrub or small tree to 4 m tall, with stout trunk, often of irregular form, fire-tolerant. Bark tessellated or rugose, grey. Leaves alternate but crowded near branchlet tips; petiole 2-5 mm long; lamina narrowly linear, 5-13 cm long, 1-1.5 mm wide, entire except an obtuse tooth each side of apex; margins revolute; upper surface hirsute, glabrescent; lower surface woolly. Inflorescence 7-15 cm long; involucral bracts closely tomentose, soon falling. Flowers golden, drying dark red-brown; style bright yellow. Perianth 23-26 mm long including limb of 2.5 mm, appressed-pubescent outside, glabrous inside. Pistil hooked, 32-37 mm long, glabrous; pollen presenter ovoid, 1 mm long. Old flowers soon falling. Follicles up to 35, prominent, elliptic, 15-28 mm long, 8-16 mm high, 8-14 mm wide, slightly rugose, glabrous. Seed obovate, 23-28 mm long; seed body obovate, 11-17 mm long, 9-12 mm wide, rugose. Fire-tolerant, sprouting by epicormic shoots. Follicles opening with fire. No close relatives. Thiele & Ladiges (1996) considered this misplaced in ser. Spicigerae and transferred it to ser. Abietinae but the latter is here restricted to those taxa with entire leaves and spherical inflorescences. In rocky, lateritic soil, sometimes at breakaway edges, in shrubland. Flowers late Mar.-July.

simplified_phrase: killed by fire; regenerates from seed; follicles mostly open without fire after several years
fire: probably killed by fire and regenerates from seed. follicles mostly opening without fire after several years.
description: shrub, rarely a tree, to 5 m tall, much-branched and spreading, without lignotuber. bark roughly fissured, grey. stems pubescent, glabrescent. leaves whorled, sometimes alternate; petiole 5-11 mm long; lamina leathery, elliptic, 3-9 cm long, 7-12 mm wide, obtuse; margins recurved, entire; upper surface loosely hirsute, glabrescent; lower surface white-matted. inflorescence 8-20 cm long; involucral bracts narrow, hirsute, persistent. flowers golden; styles yellow. perianth 25-30 mm long including limb of 3.5-4 mm, pubescent outside, also inside along upper margins. pistil hooked, 30-35 mm long, glabrous; pollen presenter ovoid, 0.5 mm long. old flowers persistent but finally falling. follicles up to circa 100, elliptic, 11-15 mm long, 2-3 mm high, 3-4 mm wide, smooth, tomentose. seed obovate-cuneate, 18-20 mm long; seed body narrowly cuneate, 10-11 mm long, smooth, with inner face slightly rugose. probably killed by fire and regenerates from seed. follicles mostly opening without fire after several years. related to littoralis which is usually a tree with longer, serrate adult leaves, the perianth more hirsute inside but the limb appressed-pubescent, and the follicles more exserted from a narrower axis. banksia littoralis grows in damper habitats and flowers later than verticillata . also closely related to seminuda , a tree with thin, usually serrate leaves, strongly recurved styles and perianths with glabrous limb; it flowers in winter. on or beside granite outcrops, usually exposed, sometimes in tall shrubland. flowers jan.-apr. ;
original_text: Shrub, rarely a tree, to 5 m tall, much-branched and spreading, without lignotuber. Bark roughly fissured, grey. Stems pubescent, glabrescent. Leaves whorled, sometimes alternate; petiole 5-11 mm long; lamina leathery, elliptic, 3-9 cm long, 7-12 mm wide, obtuse; margins recurved, entire; upper surface loosely hirsute, glabrescent; lower surface white-matted. Inflorescence 8-20 cm long; involucral bracts narrow, hirsute, persistent. Flowers golden; styles yellow. Perianth 25-30 mm long including limb of 3.5-4 mm, pubescent outside, also inside along upper margins. Pistil hooked, 30-35 mm long, glabrous; pollen presenter ovoid, 0.5 mm long. Old flowers persistent but finally falling. Follicles up to c. 100, elliptic, 11-15 mm long, 2-3 mm high, 3-4 mm wide, smooth, tomentose. Seed obovate-cuneate, 18-20 mm long; seed body narrowly cuneate, 10-11 mm long, smooth, with inner face slightly rugose. Probably killed by fire and regenerates from seed. Follicles mostly opening without fire after several years. Related to B. littoralis which is usually a tree with longer, serrate adult leaves, the perianth more hirsute inside but the limb appressed-pubescent, and the follicles more exserted from a narrower axis. Banksia littoralis grows in damper habitats and flowers later than B. verticillata . Also closely related to B. seminuda , a tree with thin, usually serrate leaves, strongly recurved styles and perianths with glabrous limb; it flowers in winter. On or beside granite outcrops, usually exposed, sometimes in tall shrubland. Flowers Jan.-Apr.

simplified_phrase: killed by fire; regenerates from seed; serotinous
fire: killed by fire and regenerates from seed. follicles usually opening with fire.
description: shrub to 7 m without lignotuber. bark smooth, grey. stems densely hirsute. leaves: petiole 15-30 mm long; lamina broadly linear, 15-35 cm long, 2.5-4 cm wide, truncate; margins flat, deeply triangular-lobed; both surfaces woolly, glabrescent except pits in lower surface. inflorescence 7-12 cm long; involucral bracts prominent, villous, persistent. flowers orange with pale pink hairs; styles orange, cream at base. perianth 38-40 mm long including limb of 8-9 mm, tomentose outside, glabrous inside. pistil 37-43 mm long, curved, glabrous; pollen presenter 5-6 mm long, fusiform, constricted near base, finely 8-ribbed. old flowers persistent, concealing follicles. follicles up to 30, elliptic, 22-28 mm long, 10-15 mm high, 13-15 mm wide, hirsute. seed obliquely obovate, 23-29 mm long; seed body triangular, 9-12 mm long, 7-9 mm wide, somewhat tuberculate on both sides, with a ridge across inner upper margin. the villous involucral bracts and woolly new growth are distinctive. related to prionotes which has less-deeply lobed leaves, a shorter indumentum, shorter bracts under the flowers, smaller follicles and the old flowers falling. killed by fire and regenerates from seed. follicles usually opening with fire. grows in deep yellow or pale red sand, in tall shrubland. flowers jan.-feb. ;
original_text: Shrub to 7 m without lignotuber. Bark smooth, grey. Stems densely hirsute. Leaves: petiole 15-30 mm long; lamina broadly linear, 15-35 cm long, 2.5-4 cm wide, truncate; margins flat, deeply triangular-lobed; both surfaces woolly, glabrescent except pits in lower surface. Inflorescence 7-12 cm long; involucral bracts prominent, villous, persistent. Flowers orange with pale pink hairs; styles orange, cream at base. Perianth 38-40 mm long including limb of 8-9 mm, tomentose outside, glabrous inside. Pistil 37-43 mm long, curved, glabrous; pollen presenter 5-6 mm long, fusiform, constricted near base, finely 8-ribbed. Old flowers persistent, concealing follicles. Follicles up to 30, elliptic, 22-28 mm long, 10-15 mm high, 13-15 mm wide, hirsute. Seed obliquely obovate, 23-29 mm long; seed body triangular, 9-12 mm long, 7-9 mm wide, somewhat tuberculate on both sides, with a ridge across inner upper margin. The villous involucral bracts and woolly new growth are distinctive. Related to B. prionotes which has less-deeply lobed leaves, a shorter indumentum, shorter bracts under the flowers, smaller follicles and the old flowers falling. Killed by fire and regenerates from seed. Follicles usually opening with fire. Grows in deep yellow or pale red sand, in tall shrubland. Flowers Jan.-Feb.

simplified_phrase: killed by fire; regenerates from seed; serotinous
fire: non-lignotuberous plants killed by fire and regenerating from seed. follicles usually opening with fire.
description: shrub to 1.5 m tall, without (rarely with) lignotuber. stems pubescent, glabrescent. leaves: petiole 1-2 mm long; lamina linear, obtuse, usually 1-2 cm long, 1.5 mm wide, rarely acute; upper surface loosely hirsute, glabrescent. inflorescence 2-3 cm long; involucral bracts small, tomentose or partly glabrous. flowers violet, sometimes green at base, rarely yellowish; style green or purple. perianth 21-27 mm long including limb of 2-3 mm, pubescent outside, hirsute inside in lower half. pistil hooked, 28-38 mm long, glabrous; pollen presenter narrowly ovoid, 0.7 mm long. old flowers persistent mainly at base of spike. follicles elliptic to rhombic, flattened, 10-25 mm long, to 6 mm high, 8-22 mm wide, pubescent, glabrescent, green and sticky at least when young, later brownish yellow. seed cuneate, 20-25 mm long; seed body falcate, 12-18 mm long, 2-2.5 mm wide. non-lignotuberous plants killed by fire and regenerating from seed. follicles usually opening with fire. no obviously close relative, but among the abietinae loosely allied to sphaerocarpa and telmatiaea . in white sand or sandy loam over laterite, clay or quartzite, in kwongan and shrubland. flowers mainly nov.-feb. ;
original_text: Shrub to 1.5 m tall, without (rarely with) lignotuber. Stems pubescent, glabrescent. Leaves: petiole 1-2 mm long; lamina linear, obtuse, usually 1-2 cm long, 1.5 mm wide, rarely acute; upper surface loosely hirsute, glabrescent. Inflorescence 2-3 cm long; involucral bracts small, tomentose or partly glabrous. Flowers violet, sometimes green at base, rarely yellowish; style green or purple. Perianth 21-27 mm long including limb of 2-3 mm, pubescent outside, hirsute inside in lower half. Pistil hooked, 28-38 mm long, glabrous; pollen presenter narrowly ovoid, 0.7 mm long. Old flowers persistent mainly at base of spike. Follicles elliptic to rhombic, flattened, 10-25 mm long, to 6 mm high, 8-22 mm wide, pubescent, glabrescent, green and sticky at least when young, later brownish yellow. Seed cuneate, 20-25 mm long; seed body falcate, 12-18 mm long, 2-2.5 mm wide. Non-lignotuberous plants killed by fire and regenerating from seed. Follicles usually opening with fire. No obviously close relative, but among the Abietinae loosely allied to B. sphaerocarpa and B. telmatiaea . In white sand or sandy loam over laterite, clay or quartzite, in kwongan and shrubland. Flowers mainly Nov.-Feb.

fire: sprouts from the trunk after fire.
description: deciduous shrub or tree to 12 m. bark tessellated or flaky, hard, dark grey or black. stems pubescent. leaves of 2 free leaflets; stipules minute, puberulous; petiole 1-3 cm long; leaflets obliquely ovate, 1.3-4 cm long, 1-3 cm wide, concolorous, puberulous, glabrescent. racemes short, axillary, commonly below leaves; pedicels 5-7 mm long, velvety. calyx broadly campanulate, ribbed, 9-14 mm long, rusty-velvety; lobes triangular. petals ovate-oblong, dull red or pink, velvety; longest 15-17 mm; others 10-12 mm long. stamens 10, all fertile, 25-40 mm long, red, glabrous; anthers 3.5-4 mm long. pistil 33-43 mm long, glabrous; stigma prominently peltate. pod oblong, rather thin, 7-21 cm long, 3-6.3 cm wide, red-brown. seeds 10 mm long, red-brown. leaflets broader than those of carronii . usually flowers before the new leaves. the roots and bark are used by aborigines to treat headache and as an antiseptic and antipyretic, and the nectar provides a sweet drink. also a useful fodder tree. sprouts from the trunk after fire. grows in sand, loam, cracking clay, calcareous or granitic soil, on flats in woodland or vine thicket and on river banks. flowers may-oct.; fruits july-mar. ;
original_text: Deciduous shrub or tree to 12 m. Bark tessellated or flaky, hard, dark grey or black. Stems pubescent. Leaves of 2 free leaflets; stipules minute, puberulous; petiole 1-3 cm long; leaflets obliquely ovate, 1.3-4 cm long, 1-3 cm wide, concolorous, puberulous, glabrescent. Racemes short, axillary, commonly below leaves; pedicels 5-7 mm long, velvety. Calyx broadly campanulate, ribbed, 9-14 mm long, rusty-velvety; lobes triangular. Petals ovate-oblong, dull red or pink, velvety; longest 15-17 mm; others 10-12 mm long. Stamens 10, all fertile, 25-40 mm long, red, glabrous; anthers 3.5-4 mm long. Pistil 33-43 mm long, glabrous; stigma prominently peltate. Pod oblong, rather thin, 7-21 cm long, 3-6.3 cm wide, red-brown. Seeds 10 mm long, red-brown. Leaflets broader than those of B. carronii . Usually flowers before the new leaves. The roots and bark are used by Aborigines to treat headache and as an antiseptic and antipyretic, and the nectar provides a sweet drink. Also a useful fodder tree. Sprouts from the trunk after fire. Grows in sand, loam, cracking clay, calcareous or granitic soil, on flats in woodland or vine thicket and on river banks. Flowers May-Oct.; fruits July-Mar.

simplified_phrase: resprouts from basal rootstock after fire
fire: regenerates from the rootstock after fire.
description: multi-stemmed dioecious shrub or tree to 10 m tall, deciduous. bark corky or tessellated, grey-brown to black. stems pubescent. leaves: stipules linear, 2-3 mm long; petiole 12-47 mm long; lamina transversely elliptic, 3-11 cm long, 4-13 cm wide, emarginate to bilobed, glabrous above, pubescent below, discolorous, with 9 nerves radiating from base. racemes terminal or in upper axils, closely pubescent; bracts triangular, 1-2 mm long, caducous; pedicels 10-20 mm long. receptacle 2-4 mm long. calyx slit nearly to base on one side, velvety, 9-11 mm long; lobes 3-4 mm long. petals narrowly obovate to spathulate, 11-16 mm long, white. stamens 10, all fertile, in male flowers alternately long and short; female flowers with staminodes. pistil 14-16 mm long; ovary tomentose and glandular; stigma peltate. pod linear, slightly compressed, 9-36 cm long, 1-2 cm wide, wrinkled longitudinally, corky, minutely and sparsely puberulous. seeds 10-30, transversely oblique, embedded in pith, obloid, 4-5 mm long, dark brown. flowers faintly scented, falling readily. regenerates from the rootstock after fire. recorded for the kimberley in j.wheeler et al. (1992) as piliostigma malabaricum var malabaricum . var acidum was said to differ in the pubescent abaxial leaf surface, apparent bitter taste of the shoots and in being deciduous, and this would apply to the australian material, but ding hou et al. , fl. males. ser. i, 12(2): 442-535 (1996), stated that in malesia there is 'clinal variation' from glabrous to pubescent forms, and that the taste requires testing. placed in subg. elayuna . grows in alluvial clay-loam by watercourses, in tall shrubland, grassland or forest, and in rocky soil in rainforest. flowers dec.-apr.; fruits may-sept. ;
original_text: Multi-stemmed dioecious shrub or tree to 10 m tall, deciduous. Bark corky or tessellated, grey-brown to black. Stems pubescent. Leaves: stipules linear, 2-3 mm long; petiole 12-47 mm long; lamina transversely elliptic, 3-11 cm long, 4-13 cm wide, emarginate to bilobed, glabrous above, pubescent below, discolorous, with 9 nerves radiating from base. Racemes terminal or in upper axils, closely pubescent; bracts triangular, 1-2 mm long, caducous; pedicels 10-20 mm long. Receptacle 2-4 mm long. Calyx slit nearly to base on one side, velvety, 9-11 mm long; lobes 3-4 mm long. Petals narrowly obovate to spathulate, 11-16 mm long, white. Stamens 10, all fertile, in male flowers alternately long and short; female flowers with staminodes. Pistil 14-16 mm long; ovary tomentose and glandular; stigma peltate. Pod linear, slightly compressed, 9-36 cm long, 1-2 cm wide, wrinkled longitudinally, corky, minutely and sparsely puberulous. Seeds 10-30, transversely oblique, embedded in pith, obloid, 4-5 mm long, dark brown. Flowers faintly scented, falling readily. Regenerates from the rootstock after fire. Recorded for the Kimberley in J.Wheeler et al. (1992) as Piliostigma malabaricum var. malabaricum . Var. acidum was said to differ in the pubescent abaxial leaf surface, apparent bitter taste of the shoots and in being deciduous, and this would apply to the Australian material, but Ding Hou et al. , Fl. Males. ser. I, 12(2): 442-535 (1996), stated that in Malesia there is 'clinal variation' from glabrous to pubescent forms, and that the taste requires testing. Placed in subg. Elayuna . Grows in alluvial clay-loam by watercourses, in tall shrubland, grassland or forest, and in rocky soil in rainforest. Flowers Dec.-Apr.; fruits May-Sept.

simplified_phrase: flowering enhanced by fire; resprouts from rhizomes after fire
fire: flowering is enhanced by fire, the plants sprouting vigorously from the rhizomes and flowering the following season.
description: leaves up to 50 cm long, pungent; base 15-25 mm wide with narrow scarious margins, sometimes lacerated. flowers scented like rotten meat. sepals and petals 7-8 cm long, slightly widened above base for circa 2.5 cm, obtuse, smooth inside, striate outside, green at base, purplish-brown at apex. stamens almost as long as perianth; anthers circa 25 mm long. capsule indurated, circa 15 mm long, smooth; dehiscence septifragal, the valves also splitting into 2 halves, each half with the inner wall forming a plate held under tension and springing upwards to eject the seed. flowering is enhanced by fire, the plants sprouting vigorously from the rhizomes and flowering the following season. the explosive seed dispersal is unique in the western australian xanthorrhoeaceae and liliaceae (g.j.keighery, austral. naturalist 15: 164, 165 (1983)). grows on swamp margins, in sedgeland and on low sandy slopes in banksia-eucalypt woodland. flowers in summer. ;
original_text: Leaves up to 50 cm long, pungent; base 15-25 mm wide with narrow scarious margins, sometimes lacerated. Flowers scented like rotten meat. Sepals and petals 7-8 cm long, slightly widened above base for c. 2.5 cm, obtuse, smooth inside, striate outside, green at base, purplish-brown at apex. Stamens almost as long as perianth; anthers c. 25 mm long. Capsule indurated, c. 15 mm long, smooth; dehiscence septifragal, the valves also splitting into 2 halves, each half with the inner wall forming a plate held under tension and springing upwards to eject the seed. Flowering is enhanced by fire, the plants sprouting vigorously from the rhizomes and flowering the following season. The explosive seed dispersal is unique in the Western Australian Xanthorrhoeaceae and Liliaceae (G.J.Keighery, W. Austral. Naturalist 15: 164, 165 (1983)). Grows on swamp margins, in sedgeland and on low sandy slopes in Banksia-eucalypt woodland. Flowers in summer.

simplified_phrase: resprouts from base after dry season fires
fire: in its first year of growth, integrifolia develops a basal rosette of leaves and a strong taproot with the facility to reshoot from the base of the plant after dry season fires. found in a variety of soil types in open habitats, such as savanna, which are subject to drought conditions and grass fires during the dry season.
description: annual or longer-lived herb, erect to 40 cm high or prostrate. vegetative parts glandular, pilose, villous or arachnoid, becoming glabrous with age; axils of radical leaves often white-tomentose. leaves sessile, with cauline leaves often semiamplexicaul; radical leaves (may be withered at time of flowering) oblanceolate, 10-120 mm long, 4-18 mm wide, entire or finely dentate, acute or obtuse; cauline leaves linear-lanceolate to elliptic, the lower larger leaves often oblanceolate, 5-95 mm long, 1-10 mm wide, entire or distantly toothed, acute to attenuate. capitula solitary, 5-7 mm long, on peduncles to 10 cm long; involucral bracts glandular, pilose; receptacle flat to slightly convex, glabrous. florets yellow, 3.2-4.5 mm long. disc florets functionally male; corolla lobes eglandular with 1-many simple or septate hairs. achenes 0.5-0.9 mm long, without ribs or ribs obscure. this species is variable in its foliage; the prostrate form (prostrata), although often distinctive with uniform sized elliptic or narrowly elliptic leaves and rooting at the nodes, exhibits intermediate states with the erect form and has not been accorded separate status. in its first year of growth, integrifolia develops a basal rosette of leaves and a strong taproot with the facility to reshoot from the base of the plant after dry season fires. the rosette has usually withered and fallen by the second season. found in a variety of soil types in open habitats, such as savanna, which are subject to drought conditions and grass fires during the dry season. flowers and fruits june-september. ;
original_text: Annual or longer-lived herb, erect to 40 cm high or prostrate. Vegetative parts glandular, pilose, villous or arachnoid, becoming glabrous with age; axils of radical leaves often white-tomentose. Leaves sessile, with cauline leaves often semiamplexicaul; radical leaves (may be withered at time of flowering) oblanceolate, 10-120 mm long, 4-18 mm wide, entire or finely dentate, acute or obtuse; cauline leaves linear-lanceolate to elliptic, the lower larger leaves often oblanceolate, 5-95 mm long, 1-10 mm wide, entire or distantly toothed, acute to attenuate. Capitula solitary, 5-7 mm long, on peduncles to 10 cm long; involucral bracts glandular, pilose; receptacle flat to slightly convex, glabrous. Florets yellow, 3.2-4.5 mm long. Disc florets functionally male; corolla lobes eglandular with 1-many simple or septate hairs. Achenes 0.5-0.9 mm long, without ribs or ribs obscure. This species is variable in its foliage; the prostrate form (B. prostrata), although often distinctive with uniform sized elliptic or narrowly elliptic leaves and rooting at the nodes, exhibits intermediate states with the erect form and has not been accorded separate status. In its first year of growth, B. integrifolia develops a basal rosette of leaves and a strong taproot with the facility to reshoot from the base of the plant after dry season fires. The rosette has usually withered and fallen by the second season. Found in a variety of soil types in open habitats, such as savanna, which are subject to drought conditions and grass fires during the dry season. Flowers and fruits June-September.

fire: this taxon is unique amongst the australian species of blumea, and probably the genus as a whole, in possessing lifeform characteristics typical of taxa of the sandstone heath communities: it is a relatively long-lived, woody shrub with vernicose foliage, vulnerable to periodic hot fires.
description: erect shrub to circa 1 m high. stems, leaves and involucral bracts glandular, vernicose; eglandular hairs rare or absent; stems striate; older stems rough with persistent leaf bases. leaves tapering gradually to a sessile base, narrowly elliptic, 10-80 mm long, 2-10 mm wide, distantly and pungently toothed, pungent at apex, with apex and lateral teeth mucronate, slightly discolorous. capitula 7-9 mm long, on short lateral branches in upper axils, forming long narrow or narrowly pyramidal bracteate panicles; involucral bracts linear, green, with dense sessile glands; receptacle flat, pubescent. florets yellow; corollas 5-5.6 mm long; disc corolla lobes eglandular, glabrous. achenes 1.2-1.5 mm long, ribbed. this taxon is unique amongst the australian species of blumea, and probably the genus as a whole, in possessing lifeform characteristics typical of taxa of the sandstone heath communities: it is a relatively long-lived, woody shrub with vernicose foliage, vulnerable to periodic hot fires. on floral characters pungens appears to be well placed in blumea, though its habitat and pyric lifeform would indicate a long separation from all other species. further studies are needed to confirm its placement in blumea. grows in heath on sandstone plateaus. flowers june-july, fruits august-september. ;
original_text: Erect shrub to c. 1 m high. Stems, leaves and involucral bracts glandular, vernicose; eglandular hairs rare or absent; stems striate; older stems rough with persistent leaf bases. Leaves tapering gradually to a sessile base, narrowly elliptic, 10-80 mm long, 2-10 mm wide, distantly and pungently toothed, pungent at apex, with apex and lateral teeth mucronate, slightly discolorous. Capitula 7-9 mm long, on short lateral branches in upper axils, forming long narrow or narrowly pyramidal bracteate panicles; involucral bracts linear, green, with dense sessile glands; receptacle flat, pubescent. Florets yellow; corollas 5-5.6 mm long; disc corolla lobes eglandular, glabrous. Achenes 1.2-1.5 mm long, ribbed. This taxon is unique amongst the Australian species of Blumea, and probably the genus as a whole, in possessing lifeform characteristics typical of taxa of the sandstone heath communities: it is a relatively long-lived, woody shrub with vernicose foliage, vulnerable to periodic hot fires. On floral characters B. pungens appears to be well placed in Blumea, though its habitat and pyric lifeform would indicate a long separation from all other species. Further studies are needed to confirm its placement in Blumea. Grows in heath on sandstone plateaus. Flowers June-July, fruits August-September.

fire: this species tolerates annual fires and many plants consist of a large number of small stems growing from a robust rootstock.
description: multistemmed, decumbent subshrub to 40 cm wide, not obviously glandular, with sparse indumentum of simple hairs on branches, leaves and abaxial surface of perianth; stellate hairs rare. leaves (3-) 5-7-foliolate, 8-20 mm long, 8-25 mm wide; rachis segments 2-8 mm long; leaflets 4-12 mm long, 0.5-1 mm wide. pedicels 1-4 mm long. perianth white to pink. sepals deltate, 4-6 mm long (-8 mm when in fruit), 1.5-4 mm wide, acute. petals 3-5.5 mm long. style glabrous.  grows on deep sand and sandstone in eucalypt open woodland.  this species tolerates annual fires and many plants consist of a large number of small stems growing from a robust rootstock. flowers november-august; fruits march-august. ;
original_text: Multistemmed, decumbent subshrub to 40 cm wide, not obviously glandular, with sparse indumentum of simple hairs on branches, leaves and abaxial surface of perianth; stellate hairs rare. Leaves (3-) 5-7-foliolate, 8-20 mm long, 8-25 mm wide; rachis segments 2-8 mm long; leaflets 4-12 mm long, 0.5-1 mm wide. Pedicels 1-4 mm long. Perianth white to pink. Sepals deltate, 4-6 mm long (-8 mm when in fruit), 1.5-4 mm wide, acute. Petals 3-5.5 mm long. Style glabrous.  Grows on deep sand and sandstone in eucalypt open woodland.  This species tolerates annual fires and many plants consist of a large number of small stems growing from a robust rootstock. Flowers November-August; fruits March-August.

fire: the plant apparently vigorously resprouts after fire (collector's notes).
description: erect shrub to 3 m high, glabrous apart from perianth. leaves sessile, elliptic, 23-55 mm long, 12-20 mm wide, cuneate to slightly cordate at base, acute. peduncle 2-4 mm long; pedicel 0.5-3 mm long. sepals deltate, 5.5-6 mm long, circa 3 mm wide (to 9-13 mm long and 4.5-6 mm wide when in fruit), green. petals 4-5 mm long, pale yellow; abaxial surface with minute, moderately dense stellate indumentum. stamens: antipetalous filaments glandular. cocci circa 6 mm long; seed not seen. grows on sandstone ridges, slopes and sheltered gullies in open shrubland and corymbia woodland. the plant apparently vigorously resprouts after fire (collector's notes). flowers collected in may, august & october; fruits collected in august and october. ;
original_text: Erect shrub to 3 m high, glabrous apart from perianth. Leaves sessile, elliptic, 23-55 mm long, 12-20 mm wide, cuneate to slightly cordate at base, acute. Peduncle 2-4 mm long; pedicel 0.5-3 mm long. Sepals deltate, 5.5-6 mm long, c. 3 mm wide (to 9-13 mm long and 4.5-6 mm wide when in fruit), green. Petals 4-5 mm long, pale yellow; abaxial surface with minute, moderately dense stellate indumentum. Stamens: antipetalous filaments glandular. Cocci c. 6 mm long; seed not seen. Grows on sandstone ridges, slopes and sheltered gullies in open shrubland and Corymbia woodland. The plant apparently vigorously resprouts after fire (Collector's notes). Flowers collected in May, August & October; fruits collected in August and October.

fire: probably once widespread in the grampians but has been reduced by fire.
description: dwarf perennial, erect or reclining, to 15 cm high. leaves flexible, 10-16 mm long, 0.5-0.7 mm wide; apex acuminate, brown; margins smooth; leaf-base margins tapering gradually from sheath, pale straw to light brown, with fine tangled hairs. scapes 3-7 cm long, unjointed, persistent; head 6-10 mm long, 4-8 mm wide, with 4-12 flowers. outer bracts of involucre 3-6, the longest 7-13 mm, smooth, the wings entire; inner bracts absent or up to 10, keeled, brown, with ne apex. floral bracts inflexed, not imbricate, mucronate, brown. perianth lobes linear. anthers glandular. seed not seen; testa of ovules colliculate. these plants produce ovules but do not set seed and the population survives by vegetative propagation. probably once widespread in the grampians but has been reduced by fire. the species must be on the verge of extinction. drought-tolerant, the leaves orange when dormant. grows on exposed ferruginous sandstone with soil of ph 5. ;
original_text: Dwarf perennial, erect or reclining, to 15 cm high. Leaves flexible, 10-16 mm long, 0.5-0.7 mm wide; apex acuminate, brown; margins smooth; leaf-base margins tapering gradually from sheath, pale straw to light brown, with fine tangled hairs. Scapes 3-7 cm long, unjointed, persistent; head 6-10 mm long, 4-8 mm wide, with 4-12 flowers. Outer bracts of involucre 3-6, the longest 7-13 mm, smooth, the wings entire; inner bracts absent or up to 10, keeled, brown, with needle-like apex. Floral bracts inflexed, not imbricate, mucronate, brown. Perianth lobes linear. Anthers glandular. Seed not seen; testa of ovules colliculate. These plants produce ovules but do not set seed and the population survives by vegetative propagation. Probably once widespread in the Grampians but has been reduced by fire. The species must be on the verge of extinction. Drought-tolerant, the leaves orange when dormant. Grows on exposed ferruginous sandstone with soil of pH 5.

simplified_phrase: genus-level observation; flowering enhanced by hot summer fires
fire: flowering is stimulated by hot summer fires and the plants appear above ground the following spring.
description: small, leafless, terrestrial orchids with tuberous root system, occurring singly or in loose groups. plants brownish or purplish. raceme 1-few-flowered, with fleshy, loosely sheathing,  purplish bracts. flowers resupinate, opening widely for 1-few days, white or pink internally, purplish externally. dorsal sepal and labellum base forming a tube around column. dorsal sepal free, broader than lateral sepals, incurved over column. lateral sepals and petals of similar size, erect at base then curved forwards. labellum hinged by a short claw to column base. labellum lamina 3-lobed, thin-textured, striped, papillate on ventral and dorsal surfaces; lateral lobes incurved around column; midlobe small, apex papillate. callus of two p ridges, papillate. column slender, curved, narrowly winged. pollinia 2, clavate, yellow, no viscidium.  has an almost exclusive association with the scented paperbark melaleuca squarrosa, less commonly with species of leptospermum. non-flowering tuber presumably survives underground for several years in association with a mycorrhizal fungus. flowering is stimulated by hot summer fires and the plants appear above ground the following spring. the flowers have a peak opening period of two to three days when the segments are spread widely apart. after this they can remain open for up to 10 days, but at this stage the floral segments do not spread as widely apart. observations on marked flowering plants show no growth above ground for at least five years after flowering. burnettia cuneata is monocarpic and reproduces solely from seed. the parent tuber is withered at flowering time and no replacement tuber is produced. flowers are pollinated by small native bees that visit while the flowers are at the fully open stage. the flowers are fragrant, but produce no nectar. ;
original_text: Small, leafless, terrestrial orchids with tuberous root system, occurring singly or in loose groups. Plants brownish or purplish. Raceme 1-few-flowered, with fleshy, loosely sheathing, leaf-like purplish bracts. Flowers resupinate, opening widely for 1-few days, white or pink internally, purplish externally. Dorsal sepal and labellum base forming a tube around column. Dorsal sepal free, broader than lateral sepals, incurved over column. Lateral sepals and petals of similar size, erect at base then curved forwards. Labellum hinged by a short claw to column base. Labellum lamina 3-lobed, thin-textured, striped, papillate on ventral and dorsal surfaces; lateral lobes incurved around column; midlobe small, apex papillate. Callus of two plate-like ridges, papillate. Column slender, curved, narrowly winged. Pollinia 2, clavate, yellow, no viscidium.  Has an almost exclusive association with the Scented Paperbark Melaleuca squarrosa, less commonly with species of Leptospermum. Non-flowering tuber presumably survives underground for several years in association with a mycorrhizal fungus. Flowering is stimulated by hot summer fires and the plants appear above ground the following spring. The flowers have a peak opening period of two to three days when the segments are spread widely apart. After this they can remain open for up to 10 days, but at this stage the floral segments do not spread as widely apart. Observations on marked flowering plants show no growth above ground for at least five years after flowering. Burnettia cuneata is monocarpic and reproduces solely from seed. The parent tuber is withered at flowering time and no replacement tuber is produced. Flowers are pollinated by small native bees that visit while the flowers are at the fully open stage. The flowers are fragrant, but produce no nectar.

simplified_phrase: flowers only after hot summer fires
fire: the majority of plants flower only in the year after hot summer fires and large burnt swamps can produce masses of flowering plants. very few flowering plants (if any) occur in the second year after a fire.
description: plant dark purplish brown. basal bract , 10-20 x 6-8 mm. flower stem 50-130 mm tall, fleshy, brittle, 1-7-flowered. flowers fleshy, 10-12 x 20-25 mm, pink or white internally, externally brownish with darker veins and stripes; labellum with red stripes, especially the underside. dorsal sepal obovate, 10-13 x 3-4 mm, strongly hooded. lateral sepals oblanceolate, 10-13 x 3-4 mm, erect then spreading, divergent. petals narrowly lanceolate, 10-13 x 2.5 mm, erect then spreading or deflexed. labellum wedge-shaped, 6-7 x 6-7 mm, obscurely 3-lobed; lateral lobes incurved; midlobe short, blunt, outer surface minutely warty. callus of 2 plates breaking up into small calli.  highly localised and disjunct; growing in wet, peaty soils in dense, shrubby swamps containing thickets of scented paperbark and species of leptospermum. it is commonest in large, swampy areas, but small colonies of the orchid can occur in small, isolated swampy patches and seepage areas that support melaleuca squarrosa. the majority of plants flower only in the year after hot summer fires and large burnt swamps can produce masses of flowering plants. very few flowering plants (if any) occur in the second year after a fire. occasional plants produce two inflorescences at a time from a single tuber. flowers september-december. ;
original_text: Plant dark purplish brown. Basal bract leaf-like, 10-20 x 6-8 mm. Flower stem 50-130 mm tall, fleshy, brittle, 1-7-flowered. Flowers fleshy, 10-12 x 20-25 mm, pink or white internally, externally brownish with darker veins and stripes; labellum with red stripes, especially the underside. Dorsal sepal obovate, 10-13 x 3-4 mm, strongly hooded. Lateral sepals oblanceolate, 10-13 x 3-4 mm, erect then spreading, divergent. Petals narrowly lanceolate, 10-13 x 2.5 mm, erect then spreading or deflexed. Labellum wedge-shaped, 6-7 x 6-7 mm, obscurely 3-lobed; lateral lobes incurved; midlobe short, blunt, outer surface minutely warty. Callus of 2 plates breaking up into small calli.  Highly localised and disjunct; growing in wet, peaty soils in dense, shrubby swamps containing thickets of scented paperbark and species of Leptospermum. It is commonest in large, swampy areas, but small colonies of the orchid can occur in small, isolated swampy patches and seepage areas that support Melaleuca squarrosa. The majority of plants flower only in the year after hot summer fires and large burnt swamps can produce masses of flowering plants. Very few flowering plants (if any) occur in the second year after a fire. Occasional plants produce two inflorescences at a time from a single tuber. Flowers September-December.

simplified_phrase: inconclusive genus-level observation; resprouts from rhizomes after fire
fire: can be aggressive colonisers of marginal or disturbed sites, when regeneration from rhizomes (particularly after fire), can be rapid and extensive.
description: slender trees or shrubs, rarely to 20 m high; heteroblastic with noticeably different developmental stages. juvenile stages with leaves with dentate margin, clustered around spinescent short shoots; inflorescences are usually simple botrya or paired solitary flowers. adult stages with leaves entire, alternate or clustered; spinescent short shoots rare; inflorescences are generally leafy, bracteose panicles, pyramidal masses of flowers on third or fourth order lateral branching. a range of intermediate stages occur between these two stages, and several species in new south wales (bursaria cayzerae, longisepala) maintain juvenile stages. inflorescences with regular, protandrous, bisexual, occasionally staminate flowers in lower inflorescence branching (andromonoecy: bursaria spinosa, occidentalis, incana). sepals are green-cream, spreading from base, shed rapidly. petals free, white, yellowing with age and sex phase change, spreading star shaped from the base. stamens with versatile yellow anthers much shorter than the white, tapering filaments; dehiscence is from slits at petal break. pistil variably stalked, flattened  tomentose; ovary mostly bilocular, ovules numerous; style slender,stigma minute; staminate flowers with pistillode tissue. fruits are capsular, loculicidally and part septicidally dehiscent, green-brown, usually flattened, purse-shaped, chartaceous, becoming woodier with age, numerous, persisting on the bush/tree for many months after seed shed. seeds numerous, red-brown, dry, flat, reniform, often winged. the genus bursaria is most closely related to rhytidosporum, a genus of procumbent shrubs less than 0.5 m high without spinescent short shoots, but with similar fruit and seeds, found mainly in subalpine areas in eastern australia. this close affinity was first suggested by mueller (1862), when describing rhytidosporum, and again by mcgillivray (1962) when he reinstated rhytidosporum as a separate genus from bursaria. the more recent morphological analyses (cayzer et al. 1999) and trnl results (chandler et al. 2007) confirm this close relationship and place these taxa in a clade with auranticarpa, a genus of small trees with corymbose, bisexual inflorescences and capsular fruit containing black, dry seeds. intermediate stage vegetation of bursaria species is often confused with the spinose citriobatus group in pittosporum, but these latter taxa are dioecious (trees with mostly male or female flowers), and the rounded, orange, capsular fruit are filled with red orange, chunky seeds immersed in a sticky resin. important secondary components of forest, woodland and mallee ecosystems. can be aggressive colonisers of marginal or disturbed sites, when regeneration from rhizomes (particularly after fire), can be rapid and extensive. earlier developmental stages provide refugia for insects and small birds and animals as well as being an important food source when other flowering plants are rare. stands found in full sun are susceptible to massive insect attack, particularly white scale (eriococcidae). flowers summer, although occasional flowers all year. ;
original_text: Slender trees or shrubs, rarely to 20 m high; heteroblastic with noticeably different developmental stages. Juvenile stages with leaves with dentate margin, clustered around spinescent short shoots; inflorescences are usually simple botrya or paired solitary flowers. Adult stages with leaves entire, alternate or clustered; spinescent short shoots rare; inflorescences are generally leafy, bracteose panicles, pyramidal masses of flowers on third or fourth order lateral branching. A range of intermediate stages occur between these two stages, and several species in New South Wales (Bursaria cayzerae, B. longisepala) maintain juvenile stages. Inflorescences with regular, protandrous, bisexual, occasionally staminate flowers in lower inflorescence branching (andromonoecy: Bursaria spinosa, B. occidentalis, B. incana). Sepals are green-cream, spreading from base, shed rapidly. Petals free, white, yellowing with age and sex phase change, spreading star shaped from the base. Stamens with versatile yellow anthers much shorter than the white, tapering filaments; dehiscence is from slits at petal break. Pistil variably stalked, flattened  tomentose; ovary mostly bilocular, ovules numerous; style slender,stigma minute; staminate flowers with pistillode tissue. Fruits are capsular, loculicidally and part septicidally dehiscent, green-brown, usually flattened, purse-shaped, chartaceous, becoming woodier with age, numerous, persisting on the bush/tree for many months after seed shed. Seeds numerous, red-brown, dry, flat, reniform, often winged. The genus Bursaria is most closely related to Rhytidosporum, a genus of procumbent shrubs less than 0.5 m high without spinescent short shoots, but with similar fruit and seeds, found mainly in subalpine areas in Eastern Australia. This close affinity was first suggested by Mueller (1862), when describing Rhytidosporum, and again by McGillivray (1962) when he reinstated Rhytidosporum as a separate genus from Bursaria. The more recent morphological analyses (Cayzer et al. 1999) and trnL results (Chandler et al. 2007) confirm this close relationship and place these taxa in a clade with Auranticarpa, a genus of small trees with corymbose, bisexual inflorescences and capsular fruit containing black, dry seeds. Intermediate stage vegetation of Bursaria species is often confused with the spinose Citriobatus group in Pittosporum, but these latter taxa are dioecious (trees with mostly male or female flowers), and the rounded, orange, capsular fruit are filled with red orange, chunky seeds immersed in a sticky resin. Important secondary components of forest, woodland and mallee ecosystems. Can be aggressive colonisers of marginal or disturbed sites, when regeneration from rhizomes (particularly after fire), can be rapid and extensive. Earlier developmental stages provide refugia for insects and small birds and animals as well as being an important food source when other flowering plants are rare. Stands found in full sun are susceptible to massive insect attack, particularly white scale (Eriococcidae). Flowers summer, although occasional flowers all year.

fire: flowering is generally enhanced by hot summer fires, especially when densely overgrown vegetation is burnt.

original_text: Most above-ground parts of these terrestrial orchids are hairy. The plants have a single basal leaf that is usually much longer than wide and subtends a stiff flower stem that usually carries a single flower, but some species can have up to 6 flowers. Flower size ranges from small with 2 lateral sepals and petals projecting forwards like fingers, to large spidery flowers with spreading tepals ending in tailed, wispy or clubbed segments. A few species are distinctive for their bizarre-shaped flowers. The sepals and petals of each species are mostly very similar in size and shape. In many species the extended tips of the tepals are covered with scent-producing glands; sometimes the tips are replaced by thickened, club-like structures (osmophores) containing the glands. These glandular tails and clubs are the site of pseudopheromone production that is important for pollination. The labellum of each Caladenia species is markedly different to all the other floral segments in shape and is often also of a contrasting colour, especially the apical lobe which in many species is bright red to maroon. The labellum is hinged by a short claw to the base of the column, usually stiffly hinged but sometimes delicately balanced. Labellum shape ranges from unlobed to distinctly 3-lobed, with the lateral lobes often broad and curved upwards to flank the column; and usually arches longitudinally in a graceful curve, often with the apex recurved or coiled inwards. Labellum margins range from entire to adorned with a fringe of variously shaped marginal teeth, these sometimes fused into a thickened band. The centre of the labellum is adorned with rows of stalked or sessile, colourful calli in various shapes, decreasing in size towards the labellum apex. In some groups of Caladenia, the basal calli are a different size and colour to the rest. The column is narrowly to broadly winged and the anther carries four bilobed, flat pollinia without a viscidium. The pollen is usually yellow, occasionally white. Most Caladenia species occur as separate individuals, some form clonal colonies, and some grow in localised clonal tufts. The root system consists of a parent tuber and replacement tuber partially covered by a fibrous multilayered tunic which extends as a sheath to the soil surface and through which each annual shoot develops. Tubers are replaced annually on short droppers, the new one often deeper in the soil than the previous one. Each tuber adds a new layer of fibre to the inner side of the tunic. The sheath of old plants consists of several layers of fibre and is expanded at each point where a tuber has developed, these structures often forming an interlinked chain. At ground level the stem swells and forms a collar, which is the primary site of fungal infection.  Species of Caladenia occur in a wide range of forested, shrubby and heathy habitats from the coast to the inland plains, and from the lowlands to montane and subalpine areas. They mostly grow in soils with free drainage, but some species have adapted to seasonally moist, wet or peaty soils. Flowering is generally enhanced by hot summer fires, especially when densely overgrown vegetation is burnt. Species of Caladenia are deciduous and die back to a dormant, fleshy tuber over summer. The tuber sprouts after soaking autumn/winter rains and develops a leaf which expands and matures before an inflorescence is produced. Caladenia species use a range of strategies to achieve cross-pollination. Most species are sexually deceptive; fooling their insect pollinators into thinking they are a desirable insect mate. Several Caladenia species use food deception to attract other types of insects by pretending to offer a food reward. A small number of Caladenia species are self-pollinating. To achieve pollination by sexual deception, the orchid lures male thynnine wasps to the flower by producing a false sex hormone (kairomone or pseudopheromone) that mimics the sex scent released by a wingless female thynnine wasp when advertising for a mate. At close range, the shape, colour and tactile features of the flower persuade the male wasp to grapple with the labellum, either attempting to mate with it or fly away with the labellum for aerial mating. Passive pivoting movements of the labellum during the grappling process bring the wasp into proximity with the pollen, depositing the pollinia on the wasp's thorax, or on the stigma when the wasp visits a second flower. Recent research has shown that some wasp-pollinated spider orchids (e.g. C. arenaria, C. hastata, C. paludosa) produce small amounts of nectar on the labellum which probably acts both as a reward and an inducement for the wasp to continue visiting other flowers. Detailed studies indicate that most sexually deceptive species of Caladenia have a relationship with a single species of wasp (Phillips et al. 2009b). However, pollinator sharing can occur between species of wasp-pollinated Caladenia, indicating geographical variation in the composition of the wasp pheromone produced by the orchid (Colin Bower, pers. comm.). Cryptic species have been shown to occur within Caladenia concinna (Bower 2001a) and C. tentaculata (Phillips et al. 2009b). Most species of Caladenia that have colourful flowers use food deception to achieve pollination. Very few species produce visible quantities of nectar on the labellum (C. nana is an exception). This system of deceit is common in the small-flowered species but also found in several of the larger-flowered spider orchids and wispy spider orchids. Although very few studies have been undertaken, the pollinators are mostly small native bees of the families Apidae (social bees), Colletidae (plasterer bees) and Halictidae (sweat bees); also flies in the families Syrphidae (hover flies) and Conopidae (thick-headed flies). Nectar scarab beetles (Cetoniinae) pollinate C. flava. Introduced honey bees (Apis mellifera) have been observed visiting flowers and removing pollinia. No apparent close or specific relationship between the pollinator and the orchid species has been noted. Self-pollination is relatively rare in Caladenia, which is perhaps surprising considering that several species extend into montane areas with climates that are not particularly congenial to insects. Altogether, about 12 species of small-flowered Caladenia are known to be self-pollinating, as well as C. graminifolia and C. cruscula, and two subspecies of the Limestone Spider Orchid (C. bicalliata subsp. bicalliata and subsp. cleistogama). Most species flower in late winter, spring and early summer. Caladenia drummondii is an exception, flowering in winter while the leaf is still not fully expanded.

description: leaf 120-180 x 4-5 mm. flower stem 200-600 mm tall, 1-3-flowered. flowers 15-20 x 25-30 mm, bright pink, externally dusky pink; labellum dark pink, calli black; column pink with darker markings. dorsal sepal 16-20 x 3-3.5 mm. lateral sepals 16-20 x 4 mm, obliquely deflexed. petals 16-20 x 3 mm. labellum 8-10 x 4.5-5.5 mm; lateral lobes entire; midlobe narrow, recurved. calli black, shiny, in 2 broad rows, densely crowded at labellum apex. column 7.5-8.5 x 3 mm, narrowly winged. hybridises with caladenia hildae. widespread but generally scattered and uncommon; growing among shrubs and tussocks in coastal scrub in sandy or peaty soil; also on montane ridges in shallow stony soil; in w vic. plants grow in dense, wet heathland and flowering is enhanced by summer fires. this species has a remarkable pollination relationship. its brightly coloured flowers probably attract insects seeking food, but the real situation is more complex. the apical part of the labellum, which protrudes noticeably from front of flower, is densely covered with crowded black calli and looks like a resting bee. male native bees, specifically hylaeus quadriceps (family colletidae), have been observed trying to mate with this 'false bee', eventually coming into contact with the anther and stigma of the orchid when their activities cause the labellum to tilt forwards (kuiter & findlater-smith 2017). flowers october-january. ;
original_text: Leaf 120-180 x 4-5 mm. Flower stem 200-600 mm tall, 1-3-flowered. Flowers 15-20 x 25-30 mm, bright pink, externally dusky pink; labellum dark pink, calli black; column pink with darker markings. Dorsal sepal 16-20 x 3-3.5 mm. Lateral sepals 16-20 x 4 mm, obliquely deflexed. Petals 16-20 x 3 mm. Labellum 8-10 x 4.5-5.5 mm; lateral lobes entire; midlobe narrow, recurved. Calli black, shiny, in 2 broad rows, densely crowded at labellum apex. Column 7.5-8.5 x 3 mm, narrowly winged. Hybridises with Caladenia hildae. Widespread but generally scattered and uncommon; growing among shrubs and tussocks in coastal scrub in sandy or peaty soil; also on montane ridges in shallow stony soil; in W Vic. plants grow in dense, wet heathland and flowering is enhanced by summer fires. This species has a remarkable pollination relationship. Its brightly coloured flowers probably attract insects seeking food, but the real situation is more complex. The apical part of the labellum, which protrudes noticeably from front of flower, is densely covered with crowded black calli and looks like a resting bee. Male native bees, specifically Hylaeus quadriceps (family Colletidae), have been observed trying to mate with this 'false bee', eventually coming into contact with the anther and stigma of the orchid when their activities cause the labellum to tilt forwards (Kuiter & Findlater-Smith 2017). Flowers October-January.

Labellum 13-17 x 7-9 mm, cream to red, often with darker veins; margins with numerous reddish or purplish teeth to 2 mm long; tip recurved. Basal calli 6-8, c. 1 mm long. Lamina calli to 1 mm long, cream, yellowish or purplish, sparse in 4 or 6 rows to labellum bend; margins with numerous slender, red teeth. Column 10-12 x 3-4 mm, translucent with red markings; basal glands c. 1 mm long, ovoid, yellow with red hairs. Hybridises with Caladenia ampla. Localised, growing in open areas among shrubs on slopes in stunted to tall forest in freely draining gravelly soil and laterite. Flowering is greatly enhanced by summer fires. Flowers late August-October.

Flowers freely in the absence of fire, but flowering plants are much easier to see on burnt ground. It usually occurs as solitary plants, but is sometimes seen crowded together in tufts. Flowers September-October.

Flowering is enhanced by summer fires. Flowers produce nectar on the labellum and are pollinated by native bees, particularly female Lasioglossum clelandii (Faast et al. (2009); a common syrphid fly, Simosyrphus grandicornis, also visited the flowers and may play a role in pollination. For details on biology and ecology see also Bates (1984). Flowers August-October.

(which match the type specimens), and are also often confused with caladenia atrovespa. hybridises with argocalla, formosa and venusta. widespread and common from coast to foothills and lower ranges in areas of reliable higher rainfall; often growing on slopes and flats among shrubs and grass in heath, heathy forest, woodland, and open forest in freely draining, fertile loams. a large, impressive species that colonises disturbed sites such as tracks and clearings. flowering is enhanced by summer fires. the flowers are pollinated by males of a large, black thynnine wasp, thynnoides pugionatus, attracted by sexual deceit. flowers september-december. ;
original_text: Leaf lanceolate, 80-150 x 12-20 mm, with prominent short, white, silky hairs. Flower stem 150-500 mm tall, sturdy, densely hairy, 1-3-flowered. Flowers reclining, 60-100 mm across, green with red central stripes; sepals with brown or yellowish brown clubs 7-12 x 1 mm; petals lacking clubs. Dorsal sepal incurved, 60-80 x 2.5-4 mm, apex becoming lax. Lateral sepals stiffly curved down at base then upswept, tips often swept forwards or obliquely erect, becoming lax with age, 60-80 x 4-5mm, nearly parallel. Petals stiffly decurved, 60-70 x 2-3 mm. Labellum very delicately hinged, 16-20 x 20-25 mm, green with white central patch and maroon apex; basal margins with 5-8 pairs of thin, green comb-teeth to 10 mm long; midlobe margins with numerous short, blunt teeth; tip recurved. Basal calli c. 5 mm long. Lamina calli to 2 mm long, slender, reddish black, clubbed, in 4 uncrowded rows onto base of maroon patch. Column incurved, 17-20 x 4-5.5 mm, greenish with red markings; basal glands c. 4 mm long, narrowly club-shaped, shortly stalked, yellow, shiny. The labellum of this species is delicately balanced and highly tremulous, vibrating even in light breeze. It is often seen balanced in a position away from column. Plants in SE N.S.W. and E Vic. typically have smaller flowers than those from S.A. and W Vic. (which match the type specimens), and are also often confused with Caladenia atrovespa. Hybridises with C. argocalla, C. formosa and C. venusta. Widespread and common from coast to foothills and lower ranges in areas of reliable higher rainfall; often growing on slopes and flats among shrubs and grass in heath, heathy forest, woodland, and open forest in freely draining, fertile loams. A large, impressive species that colonises disturbed sites such as tracks and clearings. Flowering is enhanced by summer fires. The flowers are pollinated by males of a large, black thynnine wasp, Thynnoides pugionatus, attracted by sexual deceit. Flowers September-December.

Column incurved, 11-15 x 5-5.5 mm, mostly transparent with red flecks; basal glands c. 1.3 mm long, ovoid, yellow with red hairs. Hybridises with Caladenia formosa, C. tentaculata and C. necrophylla. Widespread and locally common, especially in coastal and near-coastal areas; growing in heathland, heathy forest and open forest, in freely draining or moisture-retentive sands and loams. Flowering is greatly enhanced by summer fires. Pollination is by sexual deceit involving male thynnine wasps. Flowers September-November.

description: a natural hybrid between caladenia gladiolata and a member of the patersonii group (probably flindersica or saxatilis). creamy green to whitish green flowers 70-90 mm across. stiffly spreading sepals and petals with large, conspicuous, blackish, bay clubs. greenish labellum has 7-9 pairs of marginal teeth to 1.5 mm long. the flowers exude strong odour. localised; found growing in woodland dominated by eucalyptus cladocalyx with sparse, shrubby understorey in brown, stony loam. this distinctive hybrid appeared in the season following a hot summer fire.  flowers august-september. ;
original_text: A natural hybrid between Caladenia gladiolata and a member of the C. patersonii group (probably C. flindersica or C. saxatilis). Creamy green to whitish green flowers 70-90 mm across. Stiffly spreading sepals and petals with large, conspicuous, blackish, bayonet-like clubs. Greenish labellum has 7-9 pairs of marginal teeth to 1.5 mm long. The flowers exude strong odour. Localised; found growing in woodland dominated by Eucalyptus cladocalyx with sparse, shrubby understorey in brown, stony loam. This distinctive hybrid appeared in the season following a hot summer fire.  Flowers August-September.

It has pale yellow to whitish flowers about 25 mm across; relatively narrow segments bearing brownish hairs on the exterior; and a small, whitish yellow labellum with 2 rows of calli set on a central plate.  Granite outcrops and heathy or grassy flats. This hybrid forms extensive vegetative tufts and colonies and flowers freely, especially after fire. Flowers September-November.

original_text: A natural hybrid between Caladenia flava and C. latifolia. It has pale pink to cerise or apricot-coloured flowers about 40 mm across with yellow central suffusions; and a short, three-lobed labellum with 2 rows of calli on a central plate; the sepals and petals sometimes have distinctive, irregular, reddish stripes. Natural crosses between Caladenia flava and C. reptans or C. nana can also produce similar progeny. Grows in a range of shrubby and forested habitats. Forms small groups and localised clonal colonies that flower freely after fire. Flowers August-October.

description: leaf 80-120 x 6-8 mm, green with reddish pink streaks and dark spots. flower stem 200-500 mm tall, very thin and wiry, 1-5-flowered. flowers resembling a duck in flight, 20-25 x 6-7 mm, reddish brown, shiny, labellum darker. perianth segments 12-15 mm long, narrow, channelled, tips pointed. dorsal sepal elliptical when flattened, decurved close to column, 12-15 x 4.5-5 mm, apex mucronate. lateral sepals recurved behind labellum, margins incurved, oblong-elliptical when flattened, 12-15 x 2.5-3 mm, apex curved, pointed. petals recurved against column wings, margins incurved, oblong when flattened, 12-15 x 1-1.3 mm, apex subobtuse. labellum horizontal to obliquely erect when set; labellum strap 8-9 x 2-2.5 mm, green with thickened margins. labellum lamina shaped like a duck's head and bill, 6.5-8 x 5-6 mm, smooth, shiny, dark reddish purple, beak sometimes greenish; basal lobe circa 3.5 x 2.5 mm, , incurved back under labellum lamina. column reddish, 10-12 x 5 mm, tapered upwards when viewed from front, broadly winged from base to apex. anther circa 3 mm long, without a beak. pollinia oblong-falcate, circa 3 mm long. stigma circular, circa 3 mm across. the ribs of the capsule, which is rarely seen, are strongly winged. this orchid is very popular with visitors to the bush because of the remarkable resemblance the flowers have to a flying duck. widespread and common, especially on the coast and coastal ranges, but also further inland on higher ranges and tablelands. found growing in open forest, heathy forest, heathland, tea-tree scrub and under sheoaks, usually in freely draining sand, gravel or clay loam, very occasionally in sandy peat over quartz gravel; also colonises disturbed sites such as walking tracks, road embankments and gravel scrapes. the orchid grows in small, sparse, clonal colonies, sometimes close to the base of trees. it flowers freely without fire, but flowering is promoted when dense habitats are burnt. it is also often seen flowering in mowed or slashed areas. usually only 1 or 2 flowers are open at any time. the flowers are sturdy and quite long-lived, lasting for several weeks if not pollinated or burnt by bushfires. in dry seasons the leaves are often withered by the time flowering takes place. the final flowers of the season, which open towards the end of spring, survive well into summer if conditions are amenable. flowers have even been recorded as late as may, a six-month flowering period (jones 1970). remarkably these plants were flowering alongside the emerged leaves of the next generation.  patience is needed when studying the pollination of caleana major, as insect visitation is meagre in natural populations and insects are not readily attracted to flowers placed out during baiting studies. a couple of reports showed that the flowers of major attracted the attention of male sawflies which become effectively trapped between the triggered labellum and the column. the sawflies were identified as lophyrotoma leachii (cady 1965) from observations made at narooma, n.s.w.; and a species of pterygophorus (bates 1989) near wauchope, n.s.photographs of four species of lophyrotoma trapped in the flowers and/or carrying pollinia are presented in kuiter (2016, page 111 and 2017). identified as interrupta, nigripes, ramosa and zonalis, these images clearly show the sawfly on the labellum with its head held close to the beak, or trapped headfirst between the labellum and column. sexual deception most likely plays a role in the pollination of this species and at least one image in kuiter 2017 shows a male sawfly standing on the beak of the ducks-head labellum with its abdomen apparently probing the head in a pseudocopulatory posture. further research is obviously needed to determine the number of sawfly species involved in the pollination of major. the flowers of major can be very long-lived (6-10 weeks) and successful pollination is rare. indeed, the pioneering australian orchid botanist r.fitzgerald records seeing no insect visits and only 4 capsules developing in a population of 127 flowers that he monitored in 1878 near sydney. by comparison, caleana minor is much more frequently pollinated and commonly produces capsules. for more details on caleana major pollination see bower 2001: 141-143. flowers september-february. ;
original_text: Leaf 80-120 x 6-8 mm, green with reddish pink streaks and dark spots. Flower stem 200-500 mm tall, very thin and wiry, 1-5-flowered. Flowers resembling a duck in flight, 20-25 x 6-7 mm, reddish brown, shiny, labellum darker. Perianth segments 12-15 mm long, narrow, channelled, tips pointed. Dorsal sepal elliptical when flattened, decurved close to column, 12-15 x 4.5-5 mm, apex mucronate. Lateral sepals recurved behind labellum, margins incurved, oblong-elliptical when flattened, 12-15 x 2.5-3 mm, apex curved, pointed. Petals recurved against column wings, margins incurved, oblong when flattened, 12-15 x 1-1.3 mm, apex subobtuse. Labellum horizontal to obliquely erect when set; labellum strap 8-9 x 2-2.5 mm, green with thickened margins. Labellum lamina shaped like a duck's head and bill, 6.5-8 x 5-6 mm, smooth, shiny, dark reddish purple, beak sometimes greenish; basal lobe c. 3.5 x 2.5 mm, tail-like, incurved back under labellum lamina. Column reddish, 10-12 x 5 mm, tapered upwards when viewed from front, broadly winged from base to apex. Anther c. 3 mm long, without a beak. Pollinia oblong-falcate, c. 3 mm long. Stigma circular, c. 3 mm across. The ribs of the capsule, which is rarely seen, are strongly winged. This orchid is very popular with visitors to the bush because of the remarkable resemblance the flowers have to a flying duck. Widespread and common, especially on the coast and coastal ranges, but also further inland on higher ranges and tablelands. Found growing in open forest, heathy forest, heathland, tea-tree scrub and under sheoaks, usually in freely draining sand, gravel or clay loam, very occasionally in sandy peat over quartz gravel; also colonises disturbed sites such as walking tracks, road embankments and gravel scrapes. The orchid grows in small, sparse, clonal colonies, sometimes close to the base of trees. It flowers freely without fire, but flowering is promoted when dense habitats are burnt. It is also often seen flowering in mowed or slashed areas. Usually only 1 or 2 flowers are open at any time. The flowers are sturdy and quite long-lived, lasting for several weeks if not pollinated or burnt by bushfires. In dry seasons the leaves are often withered by the time flowering takes place. The final flowers of the season, which open towards the end of spring, survive well into summer if conditions are amenable. Flowers have even been recorded as late as May, a six-month flowering period (Jones 1970). Remarkably these plants were flowering alongside the emerged leaves of the next generation.  Patience is needed when studying the pollination of Caleana major, as insect visitation is meagre in natural populations and insects are not readily attracted to flowers placed out during baiting studies. A couple of reports showed that the flowers of C. major attracted the attention of male sawflies which become effectively trapped between the triggered labellum and the column. The sawflies were identified as Lophyrotoma leachii (Cady 1965) from observations made at Narooma, N.S.W.; and a species of Pterygophorus (Bates 1989) near Wauchope, N.S.W. Photographs of four species of Lophyrotoma trapped in the flowers and/or carrying pollinia are presented in Kuiter (2016, page 111 and 2017). Identified as L. interrupta, L. nigripes, L. ramosa and L. zonalis, these images clearly show the sawfly on the labellum with its head held close to the beak, or trapped headfirst between the labellum and column. Sexual deception most likely plays a role in the pollination of this species and at least one image in Kuiter 2017 shows a male sawfly standing on the beak of the ducks-head labellum with its abdomen apparently probing the head in a pseudocopulatory posture. Further research is obviously needed to determine the number of sawfly species involved in the pollination of C. major. The flowers of C. major can be very long-lived (6-10 weeks) and successful pollination is rare. Indeed, the pioneering Australian orchid botanist R.D. Fitzgerald records seeing no insect visits and only 4 capsules developing in a population of 127 flowers that he monitored in 1878 near Sydney. By comparison, Caleana minor is much more frequently pollinated and commonly produces capsules. For more details on Caleana major pollination see Bower 2001: 141-143. Flowers September-February.

fire: all stilt-rooted species are known to be killed by fire. 1998) following fire, while all adult plants had been killed. it takes (2) 3-5 or more years for these species to flower and presumably a substantially longer period to attain maximum reproductive potential, therefore fire frequency must be carefully controlled to ensure survival of the species. first flowering of some juvenile plants of cyanea was observed in 2005 following post-fire germination in 1999.
description: stilt-rooted or rhizomatous perennial undershrubs with sand-binding roots. stems erect or occasionally spreading. leaves sessile, alternate, linear, the base indurated and closely sheathing stem, persistent; sheath closely appressed to stem, persistent. flowers actinomorphic, bisexual, sessile, terminal, solitary, surrounded by scarious bracts, scentless. sepals and petals undifferentiated, united in a tube in lower half, the lobes spreading horizontally, chartaceous or thinly coriaceous, blue or purple, fading white, or brown with red or russet markings, variously pubescent outside. stamens inserted at base of perianth lobes; anthers attached at base, linear, prominently exserted, yellow, usually turning red or brown with age, anther filaments sigmoidal to straight. ovary 1-locular, superior; ovules 3, basally attached. style slender, exserted,  turned to one side, exceeding stamens; stigma simple. fruit indehiscent (anthocarpous), 1-seeded, falling with perianth. seed oblong, with a membranous testa. the australian plant census treats this genus within the family calectasiaceae. often confused with calytrix (myrtaceae) due to the chartaceous perianth common to both genera. indeed, in describing the new genus scaryomyrtus in a letter to joseph hooker (written from the field and probably published without mueller's permission), mueller allied the genus to calycothrix and lhotzkya, two genera now considered synonymous with calytrix, not realising until later that it was actually a monocot (barrett & wilson 2007, wilson & barrett 2010).  calectasia species are either obligate seeders (stilt-rooted species) or resprouters (rhizomatous species). all stilt-rooted species have epicormic buds above the soil surface while rhizomatous species have epicormic buds below the soil surface. stilt-rooted species take two forms, obligate stilting species (elegans, gracilis, obtusa, palustris and pignattiana) and facultative stilting species (browneana and cyanea). for obligate stilting species, stilt roots may not be observable above ground in the first three years of growth. all stilt-rooted species are known to be killed by fire. hundreds of seedlings have been observed of gracilis (keighery pers. comm.) and pignattiana (brown et al. 1998) following fire, while all adult plants had been killed. it takes (2) 3-5 or more years for these species to flower and presumably a substantially longer period to attain maximum reproductive potential, therefore fire frequency must be carefully controlled to ensure survival of the species. first flowering of some juvenile plants of cyanea was observed in 2005 following post-fire germination in 1999. ;
original_text: Stilt-rooted or rhizomatous perennial undershrubs with sand-binding roots. Stems erect or occasionally spreading. Leaves sessile, alternate, linear, the base indurated and closely sheathing stem, persistent; sheath closely appressed to stem, persistent. Flowers actinomorphic, bisexual, sessile, terminal, solitary, surrounded by scarious bracts, scentless. Sepals and petals undifferentiated, united in a tube in lower half, the lobes spreading horizontally, chartaceous or thinly coriaceous, blue or purple, fading white, or brown with red or russet markings, variously pubescent outside. Stamens inserted at base of perianth lobes; anthers attached at base, linear, prominently exserted, yellow, usually turning red or brown with age, anther filaments sigmoidal to straight. Ovary 1-locular, superior; ovules 3, basally attached. Style slender, exserted,  turned to one side, exceeding stamens; stigma simple. Fruit indehiscent (anthocarpous), 1-seeded, falling with perianth. Seed oblong, with a membranous testa. The Australian Plant Census treats this genus within the family Calectasiaceae. Often confused with Calytrix (Myrtaceae) due to the chartaceous perianth common to both genera. Indeed, in describing the new genus Scaryomyrtus in a letter to Joseph Hooker (written from the field and probably published without Mueller's permission), Mueller allied the genus to Calycothrix and Lhotzkya, two genera now considered synonymous with Calytrix, not realising until later that it was actually a monocot (Barrett & Wilson 2007, Wilson & Barrett 2010).  Calectasia species are either obligate seeders (stilt-rooted species) or resprouters (rhizomatous species). All stilt-rooted species have epicormic buds above the soil surface while rhizomatous species have epicormic buds below the soil surface. Stilt-rooted species take two forms, obligate stilting species (C. elegans, C. gracilis, C. obtusa, C. palustris and C. pignattiana) and facultative stilting species (C. browneana and C. cyanea). For obligate stilting species, stilt roots may not be observable above ground in the first three years of growth. All stilt-rooted species are known to be killed by fire. Hundreds of seedlings have been observed of C. gracilis (G. Keighery pers. comm.) and C. pignattiana (Brown et al. 1998) following fire, while all adult plants had been killed. It takes (2) 3-5 or more years for these species to flower and presumably a substantially longer period to attain maximum reproductive potential, therefore fire frequency must be carefully controlled to ensure survival of the species. First flowering of some juvenile plants of C. cyanea was observed in 2005 following post-fire germination in 1999.
