description: herb, dioecious, caespitose, perennial, with few or many culms from a narrow base; plants all female, setting abundant seed apomictically (parthenogenetic); male plants not known; cluster and sand-binding roots present. cataphylls short, to 10 mm long, pale brown. culms unbranched but with clusters of circa 40 branchlets at most nodes, erect, terete, minutely tuberculate, pubescent, bright green, to 40 cm high, 1.0-1.4 (-2.5) mm diam.; internodes 5-17, 1-6 cm long, often largely exposed and not hidden by branchlets; branchlets numerous, straight to curved or reflexed, slender, to 2 (-2.5) cm long, laterally flattened and rectangular or narrow-deltoid in section. sheaths 7-13 mm long, sparsely pilose, often reflexed, lamina erect, 2-6 mm long. spikelets (female) mostly sessile among the bases of the branchlets, numerous at each culm node, occasionally terminal on branchlets, ovoid, 4.0-6.0 mm long, 1-flowered; glumes 4-6, broad-ovate, obtuse, 1.7-3.0 mm long, straw-coloured, abaxial surface glabrous or pilose, mucro to 0.8 mm long; the uppermost glume imbricate and persistent around the fruit after dehiscence forming a rigid striate conical coat. female flowers lacking tepals; ovary unilocular; the style unbranched, slender, red, the nut closely enwrapped with the striate uppermost glume. nut ovoid, 1-1.8 mm long, with a short filiform apical beak; the pericarp soft and almost hyaline, with the brown seed visible through the pericarp; shed enclosed in the rigid striate innermost glume, with a short (0.7-1 mm) stipe below the glume. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma continuous, of a single layer of peg cells. the enwrapping of the fruit by the rigid uppermost glume is so seamless as not to be obvious. only striations due to the glume veins show that the fruit is enwrapped. this feature is shared with desmocladus diacolpicus (also parthenogenetic) and glomeratus (apparently dioecious). heath and woodland on sands in low rainfall regions; sites seasonally moist. presumably apomictic; males not known. killed by fire; regenerates by seed after fire (meney, pate & hickman 1999). flowers august-september (hollister & thiele 2014). ;

Culms unbranched but with clusters of c. 40 branchlets at most nodes, erect, terete, minutely tuberculate, pubescent, bright green, to 40 cm high, 1.0-1.4 (-2.5) mm diam.; internodes 5-17, 1-6 cm long, often largely exposed and not hidden by branchlets; branchlets numerous, straight to curved or reflexed, slender, to 2 (-2.5) cm long, laterally flattened and rectangular or narrow-deltoid in section. Sheaths 7-13 mm long, sparsely pilose, often reflexed, lamina erect, 2-6 mm long. Spikelets (female) mostly sessile among the bases of the branchlets, numerous at each culm node, occasionally terminal on branchlets, ovoid, 4.0-6.0 mm long, 1-flowered; glumes 4-6, broad-ovate, obtuse, 1.7-3.0 mm long, straw-coloured, abaxial surface glabrous or pilose, mucro to 0.8 mm long; the uppermost glume imbricate and persistent around the fruit after dehiscence forming a rigid striate conical coat. Female flowers lacking tepals; ovary unilocular; the style unbranched, slender, red, the nut closely enwrapped with the striate uppermost glume. Nut ovoid, 1-1.8 mm long, with a short filiform apical beak; the pericarp soft and almost hyaline, with the brown seed visible through the pericarp; shed enclosed in the rigid striate innermost glume, with a short (0.7-1 mm) stipe below the glume. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma continuous, of a single layer of peg cells. The enwrapping of the fruit by the rigid uppermost glume is so seamless as not to be obvious. Only striations due to the glume veins show that the fruit is enwrapped. This feature is shared with Desmocladus diacolpicus (also parthenogenetic) and D. glomeratus (apparently dioecious). Heath and woodland on sands in low rainfall regions; sites seasonally moist. Presumably apomictic; males not known. Killed by fire; regenerates by seed after fire (Meney, Pate & Hickman 1999). Flowers August-September (Hollister & Thiele 2014).

description: herb, dioecious, caespitose, perennial, forming small tussocks; cluster and sand-binding roots present. cataphylls short, 4-12 mm long, pale brown. culms erect, concavo-convex, tuberculate, green and glabrous to grey and densely pubescent with short hairs, 10-26 cm high, 0.8-1.5 mm wide, internodes 3-6; branchlets 1-3 (-4) at most nodes, straight to flexuose, floriferous, 4-6 cm long. sheaths appressed, mostly red-brown or dark brown, 3.5-7.5 mm long, truncate, glabrous apart from an apical fringe of white cilia; lamina erect, circa 0.5-2.8 mm long. male spikelets borne singly, terminal on branchlets, ovoid, 5.0-8.0 mm long, 10-14-flowered; glumes 10-14, ovate-lanceolate, 4.0-6.0 mm long, pale brown, rigid, acute, apical margin villous, mucro 0.9-1.5 mm long. female spikelets borne singly, terminal on branchlets, ellipsoid, 4-5 mm long, 1-flowered; glumes 4-6, ovate, acute, 2.3-4.0 mm long, reddish brown to pale brown, apical margin ciliate, mucro to 1.2 mm long. male flowers: tepals 2-5, oblanceolate, equal in length or inner tepals slightly shorter, 3.2-5.3 mm long; lower flowers frequently with more tepals than upper flowers; anthers exserted,1.2-1.7 mm long. female flowers lacking tepals, ovary unilocular, style 1, mostly stigmatic. nut (immature) narrow-ovoid, brown with 2 pale lateral lines, circa 2 mm long, including a short broad stipe and an apical stylar beak. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma continuous, of a single layer of peg cells. green glabrous plants and grey tomentose plants often occur mixed in the same location. deep sand, sometimes over laterite, in heath and woodland; in moderately low rainfall regions; sites seasonally moist. killed by fire, regenerates by seed after fire. wind-pollinated. flowers august-november (hollister & thiele 2014). ;

description: herb, dioecious, caespitose, perennial, mostly forming narrow-based plants of few or many culms; cluster and sand-binding roots present. cataphylls straw-coloured, short, circa 1 cm long. culms erect, terete, smooth to slightly striate, glabrous or pubescent, with long villous hairs, to 65 cm long, 0.5-2.0 mm diam.; internodes numerous, often partly exposed and not hidden by branchlets; branchlets numerous, slender, usually flexuose or tightly curled to expose internode; branchlets 6-35 per node, to 11 cm long. sheaths lax, often reflexed, ovate to spathulate, 10-27 mm long; apex obcordate; lamina erect, 2.5-11 mm long. inflorescences: male and female inflorescences similar, sessile, terminal and axillary on primary and secondary branchlets. male spikelets borne singly or in pairs, ovoid, 3.0-6.5 mm long; subtending bract circa one third length of spikelet; mucro 0.8-1.0 mm long; glumes 12-22, narrow-elliptic, glabrous, acuminate, 1.5-2.3 mm long; mucro 0.3-1.2 mm long. female spikelets borne singly, narrow-ovoid, 7.2-8.0 mm long, 1-flowered; subtending bract 1.5-2.1 mm long, circa ½ length of spikelet, with a mucro 1.1-2.5 mm long; glumes 4-6, broad-ovate, acute, 2-5.3 mm long, abaxial surface occasionally partially villous; mucro to 2.2 mm long, thin, brown, glabrous. male flowers: tepals 5, scarious, oblanceolate, acute, apex blunt,  equal in length, 1.5-2.8 mm long; anthers 0.9-1.3 mm long. female flowers: 1-5 tepals occasionally present; ovary unilocular, style 1, mostly stigmatic. nut narrow-ovoid, 2- 2.5 mm long, dark brown with pale lateral lines; with a short stipe and the style forming a conical beak. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma continuous. grows in sand, or sand with laterite, in inland rather than coastal sites, mostly in heath and shrubland. killed by fire, regeneration is by seed. wind-pollinated. flowers august-november (hollister & thiele 2014). ;

description: shrubs to small trees, sometimes scandent (calyptrotheca taitensis, not in australia), sometimes ca in appearance (didiereoideae, not in australia); stems often slightly succulent when young, becoming woody with age, usually differentiated into long and short shoots; short shoots (when present) producing leaves only or leaves and spines (paired or solitary) (in didiereoideae); tannin deposits (in didiereoideae and portulacaria, not  known in calyptrotheca, not in australia) present; dioecious (often), gynodioecious (decaryia, not in australia), monoecious, or hermaphroditic; glabrous (except for woolly hairs which may be present on the filaments). leaves usually opposite and decussate or sometimes alternate or clustered (calyptrotheca), borne singly or in pairs, sessile or subsessile, simple, leathery to succulent, flat to terete; stipules absent. inflorescences are thyrses, panicles to cymes, often fasciculate. flowers usually unisexual (but some vestiges of the opposite sex present) and then plants dioecious, or flowers bisexual (calyptrotheca, and in some portulacaria) or sometimes gynodioecious (some portulacaria species), actinomorphic, small or showy, sometimes subtended by 1 or few s bracts (not to be confused with sepaloids, which some authors have termed 'bracts'). sepaloids 2, equal or unequal, usually persistent. petaloids 4 and usually in 2 series (didiereoideae), or 5 (calyptrotheca and portulacaria), free or connate at base. stamens (4-) 5-20 or up to 60 (calyptrotheca), the filaments free, weakly adnate to the annular nectary or adnate to the petaloids, the filaments often woolly; anthers tetrasporangiate, dithecal, dorsifixed, dehiscing by longitudinal slits. pistillate flowers often with staminodes and an annular nectary. gynoecium of (2-) 3 (-4) connate carpels. ovary superior, with (2-) 3 (-4) locules; placentation basal; style 1, apical, simple; stigma usually irregularly strongly to hardly (2-) 3-lobed. ovules 1 or up to 6 (calyptrotheca) per locule. fruit a 1-seeded dry indehiscent capsule enclosed in a pair of bracts, a dry or slightly fleshy nutlet with membranous wings (portulacaria), a samara (in some portulacaria) or a 1-(rarely 2-) seeded 6-valved basally circumscissile capsule (calyptrotheca). seeds with a small funicular strophiole or an aril; endosperm undeveloped. didiereaceae are a dominant and characteristic feature of the semi-arid spiny forests of madagascar. the stems of the many species are used for firewood by the local people, which has endangered many species. ;
original_text: Shrubs to small trees, sometimes scandent (Calyptrotheca taitensis, not in Australia), sometimes cactus-like in appearance (Didiereoideae, not in Australia); stems often slightly succulent when young, becoming woody with age, usually differentiated into long and short shoots; short shoots (when present) producing leaves only or leaves and spines (paired or solitary) (in Didiereoideae); tannin deposits (in Didiereoideae and Portulacaria, not  known in Calyptrotheca, not in Australia) present; dioecious (often), gynodioecious (Decaryia, not in Australia), monoecious, or hermaphroditic; glabrous (except for woolly hairs which may be present on the filaments). Leaves usually opposite and decussate or sometimes alternate or clustered (Calyptrotheca), borne singly or in pairs, sessile or subsessile, simple, leathery to succulent, flat to terete; stipules absent. Inflorescences are thyrses, panicles to cymes, often fasciculate. Flowers usually unisexual (but some vestiges of the opposite sex present) and then plants dioecious, or flowers bisexual (Calyptrotheca, and in some Portulacaria) or sometimes gynodioecious (some Portulacaria species), actinomorphic, small or showy, sometimes subtended by 1 or few scale-like bracts (not to be confused with sepaloids, which some authors have termed 'bracts'). Sepaloids 2, equal or unequal, usually persistent. Petaloids 4 and usually in 2 series (Didiereoideae), or 5 (Calyptrotheca and Portulacaria), free or connate at base. Stamens (4-) 5-20 or up to 60 (Calyptrotheca), the filaments free, weakly adnate to the annular nectary or adnate to the petaloids, the filaments often woolly; anthers tetrasporangiate, dithecal, dorsifixed, dehiscing by longitudinal slits. Pistillate flowers often with staminodes and an annular nectary. Gynoecium of (2-) 3 (-4) connate carpels. Ovary superior, with (2-) 3 (-4) locules; placentation basal; style 1, apical, simple; stigma usually irregularly strongly to hardly (2-) 3-lobed. Ovules 1 or up to 6 (Calyptrotheca) per locule. Fruit a 1-seeded dry indehiscent capsule enclosed in a pair of bracts, a dry or slightly fleshy nutlet with membranous wings (Portulacaria), a samara (in some Portulacaria) or a 1-(rarely 2-) seeded 6-valved basally circumscissile capsule (Calyptrotheca). Seeds with a small funicular strophiole or an aril; endosperm undeveloped. Didiereaceae are a dominant and characteristic feature of the semi-arid spiny forests of Madagascar. The stems of the many species are used for firewood by the local people, which has endangered many species.

description: herb, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial, forming extensive patches. rhizomes stout, densely covered with red-brown or yellow-brown hairs. culms much-branched, upper branches often flexuose and sometimes forming dense trailing masses, terete, striate, glabrous, with persistent appressed sheaths. male and female inflorescences similar, of spikelets terminal on culms or culm branches or sessile in the axil of an upper node; erect, elongated, cylindrical, many-flowered. flowers with 6 tepals, 2 outer tepals keeled, the keel densely red-brown pubescent. male flowers with 3 stamens, anthers exserted. female flowers with a 2-locular ovary and 2 style branches strongly recurved and shortly connate at the base. fruit a capsule. seed surface smooth with longitudinal lines of transversely-elongated rectangular cells. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 1 or 2 layers of somewhat elongated peg cells, interrupted by greatly enlarged epidermal cells that meet and interrupt the parenchyma sheath over girders opposite some outer vascular bundles (mostly over alternate bundles), pillar and protective cells absent, central cavity usually present. meney et al. (1999) report the presence of pillar cells dividing the chlorenchyma but we did not observe them to be present. reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. peg cells are pali chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. pillar cells are elongate, pali cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened (lignified) walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. girders are sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles, extending from the sclerenchyma sheath all or part-way through the chlorenchyma. protective cells are modified chlorenchyma cells that are thick-walled and line the substomatal cavity (cutler 1969). cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. heathy swamps in peat; sites wet most of the year, in a region of moderate rainfall. wind-pollinated; resprouts after fire but also regenerates by seed. flowers autumn. ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial, forming extensive patches. Rhizomes stout, densely covered with red-brown or yellow-brown hairs. Culms much-branched, upper branches often flexuose and sometimes forming dense trailing masses, terete, striate, glabrous, with persistent appressed sheaths. Male and female inflorescences similar, of spikelets terminal on culms or culm branches or sessile in the axil of an upper node; erect, elongated, cylindrical, many-flowered. Flowers with 6 tepals, 2 outer tepals keeled, the keel densely red-brown pubescent. Male flowers with 3 stamens, anthers exserted. Female flowers with a 2-locular ovary and 2 style branches strongly recurved and shortly connate at the base. Fruit a capsule. Seed surface smooth with longitudinal lines of transversely-elongated rectangular cells. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 1 or 2 layers of somewhat elongated peg cells, interrupted by greatly enlarged epidermal cells that meet and interrupt the parenchyma sheath over girders opposite some outer vascular bundles (mostly over alternate bundles), pillar and protective cells absent, central cavity usually present. Meney et al. (1999) report the presence of pillar cells dividing the chlorenchyma but we did not observe them to be present. Reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. Peg cells are palisade-like chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. Pillar cells are elongate, palisade-like cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened (lignified) walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. Girders are sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles, extending from the sclerenchyma sheath all or part-way through the chlorenchyma. Protective cells are modified chlorenchyma cells that are thick-walled and line the substomatal cavity (Cutler 1969). Cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. Heathy swamps in peat; sites wet most of the year, in a region of moderate rainfall. Wind-pollinated; resprouts after fire but also regenerates by seed. Flowers autumn.

simplified_phrase: resprouts after fire and regenerates from seed after fire
fire: resprouts after fire or disturbance but also regenerates from seed.
description: herb, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial, forming extensive patches to 0.5 (-3) m across and culms forming dense trailing masses; cluster and sand-binding roots present. rhizome stout, horizontal, up to circa 20 cm long, 5-8 mm diam.; scales few, brown, scarious, partly covering a dense, yellow- to red-brown woolly pubescence. cataphylls overlapping, red-brown, glabrous. culms spaced to circa 1 cm apart on the rhizome, initially erect but the upper culm often flexuose, terete, striate, 25-75 cm long, 0.8-1.3 mm diam., glabrous, dull green; usually repeatedly branched; branches slender, erect or flexuose; internodes numerous, short, to circa 3 cm long. sheaths closely appressed, scarious, striate, straw-coloured to grey, to circa 1.2 cm long, glabrous, apex acute; lamina short, erect, 1-2 mm long; with a narrow, caducous, membranous margin. inflorescence: male and female spikelets similar, terminal on culms or culm branches or sessile in the axil of an upper node; erect, elongated, many-flowered, narrow-cylindrical, 0.5-2.5 cm long, 1.5-2.5 mm wide; spathes very small, circa 1-2 mm long, acute to obtuse, with a minute, erect mucro. male spikelets with circa 30-60 glumes, all fertile, ovate-lanceolate, brown, acuminate to subulate, 1.7-2.2 mm long; 2 outer tepals keeled, 1.4-1.8 mm long, pubescent along the keel with red-brown hairs; inner tepals flat, slightly shorter than the outer tepals, glabrous; stamens 3, filaments 1.5-2.3 mm long, anthers circa 1 mm long; pistillode absent. female flowers: tepals 6, similar to males; staminodes absent; style 2-branched, shortly connate at the base, stout, strongly recurved, almost wholly stigmatic. capsule circa 1.5 mm long. seed oblong, brown, 0.9 mm long, smooth with longitudinal lines of transversely-elongated rectangular cells. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 1 or 2 layers of somewhat elongated peg cells, interrupted by greatly enlarged epidermal cells that meet and interrupt the parenchyma sheath over girders opposite some outer vascular bundles (mostly over alternate bundles), central cavity usually present. culm anatomy: our observation is that pillar cells are absent although they are reported as present by meney et al. (1999). reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. peg cells are pali chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. pillar cells are elongate, pali cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened (lignified) walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. girders are sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles, extending from the sclerenchyma sheath all or part-way through the chlorenchyma. cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. sedge swamps, melaleuca thicket, moist shrubland or heath, in oligotrophic soil, peat or peaty sand; sites wet most of the year. wind pollinated; resprouts after fire or disturbance but also regenerates from seed. flowers recorded february, march, september, october. ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial, forming extensive patches to 0.5 (-3) m across and culms forming dense trailing masses; cluster and sand-binding roots present. Rhizome stout, horizontal, up to c. 20 cm long, 5-8 mm diam.; scales few, brown, scarious, partly covering a dense, yellow- to red-brown woolly pubescence. Cataphylls overlapping, red-brown, glabrous. Culms spaced to c. 1 cm apart on the rhizome, initially erect but the upper culm often flexuose, terete, striate, 25-75 cm long, 0.8-1.3 mm diam., glabrous, dull green; usually repeatedly branched; branches slender, erect or flexuose; internodes numerous, short, to c. 3 cm long. Sheaths closely appressed, scarious, striate, straw-coloured to grey, to c. 1.2 cm long, glabrous, apex acute; lamina short, erect, 1-2 mm long; with a narrow, caducous, membranous margin. Inflorescence: male and female spikelets similar, terminal on culms or culm branches or sessile in the axil of an upper node; erect, elongated, many-flowered, narrow-cylindrical, 0.5-2.5 cm long, 1.5-2.5 mm wide; spathes very small, c. 1-2 mm long, acute to obtuse, with a minute, erect mucro. Male spikelets with c. 30-60 glumes, all fertile, ovate-lanceolate, brown, acuminate to subulate, 1.7-2.2 mm long; margin thin, hyaline, membranous, occasionally ciliate; mucro to 1 mm long. Female spikelets with 1 or 2 sterile lower glumes, 10-50 fertile upper glumes. Male flowers: tepals 6, lanceolate, acute, brown with hyaline margin; 2 outer tepals keeled, 1.4-1.8 mm long, pubescent along the keel with red-brown hairs; inner tepals flat, slightly shorter than the outer tepals, glabrous; stamens 3, filaments 1.5-2.3 mm long, anthers c. 1 mm long; pistillode absent. Female flowers: tepals 6, similar to males; staminodes absent; style 2-branched, shortly connate at the base, stout, strongly recurved, almost wholly stigmatic. Capsule c. 1.5 mm long. Seed oblong, brown, 0.9 mm long, smooth with longitudinal lines of transversely-elongated rectangular cells. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 1 or 2 layers of somewhat elongated peg cells, interrupted by greatly enlarged epidermal cells that meet and interrupt the parenchyma sheath over girders opposite some outer vascular bundles (mostly over alternate bundles), central cavity usually present. Culm anatomy: our observation is that pillar cells are absent although they are reported as present by Meney et al. (1999). Reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. Peg cells are palisade-like chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. Pillar cells are elongate, palisade-like cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened (lignified) walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. Girders are sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles, extending from the sclerenchyma sheath all or part-way through the chlorenchyma. Cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. Sedge swamps, Melaleuca thicket, moist shrubland or heath, in oligotrophic soil, peat or peaty sand; sites wet most of the year. Wind pollinated; resprouts after fire or disturbance but also regenerates from seed. Flowers recorded February, March, September, October.

fire: flowers without fire but plants much easier to locate on burnt ground.
description: rosette leaves 4-6, narrowly elliptic to ovate, 5-12 x 3-5mm, dark-green, margins entire. flower stem 40-160mm tall, smooth; stem leaves 2-3. flower 14-16 x 4.5mm, translucent white with dark green stripes. dorsal sepal about as long as petals, acuminate. sinus nearly flat in side view, flat in front view with dark green shallow notch. free points filiform,14-16mm long. petals flared. labellum hidden, tip curved forwards, circa4.5 x 2mm, oblong, white with dark green stripes, margins minutely scabrous. localised, growing in swamps in dense heath and shrubland over moist to wet, black peaty loam. notes grows in small colonies. flowers without fire but plants much easier to locate on burnt ground. sep-oct. ;

Flower 14-16 x 4.5mm, translucent white with dark green stripes. Dorsal sepal about as long as petals, acuminate. Sinus nearly flat in side view, flat in front view with dark green shallow notch. Free points filiform,14-16mm long. Petals flared. Labellum hidden, tip curved forwards, c.4.5 x 2mm, oblong, white with dark green stripes, margins minutely scabrous. fire: flowering is inhibited in densely overgrown habitats and plants respond to summer burns by flowering strongly.
description: plants either lacking basal leaves and with 8-14 sessile stem leaves scattered up flower stem or with 3-4 stalked leaves to 40 x 25mm in loose basal group, rest occurring as scattered stem leaves. stem leaves stalkless, base encircling flower stem, lanceolate when flattened, 8-23 x 8-12mm, apex acuminate. flower stem 100-400mm tall, smooth. flower erect or slightly nodding, 16-20 x 6-8mm, green and white, tip horizontal or curved downwards. dorsal sepal with long tapered point, longer than petals. sinus slightly bulging in side view, shallowly notched in front view with dark green central area. free points filiform or slightly thickened, 20-25mm long, erect. petal margins sometimes slightly toothed. labellum hidden, tip curved forwards, 5-6 x 2mm, oblong, basal margins scabrous. locally common mainly near coast but extending further inland in some areas, growing in and around winter-wet swamps and flats dominated by swamp paperbark (melaleuca rhaphiophylla) in wet peaty soil. notes can form large clonal colonies in suitable conditions. flowering is inhibited in densely overgrown habitats and plants respond to summer burns by flowering strongly. in wet seasons plants can flower with their bases submerged in water, plants then lack basal leaves. aug-oct. ;

Stem leaves stalkless, base encircling flower stem, lanceolate when flattened, 8-23 x 8-12mm, apex acuminate. Flower stem 100-400mm tall, smooth. Flower erect or slightly nodding, 16-20 x 6-8mm, green and white, tip horizontal or curved downwards. Dorsal sepal with long tapered point, longer than petals. Sinus slightly bulging in side view, shallowly notched in front view with dark green central area. Free points filiform or slightly thickened, 20-25mm long, erect. Petal margins sometimes slightly toothed. Labellum hidden, tip curved forwards, 5-6 x 2mm, oblong, basal margins scabrous. Locally common mainly near coast but extending further inland in some areas, growing in and around winter-wet swamps and flats dominated by swamp paperbark (Melaleuca rhaphiophylla) in wet peaty soil. Notes Can form large clonal colonies in suitable conditions. Flowering is inhibited in densely overgrown habitats and plants respond to summer burns by flowering strongly. In wet seasons plants can flower with their bases submerged in water, plants then lack basal leaves. Aug-Oct.

simplified_phrase: resprouts from underground buds after fire (orchid)
fire: fires commonly destroy the above-ground growths which are replaced quickly by new shoots. stems can continue growing indefinitely until damaged by fire or browsing.
description: plants with one or more erect or straggly leafy stems 50-1500 mm long. leaves distichous, sword-shaped, 120-200 x 15 mm, curved, channelled, strongly ribbed, bases overlapping, dark green to pale green, apex pointed. racemes arising from upper axils, erect, 300-550 mm long, green, 2-20-flowered. ovaries slightly humped, pale, lightly spotted. peranth segments spreading with recurved tips. flowers 25-35 mm across, pink to mauve with dark purplish spots and blotches. dorsal sepal 18-25 x 6 mm, erect. lateral sepals 18-25 x 6 mm, widely divergent. petals 16-23 x 4-6 mm, obliquely erect, divergent. labellum 20-25 x 5-6 mm, pink to mauve; lateral lobes 5-8 x 1 mm; midlobe 7-10 x 4-8 mm, with narrow band of mauve hairs. callus ridges small, parallel. column 8-9 x 3-4 mm, white. capsules reddish brown, spotted.  locally common; growing in open forest and woodland from coast to ranges in freely draining loams and sands, often among rocks and in stony soils. fires commonly destroy the above-ground growths which are replaced quickly by new shoots. stems can continue growing indefinitely until damaged by fire or browsing. unburnt plants develop long lanky growths. flowers october-january. ;
original_text: Plants with one or more erect or straggly leafy stems 50-1500 mm long. Leaves distichous, sword-shaped, 120-200 x 15 mm, curved, channelled, strongly ribbed, bases overlapping, dark green to pale green, apex pointed. Racemes arising from upper axils, erect, 300-550 mm long, green, 2-20-flowered. Ovaries slightly humped, pale, lightly spotted. Peranth segments spreading with recurved tips. Flowers 25-35 mm across, pink to mauve with dark purplish spots and blotches. Dorsal sepal 18-25 x 6 mm, erect. Lateral sepals 18-25 x 6 mm, widely divergent. Petals 16-23 x 4-6 mm, obliquely erect, divergent. Labellum 20-25 x 5-6 mm, pink to mauve; lateral lobes 5-8 x 1 mm; midlobe 7-10 x 4-8 mm, with narrow band of mauve hairs. Callus ridges small, parallel. Column 8-9 x 3-4 mm, white. Capsules reddish brown, spotted.  Locally common; growing in open forest and woodland from coast to ranges in freely draining loams and sands, often among rocks and in stony soils. Fires commonly destroy the above-ground growths which are replaced quickly by new shoots. Stems can continue growing indefinitely until damaged by fire or browsing. Unburnt plants develop long lanky growths. Flowers October-January.

original_text: Tuberous terrestrial orchids growing as scattered individuals, in crowded tufts, or in clonal colonies. Leaves 1 to a few, basal, sessile, distichous or spirally arranged, much longer than wide, often grass-like, prostrate or erect, channelled or not, straight or spirally twisted. Racemes 1- to many-flowered, short to tall; peduncle wiry, glabrous, with 1-3 sterile bracts. Flowers resupinate, large, colourful. Tepals free, markedly dissimilar. Dorsal sepal shorter and broader than lateral sepals, base hooding the column. Lateral sepals deflexed or recurved, long, narrow, often widest near apex, acute, parallel or crossed. Petals with narrow basal stalk and broad blade that are usually distinct from each other, but sometimes stalk widening into blade. Labellum attached by its base to column base. Labellum lamina 3-lobed from near base; lateral lobes flanking column, large or small; margins entire or erose/lobed, sometimes papillate; midlobe protruding forwards like a platform, flat or centrally ridged with downcurved margins, sometimes papillate. Callus of 1 or 2 ridges on labellum base, smooth or papillate, sometimes breaking up into accessory ridges on midlobe. Column short, stamen and style fused only at base; wings large, prominent. Anther with 2 bilobed white pollinia attached directly to viscidium. Diuris flowers are colourful, readily visible, and distinctively shaped. They are not always easy to identify to species level however, because they commonly exhibit more floral variation than other Australian native orchids. Features such as flower colour, colour patterns, and flower size are normally variable within a population, sometimes to an extraordinary degree.  These orchids grow mostly in open habitats such as forests, woodlands, grasslands, and on rocky outcrops, particularly granite. They range from coastal lowlands to montane and subalpine regions up to 1,800 m altitude. Soils where they grow are freely draining for the most part, but may be seasonally moist to wet in winter and spring. Some species from W.A. actually flower with the stem bases and the leaves submerged in water. Species of Diuris can be locally common in suitable habitats and create attractive floral displays. Diuris respond strongly to seasonal conditions; it is not uncommon (for terrestrial orchids in general) that they flower in reduced numbers during a wetter-than-normal season, but flower well in the following year. They may also be more common during dry years. Diuris purdei from W.A. flowers only in the spring following a summer bushfire. D. drummondii and D. emarginata, which grow in swamps in W.A., flower in abundance in the late spring following a bushfire. Flowering is enhanced after fire in most species of Diuris, especially where the surrounding vegetation has grown very dense. The plants survive summer extremes of dryness and heat as dormant tubers. The tubers sprout after soaking rains in autumn, and the leaves develop fully before an inflorescence is produced. Flowering occurs mainly in spring and early summer, but D. opporina flowers in autumn, and a couple of western species (D. brumailis and D. recurva) flower in winter. Capsules develop in an upright position and shed seed 2-3 weeks after pollination. All species of Diuris are pollinated by insects; none are self-pollinating. Diuris pollen is loosely aggregated within the pollinarium and segments are readily detached upon contact with a sticky stigma, meaning that a single pollinarium can pollinate several flowers. However, the number of Diuris flowers that get pollinated can be very low. Not a single flower was pollinated in a colony of around 130 flowering plants of D. orientis closely observed by the author at Mt Morton, Victoria, during November 1969. In many Diuris species, the central part of the flower (the dorsal sepal and the labellum lobes), closely mimic the flower shape of native pea-flowered shrubs (family Fabaceae, tribe Mirbelieae). The flowers of these shrubs produce nectar and are commonly visited by native bees and wasps. Nectar is not produced by the Diuris flowers, although most species have coloured markings on the labellum midlobe, which are suggestive of nectar guides. Pollination studies of D. curvifolia [as D. maculata] (Beardsell et al. 1986) and true D. maculata (Indsto et al. 2006) show that bees seeking nectar or pollen are deceived into visiting the orchid flowers, and pollen removal or deposition occurs when the bees probe the basal part of the labellum and column while looking for nectar. The sticky gland on the pollinarium becomes attached to the face of the visiting bee, and sometimes bees can be seen with more than one gland attached to their faces. Male and female bees are involved in the pollination of D. curvifolia and D. maculata, the males generally appearing in their life cycle before the females and visiting the orchids early in their flowering period. Native leguminous shrubs with 'egg and bacon-type' flowers are common in habitats where Diuris grow, and their flowering periods mostly overlap with that of the orchids. The flowers of species of Bossiaea, Daviesia, Dillwynia and Pultenaea have been linked with the pollination of Diuris in the literature, but many other pea-flowered genera, including Chorizema, Gastrolobium, Gompholobium, Isotropis, Jacksonia, Nemcia and Urodon, have similar flowers and may also play a role. Not all Diuris mimic pea-flowered shrubs. The flowers of Diuris species in the D. alba /punctata group are often noticeably fragrant (D. fragrantissima for example) and do not bear a strong resemblance to native pea flowers, suggesting they employ a different strategy to lure insect visitors. A pollination study of D. alba shows that its flowers not only produce a small amount of nectar, but are attractive to insects in their own right (Indsto et al. 2007). Similarly, members of the D. behrii /chryseopsis group have distinctive semi-nodding flowers that are wider than they are long. They also have a large labellum midlobe that projects forwards like a landing platform, and a complex callus structure that is adorned with tiny, needle-like papillae. The flowers of D. behrii attract male Lasioglossum bees, but not females (Coleman 1932, Bates 1977). These bees probe with their mouthparts into a narrow, deep, nectarless hollow between the base of the column and the labellum and have been observed to pick up pollinia. Resting bees (Lasioglossum species) have been found in the flowers of some species of Diuris, including D. behrii, D. chryseopsis, D. monticola and D. subalpina, but their role in pollination, if any, remains unclear. The bees sit motionless in the flowers for long periods, sometimes even overnight, but they fly away if disturbed. Perhaps the bees find security from predators under the hooded dorsal sepal, or maybe they gain warmth from the flowers at night. For an excellent treatment of pollination in Diuris see Bower (2001, pp.128-130). For photos of pollinia-bearing insects on various Diuris flowers see Kuiter (2013, pp.86-87).

fire: flowering is enhanced by summer fires.
description: leaves 2 or 3, 100-220 x 2-2.5 mm, folded. flower stem 400-900 mm tall, 3-8-flowered. flowers 30-50 mm across, yellowish brown to brown with purplish suffusions and a purple labellum midlobe; petals yellowish brown, dorsal sepal brownish to purple-brown, labellum lateral lobes yellowish brown to purplish, midlobe purple. dorsal sepal erect, 12-15 x 16-23 mm. lateral sepals deflexed, 18-28 x 3-4.5 mm. petals obliquely erect to erect; stalk 5-7 mm long, purple-brown; blade elliptical, 18-30 x 12-15 mm, with a yellowish reverse stripe. labellum 12-16 mm long; lateral lobes 10-15 x 5-8 mm; midlobe convex, margins downcurved, wedge-shaped when flattened, 10-14 x 10-12 mm, apex recurved. callus ridge 1, 2-3 mm long. diuris amplissimus has the largest flowers of any diuris in w.a.  localised; forming vegetative colonies in moist, grassy areas in eucalyptus wandoo woodland and among shrubs in karri forests in freely draining sands. flowering is enhanced by summer fires. flowers september-november. ;
original_text: Leaves 2 or 3, 100-220 x 2-2.5 mm, folded. Flower stem 400-900 mm tall, 3-8-flowered. Flowers 30-50 mm across, yellowish brown to brown with purplish suffusions and a purple labellum midlobe; petals yellowish brown, dorsal sepal brownish to purple-brown, labellum lateral lobes yellowish brown to purplish, midlobe purple. Dorsal sepal erect, 12-15 x 16-23 mm. Lateral sepals deflexed, 18-28 x 3-4.5 mm. Petals obliquely erect to erect; stalk 5-7 mm long, purple-brown; blade elliptical, 18-30 x 12-15 mm, with a yellowish reverse stripe. Labellum 12-16 mm long; lateral lobes 10-15 x 5-8 mm; midlobe convex, margins downcurved, wedge-shaped when flattened, 10-14 x 10-12 mm, apex recurved. Callus ridge 1, 2-3 mm long. Diuris amplissimus has the largest flowers of any Diuris in W.A.  Localised; forming vegetative colonies in moist, grassy areas in Eucalyptus wandoo woodland and among shrubs in karri forests in freely draining sands. Flowering is enhanced by summer fires. Flowers September-November.

fire: flowering is greatly stimulated by summer fires.
description: leaves 4-8, 70-120 x 3-4 mm, straight or twisted. flower stem 150-400 mm, 1-5-flowered. flowers 15-20 mm across, bright yellow with two brown basal spots on dorsal sepal and brown callus outline. dorsal sepal erect to recurved, 12-15 x 6-7 mm. lateral sepals obliquely deflexed below labellum, 13-16 x 3-4 mm. petals obliquely erect to recurved; stalk 4-6 mm long, dark brown; blade 9-11 x 6-7 mm. labellum 12-15 mm long; lateral lobes 5-6 x 2.5-3 mm; midlobe flattish, margins shallow downcurved, ovate when flattened, 10-13 x 7-8 mm. callus ridges 2, 6-7 mm long, parallel.  hybridises with diuris orientis. highly localised; forming colonies on river flats and among shrubs in dense, stunted forest dominated by cup gum (eucalyptus cosmophylla); also in low heath and sedges on swamp margins. grows in moist to wet sand and clay loam. in some areas this orchid survives in exotic pine plantations. flowering is greatly stimulated by summer fires. flowers october-december. ;
original_text: Leaves 4-8, 70-120 x 3-4 mm, straight or twisted. Flower stem 150-400 mm, 1-5-flowered. Flowers 15-20 mm across, bright yellow with two brown basal spots on dorsal sepal and brown callus outline. Dorsal sepal erect to recurved, 12-15 x 6-7 mm. Lateral sepals obliquely deflexed below labellum, 13-16 x 3-4 mm. Petals obliquely erect to recurved; stalk 4-6 mm long, dark brown; blade 9-11 x 6-7 mm. Labellum 12-15 mm long; lateral lobes 5-6 x 2.5-3 mm; midlobe flattish, margins shallow downcurved, ovate when flattened, 10-13 x 7-8 mm. Callus ridges 2, 6-7 mm long, parallel.  Hybridises with Diuris orientis. Highly localised; forming colonies on river flats and among shrubs in dense, stunted forest dominated by Cup Gum (Eucalyptus cosmophylla); also in low heath and sedges on swamp margins. Grows in moist to wet sand and clay loam. In some areas this orchid survives in exotic pine plantations. Flowering is greatly stimulated by summer fires. Flowers October-December.

description: leaves 2 or 3, 50-160 x 3-8 mm, folded. flower stem 150-300 mm tall, 1-5-flowered. flowers 20-25 mm across, yellow heavily marked with red to red-brown; petals yellow, dorsal sepal yellow suffused with brown, labellum lateral lobes yellow with brown or red-brown tips, midlobe mostly red or brown. dorsal sepal erect, 6-8 x 6-9 mm. lateral sepals deflexed, crossed and recurved, 11-16 x 1.5-2.5 mm. petals obliquely erect; stalk 3-4 mm long, curved, blackish; blade elliptical, margins often wavy, 10-14 x 7-9 mm. labellum 4-5 mm long; lateral lobes 5-6 x 3-4 mm; midlobe flattish, margins shallowly downcurved, narrowly wedge-shaped when flattened, 4-4.5 x 4-4.5 mm. callus ridge 1, 3-4 mm long, yellow.  currently known from a single locality, where it grows among sedges and low shrubs in moist to wet, black, peaty soil and sandy clay around the margins of a swamp. flowers freely without fire. flowers august-early september. ;

Flowers porrect to nodding, 15-20 mm across, yellow, spotted and blotched with brown, especially exterior surfaces, fragrant. Dorsal sepal erect or recurved, 7-10 x 5-6 mm. Lateral sepals deflexed, 12-15 x 2-2.5 mm. Petals usually recurved; stalk 3-4 mm, dark red-brown; blade ovate, 4-6 x 3-4 mm, often notched. Labellum 7-1 0mm long; lateral lobes 4-6 x 2-3 mm long; midlobe spathulate, 6-8 x 3-4 mm, folded. Callus ridges 2, 4-5 mm long. This species exhibits little floral variation over its range. Unmarked, clear yellow-flowered plants are sometimes encountered in S.A. Hybridises with Diuris basaltica (see D. xfastidiosa), D. chryseopsis, D. orientis, D. pardina. Sporadic and uncommon over most of its distribution, but more frequently encountered in S.A. It ranges from near the coast to drier inland areas growing in a variety of habitats including basalt grassland, grassy woodland, native pine woodland, mallee/broombush shrubland, sedgy grassland, dry sedgelands and heathland. Soils range from freely draining to seasonally wet and swampy, acid or calcareous, and include sand, terra rossa, brown clay loam and sandy peat. Sometimes grows in crowded tufts of 10 or more plants together. The flowers have a strong, sweet, spicy, cinnamon-like fragrance noticeable on warm mornings. Flowering is promoted by summer fires. Flowers July-November; as late as December in Tas.

Exhibits little floral variation, apart from floral size, over its extensive range. Robust, large-flowered plants may be the result of polyploidy. Peloric variants which have colourful, petal-like lateral sepals are not uncommon. Hybridises rarely, producing sterile hybrids with Diuris orientis and D. punctata. Widespread and often abundant, ranging from near-coastal situations to the W slopes of the Dividing Range, semi-arid inland areas and high into the mountains. Often prominent on drier ridges and slopes within sparse forests, but also grows in wetter sites in tall forest, coastal forest, heathland and less commonly in grassland, in a wide range of freely draining soils. Flowering is enhanced by summer fires. Produces daughter tubers on the end of very long, thin, stolonoid roots and by this means forms small, spreading, vegetative colonies. A single plant excavated near Armidale, N.S.W., was found to have produced 28 daughter tubers (Tunstall 1996). For details on pollination, see Coleman (1933). Flowers August-November.

description: leaves 2 or 3 , 100-300 x 4-12 mm, folded. flower stem 200-600 mm, 1-5-flowered. flowers 25-40 mm across, pale yellow heavily suffused with light-brown, occasionally with mauve-purple in labellum; petals yellow suffused with light brown, dorsal sepal and labellum red-brown. dorsal sepal erect, 10-12 x 10-14 mm. lateral sepals deflexed, parallel or crossed, not recurved, 15-24 x 2-3 mm. petals obliquely erect; stalk 4.5-6 mm long, curved, blackish; blade oblong elliptic, 12-20 x 8-12 mm. labellum 8-10 mm long; lateral lobes 7-10 x 4-6 mm; midlobe flat to convex, margins shallowly downcurved, wedge-shaped when flattened, 7-9 x 6-9 mm. callus ridge 1, 5-7 mm long, yellow surrounded by red-brown.  locally common; growing in banksia woodland and jarrah/marri forest with a shrubby understorey in freely draining sand over limestone. flowers freely without fire. flowers september-october. ;
original_text: Leaves 2 or 3 , 100-300 x 4-12 mm, folded. Flower stem 200-600 mm, 1-5-flowered. Flowers 25-40 mm across, pale yellow heavily suffused with light-brown, occasionally with mauve-purple in labellum; petals yellow suffused with light brown, dorsal sepal and labellum red-brown. Dorsal sepal erect, 10-12 x 10-14 mm. Lateral sepals deflexed, parallel or crossed, not recurved, 15-24 x 2-3 mm. Petals obliquely erect; stalk 4.5-6 mm long, curved, blackish; blade oblong elliptic, 12-20 x 8-12 mm. Labellum 8-10 mm long; lateral lobes 7-10 x 4-6 mm; midlobe flat to convex, margins shallowly downcurved, wedge-shaped when flattened, 7-9 x 6-9 mm. Callus ridge 1, 5-7 mm long, yellow surrounded by red-brown.  Locally common; growing in Banksia woodland and jarrah/marri forest with a shrubby understorey in freely draining sand over limestone. fire: flowers freely without fire.
description: leaves 2 or 3, 80-250 x 4-7 mm, folded. flower stem 250-500 mm tall, 1-7-flowered. flowers flat in profile, 20-30 mm across, mostly yellow (often pale yellow) with reddish petal stalks and brown to purple suffusions in labellum lobes, exterior surface of all segments stained with red-brown. dorsal sepal erect or recurved, 10-13 x 12-16 mm. lateral sepals stiffly deflexed, usually crossed, mostly not recurved, 15-22 x 2.5-3.5 mm. petals obliquely erect, divergent; stalk 3-5 mm long; blade broadly elliptical, 12-18 x 9-13 mm. labellum 8-12 mm long; lateral lobes spreading widely, 8-10 x 4-6 mm; midlobe convex, margins shallowly downcurved, broadly wedge-shaped when flatttened, 8-12 x 8-11 mm, apex decurved. callus ridge 1, 4-6 mm long, yellow surrounded by brown to purple. hybridises with diuris magnifica in the southern parts of its range. locally common in loose colonies; in the northern part of its range it grows in white sand over laterite in low shrubland and kwongan; in the southern part of its range is grows in banksia woodland; also occasionally on margins of winter-wet swamps. flowers freely without fire. flowers august-early october. ;
original_text: Leaves 2 or 3, 80-250 x 4-7 mm, folded. Flower stem 250-500 mm tall, 1-7-flowered. Dorsal sepal erect or recurved, 10-13 x 12-16 mm. Lateral sepals stiffly deflexed, usually crossed, mostly not recurved, 15-22 x 2.5-3.5 mm. Petals obliquely erect, divergent; stalk 3-5 mm long; blade broadly elliptical, 12-18 x 9-13 mm. Labellum 8-12 mm long; lateral lobes spreading widely, 8-10 x 4-6 mm; midlobe convex, margins shallowly downcurved, broadly wedge-shaped when flatttened, 8-12 x 8-11 mm, apex decurved. Callus ridge 1, 4-6 mm long, yellow surrounded by brown to purple. Hybridises with Diuris magnifica in the southern parts of its range. Locally common in loose colonies; in the northern part of its range it grows in white sand over laterite in low shrubland and kwongan; in the southern part of its range is grows in Banksia woodland; also occasionally on margins of winter-wet swamps. Flowers freely without fire. Flowers August-early October.

fire: plants are commonly killed by hot fires, but large clumps can often regenerate from vegetative buds surviving within the clump.
description: plants forming dense clumps, often with sparsely branched, pendulous, yellowish stems to 600 x 2 mm, with aerial roots. leaves erect to pendulous, terete, 40-120 x 3-4 mm, fleshy, curved, shallowly grooved, green or reddish. racemes thin, 10-30 mm long, 1-2-flowered. flowers 12-16 x 15-20 mm, greenish, cream, yellow or brownish yellow with red-brown stripes on interior base of segments and on exterior of sepals, labellum white. sepals and petals moderately broad, widely spreading or recurved. dorsal sepal 8-14 x 2-3 mm. lateral sepals 8-14 x 2-3 mm. petals 8-14 x 1 mm. labellum 9-12 x 3-5 mm, strongly curved; lateral lobes erect, short, blunt; midlobe margins strongly crinkled, upper surface with 3 wavy ridges. flower colour and the degree/intensity of red striping on floral segments are variable features.  hybridises with dockrillia pugioniformis. a widespread and common lithophytic orchid (found rarely on the bases of trees) forming dense clumps (sometimes growing in extensive masses) on rocks, boulders and cliff faces on a range of rock types, including granite, granodiorite, porphyry, sandstone and dolerite. grows in a range of situations from right on the coast to the mountains, and from sun to full shade, with the leaves of plants exposed to hot sun often taking on reddish hues. its root system is extensive, wandering over the surface of rocks and penetrating crevices, lichens and other sites where litter accumulates. plants are commonly killed by hot fires, but large clumps can often regenerate from vegetative buds surviving within the clump. the leaves are commonly browsed by wallabies. flowers september-november. ;
original_text: Plants forming dense clumps, often with sparsely branched, pendulous, yellowish stems to 600 x 2 mm, with aerial roots. Leaves erect to pendulous, terete, 40-120 x 3-4 mm, fleshy, curved, shallowly grooved, green or reddish. Racemes thin, 10-30 mm long, 1-2-flowered. Flowers 12-16 x 15-20 mm, greenish, cream, yellow or brownish yellow with red-brown stripes on interior base of segments and on exterior of sepals, labellum white. Sepals and petals moderately broad, widely spreading or recurved. Dorsal sepal 8-14 x 2-3 mm. Lateral sepals 8-14 x 2-3 mm. Petals 8-14 x 1 mm. Labellum 9-12 x 3-5 mm, strongly curved; lateral lobes erect, short, blunt; midlobe margins strongly crinkled, upper surface with 3 wavy ridges. Flower colour and the degree/intensity of red striping on floral segments are variable features.  Hybridises with Dockrillia pugioniformis. A widespread and common lithophytic orchid (found rarely on the bases of trees) forming dense clumps (sometimes growing in extensive masses) on rocks, boulders and cliff faces on a range of rock types, including granite, granodiorite, porphyry, sandstone and dolerite. Grows in a range of situations from right on the coast to the mountains, and from sun to full shade, with the leaves of plants exposed to hot sun often taking on reddish hues. Its root system is extensive, wandering over the surface of rocks and penetrating crevices, lichens and other sites where litter accumulates. Plants are commonly killed by hot fires, but large clumps can often regenerate from vegetative buds surviving within the clump. The leaves are commonly browsed by wallabies. Flowers September-November.

fire: a coloniser following disturbance such as fire or roadside disturbances.
description: dioecious or rarely polygamo-dioecious spreading shrub to 1 m high. leaves simple, sessile, linear, sometimes terete, rarely oblong or obovate, acute or rarely obtuse, revolute, entire or with 1-4 irregular teeth or lobes to 2 mm long, attenuate at base, 0.8-3.5 cm long, 0.1-0.3 cm wide, glabrous or rarely puberulent. flowers solitary or 2 or 3 together; pedicels 1-4 mm long. sepals 4, ovate or rarely lanceolate, 2-3.5 mm long, caducous. stamens 8. ovary pubescent. capsule 4-angled, rarely 3-angled, excluding appendages globose or obovoid or broadly oblong in lateral view, including appendages 4.5-11.5 mm long, 5-11.5 mm wide, rarely to 20 mm, glabrous; appendages usually , sometimes , at capsule apex only, 0.5-8 mm wide, crustaceous; dehiscence septifragal. very variable in leaf shape, capsule shape, and size and shape of the fruit appendages. a coloniser following disturbance such as fire or roadside disturbances. grows in rocky situations, in granite and sandy soils in open mallee scrub, mallee heath, woodland and dry sclerophyll forest. ;
original_text: Dioecious or rarely polygamo-dioecious spreading shrub to 1 m high. Leaves simple, sessile, linear, sometimes terete, rarely oblong or obovate, acute or rarely obtuse, revolute, entire or with 1-4 irregular teeth or lobes to 2 mm long, attenuate at base, 0.8-3.5 cm long, 0.1-0.3 cm wide, glabrous or rarely puberulent. Flowers solitary or 2 or 3 together; pedicels 1-4 mm long. Sepals 4, ovate or rarely lanceolate, 2-3.5 mm long, caducous. Stamens 8. Ovary pubescent. Capsule 4-angled, rarely 3-angled, excluding appendages globose or obovoid or broadly oblong in lateral view, including appendages 4.5-11.5 mm long, 5-11.5 mm wide, rarely to 20 mm, glabrous; appendages usually horn-like, sometimes lobe-like, at capsule apex only, 0.5-8 mm wide, crustaceous; dehiscence septifragal. Very variable in leaf shape, capsule shape, and size and shape of the fruit appendages. A coloniser following disturbance such as fire or roadside disturbances. Grows in rocky situations, in granite and sandy soils in open mallee scrub, mallee heath, woodland and dry sclerophyll forest.

fire: regenerates strongly after disturbances such as grazing, drought and fire.
description: erect to spreading shrub 1.5-4 m high. leaves sessile or petiolate, usually obovate, sometimes spathulate, rarely elliptic, broadly acute to obtuse, sometimes obtuse or rounded, shortly apiculate, entire to irregularly sinuolate or irregularly denticulate, narrowly attenuate to attenuate at base; lamina 2.3-7.5 cm long, 0.6-1.6 cm wide; petiole when present 1-10 mm long. capsule similar to subsp burmanniana. dodonaea viscosa subsp spatulata shows the greatest amount of leaf morphological variation and in certain areas, e g in southern and eastern n.s.and southeastern s.a., intergrades with subsp angustissima and subsp cuneata. subsp mucronata also intergrades with subsp spatulata in western n.s.and western w.populations from the grampians in vic. show some distinction in leaf shape from most plants of this subspecies. they have obovate, slightly thicker, broader and more rigid leaves with irregularly denticulate margins. usually grows in high rainfall areas in open forest or woodlands and mallee shrublands, mostly in sandy loam. regenerates strongly after disturbances such as grazing, drought and fire. ;
original_text: Erect to spreading shrub 1.5-4 m high. Leaves sessile or petiolate, usually obovate, sometimes spathulate, rarely elliptic, broadly acute to obtuse, sometimes obtuse or rounded, shortly apiculate, entire to irregularly sinuolate or irregularly denticulate, narrowly attenuate to attenuate at base; lamina 2.3-7.5 cm long, 0.6-1.6 cm wide; petiole when present 1-10 mm long. Capsule similar to subsp. burmanniana. Dodonaea viscosa subsp. spatulata shows the greatest amount of leaf morphological variation and in certain areas, e.g. in southern and eastern N.S.W. and southeastern S.A., intergrades with subsp. angustissima and subsp. cuneata. Subsp. mucronata also intergrades with subsp. spatulata in western N.S.W. and western W.A. Populations from the Grampians in Vic. show some distinction in leaf shape from most plants of this subspecies. They have obovate, slightly thicker, broader and more rigid leaves with irregularly denticulate margins. Usually grows in high rainfall areas in open forest or woodlands and mallee shrublands, mostly in sandy loam. Regenerates strongly after disturbances such as grazing, drought and fire.

fire: flowers more profusely after fire, the inflorescence maturing beforethe leaves.
description: herb with tuber; vertical stolon 3-10 cm long. leaves in a flat rosette; lamina broadly spathulate, 2-5 cm long, 1.5-2.5 cm wide, narrowed but scarcely petiolate. inflores- cence 1, maturing before leaves develop fully, cymose, 10-30(or more)-flowered; peduncle 3-4 cm long; pedicels 3-6 mm long. calyx 5-7 mm long, divided almost to base into ovate-lanceolate lobes, the margins often deeply incised. petals obovate, 6-10 mm long, white. styles 3, each divided almost to base into filiform segments. grows in sand, loam andlaterite; flowers more profusely after fire, the inflorescence maturing beforethe leaves. variants with thick, ridged, yellow-green leaves occur commonly inlateritic and heavy soils. flowers mar.-july. ;
original_text: Herb with tuber; vertical stolon 3-10 cm long. Leaves in a flat rosette; lamina broadly spathulate, 2-5 cm long, 1.5-2.5 cm wide, narrowed but scarcely petiolate. Inflores- cence 1, maturing before leaves develop fully, cymose, 10-30(or more)-flowered; peduncle 3-4 cm long; pedicels 3-6 mm long. Calyx 5-7 mm long, divided almost to base into ovate-lanceolate lobes, the margins often deeply incised. Petals obovate, 6-10 mm long, white. Styles 3, each divided almost to base into filiform segments. Grows in sand, loam andlaterite; flowers more profusely after fire, the inflorescence maturing beforethe leaves. Variants with thick, ridged, yellow-green leaves occur commonly inlateritic and heavy soils. Flowers Mar.-July.

fire: flowers rarely, apparently only after summer burning.
description: herb with tuber; vertical stolon 5-10 cm long. leaves 10-30 in a flat rosette; lamina flabellate, up to 25 mm long, 6-10 mm wide, the distal margin red, abruptly narrowed to flat petiole 5-8 mm long. inflorescence 1, maturing before leaves develop fully, paniculate, 2-6(20)-flowered; peduncle 1-2 cm long. calyx 6-8 mm long, divided for 5-7 mm into ovate, acute lobes. petals ovate, 6-8 mm long, white or pale yellow. styles 3, each divided to base into many filiform segments. easily recognised by the flabellate leaves. flowers rarely, apparently only after summer burning. grows in deep, white sand, in low woodland and heath,often forming large colonies; inflorescence maturing before the leaves. flowersapr.-june. ;
original_text: Herb with tuber; vertical stolon 5-10 cm long. Leaves 10-30 in a flat rosette; lamina flabellate, up to 25 mm long, 6-10 mm wide, the distal margin red, abruptly narrowed to flat petiole 5-8 mm long. Inflorescence 1, maturing before leaves develop fully, paniculate, 2-6(20)-flowered; peduncle 1-2 cm long. Calyx 6-8 mm long, divided for 5-7 mm into ovate, acute lobes. Petals ovate, 6-8 mm long, white or pale yellow. Styles 3, each divided to base into many filiform segments. Easily recognised by the flabellate leaves. Flowers rarely, apparently only after summer burning. Grows in deep, white sand, in low woodland and heath,often forming large colonies; inflorescence maturing before the leaves. FlowersApr.-June.

fire: fire response unknown.
description: tree to 6 m, with stout trunk. leaves: petiole 3-7 mm long, glabrous; lamina elliptic to lanceolate, 3-6 cm long, 14-22 mm wide, pungent, usually strongly curved, woolly in small pits below; margins flat or gently recurved, serrate; teeth triangular, 1-6 each side. inflorescence terminal; involucral bracts ovate to narrowly lanceolate; outer bracts subulate; inner bracts acute, to 15 mm long, appressed-pubescent in upper half, densely ciliate; flowers 110-180 per head. perianth 22-28 mm long, yellow, shortly villous; limb 3 mm long, villous. pistil incurved, 28-32 mm long, yellow, pubescent in lowest 1/4, glabrous above; pollen presenter scarcely thickened, 1 mm long, smooth, pale green. follicles obliquely ovate to obovate, 8-15 mm long, glabrous, firmly attached, opening when mature. the most inland species of the genus and the most robust. involucral bracts enlarged in fruit. fire response unknown. since publication of the flora of australia the australian plant census accepts a.r.mast & k.r.thiele's transfer of dryandra to banksia in austral. syst. bot. 20: 63-71 (2007). as a result this taxon is treated under banksia arborea . grows among ironstone rocks in open shrubland. flowers at all seasons. ;
original_text: Tree to 6 m, with stout trunk. Leaves: petiole 3-7 mm long, glabrous; lamina elliptic to lanceolate, 3-6 cm long, 14-22 mm wide, pungent, usually strongly curved, woolly in small pits below; margins flat or gently recurved, serrate; teeth triangular, 1-6 each side. Inflorescence terminal; involucral bracts ovate to narrowly lanceolate; outer bracts subulate; inner bracts acute, to 15 mm long, appressed-pubescent in upper half, densely ciliate; flowers 110-180 per head. Perianth 22-28 mm long, yellow, shortly villous; limb 3 mm long, villous. Pistil incurved, 28-32 mm long, yellow, pubescent in lowest 1/4, glabrous above; pollen presenter scarcely thickened, 1 mm long, smooth, pale green. Follicles obliquely ovate to obovate, 8-15 mm long, glabrous, firmly attached, opening when mature. The most inland species of the genus and the most robust. Involucral bracts enlarged in fruit. Fire response unknown. Since publication of the Flora of Australia the Australian Plant Census accepts A.R.Mast & K.R.Thiele's transfer of Dryandra to Banksia in Austral. Syst. Bot. 20: 63-71 (2007). As a result this taxon is treated under Banksia arborea . Grows among ironstone rocks in open shrubland. Flowers at all seasons.

fire: shrub to 70 cm across, with short underground fire-tolerant stems.
description: shrub to 70 cm across, with short underground fire-tolerant stems. leaves: petiole 1-3 cm long; lamina pinnatipartite, 8-15 cm long, 5-8 mm wide, v-shaped in cross section; margins revolute; lobes 25-45 each side, linear, pungent; sinuses 2-5 mm across. inflorescence subtended by filiform hirsute 'bracts'; involucral bracts ovate (outer) or oblong (inner), 20-25 mm long, obtuse, glabrous or pubescent, with densely ciliate margins; flowers 75-100 per head. perianth 26-31 mm long, cream, glabrous at base, hirsute above including limb; limb 2.5-2.8 mm long, broader in upper half. pistil 39-45 mm long, yellow, glabrous except long-hirsute ovary; pollen presenter cylindrical to narrowly ovoid, slightly swollen at base, 0.7-1 mm long, green. follicles obovate, narrowed at base, sometimes curved or one side straight, 10-14 mm long, sparsely hirsute across top, otherwise glabrous. sometimes sympatric with brownii . leaf lobes narrow, as in tortifolia , but not twisted. since publication of the flora of australia the australian plant census accepts a.r.mast & k.r.thiele's transfer of dryandra to banksia in austral. syst. bot. 20: 63-71 (2007). as a result this taxon is treated under banksia arctotidis . grows in sandy loam or sandy loam over gravel in thick kwongan or mallee-kwongan. flowers sept. ;
original_text: Shrub to 70 cm across, with short underground fire-tolerant stems. Leaves: petiole 1-3 cm long; lamina pinnatipartite, 8-15 cm long, 5-8 mm wide, V-shaped in cross section; margins revolute; lobes 25-45 each side, linear, pungent; sinuses 2-5 mm across. Inflorescence subtended by filiform hirsute 'bracts'; involucral bracts ovate (outer) or oblong (inner), 20-25 mm long, obtuse, glabrous or pubescent, with densely ciliate margins; flowers 75-100 per head. Perianth 26-31 mm long, cream, glabrous at base, hirsute above including limb; limb 2.5-2.8 mm long, broader in upper half. Pistil 39-45 mm long, yellow, glabrous except long-hirsute ovary; pollen presenter cylindrical to narrowly ovoid, slightly swollen at base, 0.7-1 mm long, green. Follicles obovate, narrowed at base, sometimes curved or one side straight, 10-14 mm long, sparsely hirsute across top, otherwise glabrous. Sometimes sympatric with D. brownii . As a result this taxon is treated under Banksia arctotidis . Grows in sandy loam or sandy loam over gravel in thick kwongan or mallee-kwongan. Flowers Sept.

fire: shrub to 1.7 m across, with fire-tolerant underground stems.
description: shrub to 1.7 m across, with fire-tolerant underground stems. stems rusty-tomentose; prophylls many but not imbricate, broadly ovate, to 6 mm long. leaves: petiole 2-4 cm long, tomentose; lamina deeply pinnatipartite, pinnatisect in lower part of lamina, 20-35 cm long, 5-13 cm wide; margins revolute; lobes 20-30 each side, linear, acute, pungent, twisted so that adaxial surface is uppermost, closely curled-tomentose below where prominently 3-nerved and reticulate. inflorescence terminal, subtended by leaves; involucral bracts ovate to lanceolate, acute, dark rusty-villous; innermost bracts 35-40 mm long; flowers circa 65 per head. perianth 40-47 mm long, pale pink at base, creamy brown above, curled-tomentose above base, grading to appressed-pubescent with straight hairs in upper claw and limb; limb 11-13 mm long, acute. pistil 39-45 mm long, cream, sparsely hairy at base; pollen presenter narrower than style, 8-11 mm long, ribbed, yellow. follicles obliquely obovate, 18-19 mm long, sparsely hairy. leaves dark green above. regrowth leaves with broadly elliptic to oblong lobes. no filiform lower lobes. since publication of the flora of australia the australian plant census accepts a.r.mast & k.r.thiele's transfer of dryandra to banksia in austral. syst. bot. 20: 63-71 (2007). as a result this taxon is treated under banksia pellaeifolia . grows in gravelly loam, in mallee-kwongan. flowers in winter. ;
original_text: Shrub to 1.7 m across, with fire-tolerant underground stems. Stems rusty-tomentose; prophylls many but not imbricate, broadly ovate, to 6 mm long. Leaves: petiole 2-4 cm long, tomentose; lamina deeply pinnatipartite, pinnatisect in lower part of lamina, 20-35 cm long, 5-13 cm wide; margins revolute; lobes 20-30 each side, linear, acute, pungent, twisted so that adaxial surface is uppermost, closely curled-tomentose below where prominently 3-nerved and reticulate. Inflorescence terminal, subtended by leaves; involucral bracts ovate to lanceolate, acute, dark rusty-villous; innermost bracts 35-40 mm long; flowers c. 65 per head.
