description: leafless terrestrial orchids with rootless, fleshy, elongated rhizomes that sometimes look like a yam or potato. inflorescence racemose, multiflowered, tip of raceme sometimes nodding. flower stem fleshy, brown, solid. peduncle much longer than rachis. sterile bracts encircling stem, scarious. pedicels fleshy, obliquely erect. flowers tubular, completely enclosing labellum and column, suberect to pendulous. sepals fused along margins, fleshy, often with roughened or verrucose exterior. petals short, overlapping sepals, tips free. labellum attached weakly by basal stalk to vestigial column foot. labellum lamina 3-lobed, with flexible basal claw; lateral lobes broad, with entire to crinkled/crispate margins. callus consisting of a series of keels or ridges, papillate, often producing granules of yellow, starchy pseudopollen. capsules erect, often verrucose.  found in forested habitats and swampy areas, sometimes in peaty soil or in sites of litter accumulation. species of gastrodia are leafless and completely dependent on mycorrhizal fungi for their nutrients. a study isolating the fungi from rhizomes of sesamoides identified a range of species, the most common one being a wood-rotting saprophytic species of campanella (family marasmiaceae) (dearnaley & bougoure 2010). this study also indicated that gastrodia sesamoides can exist efficiently in a relatively simple association with a range of fungi. the main components for its survival seem to be good supply of decaying wood and a compatible fungus. this study also showed very little fungal colonisation of cells in the rhizomes of sesamoides; 2 plants had no internal fungi at all. by contrast, some exotic species of gastrodia have a much more specialised ecology which involves parasitizing their mycorrhizal fungi in an obligate mycoheterotrophic relationship. gastrodia cunnighamii, native to new zealand, is parasitic on the fungus amarillaria novae-zealanidiae, and gastrodia elata , which occurs in china, japan and many other countries, is parasitic on up to 5 species of amarillaria. the new zealand species, gastrodia minor, survives in a 3-way relationship with an ectomycorrhizal fungus and the myrtaceous shrub manuka (leptospermum scoparium). some australian species of gastrodia may also have a similar 3-way relationship. flowering is sometimes enhanced following summer fires, but fires in peaty soil may destroy the rhizomes. feral pigs are known to dig up and eat the rhizomes. the rhizomes increase in length and produce side shoots when conditions are conducive for growth. the flower stem arises terminally on the rhizome in spring and summer in southern areas, and early in the wet season in tropical areas. seeds are shed 4-8 weeks after pollination with capsules in an erect position.  the flowers release a spicy, cinn perfume which becomes very strong at about 25-30£€¹¥¡each flower lasts 2 or 3 days and the labellum is entirely enclosed within the tubular flower. the flowers are pollinated by native bees of the genus exoneura (family anthophoridae) that are attracted to the flowers by the scent. these are partially social bees that collect and carry pollen between the hairs on their hind legs. an incentive for the bees to enter the gastrodia flowers is provided in the form of fine, sugary, starch-enriched, yellow pseudopollen produced from the labellum callus within a day of the flower opening. entry into the flower is upside-down from the top and the bees move directly to the labellum callus, scratching on the callus and pseudopollen. when finished they turn around inside the flower and emerge head first in an upright position. pollinia are picked up on the thorax on a sticky patch of glue left by contact with the rostellum. iodine tests show the pseudopollen is rich in starch and scrapings from the hind legs of the bees showed they carried pseudopollen from the orchid. examination of labella from a range of gastrodia species indicates that some may not produce pseudopollen or only small quantities. at least 2 species are self-pollinating. the pollination of gastrodia sesamoides has been reported in detail (jones 1981, 1985). for photos of the native bee lasioglossum calophyllae (family halictidae) pollinating gastrodia procera see kuiter (2013, pp. 76-78). ;
original_text: Leafless terrestrial orchids with rootless, fleshy, elongated rhizomes that sometimes look like a yam or potato. Inflorescence racemose, multiflowered, tip of raceme sometimes nodding. Flower stem fleshy, brown, solid. Peduncle much longer than rachis. Sterile bracts encircling stem, scarious. Pedicels fleshy, obliquely erect. Flowers tubular, completely enclosing labellum and column, suberect to pendulous. Sepals fused along margins, fleshy, often with roughened or verrucose exterior. Petals short, overlapping sepals, tips free. Labellum attached weakly by basal stalk to vestigial column foot. Labellum lamina 3-lobed, with flexible basal claw; lateral lobes broad, with entire to crinkled/crispate margins. Callus consisting of a series of keels or ridges, papillate, often producing granules of yellow, starchy pseudopollen. Capsules erect, often verrucose.  Found in forested habitats and swampy areas, sometimes in peaty soil or in sites of litter accumulation. Species of Gastrodia are leafless and completely dependent on mycorrhizal fungi for their nutrients. A study isolating the fungi from rhizomes of G. sesamoides identified a range of species, the most common one being a wood-rotting saprophytic species of Campanella (family Marasmiaceae) (Dearnaley & Bougoure 2010). This study also indicated that Gastrodia sesamoides can exist efficiently in a relatively simple association with a range of fungi. The main components for its survival seem to be good supply of decaying wood and a compatible fungus. This study also showed very little fungal colonisation of cells in the rhizomes of G. sesamoides; 2 plants had no internal fungi at all. By contrast, some exotic species of Gastrodia have a much more specialised ecology which involves parasitizing their mycorrhizal fungi in an obligate mycoheterotrophic relationship. Gastrodia cunnighamii, native to New Zealand, is parasitic on the fungus Amarillaria novae-zealanidiae, and Gastrodia elata , which occurs in China, Japan and many other countries, is parasitic on up to 5 species of Amarillaria. The New Zealand species, Gastrodia minor, survives in a 3-way relationship with an ectomycorrhizal fungus and the myrtaceous shrub Manuka (Leptospermum scoparium). Some Australian species of Gastrodia may also have a similar 3-way relationship. Flowering is sometimes enhanced following summer fires, but fires in peaty soil may destroy the rhizomes. Feral pigs are known to dig up and eat the rhizomes. The rhizomes increase in length and produce side shoots when conditions are conducive for growth. The flower stem arises terminally on the rhizome in spring and summer in southern areas, and early in the wet season in tropical areas. Seeds are shed 4-8 weeks after pollination with capsules in an erect position.  The flowers release a spicy, cinnamon-like perfume which becomes very strong at about 25-30ƒ€¹…¡C. Each flower lasts 2 or 3 days and the labellum is entirely enclosed within the tubular flower. The flowers are pollinated by native bees of the genus Exoneura (family Anthophoridae) that are attracted to the flowers by the scent. These are partially social bees that collect and carry pollen between the hairs on their hind legs. An incentive for the bees to enter the Gastrodia flowers is provided in the form of fine, sugary, starch-enriched, yellow pseudopollen produced from the labellum callus within a day of the flower opening. Entry into the flower is upside-down from the top and the bees move directly to the labellum callus, scratching on the callus and pseudopollen. When finished they turn around inside the flower and emerge head first in an upright position. Pollinia are picked up on the thorax on a sticky patch of glue left by contact with the rostellum. Iodine tests show the pseudopollen is rich in starch and scrapings from the hind legs of the bees showed they carried pseudopollen from the orchid. Examination of labella from a range of Gastrodia species indicates that some may not produce pseudopollen or only small quantities. At least 2 species are self-pollinating. The pollination of Gastrodia sesamoides has been reported in detail (Jones 1981, 1985). For photos of the native bee Lasioglossum calophyllae (family Halictidae) pollinating Gastrodia procera see Kuiter (2013, pp. 76-78).

fire: flowering is enhanced by summer fires.
description: flower stem 250-650 mm tall, slender, brown, fleshy, shiny, nodding in bud, 5-50-flowered. flowers tubular, pendulous, 10-12 mm long, externally dark brown and warty (sometimes greyish or whitish), internally crystalline white. petal margins bluntly toothed. labellum 9-10 x 4-5 mm, white, 3-lobed; lateral lobes small, angular; midlobe with wavy to crisped and lacerated margins. callus of 3 yellow ridges that coalesce into a single ridge on midlobe, producing yellow pseudopollen. column 9-10 x 2.5 mm.  locally common; growing in accumulations of litter in jarrah forest and sheoak woodland; occasionally near swamps. flowering is enhanced by summer fires. flowers november-january. ;
original_text: Flower stem 250-650 mm tall, slender, brown, fleshy, shiny, nodding in bud, 5-50-flowered. Flowers tubular, pendulous, 10-12 mm long, externally dark brown and warty (sometimes greyish or whitish), internally crystalline white. Petal margins bluntly toothed. Labellum 9-10 x 4-5 mm, white, 3-lobed; lateral lobes small, angular; midlobe with wavy to crisped and lacerated margins. Callus of 3 yellow ridges that coalesce into a single ridge on midlobe, producing yellow pseudopollen. Column 9-10 x 2.5 mm.  Locally common; growing in accumulations of litter in jarrah forest and sheoak woodland; occasionally near swamps. Flowering is enhanced by summer fires. Flowers November-January.

fire: flowering is enhanced by summer fires.
description: flower stem 0.6-1.2 m tall, stout, dark brown to blackish, fleshy, erect in bud, 5-75-flowered. flowers tubular, held more or less horizontal to semi-nodding, 20-25 mm long, externally cinnamon brown, rough and warty, crystalline white within, fragrant. petal margins irregular or wavy. labellum 14-17 x 5-8 mm, white with thick orange margins, 3-lobed; lateral lobes narrowly triangular, curved forwards; midlobe with broadly rounded basal margins, irregular and crinkled towards apex. callus of 2 yellow to orange ridges, spreading then convergent, breaking up into irregular, thick ridges on midlobe; pseudopollen dark yellow, variable in abundance between populations. column 12-15 x 3.5-4.5 mm.  widespread and common in montane areas, less common near the coast; growing on slopes and ridges in tall, moist to wet forest in high rainfall regions, usually in humus-rich loam or among accumulations of litter. flowering is enhanced by summer fires. the flowers are lightly scented and insect-pollinated (kuiter (2013, pp. 76-78). flowers december-january. ;
original_text: Flower stem 0.6-1.2 m tall, stout, dark brown to blackish, fleshy, erect in bud, 5-75-flowered. Flowers tubular, held more or less horizontal to semi-nodding, 20-25 mm long, externally cinnamon brown, rough and warty, crystalline white within, fragrant. Petal margins irregular or wavy. Labellum 14-17 x 5-8 mm, white with thick orange margins, 3-lobed; lateral lobes narrowly triangular, curved forwards; midlobe with broadly rounded basal margins, irregular and crinkled towards apex. Callus of 2 yellow to orange ridges, spreading then convergent, breaking up into irregular, thick ridges on midlobe; pseudopollen dark yellow, variable in abundance between populations. Column 12-15 x 3.5-4.5 mm.  Widespread and common in montane areas, less common near the coast; growing on slopes and ridges in tall, moist to wet forest in high rainfall regions, usually in humus-rich loam or among accumulations of litter. Flowering is enhanced by summer fires. The flowers are lightly scented and insect-pollinated (Kuiter (2013, pp. 76-78). Flowers December-January.

fire: flowering is enhanced by summer fires.
description: flower stem 120-500 mm tall, slender, brown, fleshy, usually nodding when in bud, 4-25-flowered. flowers tubular, pendulous, 16-20 mm long, externally grey to greyish brown, smooth to warty, internally crystalline white. petal margins irregular or wavy. labellum 9-11 x 4.5-6 mm, nearly triangular, white with orange margins, 3-lobed; lateral lobes with upturned, irregular margins; midlobe yellowish, with wide, angular to triangular basal margins, irregular towards apex. callus of 2 prominent ridges, spreading then convergent, breaking up into irregular calli on midlobe, producing yellow pseudopollen. column 6.5-7.5 x 2.5-3 mm, smooth; anther cap smooth.  widespread and common; growing in coastal scrub and a range of moister, forested habitats including wet sclerophyll forest and along rainforest margins in sandy loam and clay loam. plants commonly occur close to eucalypt trunks. flowering is enhanced by summer fires. a vigorous form, which becomes naturalised in garden mulch, has flower stems that are straight when in bud, greyish white flowers, produces very little pseudopollen on the labellum and sets a very high proportion of capsules. it appears in gardens, nature strips and other mulched sites when the mulch reaches a suitable stage of decay. it has been observed in n.s.w., a.c.and new zealand. flowers september-january. ;
original_text: Flower stem 120-500 mm tall, slender, brown, fleshy, usually nodding when in bud, 4-25-flowered. Flowers tubular, pendulous, 16-20 mm long, externally grey to greyish brown, smooth to warty, internally crystalline white. Petal margins irregular or wavy. Labellum 9-11 x 4.5-6 mm, nearly triangular, white with orange margins, 3-lobed; lateral lobes with upturned, irregular margins; midlobe yellowish, with wide, angular to triangular basal margins, irregular towards apex. Callus of 2 prominent ridges, spreading then convergent, breaking up into irregular calli on midlobe, producing yellow pseudopollen. Column 6.5-7.5 x 2.5-3 mm, smooth; anther cap smooth.  Widespread and common; growing in coastal scrub and a range of moister, forested habitats including wet sclerophyll forest and along rainforest margins in sandy loam and clay loam. Plants commonly occur close to eucalypt trunks. Flowering is enhanced by summer fires. A vigorous form, which becomes naturalised in garden mulch, has flower stems that are straight when in bud, greyish white flowers, produces very little pseudopollen on the labellum and sets a very high proportion of capsules. It appears in gardens, nature strips and other mulched sites when the mulch reaches a suitable stage of decay. It has been observed in N.S.W., A.C.T. and New Zealand. Flowers September-January.

fire: associated with riparian forests, particularly when in dry conditions, simple meso-notophyll vine forests, and frequently in burnt areas as part of regeneration phase, in both acidic and basic soils.
description: shrub or small tree; branches glabrous. leaves petiolate; lamina narrowly ovate to elliptic or narrowly obovate, 6-10 cm long, 2-3 cm wide, acute to attenuate at base, entire or slightly crenulate, long-acuminate or sometimes abruptly subacute at apex, glabrous; veins 3-5 pairs. inflorescences axillary, 3-5-flowered; peduncles glabrous. calyx 1-1.5 mm long. corolla campanulate, not constricted at middle, (2.5-) 3-3.5 (-4) mm long, white, often with yellow tinge; inner surface of tube pilose, often almost to apex of lobes, with hairs 0.3-0.4 mm long. ovary glabrous or sometimes hairy at base of style; style 0.6-1.8 (-2) mm long, ‚ patent-hairy at least at base, sometimes sparsely hairy throughout. capsule 2-valved. associated with riparian forests, particularly when in dry conditions, simple meso-notophyll vine forests, and frequently in burnt areas as part of regeneration phase, in both acidic and basic soils. altitude 50-1000 m. flowers june-november; fruits september-february. ;

Inflorescences axillary, 3-5-flowered; peduncles glabrous. Calyx 1-1.5 mm long. Ovary glabrous or sometimes hairy at base of style; style 0.6-1.8 (-2) mm long, ‚ patent-hairy at least at base, sometimes sparsely hairy throughout. Capsule 2-valved. fire: flowering is enhanced by summer fires.
description: plants growing singly, scattered in loose groups, occasionally in crowded tufts, reddish or brownish, fleshy, brittle. leaf 40-180 x 2-2.5 mm; free part 10-20 mm long, ending below flowers. spike 10-25 mm long, dense, 1-12-flowered. flowers upside-down, crowded, porrect, 8-11 x 11-15 mm, greenish to brownish or reddish brown, with a reddish labellum. dorsal sepal broadly ovate, 3-3.5 x 3.5-4 mm, three red bands, margins glabrous, apex with long linear mucro. lateral sepals horizontal to erect, widely divergent, 8-10 x 1.5-2 mm, erect, apex boat-shaped. petals ovate-lanceolate, asymmetric, circa 3 x 1.5 mm, margins usually notched or unequally toothed, sometimes entire. labellum stiffly hinged to apex of column foot, oblong in basal half with marginal constriction, tapered in distal half to narrowly blunt apex, 4 x 1.5 mm, margins glabrous. callus fleshy, channelled, of 2 lobes or single and bilobed, restricted to basal part of labellum. column wings narrow, curved, entire. the biology and structure of this unique species is being closely studied by wendy grimm who has located some unusual clumps of this orchid with various-sized stem-tubers crowded together in tight groups. new t growths which can develop into separate plants are produced from the surface of parent stem tuber, beginning as small papillate outgrowths. highly localised, but cryptic and rarely seen; growing among shrubs in open forest, shrubby forest and heathy forest in freely draining, sandy and gravelly soils. flowering is enhanced by summer fires. flowers february-april. ;
original_text: Plants growing singly, scattered in loose groups, occasionally in crowded tufts, reddish or brownish, fleshy, brittle. Leaf 40-180 x 2-2.5 mm; free part 10-20 mm long, ending below flowers. Spike 10-25 mm long, dense, 1-12-flowered. Flowers upside-down, crowded, porrect, 8-11 x 11-15 mm, greenish to brownish or reddish brown, with a reddish labellum. Dorsal sepal broadly ovate, 3-3.5 x 3.5-4 mm, three red bands, margins glabrous, apex with long linear mucro. Lateral sepals horizontal to erect, widely divergent, 8-10 x 1.5-2 mm, erect, apex boat-shaped. Petals ovate-lanceolate, asymmetric, c. 3 x 1.5 mm, margins usually notched or unequally toothed, sometimes entire. Labellum stiffly hinged to apex of column foot, oblong in basal half with marginal constriction, tapered in distal half to narrowly blunt apex, 4 x 1.5 mm, margins glabrous. Callus fleshy, channelled, of 2 lobes or single and bilobed, restricted to basal part of labellum. Column wings narrow, curved, entire. The biology and structure of this unique species is being closely studied by Wendy Grimm who has located some unusual clumps of this orchid with various-sized stem-tubers crowded together in tight groups. New tuber-like growths which can develop into separate plants are produced from the surface of parent stem tuber, beginning as small papillate outgrowths. Highly localised, but cryptic and rarely seen; growing among shrubs in open forest, shrubby forest and heathy forest in freely draining, sandy and gravelly soils. Flowering is enhanced by summer fires. Flowers February-April.

fire: resprouts after fire.
description: herb, monoecious, perennial, rhizomatous, forming small tufts or large clumps to 30 cm across. rhizome horizontal, stout, 7-10 mm diam., 6-10 mm long, densely villous with white hairs partially covered by scarious scales, the scales pale brown, glossy, glabrous except for long hairs at the base and rarely distally on the keel, broadly ovate to deltoid but split along median line by sympodial growth of rhizome. cataphylls scarious, oblong, lower ones appressed; upper cataphylls erect, 2-4 cm long. culms closely spaced, mostly 5 (-8) mm apart on the rhizome, erect, 50-80 cm long, 1-1.5 mm diam., grey-green, internodes 4-6, the lowest internode and base of the second internode densely woolly with white hairs up to 3.5 mm long. sheaths: lower sheaths to 5 cm long, caducous, leaving prominent swollen nodes; the 2 or 3 uppermost sheaths persistent, often crowded below the uppermost elongated internode; (2.2-) 4.5-7.0 cm long, green or straw-coloured, glabrous, auriculate with a narrow membranous margin; lamina subulate, (1-) 4-5 (-9) mm long. inflorescence branches slender, 1-2 cm long. spikelets (1-) 2-3 per culm, ovoid, 1.2-1.7 cm long, 0.5-1 cm wide; axis zigzag; glumes 8-12, ovate to broad-lanceolate, 4-8 mm long, dark brown to black, concave, rigid, acute to acuminate, densely pubescent; margins broad, hyaline. male flowers: tepals lanceolate, dark brown, soft, densely pubescent adaxially toward the apex with pale hairs, acute, 5.5-7.5 mm long; filaments 3-7 mm long; anthers 2.5-3.5 mm long, attached slightly above the middle to the short connective. female flowers: tepals lanceolate, acute, concave, dark brown with pale hyaline margins; pubescent toward the apex with pale, tangled, branched, multicellular hairs; outer tepals keeled, circa 5 mm long; inner tepals almost flat, 6-6.5 mm long. capsule 3.5-4.0 mm long, brown, smooth, the valve margins prominently thickened and pale, often 1 or 2 carpels aborted. seeds broad-ellipsoidal, circa 1.5-2.0 mm long, patterned with convex, strongly lobed cells. culm anatomy: with grooves extending to the base of the chlorenchyma, overarched by enlarged epidermal cells; stomates and accompanying sclereids at base of the groove; ridges with a central sclerenchyma rib. grows in deep sands or laterite with sand; in seasonally moist habitats in a region of low rainfall.   wind pollinated. resprouts after fire. flowers august-september. ;
original_text: Herb, monoecious, perennial, rhizomatous, forming small tufts or large clumps to 30 cm across. Rhizome horizontal, stout, 7-10 mm diam., 6-10 mm long, densely villous with white hairs partially covered by scarious scales, the scales pale brown, glossy, glabrous except for long hairs at the base and rarely distally on the keel, broadly ovate to deltoid but split along median line by sympodial growth of rhizome. Cataphylls scarious, oblong, lower ones appressed; upper cataphylls erect, 2-4 cm long. Culms closely spaced, mostly 5 (-8) mm apart on the rhizome, erect, 50-80 cm long, 1-1.5 mm diam., grey-green, internodes 4-6, the lowest internode and base of the second internode densely woolly with white hairs up to 3.5 mm long. Sheaths: lower sheaths to 5 cm long, caducous, leaving prominent swollen nodes; the 2 or 3 uppermost sheaths persistent, often crowded below the uppermost elongated internode; (2.2-) 4.5-7.0 cm long, green or straw-coloured, glabrous, auriculate with a narrow membranous margin; lamina subulate, (1-) 4-5 (-9) mm long. Inflorescence branches slender, 1-2 cm long. Spikelets (1-) 2-3 per culm, ovoid, 1.2-1.7 cm long, 0.5-1 cm wide; axis zigzag; glumes 8-12, ovate to broad-lanceolate, 4-8 mm long, dark brown to black, concave, rigid, acute to acuminate, densely pubescent; margins broad, hyaline. Male flowers: tepals lanceolate, dark brown, soft, densely pubescent adaxially toward the apex with pale hairs, acute, 5.5-7.5 mm long; filaments 3-7 mm long; anthers 2.5-3.5 mm long, attached slightly above the middle to the short connective. Female flowers: tepals lanceolate, acute, concave, dark brown with pale hyaline margins; pubescent toward the apex with pale, tangled, branched, multicellular hairs; outer tepals keeled, c. 5 mm long; inner tepals almost flat, 6-6.5 mm long. Capsule 3.5-4.0 mm long, brown, smooth, the valve margins prominently thickened and pale, often 1 or 2 carpels aborted. Seeds broad-ellipsoidal, c. 1.5-2.0 mm long, patterned with convex, strongly lobed cells. Culm anatomy: with grooves extending to the base of the chlorenchyma, overarched by enlarged epidermal cells; stomates and accompanying sclereids at base of the groove; ridges with a central sclerenchyma rib. Grows in deep sands or laterite with sand; in seasonally moist habitats in a region of low rainfall.   Wind pollinated. Resprouts after fire. Flowers August-September.

fire: the species respond vigorously after fire or light soil disturbance.
description: glabrous erect perennial herbs; rootstock woody, bearing numerous unbranched annual stems. leaves alternate, entire, often deciduous; juvenile leaves often smaller than adults. inflorescence a terminal cyme of compound dichasia; bracts and bracteoles similar to leaves. flowers yellow or cream; pedicels filamentous. sepals 2 or 4, deltoid, smooth. petals 2 or 4, spirally twisted. stamens 4 or 8; anthers linear-oblong, 4-locular, usually shortly apiculate. ovary 1-locular, 2-4-winged or -ribbed; ovules 4, pendulous; styles 2 or 4, clavate; stigmas capitate, shortly fimbriate. fruit ovoid to obovoid or obovate, 2-4-winged or -ribbed, cream or yellow (sometimes reddish); wings decurrent in sepals (except roei ) and pedicels; pericarp between wings swollen or membranous. seed 1. the species respond vigorously after fire or light soil disturbance. ;

Petals 2 or 4, spirally twisted. Stamens 4 or 8; anthers linear-oblong, 4-locular, usually shortly apiculate. Ovary 1-locular, 2-4-winged or -ribbed; ovules 4, pendulous; styles 2 or 4, clavate; stigmas capitate, shortly fimbriate. Fruit ovoid to obovoid or obovate, 2-4-winged or -ribbed, cream or yellow (sometimes reddish); wings decurrent in sepals (except G. roei ) and pedicels; pericarp between wings swollen or membranous. Seed 1. The species respond vigorously after fire or light soil disturbance.

fire: flowering occurs freely in unburnt habitat, but massed flowering is common on burnt ground, often with larger and more deeply coloured flowers.
description: leaf 30-60 x 15-20 mm, dark green, hairy. flower stem 100-300 mm tall, 1-3-flowered. flowers 30-45 x 30-45 mm, mauve to purple, lighter and spotted towards centre, rarely all white, labellum mauve with a white base, calli yellow, column purple. dorsal sepal 18-25 x 6-8 mm, erect or recurved. lateral sepals 18-25 x 7-10 mm, divergent. petals 16-20 x 5-7 mm, spreading. labellum 7.5-9.5 x 5-6.5 mm, obscurely 3-lobed; lateral lobes mounded, white with numerous short papillae; midlobe mauve to purple. appendages fused, held erect against column or curved forwards, tip expanded, yellow, deeply notched, lobes divergent. column 8-9.5 x 4-4.5 mm, mauve, centre whitish. hybridises with glossodia minor and rarely with pheladenia deformis (see xglossadenia tutelata). a widely distributed, common and very familiar orchid that ranges from highland regions in the tropics to temperate areas and from the coast to inland hills. it grows in many different habitats including open forest, woodland and coastal heath, always in freely draining soil. the flowers increase in size for several days after opening. flowering occurs freely in unburnt habitat, but massed flowering is common on burnt ground, often with larger and more deeply coloured flowers. flowers freely in good seasons, often producing massed colourful displays. flowers august-november. ;
original_text: Leaf 30-60 x 15-20 mm, dark green, hairy. Flower stem 100-300 mm tall, 1-3-flowered. Flowers 30-45 x 30-45 mm, mauve to purple, lighter and spotted towards centre, rarely all white, labellum mauve with a white base, calli yellow, column purple. Dorsal sepal 18-25 x 6-8 mm, erect or recurved. Lateral sepals 18-25 x 7-10 mm, divergent. Petals 16-20 x 5-7 mm, spreading. Labellum 7.5-9.5 x 5-6.5 mm, obscurely 3-lobed; lateral lobes mounded, white with numerous short papillae; midlobe mauve to purple. Appendages fused, held erect against column or curved forwards, tip expanded, yellow, deeply notched, lobes divergent. Column 8-9.5 x 4-4.5 mm, mauve, centre whitish. Hybridises with Glossodia minor and rarely with Pheladenia deformis (see xGlossadenia tutelata). A widely distributed, common and very familiar orchid that ranges from highland regions in the tropics to temperate areas and from the coast to inland hills. It grows in many different habitats including open forest, woodland and coastal heath, always in freely draining soil. The flowers increase in size for several days after opening. Flowering occurs freely in unburnt habitat, but massed flowering is common on burnt ground, often with larger and more deeply coloured flowers. Flowers freely in good seasons, often producing massed colourful displays. Flowers August-November.

fire: often grows in dense, tangled shrubbery and flowers more profusely in years after a fire.
description: leaf 15-30 x 8-10 mm, dark green. flower stem 80-150 mm tall, 1- or 2-flowered. flowers 20-25 x 20-25mm, mauve to purple, centre lighter, rarely all white, labellum mauve to purple, tip sometimes white, appendages yellow or whitish with black tips, column purple. dorsal sepal 12-15 x 3-5 mm, erect or recurved. lateral sepals 12-15 x 3-5 mm, divergent. petals 10-13 x 3-5 mm. labellum 4-5 x 2-3 mm, obscurely 3-lobed; lateral lobes with numerous short, white papillae. appendages paired, joined at yellow base, parallel, curved forwards, each with a prominent, dark purple, clubbed apex. column 4.5-5.5 x 3-3.5 mm, mauve to purple. hybridises rarely with glossodia major and caladenia caerulea (bradhurst 2000). widespread and locally common; mainly growing in coastal heathland, grasstree plains and heathy forest in freely draining, sandy soils; also extending inland to dividing range in some areas of the riverina. often grows in dense, tangled shrubbery and flowers more profusely in years after a fire. flowers july-october. ;
original_text: Leaf 15-30 x 8-10 mm, dark green. Flower stem 80-150 mm tall, 1- or 2-flowered. Flowers 20-25 x 20-25mm, mauve to purple, centre lighter, rarely all white, labellum mauve to purple, tip sometimes white, appendages yellow or whitish with black tips, column purple. Dorsal sepal 12-15 x 3-5 mm, erect or recurved. Lateral sepals 12-15 x 3-5 mm, divergent. Petals 10-13 x 3-5 mm. Labellum 4-5 x 2-3 mm, obscurely 3-lobed; lateral lobes with numerous short, white papillae. Appendages paired, joined at yellow base, parallel, curved forwards, each with a prominent, dark purple, clubbed apex. Column 4.5-5.5 x 3-3.5 mm, mauve to purple. Hybridises rarely with Glossodia major and Caladenia caerulea (Bradhurst 2000). Widespread and locally common; mainly growing in coastal heathland, grasstree plains and heathy forest in freely draining, sandy soils; also extending inland to dividing range in some areas of the Riverina. Often grows in dense, tangled shrubbery and flowers more profusely in years after a fire. Flowers July-October.

fire: grows on sand plain, appearing particularly after fire.
description: erect, short-lived or perennial herb to 40 cm tall, silvery hairy. leaves mostly basal, obovate to lanceolate, sinuate-lobed to entire; lamina 5-10 cm long, 2-2.5 cm wide. inflorescence a compact spike or s thyrse, to 15 cm long; bracts oblong to linear, to 10 mm long; bracteoles linear, circa 6 mm long. sepals linear, 5 mm long, adnate to ovary along midrib only except basally. corolla circa 15 mm long, with stiff hairs inside towards base; lobes equal, circa 8 mm long; wings circa 0.5 mm wide. indusium oblong, 2 mm long. ovules to 60. fruit cylindrical, circa 6 mm long; valves entire. seeds elliptic, circa 1 mm long, black. the corolla is blue, to pinkish mauve with a yellow spot at top of throat and an inconspicuous pocket. grows on sand plain, appearing particularly after fire. flowers oct.-jan. ;
original_text: Erect, short-lived or perennial herb to 40 cm tall, silvery hairy. Leaves mostly basal, obovate to lanceolate, sinuate-lobed to entire; lamina 5-10 cm long, 2-2.5 cm wide. Inflorescence a compact spike or spike-like thyrse, to 15 cm long; bracts oblong to linear, to 10 mm long; bracteoles linear, c. 6 mm long. Sepals linear, 5 mm long, adnate to ovary along midrib only except basally. Corolla c. 15 mm long, with stiff hairs inside towards base; lobes equal, c. 8 mm long; wings c. 0.5 mm wide. Indusium oblong, 2 mm long. Ovules to 60. Fruit cylindrical, c. 6 mm long; valves entire. Seeds elliptic, c. 1 mm long, black. The corolla is blue, to pinkish mauve with a yellow spot at top of throat and an inconspicuous pocket. Grows on sand plain, appearing particularly after fire. Flowers Oct.-Jan.

fire: appearing particularly after fire and in disturbed ground.
description: usually several-stemmed, much-branched, perennial subshrub to 80 cm tall, glandular-viscid. leaves basal and cauline, obovate to oblanceolate, sometimes dentate, glandular-pubescent to glabrescent; lamina 4-7 cm long, 2-3 cm wide. flowers in loose thyrses to 40 cm long; bracts , smaller apically; peduncle to 5 cm long; bracteoles usually linear, to 10 mm long; pedicel mostly to 4 mm long corolla hairy inside; enations in regular rows bearing conspicuous tuft of hairs; lobes unequal to 14 mm long. otherwise similar to goodenia scaevolina . the corolla is blue. similar to goodenia scaevolina , differing in the more unequal corolla lobes, the more numerous simple hairs on the outside of the corolla and the more conspicuous enations inside the corolla. appearing particularly after fire and in disturbed ground. flowers chiefly mar.-oct. ;
original_text: Usually several-stemmed, much-branched, perennial subshrub to 80 cm tall, glandular-viscid. Leaves basal and cauline, obovate to oblanceolate, sometimes dentate, glandular-pubescent to glabrescent; lamina 4-7 cm long, 2-3 cm wide. Flowers in loose thyrses to 40 cm long; bracts leaf-like, smaller apically; peduncle to 5 cm long; bracteoles usually linear, to 10 mm long; pedicel mostly to 4 mm long Corolla hairy inside; enations in regular rows bearing conspicuous tuft of hairs; lobes unequal to 14 mm long. Otherwise similar to Goodenia scaevolina . The corolla is blue. Similar to Goodenia scaevolina , differing in the more unequal corolla lobes, the more numerous simple hairs on the outside of the corolla and the more conspicuous enations inside the corolla. Appearing particularly after fire and in disturbed ground. Flowers chiefly Mar.-Oct.

fire: fire response unknown.
description: shrub 0.8-2 m tall. leaves petiolate, narrowly oblong or narrowly ovate in general outline, 3-6.5 cm long, 15-25 mm wide, serrato-dentate with (6-) 13-25 pungent teeth spaced evenly around margins; base truncate to broadly cuneate; margins undulate, not recurved; surfaces similar, densely glandular-hispidulous. conflorescence terminal or axillary, simple, subglobose tending subsecund; floral rachis 1-5? mm long. pedicels 2-2.5 mm long. torus extended dorsally well beyond pedicel. flower colour: perianth red; style pale orange. perianth glabrous outside, villous inside near base. pistil 4-6 mm long, glabrous; stipe 1-3 mm long, almost perpendicular to pedicel; style not or scarcely exserted from late bud. follicle obloid, 9.5-11 mm long, glabrous. grevillea adenotricha is a distinctive species, characterised by the leaves with many evenly distributed marginal teeth, the very short pistil, and the dense indumentum of gland-tipped simple hairs occurring on most vegetative parts. this species also has the seed ellipsoidal with a recurved margin bearing a pale wavy rim, and on this feature is likely to be more closely related to longicuspis than to other members of this group. fire response unknown. flowers may-aug. ;
original_text: Shrub 0.8-2 m tall. Leaves petiolate, narrowly oblong or narrowly ovate in general outline, 3-6.5 cm long, 15-25 mm wide, serrato-dentate with (6-) 13-25 pungent teeth spaced evenly around margins; base truncate to broadly cuneate; margins undulate, not recurved; surfaces similar, densely glandular-hispidulous. Conflorescence terminal or axillary, simple, subglobose tending subsecund; floral rachis 1-5? mm long. Pedicels 2-2.5 mm long. Torus extended dorsally well beyond pedicel. Flower colour: perianth red; style pale orange. Perianth glabrous outside, villous inside near base. Pistil 4-6 mm long, glabrous; stipe 1-3 mm long, almost perpendicular to pedicel; style not or scarcely exserted from late bud. Follicle obloid, 9.5-11 mm long, glabrous. Grevillea adenotricha is a distinctive species, characterised by the leaves with many evenly distributed marginal teeth, the very short pistil, and the dense indumentum of gland-tipped simple hairs occurring on most vegetative parts. This species also has the seed ellipsoidal with a recurved margin bearing a pale wavy rim, and on this feature is likely to be more closely related to G. longicuspis than to other members of this group. Fire response unknown. Flowers May-Aug.

description: dense to open shrub, 0.8-2.5 m high, to 2.5 m across. leaves pinnatipartite and partly bipinnatifid (rarely an odd small leaf entire and elliptic), 8-16.5 cm long, 50-105 mm wide; primary lobes 5-16, simple to 6-fid; ultimate lobes subtriangular to narrowly oblong, 0.5-4 cm long, not pungent; margins shortly recurved; lower surface densely tomentose with curled hairs. unit conflorescence erect, secund; floral rachis 30-50 mm long. flower colour: perianth grey to purplish with pale hairs; style deep burgundy to scarlet or pale pinkish mauve. perianth loosely subvillous outside. pistil 15-18.5 mm long; ovary stipitate; style glabrous. follicle 9-10.5 mm long, tomentose. grevillea beadleana has rather prominent floral bracts which are 5.7-6.2 mm long and persistent to anthesis. there is some minor variation in leaf division and flower colour. plants of the guy fawkes population tend to have numerous secondary leaf lobes and burgundy styles; those of the mole population also have extensive secondary lobing and more scarlet styles. the grafton population is known from only fragmentary fresh specimens, but has more sparing secondary lobing (as does the walcha collection) and pale mauve-pink styles; this sub-coastal form probably deserves subspecific status when adequate type material becomes available. variation in habit between sites is probably due to ecotype and fire history. regenerates from seed. grows in shallow sandy-loam soils over granite leucoadamellite or (grafton population) sandstone. flowers spring. ;
original_text: Dense to open shrub, 0.8-2.5 m high, to 2.5 m across. Leaves pinnatipartite and partly bipinnatifid (rarely an odd small leaf entire and elliptic), 8-16.5 cm long, 50-105 mm wide; primary lobes 5-16, simple to 6-fid; ultimate lobes subtriangular to narrowly oblong, 0.5-4 cm long, not pungent; margins shortly recurved; lower surface densely tomentose with curled hairs. Unit conflorescence erect, secund; floral rachis 30-50 mm long. Flower colour: perianth grey to purplish with pale hairs; style deep burgundy to scarlet or pale pinkish mauve. Perianth loosely subvillous outside. Pistil 15-18.5 mm long; ovary stipitate; style glabrous. Follicle 9-10.5 mm long, tomentose. Grevillea beadleana has rather prominent floral bracts which are 5.7-6.2 mm long and persistent to anthesis. There is some minor variation in leaf division and flower colour. Plants of the Guy Fawkes population tend to have numerous secondary leaf lobes and burgundy styles; those of the Mole R. population also have extensive secondary lobing and more scarlet styles. The Grafton population is known from only fragmentary fresh specimens, but has more sparing secondary lobing (as does the Walcha collection) and pale mauve-pink styles; this sub-coastal form probably deserves subspecific status when adequate type material becomes available. Variation in habit between sites is probably due to ecotype and fire history. Regenerates from seed. Grows in shallow sandy-loam soils over granite leucoadamellite or (Grafton population) sandstone. Flowers spring.

fire: fire response uncertain.
description: open shrub 0.3-1 m tall. leaves entire, elliptic to sub-oblong, often plump, 0.5-2.0 (-3.2) cm long, 2-6 mm wide; margins recurved to shortly revolute; upper surface minutely and densely granulose; lower surface partly exposed, with a dense matted indumentum of wavy to curly hairs. conflorescence axillary or terminal on short lateral branchlets, simple, erect to decurved, 1-4-flowered; floral rachis 0.2 mm long, subsericeous. flowers abaxially oriented. flower colour: perianth and style (including style-end) red. perianth sparsely tomentose outside (densely so on limb), bearded inside near base; tepals with a prominent median ridge. pistil 6-9 mm long; ovary subsessile, villous; style tomentose, scarcely exceeding perianth after release of style-end; pollen-presenter lateral. follicle ovoid, circa 13 mm long, pubescent. grevillea crassifolia was treated by mcgillivray & makinson (grevillea 285-288 (1993)) as 'element i' of a broadly circumscribed fasciculata . it is here accepted as narrowly distinct (see under fasciculata for differences), but may intergrade with the 'northern form' of that species. the torus of crassifolia is very oblique. probably regenerates from seed only. grows in low shrubland in gravelly loam soils, usually on slopes. flowers june-dec. fire response uncertain. ;
original_text: Open shrub 0.3-1 m tall. Leaves entire, elliptic to sub-oblong, often plump, 0.5-2.0 (-3.2) cm long, 2-6 mm wide; margins recurved to shortly revolute; upper surface minutely and densely granulose; lower surface partly exposed, with a dense matted indumentum of wavy to curly hairs. Conflorescence axillary or terminal on short lateral branchlets, simple, erect to decurved, 1-4-flowered; floral rachis 0.2 mm long, subsericeous. Flowers abaxially oriented. Flower colour: perianth and style (including style-end) red. Perianth sparsely tomentose outside (densely so on limb), bearded inside near base; tepals with a prominent median ridge. Pistil 6-9 mm long; ovary subsessile, villous; style tomentose, scarcely exceeding perianth after release of style-end; pollen-presenter lateral. Follicle ovoid, c. 13 mm long, pubescent. Grevillea crassifolia was treated by McGillivray & Makinson (Grevillea 285-288 (1993)) as 'element i' of a broadly circumscribed G. fasciculata . It is here accepted as narrowly distinct (see under G. fasciculata for differences), but may intergrade with the 'northern form' of that species. The torus of G. crassifolia is very oblique. Probably regenerates from seed only. Grows in low shrubland in gravelly loam soils, usually on slopes. Flowers June-Dec. Fire response uncertain.

fire: some ability to resprout epicormically after fire.
description: shrub or tree 2-4 (-6?) m tall. leaves 15-40 cm long, pinnatipartite with 7-13 primary lobes; lower lobes sometimes bipartite; ultimate lobes elliptic or broadly elliptic to obovate, 3-18 cm long, 10-40 mm wide, pliable, basally decurrent, not pungent; margins flat; lower surface glabrous to sericeous. conflorescence simple or to 6-branched; unit conflorescence ascending to decurved, subsecund to conico-cylindrical, acropetal; ultimate floral rachis 50-150 mm long. flowers twisting to obliquely basiscopic orientation in bud stage; pedicels spreading to retrorse, 5-7 mm long. flower colour: perianth pink, or cream becoming flushed with pink, rarely reddish; style pink. perianth glabrous outside, sparingly bearded inside. pistil 32-35 mm long, glabrous; stipe 10-12 mm long. follicle subglobose, 24-33 mm long, thick-walled, glabrous. grevillea decurrens is a close sister-species to heliosperma , under which name it was included (as 'pink-flowered assortment') by mcgillivray & makinson (grevillea 215-217 (1993)). see heliosperma for differences. some ability to resprout epicormically after fire. grows in open woodland in sandy or gravelly soils. flowers mainly nov.-mar. ;
original_text: Shrub or tree 2-4 (-6?) m tall. Leaves 15-40 cm long, pinnatipartite with 7-13 primary lobes; lower lobes sometimes bipartite; ultimate lobes elliptic or broadly elliptic to obovate, 3-18 cm long, 10-40 mm wide, pliable, basally decurrent, not pungent; margins flat; lower surface glabrous to sericeous. Conflorescence simple or to 6-branched; unit conflorescence ascending to decurved, subsecund to conico-cylindrical, acropetal; ultimate floral rachis 50-150 mm long. Flowers twisting to obliquely basiscopic orientation in bud stage; pedicels spreading to retrorse, 5-7 mm long. Flower colour: perianth pink, or cream becoming flushed with pink, rarely reddish; style pink. Perianth glabrous outside, sparingly bearded inside. Pistil 32-35 mm long, glabrous; stipe 10-12 mm long. Follicle subglobose, 24-33 mm long, thick-walled, glabrous. Grevillea decurrens is a close sister-species to G. heliosperma , under which name it was included (as 'pink-flowered assortment') by McGillivray & Makinson (Grevillea 215-217 (1993)). See G. heliosperma for differences. Some ability to resprout epicormically after fire. Grows in open woodland in sandy or gravelly soils. Flowers mainly Nov.-Mar.

simplified_phrase: fire response unknown; rhizomatous or lignotuberous; capable of stem-basal suckering
fire: fire response unknown, but type material appears to have been rhizomatous or lignotuberous, and capable of stem-basal suckering.
description: low shrub to ?40 cm tall. leaves entire, well-spaced along branchlets, spreading, linear, often gently curved, 0.8-1.3 cm long, 0.5-0.6 mm wide; margins revolute; upper surface scabrid; lower surface enclosed including midvein and 1-grooved, or rarely slightly exposed near leaf base. conflorescence terminal, simple to 3-branched; unit conflorescence a decurved 1-4-flowered loose cluster, opening uncertain; floral rachis 2-6 mm long, glabrous. flowers acroscopic. flower colour: not known, probably red or red and cream. perianth glabrous outside, bearded inside. pistil circa 16 mm long; ovary shortly stipitate, glabrous or with a few ascending hairs ventrally on basal half; stipe swollen, circa 0.5 mm long, ventrally tomentose; style glabrous, slightly exserted from late bud; pollen-presenter lateral. fruit and seed not known. fire response unknown, but type material appears to have been rhizomatous or lignotuberous, and capable of stem-basal suckering. recent treatments have considered divaricata as representing a depauperate plant of rosmarinifolia . re-examination of the types indicates that while very closely related, it should be recognised as distinct. grevillea rosmarinifolia is, with the exception of a few populations in vic., non-lignotuberous and non-rhizomatous, and has pistils usually 17-23 mm long; most montane populations (subsp rosmarinifolia ) have much longer, broader leaves (1.5-4 cm long, 1-3 mm wide) than divaricata , with a non-scabrid upper surface and often with the lower surface partly exposed. narrower-leaved populations of rosmarinifolia (in either subspecies) have the leaves strongly ascending and smooth or faintly granular. recorded as growing in dry open forest. flowering recorded for apr., probably also spring months. ;
original_text: Low shrub to ?40 cm tall. Leaves entire, well-spaced along branchlets, spreading, linear, often gently curved, 0.8-1.3 cm long, 0.5-0.6 mm wide; margins revolute; upper surface scabrid; lower surface enclosed including midvein and 1-grooved, or rarely slightly exposed near leaf base. Conflorescence terminal, simple to 3-branched; unit conflorescence a decurved 1-4-flowered loose cluster, opening uncertain; floral rachis 2-6 mm long, glabrous. Flowers acroscopic. Flower colour: not known, probably red or red and cream. Perianth glabrous outside, bearded inside. Pistil c. 16 mm long; ovary shortly stipitate, glabrous or with a few ascending hairs ventrally on basal half; stipe swollen, c. 0.5 mm long, ventrally tomentose; style glabrous, slightly exserted from late bud; pollen-presenter lateral. Fruit and seed not known. Fire response unknown, but type material appears to have been rhizomatous or lignotuberous, and capable of stem-basal suckering. Recent treatments have considered G. divaricata as representing a depauperate plant of G. rosmarinifolia . Re-examination of the types indicates that while very closely related, it should be recognised as distinct. Grevillea rosmarinifolia is, with the exception of a few populations in Vic., non-lignotuberous and non-rhizomatous, and has pistils usually 17-23 mm long; most montane populations (subsp. rosmarinifolia ) have much longer, broader leaves (1.5-4 cm long, 1-3 mm wide) than G. divaricata , with a non-scabrid upper surface and often with the lower surface partly exposed. Narrower-leaved populations of G. rosmarinifolia (in either subspecies) have the leaves strongly ascending and smooth or faintly granular. Recorded as growing in dry open forest. Flowering recorded for Apr., probably also spring months.

Leaves obovate to hemispherical or rarely elliptic, 1-6 cm long, 1-4 cm wide, cuneate to amplexicaul at base, entire or with few to many broad, obtuse scarcely pungent teeth, glabrous or nearly so; margins shortly recurved; lower surface minutely pitted, with mid- and lateral veins prominent. The 'typical form' has very rotund, many-toothed, often stem-clasping leaves; it occurs inland from the sea, at the base and on the slopes of hills and peaks. The 'entire-leaved form', perhaps better named the 'beach-dune form', has the leaves entire or with a very few (to 6) broad obtuse lobes, a cuneate base (not stem-clasping) and a prostrate or nearly prostrate habit. It is apparently restricted to dunes and sand-drifts behind beaches. Grevillea infundibularis is easily distinguished by the branchlets, which are densely pilose with simple and erect glandular hairs (long-seriate, up to 15 cells long) and by its glabrous and usually funnel-like, often amplexicaul leaves. Flowers all year, mainly ?Oct.-?May.

It differs from subsp. lavandulacea which has a more finely granulose leaf upper surface, usually has > 4 flowers per unit conflorescence (at least when terminal; axillary unit conflorescences may have only two flowers), and longest leaves usually > 10 mm long, crowded on short lateral branchlets or not. The differences are of degree, and various populations of the highly variable G. lavandulacea approach the appearance of subsp. rogersii. The 'typical form' occurs in Qld and N.T., and is a (?non-lignotuberous) fire-sensitive narrow-trunked shrub or tree with mostly smooth bark, narrow leaf lobes (usually J.R.Clarkson 5227 (BRI, K, NSW, QRS)) occurs in Qld on headlands and rocky peaks on Cape York N from c. 15ºS (parapatric with erect plants of the 'typical form'); it is a prostrate to procumbent shrub to 5 m across, with the habit retained in seedlings. It sets copious amounts of seed and has weed potential overseas. Grevillea pteridifolia hybridises readily with several other species and is a parent of several commercial hybrids. Regeneration variable, usually mainly from seeds, sometimes also lignotubers, occasionally also rhizomes and epicormic shoots. Grows in a wide range of habitats including eucalypt woodland, heath, and openings in sub-rainforest scrub; often in moister sites such as floodplains, near swamps or creeks but also on ridges and slopes; soils usually sandy or occasionally clay-loams. Flowers year round, but mainly May-Sept.
