description: erect shrubs (0.5-) 1.0-2.0 (-2.5) m high, single-stemmed at base and reseeding after fire. young stems puberulous with short, straight, golden hairs. leaves oblong to obovate or obtriangular, (15-) 20-40 (-50) mm long, 5-15 (-30) mm wide, glabrous; base narrowed into a short stem-clasping petiole; intrapetiolar hair tufts absent; margins entire, with 1-4 pairs of (sometimes indistinct) teeth near the apex, which is acute or shortly apiculate and  straight or deflexed. flowers single, terminal on short lateral stems, sessile. bracts herbaceous; primary bract ovate to elliptic, acute or shortly acuminate, 7-10 mm long, glabrous; secondary bracts absent or few, grading into leaves. sepals (5-) 10-15 mm long, glabrous; outer sepals lanceolate to ovate, acute; inner sepals broadly elliptical to obovate, acute or attenuate. petals 5, yellow, obovate, 15-20 mm long, emarginate. stamens 20 (-25), in 5 bundles alternating with the carpels, each bundle with 4 or 5 stamens; filaments 1-1.2 mm long, fused except the inner one which is  free; anthers narrowly oblong to rectangular, 1.5-2.0 (-3.0) mm long, dehiscing by introrse longitudinal slits; staminodes absent. carpels 5; ovaries ovoid, glabrous; styles protruding outward and ascending, 3-5 mm long. ovules 2 per carpel. seeds orange-brown, shiny, almost globular, circa 3 mm long, circa 2.5 mm wide; aril  fleshy, yellow-orange, covering all or most of the seed.  occurs in a variety of habitats, including jarrah and marri woodlands, karri forests, banksia and mixed shrublands, and on coastal foredunes, in brown or grey sand, loam or clay. hibbertia cuneifolia is one of a small number of hibbertia species with bird- (rather than ant-) dispersed seeds. the carpels gape widely when mature, displaying the seeds with their brightly-coloured, fleshy, enveloping arils. birds have been observed foraging for these. flowers sporadically almost throughout the year, with a peak in october-december. ;
original_text: Erect shrubs (0.5-) 1.0-2.0 (-2.5) m high, single-stemmed at base and reseeding after fire. Young stems puberulous with short, straight, golden hairs. Leaves oblong to obovate or obtriangular, (15-) 20-40 (-50) mm long, 5-15 (-30) mm wide, glabrous; base narrowed into a short stem-clasping petiole; intrapetiolar hair tufts absent; margins entire, with 1-4 pairs of (sometimes indistinct) teeth near the apex, which is acute or shortly apiculate and  straight or deflexed. Flowers single, terminal on short lateral stems, sessile. Bracts herbaceous; primary bract ovate to elliptic, acute or shortly acuminate, 7-10 mm long, glabrous; secondary bracts absent or few, grading into leaves. Sepals (5-) 10-15 mm long, glabrous; outer sepals lanceolate to ovate, acute; inner sepals broadly elliptical to obovate, acute or attenuate. Petals 5, yellow, obovate, 15-20 mm long, emarginate. Stamens 20 (-25), in 5 bundles alternating with the carpels, each bundle with 4 or 5 stamens; filaments 1-1.2 mm long, fused except the inner one which is  free; anthers narrowly oblong to rectangular, 1.5-2.0 (-3.0) mm long, dehiscing by introrse longitudinal slits; staminodes absent. Carpels 5; ovaries ovoid, glabrous; styles protruding outward and ascending, 3-5 mm long. Ovules 2 per carpel. Seeds orange-brown, shiny, almost globular, c. 3 mm long, c. 2.5 mm wide; aril  fleshy, yellow-orange, covering all or most of the seed.  Occurs in a variety of habitats, including jarrah and marri woodlands, karri forests, Banksia and mixed shrublands, and on coastal foredunes, in brown or grey sand, loam or clay. Hibbertia cuneifolia is one of a small number of Hibbertia species with bird- (rather than ant-) dispersed seeds. The carpels gape widely when mature, displaying the seeds with their brightly-coloured, fleshy, enveloping arils. Birds have been observed foraging for these. Flowers sporadically almost throughout the year, with a peak in October-December.

Sepals 5.5‹€ ¢‚¬„¢6.8 mm long, herbaceous; abaxial surface sparsely to densely puberulous with fascicled and/or straight or hooked hairs; midribs not prominent, adaxial surface sparsely puberulous with minute, fine, fascicled hairs towards the apex; outer sepals ovate-acute; inner sepals similar in size, shape and indumentum to the outer but usually broader and more obtuse. Petals 5, yellow, obovate, 10-13 (-15) mm long,  deeply emarginate. Stamens (9-) 10-15 (-18), all on one side of the carpels and curving over them; filaments shortly fused at the base, 1.2-1.6 mm long; anthers rectangular, 1.8‹€ ¢‚¬„¢2.2 mm long, dehiscing by introrse, longitudinal slits; staminodes 7-20, in bundles lateral to and opposite the fertile stamens. Carpels 2; ovaries compressed-globular, densely pubescent; styles curved excentrically from the carpel apex, c. 2 mm long. Ovules 2 per carpel. Seeds globular, c. 4 mm long, glossy, red-brown; aril translucent, lacerate-margined, covering c. half the length of the seed.  Occurs in a wide variety of habitats including jarrah-marri forest and wandoo woodlands on laterites and granite, Banksia woodlands, in acid coastal sands, and Acacia shrublands on coastal limestones. Resprouting from the rootstock after fire. Flowers June-October, with occasional flowering as early as May in the north of its range and as late as January in the south.

Bracts 3-6, brown, scarious, broadly ovate, 4-8 mm long, glabrous except for a few hairs towards the acute apex; primary and secondary bracts similar. Sepals ovate, 7-10 mm long, glabrous except for a distinct patch of short, appressed hairs at the apex and a minute ciliate fringe; midribs not prominent; outer sepals acute, often scarious at the apex; inner sepals similar in size, apex shape and indumentum to the outer sepals, but broader. Petals 5, yellow, obovate, 8-10 mm long, emarginate. Stamens 35-46, in 3 groups between the carpels; filaments free, c. 1.5 mm long, not closely appressed to the carpels; anthers rectangular, 1-1.2 mm long, dehiscing by short, introrse slits at the apex; staminodes (reduced stamens) absent or few. Carpels 3; ovaries compressed-globular, glabrous; styles spreading excentrically from the carpel apex, c. 6 mm long. Ovules 2 per carpel. Seeds not seen.  Known from jarrah-Allocasuarina fraseriana forest over Banksia grandis and tall open scrubland, on flat to gentle slopes, in grey sandy loam. Grows in relatively long-unburnt moist forests in deep leaf litter, and potentially fire-sensitive. Its diffuse habit, often growing as small clumps of stems arising from ground level but connected below ground by shortly spreading rhizomes to a narrow taproot, is unusual in the genus. The rhizomes do not appear to produce adventitious roots. The above-ground stems are little-branched, slender and weak and often supported by other vegetation. Flowers August-September.

simplified_phrase: killed by fire; fire avoidance on ridges
fire: hibiscus kirstyae is restricted to ridges away from the pavement margins, presumably to afford them some degree of protection from fire. the type population consists of around 200 individuals that are estimated to live for 3-6 years between fire periods.
description: shrub to 3 m high. branchlets glabrous (seedlings with very sparse aculei circa 1-1.25 mm long). stipules at length caducous, subulate, 8-12 mm long, glabrous. climax leaves: petiole 70-115 mm long, glabrous (petiole of seedling leaves with tubercle-based aculei); lamina very broadly ovate, transversely broadly elliptic or broadly elliptic, unlobed, 80-110 mm long, 70-170 mm wide, cordate or truncate base, weakly serrate margin, rounded apex, concolorous, with yellowish pink hairs, the indumentum generally similar on each surface, midrib and primary vein indumentum similar to that of the interveinal regions, with sparse aculei, 1-1.25 mm long. foliar nectary present at base of lamina, 5-6 mm long. distal leaves on flowering shoots reduced in shape and size, elliptic, or broadly elliptic (sometimes trilobed), distinctly petiolate on reproductive shoots. flowers solitary in leaf axils; peduncles well developed, 25-80 mm long, glabrous; pedicels 12-15 mm long, glabrous; epicalyx glabrous, 9 or 10 segments, 8-12 mm long, segments free at the base, incurved, subulate, 0.3 times the length of the calyx at anthesis; calyx at anthesis 5-lobed or -partite but not splitting, not adnate to the corolla and not falling with it after anthesis, 25-27 mm long at anthesis, glabrous between the ribs, lobes with prominent marginal ribs, these glabrous or occasionally pubescent, with sparse aculei, apex very narrowly acute, calyx nectary absent, in fruit not distinctly inflated or accrescent; petals 80-85 mm long, yellow with a red nectary at the base; staminal column 30 mm long, 5-toothed at the apex, stamens scattered along distal circa 30 mm of the column ( along the entire length), anthers dark purple-red, pollen dark purple-red; style exserted circa 4 mm beyond apex of staminal column, 5-branched with branches circa 1.5 mm long, stigmas entire, capitate, ovary glabrous. capsule 15-18 mm long, glabrous, capsule beak present. seeds angular-subreniform, circa 4 mm long, glabrous, striate and minutely pectinate-pubescent. considerable effort has been undertaken to locate additional populations in the region over a period of 12 years, including extensive observations by helicopter, but no further populations have been located to date. the glabrous capsule is unusual amongst australian indigenous species, shared only with hibiscus meraukensis hochr., which is distinguished from kirstyae by having deeply 2- or 3-lobed leaves, longer epicalyx lobes more than half as long as the calyx lobes, and white petals. from a distance the glaucous leaves, yellow flowers and tall shrub habit have the appearance of a calotropis r.br. with yellow deciduous leaves, which are noxious weeds elsewhere in the kimberley. hibiscus kirstyae is restricted to ridges away from the pavement margins, presumably to afford them some degree of protection from fire. the type population consists of around 200 individuals that are estimated to live for 3-6 years between fire periods.  flowering observed january-april. ;
original_text: Shrub to 3 m high. Branchlets glabrous (seedlings with very sparse aculei c. 1-1.25 mm long). Stipules at length caducous, subulate, 8-12 mm long, glabrous. Climax leaves: petiole 70-115 mm long, glabrous (petiole of seedling leaves with tubercle-based aculei); lamina very broadly ovate, transversely broadly elliptic or broadly elliptic, unlobed, 80-110 mm long, 70-170 mm wide, cordate or truncate base, weakly serrate margin, rounded apex, concolorous, with yellowish pink hairs, the indumentum generally similar on each surface, midrib and primary vein indumentum similar to that of the interveinal regions, with sparse aculei, 1-1.25 mm long. Foliar nectary present at base of lamina, 5-6 mm long. Distal leaves on flowering shoots reduced in shape and size, elliptic, or broadly elliptic (sometimes trilobed), distinctly petiolate on reproductive shoots. Flowers solitary in leaf axils; peduncles well developed, 25-80 mm long, glabrous; pedicels 12-15 mm long, glabrous; epicalyx glabrous, 9 or 10 segments, 8-12 mm long, segments free at the base, incurved, subulate, 0.3 times the length of the calyx at anthesis; calyx at anthesis 5-lobed or -partite but not splitting, not adnate to the corolla and not falling with it after anthesis, 25-27 mm long at anthesis, glabrous between the ribs, lobes with prominent marginal ribs, these glabrous or occasionally pubescent, with sparse aculei, apex very narrowly acute, calyx nectary absent, in fruit not distinctly inflated or accrescent; petals 80-85 mm long, yellow with a red nectary at the base; staminal column 30 mm long, 5-toothed at the apex, stamens scattered along distal c. 30 mm of the column ( along the entire length), anthers dark purple-red, pollen dark purple-red; style exserted c. 4 mm beyond apex of staminal column, 5-branched with branches c. 1.5 mm long, stigmas entire, capitate, ovary glabrous. Capsule 15-18 mm long, glabrous, capsule beak present. Seeds angular-subreniform, c. 4 mm long, glabrous, striate and minutely pectinate-pubescent. Considerable effort has been undertaken to locate additional populations in the region over a period of 12 years, including extensive observations by helicopter, but no further populations have been located to date. The glabrous capsule is unusual amongst Australian indigenous species, shared only with Hibiscus meraukensis Hochr., which is distinguished from H. kirstyae by having deeply 2- or 3-lobed leaves, longer epicalyx lobes more than half as long as the calyx lobes, and white petals. From a distance the glaucous leaves, yellow flowers and tall shrub habit have the appearance of a Calotropis R.Br. with yellow deciduous leaves, which are noxious weeds elsewhere in the Kimberley. Hibiscus kirstyae is restricted to ridges away from the pavement margins, presumably to afford them some degree of protection from fire. The type population consists of around 200 individuals that are estimated to live for 3-6 years between fire periods.  Flowering observed January-April.

description: shrub or tree 2-10 m high. branchlets with stellate hairs (hairs whitish grey), very dense on young branchlets, branches becoming glabrous or subglabrous with age. stipules deciduous (shedding early and leaving a conspicuous ring scar), 25-40 mm long, with stellate hairs. mature leaves: petiole 50-130 mm long; lamina orbicular to cordiform, unlobed, 100-200 (-300) mm long, conspicuously cordate bas, entire or serrulate margin, acute, acuminate or attenuate apex, concolorous to weakly discolorous, the adaxial surfaces glabrous or almost so, the abaxial surface densely hairy with whitish grey stellate hairs. flowers sympodial in few- to several-flowered terminal and/or distal-axillary racemoid axes; pedicel 20-50 mm long, indumentum of whitish stellate hairs, articulate; epicalyx cupular with grey green indumentum, 9-10-segmented, to 20 mm long at anthesis, fused at the base; calyx 15-30 mm long, lobes very narrowly triangular, with indumentum of grey-green stellate hairs; petals 40-90 mm long, yellow, reddish-maroon petal spot present, with stellate hairs abaxially; staminal column straight, circa 50 mm long; style 5-branched, stigmas entire. capsules broadly elliptic, 15-30 mm long, indumentum of grey-green hairs, shortly beaked. seeds 3-5 mm long, glabrous. a treatment for hibiscus tiliaceus var tiliaceus on christmas island and cocos (keeling) islands is provided by du puy & telford (1993: 145). coastal habitats, on beaches, dunes, near coastal lagoons and river entrances, heath, woodland, vineforest, rainforest. commonly occurs just above the high tide mark on sandy beaches, in coastal vine thicket or other vegetation, but also in mangrove vegetation or in riparian forest along the upper, brackish reaches of tidal rivers (cowie et al. 2013: 17). on christmas island it grows on the shore terrace from very near the shore to the base of the inland cliff; on cocos (keeling) islands recorded only for the main atoll on lagoon margins, often in thickets. a common pantropical species which is usually coastal but also occurs along river and lake margins and in marshes. (du puy & telford 1993: 145). the seeds will float in water for many weeks suggesting that this species is dispersed by water (du puy & telford 1993: 145). flowers and fruits most months. flowers november-april on lord howe island. various uses. aboriginal people use the timber to make long-stemmed smoking pipes, fire sticks, carvings and the shafts of fish spears, and use the inner bark for making straps and ropes (e g blake et al. 1998, puruntatameri 2001); see also wightman & andrews (1989: 50). ;
original_text: Shrub or tree 2-10 m high. Branchlets with stellate hairs (hairs whitish grey), very dense on young branchlets, branches becoming glabrous or subglabrous with age. Stipules deciduous (shedding early and leaving a conspicuous ring scar), 25-40 mm long, with stellate hairs. Mature leaves: petiole 50-130 mm long; lamina orbicular to cordiform, unlobed, 100-200 (-300) mm long, conspicuously cordate bas, entire or serrulate margin, acute, acuminate or attenuate apex, concolorous to weakly discolorous, the adaxial surfaces glabrous or almost so, the abaxial surface densely hairy with whitish grey stellate hairs. Flowers sympodial in few- to several-flowered terminal and/or distal-axillary racemoid axes; pedicel 20-50 mm long, indumentum of whitish stellate hairs, articulate; epicalyx cupular with grey green indumentum, 9-10-segmented, to 20 mm long at anthesis, fused at the base; calyx 15-30 mm long, lobes very narrowly triangular, with indumentum of grey-green stellate hairs; petals 40-90 mm long, yellow, reddish-maroon petal spot present, with stellate hairs abaxially; staminal column straight, c. 50 mm long; style 5-branched, stigmas entire. Capsules broadly elliptic, 15-30 mm long, indumentum of grey-green hairs, shortly beaked. Seeds 3-5 mm long, glabrous. A treatment for Hibiscus tiliaceus var. tiliaceus on Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands is provided by Du Puy & Telford (1993: 145). Coastal habitats, on beaches, dunes, near coastal lagoons and river entrances, heath, woodland, vineforest, rainforest. Commonly occurs just above the high tide mark on sandy beaches, in coastal vine thicket or other vegetation, but also in mangrove vegetation or in riparian forest along the upper, brackish reaches of tidal rivers (Cowie et al. 2013: 17). On Christmas Island it grows on the shore terrace from very near the shore to the base of the inland cliff; on Cocos (Keeling) Islands recorded only for the main atoll on lagoon margins, often in thickets. A common pantropical species which is usually coastal but also occurs along river and lake margins and in marshes. (Du Puy & Telford 1993: 145). The seeds will float in water for many weeks suggesting that this species is dispersed by water (Du Puy & Telford 1993: 145). Flowers and fruits most months. Flowers November-April on Lord Howe Island. Various uses. Aboriginal people use the timber to make long-stemmed smoking pipes, fire sticks, carvings and the shafts of fish spears, and use the inner bark for making straps and ropes (e.g. Blake et al. 1998, Puruntatameri 2001); see also Wightman & Andrews (1989: 50).

fire: resprouts after fire.
description: herb, evergreen, dioecious, perennial, forming diffuse patches of widely separated stems arising singly or several together. rhizomes long slender horizontal or ascending, up to at least 30 cm long, 1.2-2.5 mm diam., with internodes 1-3 cm long. stems 15-50 cm tall, 0.8-1.5 mm diam.; internodes 1.5-7 cm long; young culms pink, old culms grey-green, glaucous, rigid and wiry, branched from near base, with a single lateral branch per node. sheaths erect, oblong-spathulate, broadest toward the apex, slightly lax, scarious, red-brown, 0.7-1.5 cm long, truncate or auriculate; lamina 0.5-3 mm long. inflorescence branches arising singly at upper nodes; flowers in clusters of 2-4 at the apex of inflorescence branches. spathes subtending flower clusters similar to sheaths but smaller, 2-5 mm long, broad-deltoid, hyaline. male and female flowers similar, outer tepals 1.6-2.0 mm long; inner tepals 2.0-2.6 mm long. fruit an ovoid small drupe circa 2.7 mm long, with a thin fleshy outer pericarp and a hard inner pericarp, shed with a short fleshy pedicel and bracts and perianth attached. the occurrence of male and female plants suggests that individual clones may be as large as 200 m across. grows in sand or peaty sand, in heath on the floodplain of watercourses, in a region of moderately low rainfall. resprouts after fire. flowers in spring. ;
original_text: Herb, evergreen, dioecious, perennial, forming diffuse patches of widely separated stems arising singly or several together. Rhizomes long slender horizontal or ascending, up to at least 30 cm long, 1.2-2.5 mm diam., with internodes 1-3 cm long. Stems 15-50 cm tall, 0.8-1.5 mm diam.; internodes 1.5-7 cm long; young culms pink, old culms grey-green, glaucous, rigid and wiry, branched from near base, with a single lateral branch per node. Sheaths erect, oblong-spathulate, broadest toward the apex, slightly lax, scarious, red-brown, 0.7-1.5 cm long, truncate or auriculate; lamina 0.5-3 mm long. Inflorescence branches arising singly at upper nodes; flowers in clusters of 2-4 at the apex of inflorescence branches. Spathes subtending flower clusters similar to sheaths but smaller, 2-5 mm long, broad-deltoid, hyaline. Male and female flowers similar, outer tepals 1.6-2.0 mm long; inner tepals 2.0-2.6 mm long. Fruit an ovoid small drupe c. 2.7 mm long, with a thin fleshy outer pericarp and a hard inner pericarp, shed with a short fleshy pedicel and bracts and perianth attached. The occurrence of male and female plants suggests that individual clones may be as large as 200 m across. Grows in sand or peaty sand, in heath on the floodplain of watercourses, in a region of moderately low rainfall. Resprouts after fire. Flowers in spring.

fire: regenerates after fire or flood by resprouting.
description: herb, evergreen, dioecious, perennial, forming large tussocks or patches of branching stems, to 3 m across. rhizomes horizontal, to 30 cm long or more, 5-9 mm diam., nodes 3-8 mm apart, bearing crowded culms, covered with short glossy brown scales 5-8 mm long. cataphylls several erect 1.5-6 cm long. stems 35-100 cm tall, 0.5-2 mm diam.; internodes (3-) 6-11 cm long; young culms pink, turning blue-green; old culms grey-green, glaucous, rigid and wiry; branching except at the lowest nodes, with (1-) 2-4 lateral branches at each node. sheaths lax, sometimes recurved, reddish brown, oblong, broadest near the middle, 2.5-3.5 cm long, truncate or auriculate; apical margin scarious; lamina 2-15 mm long. inflorescence branches 2-4 at each upper culm node. flowers shortly pedicellate, in clusters of 4-18 toward the apex of branches, subtended by broad deltoid, acute, hyaline bracts; outer bract circa 3 mm long, inner bract circa 1.5 mm long. male flowers: tepals ovate, concave, reddish or yellowish brown, soft, hyaline, acute; outer tepals 1.3-1.9 mm long; inner tepals 2-2.6 mm long. female flowers: tepals similar to males,  equal, 2.5-3 mm long. fruit a globose or elliptic small drupe with a thin fleshy outer pericarp and a hard inner pericarp, shed with a short fleshy pedicel and bracts and perianth attached, 2.2-2.7 mm long, 1.8-2.5 mm wide, red when young, aging to brown, on a stout pedicel. seed surface patterned with small convex isodiametric angular cells. grows in flood-beds of watercourses, in deep sands or saline and clayey sands. regenerates after fire or flood by resprouting. flowers in spring. ;
original_text: Herb, evergreen, dioecious, perennial, forming large tussocks or patches of branching stems, to 3 m across. Rhizomes horizontal, to 30 cm long or more, 5-9 mm diam., nodes 3-8 mm apart, bearing crowded culms, covered with short glossy brown scales 5-8 mm long. Cataphylls several erect 1.5-6 cm long. Stems 35-100 cm tall, 0.5-2 mm diam.; internodes (3-) 6-11 cm long; young culms pink, turning blue-green; old culms grey-green, glaucous, rigid and wiry; branching except at the lowest nodes, with (1-) 2-4 lateral branches at each node. Sheaths lax, sometimes recurved, reddish brown, oblong, broadest near the middle, 2.5-3.5 cm long, truncate or auriculate; apical margin scarious; lamina 2-15 mm long. Inflorescence branches 2-4 at each upper culm node. Flowers shortly pedicellate, in clusters of 4-18 toward the apex of branches, subtended by broad deltoid, acute, hyaline bracts; outer bract c. 3 mm long, inner bract c. 1.5 mm long. Male flowers: tepals ovate, concave, reddish or yellowish brown, soft, hyaline, acute; outer tepals 1.3-1.9 mm long; inner tepals 2-2.6 mm long. Female flowers: tepals similar to males,  equal, 2.5-3 mm long. Fruit a globose or elliptic small drupe with a thin fleshy outer pericarp and a hard inner pericarp, shed with a short fleshy pedicel and bracts and perianth attached, 2.2-2.7 mm long, 1.8-2.5 mm wide, red when young, aging to brown, on a stout pedicel. Seed surface patterned with small convex isodiametric angular cells. Grows in flood-beds of watercourses, in deep sands or saline and clayey sands. Regenerates after fire or flood by resprouting. Flowers in spring.

fire: commonly occurs after fire (wheeler 1987: 155).
description: perennial herb with ascending stems to 30 cm long. leaves lanceolate, acute, flat, 5-25 mm long, without stipules. flowers solitary or in 2- or 3-flowered racemes, axillary. sepals narrowly lanceolate, acute, 2-4 mm long, green. petals blue-mauve; anterior petal 5-12 mm long, 6-7 mm wide; posterior petals narrowly oblong, 2-3 mm long, 1- or 2-veined; lateral petals broadly oblong, 2-3 mm long, 3- or 4-veined. anthers with triangular appendages. capsule circa 5 mm long. seeds circa 6, finely pustulate. grows in loam in eucalyptus forest. commonly occurs after fire (wheeler 1987: 155). flowers late winter-early summer. ;
original_text: Perennial herb with ascending stems to 30 cm long. Leaves lanceolate, acute, flat, 5-25 mm long, without stipules. Flowers solitary or in 2- or 3-flowered racemes, axillary. Sepals narrowly lanceolate, acute, 2-4 mm long, green. Petals blue-mauve; anterior petal 5-12 mm long, 6-7 mm wide; posterior petals narrowly oblong, 2-3 mm long, 1- or 2-veined; lateral petals broadly oblong, 2-3 mm long, 3- or 4-veined. Anthers with triangular appendages. Capsule c. 5 mm long. Seeds c. 6, finely pustulate. Grows in loam in Eucalyptus forest. Commonly occurs after fire (Wheeler 1987: 155). Flowers late winter-early summer.

simplified_phrase: killed by fire; regenerates from seed
fire: obligate seeder, killed by fire.
description: herb, dioecious, caespitose perennial, forming many-stemmed tussocks; scales brown, partly covering a woolly pubescence. culms spreading from a narrow base, crowded, erect or ascending, usually somewhat compressed but often terete towards the base, substriate to ribbed, much-branched, 30-40 cm long, 0.5-1 mm diam.; hairs so closely appressed as to appear glabrous. sheaths red or purple-brown when young, appearing glabrous, 0.5-2 cm long, + acute; lamina erect, caducous 2-12 mm long. inflorescence: male spikelets usually numerous, erect or on pendulous branches, at the uppermost few nodes, pedicellate; females with few to circa 20 spikelets per culm. male spikelets ovoid, 2.5-4 mm long; glumes 10-15, all fertile, ovate to obovate, acute to minutely mucronate, glabrous, brown, 1.5-2 mm long. female spikelets initially very narrow-cylindrical, the glumes becoming strongly recurved, 6-10 mm long; glumes 5-8, + lanceolate, acute, 3-8 mm long, brown with a broad hyaline apical margin, glabrous. male flowers: tepals 6; 2 outer tepals slightly longer, broad-oblanceolate, truncate, 0.8-1.0 mm long; inner tepals flat, lanceolate to oblanceolate, acute to truncate; anthers circa 0.8 mm long, sometimes becoming exserted. female flowers: flower stalk with a single bract, circa 0.3 mm long; tepals 1-1.5 mm long; style 3anched in the upper third. fruit a nut with woody pericarp, narrow-cylindrical, orange-tan, 1.9-3.0 mm long, circa 1 mm wide, shed with a short stalk and perianth. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2-4 layers of short cells, interrupted by pillar cells and partial sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles. heathy swamps and shrubland, in laterite gravel or sand, in more peaty and less well-drained sites than hypolaena exsulca. wind-pollinated. obligate seeder, killed by fire. flowers spring (september, october). ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, caespitose perennial, forming many-stemmed tussocks; scales brown, partly covering a woolly pubescence. Culms spreading from a narrow base, crowded, erect or ascending, usually somewhat compressed but often terete towards the base, substriate to ribbed, much-branched, 30-40 cm long, 0.5-1 mm diam.; hairs so closely appressed as to appear glabrous. Sheaths red or purple-brown when young, appearing glabrous, 0.5-2 cm long, + acute; lamina erect, caducous 2-12 mm long. Inflorescence: male spikelets usually numerous, erect or on pendulous branches, at the uppermost few nodes, pedicellate; females with few to c. 20 spikelets per culm. Male spikelets ovoid, 2.5-4 mm long; glumes 10-15, all fertile, ovate to obovate, acute to minutely mucronate, glabrous, brown, 1.5-2 mm long. Female spikelets initially very narrow-cylindrical, the glumes becoming strongly recurved, 6-10 mm long; glumes 5-8, + lanceolate, acute, 3-8 mm long, brown with a broad hyaline apical margin, glabrous. Male flowers: tepals 6; 2 outer tepals slightly longer, broad-oblanceolate, truncate, 0.8-1.0 mm long; inner tepals flat, lanceolate to oblanceolate, acute to truncate; anthers c. 0.8 mm long, sometimes becoming exserted. Female flowers: flower stalk with a single bract, c. 0.3 mm long; tepals 1-1.5 mm long; style 3anched in the upper third. Fruit a nut with woody pericarp, narrow-cylindrical, orange-tan, 1.9-3.0 mm long, c. 1 mm wide, shed with a short stalk and perianth. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2-4 layers of short cells, interrupted by pillar cells and partial sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles. Heathy swamps and shrubland, in laterite gravel or sand, in more peaty and less well-drained sites than Hypolaena exsulca. Wind-pollinated. Obligate seeder, killed by fire. Flowers spring (September, October).

fire: resprouts after fire.
description: herb, dioecious, perennial, rhizomatous, forming dense tussocks or diffuse patches to 1 m or more across. rhizome horizontal, stout, 3-8 mm diam.; scales pale brown, scarious, partly covering a pale brown pubescence. culms spaced up to 1 cm apart, erect to sinuose, terete to slightly compressed, smooth to striate, 20-60 cm long, 0.5-1.5 mm diam., glabrous, lowest internode pubescent. sheaths scarious, 5-25 mm long, cuspidate with lamina 2-3 mm long, rarely longer. inflorescence: male spikelets usually in a large, diffuse, terminal inflorescence 10-25 cm long, numerous, pedicellate; female spikelets solitary and terminating branches or few at the distal nodes of branches. male spikelets ovoid to obloid, 3-7 mm long; glumes 10-20, all fertile, ovate, cuspidate to mucronate, glabrous, red-brown, 1.6-2.2 mm long; mucro erect, to circa 0.6 mm long. female spikelets narrow at the base but upper glumes recurved and spreading, 8-18 mm long; glumes 3-8, lanceolate, abaxial surface of lowest glumes pubescent, cuspidate, 6-12 mm long tapering to a prominent reflexed tip, initially red-brown becoming grey with age. male flowers: tepals 6, ovate; outer lateral tepals truncate, 1-1.7 mm long; inner tepals concave, obtuse to acute, 0.8-1.2 mm long; anthers circa 0.7 mm long. female flowers: bract on flower stalk single, 0.2-0.5 mm long; tepals 0.5-1.0 mm long; style 3-branched. fruit a nut with woody pericarp, globose, brown, 2.2-3.5 mm long, smooth to sparsely pitted, shed with a short thick stalk and perianth. seed narrowly cylindrical, orange-tan, 1.6 mm long, 0.9 mm wide. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2-4 layers of short cells, interrupted by pillar cells and partial sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles. forest, woodland and heath; in regions of moderate rainfall and in drier sites in moist regions; also beside streams or in swamps in sand or peaty sand. wind-pollinated. resprouts after fire. flowers september-november. ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, perennial, rhizomatous, forming dense tussocks or diffuse patches to 1 m or more across. Rhizome horizontal, stout, 3-8 mm diam.; scales pale brown, scarious, partly covering a pale brown pubescence. Culms spaced up to 1 cm apart, erect to sinuose, terete to slightly compressed, smooth to striate, 20-60 cm long, 0.5-1.5 mm diam., glabrous, lowest internode pubescent. Sheaths scarious, 5-25 mm long, cuspidate with lamina 2-3 mm long, rarely longer. Inflorescence: male spikelets usually in a large, diffuse, terminal inflorescence 10-25 cm long, numerous, pedicellate; female spikelets solitary and terminating branches or few at the distal nodes of branches. Male spikelets ovoid to obloid, 3-7 mm long; glumes 10-20, all fertile, ovate, cuspidate to mucronate, glabrous, red-brown, 1.6-2.2 mm long; mucro erect, to c. 0.6 mm long. Female spikelets narrow at the base but upper glumes recurved and spreading, 8-18 mm long; glumes 3-8, lanceolate, abaxial surface of lowest glumes pubescent, cuspidate, 6-12 mm long tapering to a prominent reflexed tip, initially red-brown becoming grey with age. Male flowers: tepals 6, ovate; outer lateral tepals truncate, 1-1.7 mm long; inner tepals concave, obtuse to acute, 0.8-1.2 mm long; anthers c. 0.7 mm long. Female flowers: bract on flower stalk single, 0.2-0.5 mm long; tepals 0.5-1.0 mm long; style 3-branched. Fruit a nut with woody pericarp, globose, brown, 2.2-3.5 mm long, smooth to sparsely pitted, shed with a short thick stalk and perianth. Seed narrowly cylindrical, orange-tan, 1.6 mm long, 0.9 mm wide. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2-4 layers of short cells, interrupted by pillar cells and partial sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles. Forest, woodland and heath; in regions of moderate rainfall and in drier sites in moist regions; also beside streams or in swamps in sand or peaty sand. Wind-pollinated. Resprouts after fire. Flowers September-November.

simplified_phrase: resprouts and regenerates from seed after fire
fire: facultative seeder, regenerating by resprouting and sometimes by seed after fire;
description: herb, dioecious, rhizomatous perennial, forming diffuse patches to 2 m across. rhizome horizontal or ascending, 2-5 mm diam., often upwardly curving and continuous with an aerial culm; scales dark brown, covering a brown pubescence. culms straight to sinuose or flexuose, terete or + compressed, striate, usually much-branched, 20-60 cm long, 1-2 mm diam., pubescent when young. sheaths closely spaced at culm base, red- to grey-brown, partially pubescent when young, to 1.5 cm long, acute or sometimes aristate; lamina short, erect, to circa 3 mm long. inflorescence: male spikelets singly or several on slender branches at uppermost nodes, pedicellate; pedicels and branchlets covered with a short whitish tomentum; female spikelets sessile, terminal and solitary, or pedicellate and 2-5 close together at uppermost nodes. male spikelets cylindrical becoming narrow-elliptical to obovoid, 3-8 mm long; glumes 15-50, with 4-20 sterile lower glumes and 6-12 fertile upper glumes, ovate, acute to shortly mucronate, 2-3 mm long, concave, dark brown, with prominent midrib and hyaline membranous margin. female spikelets erect, narrow-cylindrical or wider toward the apex, 6-15 mm long; glumes mostly 4-14, oblong-lanceolate, acutely-acuminate or occasionally shortly mucronate, 4-10 mm long, dark red-brown, glabrous. male flowers: tepals 6, lanceolate, + acute; 2 outer tepals 1.5-1.8 mm long; inner tepals flat, 1.2-1.5 mm long; anthers 0.9-1.2 mm long. female flowers: flower stalk with 1 or 2 bracts, one to 2-3 mm long, the second if present much smaller, circa 0.5-1 mm long; tepals to 1 mm long; style 3-branched. fruit a nut with woody pericarp, ovoid, 2-4.5 mm long, circa 2 mm diam., shed with short stalk and perianth. seed ovoid, orange-tan, circa 1.6 mm long, circa 0.9 mm wide. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2-4 layers of short cells, interrupted by pillar cells and partial sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles. male plants are occasionally systemically infected by fungal smut and produce enlarged pistillodes that superficially resemble fruiting capsules. usually in well drained sandy heaths and shrublands, including sandy sclerophyllous mallee and non-calcareous coastal wallum in eastern new south wales and southern queensland. wind-pollinated. facultative seeder, regenerating by resprouting and sometimes by seed after fire; see also benson & mcdougall (2005: 193). flowers august-september (benson & mcdougall 2005); late winter-spring-summer. ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, rhizomatous perennial, forming diffuse patches to 2 m across. Rhizome horizontal or ascending, 2-5 mm diam., often upwardly curving and continuous with an aerial culm; scales dark brown, covering a brown pubescence. Culms straight to sinuose or flexuose, terete or + compressed, striate, usually much-branched, 20-60 cm long, 1-2 mm diam., pubescent when young. Sheaths closely spaced at culm base, red- to grey-brown, partially pubescent when young, to 1.5 cm long, acute or sometimes aristate; lamina short, erect, to c. 3 mm long. Inflorescence: male spikelets singly or several on slender branches at uppermost nodes, pedicellate; pedicels and branchlets covered with a short whitish tomentum; female spikelets sessile, terminal and solitary, or pedicellate and 2-5 close together at uppermost nodes. Male spikelets cylindrical becoming narrow-elliptical to obovoid, 3-8 mm long; glumes 15-50, with 4-20 sterile lower glumes and 6-12 fertile upper glumes, ovate, acute to shortly mucronate, 2-3 mm long, concave, dark brown, with prominent midrib and hyaline membranous margin. Female spikelets erect, narrow-cylindrical or wider toward the apex, 6-15 mm long; glumes mostly 4-14, oblong-lanceolate, acutely-acuminate or occasionally shortly mucronate, 4-10 mm long, dark red-brown, glabrous. Male flowers: tepals 6, lanceolate, + acute; 2 outer tepals 1.5-1.8 mm long; inner tepals flat, 1.2-1.5 mm long; anthers 0.9-1.2 mm long. Female flowers: flower stalk with 1 or 2 bracts, one to 2-3 mm long, the second if present much smaller, c. 0.5-1 mm long; tepals to 1 mm long; style 3-branched. Fruit a nut with woody pericarp, ovoid, 2-4.5 mm long, c. 2 mm diam., shed with short stalk and perianth. Seed ovoid, orange-tan, c. 1.6 mm long, c. 0.9 mm wide. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2-4 layers of short cells, interrupted by pillar cells and partial sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles. Male plants are occasionally systemically infected by fungal smut and produce enlarged pistillodes that superficially resemble fruiting capsules. Usually in well drained sandy heaths and shrublands, including sandy sclerophyllous mallee and non-calcareous coastal wallum in eastern New South Wales and southern Queensland. Wind-pollinated. Facultative seeder, regenerating by resprouting and sometimes by seed after fire; see also Benson & McDougall (2005: 193). Flowers August-September (Benson & McDougall 2005); late winter-spring-summer.

description: herb, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial, forming diffuse or dense patches to 50 cm across. rhizome often upwardly curving and continuous with an aerial culm, 3-6 mm diam.; scales glossy, tan-brown covering a brown pubescence. culms crowded or to 1 cm apart, erect or ascending, straight to sinuose or flexuose, terete but often compressed above a branch, striate, usually much-branched, 20-60 cm long, circa 1-1.5 mm diam., pubescent at base of culm. sheaths closely spaced at culm base, red- to grey-brown, to 1.5 cm long, acute to cuspidate; lamina short, erect, caducous. inflorescence: male spikelets pedicellate, pedicels and branchlets sparsely white-tomentose; female spikelets sessile, terminal and solitary, or 2-5 together at the distal few nodes on short pedicels. male spikelets narrow-ellipsoidal to + ovoid, 3-7 mm long; glumes 10-30, all fertile, broad-obovate, obtuse to mucronate, 1.5-2.1 mm long, brown-hyaline, glabrous; apical margin narrowly hyaline. female spikelets erect, narrow-cylindrical but wider toward the apex, 6-15 mm long; glumes 5-8, + lanceolate, acutely-acuminate and occasionally mucronate, 4-8 mm long, orange-brown, glabrous. male flowers: tepals 6 oblanceolate; 2 outer tepals 1.0-1.7 mm long, apex truncate; inner tepals flat, acute to obtuse, 1-1.5 mm long; anthers circa 1.2 mm long. female flowers: flower stalk with 1 or 2 bracts, one to 2 mm long, the second if present much smaller; 3 outer tepals slightly longer than inner, 2.5-5 mm long; style 3-branched. fruit a nut with woody pericarp, ovoid, 2-4 mm long, 1-2.5 mm diam., tipped by persistent style base, shed with a short stalk and perianth. seed globular, light-brown, circa 1.9 mm long, circa 1.7 mm wide. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2-4 layers of short cells, interrupted by pillar cells and partial sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles. woodland, heaths and shrublands, in peaty sands. wind-pollinated. resprouts after fire. flowers august-november. ;

description: herb, dioecious, rhizomatous perennial, forming dense or sparse patches to 75 cm across. rhizomes horizontal, slender, 1.5-2.5 mm diam., pubescent or with axillary hairs; scales closely appressed, overlapping, scarious, red-brown. culms spaced up to 1 cm apart, erect to somewhat flexuose, terete, unbranched below the inflorescence, smooth to striate, 20-60 cm long, 1.0-1.5 mm diam. sheaths red- to grey-brown, glabrous, 4-8 mm long, obtuse to almost truncate; lamina short, erect, caducous, circa 0.5 mm long. inflorescence: male spikelets pedicellate; pedicels circa 1-3 mm long, originating from the uppermost few culm nodes; pedicels and branchlets shortly white tomentose; female spikelets sessile or shortly pedicellate in small, often dense, clusters at the distal nodes. male spikelets initially ovoid, becoming globose as glumes spread with age, 4-10 mm long; glumes 13-35, rarely up to 80, ovate, acute to cuspidate, 3.0-3.4 mm long, red-brown, glossy, glabrous, with a very short erect mucro; all fertile or rarely the lowest 3 glumes empty. female spikelets + ovoid, 1.5-2.0 mm long; glumes 4-6, ovate, mucronate, 1.5-2.5 mm long, membranous, brown-hyaline with a distinct midrib terminating in a short erect point. male flowers: tepals 5 or 6, lanceolate, acute; 2 outer lateral tepals slightly longer, 1.5-2.0 mm long; inner tepals flat; anthers 0.8-1.0 mm long. female flowers: tepals 1-2 mm long; style 3-branched, branches free almost to the base. fruit a nut with woody pericarp, broad-ovoid tapering to a conical apex, light red-brown, 1.5-2.0 mm long, bases of style branches persisting as beaks on the fruit; shed with surrounding glumes and perianth. seed globular, light brown, circa 0.9 mm long, circa 0.8 mm wide. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2-4 layers of short cells, interrupted by pillar cells and partial sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles. the more northerly occurrences are of small plants with culms 8-15 cm long, with few (2-6) short sheaths (4-6 mm long) and anthers more exserted, but the type collection is of short-culmed plants from a region where most plants are much taller. sometimes male plants are infected with a smut fungus and produce abnormal inflorescences that superficially resemble the females. grows in woodland, shrubland and sedge-heath, in sand or clayey sand; sites seasonally moist but in regions of low rainfall. wind-pollinated. resprouts after fire. flowers spring and summer ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, rhizomatous perennial, forming dense or sparse patches to 75 cm across. Rhizomes horizontal, slender, 1.5-2.5 mm diam., pubescent or with axillary hairs; scales closely appressed, overlapping, scarious, red-brown. Culms spaced up to 1 cm apart, erect to somewhat flexuose, terete, unbranched below the inflorescence, smooth to striate, 20-60 cm long, 1.0-1.5 mm diam. Sheaths red- to grey-brown, glabrous, 4-8 mm long, obtuse to almost truncate; lamina short, erect, caducous, c. 0.5 mm long. Inflorescence: male spikelets pedicellate; pedicels c. 1-3 mm long, originating from the uppermost few culm nodes; pedicels and branchlets shortly white tomentose; female spikelets sessile or shortly pedicellate in small, often dense, clusters at the distal nodes. Male spikelets initially ovoid, becoming globose as glumes spread with age, 4-10 mm long; glumes 13-35, rarely up to 80, ovate, acute to cuspidate, 3.0-3.4 mm long, red-brown, glossy, glabrous, with a very short erect mucro; all fertile or rarely the lowest 3 glumes empty. Female spikelets + ovoid, 1.5-2.0 mm long; glumes 4-6, ovate, mucronate, 1.5-2.5 mm long, membranous, brown-hyaline with a distinct midrib terminating in a short erect point. Male flowers: tepals 5 or 6, lanceolate, acute; 2 outer lateral tepals slightly longer, 1.5-2.0 mm long; inner tepals flat; anthers 0.8-1.0 mm long. Female flowers: tepals 1-2 mm long; style 3-branched, branches free almost to the base. Fruit a nut with woody pericarp, broad-ovoid tapering to a conical apex, light red-brown, 1.5-2.0 mm long, bases of style branches persisting as beaks on the fruit; shed with surrounding glumes and perianth. Seed globular, light brown, c. 0.9 mm long, c. 0.8 mm wide. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2-4 layers of short cells, interrupted by pillar cells and partial sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles. The more northerly occurrences are of small plants with culms 8-15 cm long, with few (2-6) short sheaths (4-6 mm long) and anthers more exserted, but the type collection is of short-culmed plants from a region where most plants are much taller. Sometimes male plants are infected with a smut fungus and produce abnormal inflorescences that superficially resemble the females. Grows in woodland, shrubland and sedge-heath, in sand or clayey sand; sites seasonally moist but in regions of low rainfall. Wind-pollinated. Resprouts after fire. Flowers spring and summer

fire: facultative seeder, regenerating after fire by resprouting or seeds.
description: herb, dioecious, caespitose, perennial, forming dense tussocks with spreading culms, the base with woolly pubescence partly covered by thin, pale to light orange-brown, overlapping scales. culms erect, 1-2 mm diam. towards the base; narrower, flexuose and much-branched above; 15-70 (-100) cm long, terete to subterete or compressed, striate, young culms densely pubescent or tomentose. sheaths 1-2 cm long on the larger culms, decreasing to circa 0.3 cm long on the branches, acute to obtuse; green to brown or straw-coloured, glabrous to densely pubescent; lamina erect or reflexed, flattened or terete, straight or curved, to 2 (-2.5) cm long. inflorescence: male spikelets sessile on branched lateral branches at most culm nodes; female spikelets solitary, sessile, on lateral branches. male spikelets ovoid to ellipsoid, 2.2-4.5 mm long, with 3-9 sterile lower glumes and 5-25 fertile upper glumes; glumes ovate, aristate, light to dark brown, glabrous to sparsely pubescent, 1.3-1.7 mm long with a mucro circa 0.1-0.4 mm long. female spikelets narrow-ovoid, 6-8.6 mm long; glumes 5-10, broad-lanceolate, acuminate, usually the abaxial surface and apical margin pubescent; glumes green to straw-coloured or brown; lower glumes 1.5-3.3 mm long, mucro 0.7-4.0 mm long; upper glumes 4-7.5 mm long. male flowers: tepals 5, lanceolate to oblanceolate, acute to acuminate; outer tepals slightly longer than inner, 1.1-1.5 mm long; inner tepals flat; staminal filaments 1.3-2.0 mm long, anthers 0.6-0.8 mm long, exserted. female flowers: flower stalk with 1 or 2 minute bracts; tepals 0.5-1.1 mm long; style 3-branched. fruit a nut with woody pericarp, globoid, 2.0-3.4 mm long, 1.5-1.8 mm wide, pitted, yellow to dark brown, glossy when fresh, shed with short stalk and perianth. seed ovoid, light orange-brown, 1.7-1.9 mm long, 0.95-1.2 mm wide. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2-4 layers of short cells, interrupted by pillar cells and partial sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles. seasonally moist sites in sand or peaty sands, often in shrubland; occasionally in slightly saline soil. wind-pollinated. facultative seeder, regenerating after fire by resprouting or seeds. flowers spring (september-october). ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, caespitose, perennial, forming dense tussocks with spreading culms, the base with woolly pubescence partly covered by thin, pale to light orange-brown, overlapping scales. Culms erect, 1-2 mm diam. towards the base; narrower, flexuose and much-branched above; 15-70 (-100) cm long, terete to subterete or compressed, striate, young culms densely pubescent or tomentose. Sheaths 1-2 cm long on the larger culms, decreasing to c. 0.3 cm long on the branches, acute to obtuse; green to brown or straw-coloured, glabrous to densely pubescent; lamina erect or reflexed, flattened or terete, straight or curved, to 2 (-2.5) cm long. Inflorescence: male spikelets sessile on branched lateral branches at most culm nodes; female spikelets solitary, sessile, on lateral branches. Male spikelets ovoid to ellipsoid, 2.2-4.5 mm long, with 3-9 sterile lower glumes and 5-25 fertile upper glumes; glumes ovate, aristate, light to dark brown, glabrous to sparsely pubescent, 1.3-1.7 mm long with a mucro c. 0.1-0.4 mm long. Female spikelets narrow-ovoid, 6-8.6 mm long; glumes 5-10, broad-lanceolate, acuminate, usually the abaxial surface and apical margin pubescent; glumes green to straw-coloured or brown; lower glumes 1.5-3.3 mm long, mucro 0.7-4.0 mm long; upper glumes 4-7.5 mm long. Male flowers: tepals 5, lanceolate to oblanceolate, acute to acuminate; outer tepals slightly longer than inner, 1.1-1.5 mm long; inner tepals flat; staminal filaments 1.3-2.0 mm long, anthers 0.6-0.8 mm long, exserted. Female flowers: flower stalk with 1 or 2 minute bracts; tepals 0.5-1.1 mm long; style 3-branched. Fruit a nut with woody pericarp, globoid, 2.0-3.4 mm long, 1.5-1.8 mm wide, pitted, yellow to dark brown, glossy when fresh, shed with short stalk and perianth. Seed ovoid, light orange-brown, 1.7-1.9 mm long, 0.95-1.2 mm wide. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2-4 layers of short cells, interrupted by pillar cells and partial sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles. Seasonally moist sites in sand or peaty sands, often in shrubland; occasionally in slightly saline soil. Wind-pollinated. Facultative seeder, regenerating after fire by resprouting or seeds. description: herb, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial, forming diffuse patches to 30 cm across. rhizome horizontal, stout, 6-9 mm diam.; scales tough, shiny, tan-brown, partly covering a pale brown pubescence. culms spaced 1-2 cm apart, erect, terete, smooth to striate, 40-60 cm long, 1.5-2.5 mm diam., basal internode densely pubescent. sheaths glabrous when mature, 15-25 mm long, cuspidate; lamina 2-4 mm long, rarely longer. inflorescence: male spikelets numerous, pedicellate; female spikelets solitary and terminal on branches, or few at the distal nodes of erect branches. male spikelets ovoid, 4-8 mm long; glumes 8-23, all fertile or up to 4 sterile lower glumes, ovate, acute, 2.5-3.7 mm long with a short erect mucro to circa 0.5 mm long, concave, glabrous, tan-brown, the upper half often paler with a narrow hyaline margin. female spikelets cylindrical, 8.5-12 mm long; glumes 4-6, lanceolate, acute, 5-7 mm long, tapering to a recurved tip, initially red-brown, becoming greyish with age; abaxial surface of lowest glumes pubescent. male flowers: tepals 5 or 6, outer tepals usually longer than inner, ovate; outer tepals apex truncate or acuminate, 1.3-1.8 mm long; third tepal equalling lateral tepals, concave, obtuse; inner tepals concave, obtuse to acute, 0.8-1.4 mm long; anthers circa 0.8 mm long. female flowers: flower stalk with a single bract, rarely a second minute bract; 1.5-2.8 mm long; tepals 3.0-3.5 mm long; style 3-branched. fruit a nut with woody pericarp, ovoid-cylindrical, rugose, brown, circa 3 mm long, circa 2.5 mm diam., the apex tipped with the persistent style-base, shed with short stalk and perianth. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2-4 layers of short cells, interrupted by pillar cells and partial sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles. low heath and dry shrubland, in sand. wind-pollinated. resprouts after fire. flowers spring (september-october). ;

Female flowers: flower stalk with a single bract, rarely a second minute bract; 1.5-2.8 mm long; tepals 3.0-3.5 mm long; style 3-branched. Fruit a nut with woody pericarp, ovoid-cylindrical, rugose, brown, c. 3 mm long, c. 2.5 mm diam., the apex tipped with the persistent style-base, shed with short stalk and perianth. description: herb, dioecious, perennial, rhizomatous. rhizome horizontal, stout, 4-6 mm diam.; scales glossy orange-brown, partly covering a brown pubescence. culms spaced mostly 1-2 cm apart, erect to slightly sinuose, compressed and concavo-convex in section, striate, branched, 30-40 cm long, 0.5-1.5 mm wide, mostly glabrous but the lower part with closely appressed flat multicellular hairs. sheaths 5-12 mm long, tapering abruptly; with an auriculate, evanescent, distal membranous margin; lamina usually absent, if present then shortly erect, circa 1 mm long. male spikelets 1-5 (-7) on each of several short slender branches at a few upper nodes of the culm, pedicellate, mostly erect, narrowly ovoid, 4.5-7.5 mm long; glumes 15-30, all fertile or with up to 6 sterile lower glumes, ovate, acute to minutely mucronate, concave, glabrous, brown, 1.8-2.3 mm long, with a broad apical hyaline margin. female spikelets usually solitary and terminal on slender erect branches, narrowly cylindrical, circa 15 mm long, circa 2 mm diam.; glumes 6-8, lanceolate, cuspidate, brown becoming greyish with age, glabrous, 6-13 mm long. male flowers: tepals 6; outer tepals oblanceolate, truncate; 1.2-1.5 mm long; inner tepals slightly longer,  flat, lanceolate to oblanceolate, acute to truncate; anthers circa 0.8 mm long. female flowers: tepals 6, dark brown, oblong, blunt, appressed to the nut, circa 2.3 mm long. fruit a nut with woody pericarp, broadly cylindrical, tapering distally, rugose, pale brown, circa 4 mm long, shed with a short stalk and perianth. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2-4 layers of short cells, interrupted by pillar cells and partial sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles. grows near streams, in poorly drained heathy swamps and woodland, in sand or clayey or peaty sand; sites moist most of the year; sometimes in seasonally inundated sites. wind-pollinated. resprouts after fire. flowers spring (september-october). ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, perennial, rhizomatous. Rhizome horizontal, stout, 4-6 mm diam.; scales glossy orange-brown, partly covering a brown pubescence. Culms spaced mostly 1-2 cm apart, erect to slightly sinuose, compressed and concavo-convex in section, striate, branched, 30-40 cm long, 0.5-1.5 mm wide, mostly glabrous but the lower part with closely appressed flat multicellular hairs. Sheaths 5-12 mm long, tapering abruptly; with an auriculate, evanescent, distal membranous margin; lamina usually absent, if present then shortly erect, c. 1 mm long. Male spikelets 1-5 (-7) on each of several short slender branches at a few upper nodes of the culm, pedicellate, mostly erect, narrowly ovoid, 4.5-7.5 mm long; glumes 15-30, all fertile or with up to 6 sterile lower glumes, ovate, acute to minutely mucronate, concave, glabrous, brown, 1.8-2.3 mm long, with a broad apical hyaline margin. Female spikelets usually solitary and terminal on slender erect branches, narrowly cylindrical, c. 15 mm long, c. 2 mm diam.; glumes 6-8, lanceolate, cuspidate, brown becoming greyish with age, glabrous, 6-13 mm long. Male flowers: tepals 6; outer tepals oblanceolate, truncate; 1.2-1.5 mm long; inner tepals slightly longer,  flat, lanceolate to oblanceolate, acute to truncate; anthers c. 0.8 mm long. Female flowers: tepals 6, dark brown, oblong, blunt, appressed to the nut, c. 2.3 mm long. Fruit a nut with woody pericarp, broadly cylindrical, tapering distally, rugose, pale brown, c. 4 mm long, shed with a short stalk and perianth. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2-4 layers of short cells, interrupted by pillar cells and partial sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles. Grows near streams, in poorly drained heathy swamps and woodland, in sand or clayey or peaty sand; sites moist most of the year; sometimes in seasonally inundated sites. Wind-pollinated. Resprouts after fire. Flowers spring (September-October).

fire: it frequently occurs in disturbed sites and is often found growing in wet patches along fire breaks in pine plantations in s.and vic.
description: corm (2-) 3-lobed. megaspores regular, type i only. microsporangia produced. isoetes drummondii is recorded as palatable to stock and native animals in tas. isoetes drummondii subsp drummondii has a peculiar spore dispersal whereby pads of mucilage form at the sporangial base near the end of the growing season. as the plant dries off the sporangia remain attached to the top of the corm during summer. at the beginning of the following wet season, the mucilage expands pushing the sporangia into the soil where they split open at the edges (t.g.osborn, botanical gazette 36: 41-54, 1922). widespread in swamps or seepages where it grows submerged or emergent in very open situations. it frequently occurs in disturbed sites and is often found growing in wet patches along fire breaks in pine plantations in s.and vic. in tas. it occurs in creeks, drains, along roadsides and open marshlands where it grows in mud, often among rocks. ;
original_text: Corm (2-) 3-lobed. Megaspores regular, Type I only. Microsporangia produced. Isoetes drummondii is recorded as palatable to stock and native animals in Tas. Isoetes drummondii subsp. drummondii has a peculiar spore dispersal whereby pads of mucilage form at the sporangial base near the end of the growing season. As the plant dries off the sporangia remain attached to the top of the corm during summer. At the beginning of the following wet season, the mucilage expands pushing the sporangia into the soil where they split open at the edges (T.G.B. Osborn, Botanical Gazette 36: 41-54, 1922). Widespread in swamps or seepages where it grows submerged or emergent in very open situations. It frequently occurs in disturbed sites and is often found growing in wet patches along fire breaks in pine plantations in S.A. and Vic. In Tas. it occurs in creeks, drains, along roadsides and open marshlands where it grows in mud, often among rocks.

fire: plants may regenerate from a woody lignotuber after fire.
description: prickly shrub, mostly 15-c. 100 cm tall, to 120 cm diam. branchlets red-brown, sparsely villous. leaves pinnatisect; petiole 1.2-5.6 cm long; lamina flat, 1.8-3.6 cm long, pungent-pointed, sparsely villous, glabrescent; lateral pinnae dichotomously or trichotomously divided. inflorescence transversely ellipsoidal to globose, terminal or axillary, sessile, solitary, to circa 30 mm diam., surrounded by leaves; involucral bracts broadly ovate to ovate, imbricate, glabrous; cone scales narrowly ovate to ovate, villous outside on lower half. flowers to circa 15 mm long, yellow, glabrous except for a tuft of hairs on apex of each tepal. pollen presenter to circa 3 mm long; basal part papillose, scarcely swollen, constricted near mid-point then dilated into a globose part; apical part glabrous, scarcely swollen except for stigmatic cup, circa 3 mm long. cones transversely ellipsoidal to globose, to circa 22 mm diam. nuts villous, ovoid, beaked, to circa 3 mm long. plants may regenerate from a woody lignotuber after fire. grows mostly in sclerophyll forest, woodland or heathland, in sand or sandy soils. flowers july-jan. ;
original_text: Prickly shrub, mostly 15-c. 100 cm tall, to 120 cm diam. Branchlets red-brown, sparsely villous. Leaves pinnatisect; petiole 1.2-5.6 cm long; lamina flat, 1.8-3.6 cm long, pungent-pointed, sparsely villous, glabrescent; lateral pinnae dichotomously or trichotomously divided. Inflorescence transversely ellipsoidal to globose, terminal or axillary, sessile, solitary, to c. 30 mm diam., surrounded by leaves; involucral bracts broadly ovate to ovate, imbricate, glabrous; cone scales narrowly ovate to ovate, villous outside on lower half. Flowers to c. 15 mm long, yellow, glabrous except for a tuft of hairs on apex of each tepal. Pollen presenter to c. 3 mm long; basal part papillose, scarcely swollen, constricted near mid-point then dilated into a globose part; apical part glabrous, scarcely swollen except for stigmatic cup, c. 3 mm long. Cones transversely ellipsoidal to globose, to c. 22 mm diam. Nuts villous, ovoid, beaked, to c. 3 mm long. Plants may regenerate from a woody lignotuber after fire. Grows mostly in sclerophyll forest, woodland or heathland, in sand or sandy soils. Flowers July-Jan.

fire: plants previously recorded by j.h.willis as occurring on the fernbank railway reserve have disappeared in recent years due to sustained burning and clearing.
description: prostrate, spreading shrub, to 1 m or more diam. branchlets reddish, pubescent. leaves variously divided into linear lobes; petiole to circa 6 cm long; lamina flat, to circa 4.5 cm long, acute, sparsely pubescent, glabrescent, minutely scabrous. inflorescence ‚globose, terminal, sessile, solitary, to circa 20-35 mm diam.; involucral bracts ovate, ‚acuminate, sparsely hairy, usually with a short, marginal fringe of hairs; cone scales numerous, imbricate, broad, truncate, villous to woolly, except for deciduous apex. flowers to circa 12 mm long, yellow, glabrous except for a tuft of hairs on apex of each tepal. pollen presenter to circa 4 mm long; basal part slightly swollen, minutely papillose, constricted near mid-point then dilated into a globose part; apical part scarcely swollen, glabrous. cones ‚globose, to circa 20 mm diam. nuts ovoid, beaked, to circa 3 mm long, villous. older plants usually have a substantial lignotuber or rootstock. plants have not been observed to regenerate from seedlings at the fernbank site in victoria and, although the seeds have proven to be viable, it would appear from the number of nests around the surviving plants, that the seed could be subject to predation by ants. plants previously recorded by j.h.willis as occurring on the fernbank railway reserve have disappeared in recent years due to sustained burning and clearing. in 1994 this species was accepted for inclusion under the victorian flora and fauna guarantee act 1988 . sometimes in open grassy areas, mostly in heath and dry sclerophyll forest, often in association with allocasuarina nana ; usually grows in sand or sandy soils. flowers oct.-dec. ;
original_text: Prostrate, spreading shrub, to 1 m or more diam. Branchlets reddish, pubescent. Leaves variously divided into linear lobes; petiole to c. 6 cm long; lamina flat, to c. 4.5 cm long, acute, sparsely pubescent, glabrescent, minutely scabrous. Inflorescence ‚globose, terminal, sessile, solitary, to c. 20-35 mm diam.; involucral bracts ovate, ‚acuminate, sparsely hairy, usually with a short, marginal fringe of hairs; cone scales numerous, imbricate, broad, truncate, villous to woolly, except for deciduous apex. Flowers to c. 12 mm long, yellow, glabrous except for a tuft of hairs on apex of each tepal. Pollen presenter to c. 4 mm long; basal part slightly swollen, minutely papillose, constricted near mid-point then dilated into a globose part; apical part scarcely swollen, glabrous. Cones ‚globose, to c. 20 mm diam. Nuts ovoid, beaked, to c. 3 mm long, villous. Older plants usually have a substantial lignotuber or rootstock. Plants have not been observed to regenerate from seedlings at the Fernbank site in Victoria and, although the seeds have proven to be viable, it would appear from the number of nests around the surviving plants, that the seed could be subject to predation by ants. Plants previously recorded by J.H.Willis as occurring on the Fernbank railway reserve have disappeared in recent years due to sustained burning and clearing. In 1994 this species was accepted for inclusion under the Victorian Flora and Fauna Guarantee Act 1988 . Sometimes in open grassy areas, mostly in heath and dry sclerophyll forest, often in association with Allocasuarina nana ; usually grows in sand or sandy soils. Flowers Oct.-Dec.

fire: flowering is enhanced by fire but is not dependent on it.
description: caudex to 8 m tall, usually solitary but sometimes in clumps. leaves to 60 cm long, 2-3 mm wide above broad base, tapering. scape 30-50 cm long; bracts imbricate, 2.5-4.5 cm long with abruptly narrowed apex, silky-villous, passing into spreading, similar bracts subtending inflorescence. inflorescence 5-6 cm diam.; floral bracts linear, canaliculate, acute, 12-15 mm long, silky on keel. sepals and petals narrowly lanceolate, 20-30 mm long, silky outside, glabrous inside except appressed hairs towards apex. stamens 29-32 mm long; anthers 3-4 mm long. style 22-25 mm long; ovary densely hirsute; stigma shortly lobed. the species varies in the persistence of the indumentum on the leaves, sometimes retaining a silvery aspect. flowering is enhanced by fire but is not dependent on it. seed set appears low. grows in sandy loam and clay loam in open woodland and heath. flowers mainly winter-spring. ;
original_text: Caudex to 8 m tall, usually solitary but sometimes in clumps. Leaves to 60 cm long, 2-3 mm wide above broad base, tapering. Scape 30-50 cm long; bracts imbricate, 2.5-4.5 cm long with abruptly narrowed apex, silky-villous, passing into spreading, similar bracts subtending inflorescence. Inflorescence 5-6 cm diam.; floral bracts linear, canaliculate, acute, 12-15 mm long, silky on keel. Sepals and petals narrowly lanceolate, 20-30 mm long, silky outside, glabrous inside except appressed hairs towards apex. Stamens 29-32 mm long; anthers 3-4 mm long. Style 22-25 mm long; ovary densely hirsute; stigma shortly lobed. The species varies in the persistence of the indumentum on the leaves, sometimes retaining a silvery aspect. Flowering is enhanced by fire but is not dependent on it. Seed set appears low. Grows in sandy loam and clay loam in open woodland and heath. Flowers mainly winter-spring.

fire: just over a year after fire at chiddarcooping hill nature reserve, plants of lechenaultia galactites were observed to be in full flower and had become the dominant lower shrub layer (sage 2003).
description: erect robust, perennial subshrub to circa 60 cm, mostly single-stemmed at base, glabrous. bark grey and rough lower down the stem. leaves crowded lower on stems, becoming scattered towards inflorescence, narrowly oblong to ovate, 2.0-7.6 mm long, mostly circa 1 mm wide, antrorse to appressed, sessile with a distinct keel or ridge on the outside surface, obtuse, glabrous. inflorescence a monochasium or dichasium; bracts or inflorescence leaves slightly longer to circa 8 mm, flatter and wider than lower stem leaves. sepals linear to very narrowly lanceolate, 4.5-9 mm long, narrowly acute, glabrous. corolla to circa 25 mm long, white to creamy white to pale blue, throat sometimes yellow, slit on adaxial side to base; glabrous outside, with long soft, simple hairs inside, dense in the throat and becoming more restricted to lobe and wing margins above; lobes almost equal in length but adaxial lobe wings generally narrower giving a distinct 2-lipped appearance to corolla; adaxial lobe to circa 10 mm wide, abaxial lobe wings to circa 12 x 7 mm, abaxial lobe wings to circa 4 mm wide, margins entire to unevenly serrated. ovary to circa 22 mm long, linear, glabrous; style to circa 8 mm long, bent, some scattered glandular hairs mostly lower down; indusium pilose above, short bristles on lips. mature fruit not seen.  grows in kwongan heaths of the northern avon wheatbelt, predominantly in sandy soils, though it is also known from clay soils and roadside gravel or laterite. just over a year after fire at chiddarcooping hill nature reserve, plants of lechenaultia galactites were observed to be in full flower and had become the dominant lower shrub layer (sage 2003). like striata, these plants were non-suckering (reproducing from seed), as opposed to the related species biloba which primarily reproduces from suckers. collected in flower june-october. peak flowering most likely occurs in september and early october. ;
original_text: Erect robust, perennial subshrub to c. 60 cm, mostly single-stemmed at base, glabrous. Bark grey and rough lower down the stem. Leaves crowded lower on stems, becoming scattered towards inflorescence, narrowly oblong to ovate, 2.0-7.6 mm long, mostly c. 1 mm wide, antrorse to appressed, sessile with a distinct keel or ridge on the outside surface, obtuse, glabrous. Inflorescence a monochasium or dichasium; bracts or inflorescence leaves slightly longer to c. 8 mm, flatter and wider than lower stem leaves. Sepals linear to very narrowly lanceolate, 4.5-9 mm long, narrowly acute, glabrous. Corolla to c. 25 mm long, white to creamy white to pale blue, throat sometimes yellow, slit on adaxial side to base; glabrous outside, with long soft, simple hairs inside, dense in the throat and becoming more restricted to lobe and wing margins above; lobes almost equal in length but adaxial lobe wings generally narrower giving a distinct 2-lipped appearance to corolla; adaxial lobe to c. 10 mm wide, abaxial lobe wings to c. 12 x 7 mm, abaxial lobe wings to c. 4 mm wide, margins entire to unevenly serrated. Ovary to c. 22 mm long, linear, glabrous; style to c. 8 mm long, bent, some scattered glandular hairs mostly lower down; indusium pilose above, short bristles on lips. Mature fruit not seen.  Grows in kwongan heaths of the northern Avon Wheatbelt, predominantly in sandy soils, though it is also known from clay soils and roadside gravel or laterite. Just over a year after fire at Chiddarcooping Hill Nature Reserve, plants of Lechenaultia galactites were observed to be in full flower and had become the dominant lower shrub layer (Sage 2003). Like L. striata, these plants were non-suckering (reproducing from seed), as opposed to the related species L. biloba which primarily reproduces from suckers. Collected in flower June-October. Peak flowering most likely occurs in September and early October.

description: divaricate, ascending, sparsely branched herb or subshrub to 30 cm high. bark sometimes rough basally, coarsely striate. leaves, sepals and ovary glabrous. leaves scattered on flowering stems, crowded on short, leafy stems, narrow, 7-11.5 mm long, rigid. flowers in loose dichasia. sepals 1-2.5 mm long. corolla 14-19 mm long, creamy white to pale mauve, sometimes with reddish brown midribs and edges of lobes; tube pubescent inside; lobes spreading, sparsely pubescent; wings on abaxial lobes rounded to triangular, 1-3 mm wide, on adaxial lobes rounded, 0.2-0.6 mm wide. ovary 7.5-14.5 mm long; style 8.5-11.5 mm long, sparsely hairy; indusium pubescent on back. fruit 19-33 mm long; articles 7-11 pairs.  grows in sand or loam over limestone, usually with scattered low shrubs.  flowers sporadically, perhaps only after recent fire. ;
original_text: Divaricate, ascending, sparsely branched herb or subshrub to 30 cm high. Bark sometimes rough basally, coarsely striate. Leaves, sepals and ovary glabrous. Leaves scattered on flowering stems, crowded on short, leafy stems, narrow, 7-11.5 mm long, rigid. Flowers in loose dichasia. Sepals 1-2.5 mm long. Corolla 14-19 mm long, creamy white to pale mauve, sometimes with reddish brown midribs and edges of lobes; tube pubescent inside; lobes spreading, sparsely pubescent; wings on abaxial lobes rounded to triangular, 1-3 mm wide, on adaxial lobes rounded, 0.2-0.6 mm wide. description: dioecious, caespitose perennial herb, with short ascending rhizomes to 7 cm long with a long, dense, white, woolly pubescence of hairs 1-2 cm long; cluster and sand-binding roots present. scales dark red-brown, glabrous except a few hairs on abaxial surface near apex. culms erect, terete, dimorphic, sterile and fertile culms dissimilar: sterile culms flexuose to tortuose, circa 30 cm long, 0.9-1.1 mm diam., minutely tuberculate, pale- to yellow-green, basally densely villous, apically glabrous, the internodes numerous, 3-5.5 cm long; circa 75-150 glumes, the lowest third of glumes with abortive flowers (sterile), the mid-third glumes fertile and persistent, the uppermost third glumes fertile and caducous; glumes brown to golden-brown, oblong, 2.2-3.0 mm long, apically obtuse, margin with white hairs; awn dark brown, 1.6-2.1 mm long. female spikelets ovoid, circa 9.5 mm long, circa 3 mm wide; glumes circa 18, lowest few sterile, upper glumes fertile, ovate, 4.5-5.0 mm long, brown; apex obtuse and often fringed with white hairs; awn stout, reflexed or recurved, dark brown, 2-4 mm long. male flowers: tepals glabrous, the lowest 2 fertile flowers with 6 tepals, all others with 5 tepals; outer tepals cuspidate, 2.6-2.9 mm long; inner tepals 2.2-2.6 mm long; anthers 1.7-2.3 mm long. female flowers: tepals 4 or 5, 2-6 mm long; outer tepals rigid, keeled, acute; inner tepals shorter, narrow-lanceolate, hyaline. nut globose, with the style base forming a short apical cap. culm anatomy: central cavity present; chlorenchyma continuous, mostly of a single layer of elongated peg cells; mostly with inward-projecting epidermal cells partially lining substomatal cavities; walls of epidermal cells thickened on outer wall and outer part of radial walls; radial walls often sinuous; often with radially elongated epidermal cells forming mounds on the culm surface; with stalked, branched multicellular hairs. reduced leaves on rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. peg cells are pali chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites.  an informative online interactive key to the western australian lepidobolus species, with abundant photographs, is given by hollister & thiele (2014). grows in yellow sand, in shrubland or dry heath on sand or sandy loam of sandplain with scattered mallee eucalypts; sometimes on rises in the sandplain. wind-pollinated; killed by fire, regenerating by seed. flowers april to may. ;
original_text: Dioecious, caespitose perennial herb, with short ascending rhizomes to 7 cm long with a long, dense, white, woolly pubescence of hairs 1-2 cm long; cluster and sand-binding roots present. Scales dark red-brown, glabrous except a few hairs on abaxial surface near apex. Culms erect, terete, dimorphic, sterile and fertile culms dissimilar: sterile culms flexuose to tortuose, c. 30 cm long, 0.9-1.1 mm diam., minutely tuberculate, pale- to yellow-green, basally densely villous, apically glabrous, the internodes numerous, 3-5.5 cm long; fertile culms much shorter than the sterile culms, 1-4 cm long, with 1-4 spikelets. Sheaths oblong, caducous, 9-11.5 mm long, pale brown, smooth, glabrous; apex obtuse; lamina subulate, 1.1-1.3 mm long. Spathes caducous, c. 9 mm long. Male spikelets cylindrical, 1.2-2.3 cm long, c. 0.5 cm wide; c. 75-150 glumes, the lowest third of glumes with abortive flowers (sterile), the mid-third glumes fertile and persistent, the uppermost third glumes fertile and caducous; glumes brown to golden-brown, oblong, 2.2-3.0 mm long, apically obtuse, margin with white hairs; awn dark brown, 1.6-2.1 mm long. Female spikelets ovoid, c. 9.5 mm long, c. 3 mm wide; glumes c. 18, lowest few sterile, upper glumes fertile, ovate, 4.5-5.0 mm long, brown; apex obtuse and often fringed with white hairs; awn stout, reflexed or recurved, dark brown, 2-4 mm long. Male flowers: tepals glabrous, the lowest 2 fertile flowers with 6 tepals, all others with 5 tepals; outer tepals cuspidate, 2.6-2.9 mm long; inner tepals 2.2-2.6 mm long; anthers 1.7-2.3 mm long. Female flowers: tepals 4 or 5, 2-6 mm long; outer tepals rigid, keeled, acute; inner tepals shorter, narrow-lanceolate, hyaline. Nut globose, with the style base forming a short apical cap. Culm anatomy: central cavity present; chlorenchyma continuous, mostly of a single layer of elongated peg cells; mostly with inward-projecting epidermal cells partially lining substomatal cavities; walls of epidermal cells thickened on outer wall and outer part of radial walls; radial walls often sinuous; often with radially elongated epidermal cells forming mounds on the culm surface; with stalked, branched multicellular hairs. Reduced leaves on rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. Peg cells are palisade-like chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. Cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites.  An informative online interactive key to the Western Australian Lepidobolus species, with abundant photographs, is given by Hollister & Thiele (2014). Grows in yellow sand, in shrubland or dry heath on sand or sandy loam of sandplain with scattered mallee eucalypts; sometimes on rises in the sandplain. Wind-pollinated; killed by fire, regenerating by seed. Flowers April to May.

description: dioecious, caespitose, perennial herb, forming large, dense, many-stemmed tussocks to 30 (-90) cm diam.; rhizomes erect or shortly spreading, pubescent; sand-binding roots present. scales dark brown, glabrous. culms crowded at the base, erect, terete, straight to sinuose, 40-70 (-100) cm long, 1.1-1.5 mm diam., unbranched, smooth to subrugose, glabrous except for lowest internode partially pubescent; with 16-30 fertile upper glumes and 6-23 sterile lower glumes; glumes broad-ovate, circa 5 mm long, 4-4.5 mm wide, abruptly tapered to an awn that is 1.1-3.0 mm long, dark brown and ciliate toward the apex with white hairs. male flowers: tepals 5; outer tepals keeled, 3.2-5.5 mm long, inner tepals 2.4-4.5 mm long; gynoecium with a single loculus and style. nut ovoid, dark brown to black, 1.8 mm long with a broad conical beak 0.8 mm long; pericarp thin and parenchymatous;
