description: herb, dioecious, caespitose, perennial, often forming large tussocks. culms 80-120 cm long, stout, terete, 1.5-2.2 mm diam., smooth to minutely striate or pitted and occasionally with a longitudinal furrow, light- to grey-green and often purplish towards the base, with a covering of pale, closely appressed, s trichomes. sheaths 0.8-1.6 (-2.2) cm long, striate, pale- to dark-brown with a covering of pale, closely-appressed, s trichomes; with an initially prominent but caducous, hyaline, membranous, apical margin to 5 mm wide; awn to 5 mm long. inflorescence: male spikelets in a much-branched, terminal fascicle 5-15 cm long, the spikelets erect to drooping on filiform pedicels; female spikelets densely clustered in a narrow, interrupted, terminal fascicle 5-20 cm long. male spikelets ovoid, 3.5-5 mm long; glumes circa 15, all fertile, ovate, acuminate to shortly aristate, 2.0-2.5 mm long (with a short awn up to 0.5 mm long), brown contrasting with pale hyaline margin, glabrous. female spikelets narrow- to broad-ovoid, 5-8 mm long; glumes up to 5 sterile lower glumes and 4-14 fertile upper glumes, broad-ovate, 2-3 mm long, brown, aristate, with a distinct pale silvery hyaline margin circa 0.2 mm wide and an erect awn 0.4-2 mm long; floral bracts 1 or 2, keeled, narrow-lanceolate to linear, 1.0-1.5 mm long, brown-hyaline, membranous, sparsely pubescent. male flowers: tepals 5, except the lowest flower in spikelet with 6 tepals, 1.0-1.5 mm long, brown-hyaline, membranous, glabrous; 2 outer tepals lanceolate, acuminate, keeled; inner tepals flat, narrow-ovate, acute; stamens 3, filaments very short, anthers 0.5-0.6 mm long. female flowers: tepals 6, inner and outer tepals similar, linear, acute, weakly keeled, membranous, brown-hyaline, sparsely pubescent, 1.0-1.5 mm long; style 3-branched, shortly connate at the base, the free portion almost wholly stigmatic. nut narrow-ellipsoid, c. 1-1.2 mm long, glossy pale-brown. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma interrupted by groups of pillar cells that extend from the parenchyma sheath to the epidermis. reduced leaves on the culm are referred to as sheaths. floral bracts are one or usually two unequal bracts on the axis between the glume and the female flower. pillar cells are elongate, pali cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. seasonally wet swamps and stream banks on oligotrophic soils or sometimes in permanently wet sites; on sandy and peaty soils. in permanently wet sites sometimes germinating while submerged, as described for meeboldina crassipes (meney & pate 1999, pate & meney 1999), which is included in (considered a synomym of) leptocarpus scariosus. wind pollinated; regenerates by seed after fire. (meney & pate 1999: 422), as meeboldina scariosa. flowers january-may. ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, caespitose, perennial, often forming large tussocks. Culms 80-120 cm long, stout, terete, 1.5-2.2 mm diam., smooth to minutely striate or pitted and occasionally with a longitudinal furrow, light- to grey-green and often purplish towards the base, with a covering of pale, closely appressed, scale-like trichomes. Sheaths 0.8-1.6 (-2.2) cm long, striate, pale- to dark-brown with a covering of pale, closely-appressed, scale-like trichomes; with an initially prominent but caducous, hyaline, membranous, apical margin to 5 mm wide; awn to 5 mm long. Inflorescence: male spikelets in a much-branched, terminal fascicle 5-15 cm long, the spikelets erect to drooping on filiform pedicels; female spikelets densely clustered in a narrow, interrupted, terminal fascicle 5-20 cm long. Male spikelets ovoid, 3.5-5 mm long; glumes c. 15, all fertile, ovate, acuminate to shortly aristate, 2.0-2.5 mm long (with a short awn up to 0.5 mm long), brown contrasting with pale hyaline margin, glabrous. Female spikelets narrow- to broad-ovoid, 5-8 mm long; glumes up to 5 sterile lower glumes and 4-14 fertile upper glumes, broad-ovate, 2-3 mm long, brown, aristate, with a distinct pale silvery hyaline margin c. 0.2 mm wide and an erect awn 0.4-2 mm long; floral bracts 1 or 2, keeled, narrow-lanceolate to linear, 1.0-1.5 mm long, brown-hyaline, membranous, sparsely pubescent. Male flowers: tepals 5, except the lowest flower in spikelet with 6 tepals, 1.0-1.5 mm long, brown-hyaline, membranous, glabrous; 2 outer tepals lanceolate, acuminate, keeled; inner tepals flat, narrow-ovate, acute; stamens 3, filaments very short, anthers 0.5-0.6 mm long. Female flowers: tepals 6, inner and outer tepals similar, linear, acute, weakly keeled, membranous, brown-hyaline, sparsely pubescent, 1.0-1.5 mm long; style 3-branched, shortly connate at the base, the free portion almost wholly stigmatic. Nut narrow-ellipsoid, c. 1-1.2 mm long, glossy pale-brown. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma interrupted by groups of pillar cells that extend from the parenchyma sheath to the epidermis. Reduced leaves on the culm are referred to as sheaths. Floral bracts are one or usually two unequal bracts on the axis between the glume and the female flower. Pillar cells are elongate, palisade-like cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. Seasonally wet swamps and stream banks on oligotrophic soils or sometimes in permanently wet sites; on sandy and peaty soils. In permanently wet sites sometimes germinating while submerged, as described for Meeboldina crassipes (Meney & Pate 1999, Pate & Meney 1999), which is included in (considered a synomym of) Leptocarpus scariosus. Wind pollinated; regenerates by seed after fire. (Meney & Pate 1999: 422), as Meeboldina scariosa. Flowers January-May.

fire: regenerates by seed after fire.
description: herb, dioecious, caespitose, perennial, forming dense tussocks to 20 cm diam. at base, with tan-brown scarious cataphylls partly covering a dense, brown, woolly pubescence. culms much- and repeatedly branched, crowded, 30-60 cm long, terete to subterete, 1-2 mm diam. at the base, narrowing to circa 0.3 mm apically, striate, grey-green with a covering of pale, sometimes caducous, s trichomes; branches thinner, numerous, dense, mostly flexuose. sheaths 5-12 mm long on the main culms, much smaller on the branches, light- to dark-brown, striate, acuminate; lamina narrow, to circa 4 mm long; margin membranous, hyaline, 2-4 mm wide, caducous. inflorescence: spikelets numerous, solitary, terminal and axillary on lateral branchlets, the branchlets straight to flexuose. male spikelets ellipsoidal, small, 4-5 (-7) mm long; glumes 4-15, all fertile, ovate, acute to acuminate, 1.7-2.5 mm long (with a short erect mucro circa 0.2 mm long), brown with pale hyaline margin, glabrous. female spikelets very small, 1.5-2.5 mm long, with 1 (or 2) flower(s), the flower closely enwrapped by 1 (rarely 2) closely appressed glumes with only the styles emerging; glumes ovate, 1.2-2.0 mm long, obtuse, occasionally with an erect, caducous awn to circa 3 mm long, brown, with broad hyaline margin, glabrous; floral bracts 1 or 2, ovate, acute to cuspidate, 1.0-2.5 mm long, brown-hyaline, glabrous to ciliate. male flowers: tepals 5, brown-hyaline, membranous, glabrous; 2 outer tepals keeled, narrow-lanceolate, 1.0-1.5 mm long with a minute, erect mucro; 3 inner tepals flat or concave, broad-lanceolate, acute, usually slightly shorter; stamens 3, filaments up to 0.8 mm long, anthers 0.9-1.2 mm long. female flowers: tepals 6, lanceolate to narrow-lanceolate, acute to cuspidate, 1-2 mm long, concave to weakly-keeled, brown-hyaline, fimbriate; inner tepals more densely fimbriate; style 3-branched, the basal half connate and persistent on the nut, the upper half free and wholly stigmatic. nut narrow-pyriform, circa 1.5 mm long, green. seed ellipsoid, circa 1 mm long. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma interrupted by groups of pillar cells that extend from the parenchyma sheath to the epidermis. reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. pillar cells are elongate, pali cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. floral bracts are one or usually two unequal bracts on the axis between the glume and the female flower. seasonally wet swamps and heathlands, on peaty sand; sites wet or moist most of the year. wind pollinated; regenerates by seed after fire. flowers spring-summer. ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, caespitose, perennial, forming dense tussocks to 20 cm diam. at base, with tan-brown scarious cataphylls partly covering a dense, brown, woolly pubescence. Culms much- and repeatedly branched, crowded, 30-60 cm long, terete to subterete, 1-2 mm diam. at the base, narrowing to c. 0.3 mm apically, striate, grey-green with a covering of pale, sometimes caducous, scale-like trichomes; branches thinner, numerous, dense, mostly flexuose. Sheaths 5-12 mm long on the main culms, much smaller on the branches, light- to dark-brown, striate, acuminate; lamina narrow, to c. 4 mm long; margin membranous, hyaline, 2-4 mm wide, caducous. Inflorescence: spikelets numerous, solitary, terminal and axillary on lateral branchlets, the branchlets straight to flexuose. Male spikelets ellipsoidal, small, 4-5 (-7) mm long; glumes 4-15, all fertile, ovate, acute to acuminate, 1.7-2.5 mm long (with a short erect mucro c. 0.2 mm long), brown with pale hyaline margin, glabrous. Female spikelets very small, 1.5-2.5 mm long, with 1 (or 2) flower(s), the flower closely enwrapped by 1 (rarely 2) closely appressed glumes with only the styles emerging; glumes ovate, 1.2-2.0 mm long, obtuse, occasionally with an erect, caducous awn to c. 3 mm long, brown, with broad hyaline margin, glabrous; floral bracts 1 or 2, ovate, acute to cuspidate, 1.0-2.5 mm long, brown-hyaline, glabrous to ciliate. Male flowers: tepals 5, brown-hyaline, membranous, glabrous; 2 outer tepals keeled, narrow-lanceolate, 1.0-1.5 mm long with a minute, erect mucro; 3 inner tepals flat or concave, broad-lanceolate, acute, usually slightly shorter; stamens 3, filaments up to 0.8 mm long, anthers 0.9-1.2 mm long. Female flowers: tepals 6, lanceolate to narrow-lanceolate, acute to cuspidate, 1-2 mm long, concave to weakly-keeled, brown-hyaline, fimbriate; inner tepals more densely fimbriate; style 3-branched, the basal half connate and persistent on the nut, the upper half free and wholly stigmatic. Nut narrow-pyriform, c. 1.5 mm long, green. Seed ellipsoid, c. 1 mm long. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma interrupted by groups of pillar cells that extend from the parenchyma sheath to the epidermis. Reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. Pillar cells are elongate, palisade-like cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. Floral bracts are one or usually two unequal bracts on the axis between the glume and the female flower. Seasonally wet swamps and heathlands, on peaty sand; sites wet or moist most of the year. Wind pollinated; regenerates by seed after fire. Flowers spring-summer.

fire: resprouts after fire.
description: herb, dioecious, rhizomatous perennial. rhizomes 2-7 mm diam., glabrous, covered with closely imbricate, pale brown, glossy, scarious scales. culms ascending at base, crowded or spaced to circa 2 cm, mostly unbranched below the inflorescence, 60-130 cm long, terete, 0.8-2 (-2.5) mm diam. sheaths 0.5-1.0 (-1.7) cm long, striate, brown, glabrous, truncate to acuminate; margin hyaline, 3-8 mm wide. male spikelets mostly small, numerous, on slender drooping branches, oblong-ovoid, 2-5 mm long, circa 1 mm diam., with 1-4 sterile lower glumes and 5-8 fertile upper glumes; glumes imbricate, ovate, obtusely to acutely acuminate, 1.8-2.7 mm long (often with a short mucro circa 0.3 mm long), brown, not glossy, with narrow indistinct pale hyaline margin, glabrous. female spikelets solitary, erect and terminal or 2-10 (-25) shortly pedicellate erect spikelets in a narrow fascicle, oblong-cylindrical becoming turbinate, 5-25 mm long, with up to 4-6 sterile lower glumes and 8-20 fertile upper glumes; glumes broad-ovate, acuminate, 6-9 mm long, red to dark-brown, coriaceous, mostly glabrous, abaxially partially pilose, with a tapering awn that becomes somewhat reflexed; bracts on the floral axis absent. male flowers: tepals (5 or) 6, ovate, obtuse to acuminate, thin, membranous, pale, brown-hyaline, glabrous; 2 outer tepals keeled, 0.8-1.6 mm long; inner tepals flat, slightly shorter; stamens 3, filaments very short, to 0.3 mm long, anthers 0.8-1.2 mm long. female flowers: base with tuft of pale hairs; tepals 6, pale; 2 outer tepals rigid, acute, cymbiform, thick and spongy near the keel, 2.5-4.0 mm long, the margins often with very short rigid hairs; 2 inner tepals thin, narrow-lanceolate, keeled, acute, 1.5-3.5 mm long, very shortly ciliate; 2 innermost tepals narrow-lanceolate, acute, 1-2.5 mm long, shortly ciliate; style 3-branched, the lower half fused, the upper half stigmatic. nut narrow-ovoid, 1-3 mm long; pericarp hyaline. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma interrupted by groups of pillar cells that extend from the parenchyma sheath to the epidermis. reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. pillar cells are elongate, pali cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. moist or seasonally moist sites on oligotrophic soils. wind pollinated; resprouts after fire. for details of ecology in the sydney region see benson & mcdougall (2005: 193). flowers november-january (hollister & thiele 2017). flowers september-november; fruits: november-march (benson & mcdougall 2005: 193). ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, rhizomatous perennial. Rhizomes 2-7 mm diam., glabrous, covered with closely imbricate, pale brown, glossy, scarious scales. Culms ascending at base, crowded or spaced to c. 2 cm, mostly unbranched below the inflorescence, 60-130 cm long, terete, 0.8-2 (-2.5) mm diam. Sheaths 0.5-1.0 (-1.7) cm long, striate, brown, glabrous, truncate to acuminate; margin hyaline, 3-8 mm wide. Male spikelets mostly small, numerous, on slender drooping branches, oblong-ovoid, 2-5 mm long, c. 1 mm diam., with 1-4 sterile lower glumes and 5-8 fertile upper glumes; glumes imbricate, ovate, obtusely to acutely acuminate, 1.8-2.7 mm long (often with a short mucro c. 0.3 mm long), brown, not glossy, with narrow indistinct pale hyaline margin, glabrous. Female spikelets solitary, erect and terminal or 2-10 (-25) shortly pedicellate erect spikelets in a narrow fascicle, oblong-cylindrical becoming turbinate, 5-25 mm long, with up to 4-6 sterile lower glumes and 8-20 fertile upper glumes; glumes broad-ovate, acuminate, 6-9 mm long, red to dark-brown, coriaceous, mostly glabrous, abaxially partially pilose, with a tapering awn that becomes somewhat reflexed; bracts on the floral axis absent. Male flowers: tepals (5 or) 6, ovate, obtuse to acuminate, thin, membranous, pale, brown-hyaline, glabrous; 2 outer tepals keeled, 0.8-1.6 mm long; inner tepals flat, slightly shorter; stamens 3, filaments very short, to 0.3 mm long, anthers 0.8-1.2 mm long. Female flowers: base with tuft of pale hairs; tepals 6, pale; 2 outer tepals rigid, acute, cymbiform, thick and spongy near the keel, 2.5-4.0 mm long, the margins often with very short rigid hairs; 2 inner tepals thin, narrow-lanceolate, keeled, acute, 1.5-3.5 mm long, very shortly ciliate; 2 innermost tepals narrow-lanceolate, acute, 1-2.5 mm long, shortly ciliate; style 3-branched, the lower half fused, the upper half stigmatic. Nut narrow-ovoid, 1-3 mm long; pericarp hyaline. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma interrupted by groups of pillar cells that extend from the parenchyma sheath to the epidermis. Reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. Pillar cells are elongate, palisade-like cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. Moist or seasonally moist sites on oligotrophic soils. Wind pollinated; resprouts after fire. For details of ecology in the Sydney region see Benson & McDougall (2005: 193). Flowers November-January (Hollister & Thiele 2017). Flowers September-November; fruits: November-March (Benson & McDougall 2005: 193).

fire: resprouting after fire.
description: herb, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial, forming diffuse patches to 30 cm across. rhizomes woody, 3-5 mm diam., tawny yellow-brown and slightly glossy, glabrous, mostly covered by scarious scales 3-5 mm long. culms ascending at the base, unbranched, 45-70 cm long, terete, 1-2 mm diam., smooth to minutely striate, light- to grey-green or purplish. sheaths few, mostly 5-8, closely appressed to the culm, acute, 1-1.7 cm long, minutely-striate, brown to grey-black; lamina to 7 mm long, weathering away; apical margin hyaline, circa 4 mm wide, weathering away. male inflorescence up to circa 15 cm long, the spikelets erect to drooping on filiform pedicels. female inflorescence narrow, interrupted, up to circa 10 cm long; culms with 10-30 (-70) spikelets. male spikelets ovoid, 4.5-5.5 mm long; glumes 10-16, ovate, acute to cuspidate, 2-2.5 mm long (the lowest few glumes shorter and empty), with a short erect awn circa 1 mm long, dark brown, glabrous, with a clearly defined pale hyaline margin 0.3-0.5 mm wide. female spikelets ellipsoid, 4-8 mm long; glumes 8-20, all fertile or several basal ones empty, glabrous, when young with the lower part brown with a distinct hyaline margin, becoming hyaline and grey with age, lanceolate, aristate, 2.5-3.5 mm long, with an erect to recurved awn to circa 1.5 mm long. male flowers: tepals 6, brown-hyaline, membranous, glabrous; 2 outer tepals keeled, oblanceolate, cuspidate, 1.0-1.6 mm long, with a very short, erect awn; inner tepals flat, broad-lanceolate, cuspidate, slightly shorter; stamens 3, filaments very short, anthers 0.6-0.8 mm long. female flowers with a tuft of short, pale hairs at the base; bracts 2, unequal, resembling tepals but outer bract shorter; tepals 6, all  equal, linear, acute to obtuse, 0.7-1.4 mm long, slightly keeled, brown or hyaline, the upper half usually prominently ciliate; style 3-branched, circa 3 mm long, the base shortly connate and persistent on the nut, the upper half stigmatic. nut narrow-ellipsoid, circa 1 mm long, yellow-brown, smooth. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma interrupted by groups of pillar cells that extend from the parenchyma sheath to the epidermis. female plants are distinctive with their small female spikelets with young glumes mostly hyaline apart from the keel and older glumes soft and pale grey. vegetatively, plants closely resemble leptocarpus tenax, especially in the ascending culm bases, but the culms are generally more slender and the culm sheaths fewer. it appears that, because of their similarity to a common species, tephrinus, males are rarely collected and more observations on spikelet size are needed to determine whether tephrinus has consistently larger male spikelets than tenax (in tenax the male spikelets are 2-5 mm long and the females are red when young, becoming dark brown, rigid and (0.5-) 2-3 cm long). reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms. pillar cells are elongate, pali cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. seasonally wet swamps, sedge or heath swamps, often in openings in forest or woodland, on peaty sand.   wind pollinated; ; resprouting after fire. flowers april-september. ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, rhizomatous, perennial, forming diffuse patches to 30 cm across. Rhizomes woody, 3-5 mm diam., tawny yellow-brown and slightly glossy, glabrous, mostly covered by scarious scales 3-5 mm long. Culms ascending at the base, unbranched, 45-70 cm long, terete, 1-2 mm diam., smooth to minutely striate, light- to grey-green or purplish. Sheaths few, mostly 5-8, closely appressed to the culm, acute, 1-1.7 cm long, minutely-striate, brown to grey-black; lamina to 7 mm long, weathering away; apical margin hyaline, c. 4 mm wide, weathering away. Male inflorescence up to c. 15 cm long, the spikelets erect to drooping on filiform pedicels. Female inflorescence narrow, interrupted, up to c. 10 cm long; culms with 10-30 (-70) spikelets. Male spikelets ovoid, 4.5-5.5 mm long; glumes 10-16, ovate, acute to cuspidate, 2-2.5 mm long (the lowest few glumes shorter and empty), with a short erect awn c. 1 mm long, dark brown, glabrous, with a clearly defined pale hyaline margin 0.3-0.5 mm wide. Female spikelets ellipsoid, 4-8 mm long; glumes 8-20, all fertile or several basal ones empty, glabrous, when young with the lower part brown with a distinct hyaline margin, becoming hyaline and grey with age, lanceolate, aristate, 2.5-3.5 mm long, with an erect to recurved awn to c. 1.5 mm long. Male flowers: tepals 6, brown-hyaline, membranous, glabrous; 2 outer tepals keeled, oblanceolate, cuspidate, 1.0-1.6 mm long, with a very short, erect awn; inner tepals flat, broad-lanceolate, cuspidate, slightly shorter; stamens 3, filaments very short, anthers 0.6-0.8 mm long. Female flowers with a tuft of short, pale hairs at the base; bracts 2, unequal, resembling tepals but outer bract shorter; tepals 6, all  equal, linear, acute to obtuse, 0.7-1.4 mm long, slightly keeled, brown or hyaline, the upper half usually prominently ciliate; style 3-branched, c. 3 mm long, the base shortly connate and persistent on the nut, the upper half stigmatic. Nut narrow-ellipsoid, c. 1 mm long, yellow-brown, smooth. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma interrupted by groups of pillar cells that extend from the parenchyma sheath to the epidermis. Female plants are distinctive with their small female spikelets with young glumes mostly hyaline apart from the keel and older glumes soft and pale grey. Vegetatively, plants closely resemble Leptocarpus tenax, especially in the ascending culm bases, but the culms are generally more slender and the culm sheaths fewer. It appears that, because of their similarity to a common species, L. tephrinus, males are rarely collected and more observations on spikelet size are needed to determine whether L. tephrinus has consistently larger male spikelets than L. tenax (in L. tenax the male spikelets are 2-5 mm long and the females are red when young, becoming dark brown, rigid and (0.5-) 2-3 cm long). Reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms. Pillar cells are elongate, palisade-like cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. Seasonally wet swamps, sedge or heath swamps, often in openings in forest or woodland, on peaty sand.   Wind pollinated; ; resprouting after fire. Flowers April-September.

fire: regenerating by resprouting after fire.
description: herb, dioecious, perennial, forming large dense tussocks to 1.8 m high and 1 m across with hard woody interlacing rhizomes. rhizomes elongated, stout, 7-10 mm diam., scales brown, covering a pale to brown woolly pubescence. culms usually spaced to circa 1 cm apart, unbranched below the inflorescence, 1-2 m long, terete, 2.5-4 mm diam. near base, somewhat striate, grey-green. sheaths 1-2 cm long, striate, pale-brown; lamina erect, usually 3-8 mm long; margin membranous, c. 3 mm wide, weathering away. inflorescence long, narrow, erect, circa 20-100 cm long; male spikelets  erect and loosely clustered in the upper 5-10 cm of each branch, branches arising from the upper 10-15 nodes of the culm and the more distal branches often repeatedly branched; female inflorescence similar to the male but usually with fewer branches. male spikelets pedicellate, with pedicels filiform, up to circa 1 cm long; spikelets ovoid, 3-5 (-9) mm long; glumes up to circa 10 (-18), all fertile, ovate, aristate, 1.2-2.5 mm long, chestnut-brown, glabrous, with a hyaline membranous margin and an erect mucro to circa 0.5 mm long. female spikelets 1-several crowded on each of many short (0.5-2 cm) final branches; glumes narrow-lanceolate to ovate, acute to aristate, 1-4 mm long, red-brown, with erect awn to circa 0.5 mm long; floral bracts 2, narrow-lanceolate, shorter and broader than tepals, glabrous. male flowers: tepals 5 or 6, acuminate, brown-hyaline, glabrous; outer tepals keeled, lanceolate, 1-1.6 mm long; inner tepals concave, ovate, slightly longer; stamens 3, filaments 0.2-0.4 mm long, anthers 0.5-1 mm long. female flowers: tepals 6, narrow-lanceolate, acute, 1-1.5 mm long, membranous; outer tepals keeled; inner tepals flat, margins densely fimbriate; style 3-branched, mostly stigmatic. nut trigonous, 0.7-1.1 mm long, brown. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma interrupted by groups of pillar cells that extend from the parenchyma sheath to the epidermis. reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. pillar cells are elongate, pali cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. on sand or clayey soil, sometimes with laterite gravel, in moist sites and on river banks; in eucalypt forest or woodland, or (less often) in melaleuca swamps or sedge swamps. wind-pollinated; regenerating by resprouting after fire. flowers september-october. ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, perennial, forming large dense tussocks to 1.8 m high and 1 m across with hard woody interlacing rhizomes. Rhizomes elongated, stout, 7-10 mm diam., scales brown, covering a pale to brown woolly pubescence. Culms usually spaced to c. 1 cm apart, unbranched below the inflorescence, 1-2 m long, terete, 2.5-4 mm diam. near base, somewhat striate, grey-green. Sheaths 1-2 cm long, striate, pale-brown; lamina erect, usually 3-8 mm long; margin membranous, c. 3 mm wide, weathering away. Inflorescence long, narrow, erect, c. 20-100 cm long; male spikelets  erect and loosely clustered in the upper 5-10 cm of each branch, branches arising from the upper 10-15 nodes of the culm and the more distal branches often repeatedly branched; female inflorescence similar to the male but usually with fewer branches. Male spikelets pedicellate, with pedicels filiform, up to c. 1 cm long; spikelets ovoid, 3-5 (-9) mm long; glumes up to c. 10 (-18), all fertile, ovate, aristate, 1.2-2.5 mm long, chestnut-brown, glabrous, with a hyaline membranous margin and an erect mucro to c. 0.5 mm long. Female spikelets 1-several crowded on each of many short (0.5-2 cm) final branches; glumes narrow-lanceolate to ovate, acute to aristate, 1-4 mm long, red-brown, with erect awn to c. 0.5 mm long; floral bracts 2, narrow-lanceolate, shorter and broader than tepals, glabrous. Male flowers: tepals 5 or 6, acuminate, brown-hyaline, glabrous; outer tepals keeled, lanceolate, 1-1.6 mm long; inner tepals concave, ovate, slightly longer; stamens 3, filaments 0.2-0.4 mm long, anthers 0.5-1 mm long. Female flowers: tepals 6, narrow-lanceolate, acute, 1-1.5 mm long, membranous; outer tepals keeled; inner tepals flat, margins densely fimbriate; style 3-branched, mostly stigmatic. Nut trigonous, 0.7-1.1 mm long, brown. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma interrupted by groups of pillar cells that extend from the parenchyma sheath to the epidermis. Reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. Pillar cells are elongate, palisade-like cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. On sand or clayey soil, sometimes with laterite gravel, in moist sites and on river banks; in eucalypt forest or woodland, or (less often) in Melaleuca swamps or sedge swamps. Wind-pollinated; regenerating by resprouting after fire. Flowers September-October.

fire: regenerates by seed after fire.
description: herb, dioecious, caespitose, perennial, forming small erect or rarely large tussocks. cataphylls scarious. culms unbranched below the inflorescence, circa 20-80 cm long, terete, 1-3 (-4) mm diam., smooth to substriate or minutely pitted, grey-green. sheaths few (2-4), 1-2.5 cm long, striate, green to brown, apex acute to truncate; margin hyaline, 5-10 mm wide but weathering away. male inflorescence with branches 5-15 cm long. female inflorescence with 5-30 erect and often densely clustered spikelets. male spikelets sessile or on drooping or erect filiform pedicels, narrow-ellipsoid, 4-8 mm long, 1-2 mm diam., becoming ovoid and up to 3 mm diam.; glumes 10-20, ovate-elliptic, acute to mucronate, 3.5-4.5 mm long, brown with a clearly defined hyaline margin and pigmented midvein. female spikelets on erect, rigid pedicels, cylindrical, 10-15 mm long, 2-5 mm diam.; glumes circa 10, rigid, broad-ovate, 4.5-8 mm long, red when young, becoming brown, tapering into a recurved rigid awn. male flowers: tepals membranous, pale brown or hyaline; outer tepals keeled, oblanceolate, mucronate to acuminate, 1.5-2.2 mm long; inner tepals equal in length to outer tepals, flat, ovate, obtuse. female flowers dorsiventrally compressed; bracts between glume and flower absent; tepals 6, 2-4 mm long; outer lateral tepals broad-obovate, keeled, the upper half thick, fleshy and convex with a broad laciniate wing; inner tepals linear-lanceolate, acute, slightly longer than outer. fruit a slender elliptical nut with a hyaline pericarp and two longitudinal pale lines, circa 1.5 mm long, shed with attached tepals. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma interrupted by groups of pillar cells that extend from the parenchyma sheath to the epidermis. reduced leaves on the culm are referred to as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. pillar cells are elongate, pali cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. seasonally moist sites with heath and shrubs on peaty sand, clay or laterite. wind pollinated; regenerates by seed after fire. flowers november, february; fruits november-december. ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, caespitose, perennial, forming small erect or rarely large tussocks. Cataphylls scarious. Culms unbranched below the inflorescence, c. 20-80 cm long, terete, 1-3 (-4) mm diam., smooth to substriate or minutely pitted, grey-green. Sheaths few (2-4), 1-2.5 cm long, striate, green to brown, apex acute to truncate; margin hyaline, 5-10 mm wide but weathering away. Male inflorescence with branches 5-15 cm long. Female inflorescence with 5-30 erect and often densely clustered spikelets. Male spikelets sessile or on drooping or erect filiform pedicels, narrow-ellipsoid, 4-8 mm long, 1-2 mm diam., becoming ovoid and up to 3 mm diam.; glumes 10-20, ovate-elliptic, acute to mucronate, 3.5-4.5 mm long, brown with a clearly defined hyaline margin and pigmented midvein. Female spikelets on erect, rigid pedicels, cylindrical, 10-15 mm long, 2-5 mm diam.; glumes c. 10, rigid, broad-ovate, 4.5-8 mm long, red when young, becoming brown, tapering into a recurved rigid awn. Male flowers: tepals membranous, pale brown or hyaline; outer tepals keeled, oblanceolate, mucronate to acuminate, 1.5-2.2 mm long; inner tepals equal in length to outer tepals, flat, ovate, obtuse. Female flowers dorsiventrally compressed; bracts between glume and flower absent; tepals 6, 2-4 mm long; outer lateral tepals broad-obovate, keeled, the upper half thick, fleshy and convex with a broad laciniate wing; inner tepals linear-lanceolate, acute, slightly longer than outer. Fruit a slender elliptical nut with a hyaline pericarp and two longitudinal pale lines, c. 1.5 mm long, shed with attached tepals. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma interrupted by groups of pillar cells that extend from the parenchyma sheath to the epidermis. Reduced leaves on the culm are referred to as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. Pillar cells are elongate, palisade-like cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. Seasonally moist sites with heath and shrubs on peaty sand, clay or laterite. Wind pollinated; regenerates by seed after fire. Flowers November, February; fruits November-December.

fire: the author observed native bees active on a colony of the orchid at anglesea, vic., in spring 1983 after a fire.
description: deciduous terrestrial tuberous orchids growing in clonal colonies. leaf single, ground-hugging, smooth, sparsely glandular-hairy; sterile plants with small accessory bract nestled in cordate leaf base. racemes 1-flowered; peduncle thin, sparsely glandular hairy. flowers resupinate, unusual shape, dull-coloured (mainly red and white), dominated by lateral sepals and petals. dorsal sepal free, shorter than lateral sepals, incurved and strongly hooding column. lateral sepals free, projecting forwards or decurved beneath labellum. petals free, erect, thin, club-shaped, densely glandular. labellum attached by its base to column base, remaining flexible. labellum lamina obscurely 3-lobed; lateral lobes erect, incurved, forming tube around column; midlobe short, decurved. calli in 2 or 4 rows, stalked, papillate; basal calli similar. column narrow, incurved. anther with 4 yellow pollinia, no viscidium.  grows in a range of forested and shrubby habitats in freely draining to seasonally wet soil. pollinated by small native bees that are attracted to the flowers by sight and a light floral fragrance. the bees land on the flower and feed on nectar that gathers at the base of the labellum. the author observed native bees active on a colony of the orchid at anglesea, vic., in spring 1983 after a fire. when feeding the bee disappears completely inside the flower and emerges head first after a short time with a pollinium attached to the thorax. movements of the labellum are visible while the insect is inside the flower; see also bates (1985). ;
original_text: Deciduous terrestrial tuberous orchids growing in clonal colonies. Leaf single, ground-hugging, smooth, sparsely glandular-hairy; sterile plants with small accessory bract nestled in cordate leaf base. Racemes 1-flowered; peduncle thin, sparsely glandular hairy. Flowers resupinate, unusual shape, dull-coloured (mainly red and white), dominated by lateral sepals and petals. Dorsal sepal free, shorter than lateral sepals, incurved and strongly hooding column. Lateral sepals free, projecting forwards or decurved beneath labellum. Petals free, erect, thin, club-shaped, densely glandular. Labellum attached by its base to column base, remaining flexible. Labellum lamina obscurely 3-lobed; lateral lobes erect, incurved, forming tube around column; midlobe short, decurved. Calli in 2 or 4 rows, stalked, papillate; basal calli similar. Column narrow, incurved. Anther with 4 yellow pollinia, no viscidium.  Grows in a range of forested and shrubby habitats in freely draining to seasonally wet soil. Pollinated by small native bees that are attracted to the flowers by sight and a light floral fragrance. The bees land on the flower and feed on nectar that gathers at the base of the labellum. The author observed native bees active on a colony of the orchid at Anglesea, Vic., in spring 1983 after a fire. When feeding the bee disappears completely inside the flower and emerges head first after a short time with a pollinium attached to the thorax. Movements of the labellum are visible while the insect is inside the flower; see also Bates (1985).

fire: flowering occurs sporadically in unburnt habitat but is dramatically stimulated following summer bushfires. the author estimated circa 400 flowering plants per square metre in some colonies in october 1983 at anglesea, vic., following very hot summer fires.
description: leaf usually prostrate, 40-90 x 15-30 mm, bright green, glabrous or nearly so, a small accessory bract present in the leaf base of sterile plants. flower stem 80-250 mm tall, wiry, glabrous, 1-3-flowered. flowers 15-20 x 10-15 mm, of unusual shape, pink to red and white, labellum white with red bars, calli yellow, column green with red bars. dorsal sepal 8-10 x 4 mm, incurved. lateral sepals asymmetrical, 8-10 x 4 mm, spreading horizontally or at a slight angle below labellum. petals narrow, club-shaped, held erect like ears, 15-18 x 2mm, densely glandular, purplish red. labellum 5.5-7 x 5.5-7mm, obscurely 3-lobed; lateral lobes entire, erect; midlobe entire, recurved. calli stalked, yellow, in 2-4 rows to base of midlobe. column 6.5-7.5 x 2.5-3 mm, greenish with red bars.  widespread and common, ranging from coast to inland areas growing in heathland, heathy forest, mallee vegetation, granite outcrops and scrub adjacent to swamps, usually in light freely draining sandy soils; in w.often occurs in winter-wet sites. reproduces vegetatively and forms extensive spreading clonal colonies. flowering occurs sporadically in unburnt habitat but is dramatically stimulated following summer bushfires. the author estimated circa 400 flowering plants per square metre in some colonies in october 1983 at anglesea, vic., following very hot summer fires. for pollination details see ecology in genus profile. for observations on pollination by native bees see also bates (1985), as caladenia menziesii. flowers august-november. ;
original_text: Leaf usually prostrate, 40-90 x 15-30 mm, bright green, glabrous or nearly so, a small accessory bract present in the leaf base of sterile plants. Flower stem 80-250 mm tall, wiry, glabrous, 1-3-flowered. Flowers 15-20 x 10-15 mm, of unusual shape, pink to red and white, labellum white with red bars, calli yellow, column green with red bars. Dorsal sepal 8-10 x 4 mm, incurved. Lateral sepals asymmetrical, 8-10 x 4 mm, spreading horizontally or at a slight angle below labellum. Petals narrow, club-shaped, held erect like ears, 15-18 x 2mm, densely glandular, purplish red. Labellum 5.5-7 x 5.5-7mm, obscurely 3-lobed; lateral lobes entire, erect; midlobe entire, recurved. Calli stalked, yellow, in 2-4 rows to base of midlobe. Column 6.5-7.5 x 2.5-3 mm, greenish with red bars.  Widespread and common, ranging from coast to inland areas growing in heathland, heathy forest, mallee vegetation, granite outcrops and scrub adjacent to swamps, usually in light freely draining sandy soils; in W.A. often occurs in winter-wet sites. Reproduces vegetatively and forms extensive spreading clonal colonies. Flowering occurs sporadically in unburnt habitat but is dramatically stimulated following summer bushfires. The author estimated c. 400 flowering plants per square metre in some colonies in October 1983 at Anglesea, Vic., following very hot summer fires. For pollination details see Ecology in genus profile. For observations on pollination by native bees see also Bates (1985), as Caladenia menziesii. Flowers August-November.

fire: juvenile plants and ones resprouting after fire commonly have elongated laminae on the culm sheaths, those of macra, muirii and curvescens to 4 cm long or longer. regenerating after fire by seed or resprouting.
description: herbs, dioecious or less often monoecious or hermaphrodite, perennial, glabrous, caespitose or rhizomatous. culms terete or slightly compressed, simple or branched, smooth or minutely rugose. sheaths absent or few or many, persistent or caducous, appressed or lax. inflorescences of many or few flowers in clusters on the culm or on inflorescence branches. flowers not appearing to be in spikelets, males and females similar in dioecious species, sessile or shortly pedicellate, with 2 unequal floral bracts shorter than the tepals. tepals 6, often rigid. male flowers with 3 stamens, anthers exserted; pistillode mostly present. female flowers with 3-locular ovary; styles or style-branches 3, very shortly connate at the base or arising close together on the ovary summit; staminodes mostly present. fruit a capsule. seeds ellipsoidal or globose, with large or small, raised, multicellular, round, ovoid or lobed colliculae arranged in lines parallel or rarely transverse to the long axis, or in an irregular pattern; sometimes also with a rectangular pattern of narrow patent plates (often with lacerate edges) or irregular raised lines over the colliculae. culm anatomy: epidermal cells with sinuous radial walls and often globular silica bodies; chlorenchyma of 1-2 (-4) layers of elongated peg-cells, pillar cells absent; substomatal cavities often lined with thick-walled 'protective cells'; central cavity (pith cavity) circular. juvenile plants and ones resprouting after fire commonly have elongated laminae on the culm sheaths, those of macra, muirii and curvescens to 4 cm long or longer. reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. floral bracts are the two bracts on the pedicel. protective cells are modified chlorenchyma cells that are thick-walled and line the substomatal cavity (cutler 1969). grow mostly in moist sites. regenerating after fire by seed or resprouting. ;
original_text: Herbs, dioecious or less often monoecious or hermaphrodite, perennial, glabrous, caespitose or rhizomatous. Culms terete or slightly compressed, simple or branched, smooth or minutely rugose. Sheaths absent or few or many, persistent or caducous, appressed or lax. Inflorescences of many or few flowers in clusters on the culm or on inflorescence branches. Flowers not appearing to be in spikelets, males and females similar in dioecious species, sessile or shortly pedicellate, with 2 unequal floral bracts shorter than the tepals. Tepals 6, often rigid. Male flowers with 3 stamens, anthers exserted; pistillode mostly present. Female flowers with 3-locular ovary; styles or style-branches 3, very shortly connate at the base or arising close together on the ovary summit; staminodes mostly present. Fruit a capsule. Seeds ellipsoidal or globose, with large or small, raised, multicellular, round, ovoid or lobed colliculae arranged in lines parallel or rarely transverse to the long axis, or in an irregular pattern; sometimes also with a rectangular pattern of narrow patent plates (often with lacerate edges) or irregular raised lines over the colliculae. Culm anatomy: epidermal cells with sinuous radial walls and often globular silica bodies; chlorenchyma of 1-2 (-4) layers of elongated peg-cells, pillar cells absent; substomatal cavities often lined with thick-walled 'protective cells'; central cavity (pith cavity) circular. Juvenile plants and ones resprouting after fire commonly have elongated laminae on the culm sheaths, those of L. macra, L. muirii and L. curvescens to 4 cm long or longer. Reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. Floral bracts are the two bracts on the pedicel. Protective cells are modified chlorenchyma cells that are thick-walled and line the substomatal cavity (Cutler 1969). Grow mostly in moist sites. Regenerating after fire by seed or resprouting.

fire: resprouts after fire.
description: herb, dioecious or monoecious, glabrous, perennial, forming small or large dense tussocks. rhizomes to 10 cm long, 3-8 mm diam.; scales scarious, glossy brown. cataphylls persistent, erect, appressed or loose, 1-10 (-15) cm long. culms numerous, crowded on the rhizome, unbranched, erect, terete or slightly flattened, 30-80 cm long, slender, 0.5-1.0 mm diam. sheaths lacking, or very rarely a single one on the culm; when present, loose, reflexed or appressed, 1-4 cm long; lamina narrow, erect or reflexed, 1.0-3.2 mm long. inflorescence many-flowered, 1-6 cm long; spathes exceeding branches, 1-4 cm long; flowers shortly pedicellate; floral bracts 2. male flowers: tepals lanceolate to narrow ovate, acuminate, yellow-brown; outer tepals longer, 2.8-3.8 mm long; anthers 1.2-2 mm long. female flowers: tepals slightly longer than males. seeds ellipsoidal, colliculate, circa 1 mm long; colliculae elongated transversely to the seed axis. morphological intergrades with lepyrodia cryptica and lepyrodia oligocolea are common where the distributions overlap. grows in moist peaty soil over sandstone or granite. resprouts after fire. for details of ecology in the sydney region see benson & mcdougall (2005: 193-194). flowers december to february (conn 1994); august-may, peak march (benson & mcdougall 2005); fruits september-november. ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious or monoecious, glabrous, perennial, forming small or large dense tussocks. Rhizomes to 10 cm long, 3-8 mm diam.; scales scarious, glossy brown. Cataphylls persistent, erect, appressed or loose, 1-10 (-15) cm long. Culms numerous, crowded on the rhizome, unbranched, erect, terete or slightly flattened, 30-80 cm long, slender, 0.5-1.0 mm diam. Sheaths lacking, or very rarely a single one on the culm; when present, loose, reflexed or appressed, 1-4 cm long; lamina narrow, erect or reflexed, 1.0-3.2 mm long. Inflorescence many-flowered, 1-6 cm long; spathes exceeding branches, 1-4 cm long; flowers shortly pedicellate; floral bracts 2. Male flowers: tepals lanceolate to narrow ovate, acuminate, yellow-brown; outer tepals longer, 2.8-3.8 mm long; anthers 1.2-2 mm long. Female flowers: tepals slightly longer than males. Seeds ellipsoidal, colliculate, c. 1 mm long; colliculae elongated transversely to the seed axis. Morphological intergrades with Lepyrodia cryptica and Lepyrodia oligocolea are common where the distributions overlap. Grows in moist peaty soil over sandstone or granite. Resprouts after fire. For details of ecology in the Sydney region see Benson & McDougall (2005: 193-194). Flowers December to February (Conn 1994); August-May, peak March (Benson & McDougall 2005); fruits September-November.

fire: resprouts after fire.
description: herb, dioecious, perennial, glabrous, forming diffuse patches of clusters of culms joined by rhizomes. rhizomes circa 5 mm diam. cataphylls red-brown, scarious, extending 1-4 cm up the culm. culms usually closely spaced, occasionally to 1 cm apart, erect, terete to slightly flattened, 40-90 cm long, 0.6-1.8 mm diam., smooth to slightly rugose, simple, with a branched inflorescence; lowest internode short (2-4 cm). sheaths 4 or 5, persistent, 1.5-4.0 cm long, loose, lax or reflexed, usually with inrolled margins, red- to dull-brown, obtuse to truncate; lamina erect, to circa 5 mm long. inflorescence 2.5-11 cm long; branches to 4 cm long, moderately crowded with flowers, lower branches spaced further apart on the culm, upper branches clustered; spathes usually exceeding branches, 1.3-2.0 cm long; floral bracts 2, cuspidate. male flowers: tepals rigid, yellow-brown, lanceolate; outer tepals longer, 3.2-4.0 mm long; inner tepals 2.9-3.5 mm long; filaments circa 2 mm long; anthers circa 2 mm long. female flowers: tepals similar to males; outer tepals 3.0-4.2 mm long; inner tepals 2.5-3.5 mm long. seeds ellipsoidal, circa 1.2 mm long, colliculate with small raised areas that are prominently ridged. morphological intergrades with anarthria and verruculosa are common where their distributions overlap. seasonally or permanently damp sites on sandstone in heath and shrubland. resprouts after fire. flowers summer. ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, perennial, glabrous, forming diffuse patches of clusters of culms joined by rhizomes. Rhizomes c. 5 mm diam. Cataphylls red-brown, scarious, extending 1-4 cm up the culm. Culms usually closely spaced, occasionally to 1 cm apart, erect, terete to slightly flattened, 40-90 cm long, 0.6-1.8 mm diam., smooth to slightly rugose, simple, with a branched inflorescence; lowest internode short (2-4 cm). Sheaths 4 or 5, persistent, 1.5-4.0 cm long, loose, lax or reflexed, usually with inrolled margins, red- to dull-brown, obtuse to truncate; lamina erect, to c. 5 mm long. Inflorescence 2.5-11 cm long; branches to 4 cm long, moderately crowded with flowers, lower branches spaced further apart on the culm, upper branches clustered; spathes usually exceeding branches, 1.3-2.0 cm long; floral bracts 2, cuspidate. Male flowers: tepals rigid, yellow-brown, lanceolate; outer tepals longer, 3.2-4.0 mm long; inner tepals 2.9-3.5 mm long; filaments c. 2 mm long; anthers c. 2 mm long. Female flowers: tepals similar to males; outer tepals 3.0-4.2 mm long; inner tepals 2.5-3.5 mm long. fire: regenerates after fire by seed.
description: herb, dioecious, perennial, glabrous, shortly rhizomatous, forming small dense tufts. cataphylls narrow lanceolate, extending 1-3 cm up the culm, often with a slender erect lamina to 3 cm long. culms erect to slightly flexuose, terete, mostly unbranched, 25-35 cm long, 1-1.5 mm diam., smooth, internodes 3 or 4; lowest internode 3-5 cm long; upper internodes 5-11 cm. sheaths caducous, 2.2-4.7 cm long, loose, pale brown; lamina erect, 0.4-4.7 cm long. inflorescence 4-5 cm long (males); 4-9 cm long (females); lower branch of inflorescence the longest, to circa 3 cm long, often spaced to 7 cm below upper branches; spathes erect though usually weathered, 1-1.5 cm long; floral bracts 2, 2.2-3.0 mm long. male flowers: tepals lanceolate, rigid, brown; outer tepals longer, 3.0-4.6 mm long; anthers 2.0-2.5 mm long. female flowers: tepals shorter than males. seeds globose, white, circa 0.9 mm diam., colliculate with circular raised areas and the surface overlain by a network of low patent plates. seasonally wet sites with heath surrounded by woodland, in peaty or clayey sand. regenerates after fire by seed. flowers spring (meney & pate 1999). ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, perennial, glabrous, shortly rhizomatous, forming small dense tufts. Cataphylls narrow lanceolate, extending 1-3 cm up the culm, often with a slender erect lamina to 3 cm long. Culms erect to slightly flexuose, terete, mostly unbranched, 25-35 cm long, 1-1.5 mm diam., smooth, internodes 3 or 4; lowest internode 3-5 cm long; upper internodes 5-11 cm. Sheaths caducous, 2.2-4.7 cm long, loose, pale brown; lamina erect, 0.4-4.7 cm long. Inflorescence 4-5 cm long (males); 4-9 cm long (females); lower branch of inflorescence the longest, to c. 3 cm long, often spaced to 7 cm below upper branches; spathes erect though usually weathered, 1-1.5 cm long; floral bracts 2, 2.2-3.0 mm long. Male flowers: tepals lanceolate, rigid, brown; outer tepals longer, 3.0-4.6 mm long; anthers 2.0-2.5 mm long. Female flowers: tepals shorter than males. Seeds globose, white, c. 0.9 mm diam., colliculate with circular raised areas and the surface overlain by a network of low patent plates. Seasonally wet sites with heath surrounded by woodland, in peaty or clayey sand. Regenerates after fire by seed. Flowers spring (Meney & Pate 1999).

fire: resprouts after fire.
description: herb, dioecious, perennial, glabrous, forming dense tussocks of crowded culms or well separated culms over an area to 1 m across. rhizomes extended, stout, 2-5 mm diam.; scales scarious, brown or straw-coloured. cataphylls scarious, straw-coloured to dark-brown, broad lanceolate, extending circa 2-3.5 cm up the culm, apex truncate with a terete, linear lamina up to 3 cm long. culms erect, occasionally slightly flexuose, + terete, 15-35 cm long, 1-1.9 mm diam., smooth, simple; internodes 3 or 4; lowest internode 4-14 cm long. sheaths slightly lax, caducous, oblong, 0.5-2.5 cm long, apex truncate; lamina 0.1-1.4 (-4.7) cm long. inflorescence up to 9.5 cm long, with few to many flowers crowded apically or on short side branches. spathes often caducous, 0.4-1 (-1.5) cm long; lamina 1-2.5 mm long; floral bracts 2, acuminate- mucronate, males 2.8-3.3 mm long, females 2.0-2.5 mm long. male flowers: tepals lanceolate, acutely acuminate, rigid, brown, tepals equal length, 3.5-4.3 mm long; anthers 2.1-2.4 mm long. female flowers: tepals similar or slightly shorter than males, inner tepals red-brown. seeds globose-elliptic, white, circa 0.9 mm diam., colliculate with lines of small circular raised areas. seasonally wet sites in eucalypt woodland with heath or shrubby understorey, in sandy clay soils over laterite or sandstone. resprouts after fire. flowers spring (meney & pate 1999). ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, perennial, glabrous, forming dense tussocks of crowded culms or well separated culms over an area to 1 m across. Cataphylls scarious, straw-coloured to dark-brown, broad lanceolate, extending c. 2-3.5 cm up the culm, apex truncate with a terete, linear lamina up to 3 cm long. Culms erect, occasionally slightly flexuose, + terete, 15-35 cm long, 1-1.9 mm diam., smooth, simple; internodes 3 or 4; lowest internode 4-14 cm long. Sheaths slightly lax, caducous, oblong, 0.5-2.5 cm long, apex truncate; lamina 0.1-1.4 (-4.7) cm long. Inflorescence up to 9.5 cm long, with few to many flowers crowded apically or on short side branches. Spathes often caducous, 0.4-1 (-1.5) cm long; lamina 1-2.5 mm long; floral bracts 2, acuminate- mucronate, males 2.8-3.3 mm long, females 2.0-2.5 mm long. Male flowers: tepals lanceolate, acutely acuminate, rigid, brown, tepals equal length, 3.5-4.3 mm long; anthers 2.1-2.4 mm long. Female flowers: tepals similar or slightly shorter than males, inner tepals red-brown. Seeds globose-elliptic, white, c. 0.9 mm diam., colliculate with lines of small circular raised areas. Seasonally wet sites in eucalypt woodland with heath or shrubby understorey, in sandy clay soils over laterite or sandstone. Resprouts after fire. Flowers spring (Meney & Pate 1999).

fire: regenerates by seed after fire.
description: herb, dioecious, perennial, glabrous, forming small tufts of culms on short rhizomes. rhizomes stout, horizontal, circa 5 mm diam.; scales scarious, brown. cataphylls straw coloured or tan, broad lanceolate or oblong, extending 0.5-4 cm up the culm, apex truncate with a linear lamina 0.8-2.0 (-5.0) cm long. culms erect, + terete, 13-35 cm long, 0.8-1.5 mm diam., smooth, close-spaced on rhizome (2-5 mm apart); internodes 2 or 3, lowest internode long, 4-12 cm long; upper internodes 5.0-16 cm long. sheaths scarious, caducous, leaving prominent nodal scars, narrow oblanceolate to oblong, 5.5-12.0 mm long, apex truncate with a lamina 1.0-1.5 mm long. inflorescence up to 11.5 cm long with flowers crowded on short branches; spathes usually longer than branches, dark brown, 0.7-2.2 cm long; flowers with 2 acuminate-mucronate floral bracts, 1.6-4.0 mm long. male flowers: inner and outer tepals equal, 4.3-5.1 mm long, lanceolate, acutely tapering, acuminate, rigid, brown, distally with wide hyaline margins; anthers 2.1-2.4 mm long. female flowers: tepals similar length to males, orange-tan; styles very shortly connate at the base. seeds white, ellipsoidal, circa 1.3 mm long, with large elliptical raised areas elongated parallel to the long axis of the seed. heath and sedge swamps, in peaty sand. regenerates by seed after fire. flowers spring (meney & pate 1999). ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, perennial, glabrous, forming small tufts of culms on short rhizomes. Rhizomes stout, horizontal, c. 5 mm diam.; scales scarious, brown. Cataphylls straw coloured or tan, broad lanceolate or oblong, extending 0.5-4 cm up the culm, apex truncate with a linear lamina 0.8-2.0 (-5.0) cm long. Culms erect, + terete, 13-35 cm long, 0.8-1.5 mm diam., smooth, close-spaced on rhizome (2-5 mm apart); internodes 2 or 3, lowest internode long, 4-12 cm long; upper internodes 5.0-16 cm long. Sheaths scarious, caducous, leaving prominent nodal scars, narrow oblanceolate to oblong, 5.5-12.0 mm long, apex truncate with a lamina 1.0-1.5 mm long. Inflorescence up to 11.5 cm long with flowers crowded on short branches; spathes usually longer than branches, dark brown, 0.7-2.2 cm long; flowers with 2 acuminate-mucronate floral bracts, 1.6-4.0 mm long. Male flowers: inner and outer tepals equal, 4.3-5.1 mm long, lanceolate, acutely tapering, acuminate, rigid, brown, distally with wide hyaline margins; anthers 2.1-2.4 mm long. Female flowers: tepals similar length to males, orange-tan; styles very shortly connate at the base. Seeds white, ellipsoidal, c. 1.3 mm long, with large elliptical raised areas elongated parallel to the long axis of the seed. Heath and sedge swamps, in peaty sand. Regenerates by seed after fire. Flowers spring (Meney & Pate 1999).

fire: probably resprouts after fire.
description: herb, monoecious, male and female flowers in the same inflorescence, either in separate clusters or mixed; perennial, glabrous, caespitose or with short horizontal rhizomes. cataphylls ovate to oblong, 1-3 cm long. culms erect, scrambling or trailing, terete, flexuose, forming large tangled tussocks up to 2 m long, 0.5-3 mm diam., repeatedly branched, the branches becoming thinner and more flexuose, smooth; lowest internode 3-5 cm long; internodes 5-10 cm through much of the stem, decreasing to circa 0.5 mm on some branch apices. sheaths persistent, to 3.5 cm long, mostly loose, truncate; lamina erect or reflexed, 1.0-3.5 mm long; margin hyaline, scarious, caducous. inflorescence to circa 30 cm long; branches elongated, often flexuose, with flowers mostly in small dense clusters widely-spaced on the branches; spathes similar to sheaths but smaller; lamina reflexed; floral bracts 2, much shorter than the flowers, ovate, acuminate, 1.1-2.0 mm long, acuminate. male flowers: tepals lanceolate, acute, purplish-brown; outer tepals 1.8-3.3 mm long, keeled, slightly shorter than the flatter inner tepals; anthers 1.7-2.0 mm long. female flowers: tepals similar or slightly longer than males, yellow-brown. seeds ellipsoidal, smooth, circa 1 mm long, not distinctly colliculate, the surface with a fine network of low patent plates. grows in damp soil, in heathland and amongst rocky outcrops; often near creeks and waterfalls. probably resprouts after fire. flowers september-january (conn 1994). ;
original_text: Herb, monoecious, male and female flowers in the same inflorescence, either in separate clusters or mixed; perennial, glabrous, caespitose or with short horizontal rhizomes. Cataphylls ovate to oblong, 1-3 cm long. Culms erect, scrambling or trailing, terete, flexuose, forming large tangled tussocks up to 2 m long, 0.5-3 mm diam., repeatedly branched, the branches becoming thinner and more flexuose, smooth; lowest internode 3-5 cm long; internodes 5-10 cm through much of the stem, decreasing to c. 0.5 mm on some branch apices. Sheaths persistent, to 3.5 cm long, mostly loose, truncate; lamina erect or reflexed, 1.0-3.5 mm long; margin hyaline, scarious, caducous. Inflorescence to c. 30 cm long; branches elongated, often flexuose, with flowers mostly in small dense clusters widely-spaced on the branches; spathes similar to sheaths but smaller; lamina reflexed; floral bracts 2, much shorter than the flowers, ovate, acuminate, 1.1-2.0 mm long, acuminate. Male flowers: tepals lanceolate, acute, purplish-brown; outer tepals 1.8-3.3 mm long, keeled, slightly shorter than the flatter inner tepals; anthers 1.7-2.0 mm long. Female flowers: tepals similar or slightly longer than males, yellow-brown. Seeds ellipsoidal, smooth, c. 1 mm long, not distinctly colliculate, the surface with a fine network of low patent plates. Grows in damp soil, in heathland and amongst rocky outcrops; often near creeks and waterfalls. Probably resprouts after fire. Flowers September-January (Conn 1994).

fire: regenerates by seed after fire.
description: herb, hermaphrodite, with bisexual flowers, perennial, glabrous, caespitose. cataphylls tan or blackish, not glossy, 0.3-1.0 cm long, truncate; lamina short, 1-4.5 mm long, erect, linear. culms few, terete, erect, 0.2-1 m long, 0.5-1.8 mm diam., smooth or slightly rugose, unbranched or with 1 or 2 inflorescence branches 2-6 cm long; lowest internode short, 1.5-2.5 cm long; upper internodes long, 7-15 cm. sheaths 4-9, persistent, closely appressed to the culm except when subtending a branch; brown, smooth or subrugose; 0.6-3.0 cm long. inflorescence of clusters of flowers crowded on the culm or on short side branches up to 4 cm long; the lower clusters separated from the upper by up to 14 cm. spathes shorter than branches, 0.6-1.2 cm long. floral bracts 2, broad lanceolate, 2.5-3.5 mm long, acute or with a short aristate tip to 2 mm long. flowers: tepals rigid, brown, abruptly tapered to an acute apex or a very short mucro, with a very narrow indistinct membranous margin; outer tepals slightly longer than inner, 3.5-3.8 mm long, lanceolate, keel thickened but not folded; inner tepals concave to flat, broad lanceolate; anthers circa 1 mm long; styles very shortly connate at the base. seeds white, ellipsoidal, circa 1.1 mm long, colliculate with irregular elliptical raised areas overlain by parallel striations. found growing in peaty sand in a swamp with agonis parviceps and sedges, and in a seasonally wet swale behind a foredune; sometimes very locally frequent. regenerates by seed after fire. flowers summer (meney & pate 1999). ;
original_text: Herb, hermaphrodite, with bisexual flowers, perennial, glabrous, caespitose. Cataphylls tan or blackish, not glossy, 0.3-1.0 cm long, truncate; lamina short, 1-4.5 mm long, erect, linear. Culms few, terete, erect, 0.2-1 m long, 0.5-1.8 mm diam., smooth or slightly rugose, unbranched or with 1 or 2 inflorescence branches 2-6 cm long; lowest internode short, 1.5-2.5 cm long; upper internodes long, 7-15 cm. Sheaths 4-9, persistent, closely appressed to the culm except when subtending a branch; brown, smooth or subrugose; 0.6-3.0 cm long. Inflorescence of clusters of flowers crowded on the culm or on short side branches up to 4 cm long; the lower clusters separated from the upper by up to 14 cm. Spathes shorter than branches, 0.6-1.2 cm long. Floral bracts 2, broad lanceolate, 2.5-3.5 mm long, acute or with a short aristate tip to 2 mm long. Flowers: tepals rigid, brown, abruptly tapered to an acute apex or a very short mucro, with a very narrow indistinct membranous margin; outer tepals slightly longer than inner, 3.5-3.8 mm long, lanceolate, keel thickened but not folded; inner tepals concave to flat, broad lanceolate; anthers c. 1 mm long; styles very shortly connate at the base. Seeds white, ellipsoidal, c. 1.1 mm long, colliculate with irregular elliptical raised areas overlain by parallel striations. Found growing in peaty sand in a swamp with Agonis parviceps and sedges, and in a seasonally wet swale behind a foredune; sometimes very locally frequent. Regenerates by seed after fire. Flowers summer (Meney & Pate 1999).

fire: resprouts after fire.
description: herb, dioecious, perennial, glabrous, plants forming large patches (e g 1-8 m across) of well separated culms. rhizomes stout, long, circa 5-8 mm diam.; scales brown, scarious. cataphylls 1.0-2.5 cm long. culms erect, terete or slightly compressed, 0.5-1.4 m long, stout, 1.5-6 mm diam., spaced 1.5-4 cm apart on the rhizome, smooth or striate, grey- to blue-green, mostly unbranched; internodes numerous (8-10), lowest internode 2-10 cm long, upper internodes 5-14 cm. sheaths persistent, loose, smooth, oblong to lanceolate, obtuse to truncate, weathering with age, young sheaths reddish, becoming purplish-brown to light-brown, 1.0-4.8 cm long; lamina erect, to 1.0 cm long. inflorescences 2.5-16.0 cm long; branches numerous, erect or spreading, 2-5 cm long, with up to 40 flowers crowded in clusters on a branch; lowest branch often 5-6 cm below upper branches; flowers purple when young; spathes shorter than branches, 0.8-1.9 cm long; floral bract single or absent, 1.5-2.3 mm long, mucronate. male flowers: outer tepals shorter, 2.0-2.3 mm long, narrow lanceolate, brown-hyaline, keeled, acute; mucro 2.0-5.0 mm long; inner tepals 2.5-2.8 mm long, broad lanceolate, flat, light brown-hyaline, acute; anthers 1.4-1.6 mm long. female flowers: outer tepals broad lanceolate, keeled, purple-brown, hyaline, 2.3-3.0 mm long, acute; mucro filiform 0.5-0.8 mm long; inner tepals ovate, purple-hyaline, flattened, 1.6-2.0 mm long, acutely acuminate. seeds ellipsoidal, brown, smooth, circa 0.9 mm long, not distinctly colliculate, the surface with a fine network of fimbriate patent plates. permanently wet areas at edges of streams and in swamps, in peaty clay, often in standing water or with melaleuca. resprouts after fire. flowers spring-summer (meney & pate 1999). ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, perennial, glabrous, plants forming large patches (e.g. 1-8 m across) of well separated culms. Rhizomes stout, long, c. 5-8 mm diam.; scales brown, scarious. Cataphylls 1.0-2.5 cm long. Culms erect, terete or slightly compressed, 0.5-1.4 m long, stout, 1.5-6 mm diam., spaced 1.5-4 cm apart on the rhizome, smooth or striate, grey- to blue-green, mostly unbranched; internodes numerous (8-10), lowest internode 2-10 cm long, upper internodes 5-14 cm. Sheaths persistent, loose, smooth, oblong to lanceolate, obtuse to truncate, weathering with age, young sheaths reddish, becoming purplish-brown to light-brown, 1.0-4.8 cm long; lamina erect, to 1.0 cm long. Inflorescences 2.5-16.0 cm long; branches numerous, erect or spreading, 2-5 cm long, with up to 40 flowers crowded in clusters on a branch; lowest branch often 5-6 cm below upper branches; flowers purple when young; spathes shorter than branches, 0.8-1.9 cm long; floral bract single or absent, 1.5-2.3 mm long, mucronate. Male flowers: outer tepals shorter, 2.0-2.3 mm long, narrow lanceolate, brown-hyaline, keeled, acute; mucro 2.0-5.0 mm long; inner tepals 2.5-2.8 mm long, broad lanceolate, flat, light brown-hyaline, acute; anthers 1.4-1.6 mm long. Female flowers: outer tepals broad lanceolate, keeled, purple-brown, hyaline, 2.3-3.0 mm long, acute; mucro filiform 0.5-0.8 mm long; inner tepals ovate, purple-hyaline, flattened, 1.6-2.0 mm long, acutely acuminate. Seeds ellipsoidal, brown, smooth, c. 0.9 mm long, not distinctly colliculate, the surface with a fine network of fimbriate patent plates. Permanently wet areas at edges of streams and in swamps, in peaty clay, often in standing water or with Melaleuca. Resprouts after fire. Flowers spring-summer (Meney & Pate 1999).

fire: resprouts after fire.
description: herb, dioecious, perennial, glabrous, caespitose. cataphylls dark tan-brown, slightly glossy, extending 1-3 cm up the culm. culms crowded, compressed or sub-terete, erect or slightly flexuose, unbranched, 15-20 cm long, 0.5-0.8 mm diam., smooth, grey-green, with 3-5 internodes; lowest internode 5-10 cm long, upper internodes shorter. sheaths broad lanceolate, closely appressed, persistent, 0.5-1.2 cm long, acute, dark brown; apical margin hyaline and often weathering away; lamina 1-2 mm long, erect or reflexed. inflorescence of flowers singly on the culm or on very short branches; males 3-12 flowers per culm, females 1-6 flowers per culm; spathes shorter than flowers; floral bracts 1.6-2.1 mm long, keeled or with a prominent midvein. male flowers: tepals broad lanceolate, acute, rigid, brown; outer tepals shorter, 1.9-2.1 mm long; inner tepals concave, 2.4-2.7 mm long; anthers 1.2-1.8 mm long. female flowers: tepals similar length to males. seeds ellipsoid-crescent shaped, brown, striate, circa 1 mm long. open patches in peaty sand, in moist sedge-heath. resprouts after fire. flowers summer (meney & pate 1999). ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, perennial, glabrous, caespitose. Cataphylls dark tan-brown, slightly glossy, extending 1-3 cm up the culm. Culms crowded, compressed or sub-terete, erect or slightly flexuose, unbranched, 15-20 cm long, 0.5-0.8 mm diam., smooth, grey-green, with 3-5 internodes; lowest internode 5-10 cm long, upper internodes shorter. Sheaths broad lanceolate, closely appressed, persistent, 0.5-1.2 cm long, acute, dark brown; apical margin hyaline and often weathering away; lamina 1-2 mm long, erect or reflexed. Inflorescence of flowers singly on the culm or on very short branches; males 3-12 flowers per culm, females 1-6 flowers per culm; spathes shorter than flowers; floral bracts 1.6-2.1 mm long, keeled or with a prominent midvein. Male flowers: tepals broad lanceolate, acute, rigid, brown; outer tepals shorter, 1.9-2.1 mm long; inner tepals concave, 2.4-2.7 mm long; anthers 1.2-1.8 mm long. Female flowers: tepals similar length to males. Seeds ellipsoid-crescent shaped, brown, striate, c. 1 mm long. Open patches in peaty sand, in moist sedge-heath. Resprouts after fire. Flowers summer (Meney & Pate 1999).

fire: regenerates by seed after fire.
description: herb, hermaphrodite, perennial, with bisexual flowers, glabrous, caespitose, forming small tussocks of crowded culms. cataphylls stramineus, 0.5-1 cm long; lamina 3-5 mm long. culms terete, numerous, branching repeatedly very near the base but unbranched above the cataphylls, curved and ascending or straight, 3-13 cm long, 0.5-1 mm diam., finely rugose or pitted; internodes 2 or 3, the lowest internode short, 0.4-2.2 cm long, often hidden by cataphylls; upper internodes longer, 3-6 cm. sheaths caducous, 0.3-1.2 cm long, appressed or loose, green or straw-coloured, apex truncate; lamina erect, 2-6 mm long. inflorescence slender, 0.5-3 cm long with 8-20 well-separated flowers sessile on the culm or on short side branches; spathes 2-6 mm long; floral bracts 2, 1.4-2.2 mm long. flowers: tepals rigid, brown hyaline; outer tepals longer, 2.3-3.2 mm long, narrow subulate, keeled; inner tepals broad lanceolate to ovate, acute, concave; anthers 1-1.8 mm long. seeds globose, white, circa 1 mm diam., colliculate with lines of small circular raised areas. heaths and eucalypt forest, in seasonally moist sand with peat or laterite gravel. regenerates by seed after fire. flowers mainly summer. fruits february-october. ;

description: herb, dioecious, perennial, glabrous, forming large dense patches of culms arising from stout rhizomes. rhizomes 4-8 mm diam.; scales pale-brown, scarious. cataphylls pale brown or blackish, 4-5 cm long. culms well-spaced, mostly 1-2 cm apart, erect, + terete, 0.5-0.8 (-1.5) m long, 1.2-2.8 mm diam., smooth to subrugose, simple or infrequently branched; lowest internode short, lowest sheath up to 3 cm above cataphylls or partly hidden by cataphylls. sheaths 7-10, persistent, 1.5-4 cm long, loose but not strongly recurved, pale- to dark-brown, obtuse to truncate; lamina erect, circa 1 (-4) mm long. inflorescence 4-20 cm long; branches erect, to 10 cm long, densely crowded with flowers; spathes shorter than branches, 1-3.5 cm long; floral bracts 1.5-2 mm long. male flowers: tepals scarious, pale-brown, oblong-lanceolate, acute or shortly acuminate, inner and outer tepals equal or the outer slightly longer, 2.3-3.0 (-3.2) mm long; anthers 1.0-1.8 mm long. female flowers: tepals similar length to males. seeds ellipsoidal, circa 0.8 mm long, colliculate with small circular raised areas, the surface cells in lines parallel to the seed longitudinal axis, but the cells rectangular and elongated transverse to that axis; the surface overlain by a network of low patent plates. grows in moist sandy coastal heath and swampy depressions in woodland. resprouts after fire. flowers summer. ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, perennial, glabrous, forming large dense patches of culms arising from stout rhizomes. Rhizomes 4-8 mm diam.; scales pale-brown, scarious. fire: resprouts after fire.
description: herb, monoecious, perennial, glabrous. rhizomes 2-5 mm diam.; scales tan to dark brown. cataphylls straw-coloured, extending 2-2.5 cm up the culm. culms closely spaced, erect, terete, 15-50 cm long, 0.5-0.9 mm diam., minutely wrinkled or pitted or rarely smooth, simple or branched; lowest internode 2-4 cm long, similar length to upper internodes. sheaths persistent; 6-22 mm long, usually loose, truncate; lamina erect or reflexed, 2-5 mm long; often with a thin indistinct, hyaline, scarious, seepage areas in open eucalypt forest with heathy understorey on granite or sandstone. resprouts after fire. flowers summer. ;
original_text: Herb, monoecious, perennial, glabrous. Rhizomes 2-5 mm diam.; scales tan to dark brown. Cataphylls straw-coloured, extending 2-2.5 cm up the culm. Culms closely spaced, erect, terete, 15-50 cm long, 0.5-0.9 mm diam., minutely wrinkled or pitted or rarely smooth, simple or branched; lowest internode 2-4 cm long, similar length to upper internodes. Sheaths persistent; 6-22 mm long, usually loose, truncate; lamina erect or reflexed, 2-5 mm long; often with a thin indistinct, hyaline, scarious, Seepage areas in open eucalypt forest with heathy understorey on granite or sandstone. fire: regenerates by seed after fire.
description: herb, female or monoecious, most specimens female, when monoecious the ¢€ž¢¢‚¬Å¡ and ¢€ž¢¢€š¬ flowers on different culms, perennial, glabrous, caespitose, forming small tussocks of crowded culms. cataphylls mostly numerous, persistent, erect, 0.5-1.5 cm long, green or scarious, apex truncate; lamina filiform, erect, 0.2-2 cm long. culms mostly straight, erect, terete to partially flattened, numerous, unbranched below inflorescence, (5-) 12-30 cm long, 0.5-1 mm diam., rugose or pitted, internodes 2 or 3; the lowest internode 2-4.5 cm long; the upper internodes longer (5.5-12 cm). sheaths caducous, 0.5-2.4 cm long, truncate; lamina erect, 2-8 mm long, occasionally longer. inflorescence narrow, erect, 1.5-6 cm long, with up to 40 moderately crowded and very shortly pedicellate flowers distally and on short side branches; branches somewhat clustered at apex of culm; spathes 0.5-1.2 cm long; floral bracts 2, 1.4-2.6 mm long. male flowers: tepals rigid, reddish brown, lanceolate, acute; outer tepals longer, 2.4-3.3 mm long, keeled; anthers circa 1.8 mm long. female flowers: tepals similar or slightly longer than males. seeds globose, white, circa 0.9 mm diam., colliculate with lines of small circular raised areas. most specimens are female or monoecious. male flowers are much less abundant than female flowers but most female flowers set seed, suggesting that apomictic development may occur. moist heaths, shrubland and woodland, in various sandy substrates, such as sandy clay, peaty sand and laterite gravel. regenerates by seed after fire. flowers september-october. fruits may-september. ;
original_text: Herb, female or monoecious, most specimens female, when monoecious the ¢€ž¢¢‚¬Å¡ and ¢€ž¢¢€š¬ flowers on different culms, perennial, glabrous, caespitose, forming small tussocks of crowded culms. Cataphylls mostly numerous, persistent, erect, 0.5-1.5 cm long, green or scarious, apex truncate; lamina filiform, erect, 0.2-2 cm long. Culms mostly straight, erect, terete to partially flattened, numerous, unbranched below inflorescence, (5-) 12-30 cm long, 0.5-1 mm diam., rugose or pitted, internodes 2 or 3; the lowest internode 2-4.5 cm long; the upper internodes longer (5.5-12 cm). Sheaths caducous, 0.5-2.4 cm long, truncate; lamina erect, 2-8 mm long, occasionally longer. Male flowers: tepals rigid, reddish brown, lanceolate, acute; outer tepals longer, 2.4-3.3 mm long, keeled; anthers c. 1.8 mm long. Female flowers: tepals similar or slightly longer than males.
