simplified_phrase: genus-level observation; regenerates from seed after fire
fire: regenerates by seed after fire or disturbance.
description: herb, perennial, dioecious, caespitose, the base pubescent; cluster and sand-binding roots present. rhizomes very short, sparsely pilose, mostly covered by glabrous scales. culms simple or occasionally with 1 or 2 branches, terete, glabrous, striate. sheaths persistent, appressed, the ligule a short membranous flap formed by the apical margins joining adaxially. male and female inflorescences similar, of large erect spikelets terminating culms or on slender pedicels at several upper nodes; spikelets with 10-20 flowers and several sterile glumes toward both base and apex; glumes rigid, dark brown or black, obtuse or with a short rigid acute tip. flowers: tepals 6, 2 outer tepals keeled and with dense red-brown hairs along the keel toward the apex, inner tepals flat. male flowers with 3 stamens, the anthers exserted. female flowers with 2 ovary loculi and 2 style branches. fruit a capsule, compressed, circular in outline. seeds broad-ellipsoid; surface cells longitudinally elongated and with sinuous walls. culm anatomy: epidermis with greatly enlarged tanniniferous cells opposite outer vascular bundles; some of these enlarged cells extending partly through the chlorenchyma but others extend to (and interrupt) the parenchyma sheath, the two types of enlarged cells mostly alternating around the culm perimeter in cross-section; chlorenchyma of 1 layer of elongated peg cells; pillar and protective cells absent, central cavity present. melanostachya shows a flavonoid pattern distinct from that of chordifex and other allied genera, including hypolaetin and flavone c-glycosides, as well as the more widely found luteolin (williams et al. 1998). reduced leaves on the culm are referred to as sheaths. peg cells are pali chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. pillar cells are elongate, pali cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened (lignified) walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. protective cells are modified chlorenchyma cells that are thick-walled and line the substomatal cavity (cutler 1969). cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. an informative online interactive key to the western australian restionaceae species, with abundant photographs, is given by hollister & thiele (2014).  wind-pollinated; regenerates by seed after fire or disturbance. ;
original_text: Herb, perennial, dioecious, caespitose, the base pubescent; cluster and sand-binding roots present. Rhizomes very short, sparsely pilose, mostly covered by glabrous scales. Culms simple or occasionally with 1 or 2 branches, terete, glabrous, striate. Sheaths persistent, appressed, the ligule a short membranous flap formed by the apical margins joining adaxially. Male and female inflorescences similar, of large erect spikelets terminating culms or on slender pedicels at several upper nodes; spikelets with 10-20 flowers and several sterile glumes toward both base and apex; glumes rigid, dark brown or black, obtuse or with a short rigid acute tip. Flowers: tepals 6, 2 outer tepals keeled and with dense red-brown hairs along the keel toward the apex, inner tepals flat. Male flowers with 3 stamens, the anthers exserted. Female flowers with 2 ovary loculi and 2 style branches. Fruit a capsule, compressed, circular in outline. Seeds broad-ellipsoid; surface cells longitudinally elongated and with sinuous walls. Culm anatomy: epidermis with greatly enlarged tanniniferous cells opposite outer vascular bundles; some of these enlarged cells extending partly through the chlorenchyma but others extend to (and interrupt) the parenchyma sheath, the two types of enlarged cells mostly alternating around the culm perimeter in cross-section; chlorenchyma of 1 layer of elongated peg cells; pillar and protective cells absent, central cavity present. Melanostachya shows a flavonoid pattern distinct from that of Chordifex and other allied genera, including hypolaetin and flavone C-glycosides, as well as the more widely found luteolin (Williams et al. 1998). Reduced leaves on the culm are referred to as sheaths. Peg cells are palisade-like chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. Pillar cells are elongate, palisade-like cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened (lignified) walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. Protective cells are modified chlorenchyma cells that are thick-walled and line the substomatal cavity (Cutler 1969). Cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. An informative online interactive key to the Western Australian Restionaceae species, with abundant photographs, is given by Hollister & Thiele (2014).  Wind-pollinated; regenerates by seed after fire or disturbance.

fire: recruits by seed after fire or disturbance.
description: herb, perennial, dioecious, caespitose, forming large dense clumps to 0.5 m across; cluster and sand-binding roots present. culms crowded, erect, terete, 50-100 cm long, 1.0-1.5 mm diam., green, striate, glabrous, simple or occasionally branched; internodes numerous. sheaths closely appressed, oblong, subulate, 1.0-2.3 cm long, scarious, glabrous, striate; ligule an erect membranous ridge 0.3 mm long formed by the apical margins joining adaxially; lamina caducous, 0.6-1.5 cm long. spikelets terminal on culms or on long slender pedicels, 1-3 on each culm. male and female spikelets similar, 1-2.8 cm long, 0.5-0.7 cm wide; males narrow-elliptic, acute, not glossy; females ovoid to globular; glumes ovate, 4-8 mm long; obtuse, minutely ciliate on lower margin, rigid and very dark brown or black apically; males with circa 20 fertile glumes; females 9-20 fertile glossy glumes. flowers: very shortly pedicellate, dorsiventrally flattened; tepals lanceolate, brown-hyaline. male flowers: outer tepals 4.0-4.5 mm long; inner tepals 3.2-4.2 mm long; filaments 5-6 mm long; anthers 2.5-3.2 mm long; pistillode minute. female flowers: outer tepals 6.0-7.5 mm long; inner tepals 4.5-6.0 mm long; staminodes 3, well-developed, circa 1.5 mm long; style branches 2, connate at the base, stigmatic almost to the base. capsule 1.5-2.0 mm long. seeds broad-ellipsoid, with longitudinally elongated cells with sinuous walls. culm anatomy: epidermis with greatly enlarged tanniniferous cells opposite outer vascular bundles, with some of these enlarged cells extending partly through the chlorenchyma but others extend to (and interrupt) the parenchyma sheath, the two types of enlarged cells mostly alternating around the perimeter of the culm cross-section; chlorenchyma of 1 layer of elongated peg cells; pillar and protective cells absent, central cavity present. melanostachya shows a flavonoid pattern distinct from that of chordifex and other allied genera, including hypolaetin and flavone c-glycosides, as well as the more widely found luteolin (williams et al. 1998). reduced leaves on the culm are referred to as sheaths. peg cells are pali chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. pillar cells are elongate, pali cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened (lignified) walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. an informative online interactive key to the western australian restionaceae species, with abundant photographs, is given by hollister & thiele (2014). seasonally inundated heaths and swamps, in peaty sand or clay, often in standing water; sites wet most of the year. wind-pollinated; recruits by seed after fire or disturbance. flowers september, october. seed maturation: 2-3 months. (meney & pate 1999, hollister & thiele 2017). ;
original_text: Herb, perennial, dioecious, caespitose, forming large dense clumps to 0.5 m across; cluster and sand-binding roots present. Culms crowded, erect, terete, 50-100 cm long, 1.0-1.5 mm diam., green, striate, glabrous, simple or occasionally branched; internodes numerous. Sheaths closely appressed, oblong, subulate, 1.0-2.3 cm long, scarious, glabrous, striate; ligule an erect membranous ridge 0.3 mm long formed by the apical margins joining adaxially; lamina caducous, 0.6-1.5 cm long. Spikelets terminal on culms or on long slender pedicels, 1-3 on each culm. Male and female spikelets similar, 1-2.8 cm long, 0.5-0.7 cm wide; males narrow-elliptic, acute, not glossy; females ovoid to globular; glumes ovate, 4-8 mm long; obtuse, minutely ciliate on lower margin, rigid and very dark brown or black apically; males with c. 20 fertile glumes; females 9-20 fertile glossy glumes. Flowers: very shortly pedicellate, dorsiventrally flattened; tepals lanceolate, brown-hyaline. Male flowers: outer tepals 4.0-4.5 mm long; inner tepals 3.2-4.2 mm long; filaments 5-6 mm long; anthers 2.5-3.2 mm long; pistillode minute. Female flowers: outer tepals 6.0-7.5 mm long; inner tepals 4.5-6.0 mm long; staminodes 3, well-developed, c. 1.5 mm long; style branches 2, connate at the base, stigmatic almost to the base. Capsule 1.5-2.0 mm long. Seeds broad-ellipsoid, with longitudinally elongated cells with sinuous walls. Culm anatomy: epidermis with greatly enlarged tanniniferous cells opposite outer vascular bundles, with some of these enlarged cells extending partly through the chlorenchyma but others extend to (and interrupt) the parenchyma sheath, the two types of enlarged cells mostly alternating around the perimeter of the culm cross-section; chlorenchyma of 1 layer of elongated peg cells; pillar and protective cells absent, central cavity present. Melanostachya shows a flavonoid pattern distinct from that of Chordifex and other allied genera, including hypolaetin and flavone C-glycosides, as well as the more widely found luteolin (Williams et al. 1998). Reduced leaves on the culm are referred to as sheaths. Peg cells are palisade-like chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. Pillar cells are elongate, palisade-like cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened (lignified) walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. Cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. An informative online interactive key to the Western Australian Restionaceae species, with abundant photographs, is given by Hollister & Thiele (2014). Seasonally inundated heaths and swamps, in peaty sand or clay, often in standing water; sites wet most of the year. Wind-pollinated; recruits by seed after fire or disturbance. Flowers September, October. Seed maturation: 2-3 months. (Meney & Pate 1999, Hollister & Thiele 2017).

original_text: Deciduous, tuberous, terrestrial orchids growing individually or in spreading clonal colonies. Leaf single, thin, onion-like, hollow. Inflorescence a dense spike or spike-like raceme that grows through the hollow leaf and emerges at a weak spot (fistula) on the longitudinal seam of the leaf, usually about halfway along, but variable according to species. Flowers resupinate, small, opening widely, green or white, each flower perched on a swollen, shortly stalked or stalkless ovary. Dorsal sepal free, broader than lateral sepals, concave, hooding the small column. Lateral sepals free, spreading, recurved, coiled or inrolled. Petals small, often partially enclosed within dorsal sepal. Labellum attached firmly by its base to column base. Labellum lamina unlobed, deflexed, tongue-like; margins smooth, crinkly or irregular, often adorned with irregular, marginal clusters of cells (termed excrescences); apex blunt, truncate or often notched, sometimes with 2 distinct lobes. Callus of smooth, dark mounds on labellum base, supplementary glandular cell clusters (termed apical callus in descriptions) often also near apex. Column tiny with a pair of ear-like wings. Pollinia 4, yellow, sectile, attached directly to viscidium or via short hamulus. Because of their inconspicuous nature and small, dull-coloured flowers these orchids are easily overlooked and generally attract limited attention by botanists. The common name 'onion orchid' for the genus as a whole is apt as all species have a tapering, terete leaf just like an onion seedling. They also called 'mignonette orchids' in Western Australia. Hybridisation is not often reported in Microtis, but seems to be common and is almost expected when 2 or more species are growing in close proximity to each other, especially in disturbed habitats. The hybrids however, are often very difficult to discern and for this reason only obvious natural hybrids are mentioned. These orchids occur in a wide range of moist to wet habitats including depressions, swamps, bogs and seepage sites, but can also be found growing in well-drained soils in heath, forest and grassland, often among grasses and herbs. They can rapidly colonise recently disturbed habitats and some species occur in gardens, lawns and pasture. Microtis species spread by seed and most species also form clonal colonies. After shedding seeds the plant dies back to a small, round tuber which remains dormant to avoid the summer extremes of heat and dryness. The tuber sprouts after soaking autumn rains and a thin, wispy leaf emerges, developing fully before flowering takes place in spring and summer. A replacement tuber is produced close to the parent tuber (which dies) and extra daughter tubers are produced at the end of thin, fleshy roots.  Flowering is best in wet years and is often enhanced by summer fires. At least 2 species flower only after hot summer fires. The flowers of several species are noticeably scented on warm to hot days. Several species of Microtis use either self-pollination or apomixis as a fail-safe strategy to ensure seed development (Bates 1981, 1983, 1984b). The process of self-pollination is relatively simple and easily observed. The stigma is situated immediately below the anther with the two organs separated by a thin, almost vestigial rostellum. The pollinarium consists of 2 pairs of pollinia connected either directly, or via a short hamulus, to a viscidium which is in contact with the rostellum. These organs are separate when the flower first opens, but swell and soften with age, eventually coming into contact (usually 2-4 days after opening), after which the pollen germinates and brings about fertilisation. Though self pollination and apomixis are the primary pollination strategies for several species of Microtis, the flowers of many species are scented and most species, if not all, produce nectar which gathers in a small well (nectary) at the base of the column. Nectar is sometimes also produced in droplets on the labellum where it can smear or coalesce. The nectar attracts a range of visitors and ensures some degree of outcrossing to maintain diversity. Insect visitors to Microtis flowers include several species of small ants which seem to be significant pollinators in this genus (Jones, 1975, Peakall & Beattie, 1989 - see M. parviflora for more details). Other small insects that visit the flowers include flies (Syrphidae, Sciaridae), beetles (Chrysomelidae, Curculionidae) and small wasps (Ichneumonidae, Braconidae, Bethylidae), some of which can bring about limited pollination (Bates 1981, Kuiter 2013, 2017). Some of these insects have been observed to remove pollinaria from freshly opened flowers and are capable of carrying out limited pollination, but the process of autogamy/apomixis impedes the removal of pollinaria from flowers more than 1 or 2 days old. The author has observed small dark weevils of an undescribed genus removing and depositing pollinaria from freshly opened flowers of M. oblonga, M. parviflora and M. unifolia while feeding on labellum nectar. For a summary of Microtis pollination see Bower 2001: pp. 184-185. For photos of insect visitors to the flowers of Microtis species see Kuiter (2013, pp. 54-58 and 2017, pp. 56-73).

Dorsal sepal porrect to obliquely erect, c. 3 x 2 mm, apex shortly pointed. Lateral sepals inrolled, narrowly elliptic-lanceolate, c. 1.5 x 0.4 mm, tapered to a long point. Labellum porrect at base then decurved, narrowly oblong, 2.5-3 x 1.5-1.8 mm, margins thick with numerous prominent groups of cell-clusters; apex broadly and shallowly notched. Basal callus of 2 separate, large, dark green, comma-like mounds; apical callus raised, granular.  Widespread and common on the coast and inland; growing in a range of habitats with moisture-retentive soil, especially near streams, seasonal watercourses and swamps, but also on coastal sandhills, granite outcrops and in open forest. Usually flowers freely in the absence of fire, especially in wet years, but it's also stimulated by summer fires in dense or overgrown habitats. Flowers November-January.

Often common in moist to wet sites, even swamps; growing among grass and shrubs in heath, open forest, wet sclerophyll forest, montane grasslands and herbfields, occasionally flowering in standing water; in montane to subalpine areas it grows in moist grassland, seepage sites and sometimes in mounds of sphagnum moss; in S.A. it is recorded as growing on mounds of peat in swamps and bogs. Usually occurs singly or in small, scattered groups and flowers best in wet seasons (flowering is generally poor in drier years). Flowering is greatly enhanced by summer fires, especially in lowland habitats, also by disturbances such as mowing and slashing. Flowers October-February.

Robinson, pers. obs). However, Wilson & Venter (2016) indicate that the ecology of this taxon is distinct, and that plants of Nepenthes tenax and N. parvula grown under identical conditions respond differently, particularly in terms of their temperature tolerances (Wilson & Venter 2016). description: leaf ground-hugging, nearly circular with cordate base, 60-120 mm across, bright green to dark purplish green and hairy above with numerous, ridged, radiating veins; glabrous and green or purplish beneath. flower stem 120-180 mm long, 1-4-flowered. flowers opening widely, 40-50 x 35-45 mm, pink, purple or pale green with a white and purple labellum. dorsal sepal 25-32 x 4-5 mm, erect. lateral sepals 25-32 x 5-6 mm, divergent. petals 24-28 x 4-5 mm, widely spreading. labellum 18-23 x 15-20 mm, base white, apex purple with darker veins; lateral lobes incurved; midlobe shallowly notched with broad, flat or shallowly ridged, glabrous plate. plants from the n.have up to 4 flowers per raceme and a much broader labellum than those from qld, which have 2 flowers per raceme. widespread and common; found growing in open forest, along rainforest margins and in thickets of monsoonal rainforest. this species occurs in large colonies consisting of hundreds of plants, but seems to flower only after fires. flowers november-december. ;

description: leaf held stiffly erect, broadly ovate, 150-200 x 50-80 mm, dark green with 7 prominent veins, on stalk 30-50 mm long. flower stem 150-250 mm long, 2-6-flowered. flowers opening tardily to widely, porrect to semi-nodding, 20-30 x 25-40 mm, pink, cream, brownish or greenish, tepals with purple veins, labellum pink to mauve. dorsal sepal 20-25 x 3-3.5 mm, erect or incurved. lateral sepals 20-25 x 3-3.5 mm, divergent. petals 19-23 x 3-3.5 mm, spreading. labellum 18-24 x 10-14 mm; midlobe with filigree of darker, hairy veins, wavy margins and 3 narrow, hairy ridges.  widespread and common; forming colonies on rainforest margins, among grass in moist to wet areas of open forest and around swamps in dark, peaty soil. this species occurs in large colonies consisting of hundreds of plants, but flowers sparsely except after fires. flower stems emerge from ground after the first heavy storms of the wet season. each flower lasts only few days and the flowering period is brief and easily missed. leaves appear 2 or 3 weeks after flowering is finished, although sometimes they can be seen emerging as the capsules develop. the author counted 19 capsules formed from 86 flowers (about 22% success rate) on racemes of this orchid at adelaide river, n.on 27 november 1980. flowers november-december. ;
original_text: Leaf held stiffly erect, broadly ovate, 150-200 x 50-80 mm, dark green with 7 prominent veins, on stalk 30-50 mm long. Flower stem 150-250 mm long, 2-6-flowered. Flowers opening tardily to widely, porrect to semi-nodding, 20-30 x 25-40 mm, pink, cream, brownish or greenish, tepals with purple veins, labellum pink to mauve. Dorsal sepal 20-25 x 3-3.5 mm, erect or incurved. Lateral sepals 20-25 x 3-3.5 mm, divergent. Petals 19-23 x 3-3.5 mm, spreading. Labellum 18-24 x 10-14 mm; midlobe with filigree of darker, hairy veins, wavy margins and 3 narrow, hairy ridges.  Widespread and common; forming colonies on rainforest margins, among grass in moist to wet areas of open forest and around swamps in dark, peaty soil. This species occurs in large colonies consisting of hundreds of plants, but flowers sparsely except after fires. Flower stems emerge from ground after the first heavy storms of the wet season. Each flower lasts only few days and the flowering period is brief and easily missed. Leaves appear 2 or 3 weeks after flowering is finished, although sometimes they can be seen emerging as the capsules develop. The author counted 19 capsules formed from 86 flowers (about 22% success rate) on racemes of this orchid at Adelaide River, N.T. on 27 November 1980. Flowers November-December.

fire: grows in a rangeof soils on coastal headlands, in deep gorges, cave openings and disturbed rainforestor softwood scrub, often among regrowth after fire.
description: corolla-tube 1.5-3 mm wide at top of calyx; lobes broad, obtuse. staminal filaments 6-11 mm long, inserted in lower half of corolla-tube. capsule dehiscing by 4 valves. testa wrinkled or with wavy-edged honeycomb. grows in a rangeof soils on coastal headlands, in deep gorges, cave openings and disturbed rainforestor softwood scrub, often among regrowth after fire. ;
original_text: Corolla-tube 1.5-3 mm wide at top of calyx; lobes broad, obtuse. Staminal filaments 6-11 mm long, inserted in lower half of corolla-tube. Capsule dehiscing by 4 valves. Testa wrinkled or with wavy-edged honeycomb. Grows in a rangeof soils on coastal headlands, in deep gorges, cave openings and disturbed rainforestor softwood scrub, often among regrowth after fire.

fire: flowers more prolifically the first season after fire.
description: spreading tree or shrub to 7 m high, glabrous except scattered hairs on bracts. leaves lanceolate, acute to rounded, 25-100 mm long, 3-6 mm wide, attenuate at base, sessile. inflorescences forming terminal fascicles; axis up to 25 cm long, angular, bearing up to 50 triads; peduncles of triads 8-16 mm long, enlarging in fruit; all flowers sessile; bracts triangular, decurrent, 4-7 mm long, 2-3 mm wide, reaching 20 mm long in fruit. calyx 1-1.5 mm long, irregularly toothed. corolla in mature bud circa 12 mm long, robust, clavate, bright orange to golden yellow. anthers 2-3 mm long; filaments epipetalous near base, the free parts circa 6 mm long. fruit circa 10 mm long, brown. flowers more prolifically the first season after fire. grows in sandy or granitic soil in open forest, woodland and heath; parasitic on many species including annuals, often connected by underground runners to hosts some distance away. flowers nov.-jan.; fruit mar.-apr. ;
original_text: Spreading tree or shrub to 7 m high, glabrous except scattered hairs on bracts. Leaves lanceolate, acute to rounded, 25-100 mm long, 3-6 mm wide, attenuate at base, sessile. Inflorescences forming terminal fascicles; axis up to 25 cm long, angular, bearing up to 50 triads; peduncles of triads 8-16 mm long, enlarging in fruit; all flowers sessile; bracts triangular, decurrent, 4-7 mm long, 2-3 mm wide, reaching 20 mm long in fruit. Calyx 1-1.5 mm long, irregularly toothed. Corolla in mature bud c. 12 mm long, robust, clavate, bright orange to golden yellow. Anthers 2-3 mm long; filaments epipetalous near base, the free parts c. 6 mm long. Fruit c. 10 mm long, brown. Flowers more prolifically the first season after fire. Grows in sandy or granitic soil in open forest, woodland and heath; parasitic on many species including annuals, often connected by underground runners to hosts some distance away. Flowers Nov.-Jan.; fruit Mar.-Apr.

fire: shrub to 60 cm, rarely taller, single-stemmed or with fire-tolerant stock and many openly-branched stems, glabrous except staminodes.
description: shrub to 60 cm, rarely taller, single-stemmed or with fire-tolerant stock and many openly-branched stems, glabrous except staminodes. branchlets almost smooth. leaves oblong to narrowly cuneate, truncate to retuse, shortly apiculate, mostly 4-10 mm long and 2-3 mm wide, sessile, semi-amplexicaul. pedicel and hypanthium together 2-3 mm long. calyx circa 0.2 mm long. corolla 3.5-4 mm long, creamy white. stamens 1.5 mm long; filaments narrow; staminodes 2 mm long, bifid, densely bearded in lower half. style 1.5 mm long. drupe ellipsoidal, 5 mm long. grows in sandy soils in sclerophyllous woodland and wallum, sometimes near swamps. ;
original_text: Shrub to 60 cm, rarely taller, single-stemmed or with fire-tolerant stock and many openly-branched stems, glabrous except staminodes. Branchlets almost smooth. Leaves oblong to narrowly cuneate, truncate to retuse, shortly apiculate, mostly 4-10 mm long and 2-3 mm wide, sessile, semi-amplexicaul. Pedicel and hypanthium together 2-3 mm long. Calyx c. 0.2 mm long. Corolla 3.5-4 mm long, creamy white. Stamens 1.5 mm long; filaments narrow; staminodes 2 mm long, bifid, densely bearded in lower half. Style 1.5 mm long. Drupe ellipsoidal, 5 mm long. Grows in sandy soils in sclerophyllous woodland and wallum, sometimes near swamps.

fire: notes fires are relatively frequent where this species grows.
description: rosette leaves 6-10, elliptical to narrowly obovate, 15-30 x 4-8mm. flower stem 100-250mm tall, 2-4mm across, 1-5-flowered. stem bracts 3-4. flowers porrect to semi-nodding, 45-55 x 7-9mm, translucent white with green or light brown lines and markings, shiny. dorsal sepal point filamentous, 15-20mm long, upcurved. lateral sepals as wide as hood, deeply concave, margins thickened, densely hairy; free points filamentous, 15-30mm long, decurved, parallel or divergent. petals with very small basal flanges, 18-21 x 5-6mm. labellum obovate, 6-7 x 3.5-4mm, thin-textured, green or brown, constricted near base; margins shallowly scalloped (appearing slightly wavy), with 20-30 spreading bristles circa1mm long; two prominent bristles circa4mm long projecting from near base; basal lobe thin, sloping backwards, with few short bristles. known from only single locality growing in grassland and grassy woodland in freely draining sandy soil. notes fires are relatively frequent where this species grows. dec-jan. ;

Flowers porrect to semi-nodding, 45-55 x 7-9mm, translucent white with green or light brown lines and markings, shiny. Dorsal sepal point filamentous, 15-20mm long, upcurved. Lateral sepals as wide as hood, deeply concave, margins thickened, densely hairy; free points filamentous, 15-30mm long, decurved, parallel or divergent. Labellum obovate, 6-7 x 3.5-4mm, thin-textured, green or brown, constricted near base; margins shallowly scalloped (appearing slightly wavy), with 20-30 spreading bristles c.1mm long; two prominent bristles c.4mm long projecting from near base; basal lobe thin, sloping backwards, with few short bristles. fire: notes although flowering in unburnt bush it is easier to see after summer fires, but may be killed by very hot summer fires.
description: rosette leaves 4-12, elliptic, 15-35 x 12-25mm. flower stem 150-350mm tall, 2-3mm across, 2-12-flowered. stem bracts 6-7. flowers porrect to semi-erect, glabrous, 23-28 x 5-8mm, hood translucent white with green markings, lateral sepals brown with paler areas. dorsal sepal point thickly filamentous, 7-7mm long, upcurved. lateral sepals as wide as hood, shallowly concave, glabrous; free points filamentous, 12-15mm long, deflexed, parallel or divergent. petals with large dark basal flanges blocking off base of opening, 12-13.5 x 3.5mm. labellum oblong-ovate, 4-4.5 x 1.5-2.2mm, dark brown, thick, shallowly channelled; marginal bristles 16-22, 1-2mm long, spreading; basal lobe thick, with few short bristles. highly localised, growing among limestone rocks in shrubby forest with moderately dense understorey in freely draining laterite and limey sand. notes although flowering in unburnt bush it is easier to see after summer fires, but may be killed by very hot summer fires. late oct-dec. ;
original_text: Rosette leaves 4-12, elliptic, 15-35 x 12-25mm. Flower stem 150-350mm tall, 2-3mm across, 2-12-flowered. Stem bracts 6-7. Flowers porrect to semi-erect, glabrous, 23-28 x 5-8mm, hood translucent white with green markings, lateral sepals brown with paler areas. Dorsal sepal point thickly filamentous, 7-7mm long, upcurved. Lateral sepals as wide as hood, shallowly concave, glabrous; free points filamentous, 12-15mm long, deflexed, parallel or divergent. Petals with large dark basal flanges blocking off base of opening, 12-13.5 x 3.5mm. Labellum oblong-ovate, 4-4.5 x 1.5-2.2mm, dark brown, thick, shallowly channelled; marginal bristles 16-22, 1-2mm long, spreading; basal lobe thick, with few short bristles. Highly localised, growing among limestone rocks in shrubby forest with moderately dense understorey in freely draining laterite and limey sand. Notes Although flowering in unburnt bush it is easier to see after summer fires, but may be killed by very hot summer fires. Late Oct-Dec.

fire: fire is an integral part of australian ecology, and many native terrestrial orchids have developed adaptations to cope with its effects. numerous terrestrial species flower profusely in the growing season after a fire, and some even rely on fire to stimulate flowering. for terrestrials, if a fire occurs during the period where the orchid has retreated to an underground tuber, it may be protected - depending on the severity of the fire and the depth of the tuber. however, fires which occur while the orchid is growing above ground or flowering may result in mortality.
description: terrestrial, epiphytic, epilithic or climbing, sometimes mycoheterotrophic, perennial herbs; arising from a creeping rhizome, annually renewed tuber or thickened rootstocks or rhizome; roots often with a spongy layer of velamen. growth monopodial or more commonly sympodial. stems sometimes swollen into pseudobulbs, sometimes bearing adventitious or aerial roots. leaves simple, glabrous or occasionally hairy, often fleshy, usually alternate, often distichous, rarely opposite, well-developed and green or sometimes reduced to scales, usually sheathing at the base (sheath usually closed and encircling the stem), usually not petiolate. inflorescence terminal or lateral, spicate, racemose, paniculate or flowers solitary; flowers bracteate and often resupinate. flowers zygomorphic, usually bisexual, or rarely unisexual in which case plants polygamous or monoecious. perianth of 6 segments in 2 whorls, free or variously fused; outer segments often similar, imbricate or valvate; inner segments usually unequal, median petal modified to form the labellum which often differs greatly in size and shape and may bear calli, hairs, fringes or other appendages. nectary sometimes contained within a spur or sac from the labellum, or rarely from the dorsal sepal. stamens 1 or 2, usually fused partly or completely to the 2 lateral staminodes and the style to form the 'column'; anthers 2-locular; pollen usually aggregated into mealy or waxy pollinia. ovary inferior, 1-celled with 3 parietal placentae, rarely 3-celled. fruit mostly a dehiscent capsule usually dehiscing by 3 or 6 longitudinal slits, or rarely fleshy and indehiscent. seeds numerous and minute, without endosperm, embryo not differentiated, requiring infection by suitable mycorrhizal fungus to germinate and/or grow. see also du puy et al. (1993: 516) and green (1994: 529). orchids are herbaceous plants placed in the monocotyledons, a major subgroup of the flowering plants, which includes the grasses, lilies, aroids, gingers, amaryllids, bananas, pandans, sedges, rushes and palms. monocotyledons only have one seed leaf at germination (unlike dicotyledons, which have two). (jones (2021). for definitions and illustrations on orchid morphology see weber & bates (1986: 2055), weston (1993: 133-134), entwisle (1994: 742), jones (2021: 14-29). see du puy et al. (1993) and green (1994) for orchidaceae treatments for the australian oceanic island territories, noting there will be taxonomic concept and nomenclatural changes since these treatments were published. epiphytic orchids have exposed roots and often prefer areas of high humidity. they are commonly found in rainforest and moist open forest, extending from the coast to high mountain ranges. a few hardy epiphytes grow in drier parts of the tropics that have monsoonal seasons. some species require shade and humidity, preferring to be low on slopes and near streams. others thrive with exposure to sun and wind, occupying the canopies of trees on mountain tops and ridges, or even exposed cliff faces. the greatest abundance and diversity of australian epiphytic orchids occurs in the tropical rainforests of northeast queensland; however, they can also be found in subtropical and temperate rainforests, littoral rainforests and mangroves fringing rivers and estuaries. a few live in the drier scrub of the kimberley, the gulf of carpentaria, cape york and the western slopes of new south wales. large epiphytes usually grow on the trunks and more substantial branches of trees, as they can become quite weighty and require more support. small epiphytes may also be found on main trunks, or further out in the canopy. some tiny specialised species (twig epiphytes) grow almost exclusively on the small branches and twigs of the outer canopy. several epiphytic orchids also grow on boulders, rock outcrops and cliff faces within the forest or along its margins, occasionally in quite exposed situations. terrestrial orchids favour the dry summers and mild, wet winters of temperate regions and are less abundant in the tropics. most terrestrial orchids are deciduous (having a dormant period), and those that grow in the tropics are usually found in areas that experience marked fluctuations in precipitation during the year. terrestrials that live in wet tropical forests are usually evergreen. australian native terrestrial orchids have adapted to a wide range of habitats and soil types. while the greatest diversity occurs in the sclerophyll forests of the south, terrestrial orchids can also be found in coastal swamps, dunes and heathlands; mallee scrub and heathlands; native pine (callitris) and sheoak (casuarina) forests; grasslands; and western australia's sandplain heath. subalpine regions of the southeastern mainland and tasmania support many unique terrestrial species. subalpine habitats include snow gum forests, moist grasslands, high altitude meadows, button-grass plains, moors and fens; a few species even survive in windswept alpine tundra. soils in these cool regions are moist to wet for much of the year. along the tropical and subtropical east coast, a few terrestrial orchids occur in rainforest, while others have adapted to the high tablelands and mountains where the climate is modified by altitude. within a given area, different terrestrial orchid species inhabit different microclimates - some favour exposed slopes and ridges; others grow in shade on sheltered slopes, embankments, gullies and beside watercourses. for details on the biology of orchids see chapter 3 in jones (2021: 30-41). the majority of the world's orchids grow as epiphytes on trees, enabling them to take advantage of the increased light and air movement available in the microclimate of the tree canopy, compared with the forest floor. epiphytic orchids are not parasites; they live independently of the host tree, creating sugars through photosynthesis, and obtaining nutrients from animal droppings, detritus and compounds leached from the bark of the host. rock-dwelling species are known as lithophytes, but it is not uncommon for epiphytes to also grow on rocks if the prevailing climate is suitable for their survival. to cope with harsh climatic conditions, such as regular dry seasons or exposed sites, some epiphytic orchids use a metabolic system known as crassulacean acid metabolism (cam), rather than c3 or c4 photosynthesis. cam allows plants to capture and store solar energy during the day, then complete the process of photosynthesis at night, when humidity is higher and plants are at less risk of desiccation. in contrast, many terrestrial orchids have a dormant period which allows them to withstand unsuitable climatic conditions. the plants die back to a fleshy underground tuber and regrow again when conditions become suitable. some terrestrial orchids are evergreen, with leaves present all year; these generally grow in habitats that are consistently moist. orchids have evolved a wide range of strategies to encourage cross-pollination of their flowers. these include food rewards, food deception (pretending to offer a reward, often by mimicking other flowers) and sexual deception (pretending to be a desirable mate). orchids are pollinated by various creatures, including birds, beetles, moths, flies, ants, bees and wasps. orchids often provide examples of co-evolution, e g between the madagascan endemic darwin's orchid angraecum sesquipedale, with its long flower nectar spur, and a specialised moth-pollinator, with its long proboscis to reach the nectar. several australian native orchids also produce seeds after self-pollination (the seeds are fertilised by the individual's own pollen without the intervention of a pollinator). many native orchids, especially terrestrials, have evolved vegetative (asexual) methods of reproduction, allowing the plants to spread and form colonies. plants that are produced asexually are genetically identical to the parent plant. the seeds of most orchids are  and are usually dispersed on the wind. however, the fruit of rhizanthella species (underground orchids) are unusual; they are called mycoheterotrophs and gain the nutrients they need by parasitising ectomycorrhizal fungi. fire is an integral part of australian ecology, and many native terrestrial orchids have developed adaptations to cope with its effects. numerous terrestrial species flower profusely in the growing season after a fire, and some even rely on fire to stimulate flowering. for terrestrials, if a fire occurs during the period where the orchid has retreated to an underground tuber, it may be protected - depending on the severity of the fire and the depth of the tuber. however, fires which occur while the orchid is growing above ground or flowering may result in mortality. in contrast, epiphytic orchids (which typically occur in wetter forests that rarely burn) are likely to be killed outright if they are burnt. epiphytes rely on seeds distributed from unburnt areas to recolonise burnt habitats. orchids are increasingly threatened by a variety of pressures. these include over-collecting, destruction by feral animals, climate change, and habitat loss or fragmentation due to activities such as logging, construction and agriculture. specialised relationships with pollinators and mycorrhizal fungi make orchids particularly vulnerable because these organisms are also subject to pressures of habitat loss and climate change. the unique biology of orchids and their specialised relationships pose considerable challenges for their conservation. ;
original_text: Terrestrial, epiphytic, epilithic or climbing, sometimes mycoheterotrophic, perennial herbs; arising from a creeping rhizome, annually renewed tuber or thickened rootstocks or rhizome; roots often with a spongy layer of velamen. Growth monopodial or more commonly sympodial. Stems sometimes swollen into pseudobulbs, sometimes bearing adventitious or aerial roots. Leaves simple, glabrous or occasionally hairy, often fleshy, usually alternate, often distichous, rarely opposite, well-developed and green or sometimes reduced to scales, usually sheathing at the base (sheath usually closed and encircling the stem), usually not petiolate. Inflorescence terminal or lateral, spicate, racemose, paniculate or flowers solitary; flowers bracteate and often resupinate. Flowers zygomorphic, usually bisexual, or rarely unisexual in which case plants polygamous or monoecious. Perianth of 6 segments in 2 whorls, free or variously fused; outer segments often similar, imbricate or valvate; inner segments usually unequal, median petal modified to form the labellum which often differs greatly in size and shape and may bear calli, hairs, fringes or other appendages. Nectary sometimes contained within a spur or sac from the labellum, or rarely from the dorsal sepal. Stamens 1 or 2, usually fused partly or completely to the 2 lateral staminodes and the style to form the 'column'; anthers 2-locular; pollen usually aggregated into mealy or waxy pollinia. Ovary inferior, 1-celled with 3 parietal placentae, rarely 3-celled. Fruit mostly a dehiscent capsule usually dehiscing by 3 or 6 longitudinal slits, or rarely fleshy and indehiscent. Seeds numerous and minute, without endosperm, embryo not differentiated, requiring infection by suitable mycorrhizal fungus to germinate and/or grow. See also Du Puy et al. (1993: 516) and Green (1994: 529). Orchids are herbaceous plants placed in the monocotyledons, a major subgroup of the flowering plants, which includes the grasses, lilies, aroids, gingers, amaryllids, bananas, pandans, sedges, rushes and palms. Monocotyledons only have one seed leaf at germination (unlike dicotyledons, which have two). (Jones (2021). For definitions and illustrations on orchid morphology see Weber & Bates (1986: 2055), Weston (1993: 133-134), Entwisle (1994: 742), Jones (2021: 14-29). See Du Puy et al. (1993) and Green (1994) for Orchidaceae treatments for the Australian Oceanic Island territories, noting there will be taxonomic concept and nomenclatural changes since these treatments were published. Epiphytic orchids have exposed roots and often prefer areas of high humidity. They are commonly found in rainforest and moist open forest, extending from the coast to high mountain ranges. A few hardy epiphytes grow in drier parts of the tropics that have monsoonal seasons. Some species require shade and humidity, preferring to be low on slopes and near streams. Others thrive with exposure to sun and wind, occupying the canopies of trees on mountain tops and ridges, or even exposed cliff faces. The greatest abundance and diversity of Australian epiphytic orchids occurs in the tropical rainforests of northeast Queensland; however, they can also be found in subtropical and temperate rainforests, littoral rainforests and mangroves fringing rivers and estuaries. A few live in the drier scrub of the Kimberley, the Gulf of Carpentaria, Cape York and the western slopes of New South Wales. Large epiphytes usually grow on the trunks and more substantial branches of trees, as they can become quite weighty and require more support. Small epiphytes may also be found on main trunks, or further out in the canopy. Some tiny specialised species (twig epiphytes) grow almost exclusively on the small branches and twigs of the outer canopy. Several epiphytic orchids also grow on boulders, rock outcrops and cliff faces within the forest or along its margins, occasionally in quite exposed situations. Terrestrial orchids favour the dry summers and mild, wet winters of temperate regions and are less abundant in the tropics. Most terrestrial orchids are deciduous (having a dormant period), and those that grow in the tropics are usually found in areas that experience marked fluctuations in precipitation during the year. Terrestrials that live in wet tropical forests are usually evergreen. Australian native terrestrial orchids have adapted to a wide range of habitats and soil types. While the greatest diversity occurs in the sclerophyll forests of the south, terrestrial orchids can also be found in coastal swamps, dunes and heathlands; mallee scrub and heathlands; native pine (Callitris) and sheoak (casuarina) forests; grasslands; and Western Australia's sandplain heath. Subalpine regions of the southeastern mainland and Tasmania support many unique terrestrial species. Subalpine habitats include snow gum forests, moist grasslands, high altitude meadows, button-grass plains, moors and fens; a few species even survive in windswept alpine tundra. Soils in these cool regions are moist to wet for much of the year. Along the tropical and subtropical east coast, a few terrestrial orchids occur in rainforest, while others have adapted to the high tablelands and mountains where the climate is modified by altitude. Within a given area, different terrestrial orchid species inhabit different microclimates - some favour exposed slopes and ridges; others grow in shade on sheltered slopes, embankments, gullies and beside watercourses. For details on the biology of orchids see Chapter 3 in Jones (2021: 30-41). The majority of the World's orchids grow as epiphytes on trees, enabling them to take advantage of the increased light and air movement available in the microclimate of the tree canopy, compared with the forest floor. Epiphytic orchids are not parasites; they live independently of the host tree, creating sugars through photosynthesis, and obtaining nutrients from animal droppings, detritus and compounds leached from the bark of the host. Rock-dwelling species are known as lithophytes, but it is not uncommon for epiphytes to also grow on rocks if the prevailing climate is suitable for their survival. To cope with harsh climatic conditions, such as regular dry seasons or exposed sites, some epiphytic orchids use a metabolic system known as Crassulacean Acid Metabolism (CAM), rather than C3 or C4 photosynthesis. CAM allows plants to capture and store solar energy during the day, then complete the process of photosynthesis at night, when humidity is higher and plants are at less risk of desiccation. In contrast, many terrestrial orchids have a dormant period which allows them to withstand unsuitable climatic conditions. The plants die back to a fleshy underground tuber and regrow again when conditions become suitable. Some terrestrial orchids are evergreen, with leaves present all year; these generally grow in habitats that are consistently moist. Orchids have evolved a wide range of strategies to encourage cross-pollination of their flowers. These include food rewards, food deception (pretending to offer a reward, often by mimicking other flowers) and sexual deception (pretending to be a desirable mate). Orchids are pollinated by various creatures, including birds, beetles, moths, flies, ants, bees and wasps. Orchids often provide examples of co-evolution, e.g. between the Madagascan endemic Darwin's Orchid Angraecum sesquipedale, with its long flower nectar spur, and a specialised moth-pollinator, with its long proboscis to reach the nectar. Several Australian native orchids also produce seeds after self-pollination (the seeds are fertilised by the individual's own pollen without the intervention of a pollinator). Many native orchids, especially terrestrials, have evolved vegetative (asexual) methods of reproduction, allowing the plants to spread and form colonies. Plants that are produced asexually are genetically identical to the parent plant. The seeds of most orchids are dust-like and are usually dispersed on the wind. However, the fruit of Rhizanthella species (underground orchids) are unusual; they don't dehisce but develop into fleshy, berry-like fruit that contain comparatively large, hard seeds. These fleshy fruits are probably eaten by truffle-seeking mammals, then the seeds are dispersed in their dung. The minute seeds of orchids lack any nutrients and require inoculation by a mycorrhizal fungus to provide nutrients for germination and growth. An orchid species may associate with just a single fungus species, but some use a range of fungal partners. Some orchids continue to rely on mycorrhizal relationships throughout their lifetime. Several orchid species lack chlorophyll and cannot photosynthesise; they are called mycoheterotrophs and gain the nutrients they need by parasitising ectomycorrhizal fungi. Fire is an integral part of Australian ecology, and many native terrestrial orchids have developed adaptations to cope with its effects. Numerous terrestrial species flower profusely in the growing season after a fire, and some even rely on fire to stimulate flowering. For terrestrials, if a fire occurs during the period where the orchid has retreated to an underground tuber, it may be protected - depending on the severity of the fire and the depth of the tuber. However, fires which occur while the orchid is growing above ground or flowering may result in mortality. In contrast, epiphytic orchids (which typically occur in wetter forests that rarely burn) are likely to be killed outright if they are burnt. Epiphytes rely on seeds distributed from unburnt areas to recolonise burnt habitats. Orchids are increasingly threatened by a variety of pressures. These include over-collecting, destruction by feral animals, climate change, and habitat loss or fragmentation due to activities such as logging, construction and agriculture. Specialised relationships with pollinators and mycorrhizal fungi make orchids particularly vulnerable because these organisms are also subject to pressures of habitat loss and climate change. The unique biology of orchids and their specialised relationships pose considerable challenges for their conservation.

simplified_phrase: killed by fire; flowering enhanced by summer fires
fire: it often flowers better after summer fires but it may also be badly impacted and take several seasons to recover from fire.
description: leaves 2-5, in an erect tuft, 150-300 x 2-3mm, grasslike, channelled. flower stem 300-600mm, rigid, yellowish or blackish, 1-9-flowered. flowers 8-10mm across, usually brownish or blackish, occasionally yellowish-green or completely black apart from labellum. dorsal sepal projected forwards, deeply concave, 9-12 x 8-10mm, strongly hooded over column. lateral sepals erect, outcurved or spreading, terete to terete-spathulate and , 20-25 x 1mm, margins strongly incurved or inrolled. petals hidden within dorsal sepal, 4-5 x 2-3mm, tips blunt or notched. labellum 10-12mm long, 3-lobed; lateral lobes 5-6 x 1.5mm; midlobe strongly recurved, 4.5-6 x 4-5mm, with prominent yellow central patch, margins incurved. column 4.5-5.5 x 3-4mm; column wings narrow, papillate. widespread and often locally common, growing among shrubs, tussocks and sedges in open forest, woodland and heath in a range of soil moisture regimes from freely draining loams in drier sites to moisture-retentive sands and loams; also among grass and sedges in seasonally wet flats to swamps and swamp margins in clay and peat. notes this orchid survives and flowers freely in overgrown habitats. it often flowers better after summer fires but it may also be badly impacted and take several seasons to recover from fire. flowers retain their shape and basic structure long after pollination and old flower stems are recognisable for months after plants have died back. var: this species exhibits variation over its range that is worthy of further study. plants with green or yellowish-green flowers are not uncommon among populations but plants with short b leaves and unusually small green flowers occur in swampy near-coastal areas of nsw (these plants are very similar to strictum forma viride hatch from nz). very robust plants with large dark brown to black flowers with an elongated labellum midlobe occur in dense swamps in otway region, vic. in drier forests of nsw plants often only have 1-3 small flowers with a narrow elongated labellum midlobe and very sparsely papillate column wings. although flowers are self-pollinating, plants with fragrant flowers occur in some areas and may be capable of outcrossing depending on state of viscidium. oct-jan. ;
original_text: Leaves 2-5, in an erect tuft, 150-300 x 2-3mm, grass-like, channelled. Flower stem 300-600mm, rigid, yellowish or blackish, 1-9-flowered. Flowers 8-10mm across, usually brownish or blackish, occasionally yellowish-green or completely black apart from labellum. Dorsal sepal projected forwards, deeply concave, 9-12 x 8-10mm, strongly hooded over column. Lateral sepals erect, outcurved or spreading, terete to terete-spathulate and horn-like, 20-25 x 1mm, margins strongly incurved or inrolled. Petals hidden within dorsal sepal, 4-5 x 2-3mm, tips blunt or notched. Labellum 10-12mm long, 3-lobed; lateral lobes 5-6 x 1.5mm; midlobe strongly recurved, 4.5-6 x 4-5mm, with prominent yellow central patch, margins incurved. Column 4.5-5.5 x 3-4mm; column wings narrow, papillate. Widespread and often locally common, growing among shrubs, tussocks and sedges in open forest, woodland and heath in a range of soil moisture regimes from freely draining loams in drier sites to moisture-retentive sands and loams; also among grass and sedges in seasonally wet flats to swamps and swamp margins in clay and peat. Notes This orchid survives and flowers freely in overgrown habitats. It often flowers better after summer fires but it may also be badly impacted and take several seasons to recover from fire. Flowers retain their shape and basic structure long after pollination and old flower stems are recognisable for months after plants have died back. Var.: This species exhibits variation over its range that is worthy of further study. Plants with green or yellowish-green flowers are not uncommon among populations but plants with short bract-like leaves and unusually small green flowers occur in swampy near-coastal areas of NSW (these plants are very similar to O. strictum forma viride Hatch from NZ). Very robust plants with large dark brown to black flowers with an elongated labellum midlobe occur in dense swamps in Otway region, Vic. In drier forests of NSW plants often only have 1-3 small flowers with a narrow elongated labellum midlobe and very sparsely papillate column wings. Although flowers are self-pollinating, plants with fragrant flowers occur in some areas and may be capable of outcrossing depending on state of viscidium. Oct-Jan.

fire: a study on the role of fire in germinating the annual wild rice oryza meridionalis and threats to its wetland habitats from exotic grass invasions is provided by williams et al.
description: annual or sometimes perennial, caespitose. culms erect to geniculately decumbent, 0.3-2 m high; creeping and fallen stems often tillering and rooting at nodes. leaves: ligule 5-20 (-30) mm long, acute; blade 6-47 cm long, 4-14 mm wide, scabrous on upper surface and margins. panicles 9-30 cm long; primary branches smooth to antrorsely scabrous. spikelets disarticulating, mostly 6.5-10 mm long; pedicel glabrous or sparsely scaberulous. sterile florets: lemma ovate to lanceolate, (1.5-) 2-4 (-5) mm long, acuminate (often longacuminate to aristate) or subulate, glabrous or midnerve and/or margins scaberulous. bisexual floret: lemma mostly obovate, (6-) 6.5-9 mm long, awned, coriaceous to cartilaginous, 5-nerved; lemma awn (30-) 60-150 mm long, terete to subterete; palea (5.5-) 6.5-8 (-8.5) mm long, with awn circa 0.3-1 mm long; anthers 1.3-2.5 (-3) mm long; stigmas blackish purple or brown. caryopsis lanceoloid to oblanceoloid or obloid-ellipsoidal, laterally compressed, (5-) 5.5-7.5 (-8.3) mm long. oryza meridionalis is sometimes treated as a synonym of rufipogon, see notes under that species. these aa genome wild rice species are sometimes distinguished by their panicles: meridionalis often has contracted panicles with branches  appressed (sometimes later spreading) and secondary branching is rare, while rufipogon usually has open panicles (lu & jackson 2004: 17 & 28). grows in shallow or sometimes deeper water, in aquatic to drying conditions, on margins of lagoons, waterholes and creeks, in depressions, temporary pools, drainage channels, grasslands, swamps, including seasonal swamps, often in cracking clay (sometimes in loams and sandy soils) and on floodplains.  a study on the role of fire in germinating the annual wild rice oryza meridionalis and threats to its wetland habitats from exotic grass invasions is provided by williams et al. (2011).  flowers march-june. ;
original_text: Annual or sometimes perennial, caespitose. Culms erect to geniculately decumbent, 0.3-2 m high; creeping and fallen stems often tillering and rooting at nodes. Leaves: ligule 5-20 (-30) mm long, acute; blade 6-47 cm long, 4-14 mm wide, scabrous on upper surface and margins. Panicles 9-30 cm long; primary branches smooth to antrorsely scabrous. Spikelets disarticulating, mostly 6.5-10 mm long; pedicel glabrous or sparsely scaberulous. Sterile florets: lemma ovate to lanceolate, (1.5-) 2-4 (-5) mm long, acuminate (often longacuminate to aristate) or subulate, glabrous or midnerve and/or margins scaberulous. Bisexual floret: lemma mostly obovate, (6-) 6.5-9 mm long, awned, coriaceous to cartilaginous, 5-nerved; lemma awn (30-) 60-150 mm long, terete to subterete; palea (5.5-) 6.5-8 (-8.5) mm long, with awn c. 0.3-1 mm long; anthers 1.3-2.5 (-3) mm long; stigmas blackish purple or brown. Caryopsis lanceoloid to oblanceoloid or obloid-ellipsoidal, laterally compressed, (5-) 5.5-7.5 (-8.3) mm long. Oryza meridionalis is sometimes treated as a synonym of O. rufipogon, see notes under that species. These AA genome wild rice species are sometimes distinguished by their panicles: O. meridionalis often has contracted panicles with branches  appressed (sometimes later spreading) and secondary branching is rare, while O. rufipogon usually has open panicles (Lu & Jackson 2004: 17 & 28). Grows in shallow or sometimes deeper water, in aquatic to drying conditions, on margins of lagoons, waterholes and creeks, in depressions, temporary pools, drainage channels, grasslands, swamps, including seasonal swamps, often in cracking clay (sometimes in loams and sandy soils) and on floodplains.  A study on the role of fire in germinating the annual wild rice Oryza meridionalis and threats to its wetland habitats from exotic grass invasions is provided by Williams et al. (2011).  Flowers March-June.

fire: (1997) note that in western australia oxalis glabra is common on heavy soils, in disturbed woodland, paddock edges, along firebreaks and tracks, and other disturbed sites.
description: perennial herb with erect slender stems 5-30 cm high, 0.4-0.8 mm wide, minutely pubescent; bulb ovoid, acute, 5-9 mm long, tunics smooth, dark brown; bulbils subterranean, formed on slender, delicate rhizomes. indumentum of simple eglandular hairs (rarely glandular on sepals). stipules tapering into petiole. leaves cauline or usually terminally congested, palmately trifoliolate; petiole 4-22 mm long, as long as leaves or exceeding leaves; leaflets sessile, linear, oblong or cuneate, 5-15 mm long, 1.3-2 mm wide, emarginate, often conduplicate, margins ciliate, the lamina bright green or slightly grey green, glabrous, with rather large bli epidermal cells above, and finely papillose below with or without 2 minute apical calli. inflorescences terminal or axillary, 1-flowered; peduncles 20-100 mm long, longer than leaves. bracts situated near or imbricating the calyx, linear-subulate or apex obtuse, 2-3.5 mm long, with scattered ascending, antrorse hairs, with 2 calli near apex. sepals lanceolate or linear-lanceolate, 5-9 mm long, glabrous, rarely glandular ciliate, sometimes indistinctly bicallose at the apex. petals obovate, 15-30 mm long, bright pink, yellow at base, glabrous. stamens at 2 levels; filaments: the longer set sparsely glandular-pilose. ovary pilose on the upper half or near the apex. styles pubescent. capsules not developed in australia.  hussey et al. (1997) note that in western australia oxalis glabra is common on heavy soils, in disturbed woodland, paddock edges, along firebreaks and tracks, and other disturbed sites. in victoria, the species is locally common in weedy mown/slashed nature strips and in degraded grassland on basalt clays at craigieburn. also noted from degraded eucalyptus camaldulensis woodland at somerton. potential invasive weed difficult to eradicate. flowers july-august. ;
original_text: Perennial herb with erect slender stems 5-30 cm high, 0.4-0.8 mm wide, minutely pubescent; bulb ovoid, acute, 5-9 mm long, tunics smooth, dark brown; bulbils subterranean, formed on slender, delicate rhizomes. Indumentum of simple eglandular hairs (rarely glandular on sepals). Stipules tapering into petiole. Leaves cauline or usually terminally congested, palmately trifoliolate; petiole 4-22 mm long, as long as leaves or exceeding leaves; leaflets sessile, linear, oblong or cuneate, 5-15 mm long, 1.3-2 mm wide, emarginate, often conduplicate, margins ciliate, the lamina bright green or slightly grey green, glabrous, with rather large blister-like epidermal cells above, and finely papillose below with or without 2 minute apical calli. Inflorescences terminal or axillary, 1-flowered; peduncles 20-100 mm long, longer than leaves. Bracts situated near or imbricating the calyx, linear-subulate or apex obtuse, 2-3.5 mm long, with scattered ascending, antrorse hairs, with 2 calli near apex. Sepals lanceolate or linear-lanceolate, 5-9 mm long, glabrous, rarely glandular ciliate, sometimes indistinctly bicallose at the apex. Petals obovate, 15-30 mm long, bright pink, yellow at base, glabrous. Stamens at 2 levels; filaments: the longer set sparsely glandular-pilose. Ovary pilose on the upper half or near the apex. Styles pubescent. Capsules not developed in Australia.  Hussey et al. (1997) note that in Western Australia Oxalis glabra is common on heavy soils, in disturbed woodland, paddock edges, along firebreaks and tracks, and other disturbed sites. In Victoria, the species is locally common in weedy mown/slashed nature strips and in degraded grassland on basalt clays at Craigieburn. Also noted from degraded Eucalyptus camaldulensis woodland at Somerton. Potential invasive weed difficult to eradicate. Flowers July-August.

fire: flowering may be promoted by fire (certainly the flowers are easier to see on burnt ground).
description: leaves one or two per shoot, one leaf larger than other, 300-450 x 8-10mm, dark green, pleated, sharply pointed, tapered to long basal stalk. flower stem 300-600mm tall, 4-10-flowered. flowers well spaced, not opening widely, 10-12 x 4-5mm, somewhat tubular, dull pink with yellow tips, externally hairy. dorsal sepal 10-12 x 4mm, margins incurved. lateral sepals 10-12 x 5-6mm, base humped. petals 10-12 x 2.5mm. labellum 10-12 x 6-8mm, curved, 3-lobed; lateral lobes erect; midlobe papillate, apex truncate. callus of three-five bright yellow sinuous ridges. highly localised, growing in seasonally wet grassy patches in woodland and forest, often amongst swards of blady grass - in new guinea known as kunai grass. the leaves of this orchid closely resemble those of blady grass, making the orchid plants difficult to locate. notes observations suggest this orchid may form small clonal colonies. flowering may be promoted by fire (certainly the flowers are easier to see on burnt ground). nov-dec. ;
original_text: Leaves one or two per shoot, one leaf larger than other, 300-450 x 8-10mm, dark green, pleated, sharply pointed, tapered to long basal stalk. Flower stem 300-600mm tall, 4-10-flowered. Flowers well spaced, not opening widely, 10-12 x 4-5mm, somewhat tubular, dull pink with yellow tips, externally hairy. Dorsal sepal 10-12 x 4mm, margins incurved. Lateral sepals 10-12 x 5-6mm, base humped. Petals 10-12 x 2.5mm. Labellum 10-12 x 6-8mm, curved, 3-lobed; lateral lobes erect; midlobe papillate, apex truncate. Callus of three-five bright yellow sinuous ridges. Highly localised, growing in seasonally wet grassy patches in woodland and forest, often amongst swards of blady grass - in New Guinea known as kunai grass. The leaves of this orchid closely resemble those of blady grass, making the orchid plants difficult to locate. Notes Observations suggest this orchid may form small clonal colonies. Flowering may be promoted by fire (certainly the flowers are easier to see on burnt ground). Nov-Dec.

fire: for details on environmental preferences and tolerances (climate, soils, impacts of fire, waterlogging, wind, etc.), growth and development, propagation, genetics and many other features of the species see thomson et al., pandanus tectorius (pandanus) (2006) and references therein.
description: shrub or tree to 8 (-12) m high; prop roots usually numerous, to 1 (-1.7) m long; trunk and prop roots with warty nodules. leaves erect, to 1.5 (-1.7) m long, (5-) 6-10 cm wide, sometimes glaucous; margins usually armed with prickles throughout, sometimes absent towards middle of leaf; midrib often without prickles in lower half, usually prickly above. male flowers: stemonophores with circa 15 stamens; anthers circa 2 mm long. fruiting head solitary, pendent, ellipsoid to broadly ovoid, 15-30 cm long, 10-20 cm diam., with up to 80 phalanges, orange-red. phalanges with (5-) 8-15 (-20) carpels,  globose,  compressed, 3.8-6.5 cm long, 2-6.8 cm wide, (4-) 5 or 6 (-8)-angled,  truncate to convex apically, smooth and  shining on side faces, with sutures absent or sometimes visible in upper part. carpel apices  pyramidal, (0-) 2-6 (-8) mm high,  equal or marginal ones larger; stigmas usually oblique. see also stone (1993: 436), cooper & cooper (2004: 390), thomson et al. (2006).  found in coastal areas, on coral sands and rocky beaches and headlands, or on seaside fringes of forests coming down to the beach. on cocos (keeling) islands occurs on the strand in white, coralline sand (stone 1993: 436). for details on environmental preferences and tolerances (climate, soils, impacts of fire, waterlogging, wind, etc.), growth and development, propagation, genetics and many other features of the species see thomson et al., pandanus tectorius (pandanus) (2006) and references therein. has drift propagules with ability to colonise remote islands (sea-dispersed disseminule illustrated by claussen (2005: 135). the tree is sand and salt tolerant (beasley 2009: 195). the fruit is eaten by palm cockatoos (cooper & cooper 2004: 390). fruits throughout the year. ;
original_text: Shrub or tree to 8 (-12) m high; prop roots usually numerous, to 1 (-1.7) m long; trunk and prop roots with warty nodules. Leaves erect, to 1.5 (-1.7) m long, (5-) 6-10 cm wide, sometimes glaucous; margins usually armed with prickles throughout, sometimes absent towards middle of leaf; midrib often without prickles in lower half, usually prickly above. Male flowers: stemonophores with c. 15 stamens; anthers c. 2 mm long. Fruiting head solitary, pendent, ellipsoid to broadly ovoid, 15-30 cm long, 10-20 cm diam., with up to 80 phalanges, orange-red. Phalanges with (5-) 8-15 (-20) carpels,  globose,  compressed, 3.8-6.5 cm long, 2-6.8 cm wide, (4-) 5 or 6 (-8)-angled,  truncate to convex apically, smooth and  shining on side faces, with sutures absent or sometimes visible in upper part. Carpel apices  pyramidal, (0-) 2-6 (-8) mm high,  equal or marginal ones larger; stigmas usually oblique. See also Stone (1993: 436), Cooper & Cooper (2004: 390), Thomson et al. (2006).  Found in coastal areas, on coral sands and rocky beaches and headlands, or on seaside fringes of forests coming down to the beach. On Cocos (Keeling) Islands occurs on the strand in white, coralline sand (Stone 1993: 436). For details on environmental preferences and tolerances (climate, soils, impacts of fire, waterlogging, wind, etc.), growth and development, propagation, genetics and many other features of the species see Thomson et al., Pandanus tectorius (Pandanus) (2006) and references therein. Has drift propagules with ability to colonise remote islands (sea-dispersed disseminule illustrated by Claussen (2005: 135). The tree is sand and salt tolerant (Beasley 2009: 195). The fruit is eaten by Palm Cockatoos (Cooper & Cooper 2004: 390). Fruits throughout the year.

original_text: Tuberous terrestrial orchids vegetatively and morphologically similar to species of Prasophyllum but reproducing mainly by seed and with a short ovary about as wide as long and projecting at a steep angle out from flower stem. Leaf single, hollow; developing inflorescence breaking through leaf in a similar way to Prasophyllum. Plant size more variable, ranging from short slender species to tall robust plants but none as tall as the imperial species of Prasophyllum from WA. Many species have colourful flowers that open widely and are scented, but some species lack any apparent scent and a few species have flowers that open tardily or remain closed. Floral parts are basically similar in both Prasophyllum and Paraprasophyllum. Lateral sepals free or partially fused, often breaking free, less commonly forming a fused synsepalum. Petals narrow to flared, often broader and more colourful than Prasophyllum. Labellum prominent, often white or colourful; margins often more intensely crisped, crinkled or wavy. Column and pollinarium similar to Prasophyllum. Commonly encountered in well-watered habitats closer to coast and in adjacent inland areas, but a range of hardy species extend into drier, semi-arid regions where rainfall has a critical influence on their growth and flowering. Overall the genus ranges from coast to inland areas and montane and alpine regions, growing in a wide range of forested, shrubby or grassy habitats. Wetter habitats include swamps, bogs, depressions, drainage lines and seepage sites. Growth Cycle: After shedding seeds the plant dies back to a small roundish tuber which remains dormant to avoid summer extremes of heat and dryness. Tuber sprouts after soaking autumn rains and a thin wispy leaf emerges which grows and develops fully before flowering which takes place in spring and summer. A replacement tuber is produced close to parent tuber (which dies). Some clumping or tufting species produce one or more extra daughter tubers close to base of the parent plant. Notes Paraprasophyllum is a large diverse genus that is mainly found in E Australia where it has spread into a wide range of habitats. The larger species which have conspicuous flowers displayed on relatively tall spikes attract the attention of visitors to the bush, but many of the smaller less-showy species are easily overlooked. The common name of leek orchid is shared with Prasophyllum as both groups have a tapered terete leaf resembling that of a leek plant. Flowering is best in wet years, especially for those species growing in drier inland districts. Some species will only flower in the year after their habitat is burnt by a hot summer fire, and the flowering of many other species is enhanced by such an event. Some species also flower in response to habitat disturbance such as mowing or slashing. Molec. Poll. Species of Paraprasophyllum have a similar basic pollination syndrome to that of Prasophyllum making use of a similar range of insect vectors. Several smaller-flowered species however produce capsules and seeds from almost every flower and are either self-pollinating or apomictic (see P. lindleyanum entry and other members of the P. fitzgeraldii group). The flowers of some of these species are strongly scented and attract insects, indicating that some degree of outcrossing is possible. Apomixis might be quite common in some groups of Paraprasophyllum, especially the small-flowered species from areas of low and unreliable rainfall (Bates 1984c). For a summary of the pollination of Prasophyllum sensu lato see Bower (2001b, pp. 189-192). Natural Hybrids: Natural hybrids are generally uncommon in the genus but occur sporadically between some sympatric species growing in close proximity. Systematic Notes Species of Paraprasophyllum are generally difficult to identify and cause problems with casual visitors to the bush and scientists alike. In this book the inflorescence is treated as a spike although in many species the flowers are very shortly stalked (this feature is included in the description where known). As in Prasophyllum, the shape and size of the labellum and callus given in the descriptions are obtained when the labellum is removed and flattened. It is very difficult to estimate the shape of the labellum from a front-on view of the flower because in most species only the apical part of the lamina above the bend in the labellum is visible and the basal part is necessary to obtain an accurate shape and measure. This also applies to the basal part of the callus. Additionally the hidden basal labellum margins are usually entire, whereas the distal margins are commonly irregular or wavy/crinkled/crispate to varying degrees. Systematic Studies: Bates 2015a, Jones 1998e, 2000a, 2018a, Jones & Bates 2017c, Jones & Copeland 2018a,e, Jones & Rouse 2006, 2017, 2018. Arrangement of species: Although three subgenera are recognised within Paraprasophyllum, the vast majority occur in the typical subgenus. This subgenus is here arranged in groups to aid with identification but this is a very complex genus and the grouping is loose. Some species are morphologically similar, others are grouped together based on accessory features such as habitat and altitude. Useful linking features are indicated at the start of each group. Until a comprehensive DNA-based molecular study of the genus is undertaken the true relationships between many of the taxa remains as educated guesswork.

simplified_phrase: flowers without fire; flowering enhanced by summer fires
fire: notes flowers without fire but flowering is enhanced by summer burns, especially in densely overgrown habitats.
description: plants 200-400mm tall. free part of leaf to 100 x 3-5mm. spike 50-110mm long, 5-25-flowered. ovary sessile, green, shiny. flowers moderately crowded to crowded, scented, 14-16 x 7-9mm, green, reddish or brownish, labellum whitish or pinkish, callus green or yellowish. dorsal sepal 7.5-9 x 3.5-4mm, incurved, decurved or recurved. lateral sepals free or fused at base, 7.5-9 x 2-2.5mm, obliquely erect to recurved. petals 7-9 x 1-1.5mm, incurved to spreading. labellum shortly stalked, broadly elliptic at base then contracted into a short pointed tail, 6-8 x 3.5-5mm, sharply recurved near middle then erect. callus broad at base then tapered, deeply channelled, extending nearly to labellum apex. highly localised, growing among shrubs, tussocks and sedges in coastal and near-coastal heathland and heathy forest in freely draining sandy loam. notes flowers without fire but flowering is enhanced by summer burns, especially in densely overgrown habitats. nov-dec. ;
original_text: Plants 200-400mm tall. Free part of leaf to 100 x 3-5mm. Spike 50-110mm long, 5-25-flowered. Ovary sessile, green, shiny. Flowers moderately crowded to crowded, scented, 14-16 x 7-9mm, green, reddish or brownish, labellum whitish or pinkish, callus green or yellowish. Dorsal sepal 7.5-9 x 3.5-4mm, incurved, decurved or recurved. Lateral sepals free or fused at base, 7.5-9 x 2-2.5mm, obliquely erect to recurved. Petals 7-9 x 1-1.5mm, incurved to spreading. Labellum shortly stalked, broadly elliptic at base then contracted into a short pointed tail, 6-8 x 3.5-5mm, sharply recurved near middle then erect. Callus broad at base then tapered, deeply channelled, extending nearly to labellum apex. Highly localised, growing among shrubs, tussocks and sedges in coastal and near-coastal heathland and heathy forest in freely draining sandy loam. Notes Flowers without fire but flowering is enhanced by summer burns, especially in densely overgrown habitats. Nov-Dec.

description: plants 300-400mm tall. free part of leaf to 250 x 4-6mm. spike 70-150mm long, 5-15-flowered. ovary sessile to shortly stalked, green, shiny. flowers well spaced to moderately crowded, sweetly scented, 12-15 x 7-12mm, greenish-red to brownish-red or brown, petals white with central red band, labellum white, callus yellowish. dorsal sepal 8-10 x 2.5-3mm, incurved to decurved, with three fine dark nerves. lateral sepals free, 8-10 x 1.6-2mm, obliquely erect, divergent, falcate, base not humped, apex acuminate. petals narrowly spathulate, 8-10 x 1.7-2mm, porrect to divergent, apex blunt to pointed. labellum sessile, oblong-lanceolate, 8.5-10.5 x 3.5-4mm, sharply recurved at more than right angles near middle, distal part often protruding through lateral sepals, margins strongly wavy/crinkled. callus relatively broad, ovate to elliptic, grooved, ending just past labellum bend, apex notched. restricted and generally uncommon, growing in grassy woodlands dominated by snow gum and banksia integrifolia subsp monticola in rich dark clay loams derived from basalt. notes flowers freely in absence of fire but flowering may also be enhanced following summer fires. in some areas grows with holzingeri which begins flowering as basalticum is finishing. no hybrids have been found. early nov-late dec. ;

description: plants 300-650mm tall. free part of leaf to 200 x 4-8mm. spike 50-120mm long, 8-35-flowered. ovary sessile, green. flowers crowded, lightly scented, 18-24 x 11-14mm, dark greenish-brown to purplish-brown, petals white with green or reddish band, labellum crystalline white, callus yellowish-green. dorsal sepal 10-12 x 4-4.5mm, decurved, with three to five dark nerves. lateral sepals free, 10-12 x 2-2.2mm, erect, widely divergent, pointed. petals 10.5-14 x 1.6-2mm, divergent, white towards apex, margins irregular. labellum sessile, broadly ovate-lanceolate, sharply recurved back on itself from near middle, 12-15 x 5.7mm, distal margins strongly folded and wavy/crinkled, papillate. callus narrow, grooved, ending just past labellum bend, not notched. widely distributed but disjunct and now restricted to remnant patches of vegetation dominated by white cypress pine with sparse groundcover of forbs and weeds in freely draining red sandy loam. notes flowers without fire. easily seen among the sparse vegetation where it grows. sep-nov. ;
