simplified_phrase: flowering enhanced by fire; flowers without fire
fire: notes generally produces an incredible response to hot summer fires, usually flowering en masse the following season and then surviving underground in a mycorrhizal relationship with suitable fungi without flowering for years or even decades until the next fire. as an example, hundreds of thousands of plants flowered in the mountains of the act after the 2003 fires but not a single flowering plant could be found the following spring. at some sites however, often in heath or swampy areas near the coast, plants of this orchid flower regularly without the intervention of fire, although in low numbers.
description: plants 200-500mm tall, green, brownish or blackish. free part of leaf usually short, 20-80(-120) x 4-7mm, often blackish. ovary shortly stalked. spike 80-200mm long, 8-22-flowered. flowers well-spaced to crowded, unscented, 10-14 x 7-10mm, green, dark brown, blackish or purplish, labellum crystalline white, callus green, yellow or whitish. dorsal sepal 6-8 x 3-4mm. lateral sepals usually fused, each sepal 6-8 x 2mm. petals 6-8 x 1.5mm, margins often crinkled. labellum sessile, oblong, sharply folded back on itself, apex often touching base, 6-8 x 3.5-4mm, margins crinkled. callus ending just beyond labellum bend, apex papillate. extremely widespread from coast to mountains and often locally common, growing in many types of forested habitats, shrubland, sedgeland and heath, in moisture-retentive to freely draining sand, peat, clay loam and fertile well-structured loam. notes generally produces an incredible response to hot summer fires, usually flowering en masse the following season and then surviving underground in a mycorrhizal relationship with suitable fungi without flowering for years or even decades until the next fire. as an example, hundreds of thousands of plants flowered in the mountains of the act after the 2003 fires but not a single flowering plant could be found the following spring. at some sites however, often in heath or swampy areas near the coast, plants of this orchid flower regularly without the intervention of fire, although in low numbers. this species exhibits some variation over its range, mainly in vegetative features but the flowers seem to be remarkably uniform. a genetic study over the range of the species may provide surprising results. var populations in higher parts of the snowy mtns with blackish fasciated flower stems, warty ovaries and long densely papillate labellum callus warrant further study. aug-jan. ;
original_text: Plants 200-500mm tall, green, brownish or blackish. Free part of leaf usually short, 20-80(-120) x 4-7mm, often blackish. Ovary shortly stalked. Spike 80-200mm long, 8-22-flowered. Flowers well-spaced to crowded, unscented, 10-14 x 7-10mm, green, dark brown, blackish or purplish, labellum crystalline white, callus green, yellow or whitish. Dorsal sepal 6-8 x 3-4mm. Lateral sepals usually fused, each sepal 6-8 x 2mm. Petals 6-8 x 1.5mm, margins often crinkled. Labellum sessile, oblong, sharply folded back on itself, apex often touching base, 6-8 x 3.5-4mm, margins crinkled. Callus ending just beyond labellum bend, apex papillate. Extremely widespread from coast to mountains and often locally common, growing in many types of forested habitats, shrubland, sedgeland and heath, in moisture-retentive to freely draining sand, peat, clay loam and fertile well-structured loam. Notes Generally produces an incredible response to hot summer fires, usually flowering en masse the following season and then surviving underground in a mycorrhizal relationship with suitable fungi without flowering for years or even decades until the next fire. As an example, hundreds of thousands of plants flowered in the mountains of the ACT after the 2003 fires but not a single flowering plant could be found the following spring. At some sites however, often in heath or swampy areas near the coast, plants of this orchid flower regularly without the intervention of fire, although in low numbers. This species exhibits some variation over its range, mainly in vegetative features but the flowers seem to be remarkably uniform. A genetic study over the range of the species may provide surprising results. Var. Populations in higher parts of the Snowy Mtns with blackish fasciated flower stems, warty ovaries and long densely papillate labellum callus warrant further study. Aug-Jan.

fire: notes flowers freely in absence of fire.

Petals narrowly linear, 7-8 x 1-1.8mm, porrect to divergent, apex pointed. Labellum sessile, oblong-lanceolate, 8.5-10.5 x 4.5-5.5mm, sharply recurved at right angles near middle, distal part recurved but not generally protruding through lateral sepals, margins strongly wavy/crinkled. Callus relatively broad, ovate to elliptic, grooved, ending well beyond labellum bend, apex entire or slightly notched. Highly restricted and rare, growing in grassy woodland dominated by yellow box and blakely's red gum (Eucalyptus blakelyi) with a groundcover of kangaroo grass and snow grass in rich dark loam over basalt. Notes Flowers freely in absence of fire. Mid-Sep-mid-Oct.

fire: flowers freely in absence of fire.
description: plants 50-140mm tall, flower stem sometimes deep red. base of stem red. free part of leaf 50-150 x 1-2mm. spike 10-30mm long, narrow, 3-15-flowered. ovary sessile, humped, prominently swollen, projecting at wide angle. flowers widely spaced, lightly scented or unscented, 3-4 x 2-3mm, yellowish-green to green, sometimes with red tints or red margins on segments, labellum green, callus green or red. dorsal sepal 2-2.5 x 1.2-1.8mm, decurved. lateral sepals fused in basal half then free, each sepal 2.5-3 x 0.8mm, with short blunt tips. petals 2-2.5 x 1.2mm, porrect to spreading. labellum sessile, ovate to ovate-lanceolate, sharply recurved above middle, 2-2.5 x 1.5mm, fleshy, apex recurved. callus broad at base then narrowed, greenish, extending nearly to labellum apex. widespread but restricted to within 10km of coast, growing among leaf litter in sparse coastal scrub and heath in calcareous sand, sand over travertine limestone and red to red-brown loam over limestone. notes generally inconspicuous and the plants, which occur singly or in small groups, are readily overlooked. flowers freely in absence of fire. poll. this species exhibits some variation. flowers short-lived and usually lack any fragrance but may sometimes be lightly scented. some variants may be self-pollinating or even apomictic since the capsules can develop 'seeds' in the absence of pollen (bates 1984c, 1989a), whereas others have functional pollinaria adapted for insect removal. mainly sep (-oct). ;
original_text: Plants 50-140mm tall, flower stem sometimes deep red. Base of stem red. Free part of leaf 50-150 x 1-2mm. Spike 10-30mm long, narrow, 3-15-flowered. Ovary sessile, humped, prominently swollen, projecting at wide angle. Flowers widely spaced, lightly scented or unscented, 3-4 x 2-3mm, yellowish-green to green, sometimes with red tints or red margins on segments, labellum green, callus green or red. Dorsal sepal 2-2.5 x 1.2-1.8mm, decurved. Lateral sepals fused in basal half then free, each sepal 2.5-3 x 0.8mm, with short blunt tips. Petals 2-2.5 x 1.2mm, porrect to spreading. Labellum sessile, ovate to ovate-lanceolate, sharply recurved above middle, 2-2.5 x 1.5mm, fleshy, apex recurved. Callus broad at base then narrowed, greenish, extending nearly to labellum apex. Widespread but restricted to within 10km of coast, growing among leaf litter in sparse coastal scrub and heath in calcareous sand, sand over travertine limestone and red to red-brown loam over limestone. Notes Generally inconspicuous and the plants, which occur singly or in small groups, are readily overlooked. Flowers freely in absence of fire. Poll. This species exhibits some variation. Flowers short-lived and usually lack any fragrance but may sometimes be lightly scented. Some variants may be self-pollinating or even apomictic since the capsules can develop 'seeds' in the absence of pollen (Bates 1984c, 1989a), whereas others have functional pollinaria adapted for insect removal. Mainly Sep (-Oct).

fire: notes flowers freely without fire.
description: plants 300-400mm tall. free part of leaf to 120 x 3-5mm, often yellowish-green or withered. spike 50-100mm long, 10-20-flowered. ovary shortly stalked, pale green, smooth or minutely warty. flowers well spaced to crowded, strongly scented, 16-19 x 9-11mm, whitish-brown to light greenish-brown, sometimes with red or purplish tones, labellum greenish-white, callus green or brown. dorsal sepal 8-12 x 3mm, decurved. lateral sepals free, 7-10 x 1.5mm, erect, widely divergent. petals 7-11 x 1mm, widely spreading, with darker median stripe. labellum sessile, ovate-lanceolate, 6-8 x 3.5-4mm, sharply recurved near middle, distal margins shallowly folded or recurved, lightly crinkled. callus broad, fleshy, raised, extending well past labellum bend. relatively widespread and common on inland plains growing in tussock grassland, woodland dominated by white cypress pine and drier box-ironbark eucalypt forest with sparse understorey in freely draining sand and loam; less commonly among grass and shrubs on rocky outcrops. notes flowers freely without fire. flowers have strong sweet scent. sep-oct. ;

fire: notes flowers freely after fire but absent from unburnt or overgrown habitat.
description: plants 400-700mm tall. free part of leaf to 200 x 3-5mm, erect. spike 80-120mm long, 12-25-flowered. ovary sessile to shortly stalked, green, shiny. flowers crowded, sweetly scented, 15-20 x 15-18mm, greenish brown to brownish, petals white with central pinkish to brownish band, labellum white, callus yellowish green with white margin. dorsal sepal 9-11 x 3.5-4mm, usually decurved, with three-five fine dark nerves, apex subacute. lateral sepals free, widely divergent, 9-11 x 2.5mm, erect, straight, base not humped, margins strongly incurved, apex subacute. petals widely spreading, spathulate, 10-11.5 x 3mm, distal margins irregular to slightly wavy, apex bluntly pointed. labellum sessile, oblong, 10-12 x 4.5-5mm, sharply recurved at right angles near middle, distal part recurved and often protruding through lateral sepals, margins strongly wavy/crinkled. callus relatively broad, ovate-oblong, grooved, ending just beyond labellum bend, apex shallowly notched. highly restricted and rarely seen, growing on upper slopes and ridges in grassy open forest dominated by red stringybark, broad-leaved peppermint (eucalyptus dives) and silver-leaf candlebark (canobolensis) in well-drained basaltic loam. notes flowers freely after fire but absent from unburnt or overgrown habitat. mid-oct-nov. ;
original_text: Plants 400-700mm tall. Free part of leaf to 200 x 3-5mm, erect. Spike 80-120mm long, 12-25-flowered. Ovary sessile to shortly stalked, green, shiny. Highly restricted and rarely seen, growing on upper slopes and ridges in grassy open forest dominated by red stringybark, broad-leaved peppermint (Eucalyptus dives) and silver-leaf candlebark (E. canobolensis) in well-drained basaltic loam. fire: notes flowering strongly enhanced by fire.
description: plants 100-500mm tall. free part of leaf to 100 x 6-7mm. spike 80-120mm long, 10-20-flowered. ovary sessile or shortly stalked, green to brown. flowers moderately spaced, lightly scented, 14-17 x 7-8mm, dark brown, labellum brown, callus dark brownish-green. dorsal sepal 8-9 x 4mm, incurved to decurved. lateral sepals free, 8-9 x 3mm, erect or recurved. petals 7-8 x 1.4mm, porrect, with dark median line. labellum shortly stalked, broadly elliptic at base, 6.5-7.5 x 4.5-5mm, sharply recurved near middle where contracted and tapered to apex, distal margins crinkled. callus shiny, thick, fleshy, extending nearly to labellum apex. highly localised, growing in stunted coastal scrub exposed to winds from sea, sometimes among rocks, and damp heath in sandy loam and shallow stony soil. notes flowering strongly enhanced by fire. late nov-jan. ;

description: plants 300-500mm tall. free part of leaf to 250 x 3-7mm. spike 100-200mm long, 10-35-flowered. ovary shortly stalked, green. flowers well-spaced to crowded, lightly scented, 12-15 x 6-7mm, greenish-brown to reddish-brown, labellum dark red-brown, callus green. dorsal sepal 6-7 x 3-3.5mm, decurved. lateral sepals free, 8-9 x 1.5-2mm, parallel, papillate to warty. petals 5.5-6.5 x 1.3mm, spreading to incurved, blunt. labellum shortly stalked, broadly elliptical, 5-6 x 4.5-5mm, recurved near middle where contracted and ending in short tail. callus broad, fleshy, ending just beyond labellum bend. known from four localities growing in grassland dominated by kangaroo grass on freely draining well-structured red-brown basalt loam and grey sandy loam derived from granite. notes flowers without fire. oct-early dec. ;

description: plants single, 150-300mm tall. free part of leaf to 150 x 3-4mm. spike slender, 60-120mm long, 10-20-flowered. ovary sessile. flowers uncrowded, opening widely, lightly scented, 10-12 x 5-7mm, greenish-brown to pinkish-cream, labellum whitish or pinkish, callus brown. dorsal sepal 4-5 x 2mm, decurved, with three darker veins. lateral sepals erect and recurved, free or fused at base, 4.5-5.5 x 1.2mm, parallel. petals upswept, linear-spathulate, 4-5 x 1mm, widely spreading, pale with faint central band. labellum shortly stalked, porrect to obliquely erect, ovate-lanceolate, 4-4.5 x 2.3mm, sharply recurved near middle then erect, margins entire, folded in to callus near middle. callus fleshy, shiny, shallowly channelled, shallowly folded and transversely ridged, extending nearly to labellum apex. anther warty. highly localised, growing among scattered snow gums in dense grassland, forbs and weeds in heavy brown clay loam. notes flowers without fire. most of habitat has been cleared for agriculture. range may extend into vic around bendoc. late nov-dec. ;

Labellum shortly stalked, porrect to obliquely erect, ovate-lanceolate, 4-4.5 x 2.3mm, sharply recurved near middle then erect, margins entire, folded in to callus near middle. Callus fleshy, shiny, shallowly channelled, shallowly folded and transversely ridged, extending nearly to labellum apex. Anther warty. Highly localised, growing among scattered snow gums in dense grassland, forbs and weeds in heavy brown clay loam. Notes Flowers without fire. Most of habitat has been cleared for agriculture. Range may extend into Vic around Bendoc. Late Nov-Dec.

description: plants 300-600mm tall. free part of leaf to 200 x 4-6mm. spike slender, 100-150mm long, 12-20-flowered. ovary sessile to shortly stalked, green, shiny. flowers moderately crowded, lightly scented, 12-14 x 9-11mm, greenish-brown, petals white with short central brown band, labellum white, callus green to brownish. dorsal sepal 8-10 x 3.5-4mm, usually decurved, with three dark nerves, apex acuminate. lateral sepals free, 9-10 x 2-2.2mm, obliquely erect to erect, widely divergent, falcate, base humped, apex acuminate. petals linear to linear-spathulate, 9-11 x 1.6-2mm, widely divergent, distal margins slightly irregular, apex shortly pointed. labellum sessile, oblong, 8.5-10.5 x 5-5.5mm, base not humped, sharply recurved at right angles near middle, distal part more or less erect, margins finely crenate to crenulate. callus relatively broad, ovate-wedge-shaped, grooved, ending just past labellum bend, apex shallowly notched. highly localised and uncommon, growing among shrubs and tussocks in montane forest dominated by snowgums in moist brown gravelly loam. notes flowers in absence of fire but flowering enhanced following a summer burn. nov-dec. ;
original_text: Plants 300-600mm tall. Free part of leaf to 200 x 4-6mm. Spike slender, 100-150mm long, 12-20-flowered. Ovary sessile to shortly stalked, green, shiny. Flowers moderately crowded, lightly scented, 12-14 x 9-11mm, greenish-brown, petals white with short central brown band, labellum white, callus green to brownish. Dorsal sepal 8-10 x 3.5-4mm, usually decurved, with three dark nerves, apex acuminate. Lateral sepals free, 9-10 x 2-2.2mm, obliquely erect to erect, widely divergent, falcate, base humped, apex acuminate. Petals linear to linear-spathulate, 9-11 x 1.6-2mm, widely divergent, distal margins slightly irregular, apex shortly pointed. Labellum sessile, oblong, 8.5-10.5 x 5-5.5mm, base not humped, sharply recurved at right angles near middle, distal part more or less erect, margins finely crenate to crenulate. Callus relatively broad, ovate-wedge-shaped, grooved, ending just past labellum bend, apex shallowly notched. Highly localised and uncommon, growing among shrubs and tussocks in montane forest dominated by snowgums in moist brown gravelly loam. Notes Flowers in absence of fire but flowering enhanced following a summer burn. Nov-Dec.

fire: flowering promoted by fire and slashing.
description: plants 300-500mm tall. free part of leaf to 150 x 4-6mm. spike 80-120mm long, 15-35-flowered. ovary shortly stalked, bright green. flowers crowded, opening widely, lightly scented, 16-18 x 6-8mm, greenish-white to purplish, labellum green or with pink or mauve tones, callus greenish. dorsal sepal 7-9 x 3-3.5mm, decurved. lateral sepals free, 6-7.5 x 2-2.3mm, nearly parallel, erect or recurved. petals 6-7 x 1-1.2mm, porrect to incurved. labellum shortly stalked, ovate-lanceolate, 6-7 x 3-3.5mm, sharply recurved near middle, base broadest, margins constricted near middle, ending in a narrow tail not much wider than callus, distal margins slightly irregular. callus raised, fleshy, extending nearly to labellum apex. known from only a single locality and less than 50 plants where it grows among dense rushes and sedges in low-lying marshy habitat in heavy clay loam. soil wet when orchid flowers but dries out over summer. flowering promoted by fire and slashing. dec-jan. ;
original_text: Plants 300-500mm tall. Free part of leaf to 150 x 4-6mm. Spike 80-120mm long, 15-35-flowered. Ovary shortly stalked, bright green. Flowers crowded, opening widely, lightly scented, 16-18 x 6-8mm, greenish-white to purplish, labellum green or with pink or mauve tones, callus greenish. Dorsal sepal 7-9 x 3-3.5mm, decurved. Lateral sepals free, 6-7.5 x 2-2.3mm, nearly parallel, erect or recurved. Petals 6-7 x 1-1.2mm, porrect to incurved. Labellum shortly stalked, ovate-lanceolate, 6-7 x 3-3.5mm, sharply recurved near middle, base broadest, margins constricted near middle, ending in a narrow tail not much wider than callus, distal margins slightly irregular. Callus raised, fleshy, extending nearly to labellum apex. Known from only a single locality and less than 50 plants where it grows among dense rushes and sedges in low-lying marshy habitat in heavy clay loam. Soil wet when orchid flowers but dries out over summer. Flowering promoted by fire and slashing. Dec-Jan.

simplified_phrase: flowers without fire; flowering enhanced by summer fires
fire: flowering occurs without fire but is enhanced by summer fires and disturbance such as slashing, especially in dense overgrown habitats.
description: plants 200-350mm tall. free part of leaf to 150 x 5-6mm, bright green. spike 100-180mm long, 12-50-flowered. ovary shortly stalked. flowers not crowded, scented, 9-11 x 6-7mm, bright green, labellum white, rarely pink, callus green. dorsal sepal 6-7 x 2mm. lateral sepals free, 6-7 x 1.5mm, divergent. petals 4-5 x 1.5mm, porrect, white or pinkish. labellum sessile, narrowly ovate-lanceolate, 5-6 x 3mm, porrect and flexed in sigmoid curve, papillate, margins incurved, crinkled. callus narrow, papillate, extending beyond labellum flexure. relatively widespread but disjunct and uncommon, mainly growing in coastal and near-coastal open forest, scrub, shrubby forest, sedgeland and heath in freely draining sands, gravels and clay loam; also in open forest and occasional in moister montane and subalpine forests in well-structured loams. notes this slender, mainly green species, which is easily overlooked, usually occurs singly or in small populations. flowering occurs without fire but is enhanced by summer fires and disturbance such as slashing, especially in dense overgrown habitats. poll. the author has shown that some variants of paraprasophyllum lindleyanum are apomictic in a controlled experiment carried out in insect-proof cages, whereby apparently normal 'seeds' were produced from flowers that had their pollinaria removed early in anthesis. however in contrast, ruiter (2017a) has photographed and collected tiny wasps on flowers of this orchid carrying the orchid's pollinaria on their thorax. sep-dec (-jan). ;
original_text: Plants 200-350mm tall. Free part of leaf to 150 x 5-6mm, bright green. Spike 100-180mm long, 12-50-flowered. Ovary shortly stalked. Flowers not crowded, scented, 9-11 x 6-7mm, bright green, labellum white, rarely pink, callus green. Dorsal sepal 6-7 x 2mm. Lateral sepals free, 6-7 x 1.5mm, divergent. Petals 4-5 x 1.5mm, porrect, white or pinkish. Labellum sessile, narrowly ovate-lanceolate, 5-6 x 3mm, porrect and flexed in sigmoid curve, papillate, margins incurved, crinkled. Callus narrow, papillate, extending beyond labellum flexure. Relatively widespread but disjunct and uncommon, mainly growing in coastal and near-coastal open forest, scrub, shrubby forest, sedgeland and heath in freely draining sands, gravels and clay loam; also in open forest and occasional in moister montane and subalpine forests in well-structured loams. Notes This slender, mainly green species, which is easily overlooked, usually occurs singly or in small populations. Flowering occurs without fire but is enhanced by summer fires and disturbance such as slashing, especially in dense overgrown habitats. Poll. The author has shown that some variants of Paraprasophyllum lindleyanum are apomictic in a controlled experiment carried out in insect-proof cages, whereby apparently normal 'seeds' were produced from flowers that had their pollinaria removed early in anthesis. However in contrast, Ruiter (2017a) has photographed and collected tiny wasps on flowers of this orchid carrying the orchid's pollinaria on their thorax. Sep-Dec (-Jan).

fire: flowering occurs in absence of fire but is reduced or absent in overgrown habitats.
description: plants 300-500mm tall. free part of leaf to 200 x 5-9mm. spike 80-120mm long, 10-40-flowered. ovary shortly stalked. flowers crowded, opening widely, scented, 8-12 x 7-10mm, greenish or light brown with red, pink or mauve tones, labellum white or pink, callus green to brown. dorsal sepal 6-8 x 3.5-4.5mm, incurved. lateral sepals free, 7-9 x 2.5-3mm, erect and incurved, divergent. petals 6-7 x 2-2.4mm, porrect to incurved, often with crinkled margins. labellum shortly stalked, broadly ovate with short  apex, 6-7 x 5-6.5mm, sharply recurved above middle, margins strongly wavy/crinkled. callus broad, raised, fleshy, shiny, often warty, extending just beyond labellum bend. highly localised on stabilised dunes and swales close to sea, growing in or adjacent to coastal scrub, sedgy patches and heath in calcareous sand and seasonally moist sand over red loam. notes flowers sweetly scented. flowering occurs in absence of fire but is reduced or absent in overgrown habitats. dec-jan. ;
original_text: Plants 300-500mm tall. Free part of leaf to 200 x 5-9mm. Spike 80-120mm long, 10-40-flowered. Ovary shortly stalked. Flowers crowded, opening widely, scented, 8-12 x 7-10mm, greenish or light brown with red, pink or mauve tones, labellum white or pink, callus green to brown. Dorsal sepal 6-8 x 3.5-4.5mm, incurved. Lateral sepals free, 7-9 x 2.5-3mm, erect and incurved, divergent. Petals 6-7 x 2-2.4mm, porrect to incurved, often with crinkled margins. Labellum shortly stalked, broadly ovate with short tail-like apex, 6-7 x 5-6.5mm, sharply recurved above middle, margins strongly wavy/crinkled. Callus broad, raised, fleshy, shiny, often warty, extending just beyond labellum bend. Highly localised on stabilised dunes and swales close to sea, growing in or adjacent to coastal scrub, sedgy patches and heath in calcareous sand and seasonally moist sand over red loam. Notes Flowers sweetly scented. Flowering occurs in absence of fire but is reduced or absent in overgrown habitats. Dec-Jan.

fire: notes flowers without fire.
description: plants 300-600mm tall. free part of leaf to 200 x 6-8mm. spike 80-200mm long, 15-40-flowered. ovary shortly stalked, bright green, shiny. flowers crowded, lightly scented, 20-25 x 11-15mm, yellowish-green, brownish or pinkish, labellum pinkish or brownish, callus green. dorsal sepal 9-12.5 x 3-4mm, decurved or recurved. lateral sepals fused partly or fully, each sepal 8.5-13.5 x 1.5-2mm, parallel, recurved. petals 7-11.5 x 0.8-1.1mm, porrect to spreading. labellum shortly stalked, narrowly ovate-lanceolate, 7-11 x 3-4.5mm, sharply recurved near middle, base broadest then tapered or constricted, distal margins slightly irregular. callus fleshy, channelled, extending nearly to labellum apex. localised, growing among shrubs and tussocks in sparse open forest dominated by brown stringybark in freely draining gravelly or sandy loams. notes flowers without fire. nov-dec. ;

fire: notes flowers freely in absence of fire.
description: plants 150-450mm tall. free part of leaf to 120 x 2-3mm, stiff to rigid. spike 80-180mm long, narrow, 15-30-flowered. ovary sessile, green shiny, projecting at wide angle. flowers widely spaced, 8-9 x 4mm, pale green with reddish or purplish markings, labellum green with reddish or purple margins, callus light green (sometimes wholly green flowers with red labellum). dorsal sepal 4.5-5 x 1.8-2.2mm, decurved. lateral sepals fused basally then free, 5.5-6 x 1.2mm, with short terete tips. petals 3.5 x 1.3mm porrect. labellum shortly stalked, ovate, sharply recurved near middle, 3.2-3.5 x 2mm, margins slightly crinkled. callus prominent, extending nearly to labellum apex where very slender. locally common, growing in swamps, seepage areas and seasonally wet flats, often flowering while plants partly submerged. notes flowers freely in absence of fire. sometimes grows in loose clumps or tufts of few to several plants. aug-jan. ;

fire: notes flowering occurs without fire.
description: plants 500-800mm tall. free part of leaf to 200 x 6-8mm. spike 60-220mm long, 12-25-flowered. ovary shortly stalked, green, shiny. flowers widely spaced to moderately crowded, lightly scented, 9-12 x 8-10mm, greenish-brown, petals white, labellum white, callus green. dorsal sepal 7-8 x 3.5-4mm, decurved. lateral sepals free, 7-8 x 2mm, obliquely erect, widely divergent. petals 7-8 x 2mm, widest near apex, blunt, mostly spreading. labellum sessile, narrowly oblanceolate, sharply recurved near middle, 8-9 x 3.5-4mm, distal margins densely wavy/crinkled. callus fleshy, channelled, ending just beyond labellum bend, apex broadly notched. known from only a single locality but locally common, growing in open woodland dominated by large old manna gums with a dense understorey of irongrass tussocks or sagg (lomandra longifolia). soil is well-drained sandy loam. notes flowering occurs without fire. oct-nov. ;

fire: notes more frequently seen after fire.
description: plants slender, 150-320mm tall. free part of leaf to 40 x 3mm. spike 30-70mm long, 5-20-flowered. ovary sessile, short, narrowly obovoid, shiny, strongly ribbed. flowers not crowded, sweetly scented, 6-8 x 7-10mm, maroon, magenta or purple and green, labellum pale purple to maroon, callus dark, glistening. dorsal sepal circa5-7 x 2-3mm, held horizontally, with three brown veins. lateral sepals free, 5-8 x 1-2mm, obliquely erect, strongly recurved, divergent. petals 5-6 x 1-1.5mm, widely spreading, purple-maroon with pale margins. labellum sessile, ovate-oblong, 5-6 x 2-4mm, sharply recurved near middle, papillate, margins irregularly wavy/crinkled, papillate. callus raised, fleshy, glistening, smooth centrally, margins papillate, extending just past labellum bend. localised, growing in fertile soils of inland plains in woodland and mallee-broombush with yellow gum and native pines; less commonly in mallee heath on limestone. notes more frequently seen after fire. late sep-oct. ;
original_text: Plants slender, 150-320mm tall. Free part of leaf to 40 x 3mm. Spike 30-70mm long, 5-20-flowered. Ovary sessile, short, narrowly obovoid, shiny, strongly ribbed. fire: notes flowers without fire.
description: plants 150-350mm tall. free part of leaf to 150 x 2-5mm. spike 60-110mm long, 7-25-flowered. ovary sessile. flowers well spaced to moderately crowded, scented, 10-12 x 7-8mm, pale green to yellowish-green or brownish, sometimes purplish, labellum cream, yellowish or pink, callus green or brownish. dorsal sepal 7-8 x 3-3.5mm, decurved. lateral sepals free or fused, 7-8.5 x 1.4mm, obliquely erect, straight or recurved, parallel, pointed. petals 5-6 x 1.5mm, porrect or spreading. labellum sessile, ovate-lanceolate, surface smooth, sharply reflexed near middle, 4.5-5.5 x 3.5mm, basal margins smooth, distal margins crinkled. callus narrow, raised, shiny, extending nearly to labellum apex. widespread and often locally common growing in grassland, grassy forest, callitris woodland, mallee heath and mallee shrubland in freely draining sands, gravels and clay loam; less commonly on rocky slopes in open forest. notes flowers without fire. flowers abundantly in wet seasons. aug-oct. ;

fire: notes flowers freely without fire.
description: plants 100-200mm tall. free part of leaf to 100 x 3-5mm. spike 40-80mm long, 3-12-flowered. ovaries stalked, turgid, warty (sometimes smooth). flowers well-spaced, lightly scented, 7-11 x 5-8mm, greenish with brown tints, labellum greenish-white or pinkish, callus green. segments thick-textured. dorsal sepal 5-7 x 2.5-3mm, incurved. lateral sepals free, flat, 5-7 x 1.5-2mm, erect to recurved, parallel or slightly divergent. petals 5-6 x 1.5mm, porrect to spreading. labellum shortly stalked, ovate-lanceolate, 4.5-5.5 x 3-3.5mm, sharply recurved near middle, sparsely papillate, margins irregularly crinkled and papillate. callus broad, flat, margins sparsely papillate, extending well past labellum bend. widespread but disjunct, growing in mallee shrubland, broombush and heath in clay loam and red to brown loam over terra rossa limestone. notes flowers freely without fire. has sweetly scented flowers. sep-nov. ;

simplified_phrase: flowers without fire; flowering enhanced by hot summer fires
fire: notes flowering occurs in absence of fire but strongly enhanced following hot summer fires.
description: plants 200-400mm tall. free part of leaf to 250 x 4-7mm. spike 60-100mm long, 10-30 flowered. ovary shortly stalked. flowers moderately crowded, strongly scented, 12-15 x 8-10mm, greenish-brown with white petal tips, labellum white, callus green to yellowish-green. dorsal sepal 9.5-10.5 x 4.8mm, decurved. lateral sepals free, 10-12 x 3mm, obliquely erect, divergent. petals 9-11 x 2mm, porrect or incurved. labellum sessile, narrowly ovate-lanceolate, sharply recurved back on itself near middle, 9-11 x 5-5.5mm, margins strongly wavy/crinkled. callus ending just beyond labellum bend, apex notched. widespread but localised, growing in dense low heath on coastal bluffs, headlands and consolidated dunes in sand and sand over limestone; also in taller heathy coastal peppermint scrub. notes flowering occurs in absence of fire but strongly enhanced following hot summer fires. flowers intensely fragrant on warm to hot days. sep-oct. ;
original_text: Plants 200-400mm tall. Free part of leaf to 250 x 4-7mm. Spike 60-100mm long, 10-30 flowered. Ovary shortly stalked. Lateral sepals free, 10-12 x 3mm, obliquely erect, divergent. Petals 9-11 x 2mm, porrect or incurved. Labellum sessile, narrowly ovate-lanceolate, sharply recurved back on itself near middle, 9-11 x 5-5.5mm, margins strongly wavy/crinkled. Callus ending just beyond labellum bend, apex notched. Widespread but localised, growing in dense low heath on coastal bluffs, headlands and consolidated dunes in sand and sand over limestone; also in taller heathy coastal peppermint scrub. Notes Flowering occurs in absence of fire but strongly enhanced following hot summer fires. Flowers intensely fragrant on warm to hot days. Sep-Oct.

fire: notes flowering strongly enhanced by summer fires.
description: plants 300-800mm tall. free part of leaf to 150 x 4-6mm. spike 60-100mm long, 8-35-flowered. ovary shortly stalked, green, shiny. flowers usually well spaced, lightly to strongly scented, 13-17 x 9-12mm, greenish-brown or pinkish-brown, petals wholly pink, pink with white tip or white with brownish band, labellum white or pink, callus green or yellowish-green. dorsal sepal 8-11 x 3.5-4mm, incurved to decurved. lateral sepals free, 8-10 x 2mm, obliquely erect, widely divergent, pointed. petals 7-9 x 1.2-1.5mm, incurved to divergent, pointed. labellum shortly stalked, oblong-lanceolate, 9-12 x 4.5mm, base slightly humped, sharply recurved near middle, distal part almost touching basal part and protruding through lateral sepals, margins wavy/crinkled. callus narrow, grooved, ending just past labellum bend. widespread but disjunct, growing on slopes and ridges in dry woodland dominated by peppermint box and grey box in clay loam; also in heathy woodland and heath in sandy soils. notes flowering strongly enhanced by summer fires. flowers strongly and sweetly fragrant. this species is poorly understood and the epithet 'odoratum' has been applied loosely to several similar taxa distributed in se australia. a number of these superficially similar taxa described in recent years are included in this book. the detailed description given in this entry applies to odoratum in the strict sense. oct-nov. ;
original_text: Plants 300-800mm tall. Free part of leaf to 150 x 4-6mm. Spike 60-100mm long, 8-35-flowered. Ovary shortly stalked, green, shiny. Flowers usually well spaced, lightly to strongly scented, 13-17 x 9-12mm, greenish-brown or pinkish-brown, petals wholly pink, pink with white tip or white with brownish band, labellum white or pink, callus green or yellowish-green. Dorsal sepal 8-11 x 3.5-4mm, incurved to decurved. Lateral sepals free, 8-10 x 2mm, obliquely erect, widely divergent, pointed. Petals 7-9 x 1.2-1.5mm, incurved to divergent, pointed. Labellum shortly stalked, oblong-lanceolate, 9-12 x 4.5mm, base slightly humped, sharply recurved near middle, distal part almost touching basal part and protruding through lateral sepals, margins wavy/crinkled. Callus narrow, grooved, ending just past labellum bend. Widespread but disjunct, growing on slopes and ridges in dry woodland dominated by peppermint box and grey box in clay loam; also in heathy woodland and heath in sandy soils. Notes Flowering strongly enhanced by summer fires. Flowers strongly and sweetly fragrant. This species is poorly understood and the epithet 'odoratum' has been applied loosely to several similar taxa distributed in SE Australia. A number of these superficially similar taxa described in recent years are included in this book. The detailed description given in this entry applies to P. odoratum in the strict sense. Oct-Nov.

fire: notes flowers without fire.
description: plants 200-400mm tall. free part of leaf to 100 x 1-2mm. spike 50-120mm long, unscented, 10-35-flowered. ovary sessile, slender, green. flowers well spaced to moderately crowded, 5-8 x 5-8mm, cream to greenish-yellow or pale yellow with dark lines, labellum white, callus green. dorsal sepal 8-9 x 2.5-3mm, incurved, apex blunt, often recurved. lateral sepals free, 8-9 x 2mm, obliquely erect, nearly parallel or divergent, blunt. petals linear, 9-10 x 2mm, porrect to spreading, blunt. labellum sessile, elliptic, obliquely erect, 6-7 x 3-3.5mm, sharply recurved near blunt apex, distal margins irregular. callus a broad, central, slightly ribbed band extending three-quarters of way to labellum apex. widespread and common growing in loose groups among shrubs in woodland, on swamp margins and depressions in inland areas and on granite outcrops. notes flowers without fire. sep-oct. ;

Widespread and common growing in loose groups among shrubs in woodland, on swamp margins and depressions in inland areas and on granite outcrops. Notes Flowers without fire. Sep-Oct.

description: plants 200-400mm tall. free part of leaf to 200 x 3-4mm. spike 60-100mm long, 10-30-flowered. ovary shortly stalked. flowers widely spaced, lightly scented, 5-7 x 5-7mm, dark greenish-brown to purplish-brown, labellum pink, callus green. dorsal sepal 4.5-5 x 2.5mm, incurved. lateral sepals basally fused, each sepal 4.5-5 x 1.5mm, erect and recurved, nearly parallel. petals 4.5 x 1mm, porrect to incurved, blunt. labellum shortly stalked, broadly ovate-triangular, 4-4.5 x 3mm, sharply recurved and constricted near middle, then tapered, margins entire. callus basally broad and wrinkled then tapered, fleshy, shiny, extending nearly to labellum apex. widely distributed but disjunct, uncommon and apparently restricted to coastal regions, growing in moist to wet dense coastal heath, coastal scrub and grass-tree plains in sandy loam and peaty soils. notes flowers sparsely in overgrown habitats but is strongly enhanced by summer fires and disturbance such as slashing. this elusive and rarely seen species appears to have disappeared from sites in south gippsland where historical records indicate it was distributed between wilsons promontory and the yarram/port albert district. historical records from far sw victoria (nelson, gorae) require confirmation. oct-nov. ;

Callus thick, fleshy, bulbous, extending nearly to labellum apex. Relatively widespread, growing in a range of sedgy, heathy and scrubby habitats in freely draining or poorly drained sandy and peaty soils. Notes Flowers without fire but flowering is strongly enhanced by summer fires and disturbance, especially in overgrown habitats. Often found growing along edges of tracks and seepage sites on road embankments. Oct-Dec.

Labellum sessile, oblong, 8-9 x 4-4.5mm, sharply recurved near middle, distal margins strongly folded and wavy/crinkled. Callus raised, grooved, ending beyond bend, apex notched. Highly restricted and known from about seven collections in ACT, growing among tall grass and rushes in montane to subalpine swamps in moist to wet loam. Notes Flowers lack any scent. Discovered in 2005 in an area burnt in the 2003 fires; growing close to P. viriosum but no hybrids found. Jan-Feb.

fire: notes flowers without fire.
description: plants 300-450mm tall. free part of leaf to 300 x 3-6mm. spike 80-150mm long, 12-35-flowered. ovary shortly stalked, green. flowers moderately crowded, lightly scented, 10-12 x 7-9mm, greenish-brown to brownish, labellum cream, pinkish or brown, callus green or pink. dorsal sepal 7-9 x 3-4mm, with three darker lines, decurved. lateral sepals free, 7.5-9 x 2.3-2.8mm, widely divergent, tips strongly bidentate. petals 6.5-7.5 x 2mm, porrect to spreading, blunt to pointed. labellum shortly stalked, broadly ovate, 6.5-7.5 x 4.5-5.5mm, obliquely erect, recurved and contracted just above middle, margins strongly wavy/crinkled. callus raised, grooved, extending nearly to labellum apex, with short  apex. restricted to few sites in w victoria growing in moist to wet grassland developed on black basaltic loam. notes flowers without fire. late oct-dec. ;

fire: notes flowering greatly enhanced by fire.
description: plants 200-400mm tall. free part of leaf 200-350 x 7-10mm. spike 50-80mm long, 12-18-flowered. ovary sessile, green, shiny. flowers crowded, scented, 11-14 x 7-9mm, pale green to greenish-brown, labellum white with red to brown tints, callus greenish. dorsal sepal 7-10 x 3-4mm, decurved, sometimes with brown central band. lateral sepals fused basally, tips free, each sepal 7-10 x 2mm, parallel, erect behind labellum. petals 5-8 x 1-2mm, upcurved, spreading, with dark central band. labellum shortly stalked, ovate-lanceolate, 7-8 x 5-6mm, base broad, distally contracted to short,  apex, shallowly recurved near middle, distal margins weakly wavy/crinkled. callus very broad, fleshy, constricted near apex, extending just beyond labellum bend. localised, growing among shrubs in wallum-heath communities and among tussocks on stabilised dunes in sand and sandy loam. notes flowering greatly enhanced by fire. much of habitat has now been cleared or urbanised. aug-sep. ;

fire: flowering and fruiting in passiflora cinnabarina is promoted by fire (ellison 1999).
description: perennial climber to circa 4 m long, with simple axillary tendrils, glabrous. stem terete, slender. stipules linear-subulate, (1-) 3-8 mm long, curved. leaves alternate, 3-lobed for circa one third-two thirds of length; lobes broadest about midway, especially middle one, obtuse to acute, each with a single main vein, sometimes in younger foliage sublobing apparent; lamina (2-) 4-7 (-12) cm long, (2-) 6-8 (-13) cm wide, without glands or with 2-6 small glands scattered on either side of midvein, base truncate to cordate; margin entire; petiole (1-) 2-4 (-6) cm long, without glands. flowers bisexual, borne singly in leaf axils, 4-7 cm diam.; pedicels (2-) 3-5 cm long; bracts 3, filiform, 6-12 mm long, circa 0.5 mm wide. sepals red adaxially, greenish red abaxially, 20-35 mm long, keeled. petals red, 8-15 mm long. corona 2 closely aligned series of filaments, often appearing as one, yellow; outer series 8-15 mm long; inner series 4-7 mm long; operculum whitish, membranous, plicate, 5-6 (-8) mm long, upper margin fimbriate. androgynophore 20-40 mm long, straight. stamens 5. styles 3. fruit an ellipsoidal to spheroid berry, 2-4 cm long, 2-2.5 cm wide, green. seeds reticulate.  often in rocky areas, along rivers in gorges or on disturbed sites among temperate rainforest and sclerophyll forest. flowering and fruiting in passiflora cinnabarina is promoted by fire (ellison 1999). the fruit of cinnabarina is eaten by grey-headed flying fox, pteropus poliocephalus temminck (eby 1995), and the leaves are one of the larval food plants for the glasswing butterfly, acraea andromacha fabricius (braby 2000). flowers september to january and fruits october to january. ;
original_text: Perennial climber to c. 4 m long, with simple axillary tendrils, glabrous. Stem terete, slender. Stipules linear-subulate, (1-) 3-8 mm long, curved. Leaves alternate, 3-lobed for c. one third-two thirds of length; lobes broadest about midway, especially middle one, obtuse to acute, each with a single main vein, sometimes in younger foliage sublobing apparent; lamina (2-) 4-7 (-12) cm long, (2-) 6-8 (-13) cm wide, without glands or with 2-6 small glands scattered on either side of midvein, base truncate to cordate; margin entire; petiole (1-) 2-4 (-6) cm long, without glands. Flowers bisexual, borne singly in leaf axils, 4-7 cm diam.; pedicels (2-) 3-5 cm long; bracts 3, filiform, 6-12 mm long, c. 0.5 mm wide. Sepals red adaxially, greenish red abaxially, 20-35 mm long, keeled. Petals red, 8-15 mm long. Corona 2 closely aligned series of filaments, often appearing as one, yellow; outer series 8-15 mm long; inner series 4-7 mm long; operculum whitish, membranous, plicate, 5-6 (-8) mm long, upper margin fimbriate. Androgynophore 20-40 mm long, straight. Stamens 5. Styles 3. Fruit an ellipsoidal to spheroid berry, 2-4 cm long, 2-2.5 cm wide, green. Seeds reticulate.  Often in rocky areas, along rivers in gorges or on disturbed sites among temperate rainforest and sclerophyll forest. Flowering and fruiting in Passiflora cinnabarina is promoted by fire (Ellison 1999). The fruit of P. cinnabarina is eaten by Grey-headed Flying Fox, Pteropus poliocephalus Temminck (Eby 1995), and the leaves are one of the larval food plants for the Glasswing Butterfly, Acraea andromacha Fabricius (Braby 2000). Flowers September to January and fruits October to January.

fire: fire causes rapid regrowth in passiflora herbertiana (benson & mcdougall 1999).
description: perennial climber to circa 5 m long, with simple axillary tendrils, pubescent or rarely glabrous. stem terete, slender. stipules linear, 1-4 mm long, circa 0.5 mm wide. leaves alternate, 3-5-lobed (rarely not lobed and ovate) for about one third to ½ of length; lobes broadest at base, triangular, acute, sometimes rounded or mucronate, each with a single main vein; lamina 3.5-12 (-15) cm long, (3.5-) 5-13 (-16) cm wide, without glands or with 1-3 (-8) scattered near leaf sinuses, base round to cordate, margin entire; petiole 1-5 (-7.5) cm long, with 2 dark glands (0.5-2 mm diam.) near lamina. flowers bisexual, borne singly in leaf axils, 4-6.5 cm diam.; pedicels 1.5-3.5 cm long; bracts 3, filiform, 1-3 mm long, circa 0.5 mm wide. sepals greenish yellow, yellow or orange, ageing salmon pink, 20-40 mm long, keeled. petals greenish yellow, yellow or orange-yellow, ageing salmon pink, (5-) 8-22 mm long. corona a single series of filaments, yellow, 4-15 mm long. operculum white or yellow, membranous, plicate, 5-10 mm long. androgynophore straight, 15-40 mm long. stamens 5. styles 3 (4). fruit a subglobose to ellipsoidal berry, 2.5-7 cm long, 1.5-4 cm wide, green with pale spots. seeds reticulate.  along the margins of rainforest and in wet sclerophyll forest, often in open or disturbed areas. fire causes rapid regrowth in passiflora herbertiana (benson & mcdougall 1999). the fruit is eaten by grey-headed flying fox, pteropus poliocephalus temminck (eby 1995), and the leaves are one of the larval food plants for the glasswing butterfly acraea andromacha fabricius (braby 2000). flowers may to february and fruits primarily may to march (krosnick 2006). ;
original_text: Perennial climber to c. 5 m long, with simple axillary tendrils, pubescent or rarely glabrous. Stem terete, slender. Stipules linear, 1-4 mm long, c. 0.5 mm wide. Leaves alternate, 3-5-lobed (rarely not lobed and ovate) for about one third to ½ of length; lobes broadest at base, triangular, acute, sometimes rounded or mucronate, each with a single main vein; lamina 3.5-12 (-15) cm long, (3.5-) 5-13 (-16) cm wide, without glands or with 1-3 (-8) scattered near leaf sinuses, base round to cordate, margin entire; petiole 1-5 (-7.5) cm long, with 2 dark glands (0.5-2 mm diam.) near lamina. Flowers bisexual, borne singly in leaf axils, 4-6.5 cm diam.; pedicels 1.5-3.5 cm long; bracts 3, filiform, 1-3 mm long, c. 0.5 mm wide. Sepals greenish yellow, yellow or orange, ageing salmon pink, 20-40 mm long, keeled. Petals greenish yellow, yellow or orange-yellow, ageing salmon pink, (5-) 8-22 mm long. Corona a single series of filaments, yellow, 4-15 mm long. Operculum white or yellow, membranous, plicate, 5-10 mm long. Androgynophore straight, 15-40 mm long. Stamens 5. Styles 3 (4). Fruit a subglobose to ellipsoidal berry, 2.5-7 cm long, 1.5-4 cm wide, green with pale spots. Seeds reticulate.  Along the margins of rainforest and in wet sclerophyll forest, often in open or disturbed areas. Fire causes rapid regrowth in Passiflora herbertiana (Benson & McDougall 1999). The fruit is eaten by Grey-headed Flying Fox, Pteropus poliocephalus Temminck (Eby 1995), and the leaves are one of the larval food plants for the Glasswing Butterfly Acraea andromacha Fabricius (Braby 2000). Flowers May to February and fruits primarily May to March (Krosnick 2006).

fire: flowering may be enhanced by winter fires opening up the habitat.
description: leaves three to five, basal, erect, 30-100 x 7-16mm, dark green. flower stem 150-450mm tall, 3-25-flowered. flowers 9-11 x 12-15mm, white. dorsal sepal 6.5-8.5 x 4.5-5mm. lateral sepals widely divergent 7-9 x 4-4.5mm, horizontal. petals 6-8 x 3.5-4mm. labellum spreading to erect, 8-10 x 4-4.5mm, curved, unlobed or occasionally 3-lobed; lateral lobes (if present) tapered, 0-3 x 1mm, at about 45° to midlobe; midlobe 6 x 3mm, tapered. spur 2.5-12 x 1.2mm, straight or shallowly curved. highly localised, growing in more or less bare patches among low shrubs, forbs and grasses in seepage areas in sparse woodland and wallum in moist to wet grey to white sandy soils. notes most southerly member of genus in australia, occurring some 450km s of its nearest relative. flowers have light to strong tangy fragrance. flowering may be enhanced by winter fires opening up the habitat. jan-mar. ;
original_text: Leaves three to five, basal, erect, 30-100 x 7-16mm, dark green. Flower stem 150-450mm tall, 3-25-flowered. Flowers 9-11 x 12-15mm, white. Dorsal sepal 6.5-8.5 x 4.5-5mm. Lateral sepals widely divergent 7-9 x 4-4.5mm, horizontal. Petals 6-8 x 3.5-4mm. Labellum spreading to erect, 8-10 x 4-4.5mm, curved, unlobed or occasionally 3-lobed; lateral lobes (if present) tapered, 0-3 x 1mm, at about 45° to midlobe; midlobe 6 x 3mm, tapered. Spur 2.5-12 x 1.2mm, straight or shallowly curved. Highly localised, growing in more or less bare patches among low shrubs, forbs and grasses in seepage areas in sparse woodland and wallum in moist to wet grey to white sandy soils. Notes Most southerly member of genus in Australia, occurring some 450km S of its nearest relative. Flowers have light to strong tangy fragrance. fire: notes flowering influenced by early arrival of wet season and possibly also by dry season fires.

fire: reportedly common after fire in limestone country.
description: shrub 0.5-1.0 (-2.0) m high. leaves lanceolate, 80-90 mm long, 10-20 (-25) mm wide, midgreen to dark green; both surfaces smooth, shiny, sparsely hispid; hairs white, 0.2-0.3 mm long, erect or curved, 1- or 2-celled with basal cell conspicuously swollen, separate by (1-) several times their own length. upper stems and involucral bracts with hairs as for leaves. achenes ovate, 5.5-6.5 mm long, 4.0-4.5 mm wide, grey black, weakly keeled abaxially and abaxially, otherwise smooth apart from minute tubercles/hair bases, very shortly and sparsely pilose throughout or just apically; wings red-brown, membranous, spreading entire or lacerate, with a few tiny hairs marginally. found in open situations in spinifex (triodia) hummock grasslands, sandplains, on limestone and dolomite outcrops and stony watercourses, to altitudes of at least 300 m. reportedly common after fire in limestone country. flowers (may-) june-october (-december); fruits august-november (-december). ;
original_text: Shrub 0.5-1.0 (-2.0) m high. Leaves lanceolate, 80-90 mm long, 10-20 (-25) mm wide, midgreen to dark green; both surfaces smooth, shiny, sparsely hispid; hairs white, 0.2-0.3 mm long, erect or curved, 1- or 2-celled with basal cell conspicuously swollen, separate by (1-) several times their own length. Upper stems and involucral bracts with hairs as for leaves. Achenes ovate, 5.5-6.5 mm long, 4.0-4.5 mm wide, grey black, weakly keeled abaxially and abaxially, otherwise smooth apart from minute tubercles/hair bases, very shortly and sparsely pilose throughout or just apically; wings red-brown, membranous, spreading entire or lacerate, with a few tiny hairs marginally. Found in open situations in spinifex (Triodia) hummock grasslands, sandplains, on limestone and dolomite outcrops and stony watercourses, to altitudes of at least 300 m. Reportedly common after fire in limestone country. Flowers (May-) June-October (-December); fruits August-November (-December).

fire: after fire, plants of saccata and comata regenerate vigorously and produce large inflorescences the following summer.
description: erect to spreading shrubs 0.2-1.5 m tall. bark smooth, sometimes flaky towards base. hairs greyish, antrorsely spreading to patent or curly. young branchlets moderately to densely hairy. leaves linear, 5-17 cm long, 0.8-1.4 mm wide, flat with recurved to revolute margins to subterete and grooved underneath, usually slightly incurved, spreading to erect, straight, innocuous, sometimes slightly glaucous, sparsely to moderately hairy when immature, glabrescent, smooth to slightly scaberulous. inflorescence usually auxotelic, 10-90-flowered; rachis 2-45 cm long. flowers subtended by scale leaves and leaves; pedicels 3.5-12 mm long, erect to spreading, moderately to densely hairy; tepals 9-14 mm long, acute to acuminate, moderately to densely hairy on outside; ventral tepal deeply saccate. anthers yellow with white tips; appendage obtuse, 1.2-2.2 mm long, not recurved. in saccata a morphocline runs from north to south, the extremes of which are characterised below. northern populations (wanneroo-lake pinjar area): leaves leathery, subterete, grooved underneath; flowers comparatively small (dorsal tepal 9-10 mm long). southern populations (yallingup-yalgorup area): leaves soft, dorsiventrally compressed; flowers comparatively large (dorsal tepal 12-14 mm long). after fire, plants of saccata and comata regenerate vigorously and produce large inflorescences the following summer. the size of new shoots decreases each year thereafter until the plant becomes senescent and no flowers and only short vegetative shoots are produced. grows in forest and woodland dominated by eucalyptus marginata and/or calophylla or, less frequently, in banksia woodland or forest, in white or grey sand or in gravelly soil. flowers july-jan. ;
original_text: Erect to spreading shrubs 0.2-1.5 m tall. Bark smooth, sometimes flaky towards base. Hairs greyish, antrorsely spreading to patent or curly. Young branchlets moderately to densely hairy. Leaves linear, 5-17 cm long, 0.8-1.4 mm wide, flat with recurved to revolute margins to subterete and grooved underneath, usually slightly incurved, spreading to erect, straight, innocuous, sometimes slightly glaucous, sparsely to moderately hairy when immature, glabrescent, smooth to slightly scaberulous. Inflorescence usually auxotelic, 10-90-flowered; rachis 2-45 cm long. Flowers subtended by scale leaves and leaves; pedicels 3.5-12 mm long, erect to spreading, moderately to densely hairy; tepals 9-14 mm long, acute to acuminate, moderately to densely hairy on outside; ventral tepal deeply saccate. Anthers yellow with white tips; appendage obtuse, 1.2-2.2 mm long, not recurved. In P. saccata a morphocline runs from north to south, the extremes of which are characterised below. Northern populations (Wanneroo-Lake Pinjar area): leaves leathery, subterete, grooved underneath; flowers comparatively small (dorsal tepal 9-10 mm long). Southern populations (Yallingup-Yalgorup area): leaves soft, dorsiventrally compressed; flowers comparatively large (dorsal tepal 12-14 mm long). After fire, plants of P. saccata and P. comata regenerate vigorously and produce large inflorescences the following summer. The size of new shoots decreases each year thereafter until the plant becomes senescent and no flowers and only short vegetative shoots are produced. Grows in forest and woodland dominated by Eucalyptus marginata and/or E. calophylla or, less frequently, in Banksia woodland or forest, in white or grey sand or in gravelly soil. Flowers July-Jan.

fire: intergrades between canescens and pulchella occur where the two species are found together, e g, the central tablelands of n.s.petrophile canescens has been observed to regenerate from a lignotuber after fire.
description: erect shrub 2-3 m tall. branchlets and leaves hoary to silky, glabrescent. leaves 3-11 cm long overall; petiole 2-5 cm long; lamina terete, pinnately divided, not rigid; pinnae usually divided once or twice, acute or obtuse, 2-18 mm long. inflorescence ovoid, terminal, sessile, solitary or in clusters of 2-4, 10-25 mm long; involucral bracts hairy on both surfaces, narrowly triangular, acute; cone scales ferruginous-velvety, glabrescent, broadly ovate, acuminate. flowers 9-12 mm long, white to pale cream, appressed-silky. pollen presenter fusiform, circa 3-4 mm long, with short, ascending hairs. cones ovoid or sometimes globose, 15-40 mm long. nuts circa 3 mm long. intergrades between canescens and pulchella occur where the two species are found together, e g, the central tablelands of n.s.petrophile canescens has been observed to regenerate from a lignotuber after fire. grows in dry sclerophyll forest, sandy heath and eucalyptus forest in sandy soils derived from granite or sandstone. flowers sept.-jan. ;
original_text: Erect shrub 2-3 m tall. Branchlets and leaves hoary to silky, glabrescent. Leaves 3-11 cm long overall; petiole 2-5 cm long; lamina terete, pinnately divided, not rigid; pinnae usually divided once or twice, acute or obtuse, 2-18 mm long. Inflorescence ovoid, terminal, sessile, solitary or in clusters of 2-4, 10-25 mm long; involucral bracts hairy on both surfaces, narrowly triangular, acute; cone scales ferruginous-velvety, glabrescent, broadly ovate, acuminate. Flowers 9-12 mm long, white to pale cream, appressed-silky. Pollen presenter fusiform, c. 3-4 mm long, with short, ascending hairs. Cones ovoid or sometimes globose, 15-40 mm long. Nuts c. 3 mm long. Intergrades between P. canescens and P. pulchella occur where the two species are found together, e.g., the central tablelands of N.S.W. Petrophile canescens has been observed to regenerate from a lignotuber after fire. Grows in dry sclerophyll forest, sandy heath and Eucalyptus forest in sandy soils derived from granite or sandstone. Flowers Sept.-Jan.

fire: this species has been reported to sprout from a lignotuber after fire.
description: erect shrub to 0.8 m tall. branchlets glabrous, glaucous. leaves narrowly obovate, 5-12 cm long overall, 1.5-10 mm wide, usually rather strongly curved, flattened, recurved at apex, obtuse or with a short, straight or curved point, thick, glabrous. inflorescence terminal or axillary, solitary, sessile, ovoid to globular, to 25 mm long; involucral bracts numerous, linear-subulate, glabrous; cone scales broadly obovate, acuminate, glabrous towards apex, hirsute at base. flowers to 3.5 cm long, grey-pink or mauve to almost white, densely villous. pollen presenter 4-5 mm long overall, narrowly turbinate below brush; brush ridged, circa 3 mm long, with short, spreading hairs. cones ovoid, circa 25 mm long. nuts circa 3 mm long. this species has been reported to sprout from a lignotuber after fire. grows in open banksia or jarrah woodland and in low open heath, on sandplains and in laterite. flowers aug.-nov. ;
original_text: Erect shrub to 0.8 m tall. Branchlets glabrous, glaucous. Leaves narrowly obovate, 5-12 cm long overall, 1.5-10 mm wide, usually rather strongly curved, flattened, recurved at apex, obtuse or with a short, straight or curved point, thick, glabrous. Inflorescence terminal or axillary, solitary, sessile, ovoid to globular, to 25 mm long; involucral bracts numerous, linear-subulate, glabrous; cone scales broadly obovate, acuminate, glabrous towards apex, hirsute at base. Flowers to 3.5 cm long, grey-pink or mauve to almost white, densely villous. Pollen presenter 4-5 mm long overall, narrowly turbinate below brush; brush ridged, c. 3 mm long, with short, spreading hairs. Cones ovoid, c. 25 mm long. Nuts c. 3 mm long. This species has been reported to sprout from a lignotuber after fire. Grows in open Banksia or Jarrah woodland and in low open heath, on sandplains and in laterite. Flowers Aug.-Nov.

description: leaf 40-100 x 3-5mm, bright green, sparsely hairy. flower stem 50-150mm tall, very thin and wiry, sparsely hairy, 1-flowered. flowers 25-35 x 30-40mm, bright blue, rarely pinkish, white or yellow. dorsal sepal 12-15 x 4mm, erect or recurved. lateral sepals 10-13 x 4mm, obliquely deflexed, nearly parallel. petals 10-13 x 4mm. labellum 7-10 x 5-6mm, obscurely 3-lobed; lateral lobes erect, entire; midlobe triangular, recurved, dark purple, fringed with slender teeth. calli slender, crowded, in 4-8 rows, of two types, basal ones appearing spiky, distal ones smooth. column 9-11 x 3mm, blue, hairy. widespread and abundant from coast to inland areas, growing in a wide range of habitats including coastal scrub, heath, heathy forest, open forest, woodland and mallee vegetation in freely draining sands and clay loams; also in moss pockets on granite outcrops in wnotes flowers have sweet spicy perfume. often grows in small dense clonal tufts of up to 15 plants. plants flower well in unburnt habitat but flowering can be dramatically increased in the spring after a fire, especially in overgrown heathy habitats. the author counted 10 capsules formed from 15 flowers  circa66% success rate) in a single clump of this orchid at anglesea, vic, in oct 1983. jun-oct. ;
original_text: Leaf 40-100 x 3-5mm, bright green, sparsely hairy. Flower stem 50-150mm tall, very thin and wiry, sparsely hairy, 1-flowered. Flowers 25-35 x 30-40mm, bright blue, rarely pinkish, white or yellow. Dorsal sepal 12-15 x 4mm, erect or recurved. Lateral sepals 10-13 x 4mm, obliquely deflexed, nearly parallel. Petals 10-13 x 4mm. Labellum 7-10 x 5-6mm, obscurely 3-lobed; lateral lobes erect, entire; midlobe triangular, recurved, dark purple, fringed with slender teeth. Calli slender, crowded, in 4-8 rows, of two types, basal ones appearing spiky, distal ones smooth. Column 9-11 x 3mm, blue, hairy. Widespread and abundant from coast to inland areas, growing in a wide range of habitats including coastal scrub, heath, heathy forest, open forest, woodland and mallee vegetation in freely draining sands and clay loams; also in moss pockets on granite outcrops in WA. Notes Flowers have sweet spicy perfume. Often grows in small dense clonal tufts of up to 15 plants. Plants flower well in unburnt habitat but flowering can be dramatically increased in the spring after a fire, especially in overgrown heathy habitats. The author counted 10 capsules formed from 15 flowers (c.66% success rate) in a single clump of this orchid at Anglesea, Vic, in Oct 1983. Jun-Oct.

fire: pittosporum undulatum has a vigorous rhizomatous root system which survives all but the most intense wild fires, and a habit of holding the large leaves of its coppice growth horizontal blocks light for other seeds to germinate.
description: tree 5-13 m high, with a rounded canopy; bark dark grey, fissured, new stems with cuticular ridging, glabrous, grey. cotyledons with glandular and short-base t-shaped hairs, elliptic, circa 14 mm long and 6 mm wide, apices acute, distinctly petiolate. seedling leaves immediately alternate, almost trilobed margins rapidly entire, elliptic to obovate. adult leaves whorled; lamina elliptic, 90-120 mm long, 30-45 mm wide, cuneate, undulate, small drip tip, upper surface glossy green, lower surface paler, both surfaces glabrous; petiole 16-26 mm long. inflorescences terminal, umbels of three flowers, floral axes protected by up to 4 layers of overlapping bracts; pedicels angular, ridged more than about 10 mm long with small, caducous bracteoles. sepals 8-10 mm long, mostly cupular, cohering to the middle but totally separated on one side, then acuminate, spreading recurved, margins hairy. petals almost linear, clawed, cohering in throat, blade recurved, cream, aromatic. male flowers more numerous and generally longer (12-18 mm) than female flower; anthers noticeably exserted, sagittate but with a very shallow basal sinus, yellow; filaments much longer than anthers, tapering from a wide base, white. pistil can appear cryptically perfect with the ovary and style both about 4 mm long, the ovary with nil or few ovules. although dioecious, most male plants produce the occasional fruit. female flowers are fewer (less branching) shorter and fatter (12-14 mm); stamens can range from vestigial staminodes without anthers, to shrivelled anthers barely reaching the style base that may or may not be capable of producing pollen, not exserted. stigma lobed-capitate; style shorter than ovary, thick; ovary fat, globose, hairy, 4-5 mm long, incompletely (tri-) bi-locular with numerous ovules; basal nectary present. fruit a dehiscent capsule, globuse, 10-12 mm long, 10-15 mm diam., orange-yellow when mature, inner yellow; apices heart-shaped; seeds numerous, red-brown, slightly glandular, cohering. declared a weed in victoria. restricting horticultural plantings to just male plants is not a solution as most of these plants also produce occasional fruits; all forms are self-compatible and plants range from dioecious to monoecious. neither the recent morphological nor the dna analyses are informative on the affinities of this species. noticeably the two truly wide-ranging/weedy pittosporum species in australia (undulatum and ferrugineum) both display the full spectrum of sex strategies from unisexual flowers with staminode or pistillode tissue, to perfect and clearly viable bisexual flowers, often in the same inflorescence. hybrids are becoming more frequent between pittosporum bicolor and undulatum as the latter continues its range expansion. pittosporum bicolor has rather narrow elliptic leaves with a persistent indumentum on the undersurface, maroon streaked yellow flowers and black fruits with red seeds. hybrids between these two taxa tend to have bicolor foliage (although wider and often longer), undulatum flowers (complete with vestigial staminodes) and fruits with orange seeds. for an account of pittosporum undulatum on norfolk and lord howe islands, where introduced and escaped from cultivation, see green (1994: 158). in 1956, r.cooper stated that pittosporum undulatum was naturally occurring in marginal rainforest throughout the coastal ranges of southeastern australia. grows in wet sclerophyll to sheltered dry sclerophyll forests and scrubs. this species presents its seeds attractively packaged and cohering for easy bird dispersal; seed production on female trees is enormous. pittosporum undulatum has a vigorous rhizomatous root system which survives all but the most intense wild fires, and a habit of holding the large leaves of its coppice growth horizontal blocks light for other seeds to germinate. this ensures very rapid colonisation, particularly on disturbed sites (gleadow 1982). for details on biology and ecology see mullett (2009) and references therein. peak flowering in spring. ;
original_text: Tree 5-13 m high, with a rounded canopy; bark dark grey, fissured, new stems with cuticular ridging, glabrous, grey. Cotyledons with glandular and short-base T-shaped hairs, elliptic, c. 14 mm long and 6 mm wide, apices acute, distinctly petiolate. Seedling leaves immediately alternate, almost trilobed margins rapidly entire, elliptic to obovate. Adult leaves whorled; lamina elliptic, 90-120 mm long, 30-45 mm wide, cuneate, undulate, small drip tip, upper surface glossy green, lower surface paler, both surfaces glabrous; petiole 16-26 mm long. Inflorescences terminal, umbels of three flowers, floral axes protected by up to 4 layers of overlapping bracts; pedicels angular, ridged more than about 10 mm long with small, caducous bracteoles. Sepals 8-10 mm long, mostly cupular, cohering to the middle but totally separated on one side, then acuminate, spreading recurved, margins hairy. Petals almost linear, clawed, cohering in throat, blade recurved, cream, aromatic. Male flowers more numerous and generally longer (12-18 mm) than female flower; anthers noticeably exserted, sagittate but with a very shallow basal sinus, yellow; filaments much longer than anthers, tapering from a wide base, white. Pistil can appear cryptically perfect with the ovary and style both about 4 mm long, the ovary with nil or few ovules. Although dioecious, most male plants produce the occasional fruit. Female flowers are fewer (less branching) shorter and fatter (12-14 mm); stamens can range from vestigial staminodes without anthers, to shrivelled anthers barely reaching the style base that may or may not be capable of producing pollen, not exserted. Stigma lobed-capitate; style shorter than ovary, thick; ovary fat, globose, hairy, 4-5 mm long, incompletely (tri-) bi-locular with numerous ovules; basal nectary present. Fruit a dehiscent capsule, globuse, 10-12 mm long, 10-15 mm diam., orange-yellow when mature, inner yellow; apices heart-shaped; seeds numerous, red-brown, slightly glandular, cohering. Declared a weed in Victoria. Restricting horticultural plantings to just male plants is not a solution as most of these plants also produce occasional fruits; all forms are self-compatible and plants range from dioecious to monoecious. Neither the recent morphological nor the DNA analyses are informative on the affinities of this species. Noticeably the two truly wide-ranging/weedy Pittosporum species in Australia (P. undulatum and P. ferrugineum) both display the full spectrum of sex strategies from unisexual flowers with staminode or pistillode tissue, to perfect and clearly viable bisexual flowers, often in the same inflorescence. Hybrids are becoming more frequent between Pittosporum bicolor and P. undulatum as the latter continues its range expansion. Pittosporum bicolor has rather narrow elliptic leaves with a persistent indumentum on the undersurface, maroon streaked yellow flowers and black fruits with red seeds. Hybrids between these two taxa tend to have bicolor foliage (although wider and often longer), undulatum flowers (complete with vestigial staminodes) and fruits with orange seeds. For an account of Pittosporum undulatum on Norfolk and Lord Howe Islands, where introduced and escaped from cultivation, see Green (1994: 158). In 1956, R.C. Cooper stated that Pittosporum undulatum was naturally occurring in marginal rainforest throughout the coastal ranges of southeastern Australia. Grows in wet sclerophyll to sheltered dry sclerophyll forests and scrubs. This species presents its seeds attractively packaged and cohering for easy bird dispersal; seed production on female trees is enormous. Pittosporum undulatum has a vigorous rhizomatous root system which survives all but the most intense wild fires, and a habit of holding the large leaves of its coppice growth horizontal blocks light for other seeds to germinate. This ensures very rapid colonisation, particularly on disturbed sites (Gleadow 1982). For details on biology and ecology see Mullett (2009) and references therein. Peak flowering in spring.

fire: killed by fire;
description: herbs, perennial, dioecious, caespitose, the base pubescent in the axils of glabrous cataphylls; cluster roots present. culms unbranched below the inflorescence, erect, compressed, striate, without scabrid edges, glabrous. sheaths persistent, appressed, scarious or membranous with an auriculate apex, the lamina broad, herbaceous becoming membranous; ligule area marked by a change in surface texture but not by a ridge or flap. male and female inflorescences with spikelets at several or many nodes of slender inflorescence branches, erect or the males somewhat pendulous; the branches singly or in clusters at several upper nodes. male spikelets with several flowers and many sterile lower glumes; female spikelets with 1 or several flowers; glumes blunt or acute. male flowers: tepals 6, 2 outer tepals keeled, stamens 3, anthers not exserted. female flowers: tepals 6, 2 outer tepals keeled, ovary 3-locular, style branches 3. fruit a capsule. seeds with irregular pattern of subangular or slightly lobed, flat or slightly convex, isodiametric cells. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2 or 3 layers of short peg cells; interrupted opposite outer vascular bundles by narrow, radially elongated sclerenchyma girders extending from parenchyma sheath to the epidermis; pillar cells absent; central cavity present. the seed surface of slightly convex, isodiametric cells differs from the seeds of chordifex which are mostly colliculate with lines of convex cells, and from the flat rectangular cells of tremulina. reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms. peg cells are pali chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. girders are sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles, extending from the sclerenchyma sheath all or part-way through the chlorenchyma. cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites.  an informative online interactive key to the western australian species of restionaceae, with abundant photographs, is given by hollister & thiele (2014). seasonally inundated heaths and swamps, in peat or sand, on edges of permanent water of streams. killed by fire; regeneration is by seed. wind-pollinated. ;
original_text: Herbs, perennial, dioecious, caespitose, the base pubescent in the axils of glabrous cataphylls; cluster roots present. Culms unbranched below the inflorescence, erect, compressed, striate, without scabrid edges, glabrous. Sheaths persistent, appressed, scarious or membranous with an auriculate apex, the lamina broad, herbaceous becoming membranous; ligule area marked by a change in surface texture but not by a ridge or flap. Male and female inflorescences with spikelets at several or many nodes of slender inflorescence branches, erect or the males somewhat pendulous; the branches singly or in clusters at several upper nodes. Male spikelets with several flowers and many sterile lower glumes; female spikelets with 1 or several flowers; glumes blunt or acute. Male flowers: tepals 6, 2 outer tepals keeled, stamens 3, anthers not exserted. Female flowers: tepals 6, 2 outer tepals keeled, ovary 3-locular, style branches 3. Fruit a capsule. Seeds with irregular pattern of subangular or slightly lobed, flat or slightly convex, isodiametric cells. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2 or 3 layers of short peg cells; interrupted opposite outer vascular bundles by narrow, radially elongated sclerenchyma girders extending from parenchyma sheath to the epidermis; pillar cells absent; central cavity present. The seed surface of slightly convex, isodiametric cells differs from the seeds of Chordifex which are mostly colliculate with lines of convex cells, and from the flat rectangular cells of Tremulina. Reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms. Peg cells are palisade-like chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. Girders are sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles, extending from the sclerenchyma sheath all or part-way through the chlorenchyma. Cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites.  An informative online interactive key to the Western Australian species of Restionaceae, with abundant photographs, is given by Hollister & Thiele (2014). Seasonally inundated heaths and swamps, in peat or sand, on edges of permanent water of streams. Killed by fire; regeneration is by seed. Wind-pollinated.

reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths. peg-cells are pali chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. girders are sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles, extending from the sclerenchyma sheath all or part-way through the chlorenchyma. cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. an informative online interactive key to the western australian species of restionaceae, with abundant photographs, is given by hollister & thiele (2014). heaths and shrublands, in peat or sand, sometimes in standing water in seasonal swamps; original_text: Herb, perennial, dioecious, caespitose, forming dense, small clumps or large tussocks to 25 cm across at base; cluster roots present. Culms erect, straight, compressed or flattened-cylindrical, simple, 70-90 cm long, 1.2-2.5 mm diam., striate, glabrous, yellow-green, with several internodes 7.0-15.5 cm long. Sheaths closely appressed, 2.0-2.8 cm long, striate, glabrous, the lower one third green and herbaceous, the distal two thirds brown and scarious; apex with a central, flattened, truncate, brown, herbaceous becoming scarious lamina c. 5 mm long, bordered by a pair of flat auricles 3-5 mm long, but often weathering away; ligule area marked by a change in surface texture but not by a ridge or flap. Inflorescence short, narrow, 6-14 cm long; females more erect and crowded; male spikelets drooping on short, unequal, branching pedicels arising from axils of spathes at upper nodes; spathes similar to the culm sheaths but shorter. Male spikelets ovoid to spherical, c. 2.5-4.5 mm long, 1.5-2.5 mm wide. Male glumes: 14-18 sterile lower and 5-7 fertile upper, elliptic, 2.5-3.0 mm long, obtuse, smooth, glossy, red-brown to brown, mostly glabrous, the margin often shortly pubescent. Female spikelets similar to males but becoming lax and spreading when mature. Female glumes: 20-25 sterile lower and 5-7 fertile upper; similar to males. Male flowers: tepals 6, narrow-lanceolate, glabrous; 2 outer tepals keeled and the 3rd outer tepal flat, 2.0-2.5 mm long; 3 inner tepals flat, 1.9-2.1 mm long; stamens 3; filaments c. 1 mm long; anthers c. 1.3-1.8 mm long, not exserted; pistillode absent. Female flowers: tepals 6, similar to but more rigid than male tepals, 2.2-3.0 mm long; 2 abaxial inner tepals sparsely pubescent, others mostly glabrous or 2 lateral outer tepals with a few hairs; staminodes 3; styles 3, basally connate and persistent, wholly stigmatic. Capsule trilocular, 1.0-1.5 mm long, 1 mm wide. Seed ellipsoid, c. 0.5 mm long, pale brown. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 2 or 3 layers of short peg cells; interrupted opposite outer vascular bundles by narrow, radially elongated sclerenchyma girders. The seed surface of slightly convex, isodiametric cells differs from the seeds of Chordifex which are mostly colliculate with lines of convex cells, and from the flat rectangular cells of Tremulina. Reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths. Peg-cells are palisade-like chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. Girders are sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles, extending from the sclerenchyma sheath all or part-way through the chlorenchyma. Cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. An informative online interactive key to the Western Australian species of Restionaceae, with abundant photographs, is given by Hollister & Thiele (2014). Heaths and shrublands, in peat or sand, sometimes in standing water in seasonal swamps; sites wet most of the year. Killed by fire; regeneration is by seed. Wind-pollinated. Flowers April, May, September. Seed maturation: 12-15 months. (Meney et al. 1999, Hollister & Thiele 2017).
