original_text: Herb, perennial, dioecious, caespitose, forming dense tussocks c. 20 cm across; base pilose with pale hairs; cluster roots present. Cataphylls similar to culm sheaths but shorter, glabrous. Culms erect, straight, compressed, unbranched, 60-85 cm long, 1.3-2.2 mm wide, striate, glabrous, bright green; internodes few, 8-25 cm long. Sheaths closely appressed, c. 7-15 mm long, glabrous, scarious-hyaline, brown, with narrow-elliptic auricles 5 mm long; lamina 10-15 mm long, 2-2.5 mm wide, truncate, often weathering away; ligule area marked by a change in surface texture but not by a ridge or flap. Inflorescence with short, slender, erect branches at several closely spaced upper nodes; branches bearing several spikelets on filiform pedicels. Male spikelets narrow acute-ovoid, 4-5 mm long; glumes lanceolate, acute, dull tan-brown, glabrous or very shortly ciliate, to 4 mm long, lower glumes shorter. Female spikelets ovoid, 5-7 mm long, 2-3 mm wide, with 9-15 sterile lower glumes and 1 or 2 fertile upper glumes; glumes similar to males; a few of the lowest glumes with a very short, blunt mucro. Male flowers: tepals 6, narrow-lanceolate, hyaline, glabrous; 2 outer tepals keeled, 3-3.5 mm long; 3rd outer tepal and inner tepals flat, slightly shorter; stamens 3; filaments c. 1 mm long, anthers c. 1.3-1.8 mm long, not exserted. Female flowers: tepals 6, concave, glabrous, red-brown with broad hyaline margin, lanceolate, acute, 3-5 mm long; staminodes 3; ovary trilocular; styles 3, shortly connate at the base. Capsule trilocular, c. 1.2 mm long. Seed ellipsoid, c. 0.9 mm long, pale brown. The seed surface of slightly convex, isodiametric cells differs from the seeds of Chordifex which are mostly colliculate with lines of convex cells, and from the flat rectangular cells of Tremulina. Reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths. Peg cells are palisade-like chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. Girders are sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles, extending from the sclerenchyma sheath all or part-way through the chlorenchyma. Cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. An informative online interactive key to the Western Australian species of Restionaceae, with abundant photographs, is given by Hollister & Thiele (2014). Grows on stream banks, in moist peaty sand in sedgeland with tall shrubs; sites constantly moist with considerable seepage through the substrate. Killed by fire; regeneration is by seed. Wind-pollinated. Flowers November.

description: flower stem 200-400mm tall. leaves 12-18, 10-40 x 6-15mm, dark green with pale translucent or yellowish interveinal areas and netted veins. flower erect to semi-nodding, 90-120 x 8-10mm, transparent to translucent with bright green veins and brown to black frontal markings. dorsal sepal point filamentous, 25-35mm long, suberect. lateral sepals deflexed, 60-65mm long; pad dark brown; free points almost filamentous, 48-55mm long, often widely divergent. petals purplish-brown, 40-45mm long. labellum reddish-brown, 25-35mm long, th, shallowly curved; labellum hairs sparse, pale yellow, 5-12mm long; apical knob , 2-2.5 x 0.8mm, thin, dark brown. column 18-22mm long, greenish-white. restricted to small coastal and near-coastal area, growing in banksia shrubland and jarrah/peppermint woodland in freely draining grey sand. notes grows in shrubby habitat that becomes densely overgrown soon after fire, inhibiting flowering of the orchid. late aug-early nov. ;

description: stiffly erect, few-branched, glabrescent annual herb to 50 (-260) cm high. leaves lanceolate to narrowly lanceolate, acuminate to subulate, 10-30 mm long (stem leaves usually shorter than the basal ones), 1.5-5 mm wide. flowers whitish, in terminal racemes 5-20 cm long; bracts and bracteoles subulate, circa 1 mm long, membranous and soon caducous; pedicels filiform, 1.5-2.5 mm long; sepals free, the upper and lower ones narrowly lanceolate, 2-3 mm long, alae (wing sepals) elliptic, 7-9 mm long, 3-3.5 mm wide in fruit, distinctly 3-veined; corolla 4-5 mm long, keel appendages circa 1 mm long and much-branched, lateral petals entire, subequal to keel. capsule obcordate, circa 5 mm long, narrower than sepals. seed obloid, circa 2 mm long, silky, with aril circa 0.3 mm long. capsule and seed morphology, including capsule ornamentation and the seed elaiosome, are provided by aydin (2019). in victoria, recorded from roadside ditches or dry lake beds, sometimes locally abundant (vicflora 2021); in south australia recorded from disturbed grassland, grassy area protruding into swamp, sedgeland swamp, scrub, coastal plain heath, sandy soil in a firebreak, clay soils and swales by roadsides, clay rises under bulloke, roadside remnant native vegetation including a woodland reserve. flowers october-december. ;

Leaves lanceolate to narrowly lanceolate, acuminate to subulate, 10-30 mm long (stem leaves usually shorter than the basal ones), 1.5-5 mm wide. Flowers whitish, in terminal racemes 5-20 cm long; bracts and bracteoles subulate, c. 1 mm long, membranous and soon caducous; pedicels filiform, 1.5-2.5 mm long; sepals free, the upper and lower ones narrowly lanceolate, 2-3 mm long, alae (wing sepals) elliptic, 7-9 mm long, 3-3.5 mm wide in fruit, distinctly 3-veined; corolla 4-5 mm long, keel appendages c. 1 mm long and much-branched, lateral petals entire, subequal to keel. Capsule obcordate, c. 5 mm long, narrower than sepals. Seed obloid, c. 2 mm long, silky, with aril c. 0.3 mm long. Capsule and seed morphology, including capsule ornamentation and the seed elaiosome, are provided by Aydin (2019). In Victoria, recorded from roadside ditches or dry lake beds, sometimes locally abundant (VicFlora 2021); in South Australia recorded from disturbed grassland, grassy area protruding into swamp, sedgeland swamp, scrub, coastal plain heath, sandy soil in a firebreak, clay soils and swales by roadsides, clay rises under Bulloke, roadside remnant native vegetation including a woodland reserve. Flowers October-December.

description: perennial much-branched, densely foliaged shrub to 3 m (rarely to 5 m) high. young stems with short curly hairs, glabrous when older. leaves elliptic to obovate, obtuse and slightly apiculate or rarely slightly retuse, (10-) 15-30 (-50) mm long, 6¢€š¬¢‚¬„¢15 mm wide, glabrous or very sparsely hairy; petiole 1-2 mm long. flowers clustered in short, simple, terminal racemes 4¢€š¬¢‚¬„¢5 cm long, the racemes circa 5-flowered; perianth purple to pale lilac (lower two thirds of keel often contrastingly paler to white), sometimes dense colour restricted to veins on a paler ground; pedicels 5-10 mm long; bracts suborbicular, 1-3 mm long, persistent; 3 outer sepals broadly oblique-ovate, 5-7 mm long; alae (wing sepals) petaloid, ovate-orbicular, (10¢€š¬¢‚¬„¢) 15-17 mm long, slightly longer than corolla; keel circa 10 mm long, bearing a crest of two much-branched appendages 4-6 mm long; outer petals 2-lobed, circa ?-¼ length of keel; keel with a fimbriate crest near apex; style curved. capsule suborbicular, circa 10 mm long, circa 8 mm wide, glabrous. seeds obloid to ovoid, 4¢€š¬¢‚¬„¢5 mm long, dark brown to black, sparsely hairy; aril 3-lobed. polygala myrtifolia is a known or potentially serious environmental weed in several regions of naturalisation, e g south australia, some coastal areas of victoria and norfolk island; see south australian coast protection board (2003), sandercock & schmucker (2006), adair et al. (2012), inkson (2015), weeds of australia (2016), agriculture victoria (2020), and references therein. for an account of polygala myrtifolia on norfolk island, where it probably escaped from cultivation and is potentially a serious weed, see green (1994: 240). polygala myrtifoilia is a declared plant under the landscape south australia act 2019. it is given a 'very high' risk rating as an environmental weed on the advisory list of environmental weeds in victoria (white et al. 2018). roadsides, disturbed sites, grasslands, coastal dunes, wetland margins, riparian areas and open woodlands. the species has an affinity for sandy (especially calcareous) soils, and is tolerant of salt. seeds are reportedly spread by water, ants, birds, wind and by human vectors (earth movement, vehicles, garden refuse dumping). carter et al. (1992) state that polygala myrtifolia does not tolerate grazing, only establishing in areas from which livestock have been excluded; they also report that mature plants are killed by hot fires, but seedling regeneration is rapid, that seeds survive in the soil for two or three years, germinating in may and june (in south australia), that small plants  wa florabase (accessed may 2021) estimates soil seedbank persistence at 1¢€š¬¢‚¬„¢5 years, notes that the species does not resprout or produce root suckers, and undergoes mass soil seedbank germination after fire. eyre peninsula nrm board (2018) however implies that seed longevity in the soil may be over ten years. flowering peak in september¢€š¬¢‚¬„¢october, but can bear flowers at any time of year. ;
original_text: Perennial much-branched, densely foliaged shrub to 3 m (rarely to 5 m) high. Young stems with short curly hairs, glabrous when older. Leaves elliptic to obovate, obtuse and slightly apiculate or rarely slightly retuse, (10-) 15-30 (-50) mm long, 6¢€š¬¢‚¬„¢15 mm wide, glabrous or very sparsely hairy; petiole 1-2 mm long. Flowers clustered in short, simple, terminal racemes 4¢€š¬¢‚¬„¢5 cm long, the racemes c. 5-flowered; perianth purple to pale lilac (lower two thirds of keel often contrastingly paler to white), sometimes dense colour restricted to veins on a paler ground; pedicels 5-10 mm long; bracts suborbicular, 1-3 mm long, persistent; 3 outer sepals broadly oblique-ovate, 5-7 mm long; alae (wing sepals) petaloid, ovate-orbicular, (10¢€š¬¢‚¬„¢) 15-17 mm long, slightly longer than corolla; keel c. 10 mm long, bearing a crest of two much-branched appendages 4-6 mm long; outer petals 2-lobed, c. ?-¼ length of keel; keel with a fimbriate crest near apex; style curved. Capsule suborbicular, c. 10 mm long, c. 8 mm wide, glabrous. Seeds obloid to ovoid, 4¢€š¬¢‚¬„¢5 mm long, dark brown to black, sparsely hairy; aril 3-lobed. Polygala myrtifolia is a known or potentially serious environmental weed in several regions of naturalisation, e.g. South Australia, some coastal areas of Victoria and Norfolk Island; see South Australian Coast Protection Board (2003), Sandercock & Schmucker (2006), Adair et al. (2012), Inkson (2015), Weeds of Australia (2016), Agriculture Victoria (2020), and references therein. For an account of Polygala myrtifolia on Norfolk Island, where it probably escaped from cultivation and is potentially a serious weed, see Green (1994: 240). Polygala myrtifoilia is a Declared Plant under the Landscape South Australia Act 2019. It is given a 'very high' risk rating as an environmental weed on the Advisory List of Environmental Weeds in Victoria (White et al. 2018). Roadsides, disturbed sites, grasslands, coastal dunes, wetland margins, riparian areas and open woodlands. The species has an affinity for sandy (especially calcareous) soils, and is tolerant of salt. Seeds are reportedly spread by water, ants, birds, wind and by human vectors (earth movement, vehicles, garden refuse dumping). Carter et al. (1992) state that Polygala myrtifolia does not tolerate grazing, only establishing in areas from which livestock have been excluded; they also report that mature plants are killed by hot fires, but seedling regeneration is rapid, that seeds survive in the soil for two or three years, germinating in May and June (in South Australia), that small plants  WA FloraBase (accessed May 2021) estimates soil seedbank persistence at 1¢€š¬¢‚¬„¢5 years, notes that the species does not resprout or produce root suckers, and undergoes mass soil seedbank germination after fire. Eyre Peninsula NRM Board (2018) however implies that seed longevity in the soil may be over ten years. Flowering peak in September¢€š¬¢‚¬„¢October, but can bear flowers at any time of year.

original_text: Deciduous terrestrial tuberous orchids growing in clonal colonies, less commonly as scattered individuals. Leaf single, leek-like, thin, hollow, usually pink to red-purple at base. In flowering plants the developing inflorescence grows up inside the leaf and breaks through at a weak point (fistula) in the longitudinal seam of the leaf, leaving the apical lamina free. Inflorescence sparse to dense spike or spike-like raceme, few to multiflowered. Flowers non-resupinate, dull-coloured, usually opening widely, often scented, each flower perched on end of long slender sessile or shortly stalked ovary appressed close to flower stem. Dorsal sepal free, broader than lateral sepals, recurved or incurved and hooding column. Lateral sepals usually fused to form synsepalum, erect behind labellum. Petals free, narrow, more colourful than sepals, incurved or divergent. Labellum immoveably fixed to anterior base of column by short immobile claw. Labellum lamina unlobed, large, conspicuous, recurved near middle, basal margins entire, distal margins strongly wavy or crinkled. Callus a large fleshy plate on upper labellum surface, often wet and shiny (nectar), often different colour to labellum, base sunken or basin-like, central part part grooved or channelled, margins extended like flanges or extra ridges. Column short (not much longer than wide), without basal foot; two erect wing-like lobes flank anther and stigma. Pollinia four, sectile, yellow, attached via a hamulus to viscidium. These orchids commonly grow in areas of reliable rainfall in coastal and near-coastal areas, much less frequently in drier situations further inland. They usually grow among shrubs, grasses and sedges in heath, forests, woodlands, shrublands, swamps, bogs, depressions, drainage lines and seepage sites. Ecology: Flowering in all species is enhanced following a summer fire. Some species, especially from WA, are totally dependant on fire to induce flowering. A few species will flower after mowing, slashing or grading. Growth Cycle: After shedding seeds the plant dies back to a small roundish tuber which remains dormant to avoid summer extremes of heat and dryness. The tuber sprouts after soaking autumn rains and a leaf emerges which grows and develops fully before flowering which takes place mainly in spring and summer, rarely winter. A replacement tuber is produced close to the parent tuber (which dies). Most species also produce daughter tubers on the end of long stolonoid roots. Notes The common name of leek orchid is apt as the plants have a tapered terete leaf resembling that of a leek plant. The genus includes the tallest of the Australian terrestrial orchids with some plants exceeding 2m in height and with up to 100 flowers. Prasophyllum elatum and P. fimbria begin flowering in winter, others are spring or summer flowering. Poll. Species of Prasophyllum and Paraprasophyllum produce dense spikes of colourful, sweetly scented flowers that reward visiting insects with a feed of nectar. The nectar, produced from the callus, is evident as droplets and smears on the surface of the callus and accumulates in the bowl-like base of the labellum. The flowers are visited by a range of native insects including bees (Halictidae, Colletidae, Megachilidae), wasps (Argidae, Scoliidae, Ichneumonidae, Sphecidae, Thynninae), flies (Syrphidae) and beetles (Chrysomelidae, Curculionidae, Dermestidae, Staphylidinae). Specific pollination relationships in the genus seem to be rare or absent, rather a range of local insects can effect pollination. The insects move headfirst into the flower when feeding on the nectar and work the inflorescence, travelling from flower to flower. The pollinaria are mostly picked up on the head, often on or close to the mouthparts. Larger insects often carry several pollinaria at one time and sometimes residual viscidia can be observed still attached to the insect after the pollinia are lost. Occasionally a whole pollinarium is deposited on a stigma by an insect but mostly small clumps of pollen adhere to the stigma when the pollinarium is brushed against it during an insect's visit. Often pollinaria can be found attached to parts of the flowers and the stems after being brushed off during grooming by an annoyed or overloaded insect. A wide range of insects that are too small to effect pollination also visit the flowers to feed on the nectar and sometimes become stuck in the stigma. Individual pollination studies, mostly detailed as Prasophyllum sensu lato, include Coleman (1933a), Jones (1972b), Bates (1984d), Bernhardt & Burns-Balogh (1986b). For an excellent detailed summary of Prasophyllum pollination see Bower (2001b, pp. 189-192). For photos of insects visiting the flowers of various species of Paraprasophyllum (as Prasophyllum) see Kuiter (2013, pp. 68-69, 2017a, pp 8-35). Natural Hybrids: Natural hybrids are generally rare in the genus but occur sporadically between some species, usually in sites that have been disturbed in some way. Arrangement of species: Species of Prasophyllum can be difficult to identify and where possible, related or similar-looking species have been grouped together to aid with identification. The shapes and measurements of the labellum and callus given in the descriptions are obtained when the labellum is removed and flattened. It is very difficult to estimate the shape and size of the labellum from a front-on view while it is attached to the flower, because in most species only the apical part of the lamina above the bend in the labellum is visible and the basal part is necessary to obtain an accurate shape and true measure of size. This also applies to the basal part of the callus. Additionally the hidden basal labellum margins are usually entire, whereas the distal margins are commonly irregular or wavy/crinkled/crispate to varying degrees. Useful linking features are indicated in bold at the start of each group. GROUP 1: WHITE-LIPPED SPECIES Ovaries elongated, linear-oblong, much longer than wide, held flat against flower stem; labellum white.

simplified_phrase: flowering enhanced by summer fires; flowers without fire
fire: notes flowering, which occurs sporadically in absence of fire, is strongly enhanced by summer fires and disturbance such as slashing.
description: plants 600-900mm tall. free part of leaf to 350 x 7-10mm. spike 100-180mm long, 10-60-flowered. ovary sessile, long, green, appressed to stem. flowers well-spaced to crowded, strongly scented, 16-20 x 12-15mm, greenish, yellowish or brownish with reddish stripes, labellum lamina crystalline white, callus yellowish-green. dorsal sepal 8-10 x 3-4mm, decurved. lateral sepals erect, usually fused, each sepal 8-10 x 3mm. petals 6-8 x 3mm, spreading or incurved. labellum sessile, sharply recurved near middle, 8-11 x 2.5-4mm, margins intensely wavy/crinkled. callus raised, channelled, extending well past labellum bend, ending in two raised bumps. widespread and common growing in a wide range of habitats including open forest, woodland, bogs, swamps and swamp margins, heathland, sedgeland, buttongrass moorland and grassland in seasonally moist to wet sandy soils, clays and peat. notes flowering, which occurs sporadically in absence of fire, is strongly enhanced by summer fires and disturbance such as slashing. historical note: first collected by david nelson, naturalist on board the discovery on captain james cook's third voyage to the pacific. cook's ships, resolution and discovery, anchored at adventure bay on bruny is., tas, in late jan 1777. the orchid was found during a collecting trip ashore. the specimens collected by nelson were later described by robert brown as prasophyllum australe and later selected as the type for the genus prasophyllum (clements 1989). oct-jan. ;
original_text: Plants 600-900mm tall. Free part of leaf to 350 x 7-10mm. Spike 100-180mm long, 10-60-flowered. Ovary sessile, long, green, appressed to stem. Flowers well-spaced to crowded, strongly scented, 16-20 x 12-15mm, greenish, yellowish or brownish with reddish stripes, labellum lamina crystalline white, callus yellowish-green. Dorsal sepal 8-10 x 3-4mm, decurved. Lateral sepals erect, usually fused, each sepal 8-10 x 3mm. Petals 6-8 x 3mm, spreading or incurved. Labellum sessile, sharply recurved near middle, 8-11 x 2.5-4mm, margins intensely wavy/crinkled. Callus raised, channelled, extending well past labellum bend, ending in two raised bumps. Widespread and common growing in a wide range of habitats including open forest, woodland, bogs, swamps and swamp margins, heathland, sedgeland, buttongrass moorland and grassland in seasonally moist to wet sandy soils, clays and peat. Notes Flowering, which occurs sporadically in absence of fire, is strongly enhanced by summer fires and disturbance such as slashing. Historical note: First collected by David Nelson, naturalist on board the Discovery on Captain James Cook's third voyage to the Pacific. Cook's ships, Resolution and Discovery, anchored at Adventure Bay on Bruny Is., Tas, in late Jan 1777. The orchid was found during a collecting trip ashore. The specimens collected by Nelson were later described by Robert Brown as Prasophyllum australe and later selected as the type for the genus Prasophyllum (Clements 1989). Oct-Jan.

simplified_phrase: flowering enhanced by hot summer fires
fire: notes flowering is greatly enhanced by hot summer fires.
description: plants 500-1,200mm tall. free part of leaf to 220 x 7-10mm. spike 100-180mm long, 30-90-flowered. ovary sessile, long, green, appressed. flowers crowded, scented, 16-20 x 12-15mm, pale green to tan with brown stripes, labellum lamina white, callus green. dorsal sepal 8-10 x 4-5mm, curved forwards. lateral sepals fused (base and tips free), erect behind labellum, each sepal 9-11 x 2-2.5mm, margins incurved. petals 7-9 x 2-2.5mm, incurved or obliquely erect. labellum shortly stalked, elliptic, gently recurved near middle, 9-11.5 x 7-8.5mm, margins wavy/crinkled. callus broad, extending well past labellum bend. relatively widespread and locally common growing in swamps, seasonally wet flats and also among shrubs and heath in high-rainfall forest in freely draining soil. notes flowering is greatly enhanced by hot summer fires. nov-jan. ;
original_text: Plants 500-1,200mm tall. Free part of leaf to 220 x 7-10mm. Spike 100-180mm long, 30-90-flowered. Ovary sessile, long, green, appressed. Flowers crowded, scented, 16-20 x 12-15mm, pale green to tan with brown stripes, labellum lamina white, callus green. Dorsal sepal 8-10 x 4-5mm, curved forwards. Lateral sepals fused (base and tips free), erect behind labellum, each sepal 9-11 x 2-2.5mm, margins incurved. Petals 7-9 x 2-2.5mm, incurved or obliquely erect. Labellum shortly stalked, elliptic, gently recurved near middle, 9-11.5 x 7-8.5mm, margins wavy/crinkled. Callus broad, extending well past labellum bend. Relatively widespread and locally common growing in swamps, seasonally wet flats and also among shrubs and heath in high-rainfall forest in freely draining soil. Notes Flowering is greatly enhanced by hot summer fires. Nov-Jan.

fire: notes forms vegetative colonies and flowers only after fire.

simplified_phrase: flowering enhanced by hot summer fires
fire: notes individual plants or small groups can be found in unburnt habitat but mass flowering is common after hot summer fires.
description: robust species. whole plants often blackish, 800-1,600mm tall. free part of leaf to 200 x 10-15mm, green to brown or often blackish. spike 190-400mm long, 15-60(-100)-flowered. ovary sessile, long, green to brown or often blackish, appressed to stem. flowers crowded, scented, 10-15 x 7-10mm, yellow, yellowish-green, brownish or purplish (sometimes wholly dark purple), labellum lamina white, mauve or pink, callus green to yellowish-green. dorsal sepal 8-11 x 3-5mm, decurved to incurved. lateral sepals fused, each sepal 8-11 x 3-4mm, erect behind labellum. petals 7-9 x 2.5mm, spreading. labellum shortly stalked, recurved gently near middle, 8-9 x 6mm, margins intensely wavy/crinkled. callus broad, narrowing distally, extending nearly to labellum apex, margins ridged or raised. a very widespread and common orchid that grows in a wide range of habitats from coast to inland areas including open forest, woodland, heathy woodland, mallee shrubland, mallee heath, buttongrass moorland, swamp margins, sedgeland, coastal heath, grassy headlands and rock outcrops in freely draining to seasonally moist sands, gravels, peats and loams. notes individual plants or small groups can be found in unburnt habitat but mass flowering is common after hot summer fires. flowering is also promoted by disturbance such as mowing or slashing. plants in burnt habitats often blackish and resemble burnt sticks which may help to avoid predation by herbivores (a ploy that is not always successful). var: this very widespread species exhibits variation in floral features that is worthy of further study. variants with yellow flowers occur in several parts of southern australia. a preliminary dna-based phylogenetic study showed populations from wa to be distinct from those of e states (see macrotys entry) aug-jan. ;
original_text: Robust species. Whole plants often blackish, 800-1,600mm tall. Free part of leaf to 200 x 10-15mm, green to brown or often blackish. Spike 190-400mm long, 15-60(-100)-flowered. Ovary sessile, long, green to brown or often blackish, appressed to stem. Flowers crowded, scented, 10-15 x 7-10mm, yellow, yellowish-green, brownish or purplish (sometimes wholly dark purple), labellum lamina white, mauve or pink, callus green to yellowish-green. Dorsal sepal 8-11 x 3-5mm, decurved to incurved. Lateral sepals fused, each sepal 8-11 x 3-4mm, erect behind labellum. Petals 7-9 x 2.5mm, spreading. Labellum shortly stalked, recurved gently near middle, 8-9 x 6mm, margins intensely wavy/crinkled. Callus broad, narrowing distally, extending nearly to labellum apex, margins ridged or raised. A very widespread and common orchid that grows in a wide range of habitats from coast to inland areas including open forest, woodland, heathy woodland, mallee shrubland, mallee heath, buttongrass moorland, swamp margins, sedgeland, coastal heath, grassy headlands and rock outcrops in freely draining to seasonally moist sands, gravels, peats and loams. Notes Individual plants or small groups can be found in unburnt habitat but mass flowering is common after hot summer fires. Flowering is also promoted by disturbance such as mowing or slashing. Plants in burnt habitats often blackish and resemble burnt sticks which may help to avoid predation by herbivores (a ploy that is not always successful). Var.: This very widespread species exhibits variation in floral features that is worthy of further study. Variants with yellow flowers occur in several parts of southern Australia. A preliminary DNA-based phylogenetic study showed populations from WA to be distinct from those of E states (see P. macrotys entry) Aug-Jan.

simplified_phrase: flowering enhanced by hot summer fires
fire: notes mainly flowers in the season following a hot summer fire, and is often abundant in habitats that were densely overgrown prior to the burn. occasional plants flower in the second year after a fire, especially in swampy areas.
description: plants 500-1,000mm tall. free part of leaf to 200 x 6-10mm, green or black. spike 100-400mm long, 15-75-flowered. ovary sessile, long, appressed, green or black. flowers crowded, scented, 15-18 x 10-15mm, green, brown or blackish, labellum lamina crystalline white, callus bright pink to red. dorsal sepal 12-16 x 3-4.5mm, curved forwards, sharply pointed. lateral sepals usually fused but often free at base, erect or recurved, each sepal 11-15 x 2-2.5mm, margins flat. petals 12-15 x 1-2mm, sharply pointed, incurved. labellum sessile, sharply recurved near middle (sometimes gently recurved), 8-15 x 6-7mm, margins crinkled and delicately fringed. callus prominent, with deeply toothed fringed margins, extending nearly to labellum apex. widely distributed and often locally common, growing in a wide range of habitats from seasonally wet flats, depressions, swamps and drainage lines to freely draining soils in woodland, open forest, coastal scrub and heath. notes mainly flowers in the season following a hot summer fire, and is often abundant in habitats that were densely overgrown prior to the burn. occasional plants flower in the second year after a fire, especially in swampy areas. flowering takes place over a very long period (3-5 months), even within a single burnt area with new plants emerging as earlier ones are shedding seed. plants exhibit substantial variation in vigour, stem and leaf colour (green, yellowish or black), flower size, flower number, density of flowers and the degree of fringing on the labellum and callus (sometimes with hardly any fringing obvious). one variant, named as gracillimum by w.h.nicholls from specimens collected at yarloop, wa, is based on slender plants with well-spaced flowers and few fringes on the labellum. it falls well within the range of variation of fimbria. mid-jun-oct. ;
original_text: Plants 500-1,000mm tall. Free part of leaf to 200 x 6-10mm, green or black. Spike 100-400mm long, 15-75-flowered. Ovary sessile, long, appressed, green or black. Flowers crowded, scented, 15-18 x 10-15mm, green, brown or blackish, labellum lamina crystalline white, callus bright pink to red. Dorsal sepal 12-16 x 3-4.5mm, curved forwards, sharply pointed. Lateral sepals usually fused but often free at base, erect or recurved, each sepal 11-15 x 2-2.5mm, margins flat. Petals 12-15 x 1-2mm, sharply pointed, incurved. Labellum sessile, sharply recurved near middle (sometimes gently recurved), 8-15 x 6-7mm, margins crinkled and delicately fringed. Callus prominent, with deeply toothed fringed margins, extending nearly to labellum apex. Widely distributed and often locally common, growing in a wide range of habitats from seasonally wet flats, depressions, swamps and drainage lines to freely draining soils in woodland, open forest, coastal scrub and heath. Notes Mainly flowers in the season following a hot summer fire, and is often abundant in habitats that were densely overgrown prior to the burn. Occasional plants flower in the second year after a fire, especially in swampy areas. Flowering takes place over a very long period (3-5 months), even within a single burnt area with new plants emerging as earlier ones are shedding seed. Plants exhibit substantial variation in vigour, stem and leaf colour (green, yellowish or black), flower size, flower number, density of flowers and the degree of fringing on the labellum and callus (sometimes with hardly any fringing obvious). One variant, named as P. gracillimum by W.H.Nicholls from specimens collected at Yarloop, WA, is based on slender plants with well-spaced flowers and few fringes on the labellum. It falls well within the range of variation of P. fimbria. Mid-Jun-Oct.

simplified_phrase: flowers without fire; flowering enhanced by fire
fire: notes flowering occurs without fire but is also promoted by fire with plants are much easier to see on burnt ground.
description: plants 400-900mm tall. free part of leaf stiff, to 300 x 5mm, often purplish. spike 80-200mm long, 6-50(-70)-flowered. ovary sessile, long, green, appressed to stem. flowers moderately crowded, strong spicy scent, 8-10 x 8-10mm, yellow to yellowish-green or greenish-brown, sometimes with reddish markings, labellum lamina green with white margins, callus green (rarely flowers wholly dark green with white labellum). dorsal sepal 6-8 x 3mm, incurved. lateral sepals fused, hooding labellum, each sepal 6-8 x 3mm. petals 6-8 x 3mm, incurved to spreading. labellum sessile, erect at base, gently recurved near middle, 5-7 x 3-4mm, margins crinkled or frilly. callus extending just beyond labellum bend, base broad, margins wrinkled. widespread but generally uncommon, often occurring as scattered individuals or in small groups growing mainly in areas of reliable high rainfall such as montane woodland in well-structured mountain loam, moist to wet medium to tall forest in clay loam, heathy forest, coastal scrub and heath in freely draining sands and gravels. notes flowering occurs without fire but is also promoted by fire with plants are much easier to see on burnt ground. ecology: unusual in the genus with its much reduced stiff leaf blade, which is often purplish, and its oddly developed root system which consists of misshapen tubers and fleshy  growths that are aggregated together in a structure that resembles a rhizome (see plate 111, nicholls 1969). plants contain chlorophyll and are able to photosynthesise but are actually partially mycoheterotrophic, needing a fungal relationship to provide extra carbon and nutrients to sustain growth. usually grows close to base of a eucalypt or among decaying wood. oct-feb. ;
original_text: Plants 400-900mm tall. Free part of leaf stiff, to 300 x 5mm, often purplish. Spike 80-200mm long, 6-50(-70)-flowered. Ovary sessile, long, green, appressed to stem. Flowers moderately crowded, strong spicy scent, 8-10 x 8-10mm, yellow to yellowish-green or greenish-brown, sometimes with reddish markings, labellum lamina green with white margins, callus green (rarely flowers wholly dark green with white labellum). Dorsal sepal 6-8 x 3mm, incurved. Lateral sepals fused, hooding labellum, each sepal 6-8 x 3mm. Petals 6-8 x 3mm, incurved to spreading. Labellum sessile, erect at base, gently recurved near middle, 5-7 x 3-4mm, margins crinkled or frilly. Callus extending just beyond labellum bend, base broad, margins wrinkled. Widespread but generally uncommon, often occurring as scattered individuals or in small groups growing mainly in areas of reliable high rainfall such as montane woodland in well-structured mountain loam, moist to wet medium to tall forest in clay loam, heathy forest, coastal scrub and heath in freely draining sands and gravels. Notes Flowering occurs without fire but is also promoted by fire with plants are much easier to see on burnt ground. Ecology: Unusual in the genus with its much reduced stiff leaf blade, which is often purplish, and its oddly developed root system which consists of misshapen tubers and fleshy root-like growths that are aggregated together in a structure that resembles a rhizome (see Plate 111, Nicholls 1969). Plants contain chlorophyll and are able to photosynthesise but are actually partially mycoheterotrophic, needing a fungal relationship to provide extra carbon and nutrients to sustain growth. Usually grows close to base of a eucalypt or among decaying wood. Oct-Feb.

fire: grows on swamp margin and on damp shaded banks in an area densely overgrown with exotic species regenerating from adjacent garden after bushfire.
description: stipe and rachis dark chestnut-brown at base, yellow-brown at apex, bearing sparse non-glandular hairs or  glabrous; stipe to 130 cm long, 10-12 mm diam., woody. lamina broadly elliptic or broadly ovate, to 180 cm long and 100 cm wide, 3- or 4-pinnate at base, glabrous above, with abundant colourless (occasionally red-brown) spreading non-glandular hairs along midribs and veins of undersurface. longest primary pinnae to 85 cm long and 40 cm wide. secondary pinnae arising at wide angles; to 24 cm long and 8 cm wide; midribs of primary and secondary pinnae lacking free lobes or wings. tertiary pinnae decreasing gradually in length on each secondary pinna; longest to 40 mm long and 13 mm wide, sometimes with winged midribs. quaternary pinnae to 6 mm long and 2 mm wide; ultimate pinnules linear, straight, acute, entire, adnate. indusium to 5 mm wide, membranous, fimbriate, hairy. [sporangia and spores not seen in australian material.] similar to pteridium revolutum but differing in the lamina which is 3- or 4-pinnate at the base, the straight pinnules and the indusium which is more than 0.2 mm wide. grows on swamp margin and on damp shaded banks in an area densely overgrown with exotic species regenerating from adjacent garden after bushfire. ;
original_text: Stipe and rachis dark chestnut-brown at base, yellow-brown at apex, bearing sparse non-glandular hairs or  glabrous; stipe to 130 cm long, 10-12 mm diam., woody. Lamina broadly elliptic or broadly ovate, to 180 cm long and 100 cm wide, 3- or 4-pinnate at base, glabrous above, with abundant colourless (occasionally red-brown) spreading non-glandular hairs along midribs and veins of undersurface. Longest primary pinnae to 85 cm long and 40 cm wide. Secondary pinnae arising at wide angles; to 24 cm long and 8 cm wide; midribs of primary and secondary pinnae lacking free lobes or wings. Tertiary pinnae decreasing gradually in length on each secondary pinna; longest to 40 mm long and 13 mm wide, sometimes with winged midribs. Quaternary pinnae to 6 mm long and 2 mm wide; ultimate pinnules linear, straight, acute, entire, adnate. Indusium to 5 mm wide, membranous, fimbriate, hairy. [Sporangia and spores not seen in Australian material.] Similar to Pteridium revolutum but differing in the lamina which is 3- or 4-pinnate at the base, the straight pinnules and the indusium which is more than 0.2 mm wide. Grows on swamp margin and on damp shaded banks in an area densely overgrown with exotic species regenerating from adjacent garden after bushfire.

fire: the area where it occurs was impacted severely by hot fires in 2003 and then devastated by storms which caused flooding, covering many of the orchids with deep alluvium.
description: leaves 3-5 in loose rosette or scattered up stem, 40-60 x 15-18mm, dark green, fleshy, margins entire. flower stem 150-300mm tall, stout, fleshy, smooth. flower semi-nodding, 40-45 x 14-18mm, translucent white and dark green, lateral sepals, petals and apex of hood brown. dorsal sepal much longer than petals, sharply pointed. lateral sepals loosely embracing galea and separated from petals by wide side gap, scabrous. sinus curved in side view, deeply notched in front view. free points tapered, 25-35mm long, erect, extending high above hood. petals flared. labellum sharply curved near apex, protruding from sinus when set, 18-21 x 3.5-4mm, dark brown, blunt. highly localised, growing among grasses and sedges on moist flats along floodplains of two small streams in tall open forest in moisture-retentive clay loam. notes this is a rare natural hybrid between falcata and cucullata subsp sylvicola. the area where it occurs was impacted severely by hot fires in 2003 and then devastated by storms which caused flooding, covering many of the orchids with deep alluvium. nov-dec. ;
original_text: Leaves 3-5 in loose rosette or scattered up stem, 40-60 x 15-18mm, dark green, fleshy, margins entire. Flower stem 150-300mm tall, stout, fleshy, smooth. Flower semi-nodding, 40-45 x 14-18mm, translucent white and dark green, lateral sepals, petals and apex of hood brown. Dorsal sepal much longer than petals, sharply pointed. Lateral sepals loosely embracing galea and separated from petals by wide side gap, scabrous. Sinus curved in side view, deeply notched in front view. Free points tapered, 25-35mm long, erect, extending high above hood. Petals flared. Labellum sharply curved near apex, protruding from sinus when set, 18-21 x 3.5-4mm, dark brown, blunt. Highly localised, growing among grasses and sedges on moist flats along floodplains of two small streams in tall open forest in moisture-retentive clay loam. Notes This is a rare natural hybrid between P. falcata and P. cucullata subsp. sylvicola. The area where it occurs was impacted severely by hot fires in 2003 and then devastated by storms which caused flooding, covering many of the orchids with deep alluvium. Nov-Dec.

simplified_phrase: genus-level observation; flowers mainly after hot summer fires
fire: notes both species flower poorly except after hot summer fires when massed flowering is common.
description: terrestrial tuberous orchids growing in loose to crowded clonal colonies. leaves 1-3, basal, ground-hugging, leathery, fleshy, margins flat. racemes 1-few-flowered; peduncle stiff, wiry, 1-3 sterile bracts. flowers resupinate, dull-coloured flowers. tepals free, narrow, leathery. dorsal sepal broader than lateral sepals, closely hooding column. lateral sepals decurved. petals spreading. labellum stiffly attached by its base to column base, remaining flexible. labellum lamina 3-lobed, curved, striped, externally papillate; lateral lobes narrow, embracing column; midlobe narrow, margins entire, finely toothed or lobed. callus of central plate and irregularly arranged small calli. column slender, curved, narrowly winged, papillate near anther. pollinia four, clavate, mealy, no viscidium. clonal colonies in forested habitats and heathland. notes both species flower poorly except after hot summer fires when massed flowering is common. poll. by small native bees seeking nectar (see nigricans entry). ;
original_text: Terrestrial tuberous orchids growing in loose to crowded clonal colonies. Leaves 1-3, basal, ground-hugging, leathery, fleshy, margins flat. Racemes 1-few-flowered; peduncle stiff, wiry, 1-3 sterile bracts. Flowers resupinate, dull-coloured flowers. Tepals free, narrow, leathery. Dorsal sepal broader than lateral sepals, closely hooding column. Lateral sepals decurved. Petals spreading. Labellum stiffly attached by its base to column base, remaining flexible. Labellum lamina 3-lobed, curved, striped, externally papillate; lateral lobes narrow, embracing column; midlobe narrow, margins entire, finely toothed or lobed. Callus of central plate and irregularly arranged small calli. Column slender, curved, narrowly winged, papillate near anther. Pollinia four, clavate, mealy, no viscidium. Clonal colonies in forested habitats and heathland. Notes Both species flower poorly except after hot summer fires when massed flowering is common. Poll. By small native bees seeking nectar (see P. nigricans entry).

simplified_phrase: flowers only after hot summer fires
fire: notes flowers only after hot summer fires.
description: leaves 2 or 3, overlapping in a tight rosette, ovate, ground-hugging, 35-70 x 20-35mm, fleshy, pale green. flower stem 100-300mm tall, stiff, 1-7-flowered. flowers 15-20 x 25-35mm, pink and white, sometimes wholly white or spotted with crimson. dorsal sepal narrowly obovate, 17-20 x 7-8mm, hooding column. lateral sepals narrowly obovate, 17-19 x 3mm, arching or erect at base then decurved, divergent. petals narrowly obovate, 18-20 x 3-4mm, arching or erect at base then decurved. labellum obovate, 13-16 x 7-8mm, base obliquely erect then gently curved, pink with conspicuous red bars; lateral lobes large, erect beside column, finely toothed; midlobe short, recurved. callus a narrow central plate with numerous sessile calli in lines coinciding with red bars. column incurved, 10-11x 3-3.5mm, white to pink. locally common, growing in winter-wet swamps, flats, beside streams and drainage lines in dense coastal scrub in black peaty soil; less commonly on granite outcrops. notes flowers only after hot summer fires. although this orchid grows in dense vegetative colonies, is difficult to find in unburnt habitat. flowers strongly scented on hot days. oct-early dec. ;
original_text: Leaves 2 or 3, overlapping in a tight rosette, ovate, ground-hugging, 35-70 x 20-35mm, fleshy, pale green. Flower stem 100-300mm tall, stiff, 1-7-flowered. Flowers 15-20 x 25-35mm, pink and white, sometimes wholly white or spotted with crimson. Dorsal sepal narrowly obovate, 17-20 x 7-8mm, hooding column. Lateral sepals narrowly obovate, 17-19 x 3mm, arching or erect at base then decurved, divergent. Petals narrowly obovate, 18-20 x 3-4mm, arching or erect at base then decurved. Labellum obovate, 13-16 x 7-8mm, base obliquely erect then gently curved, pink with conspicuous red bars; lateral lobes large, erect beside column, finely toothed; midlobe short, recurved. Callus a narrow central plate with numerous sessile calli in lines coinciding with red bars. Column incurved, 10-11x 3-3.5mm, white to pink. Locally common, growing in winter-wet swamps, flats, beside streams and drainage lines in dense coastal scrub in black peaty soil; less commonly on granite outcrops. Notes Flowers only after hot summer fires. Although this orchid grows in dense vegetative colonies, is difficult to find in unburnt habitat. Flowers strongly scented on hot days. Oct-early Dec.

simplified_phrase: flowers mainly after hot summer fires
fire: it flowers in mass after hot summer fires, rarely without fires;
description: leaf single, broadly ovate to heart-shaped, ground-hugging, 25-130 x 40-80mm, fleshy, bright green with pale veins, often with black marks. flower stem 100-300mm long, fleshy, with 2-3 loose leafy stem bracts to 40mm long, 1-8-flowered. flowers nodding, 20-30 x 30-40mm, white with red stripes and markings (rarely pink or yellow). dorsal sepal ovate-lanceolate, 25-30 x 5-7mm, hooding column. lateral sepals linear, 25-30 x 2mm, deflexed, divergent. petals linear, 22-27 x 3mm, spreading. labellum 10-12 x 6-8mm, curved, white with crimson lines; lateral lobes erect; midlobe short, deeply fringed, the fringes branched. callus a narrow tapered central plate with a few small scattered sessile calli. column incurved, 9-10 x 3.5-4mm, a cluster of large papillae behind anther. widespread and common from coast to inland areas, growing in many habitats, including coastal scrub, heathland, heathy forest, open forest, woodland and mallee shrubland in freely draining to moisture-retentive sands and loams. notes forms extensive vegetative colonies, from dense with overlapping leaves to plants scattered and well separated. it flowers in mass after hot summer fires, rarely without fires; sometimes a few plants flower after mowing or slashing. all parts of the plants dry a sombre black which earns it its botanical epithet (nigricans) and the common name of undertaker orchid. poll. the author observed small native bees visiting flowers at anglesea, vic., and witnessed the removal and deposition of pollinia. the bees entered the flower headfirst via the labellum and completely disappeared inside the tube between the labellum and column. their passage inside the flower can be followed by movements of the labellum. the bees were in the flower for a few minutes, spending much of their time at the bottom of the labellum feeding on nectar. they exit backwards from the flower with the pollinia attached to the thorax. for photos involving the bee homalictus punctatus see kuiter (2013, pp. 82-83). aug-nov. ;
original_text: Leaf single, broadly ovate to heart-shaped, ground-hugging, 25-130 x 40-80mm, fleshy, bright green with pale veins, often with black marks. Flower stem 100-300mm long, fleshy, with 2-3 loose leafy stem bracts to 40mm long, 1-8-flowered. Flowers nodding, 20-30 x 30-40mm, white with red stripes and markings (rarely pink or yellow). Dorsal sepal ovate-lanceolate, 25-30 x 5-7mm, hooding column. Lateral sepals linear, 25-30 x 2mm, deflexed, divergent. Petals linear, 22-27 x 3mm, spreading. Labellum 10-12 x 6-8mm, curved, white with crimson lines; lateral lobes erect; midlobe short, deeply fringed, the fringes branched. Callus a narrow tapered central plate with a few small scattered sessile calli. Column incurved, 9-10 x 3.5-4mm, a cluster of large papillae behind anther. Widespread and common from coast to inland areas, growing in many habitats, including coastal scrub, heathland, heathy forest, open forest, woodland and mallee shrubland in freely draining to moisture-retentive sands and loams. Notes Forms extensive vegetative colonies, from dense with overlapping leaves to plants scattered and well separated. It flowers in mass after hot summer fires, rarely without fires; sometimes a few plants flower after mowing or slashing. All parts of the plants dry a sombre black which earns it its botanical epithet (nigricans) and the common name of undertaker orchid. Poll. The author observed small native bees visiting flowers at Anglesea, Vic., and witnessed the removal and deposition of pollinia. The bees entered the flower headfirst via the labellum and completely disappeared inside the tube between the labellum and column. Their passage inside the flower can be followed by movements of the labellum. The bees were in the flower for a few minutes, spending much of their time at the bottom of the labellum feeding on nectar. They exit backwards from the flower with the pollinia attached to the thorax. For photos involving the bee Homalictus punctatus see Kuiter (2013, pp. 82-83). Aug-Nov.

fire: the bark is fire-retardant.
description: evergreen tree to circa 10 (-15+) m high, with spreading canopy. bark thick (to 5 (-7) cm or more), deeply furrowed, corky, grey. leaves: lamina ovate (to narrow-ovate), occasionally some leaves  elliptic or elliptic-oblong, mostly 4-7 cm long, 2-3.5 (-4) cm wide (can vary on the same plant with some smaller leaves circa 3 x 1.5 cm and larger leaves to circa 8 x 4.5 cm), tough-textured ( leathery), base rounded to truncate or occasionally subcordate, margin with (2-) 4-6 pairs of short acute teeth, rarely entire, sometimes  wavy, the lateral veins excurrent as a short bristle or point to circa 3 mm long, the upper surface dark green and  shiny, finally glabrous (or scattered minute stellate hairs remaining), the lower surface pale grey-green, densely tomentose with minute stellate hairs (stellate multicellular hairs illustrated in sim£Æ’µes et al. 2020); petiole 5-15 mm long, tomentose with indumentum similar to underleaf surface. acorns narrow-ovoid to  obloid, narrow-obloid-ellipsoid or ellipsoid, 1.5-4 (-4.5) cm long, singly or paired on peduncles circa 5-10 mm long; cupule up to half as long as acorn, initially shaggy from the free tips of the scales, but finally scales barely raised. the leaves contain and may be a potential source of the bioactive compound lupeol (sim£Æ’µes et al. 2020). the bark is fire-retardant.  wind pollinated and monoecious (separate male and female flowers on the same plant). cork oak forests play an important ecological role in terms of carbon sequestration, soil protection, hydrological cycle regulation and ecosystem sustainability (sim£Æ’µes et al. 2020). catkins appear in spring. acorns produced mostly march-may. ;
original_text: Evergreen tree to c. 10 (-15+) m high, with spreading canopy. Bark thick (to 5 (-7) cm or more), deeply furrowed, corky, grey. Leaves: lamina ovate (to narrow-ovate), occasionally some leaves  elliptic or elliptic-oblong, mostly 4-7 cm long, 2-3.5 (-4) cm wide (can vary on the same plant with some smaller leaves c. 3 x 1.5 cm and larger leaves to c. 8 x 4.5 cm), tough-textured ( leathery), base rounded to truncate or occasionally subcordate, margin with (2-) 4-6 pairs of short acute teeth, rarely entire, sometimes  wavy, the lateral veins excurrent as a short bristle or point to c. 3 mm long, the upper surface dark green and  shiny, finally glabrous (or scattered minute stellate hairs remaining), the lower surface pale grey-green, densely tomentose with minute stellate hairs (stellate multicellular hairs illustrated in SimƒÆ’µes et al. 2020); petiole 5-15 mm long, tomentose with indumentum similar to underleaf surface. Acorns narrow-ovoid to  obloid, narrow-obloid-ellipsoid or ellipsoid, 1.5-4 (-4.5) cm long, singly or paired on peduncles c. 5-10 mm long; cupule up to half as long as acorn, initially shaggy from the free tips of the scales, but finally scales barely raised. The leaves contain and may be a potential source of the bioactive compound lupeol (SimƒÆ’µes et al. 2020). The bark is fire-retardant.  Wind pollinated and monoecious (separate male and female flowers on the same plant). Cork Oak forests play an important ecological role in terms of carbon sequestration, soil protection, hydrological cycle regulation and ecosystem sustainability (SimƒÆ’µes et al. 2020). Catkins appear in spring. Acorns produced mostly March-May.

fire: biology, reproduction and regeneration after fire of many species have been investigated (meney & pate 1999 and references therein).
description: perennial (or in *centrolepidoideae often diminutive and annual) herbs with a rush- or s habit (rarely cushion-forming); caespitose or with creeping rhizomes, dioecious or rarely monoecious or hermaphrodite (in centrolepidoideae hermaphrodite). stems (culms) green and photosynthetic, terete to angular or flattened, simple or branching, sometimes with verticillate branching; straight or flexuous, solid or hollow, sometimes dimorphic with dissimilar fertile and vegetative culms; consisting of one, several or many internodes. leaves cauline (or basal) in adult plants reduced to sheathing scales with a small linear or subulate lamina (or lamina not reduced); sheath closely imbricate or loose, margins overlapping, at least at the base, caducous or persistent. inflorescence of spikelets with imbricate glumes, spikelet structure sometimes not apparent; spikelets with 1-many flowers, solitary and terminal, or axillary, or in a racemose inflorescence when dioecious, male and female inflorescences similar or very different. flowers 3- or 2-merous, small, each in the axil of a + scarious glume, often dorsiventrally compressed; bracts on the floral axis 1 or 2, or absent. perianth of 6 tepals in 2 whorls, or reduced or absent; tepals mostly scarious. male flowers: stamens 3 or 2 or 1, opposite the inner tepals; filaments free and filiform or rarely short; anthers 1-locular, dorsifixed, dehiscing by a longitudinal slit; pistillode often present. female flowers: staminodes 2 or 3 or absent; ovary superior, sessile or shortly stipitate, 1-3-locular; styles 1-3, free or partially fused; ovule solitary in each loculus, pendulous. (or with several or many carpels at different levels on an elongated receptacle). fruit a loculicidal capsule, or a small nut often dispersed with attached glume and tepals (or the carpels each loculicidally dehiscent). seeds often with distinctive surface ornamentation. culm anatomy: sclerenchyma cylinder and parenchyma sheath present. *character states given in parenthesis are limited to subfamily centrolepidoideae. some genera have been described as lacking spikelet inflorescence structure, but spikelets appear to be a feature of the whole restiid clade (restionaceae and anarthriaceae) (kircher 1986, sokoloff et al. 2009, 2015, fominchev et al. 2019). restionaceae lack bracteoles but bracts indicating the positions of aborted flowers are often present. culm anatomy presents many distinctive features and cell-types useful in characterising subfamilies, genera and species and a wide range of features that may protect the chlorenchyma in situations of seasonal drought. differences in culm anatomy between african and australasian members have long been recognised (cutler 1969, johnson & briggs 1981, linder 2000). anatomical features are also reported for african members by linder (1984) and for australian genera by pate and delfs (1999) and meney et al. (1999). the following terms for the distinctive anatomical cell types or structures were mostly defined by cutler (1969) and are used in the descriptions of culm anatomy. peg cells are pali chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. protective cells: modified cells of the chlorenchyma with slightly to moderately thickened lignified walls surrounding a substomatal cavity forming a tube extending all or part way through the chlorenchyma. these occur in restionoideae and sporadanthoideae, being absent from leptocarpoideae. pillar cells: are elongate, pali cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened (lignified) walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. pillar cells are restricted to leptocarpoideae, but there appear to have been homoplasious losses of this feature in at least four leptocarpoid clades (briggs et al. 2000). girders are sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles, extending from the sclerenchyma sheath all or part-way through the chlorenchyma. these occur in a few genera of leptocarpoideae. cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. patterns and rates of evolution of australian members have been contrasted with african clades (linder et al. 2003) and correlated with environmental events in australia (crisp & cook 2007). fossils of milfordia and restiocarpum pollen and fruits have been attributed to restionaceae (e g dettmann & clifford 2000). some species are heteroblastic, with different morphology of vegetative and reproductive stems; these may differ functionally (ehmig et al. 2018). an informative online interactive key to the western australian species, with abundant photographs, is given by hollister & thiele (2014). mostly in low-nutrient soils. ranging from arid to wet but mostly associated with seasonal drought in mediterranean or (less often) monsoonal climates. mostly dioecious; wind-pollinated; rarely apomictic. biology, reproduction and regeneration after fire of many species have been investigated (meney & pate 1999 and references therein). ;
original_text: Perennial (or in *Centrolepidoideae often diminutive and annual) herbs with a rush- or sedge-like habit (rarely cushion-forming); caespitose or with creeping rhizomes, dioecious or rarely monoecious or hermaphrodite (in Centrolepidoideae hermaphrodite). Stems (culms) green and photosynthetic, terete to angular or flattened, simple or branching, sometimes with verticillate branching; straight or flexuous, solid or hollow, sometimes dimorphic with dissimilar fertile and vegetative culms; consisting of one, several or many internodes. Leaves cauline (or basal) in adult plants reduced to sheathing scales with a small linear or subulate lamina (or lamina not reduced); sheath closely imbricate or loose, margins overlapping, at least at the base, caducous or persistent. Inflorescence of spikelets with imbricate glumes, spikelet structure sometimes not apparent; spikelets with 1-many flowers, solitary and terminal, or axillary, or in a racemose inflorescence When dioecious, male and female inflorescences similar or very different. Flowers 3- or 2-merous, small, each in the axil of a + scarious glume, often dorsiventrally compressed; bracts on the floral axis 1 or 2, or absent. Perianth of 6 tepals in 2 whorls, or reduced or absent; tepals mostly scarious. Male flowers: stamens 3 or 2 or 1, opposite the inner tepals; filaments free and filiform or rarely short; anthers 1-locular, dorsifixed, dehiscing by a longitudinal slit; pistillode often present. Female flowers: staminodes 2 or 3 or absent; ovary superior, sessile or shortly stipitate, 1-3-locular; styles 1-3, free or partially fused; ovule solitary in each loculus, pendulous. (or with several or many carpels at different levels on an elongated receptacle). Fruit a loculicidal capsule, or a small nut often dispersed with attached glume and tepals (or the carpels each loculicidally dehiscent). Seeds often with distinctive surface ornamentation. Culm anatomy: sclerenchyma cylinder and parenchyma sheath present. *Character states given in parenthesis are limited to subfamily Centrolepidoideae. Some genera have been described as lacking spikelet inflorescence structure, but spikelets appear to be a feature of the whole restiid clade (Restionaceae and Anarthriaceae) (Kircher 1986, Sokoloff et al. 2009, 2015, Fominchev et al. 2019). Restionaceae lack bracteoles but bracts indicating the positions of aborted flowers are often present. Culm anatomy presents many distinctive features and cell-types useful in characterising subfamilies, genera and species and a wide range of features that may protect the chlorenchyma in situations of seasonal drought. Differences in culm anatomy between African and Australasian members have long been recognised (Cutler 1969, Johnson & Briggs 1981, Linder 2000). Anatomical features are also reported for African members by Linder (1984) and for Australian genera by Pate and Delfs (1999) and Meney et al. (1999). The following terms for the distinctive anatomical cell types or structures were mostly defined by Cutler (1969) and are used in the descriptions of culm anatomy. Peg cells are palisade-like chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. Protective cells: modified cells of the chlorenchyma with slightly to moderately thickened lignified walls surrounding a substomatal cavity forming a tube extending all or part way through the chlorenchyma. These occur in Restionoideae and Sporadanthoideae, being absent from Leptocarpoideae. Pillar cells: are elongate, palisade-like cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened (lignified) walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. Pillar cells are restricted to Leptocarpoideae, but there appear to have been homoplasious losses of this feature in at least four leptocarpoid clades (Briggs et al. 2000). Girders are sclerenchyma ridges opposite the outer vascular bundles, extending from the sclerenchyma sheath all or part-way through the chlorenchyma. These occur in a few genera of Leptocarpoideae. Cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. Patterns and rates of evolution of Australian members have been contrasted with African clades (Linder et al. 2003) and correlated with environmental events in Australia (Crisp & Cook 2007). Fossils of Milfordia and Restiocarpum pollen and fruits have been attributed to Restionaceae (e.g. Dettmann & Clifford 2000). Some species are heteroblastic, with different morphology of vegetative and reproductive stems; these may differ functionally (Ehmig et al. 2018). An informative online interactive key to the Western Australian species, with abundant photographs, is given by Hollister & Thiele (2014). Mostly in low-nutrient soils. Ranging from arid to wet but mostly associated with seasonal drought in Mediterranean or (less often) monsoonal climates. Mostly dioecious; wind-pollinated; rarely apomictic. Biology, reproduction and regeneration after fire of many species have been investigated (Meney & Pate 1999 and references therein).

simplified_phrase: resprouts from rhizomes after fire; flowering suppressed by fire
fire: the impact of a bushfire at alum mountain showed that rhizanthella flowerheads covered by thick litter were destroyed, eliminating seed production for that year, but the rhizomes, which were more deeply buried, regrew below the damaged tissue.
description: rhizome 100-150 x 5-10 mm, fleshy, white, with overlapping fleshy bracts. peduncle with numerous overlapping bracts. flowerhead 15-30 mm wide, conical, fleshy. sterile sheathing bracts surrounding flowerhead, about 18, triangular, 1-veined, 6-8 x 2-3 mm, overlapping, drab white, becoming reddish or purplish on exposure. short floral bracts subtending flowers, circa 7 x 3 mm, triangular, 1-veined. flowers 15-30 per head, tubular, 6-8 x 3 mm, creamy white maturing to pink, red, maroon or purplish. sepals and petals free, remaining in close proximity, labellum protruding between lateral sepals. dorsal sepal 3-3.5 x 1.8-2 mm, including an apical point circa 0.5 mm long. lateral sepals 3.5-4 x 2-2.2 mm, including an apical point circa 1.5 mm long. petals 2-2.3 x 1.5 mm. labellum broadly heart-shaped, circa 2 x 2 mm, curved, fleshy, dark red, papillate. fruit a drupe, yellow, containing 16-900 seeds. much of the early history of this orchid presented here is based on material from lionel gilbert's fascinating book the orchid man (gilbert 1992), which all orchid lovers should read. cryptanthemis slateri was discovered in november 1931 on the lower western slopes of alum mountain, bulahdelah, in north-central coastal n.s.by ernest william slater when he was digging up a plant or plants of a dipodium for friends (probably variegatum which is common in the area). slater thought the 'curious object might be of orchidaceous character' and sent the specimen together with the dipodium plants to mr & mrs frederick fieldsend of east maitland who were friends with the reverend herman rupp, a noted orchid authority in n.s.at the time. although the flowers were withered, rupp realized it was an orchid and recognised its similarity to rhizanthella gardneri which had been discovered in w.some three years earlier. a very excited rupp immediately contacted slater and within a week 4 more specimens were found. these were used by rupp as type material to erect the genus cryptanthemis and formally name the species as cryptanthemis slateri (rupp 1932); he later provided more details of the species in another paper (rupp 1934).  the discovery of this orchid created much excitement in the eastern australian botanical community and many people looked for the novelty, often digging up dipodium plants while searching. such was the interest in the underground species that rupp observed 'so much interest has been aroused by cryptanthemis that i tremble for the welfare of dipodium, which is a beautiful thing.' rupp visited bulahdelah in 1933 and photographed a partly excavated plant of the orchid in situ. an article on the species with 2 full pages of photos was included in the australian orchid review for june 1938. in stark contrast with western australia's rhizanthella gardneri, this eastern species occurs in areas with a high and reliable rainfall; bulahdelah for example, where most of the research on slateri has been carried out, has an annual rainfall of circa 1,350 mm per annum. slateri is found in a range of forested habitats all of which include shrubs and trees in the family myrtaceae, particularly open forest and woodland with species of angophora, corymbia, eucalyptus, leptospermum and melaleuca. other diverse habitats include wet sclerophyll forest, littoral rainforest and streambank vegetation with species of syncarpia and tristaniopsis. soils are mostly freely draining sand or loam. apart from the general importance of myrtaceous plants, no tree or shrub species forms a common link between the localities. most of the details of the biology of this species, which is very similar to that outlined for rhizanthella gardneri, have come from the research carried out by mark clements for the centre for plant biodiversity research in canberra. mark has kindly made the results of his studies freely available for my use. plants of slateri can occur singly, but most often form clumps comprising single or conjoined rhizomes at a depth of 20-25 cm underground. growth occurs all year round, but fluctuates in response to rain. plants occur in various stages of development with new and old growths present on the same plant. rhizomes consist of a series of internodes with meristematic buds at the nodes, each subtended by a small bract. new lateral rhizomes arise from these buds. the basal area where it is attached to the parent rhizome is only a few millimeters wide, but older parts reach 10-15 mm across. the narrow basal connection is easily broken, but separated parts can develop individually. excavations of several plants revealed an interconnected labyrinth of multiple decaying, mature, developing and immature rhizomes up to 25 cm apart at the furthest points. in one case up to 27 individual rhizomes (plants) were found in an area of about 250 cm2. rhizomes first develop laterally, flowering when large enough. prior to flowering, the apex of the largest rhizomes grow towards the soil surface, taking 4 to 6 months before developing a capitulum that just emerges at the soil surface under the litter layer, anytime between january and october. flowering occurs from august to early november. the capitulum, which is slightly funnel-shaped, consists of an outer layer of sterile sheathing bracts and a series of spirally arranged individual flowers (up to 30), each subtended
