original_text: Rhizome 100-150 x 5-10 mm, fleshy, white, with overlapping fleshy bracts. Peduncle with numerous overlapping bracts. Flowerhead 15-30 mm wide, conical, fleshy. Sterile sheathing bracts surrounding flowerhead, about 18, triangular, 1-veined, 6-8 x 2-3 mm, overlapping, drab white, becoming reddish or purplish on exposure. Short floral bracts subtending flowers, c. 7 x 3 mm, triangular, 1-veined. Flowers 15-30 per head, tubular, 6-8 x 3 mm, creamy white maturing to pink, red, maroon or purplish. Sepals and petals free, remaining in close proximity, labellum protruding between lateral sepals. Dorsal sepal 3-3.5 x 1.8-2 mm, including an apical point c. 0.5 mm long. Lateral sepals 3.5-4 x 2-2.2 mm, including an apical point c. 1.5 mm long. Petals 2-2.3 x 1.5 mm. Labellum broadly heart-shaped, c. 2 x 2 mm, curved, fleshy, dark red, papillate. Fruit a drupe, yellow, containing 16-900 seeds. Much of the early history of this orchid presented here is based on material from Lionel Gilbert's fascinating book The Orchid Man (Gilbert 1992), which all orchid lovers should read. Cryptanthemis slateri was discovered in November 1931 on the lower western slopes of Alum Mountain, Bulahdelah, in north-central coastal N.S.W. by Ernest William Slater when he was digging up a plant or plants of a Dipodium for friends (probably D. variegatum which is common in the area). Slater thought the 'curious object might be of orchidaceous character' and sent the specimen together with the Dipodium plants to Mr & Mrs Frederick J. Fieldsend of East Maitland who were friends with the Reverend Herman Rupp, a noted orchid authority in N.S.W. at the time. Although the flowers were withered, Rupp realized it was an orchid and recognised its similarity to Rhizanthella gardneri which had been discovered in W.A. some three years earlier. A very excited Rupp immediately contacted Slater and within a week 4 more specimens were found. These were used by Rupp as type material to erect the genus Cryptanthemis and formally name the species as Cryptanthemis slateri (Rupp 1932); he later provided more details of the species in another paper (Rupp 1934).  The discovery of this orchid created much excitement in the eastern Australian botanical community and many people looked for the novelty, often digging up Dipodium plants while searching. Such was the interest in the underground species that Rupp observed 'So much interest has been aroused by Cryptanthemis that I tremble for the welfare of Dipodium, which is a beautiful thing.' Rupp visited Bulahdelah in 1933 and photographed a partly excavated plant of the orchid in situ. An article on the species with 2 full pages of photos was included in the Australian Orchid Review for June 1938. In stark contrast with Western Australia's Rhizanthella gardneri, this eastern species occurs in areas with a high and reliable rainfall; Bulahdelah for example, where most of the research on R. slateri has been carried out, has an annual rainfall of c. 1,350 mm per annum. R. slateri is found in a range of forested habitats all of which include shrubs and trees in the family Myrtaceae, particularly open forest and woodland with species of Angophora, Corymbia, Eucalyptus, Leptospermum and Melaleuca. Other diverse habitats include wet sclerophyll forest, littoral rainforest and streambank vegetation with species of Syncarpia and Tristaniopsis. Soils are mostly freely draining sand or loam. Apart from the general importance of myrtaceous plants, no tree or shrub species forms a common link between the localities. Most of the details of the biology of this species, which is very similar to that outlined for Rhizanthella gardneri, have come from the research carried out by Mark Clements for the Centre for Plant Biodiversity Research in Canberra. Mark has kindly made the results of his studies freely available for my use. Plants of R. slateri can occur singly, but most often form clumps comprising single or conjoined rhizomes at a depth of 20-25 cm underground. Growth occurs all year round, but fluctuates in response to rain. Plants occur in various stages of development with new and old growths present on the same plant. Rhizomes consist of a series of internodes with meristematic buds at the nodes, each subtended by a small bract. New lateral rhizomes arise from these buds. The basal area where it is attached to the parent rhizome is only a few millimeters wide, but older parts reach 10-15 mm across. The narrow basal connection is easily broken, but separated parts can develop individually. Excavations of several plants revealed an interconnected labyrinth of multiple decaying, mature, developing and immature rhizomes up to 25 cm apart at the furthest points. In one case up to 27 individual rhizomes (plants) were found in an area of about 250 cm2. Rhizomes first develop laterally, flowering when large enough. Prior to flowering, the apex of the largest rhizomes grow towards the soil surface, taking 4 to 6 months before developing a capitulum that just emerges at the soil surface under the litter layer, anytime between January and October. Flowering occurs from August to early November. The capitulum, which is slightly funnel-shaped, consists of an outer layer of sterile sheathing bracts and a series of spirally arranged individual flowers (up to 30), each subtended by a floral bract. Individual flowers are tubular, creamy white, maturing to pink, red or maroon with the sepals and petals held close together, the triangular labellum protruding between them. Rhizanthella slateri is pollinated by small microdipterans (gnats), possibly attracted by a mushroom-like odour. They enter the open flower, possibly deceived into laying eggs or seeking nectar, and pick up a pollinarium on the thorax when leaving the flower. Deposition on the stigma occurs when visiting another flower. The percentage of pollination observed in flowerheads is unusually high (70-100%), indicating an efficient system and a strong attraction for the pollinators. Self-pollination has been ruled out because cultivated plants grown out of their natural habitat do not produce capsules. Pollinated flowers develop into fleshy, indehiscent drupes that take 11-12 months to mature. At first the cream-coloured ovaries develop below the ground surface, enlarging to a cluster of fleshy, yellow, aromatic drupes at or near the soil surface but under the litter layer. The ripe berry-like fruit contain dark brown sclerotic seeds, 16-900 per fruit. Seed dispersal is probably by truffle-eating animals such as swamp wallabies and bandicoots feeding on the ripe fruit, or birds such as choughs and bower birds, the seeds passing through the gut and being dispersed in dung. The impact of a bushfire at Alum Mountain showed that Rhizanthella flowerheads covered by thick litter were destroyed, eliminating seed production for that year, but the rhizomes, which were more deeply buried, regrew below the damaged tissue. Flowers August-November.

fire: it also responds well to winter fires, resulting in abundant growth later in spring (mellichamp & case 2009).
description: perennial herb to 1 m high, rhizomatous, forming dense clumps, producing new leaves each year. carnivorous leaves: tubular 'pitchers', erect, hollow, widening towards opening at the apex, lower part of tube green, upper part white or whitish pink with distinct green to pink to reddish venation, glabrous or finely pubescent, the rim loosely revolute, often with an everted indentation forming a spout with a narrow wing running below outside of the tube, the operculum ('hood') wavy- or ruffled-edged, longer than wide, with downward-pointing hairs on the underside. pitchers marcescent and can vary in size at different growth stages and during the year. non-carnivorous leaves (phyllodia): flat, narrow to oblanceolate (to 20 cm or more long), green, may be produced in winter, when stressed or after flowering. flowers solitary, borne on a long, slender, leafless stem, nodding, maroon to red or brownish red, slightly sweet-scented; sepals 5, p, to 5 cm long, persistent; petals 5, hanging, to 5 (-7) cm long, distal portion orbiculate to rhombic, falling soon after flowering; style, including distinct style disc, umbrella-shaped, disc to 7 cm diam., reddish; stamens numerous. capsule 5-parted, round, to 2 cm diam., warty, acropetally dehiscent, with numerous small seeds. one of the largest and showiest sarracenia species. grows in wet habitats. in australia it was found growing in a hanging swamp on the edge of a rock platform of narrabeen sandstone; associated with sphagnum, lepidosperma sp., gymnoschoenus sphaerocephalus, lepyrodia scariosa, empodisma minus, drosera binata, epacris pulchella and leptospermum juniperinum. sarracenia leucophylla is capable of forming extensive, nearly pure stands in open, wet meadows and seepage slopes where it grows in the gulf coast region, united states; it also responds well to winter fires, resulting in abundant growth later in spring (mellichamp & case 2009). ;
original_text: Perennial herb to 1 m high, rhizomatous, forming dense clumps, producing new leaves each year. Carnivorous leaves: tubular 'pitchers', erect, hollow, widening towards opening at the apex, lower part of tube green, upper part white or whitish pink with distinct green to pink to reddish venation, glabrous or finely pubescent, the rim loosely revolute, often with an everted indentation forming a spout with a narrow wing running below outside of the tube, the operculum ('hood') wavy- or ruffled-edged, longer than wide, with downward-pointing hairs on the underside. Pitchers marcescent and can vary in size at different growth stages and during the year. Non-carnivorous leaves (phyllodia): flat, narrow to oblanceolate (to 20 cm or more long), green, may be produced in winter, when stressed or after flowering. Flowers solitary, borne on a long, slender, leafless stem, nodding, maroon to red or brownish red, slightly sweet-scented; sepals 5, petal-like, to 5 cm long, persistent; petals 5, hanging, to 5 (-7) cm long, distal portion orbiculate to rhombic, falling soon after flowering; style, including distinct style disc, umbrella-shaped, disc to 7 cm diam., reddish; stamens numerous. Capsule 5-parted, round, to 2 cm diam., warty, acropetally dehiscent, with numerous small seeds. One of the largest and showiest Sarracenia species. Grows in wet habitats. In Australia it was found growing in a hanging swamp on the edge of a rock platform of Narrabeen sandstone; associated with Sphagnum, Lepidosperma sp., Gymnoschoenus sphaerocephalus, Lepyrodia scariosa, Empodisma minus, Drosera binata, Epacris pulchella and Leptospermum juniperinum. Sarracenia leucophylla is capable of forming extensive, nearly pure stands in open, wet meadows and seepage slopes where it grows in the Gulf Coast region, United States; it also responds well to winter fires, resulting in abundant growth later in spring (Mellichamp & Case 2009).

fire: reportedly a fire tolerant species (crowder & saggers 2010).
description: culms 60-100 cm high, simple, with nodes conspicuously bearded or glabrous. leaves: ligule 1-2.5 mm long; blade 15-30 cm long, 2-3 mm wide. inflorescence a single raceme 7-12 cm long, 12-20-jointed; raceme internodes and pedicels 3.5-4 mm long, with ciliate margins, internodes and pedicels asymmetrical in cross-section with groove along inner or adaxial surface and rounded on outer or abaxial surface. sessile spikelets lanceolate to narrowly elliptic or narrowly oblong; lower glume 8-10 mm long, grooved or depressed throughout or below middle, 6-veined, glabrous, stiffly coriaceous, apex tapering into bifid linear lobes, with narrow wings especially at apex or without wings; upper glume circa 6-7.5 mm long (not including awn), 3-veined, scabrous on lateral veins and long-ciliate on margins, membranous, winged on keel at apex, with awn to 10 mm long; lower lemma 6-7 mm long, hyaline, apex acute and awnless; lower palea slightly shorter, hyaline; upper lemma circa 5 mm long, hyaline, tapering into two linear lobes, with awn 20-40 mm long; upper palea circa 5 mm long; anthers circa 3 mm long. pedicellate spikelets lanceolate to narrowly elliptic, circa 8-9 mm long (including tapered apex); lower glume 7-veined, long-ciliate on margins, tapered into short linear apex, bifid or entire; upper glume  equal, 3-veined, apex tapered, entire; lower lemma circa 6 mm long, palea absent; upper lemma circa 5 mm long; palea circa 5 mm long, anthers to 5 mm long. caryopsis concave on one side, compressed dorsoventrally. older plants often discernible in the landscape as wiry tussocks of pale or white stems. common in savanna country where distributed although rarely dominant (crowder & saggers 2010). reportedly a fire tolerant species (crowder & saggers 2010). flowers all year but predominantly in summer or during the wet season. ;

Sessile spikelets lanceolate to narrowly elliptic or narrowly oblong; lower glume 8-10 mm long, grooved or depressed throughout or below middle, 6-veined, glabrous, stiffly coriaceous, apex tapering into bifid linear lobes, with narrow wings especially at apex or without wings; upper glume c. 6-7.5 mm long (not including awn), 3-veined, scabrous on lateral veins and long-ciliate on margins, membranous, winged on keel at apex, with awn to 10 mm long; lower lemma 6-7 mm long, hyaline, apex acute and awnless; lower palea slightly shorter, hyaline; upper lemma c. 5 mm long, hyaline, tapering into two linear lobes, with awn 20-40 mm long; upper palea c. 5 mm long; anthers c. 3 mm long. Pedicellate spikelets lanceolate to narrowly elliptic, c. 8-9 mm long (including tapered apex); lower glume 7-veined, long-ciliate on margins, tapered into short linear apex, bifid or entire; upper glume  equal, 3-veined, apex tapered, entire; lower lemma c. 6 mm long, palea absent; upper lemma c. 5 mm long; palea c. 5 mm long, anthers to 5 mm long. Caryopsis concave on one side, compressed dorsoventrally. Older plants often discernible in the landscape as wiry tussocks of pale or white stems. Common in savanna country where distributed although rarely dominant (Crowder & Saggers 2010). Reportedly a fire tolerant species (Crowder & Saggers 2010). Flowers all year but predominantly in summer or during the wet season.

fire: the seeds are primarily wind-dispersed, but the slashing of fire breaks in infested areas and the movement of contaminated soil are also thought to assist the spread of this species.
description: erect perennial to circa 1.5 m high, glabrous. leaves oblanceolate to narrowly elliptic, to 12 cm long, with l:w ratio circa 2-4, lobate, with lobes antrorse; base hardly to moderately narrower; margin dentate or denticulate. capitula few to numerous per stem; calycular bracteoles 10-16, 3-4 mm long, circa 0.8 mm wide; involucre circa 7 mm long, circa 5-8 mm diam.; bracts 20-22. florets numerous; ligulate florets circa 13; ligule 10-20 mm long, 4-veined, pink to purple. achenes narrowly obloid, 2-2.5 mm long, brown or olive-brown, with papillose hairs in narrow bands. pappus caducous, circa 7 mm long. grows in coastal sites on sand dunes and among rocks, in heathland and shrubland. reproduces mainly by seed, but can also spread vegetatively from fallen branches that readily take root. the seeds are primarily wind-dispersed, but the slashing of fire breaks in infested areas and the movement of contaminated soil are also thought to assist the spread of this species. (queensland government 2016). flowers spring-summer. ;
original_text: Erect perennial to c. 1.5 m high, glabrous. Leaves oblanceolate to narrowly elliptic, to 12 cm long, with l:w ratio c. 2-4, lobate, with lobes antrorse; base hardly to moderately narrower; margin dentate or denticulate. Capitula few to numerous per stem; calycular bracteoles 10-16, 3-4 mm long, c. 0.8 mm wide; involucre c. 7 mm long, c. 5-8 mm diam.; bracts 20-22. Florets numerous; ligulate florets c. 13; ligule 10-20 mm long, 4-veined, pink to purple. Achenes narrowly obloid, 2-2.5 mm long, brown or olive-brown, with papillose hairs in narrow bands. Pappus caducous, c. 7 mm long. Grows in coastal sites on sand dunes and among rocks, in heathland and shrubland. Reproduces mainly by seed, but can also spread vegetatively from fallen branches that readily take root. The seeds are primarily wind-dispersed, but the slashing of fire breaks in infested areas and the movement of contaminated soil are also thought to assist the spread of this species. (Queensland Government 2016). Flowers spring-summer.

fire: the rootstock is often enlarged just below ground level, probably facilitating regeneration after fire.
description: undershrub, spreading, to 0.3 m tall, pubescent except for the petals and stamens. leaves 2-3 cm long including a terete petiole 3-6 (-8) mm long; stipules acicular, persistent; leaflets in 2-3 pairs spaced 4-10 mm apart, narrowly elliptic to elliptic, 5-15 mm long, 3-5 mm wide, increasing distally, broadly acute or obtuse; glands between all leaflet pairs, cylindric or clavate, rounded or pointed, stipitate. inflorescence subumbellate, of 2-3 flowers, axillary, distributed along the stems; peduncle 10-20 mm long; pedicels circa 2 mm long; bracts usually caducous. petals circa 4 mm long. fertile stamens 10; filaments subequal, circa 1 mm long; anthers subequal, 4-5 mm long. pod flat, 2-2.5 cm long, circa 10 mm wide, straight, entire. seeds dull. resembles cardiosperma and related species of southern australia in the short petioles and small flowers, but differs in the leaflets increasing in size distally. the rootstock is often enlarged just below ground level, probably facilitating regeneration after fire. widely distributed in deep, red, desert sands. flowers jan.-aug. ;
original_text: Undershrub, spreading, to 0.3 m tall, pubescent except for the petals and stamens. Leaves 2-3 cm long including a terete petiole 3-6 (-8) mm long; stipules acicular, persistent; leaflets in 2-3 pairs spaced 4-10 mm apart, narrowly elliptic to elliptic, 5-15 mm long, 3-5 mm wide, increasing distally, broadly acute or obtuse; glands between all leaflet pairs, cylindric or clavate, rounded or pointed, stipitate. Inflorescence subumbellate, of 2-3 flowers, axillary, distributed along the stems; peduncle 10-20 mm long; pedicels c. 2 mm long; bracts usually caducous. Petals c. 4 mm long. Fertile stamens 10; filaments subequal, c. 1 mm long; anthers subequal, 4-5 mm long. Pod flat, 2-2.5 cm long, c. 10 mm wide, straight, entire. Seeds dull. Resembles S. cardiosperma and related species of southern Australia in the short petioles and small flowers, but differs in the leaflets increasing in size distally. The rootstock is often enlarged just below ground level, probably facilitating regeneration after fire. Widely distributed in deep, red, desert sands. Flowers Jan.-Aug.

description: shrub, spreading, to 0.8 m high, glabrous. leaves 8-12 cm long including a terete petiole 20-40 mm long; stipules acicular, caducous; leaflets in 5-12 pairs spaced 15-20 mm apart, linear to elliptic, 30-60 mm long, 5-15 mm wide, obtuse and mucronate to emarginate; glands absent. inflorescence dense, of 20-60 flowers, terminal and in upper axils; peduncle 20-80 mm long; pedicels 10-25 mm long; bracts subpersistent. petals circa 15 mm long. fertile stamens 7, with 3 adaxial staminodes; filaments subequal, circa 1 mm long; anthers unequal, the largest two circa 10 mm long, the others 3-5 mm long. pod flat, 3.5-7 cm long, 8-12 mm wide, straight, entire. seeds dull, with a short areole. found in semi-arid areas, especially in disturbed sites. suckers from roots, and seedlings establish readily following fire. because of its ability to profusely sucker and form thickets it can become a potential weed in places. ;
original_text: Shrub, spreading, to 0.8 m high, glabrous. Leaves 8-12 cm long including a terete petiole 20-40 mm long; stipules acicular, caducous; leaflets in 5-12 pairs spaced 15-20 mm apart, linear to elliptic, 30-60 mm long, 5-15 mm wide, obtuse and mucronate to emarginate; glands absent. Inflorescence dense, of 20-60 flowers, terminal and in upper axils; peduncle 20-80 mm long; pedicels 10-25 mm long; bracts subpersistent. Petals c. 15 mm long. Pod flat, 3.5-7 cm long, 8-12 mm wide, straight, entire. Seeds dull, with a short areole. Found in semi-arid areas, especially in disturbed sites. Suckers from roots, and seedlings establish readily following fire. Because of its ability to profusely sucker and form thickets it can become a potential weed in places.

description: annual or perennial herbs, shrubs or small trees, sometimes trailing or climbing, many species spreading by means of suckers and thus forming colonies (clonal), pubescent with glandular or simple or stellate non-glandular hairs, rarely glabrous; prickles present or absent. leaves usually alternate, sometimes paired, simple or pinnate, entire or lobed, petiolate. inflorescence , often scorpioid or becoming ra, subumbellate or pan, terminal, lateral, axillary, extra-axillary or leaf-opposed. flowers usually bisexual, rarely male or female, actinomorphic or slightly zygomorphic. calyx campanulate, rotate or cup-shaped, usually 5 (rarely 4-10)-lobed, sometimes enlarged in fruit. corolla stellate and deeply incised to rotate, rarely campanulate, purple or blue, less often white or yellow, usually 5 (rarely 4-10)-lobed, the lobes folded in bud. stamens 5, usually equal, inserted in throat of corolla; anthers bilocular, basifixed, cohering and  around style or not cohering, dehiscing by terminal pores or slits, rarely by longitudinal slits; in former lycopersicon species the anthers each with an apical elongated sterile appendage, cohering to form a cone around style, and dehiscing inwards by longitudinal slits. ovary 2 (occasionally 3 or 4)-locular. stigma terminal, capitate or bifid. fruit a succulent, papery or bony berry, rarely subcapsular, sometimes enclosed by inflated calyx. seeds orbicular to sub-reniform. [note, this description from the flora of australia volume 29 (purdie et al. 1982) may require further revision; at the time of publication, lycopersicon was treated as a separate genus (see purdie et al. 1982: 175, 177; barker & telford 1993: 338-339) but is now considered a synonym of solanum - editor, 19 april 2021.] dioecious species are confined mainly to tropical western australia and the northern territory.  [the solanum treatment from the flora of australia volume 29 (1982) requires major revision - editor, 19 april 2021.] occurs in all except saline, alpine and aquatic habitats. many species are weedy, some common after fire. the highest numbers of species occur in the tropics, but many of these are not well collected and hence are poorly known; their juvenile and mature plants are often morphologically very different. many species occur in arid or semi-arid areas, often widespread, some with relict distributions. ;
original_text: Annual or perennial herbs, shrubs or small trees, sometimes trailing or climbing, many species spreading by means of suckers and thus forming colonies (clonal), pubescent with glandular or simple or stellate non-glandular hairs, rarely glabrous; prickles present or absent. Leaves usually alternate, sometimes paired, simple or pinnate, entire or lobed, petiolate. Inflorescence cyme-like, often scorpioid or becoming raceme-like, subumbellate or panicle-like, terminal, lateral, axillary, extra-axillary or leaf-opposed. Flowers usually bisexual, rarely male or female, actinomorphic or slightly zygomorphic. Calyx campanulate, rotate or cup-shaped, usually 5 (rarely 4-10)-lobed, sometimes enlarged in fruit. Corolla stellate and deeply incised to rotate, rarely campanulate, purple or blue, less often white or yellow, usually 5 (rarely 4-10)-lobed, the lobes folded in bud. Stamens 5, usually equal, inserted in throat of corolla; anthers bilocular, basifixed, cohering and cone-like around style or not cohering, dehiscing by terminal pores or slits, rarely by longitudinal slits; in former Lycopersicon species the anthers each with an apical elongated sterile appendage, cohering to form a cone around style, and dehiscing inwards by longitudinal slits. Ovary 2 (occasionally 3 or 4)-locular. Stigma terminal, capitate or bifid. Fruit a succulent, papery or bony berry, rarely subcapsular, sometimes enclosed by inflated calyx. Seeds orbicular to sub-reniform. [Note, this description from the Flora of Australia Volume 29 (Purdie et al. 1982) may require further revision; at the time of publication, Lycopersicon was treated as a separate genus (see Purdie et al. 1982: 175, 177; Barker & Telford 1993: 338-339) but is now considered a synonym of Solanum - Editor, 19 April 2021.] Dioecious species are confined mainly to tropical Western Australia and the Northern Territory.  [The Solanum treatment from the Flora of Australia Volume 29 (1982) requires major revision - Editor, 19 April 2021.] Occurs in all except saline, alpine and aquatic habitats. Many species are weedy, some common after fire. The highest numbers of species occur in the tropics, but many of these are not well collected and hence are poorly known; their juvenile and mature plants are often morphologically very different. Many species occur in arid or semi-arid areas, often widespread, some with relict distributions.

fire: common in recently burnt scrub.
description: sprawling, clonal, herbaceous perennial with usually annual stems to 25 cm long, green or greenish-yellow, almost glabrous to sparsely pubescent with simple hairs, occasional stellate hairs and minute glandular hairs; prickles to 15 mm long, abundant on all parts except corolla. leaves elliptic; lamina 3-7 cm long, 1-3 cm wide, sometimes larger, almost concolorous, lobed; lobes obtusely triangular, shallowly lobed; petiole usually up to 15 mm long. inflorescence 1-10-flowered; peduncle 5-10 mm long; rachis 1-3 cm long; pedicels 5-10 mm long. calyx 4-8 mm long, enlarged in fruit; lobes narrowly triangular, 2-4 mm long. corolla broadly stellate to rotate, 15-25 mm diam., pale blue or white. anthers 5 mm long. berry globular, 15-25 mm diam., drying blackish; fruiting peduncle to 30 mm long, pedicels 15-20 mm long, calyx circa 15-25 mm diam. seeds 2-2.5 mm long, dark grey to almost black. closely relatedto hoplopetalum bitter & summerh.,but distinguished by being almost glabrous. treated fruit eaten by aborigines. usually occurs onsandy plains; common in recently burnt scrub. ;
original_text: Sprawling, clonal, herbaceous perennial with usually annual stems to 25 cm long, green or greenish-yellow, almost glabrous to sparsely pubescent with simple hairs, occasional stellate hairs and minute glandular hairs; prickles to 15 mm long, abundant on all parts except corolla. Leaves elliptic; lamina 3-7 cm long, 1-3 cm wide, sometimes larger, almost concolorous, lobed; lobes obtusely triangular, shallowly lobed; petiole usually up to 15 mm long. Inflorescence 1-10-flowered; peduncle 5-10 mm long; rachis 1-3 cm long; pedicels 5-10 mm long. Calyx 4-8 mm long, enlarged in fruit; lobes narrowly triangular, 2-4 mm long. Corolla broadly stellate to rotate, 15-25 mm diam., pale blue or white. Anthers 5 mm long. Berry globular, 15-25 mm diam., drying blackish; fruiting peduncle to 30 mm long, pedicels 15-20 mm long, calyx c. 15-25 mm diam. Seeds 2-2.5 mm long, dark grey to almost black. Closely relatedto S. hoplopetalum Bitter & Summerh.,but distinguished by being almost glabrous. Treated fruit eaten by Aborigines. Usually occurs onsandy plains; common in recently burnt scrub.

fire: abundantafter fire.
description: erect shrub to 2 m, green, glabrous except for minute hairs on petal apices; prickles absent. leaves elliptic to lanceolate; lamina 3-8 cm long, 1-2 cm wide, sometimes larger, concolorous, usually entire; petiole to 1 cm long. juvenile leaves up to 19 cm long and 9 cm wide, shallowly lobed towards base. inflorescence up to 12-flowered; rachis to 5 cm long; peduncle absent or to 1 cm long; pedicels to 25 mm long. calyx 3-5 mm long; lobes broadly triangular, 2-3 mm long. corolla rotate, 20-30 mm diam., violet; lobes notched. anthers 2-2.5 mm long. berry globular, 10-15 mm diam., green or tinged purple. seeds 2-2.5 mm long, greyish to dark brown. stone- cell granules 1-3 mm diam. aboriginal food plant in s.closely related to symonii eichler; distinguished by the globular fruit and smaller flowers. usually grows in sandy, often alkaline, soils, at baseof dunes, disturbed roadside areas, and alluvial gravels and terraces of seasonally flooded creeks. often associated with mallee eucalypt woodlands; abundantafter fire. ;

Eichler; distinguished by the globular fruit and smaller flowers. fire: flowering appears to be stimulated by fire.
description: rosette leaves 3-8, ovate, 5-11 x 3-7mm, dull green, margins entire. flower stem 100-400mm tall, wiry, 1-12-flowered. flowers moderately crowded, 1-4 open at once, 7-9 x 3-3.5mm, green and white, apex bright red-brown. dorsal sepal about as long as petals, scabrous, petals smooth. synsepalum flat to shallowly curved in side view, stepped sharply inwards at top; frontal opening flat with shallow notch. free points triangular-tapered, acuminate, 2-2.5mm long, just reaching top of hood. labellum not visible through sinus in any position, broadly elliptical, 3-3.5 x 1.2-1.4mm, red to red-brown and white, blunt. localised, growing among shrubs on ridges and slopes in forest dominated by messmate and long-leaved box in shallow clay loams that can be seasonally wet. notes often grows in open sites between shrubs and can also colonise tracks, road verges and disturbed sites. flowering appears to be stimulated by fire. apr-jun. ;

fire: flowering is promoted in the season following summer fires.
description: rosette leaves 3-7, ovate, 5-15 x 4-10mm, dark green, shiny, margins entire. flower stem 100-200mm tall, wiry, 1-4-flowered. flowers well spaced, 1-3 open at once, externally scabrous, 8-10 x 4-4.5mm, base green with prominent white patch, apex dark brown to blackish. dorsal sepal of similar length to petals, both scabrous. synsepalum bulging in side view, stepped in suddenly at top; frontal opening flat with central notch. free points sharply tapered, circa3.5mm long, just reaching top of hood. labellum not visible through sinus in any position, elliptical, 3.3-3.7 x 1.4-1.6mm, dark brown to red-brown and white, broadly blunt. highly localised, growing in heath and heathy forest developed on sandstone in freely draining to moisture-retentive sand and sandy clay loam. the plants commonly grow in open sites, often on margins of sandstone outcrops or in shallow soil in rock fissures or over rock plates, less commonly in moss under tall shrubs. notes remarkable in that growth cycle is completely the reverse of all other members of the genus. the rosettes emerge first in autumn and the inflorescences develop in spring. rosettes actually develop from the parent (old) tuber and the flower stem is produced from the new replacement tuber, while both tubers are still connected. in all other species of speculantha the rosette arises after flowering and is borne on a lateral growth from the base of the flower stem, often after flowering is finished. the rosettes of vernalis are always present at flowering time and new rosettes can subsequently develop on lateral growths which arise from the base of the inflorescence. the spring flowering period is also notable since related species flower in summer, autumn and early winter. flowering is promoted in the season following summer fires. aug-nov. ;
original_text: Rosette leaves 3-7, ovate, 5-15 x 4-10mm, dark green, shiny, margins entire. Flower stem 100-200mm tall, wiry, 1-4-flowered. Flowers well spaced, 1-3 open at once, externally scabrous, 8-10 x 4-4.5mm, base green with prominent white patch, apex dark brown to blackish. Dorsal sepal of similar length to petals, both scabrous. Synsepalum bulging in side view, stepped in suddenly at top; frontal opening flat with central notch. Free points sharply tapered, c.3.5mm long, just reaching top of hood. Labellum not visible through sinus in any position, elliptical, 3.3-3.7 x 1.4-1.6mm, dark brown to red-brown and white, broadly blunt. Highly localised, growing in heath and heathy forest developed on sandstone in freely draining to moisture-retentive sand and sandy clay loam. The plants commonly grow in open sites, often on margins of sandstone outcrops or in shallow soil in rock fissures or over rock plates, less commonly in moss under tall shrubs. Notes Remarkable in that growth cycle is completely the reverse of all other members of the genus. The rosettes emerge first in autumn and the inflorescences develop in spring. Rosettes actually develop from the parent (old) tuber and the flower stem is produced from the new replacement tuber, while both tubers are still connected. In all other species of Speculantha the rosette arises after flowering and is borne on a lateral growth from the base of the flower stem, often after flowering is finished. The rosettes of S. vernalis are always present at flowering time and new rosettes can subsequently develop on lateral growths which arise from the base of the inflorescence. The spring flowering period is also notable since related species flower in summer, autumn and early winter. Flowering is promoted in the season following summer fires. Aug-Nov.

fire: notes speculantha vescula has taken advantage of the mowing regime that is designed to keep the road verge clear within jervis bay nit more than likely occurs in other habitats in the vicinity of jervis bay but has probably been disadvantaged by the strictly controlled fire regimes imposed throughout the area.
description: rosette leaves 3-6, ovate, 3-10 x 3-8mm, green, margins entire. flower stem 80-200mm tall, very thin, wiry, 1-4-flowered. flowers moderately crowded, 1-2 open at once, externally scabrous, 7-9 x 3-3.5mm, pale green and brown. dorsal sepal about as long as petals, both scabrous. synsepalum bulging in side view, curved inwards at top; frontal opening deeply notched. free points triangular, acuminate, 2-2.5mm, just reaching top of hood. labellum tip visible through sinus opening in set position, narrowly obovate, 3.5-4 x 1-1.3mm, pale brown and white. highly localised and known from only one locality, growing in slashed heath and grassland beside road in freely draining grey-black sandy loam. surrounding vegetation is tall dense heathland which in the natural balance would be burnt regularly. notes speculantha vescula has taken advantage of the mowing regime that is designed to keep the road verge clear within jervis bay nit more than likely occurs in other habitats in the vicinity of jervis bay but has probably been disadvantaged by the strictly controlled fire regimes imposed throughout the area. mar-early may. ;
original_text: Rosette leaves 3-6, ovate, 3-10 x 3-8mm, green, margins entire. Flower stem 80-200mm tall, very thin, wiry, 1-4-flowered. Flowers moderately crowded, 1-2 open at once, externally scabrous, 7-9 x 3-3.5mm, pale green and brown. Dorsal sepal about as long as petals, both scabrous. Synsepalum bulging in side view, curved inwards at top; frontal opening deeply notched. Free points triangular, acuminate, 2-2.5mm, just reaching top of hood. Labellum tip visible through sinus opening in set position, narrowly obovate, 3.5-4 x 1-1.3mm, pale brown and white. Highly localised and known from only one locality, growing in slashed heath and grassland beside road in freely draining grey-black sandy loam. Surrounding vegetation is tall dense heathland which in the natural balance would be burnt regularly. Notes Speculantha vescula has taken advantage of the mowing regime that is designed to keep the road verge clear within Jervis Bay NP. It more than likely occurs in other habitats in the vicinity of Jervis Bay but has probably been disadvantaged by the strictly controlled fire regimes imposed throughout the area. Mar-early May.

fire: some species resprout after fire but sporadanthus strictus and the two new zealand species re-establish from seed.
description: herbs, dioecious or rarely some plants monoecious, perennial, rhizomatous or caespitose, base glabrous or pubescent. culms simple or branched, glabrous, smooth or minutely rugose. sheaths persistent, mostly closely appressed, glabrous; lamina terete, erect or reflexed. inflorescence erect, similar in both sexes; spikelet structure of inflorescences not obvious, subtending bracts similar to upper sheaths, usually shorter than the inflorescence branches. flowers sessile or shortly pedicellate, with 1 or 2 bracts; tepals 6, glabrous. male flowers: stamens 3, wholly or partly exserted; filaments free, filiform; pistillode present. female flowers: tepals similar to males; staminodes present; in australian species ovary 3-locular and styles 3, free, arising from the outer corners of the ovary summit, style bases persistent, fruit a capsule [or in new zealand species ovary 1-locular, style 1, fruit either dehiscent (ferrugineus de lange, heenan & b.d.clarkson) or an indehiscent nut (traversii (f.muell.) buchanan)]; carpel margins thickened and pale. seeds with an irregular network of raised 'plates' or ridges over irregularly arranged,  convex surface cells or with longitudinal lines of convex cells. culm anatomy: epidermal cells with sinuous walls and globular silica bodies, transverse (horizontal) lines of stomates visible on culm surface, chlorenchyma of horizontal plates of pali cells (2 layers of short cells), pillar cells absent, substomatal cavities lined by protective cells, central cavity angular, (2- or) 3-angled. reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. peg cells are pali chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. protective cells are modified chlorenchyma cells that are thick-walled and line the substomatal cavity, forming a tube extending all or part way through the chlorenchyma (cutler 1969). cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. floral bracts are one or two bracts on the floral axis; they mark the position of nodes where flowers in the spikelet do not develop. moist sites, swamps, bogs, stream banks. all species form cluster roots. such roots, with culms, form restiad peat in large bogs (campbell 1975, de lange et al. 1999). some species resprout after fire but sporadanthus strictus and the two new zealand species re-establish from seed. wind pollinated. ;
original_text: Herbs, dioecious or rarely some plants monoecious, perennial, rhizomatous or caespitose, base glabrous or pubescent. Culms simple or branched, glabrous, smooth or minutely rugose. Sheaths persistent, mostly closely appressed, glabrous; lamina terete, erect or reflexed. Inflorescence erect, similar in both sexes; spikelet structure of inflorescences not obvious, subtending bracts similar to upper sheaths, usually shorter than the inflorescence branches. Flowers sessile or shortly pedicellate, with 1 or 2 bracts; tepals 6, glabrous. Male flowers: stamens 3, wholly or partly exserted; filaments free, filiform; pistillode present. Female flowers: tepals similar to males; staminodes present; in Australian species ovary 3-locular and styles 3, free, arising from the outer corners of the ovary summit, style bases persistent, fruit a capsule [or in New Zealand species ovary 1-locular, style 1, fruit either dehiscent (S. ferrugineus de Lange, Heenan & B.D.Clarkson) or an indehiscent nut (S. traversii (F.Muell.) Buchanan)]; carpel margins thickened and pale. Seeds with an irregular network of raised 'plates' or ridges over irregularly arranged,  convex surface cells or with longitudinal lines of convex cells. Culm anatomy: epidermal cells with sinuous walls and globular silica bodies, transverse (horizontal) lines of stomates visible on culm surface, chlorenchyma of horizontal plates of palisade-like cells (2 layers of short cells), pillar cells absent, substomatal cavities lined by protective cells, central cavity angular, (2- or) 3-angled. Reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. Peg cells are palisade-like chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. Protective cells are modified chlorenchyma cells that are thick-walled and line the substomatal cavity, forming a tube extending all or part way through the chlorenchyma (Cutler 1969). Cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. Floral bracts are one or two bracts on the floral axis; they mark the position of nodes where flowers in the spikelet do not develop. Moist sites, swamps, bogs, stream banks. All species form cluster roots. Such roots, with culms, form restiad peat in large bogs (Campbell 1975, de Lange et al. 1999). Some species resprout after fire but Sporadanthus strictus and the two New Zealand species re-establish from seed. Wind pollinated.

reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. peg cells are pali chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. protective cells are modified chlorenchyma cells that are thick-walled and line the substomatal cavity, forming a tube extending all or part way through the chlorenchyma (cutler 1969). cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. floral bracts are one or two bracts on the floral axis; they mark the position of nodes where flowers in the spikelet do not develop. wet peaty or sandy soil, in open forest, melaleuca swamps and along creek banks. wind-pollinated. resprouts after fire. flowers may-june; fruits september. ;
original_text: Herb, dioecious, perennial, forming large diffuse patches. Cluster-roots present. Rhizomes stout, horizontal or arcuate, 5-6 mm diam., with a  continuous covering of brown scarious scales covering a pale woolly pubescence or glabrous. Cataphylls several, 5-25 cm long, appressed, brown, papery, covering the base of a greatly elongated sheath extending up the culm as much as 25 cm and sometimes with a second elongated sheath just above the first up to 15 cm long, dull brown, obtuse with an erect lamina c. 5 mm long. Culms spaced on the rhizome at intervals of c. 1-4 cm, terete, 1.0-1.5 m long, 2-7 mm diam. at the base, 1-2 mm diam. mid-culm, yellow- to blue-green, smooth to subrugose, simple or infrequently branched. Inflorescence usually interrupted, 3-10 cm long, with short ascending branches to 2 cm long densely crowded with flowers; spathes on the main axis  sheath-like although shorter and narrower and becoming acute and scarious towards the inflorescence apex; bracts numerous on the branches and to 5 mm long, lanceolate, hyaline, acuminate to aristate with a filiform awn, pale-brown. Reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. Peg cells are palisade-like chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. Protective cells are modified chlorenchyma cells that are thick-walled and line the substomatal cavity, forming a tube extending all or part way through the chlorenchyma (Cutler 1969). Cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. Floral bracts are one or two bracts on the floral axis; they mark the position of nodes where flowers in the spikelet do not develop. Wet peaty or sandy soil, in open forest, Melaleuca swamps and along creek banks. Wind-pollinated. Resprouts after fire. Flowers May-June; fruits September.

description: herb, dioecious or rarely monoecious, perennial, rhizomatous, forming large many-stemmed tussocks with the culms trailing and tangled. rhizomes horizontal, 3-8 mm diam., glabrous, with scarious scales that mostly weather away. cluster-roots present. cataphylls scarious, ovate-lanceolate, 1-3 cm long. culms erect or trailing, terete or subterete, with few or many branches, circa 30-150 cm long, 1-2 mm diam. near the base. sheaths 1-3 cm long, light-brown to red-brown, apex usually weathered; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. floral bracts are one or two bracts on the floral axis; they mark the position of nodes where flowers in the spikelet do not develop. wet sandy or peaty soil and margins of swamps; original_text: Herb, dioecious or rarely monoecious, perennial, rhizomatous, forming large many-stemmed tussocks with the culms trailing and tangled. Rhizomes horizontal, 3-8 mm diam., glabrous, with scarious scales that mostly weather away. Cluster-roots present. Cataphylls scarious, ovate-lanceolate, 1-3 cm long. Culms erect or trailing, terete or subterete, with few or many branches, c. 30-150 cm long, 1-2 mm diam. near the base. Sheaths 1-3 cm long, light-brown to red-brown, apex usually weathered; lamina terete, c. 2 mm long, present only on young sheaths. Inflorescence narrow, terminal, erect, 3-10 cm long; spathes on the main axis 10-15 mm long, much shorter than the branches that they subtend, distally membranous, fragile, soon weathering and becoming inconspicuous; secondary bracts broad-lanceolate, acute, membranous, 3-8 mm long; floral bracts lanceolate to ovate, hyaline, 1.2-3.5 mm long. Male flowers: tepals 6, ovate-lanceolate, mucronate, red-brown, glossy, becoming rigid; outer tepals 1.4-2.3 mm long; inner tepals distinctly longer, 2-2.7 mm long; filaments 1.4-2.0 mm long; anthers partly exserted, 1.0-1.6 mm long. Female flowers: tepals similar to males, becoming rigid in fruit. Capsule globular, 1-1.5 mm diam, with the bases of the 3 styles persistent as angular points. Seeds narrow-ovoid, surface cells polygonal to rectangular, elongated lengthwise along the seed, overlain by a network of narrow ridges. Culm anatomy: epidermal cells with sinuous walls and globular silica bodies, transverse (horizontal) pale bands of stomates visible on culm surface, chlorenchyma of horizontal plates of palisade-like cells (2 layers of short cells), substomatal cavities lined by protective cells, central cavity angular, (2- or) 3-angled. Reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; cataphylls are erect leaves at the base of the culms; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. Peg cells are palisade-like chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. Protective cells are modified chlorenchyma cells that are thick-walled and line the substomatal cavity, forming a tube extending all or part way through the chlorenchyma (Cutler 1969). Cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites. Floral bracts are one or two bracts on the floral axis; they mark the position of nodes where flowers in the spikelet do not develop. Wet sandy or peaty soil and margins of swamps; oligotrophic sites.  Wind-pollinated. Resprouts after fire. Flowers March-September.
