fire: shrub or perennial herb with fire-tolerant rootstock.
description: shrub or perennial herb with fire-tolerant rootstock. stems several, to 15 cm long. leaves borne along more than half the stem, soft; petiole terete, 4-10 mm long; lamina divided 4 or 5 times into terete, straight lobes; ultimate lobes erect, 1-5 mm long. scape 14-16 cm tall, simple or sparingly branched; branches erect; stems curved; heads 12-14 mm diam.; bracts lanceolate, acute, 1.5-3 mm long, glabrous. perianth 5 mm long; limb circa as wide as tube. fruit 2 mm diam., silky. distinguished especially by the small leaves that are less divided and extend further up the stem than in the other terete-leaved species. inland specimens have more woody stems. it has often been included in the synonymy of simplex . grows in sand in kwongan. flowers sept.-oct.; fruits nov.-dec. ;
original_text: Shrub or perennial herb with fire-tolerant rootstock. Stems several, to 15 cm long. Leaves borne along more than half the stem, soft; petiole terete, 4-10 mm long; lamina divided 4 or 5 times into terete, straight lobes; ultimate lobes erect, 1-5 mm long. Scape 14-16 cm tall, simple or sparingly branched; branches erect; stems curved; heads 12-14 mm diam.; bracts lanceolate, acute, 1.5-3 mm long, glabrous. Perianth 5 mm long; limb c. as wide as tube. Fruit 2 mm diam., silky. Distinguished especially by the small leaves that are less divided and extend further up the stem than in the other terete-leaved species. Inland specimens have more woody stems. It has often been included in the synonymy of S. simplex . Grows in sand in kwongan. Flowers Sept.-Oct.; fruits Nov.-Dec.

fire: flowering is enhanced the first season after fire.
description: shrub with woody rootstock. stems many, to 70 cm long. leaves extending well up stem, leathery; petiole 3-10 cm long, terete at base, flattened upwards; lamina to 10 cm long, divided up to 3 times into flat, obtuse, often shallowly hooded lobes 1-15 mm wide. scape to 1.5 m tall; panicle much-branched; heads 9-15 mm diam.; bracts ovate, obtuse to acute, 0.5-1 mm long, glabrous. perianth 3-7 mm long; limb narrower than tube. nut 4-5.5 mm diam., silky, hairy on top. easily distinguished by the robust habit, flat leaf segments and large nut. variable in the width of leaf lobes and in the size and density of the panicle. flowers pungently scented. the common name refers to the fact that wall plaster made using sand from where the species occurs turns blue. flowering is enhanced the first season after fire. grows in deep sand, in kwongan, shrubland and woodland. flowers sept.-oct.; fruits oct.-jan. ;
original_text: Shrub with woody rootstock. Stems many, to 70 cm long. Leaves extending well up stem, leathery; petiole 3-10 cm long, terete at base, flattened upwards; lamina to 10 cm long, divided up to 3 times into flat, obtuse, often shallowly hooded lobes 1-15 mm wide. Scape to 1.5 m tall; panicle much-branched; heads 9-15 mm diam.; bracts ovate, obtuse to acute, 0.5-1 mm long, glabrous. Perianth 3-7 mm long; limb narrower than tube. Nut 4-5.5 mm diam., silky, hairy on top. Easily distinguished by the robust habit, flat leaf segments and large nut. Variable in the width of leaf lobes and in the size and density of the panicle. Flowers pungently scented. The common name refers to the fact that wall plaster made using sand from where the species occurs turns blue. Flowering is enhanced the first season after fire. Grows in deep sand, in kwongan, shrubland and woodland. Flowers Sept.-Oct.; fruits Oct.-Jan.

fire: perennial herb with verrucose taproot, probably fire-sensitive.
description: perennial herb with verrucose taproot, probably fire-sensitive. stems 1-several, 5-25 cm long. leaves soft; petiole 1.5-6.5 cm long; lamina divided up to 10 times into terete, curved lobes; ultimate lobes erect, 1-4 mm long. scape 10-100 cm tall, openly branched; stems curved; heads 10-12 mm diam.; bracts ovate-triangular, obtuse, 0.8-1.2 mm long, tomentose. perianth 5-6 mm long; limb narrower than tube. nut 2 mm diam., densely silky. variable in size of plant, sometimes flowering when circa 10 cm tall, possibly in the first year. grows in sand and shale, in kwongan or woodland on hillsides and low-lying areas. flowers sept.-oct.; fruits nov.-dec. ;
original_text: Perennial herb with verrucose taproot, probably fire-sensitive. Stems 1-several, 5-25 cm long. Leaves soft; petiole 1.5-6.5 cm long; lamina divided up to 10 times into terete, curved lobes; ultimate lobes erect, 1-4 mm long. Scape 10-100 cm tall, openly branched; stems curved; heads 10-12 mm diam.; bracts ovate-triangular, obtuse, 0.8-1.2 mm long, tomentose. Perianth 5-6 mm long; limb narrower than tube. Nut 2 mm diam., densely silky. Variable in size of plant, sometimes flowering when c. 10 cm tall, possibly in the first year. Grows in sand and shale, in kwongan or woodland on hillsides and low-lying areas. Flowers Sept.-Oct.; fruits Nov.-Dec.

fire: plants sometimes with fire-tolerant rootstock, sometimes suckering. seed set in most species, even fire-sensitive ones, is low.
description: small shrubs. adult leaves usually pinnatipartite, sometimes pinnate, simple or little-divided; petiole with sheathing base; secondary venation a fine reticulum. flowers bisexual, in terminal or axillary spikes, each solitary, subtended by a bract. perianth tubular, zygomorphic, yellow, opening in upper third to half; adaxial tepal longest and broadest, hooded; lateral 2 falcate; abaxial smallest, usually with a small, reflexed tip. stamens on short, thick filaments; adaxial sterile; 2 lateral 1-locular; abaxial 2-locular; pollen ejected mechanically. stigma p or narrow, usually 2-lobed and with a narrow, semitranslucent border, dorsally attached from its base to sterile filament by a narrow column; ovary 1-locular, sessile, in all but 1 species with an apical ring of large, translucent glands; ovule 1. fruit an obovoid, ellipsoidal or cylindrical, crustaceous nut. the flora of australia recognised the genus with 50 species, but research is continuing towards resolving several species complexes as well as the infrasectional classification in sect. synaphea. since publication of the flora of australia the australian plant census lists 52 species. plants sometimes with fire-tolerant rootstock, sometimes suckering. leaf morphology is extraordinarily varied whereas flower colour is relatively uniform. first seedling and regrowth leaves (in species for which these stages are known) are always simple and entire. in many species, particularly those with inflorescences greatly exceeding the foliage, the spikes elongate markedly during development; in the descriptions below, length of spike and flower density are taken at an early- to mid-flowering stage. the flowers are scentless or in some species possibly faintly scented. at anthesis the anthers and stigma are held tightly together under tension; on being touched, the stigma flicks across and the pollen is ejected (as in conospermum ). thus the style end is not a passive pollen presenter as in many proteaceae. the purpose of the translucent glands on the apex of the ovary is unknown. pollinators are also unknown. seed set in most species, even fire-sensitive ones, is low. for the leaves, only those of flowering stems are described. upper leaves are usually smaller than lower. in addition to general shape and division, the three-dimensional form of the leaf varies between species: the terms 'flat', 'undulate' and 'multiplanar' are used, the last for leaves in which the lobes (which may be flat or concave) are held in various planes. the appearance of the reticulate leaf venation is described from the dried state when differences between species are more marked than in the fresh state. the tip of the abaxial tepal is usually reflexed and is described only when there is a significant difference from that state. measurements of floral parts were taken from pickled or soaked flowers. the length of the stigma includes the apical lobes or horns. ;
original_text: Small shrubs. Adult leaves usually pinnatipartite, sometimes pinnate, simple or little-divided; petiole with sheathing base; secondary venation a fine reticulum. Flowers bisexual, in terminal or axillary spikes, each solitary, subtended by a bract. Perianth tubular, zygomorphic, yellow, opening in upper third to half; adaxial tepal longest and broadest, hooded; lateral 2 falcate; abaxial smallest, usually with a small, reflexed tip. Stamens on short, thick filaments; adaxial sterile; 2 lateral 1-locular; abaxial 2-locular; pollen ejected mechanically. Stigma plate-like or narrow, usually 2-lobed and with a narrow, semitranslucent border, dorsally attached from its base to sterile filament by a narrow column; ovary 1-locular, sessile, in all but 1 species with an apical ring of large, translucent glands; ovule 1. Fruit an obovoid, ellipsoidal or cylindrical, crustaceous nut. The Flora of Australia recognised the genus with 50 species, but research is continuing towards resolving several species complexes as well as the infrasectional classification in sect. Synaphea. Since publication of the Flora of Australia the Australian Plant Census lists 52 species. Plants sometimes with fire-tolerant rootstock, sometimes suckering. Leaf morphology is extraordinarily varied whereas flower colour is relatively uniform. First seedling and regrowth leaves (in species for which these stages are known) are always simple and entire. In many species, particularly those with inflorescences greatly exceeding the foliage, the spikes elongate markedly during development; in the descriptions below, length of spike and flower density are taken at an early- to mid-flowering stage. The flowers are scentless or in some species possibly faintly scented. At anthesis the anthers and stigma are held tightly together under tension; on being touched, the stigma flicks across and the pollen is ejected (as in Conospermum ). Thus the style end is not a passive pollen presenter as in many Proteaceae. The purpose of the translucent glands on the apex of the ovary is unknown. Pollinators are also unknown. Seed set in most species, even fire-sensitive ones, is low. For the leaves, only those of flowering stems are described. Upper leaves are usually smaller than lower. In addition to general shape and division, the three-dimensional form of the leaf varies between species: the terms 'flat', 'undulate' and 'multiplanar' are used, the last for leaves in which the lobes (which may be flat or concave) are held in various planes. The appearance of the reticulate leaf venation is described from the dried state when differences between species are more marked than in the fresh state. The tip of the abaxial tepal is usually reflexed and is described only when there is a significant difference from that state. Measurements of floral parts were taken from pickled or soaked flowers. The length of the stigma includes the apical lobes or horns.

fire: rootstock probably fire-tolerant.
description: stems 1-several, to 35 cm tall, appressed-pubescent, glabrescent. leaves tripartite; petiole 4-6 mm long, reduced to sheathing base; lower leaves with petiole to 6 cm long; lamina 2-3 cm long, 3-5 cm wide, very undulate and multiplanar, sparsely puberulous, glabrescent; primary lobes 3-4 mm wide, very concave; secondary lobes tripartite, concave, pungently 1-3-dentate. spikes 1-3 cm long; flowers crowded; peduncle 1-2 cm long, pubescent; rachis puberulous; bracts 2 mm long, obtuse, glabrous except puberulous base and margins. perianth opening narrowly, sparsely puberulous; adaxial tepal 5-6.5 mm long, 1.8-2.8 mm wide, straight but convex over stigma; abaxial tepal 5 mm long with erect, narrow apex. stigma ovate to oblong with broadened base, minutely emarginate, concave, very thick, incurved at apex, 1.4-1.8 mm long, 0.9-1.1 mm wide; ovary pubescent. fruit ellipsoidal, beaked, 5 mm long, pilose. for many years this name has been used in a broad sense to include spinulosa and several taxa separated here, such as media . synaphea polymorpha can be distinguished readily by its longer, oblong stigma with incurved apex. the stems are usually red, in contrast to the pale yellow or green stems of spinulosa and media . rootstock probably fire-tolerant. grows in sandy loam and lateritic soil, in woodland and kwongan. flowers aug.-nov. ;
original_text: Stems 1-several, to 35 cm tall, appressed-pubescent, glabrescent. Leaves tripartite; petiole 4-6 mm long, reduced to sheathing base; lower leaves with petiole to 6 cm long; lamina 2-3 cm long, 3-5 cm wide, very undulate and multiplanar, sparsely puberulous, glabrescent; primary lobes 3-4 mm wide, very concave; secondary lobes tripartite, concave, pungently 1-3-dentate. Spikes 1-3 cm long; flowers crowded; peduncle 1-2 cm long, pubescent; rachis puberulous; bracts 2 mm long, obtuse, glabrous except puberulous base and margins. Perianth opening narrowly, sparsely puberulous; adaxial tepal 5-6.5 mm long, 1.8-2.8 mm wide, straight but convex over stigma; abaxial tepal 5 mm long with erect, narrow apex. Stigma ovate to oblong with broadened base, minutely emarginate, concave, very thick, incurved at apex, 1.4-1.8 mm long, 0.9-1.1 mm wide; ovary pubescent. Fruit ellipsoidal, beaked, 5 mm long, pilose. For many years this name has been used in a broad sense to include S. spinulosa and several taxa separated here, such as S. media . Synaphea polymorpha can be distinguished readily by its longer, oblong stigma with incurved apex. The stems are usually red, in contrast to the pale yellow or green stems of S. spinulosa and S. media . Rootstock probably fire-tolerant. Grows in sandy loam and lateritic soil, in woodland and kwongan. Flowers Aug.-Nov.

fire: rootstock fire-tolerant.
description: stems pubescent, often also hirsute. bracts acute, 2-3 mm long, silky-pubescent. perianth finely pubescent; adaxial tepal 4.4-5 mm long, 1.4-2 mm wide; abaxial tepal 3.5-4 mm long. stigma transversely elliptic to squarish obovate, 0.9-1 mm long and wide, flat or margins reflexed. fruit 4-5 mm long. rootstock fire-tolerant. very variable. welshpool, f.m.c.schock , has the adaxial tepal 6.5 mm long and 2.5 mm wide, and the abaxial tepal 5.5 mm long. collections from as far north as geraldton and from the central wheatbelt may belong here. grows in sand and sandy gravel in banksia woodland and kwongan. flowers july-oct. ;
original_text: Stems pubescent, often also hirsute. Bracts acute, 2-3 mm long, silky-pubescent. Perianth finely pubescent; adaxial tepal 4.4-5 mm long, 1.4-2 mm wide; abaxial tepal 3.5-4 mm long. Stigma transversely elliptic to squarish obovate, 0.9-1 mm long and wide, flat or margins reflexed. Fruit 4-5 mm long. Rootstock fire-tolerant. Very variable. Welshpool, F.M.C.Schock , has the adaxial tepal 6.5 mm long and 2.5 mm wide, and the abaxial tepal 5.5 mm long. Collections from as far north as Geraldton and from the central wheatbelt may belong here. Grows in sand and sandy gravel in Banksia woodland and kwongan. Flowers July-Oct.

fire: resprouts after fire or disturbance.
description: herb, perennial, dioecious, rhizomatous, with culms and rhizomes arising from a narrow base; rhizomes stout; plants glabrous except for tufts of hairs in the cataphyll and sheath axils; cluster roots present. culms stout and erect near base, much-branched, striate, with appressed, persistent sheaths; upper branches slender, terete to compressed, flexuose, forming tangled masses. male spikelets in small clusters at several upper nodes of culm branches, the glumes mostly fertile. female spikelets solitary at several upper nodes, 1-flowered. male flowers: tepals 5 (or 6), 2 outer tepals keeled, inner tepals flat; stamens 3, anthers exserted. female flowers: glumes and tepals reduced to small membranous scales; ovary unilocular, style branches 3 (less often 2), shortly connate. fruit a capsule (meney et al. 1999), seeds rarely produced, mature fruit and seed not seen. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 1 layer of elongated peg cells interrupted by pillar cells over some outer vascular bundles, protective cells lacking; central cavity lobed or angular in the lower culm resulting from inner vascular bundles arranged in large aggregations that are separated by a broad band of sclerenchyma from the outer vascular bundles. most female plants bearing numerous large spik galls. reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. peg cells are pali chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. pillar cells are elongate, pali cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. protective cells are modified chlorenchyma cells that are thick-walled and line the substomatal cavity (cutler 1969). cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites.  an informative online interactive key to the western australian restionaceae species, with abundant photographs, is given by hollister & thiele (2014). flood-beds or river banks, in a high rainfall region; sites moist most of the year. wind-pollinated; resprouts after fire or disturbance. ;
original_text: Herb, perennial, dioecious, rhizomatous, with culms and rhizomes arising from a narrow base; rhizomes stout; plants glabrous except for tufts of hairs in the cataphyll and sheath axils; cluster roots present. Culms stout and erect near base, much-branched, striate, with appressed, persistent sheaths; upper branches slender, terete to compressed, flexuose, forming tangled masses. Male spikelets in small clusters at several upper nodes of culm branches, the glumes mostly fertile. Female spikelets solitary at several upper nodes, 1-flowered. Male flowers: tepals 5 (or 6), 2 outer tepals keeled, inner tepals flat; stamens 3, anthers exserted. Female flowers: glumes and tepals reduced to small membranous scales; ovary unilocular, style branches 3 (less often 2), shortly connate. Fruit a capsule (Meney et al. 1999), seeds rarely produced, mature fruit and seed not seen. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 1 layer of elongated peg cells interrupted by pillar cells over some outer vascular bundles, protective cells lacking; central cavity lobed or angular in the lower culm resulting from inner vascular bundles arranged in large aggregations that are separated by a broad band of sclerenchyma from the outer vascular bundles. Most female plants bearing numerous large spikelet-like galls. Reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. Peg cells are palisade-like chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. Pillar cells are elongate, palisade-like cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. Protective cells are modified chlorenchyma cells that are thick-walled and line the substomatal cavity (Cutler 1969). Cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites.  An informative online interactive key to the Western Australian Restionaceae species, with abundant photographs, is given by Hollister & Thiele (2014). Flood-beds or river banks, in a high rainfall region; sites moist most of the year. Wind-pollinated; resprouts after fire or disturbance.

fire: regenerates after fire by resprouting.
description: herb, perennial, dioecious, rhizomatous, glabrous except for tufts of hairs in the cataphyll and sheath axils. rhizomes long, creeping or ascending, 5-7 mm diam.; cluster roots present. culms to 2 m long, blue-grey, stout and erect toward the base, 4-7 mm diam.; upper branches slender and flexuose. sheaths appressed, green to brown or straw-coloured, 0.5-3.0 cm long; lamina erect, herbaceous, filiform, 1-3 mm long. male spikelets ellipsoidal, 3.3-7.0 mm long; glumes 4-13, acute to mucronate, keeled, 2.8-4.0 mm long, purplish to green or straw-coloured, glabrous or basally pubescent; mucro to 2.2 mm long. female spikelets: 1-flowered, only the stigmas emerging from the subtending spathe; glumes 2 or 3, scarious, ovate, circa 0.3 mm long;. male flowers: tepals 5 (or 6), lanceolate, acute; outer tepals slightly longer, 2.4-3.2 mm long; stamens 3, anthers exserted, filaments 3-5 mm long, anthers 1.2-2.0 mm long. female flowers: tepals reduced to small membranous deltoid scales circa 0.7 mm long; ovary unilocular, style branches 3 (less often 2), fused 1/8-1/2 of length. most female plants bear numerous large spik galls, 1.2-3.5 cm long with circa 80 sterile 'glumes', the 'glumes' 6-15 mm long, narrow-elliptic, acuminate, green or straw-coloured. seed rarely produced and not seen. culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 1 layer of elongated peg cells interrupted by pillar cells over some outer vascular bundles, central cavity lobed or angular in the lower culm resulting from inner vascular bundles arranged in large aggregations that are separated by a broad band of sclerenchyma from the outer vascular bundles. large spik galls with pale narrow-lanceolate scarious 'glumes' frequent on female plants. reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. peg cells are pali chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. pillar cells are elongate, pali cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened (lignified) walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites.  an informative online interactive key to the western australian species of restionaceae, with abundant photographs, is given by hollister & thiele (2014). flood-beds or river banks, often in dense thickets in wooded or tall shrubland areas; in a region of high rainfall, in seasonally or permanently wet sands and peats; sites moist most of the year. wind-pollinated but fruits rarely formed; regenerates after fire by resprouting. flowers spring. ;
original_text: Herb, perennial, dioecious, rhizomatous, glabrous except for tufts of hairs in the cataphyll and sheath axils. Rhizomes long, creeping or ascending, 5-7 mm diam.; cluster roots present. Culms to 2 m long, blue-grey, stout and erect toward the base, 4-7 mm diam.; upper branches slender and flexuose. Sheaths appressed, green to brown or straw-coloured, 0.5-3.0 cm long; lamina erect, herbaceous, filiform, 1-3 mm long. Male spikelets ellipsoidal, 3.3-7.0 mm long; glumes 4-13, acute to mucronate, keeled, 2.8-4.0 mm long, purplish to green or straw-coloured, glabrous or basally pubescent; mucro to 2.2 mm long. Female spikelets: 1-flowered, only the stigmas emerging from the subtending spathe; glumes 2 or 3, scarious, ovate, c. 0.3 mm long;. Male flowers: tepals 5 (or 6), lanceolate, acute; outer tepals slightly longer, 2.4-3.2 mm long; stamens 3, anthers exserted, filaments 3-5 mm long, anthers 1.2-2.0 mm long. Female flowers: tepals reduced to small membranous deltoid scales c. 0.7 mm long; ovary unilocular, style branches 3 (less often 2), fused 1/8-1/2 of length. Most female plants bear numerous large spikelet-like galls, 1.2-3.5 cm long with c. 80 sterile 'glumes', the 'glumes' 6-15 mm long, narrow-elliptic, acuminate, green or straw-coloured. Seed rarely produced and not seen. Culm anatomy: chlorenchyma of 1 layer of elongated peg cells interrupted by pillar cells over some outer vascular bundles, central cavity lobed or angular in the lower culm resulting from inner vascular bundles arranged in large aggregations that are separated by a broad band of sclerenchyma from the outer vascular bundles. Large spikelet-like galls with pale narrow-lanceolate scarious 'glumes' frequent on female plants. Reduced leaves on horizontal rhizomes are referred to as scales; reduced leaves on the culm as sheaths; spathes are the primary bracts subtending the inflorescence or inflorescence branches. Peg cells are palisade-like chlorenchyma cells with lines of peg-like projections that meet the similar projections of adjacent cells. Pillar cells are elongate, palisade-like cells of the parenchyma sheath, usually with moderately thickened (lignified) walls, radiating from the sclerenchyma sheath to the epidermis, dividing the chlorenchyma into longitudinal bands. Cluster roots form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets; they may form a mat just beneath the soil surface and are mostly found in plants of oligotrophic sites.  An informative online interactive key to the Western Australian species of Restionaceae, with abundant photographs, is given by Hollister & Thiele (2014). Flood-beds or river banks, often in dense thickets in wooded or tall shrubland areas; in a region of high rainfall, in seasonally or permanently wet sands and peats; sites moist most of the year. Wind-pollinated but fruits rarely formed; regenerates after fire by resprouting. Flowers spring.

fire: often abundant after fire.
description: prostrate, robust herb with stems to 2 m long, glabrous. leaves narrowly linear, usually semi-terete, acute, mostly 2-9 cm long, rarely obovate; stipules minute. male plant: flowers in erect or ascending axillary and terminal racemes of up to 10 flowers; calyx broadly cupular, 2 mm long, shallowly lobed; stamens 11-17, the anthers 1.3 mm long; disc smooth. female plant: flowers solitary, axillary, sessile or shortly pedicellate; calyx circa 1 mm long, the lobes triangular-ovate; ovary depressed-spherical, 3-4 mm diam., granular-papillose; stigmas tapering, 2-4 mm long, shortly united. fruit indehiscent, depressed-spherical, hard, 10-20 mm diam., rugose to echinate, rarely almost smooth, orange-brown becoming straw-coloured; apical orifice enclosing old stigmas. seed oblong, smooth, 2.5 mm long, bright brown, with basal aril. a collection from stockyard gully (george 11779, perth) represents either a new species of tersonia or a new genus. lt is an erect shrub with lanceolate leaves and syncarpous, 5-7-1ocular ovary; the male is unknown. grows in sand, often over limestone, in heath andlow open-woodland; often abundant after fire. ;
original_text: Prostrate, robust herb with stems to 2 m long, glabrous. Leaves narrowly linear, usually semi-terete, acute, mostly 2-9 cm long, rarely obovate; stipules minute. Male plant: flowers in erect or ascending axillary and terminal racemes of up to 10 flowers; calyx broadly cupular, 2 mm long, shallowly lobed; stamens 11-17, the anthers 1.3 mm long; disc smooth. Female plant: flowers solitary, axillary, sessile or shortly pedicellate; calyx c. 1 mm long, the lobes triangular-ovate; ovary depressed-spherical, 3-4 mm diam., granular-papillose; stigmas tapering, 2-4 mm long, shortly united. Fruit indehiscent, depressed-spherical, hard, 10-20 mm diam., rugose to echinate, rarely almost smooth, orange-brown becoming straw-coloured; apical orifice enclosing old stigmas. Seed oblong, smooth, 2.5 mm long, bright brown, with basal aril. A collection from Stockyard Gully (A. S. George 11779, PERTH) represents either a new species of Tersonia or a new genus. lt is an erect shrub with lanceolate leaves and syncarpous, 5-7-1ocular ovary; the male is unknown. Grows in sand, often over limestone, in heath andlow open-woodland; often abundant after fire.

simplified_phrase: killed by hot fires; resprouts from surviving vegetative buds
fire: notes plants of these orchids are commonly killed by hot fires but large clumps can often regenerate from vegetative buds surviving within the clump.
description: roots spreading (rarely erect). pseudobulbs usually tapered, occasionally cylindrical, 100-400 x 30-60mm, straight or curved, green or yellowish, round in cross-section. leaves 2-5, spreading, 100-250 x 40-80mm, thick, leathery, dark green. racemes 200-600mm long, 30-100-flowered, with or without short peduncle. flowers 45-65 x 40-52mm, white, cream or dull yellow, crowded. dorsal sepal 25-33 x 4-6mm. lateral sepals 20-25 x 7-9mm. petals 20-30 x 1.5-3mm. labellum 10-15 x 10-13mm, spotted or streaked with reddish-purple; gap between lateral lobes and midlobe short and narrow; lateral lobes erect, blunt; midlobe broadly rounded. widespread and common in coastal localities, in some areas overlooking the ocean, but also extending w to ranges, tablelands and gorges, growing on rocks, boulders, gorges, escarpments, cliff faces and trees in wide range of habitats and positions from exposed to shade. notes plants of these orchids are commonly killed by hot fires but large clumps can often regenerate from vegetative buds surviving within the clump. poll. all variants in this complex are mainly outcrossing and range of insects are attracted to the flowers including native bees, syrphid flies and introduced honey bees. the most efficient pollinators are native bees in the genus tetragonula (formerly trigona - more than one species is involved) with other genera, hylaeus (colletidae), lasioglossum and homalictus brisbanensis (both in halictidae), observed to remove pollinia and classified as probable pollinators (adams (1991). var: the following components of this complex have previously been recognised as distinct taxa and given formal botanical names, but are now informally grouped here as variants of speciosus. most of these variants are cultivated by enthusiasts and their alternative names are included below to help recognise change in status. these variants are often difficult to define with certainty due to lack of genetic stability and the impact of hybridisation. ¢€š¬¢ thelychiton epiphyticus d.l.jones¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯m.a.clem. (2006) notes a variant from the illawarra region of nsw (robertson to cambewarra) that grows on trees in tall moist to wet forests, including rainforest, and around waterfalls and escarpments and on cliff faces. it was segregated from speciosus based on long, usually cylindrical pseudobulbs and racemes with a short thick peduncle. ¢€š¬¢ thelychiton tarberi (m.a.clem.¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯d.l.jones) m.a.clem.¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯d.l.jones (2002) other names: dendrobium speciosum var hillii mast. (1877), speciosum subsp hillii (mast.) d.p.banks¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯clemesha, (1990), tarberi m.a.clem.¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯d.l.jones (1989). notes a widespread and common variant known by aborigines around brisbane as tar beri that has erect litter-trapping roots, cylindrical pseudobulbs, racemes without obvious peduncle and small, white or cream flowers. it ranges from maleny in se qld to mangrove mtn in nsw and inland to darling downs growing on trees and rocks in moist forest and rainforest, sometimes forming huge clumps several metres across. plants from inland areas grow on rocks and have shorter pseudobulbs thick at base and fewer aerial roots. ¢€š¬¢ thelychiton rex (m.a.clem.¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯d.l.jones) m.a.clem.¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯d.l.jones (2002) other names: dendrobium speciosum var grandiflorum f.m.bailey (1896), rex m.a.clem.¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯d.l.jones (1989), speciosum subsp grandiflorum (f.m.bailey) d.p.banks¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯clemesha (1990). notes a common variant, spectacular when in flower, that has a mixture of erect litter-trapping roots and spreading roots, short to long pseudobulbs that are usually cylindrical, racemes without an obvious peduncle and large, creamy-yellow to bright yellow flowers. it is locally common in central and s qld (mt larcom-calliope ra. to bunya mtns-conondale) growing on trees and rocks on ridges and slopes in rainforest and streamside vegetation. plants growing on trees form large bulky clumps with upright growth habit, whereas plants on rocks tend to have shorter pseudobulbs with swollen base. ¢€š¬¢ thelychiton capricornicus (clemesha) m.a.clem.¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯d.l.jones (2002) other names: dendrobium speciosum var capricornicum clemesha (1982). notes a localised variant that has spreading roots, cylindrical pseudobulbs, arching to drooping racemes with long peduncle and small white flowers. it grows on rock faces of old volcanic plugs in central qld (byfield ra. to yeppoon and rockhampton area). new growths are sometimes stained purplish. ¢€š¬¢ thelychiton coriaceus d.l.jones¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯m.a.clem. (2006) other names: dendrobium speciosum var carnarvonense p.b.adams (2006), speciosum var blackdownense p.b.adams (2006). notes an inland variant that has spreading roots, relatively short tapered pseudobulbs, racemes with slender smooth peduncle and thick and fleshy, creamy-yellow to yellow flowers. it grows on boulders, escarpments and cliff faces in central qld (blackdown tlnd, carnarvon gorge and mt moffat). new growths and young leaves are dark purple colour. jul-oct. ;
original_text: Roots spreading (rarely erect). Pseudobulbs usually tapered, occasionally cylindrical, 100-400 x 30-60mm, straight or curved, green or yellowish, round in cross-section. Leaves 2-5, spreading, 100-250 x 40-80mm, thick, leathery, dark green. Racemes 200-600mm long, 30-100-flowered, with or without short peduncle. Flowers 45-65 x 40-52mm, white, cream or dull yellow, crowded. Dorsal sepal 25-33 x 4-6mm. Lateral sepals 20-25 x 7-9mm. Petals 20-30 x 1.5-3mm. Labellum 10-15 x 10-13mm, spotted or streaked with reddish-purple; gap between lateral lobes and midlobe short and narrow; lateral lobes erect, blunt; midlobe broadly rounded. Widespread and common in coastal localities, in some areas overlooking the ocean, but also extending W to ranges, tablelands and gorges, growing on rocks, boulders, gorges, escarpments, cliff faces and trees in wide range of habitats and positions from exposed to shade. Notes Plants of these orchids are commonly killed by hot fires but large clumps can often regenerate from vegetative buds surviving within the clump. Poll. All variants in this complex are mainly outcrossing and range of insects are attracted to the flowers including native bees, syrphid flies and introduced honey bees. The most efficient pollinators are native bees in the genus Tetragonula (formerly Trigona - more than one species is involved) with other genera, Hylaeus (Colletidae), Lasioglossum and Homalictus brisbanensis (both in Halictidae), observed to remove pollinia and classified as probable pollinators (Adams (1991). Var.: The following components of this complex have previously been recognised as distinct taxa and given formal botanical names, but are now informally grouped here as variants of T. speciosus. Most of these variants are cultivated by enthusiasts and their alternative names are included below to help recognise change in status. These variants are often difficult to define with certainty due to lack of genetic stability and the impact of hybridisation. ¢€š¬¢ Thelychiton epiphyticus D.L.Jones¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯M.A.Clem. (2006) Notes A variant from the Illawarra region of NSW (Robertson to Cambewarra) that grows on trees in tall moist to wet forests, including rainforest, and around waterfalls and escarpments and on cliff faces. It was segregated from T. speciosus based on long, usually cylindrical pseudobulbs and racemes with a short thick peduncle. ¢€š¬¢ Thelychiton tarberi (M.A.Clem.¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯D.L.Jones) M.A.Clem.¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯D.L.Jones (2002) Other names: Dendrobium speciosum var. hillii Mast. (1877), D. speciosum subsp. hillii (Mast.) D.P.Banks¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯Clemesha, (1990), D. tarberi M.A.Clem.¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯D.L.Jones (1989). Notes A widespread and common variant known by Aborigines around Brisbane as Tar Beri that has erect litter-trapping roots, cylindrical pseudobulbs, racemes without obvious peduncle and small, white or cream flowers. It ranges from Maleny in SE Qld to Mangrove Mtn in NSW and inland to Darling Downs growing on trees and rocks in moist forest and rainforest, sometimes forming huge clumps several metres across. Plants from inland areas grow on rocks and have shorter pseudobulbs thick at base and fewer aerial roots. ¢€š¬¢ Thelychiton rex (M.A.Clem.¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯D.L.Jones) M.A.Clem.¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯D.L.Jones (2002) Other names: Dendrobium speciosum var. grandiflorum F.M.Bailey (1896), D. rex M.A.Clem.¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯D.L.Jones (1989), D. speciosum subsp. grandiflorum (F.M.Bailey) D.P.Banks¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯Clemesha (1990). Notes A common variant, spectacular when in flower, that has a mixture of erect litter-trapping roots and spreading roots, short to long pseudobulbs that are usually cylindrical, racemes without an obvious peduncle and large, creamy-yellow to bright yellow flowers. It is locally common in central and S Qld (Mt Larcom-Calliope Ra. to Bunya Mtns-Conondale) growing on trees and rocks on ridges and slopes in rainforest and streamside vegetation. Plants growing on trees form large bulky clumps with upright growth habit, whereas plants on rocks tend to have shorter pseudobulbs with swollen base. ¢€š¬¢ Thelychiton capricornicus (Clemesha) M.A.Clem.¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯D.L.Jones (2002) Other names: Dendrobium speciosum var. capricornicum Clemesha (1982). Notes A localised variant that has spreading roots, cylindrical pseudobulbs, arching to drooping racemes with long peduncle and small white flowers. It grows on rock faces of old volcanic plugs in central Qld (Byfield Ra. to Yeppoon and Rockhampton area). New growths are sometimes stained purplish. ¢€š¬¢ Thelychiton coriaceus D.L.Jones¢€š¬¯&¢€š¬¯M.A.Clem. (2006) Other names: Dendrobium speciosum var. carnarvonense P.B.Adams (2006), D. speciosum var. blackdownense P.B.Adams (2006). Notes An inland variant that has spreading roots, relatively short tapered pseudobulbs, racemes with slender smooth peduncle and thick and fleshy, creamy-yellow to yellow flowers. It grows on boulders, escarpments and cliff faces in central Qld (Blackdown Tlnd, Carnarvon Gorge and Mt Moffat). New growths and young leaves are dark purple colour. Jul-Oct.

fire: mostly seen on firebreaks and along edges of tracks.
description: leaf 40-100 x circa2mm, dull green with pink tints. flower stem 100-220 x circa0.8mm, pink, 1-4-flowered. sterile bracts two. flowers 8-12mm across, deep blue or purple-blue with dark blue lines and few relatively large dark spots on petals and dorsal sepal. sepals and petals 5-7 x 2.5-3mm (labellum smallest); externally sepals pink or brown with white edges. column 4-5 x 2-2.5mm, white or pale blue; post-anther lobe short, partly hooding anther, dark blue with angular red apex ending abruptly as if cut off; column arms 0.5-0.8mm long, straight or sharply upcurved; hair-tufts mop-like, sparse, white, hairs circa0.5mm long. anther in middle of column. highly restricted, growing in low heathland in moist to wet sandy or peaty soils around margins of swamps and peat bogs; mostly seen on firebreaks and along edges of tracks. notes the flowers, which generally open tardily even on warm humid days are short-lived and apparently self-pollinating. late oct-early nov. ;
original_text: Leaf 40-100 x c.2mm, dull green with pink tints. Flower stem 100-220 x c.0.8mm, pink, 1-4-flowered. Sterile bracts two. Flowers 8-12mm across, deep blue or purple-blue with dark blue lines and few relatively large dark spots on petals and dorsal sepal. Sepals and petals 5-7 x 2.5-3mm (labellum smallest); externally sepals pink or brown with white edges. Column 4-5 x 2-2.5mm, white or pale blue; post-anther lobe short, partly hooding anther, dark blue with angular red apex ending abruptly as if cut off; column arms 0.5-0.8mm long, straight or sharply upcurved; hair-tufts mop-like, sparse, white, hairs c.0.5mm long. Highly restricted, growing in low heathland in moist to wet sandy or peaty soils around margins of swamps and peat bogs; mostly seen on firebreaks and along edges of tracks. fire: flowering is greatly enhanced by summer fires resulting in impressive floral displays.
description: leaf terete or channelled, 50-180 x 2-3mm, dark green, base reddish. flower stem flexuose, 150-300 x 1.5-2mm, wiry, often pinkish, 1-4-flowered. sterile bracts two. flowers 20-35mm across, internally pale yellow to deep yellow (rarely white), externally reddish-brown. sepals and petals 10-18 x 4-6mm, outer surface of sepals with broad reddish-brown band which sometimes stains inner surface reddish. column 5-6 x 2-3mm, yellow; post-anther lobe absent; apex narrowed, smooth; column arms dark brown, ear-like, held high above column or bent forwards or sideways, usually notched, surface minutely roughened or hairy. anther yellow to orange, papillate. widespread and common from coast to inland plains and ranges, forming small to extensive free-flowering colonies in many different open habitats. often prominent close to coast growing in heathland, grassy patches and scrub in freely draining to poorly drained sandy or peaty soils, but can also be a feature of inland vegetation including open forest, mallee shrubland and woodland in freely draining sands and clay loams; less commonly in seasonally wet open sites among sedges and in shallow soil over rock plates and in rock crevices. notes a familiar orchid that is popular with children. flowering is greatly enhanced by summer fires resulting in impressive floral displays. the insect-pollinated flowers, which open readily, even on cool days, can last for several weeks and have a lemon-scented or vanilla fragrance. mainly sep and oct, but as early as jul and as late as nov depending on region and season. ;
original_text: Leaf terete or channelled, 50-180 x 2-3mm, dark green, base reddish. Flower stem flexuose, 150-300 x 1.5-2mm, wiry, often pinkish, 1-4-flowered. Sterile bracts two. Flowers 20-35mm across, internally pale yellow to deep yellow (rarely white), externally reddish-brown. Sepals and petals 10-18 x 4-6mm, outer surface of sepals with broad reddish-brown band which sometimes stains inner surface reddish. Column 5-6 x 2-3mm, yellow; post-anther lobe absent; apex narrowed, smooth; column arms dark brown, ear-like, held high above column or bent forwards or sideways, usually notched, surface minutely roughened or hairy. Anther yellow to orange, papillate. Widespread and common from coast to inland plains and ranges, forming small to extensive free-flowering colonies in many different open habitats. Often prominent close to coast growing in heathland, grassy patches and scrub in freely draining to poorly drained sandy or peaty soils, but can also be a feature of inland vegetation including open forest, mallee shrubland and woodland in freely draining sands and clay loams; less commonly in seasonally wet open sites among sedges and in shallow soil over rock plates and in rock crevices. Notes A familiar orchid that is popular with children. Flowering is greatly enhanced by summer fires resulting in impressive floral displays. The insect-pollinated flowers, which open readily, even on cool days, can last for several weeks and have a lemon-scented or vanilla fragrance. Mainly Sep and Oct, but as early as Jul and as late as Nov depending on region and season.

fire: this is one of our most spectacular terrestrial orchids and flowering plants produce an impressive display, especially on burnt ground as they respond well to summer fires.
description: leaf 100-400 x 5-40mm, very thick, fleshy, light green to dark green with purplish base, often with dark blotches. flower stem 200-1,000 x 4-9mm, 2-40-flowered. sterile bracts 1-4, large, lowest bract . flowers 20-45mm across, crowded, scented, internally pale blue, deep blue, violet or purplish with darker veins, externally brownish. sepals and petals 10-25 x 4-10mm, concave to flat. column 6-8 x 2-3.5mm, cream to white, pale blue or greenish; post-anther lobe not hooding anther, 2-3 x 1.5-2.2mm, purplish-brown with yellow apex, narrowed to slender incurved elongate toothed s structure; column arms converging, 1.5-2.5mm long, obliquely erect; hair-tufts toothb, dense, white to pale yellow, hairs 1-1.7mm long. anther at base of column. widespread and locally common, growing in open forest, woodland, heathy forest, heathland, buttongrass moorland and around swamp margins in freely draining to wettish sandy and clay soils and peat; less commonly in dense winter-wet swamps with the plants in standing water. notes there has been considerable confusion about the correct identity of this species for more than 100 years and the epithet 'aristata' has been variously applied to members of the nuda complex. this is one of our most spectacular terrestrial orchids and flowering plants produce an impressive display, especially on burnt ground as they respond well to summer fires. the long-lasting, scented, insect-pollinated flowers open readily on sunny days. a rust fungus, uromyces thelymitrae, sometimes infects the plants producing small yellow pustules on the leaves. poll. the author has collected fast-flying native bees flying straight to the column and vigorously investigating the hair tufts with movements of the abdomen, then flying away with the pollinarium attached on the upper side of one of the last two abdominal segments (jones 1981). historical note: thelymitra murdochiae, a freak pelorial variant of aristata with sac-like stigma separate from the other column organs, was described by w.h.nicholls after mrs j.r.murdoch from solitary plant found at wonthaggi, s vic, by ern homann in 1933. homann believed it was a freak but nicholls still described it as new. sep-nov. ;
original_text: Leaf 100-400 x 5-40mm, very thick, fleshy, light green to dark green with purplish base, often with dark blotches. Flower stem 200-1,000 x 4-9mm, 2-40-flowered. Sterile bracts 1-4, large, lowest bract leaf-like. Flowers 20-45mm across, crowded, scented, internally pale blue, deep blue, violet or purplish with darker veins, externally brownish. Sepals and petals 10-25 x 4-10mm, concave to flat. Column 6-8 x 2-3.5mm, cream to white, pale blue or greenish; post-anther lobe not hooding anther, 2-3 x 1.5-2.2mm, purplish-brown with yellow apex, narrowed to slender incurved elongate toothed strap-like structure; column arms converging, 1.5-2.5mm long, obliquely erect; hair-tufts toothbrush-like, dense, white to pale yellow, hairs 1-1.7mm long. Anther at base of column. Widespread and locally common, growing in open forest, woodland, heathy forest, heathland, buttongrass moorland and around swamp margins in freely draining to wettish sandy and clay soils and peat; less commonly in dense winter-wet swamps with the plants in standing water. Notes There has been considerable confusion about the correct identity of this species for more than 100 years and the epithet 'aristata' has been variously applied to members of the T. nuda complex. This is one of our most spectacular terrestrial orchids and flowering plants produce an impressive display, especially on burnt ground as they respond well to summer fires. The long-lasting, scented, insect-pollinated flowers open readily on sunny days. A rust fungus, Uromyces thelymitrae, sometimes infects the plants producing small yellow pustules on the leaves. Poll. The author has collected fast-flying native bees flying straight to the column and vigorously investigating the hair tufts with movements of the abdomen, then flying away with the pollinarium attached on the upper side of one of the last two abdominal segments (Jones 1981). Historical note: Thelymitra murdochiae, a freak pelorial variant of T. aristata with sac-like stigma separate from the other column organs, was described by W.H.Nicholls after Mrs J.R.Murdoch from solitary plant found at Wonthaggi, S Vic, by Ern Homann in 1933. Homann believed it was a freak but Nicholls still described it as new. Sep-Nov.

fire: this lovely species flowers in the absence of fire but is more frequent following summer burn.
description: leaf 100-270 x 3-8mm, channelled, dark green, base purplish. flower stem 130-450 x 1-2.2mm, 1-10-flowered. sterile bract usually one. flowers 20-27mm across (rarely as small as 13mm across), interior dark azure blue with darker longitudinal veins, sometimes flushed with mauve or pink, exterior often brownish. sepals and petals 6-13 x 3-7mm, concave; labellum narrower than petals. column 2.5-4.5 x 2-2.5mm, blue to purplish, winged with projecting flanges; post-anther lobe slightly hooding anther, 0.5-1 x 1-2mm, dark purplish to blackish with yellow tip, apex in short arc, toothed or warty; auxiliary lobes converging, fleshy, rod-like, widest at base, tapered, apex yellow, toothed or warty; column arms obliquely erect, converging, tapered, 1.2-2mm long; hair tufts mop-like, white or purplish, hairs 0.7-1mm long. anther at base of column. localised in heathy forest, heathland and mallee shrubland, growing in freely draining sand or sandy loam; occasionally in wetter soils around margins of swamps; also on crests and slopes of stabilised dunes; in sa often growing in terra rossa soil over limestone sheets. notes showy insect-pollinated flowers open freely on hot days. this lovely species flowers in the absence of fire but is more frequent following summer burn. sep-dec. ;

fire: flowering enhanced by summer fires.
description: leaf ovate to ovate-lanceolate, 50-150 x 20-35mm, bright green to yellowish-green. flower stem 100-550 x 3-5mm, green, 2-15-flowered. sterile bracts usually two, sometimes three. flowers 25-40mm across, internally yellow or greenish-yellow with numerous reddish-brown to dark brown spots, blotches and suffusions (occasionally wholly yellow to greenish yellow), externally dull greenish-brown. sepals and petals 10-20 x 4-8mm, labellum narrowest. column 6-9 x 4-6mm, yellow or greenish with reddish-brown spots, very broadly winged, wings spreading like mantle, yellow, spotted, deeply fringed or toothed (teeth to 1.7mm long); dorsal surface of post-anther lobe covered with dense mass of orange  papillae; supra-anther lobe 1.7-2.5mm long, rod-like with swollen clubbed apex; lateral lobes 1-2mm long, fi, yellow. anther near column base, with curved bulbous  appendage 2.5-3.5mm long. widespread and common, growing in range of habitats in open forest, heathy forest, shrubland and heathland in freely draining sandy soil and clay loam. in wa, where it is much more common than in e states, this species is often found in winter-wet flats, in dense wet heath over laterite and on margins of inland granite outcrops. notes long-lasting flowers open freely on warm to hot days and are apparently self-pollinating since the plants produce numerous seed capsules. flowering enhanced by summer fires. var: the flowers of this widely distributed species vary in colour, floral patterns and column features. plants with pure yellowish flowers are sometimes seen. populations in south stirlings and ongerop area of wa are under study and likely to be recognised as new species. sep-dec. ;
original_text: Leaf ovate to ovate-lanceolate, 50-150 x 20-35mm, bright green to yellowish-green. Flower stem 100-550 x 3-5mm, green, 2-15-flowered. Sterile bracts usually two, sometimes three. Flowers 25-40mm across, internally yellow or greenish-yellow with numerous reddish-brown to dark brown spots, blotches and suffusions (occasionally wholly yellow to greenish yellow), externally dull greenish-brown. Sepals and petals 10-20 x 4-8mm, labellum narrowest. Column 6-9 x 4-6mm, yellow or greenish with reddish-brown spots, very broadly winged, wings spreading like mantle, yellow, spotted, deeply fringed or toothed (teeth to 1.7mm long); dorsal surface of post-anther lobe covered with dense mass of orange hair-like papillae; supra-anther lobe 1.7-2.5mm long, rod-like with swollen clubbed apex; lateral lobes 1-2mm long, finger-like, yellow. Anther near column base, with curved bulbous beak-like appendage 2.5-3.5mm long. Widespread and common, growing in range of habitats in open forest, heathy forest, shrubland and heathland in freely draining sandy soil and clay loam. In WA, where it is much more common than in E states, this species is often found in winter-wet flats, in dense wet heath over laterite and on margins of inland granite outcrops. Notes Long-lasting flowers open freely on warm to hot days and are apparently self-pollinating since the plants produce numerous seed capsules. Flowering enhanced by summer fires. Var.: The flowers of this widely distributed species vary in colour, floral patterns and column features. Plants with pure yellowish flowers are sometimes seen. Populations in South Stirlings and Ongerop area of WA are under study and likely to be recognised as new species. Sep-Dec.

fire: notes flowering enhanced by summer fires.
description: leaf 100-250 x 4-5mm. flower stem 200-500 x 3-6mm, 2-15-flowered. sterile bracts two or three. flowers bell-shaped, 15-20mm across, light blue or purple (sometimes mauve or pink) with prominent broad dark blue longitudinal veins. sepals and petals 7-10 x 4-6mm, concave; labellum as broad as petals. column divided into three parts, 3.5-4 x 3mm, dark blue to purplish with blackish crest and yellow tips; post-anther lobe not hooding anther, short, narrow, crested, with crowded short fi papillae; auxiliary lobes converging, obliquely erect, apex lobed, yellow; column arms spreading forwards to obliquely erect; hair-tufts dense, b, hairs white or yellow. anther near middle of column. widespread and common but mostly coastal or near-coastal, growing in freely draining sandy soil in woodland and among low scrub. notes flowering enhanced by summer fires. insect-pollinated flowers open freely on sunny days and perianth segments do not spread widely but rather remain cupped to impart bell-shaped appearance to flowers. sep-oct. ;
original_text: Leaf 100-250 x 4-5mm. Flower stem 200-500 x 3-6mm, 2-15-flowered. Sterile bracts two or three. fire: it responds strongly to summer fires, especially in overgrown habitats and studies suggest that this orchid may disappear from dense habitats that remain unburnt (calder et al.
description: plants single or in small tufts. leaf often arising at an acute angle to soil surface, 180-300 x 15-30mm, thick, leathery, dark green with reddish base, whole leaf often yellowish-green. flower stem 200-500 x 4-7mm, 5-25-flowered. sterile bracts one or two. flowers 25-42mm across, cream, pink, greenish blue, pale blue, greyish blue, orange, reddish or bronzy with coppery sheen, scented. sepals and petals 12-20 x 4-10mm, thick-textured, concave; labellum narrower than other segments. column 5-8 x 2.3-4.5mm, same colour as perianth, 3-lobed; post-anther lobe not hooding anther, 2-3 x 1-1.5mm, s, narrowed upwards, incurved, reddish-brown with purplish collar, apex yellow, irregularly toothed; auxiliary lobes s, 1-1.7mm long, incurved and often interlocking, apex yellow, irregularly toothed; column arms converging, porrect to obliquely erect, circa1.5mm long; hair tufts toothb, dense, hairs white, 1-2mm long. anther at base of column. widely distributed but now restricted to isolated populations that range from coastal districts, where it grows in grassland, heathland, sedgeland and shrubby forest in seasonally wet sandy soils, to inland areas in drier forest and mallee communities, usually in freely draining sandy soil. notes long-lasting, sweetly but lightly fragrant, colourful, insect-pollinated flowers open freely on hot sunny days. this orchid is commonest in open situations growing among low vegetation, but it also occurs in taller shrubby habitats. it responds strongly to summer fires, especially in overgrown habitats and studies suggest that this orchid may disappear from dense habitats that remain unburnt (calder et al. 1989, swifft (2007). these studies also report that nearly all seedlings of this orchid were found in open sites where disturbance, such as digging by animals, had occurred. the plants were also found to be highly palatable to grazing animals. poll. pollinated by native bees in genera nomia and lasioglossum (halictidae) and a species of blow fly, calliphora stygia, lured into visiting nectarless flowers by floral colours and fragrance (cropper & calder 1990). sep-nov. ;
original_text: Plants single or in small tufts. Leaf often arising at an acute angle to soil surface, 180-300 x 15-30mm, thick, leathery, dark green with reddish base, whole leaf often yellowish-green. Flower stem 200-500 x 4-7mm, 5-25-flowered. Sterile bracts one or two. Flowers 25-42mm across, cream, pink, greenish blue, pale blue, greyish blue, orange, reddish or bronzy with coppery sheen, scented. Sepals and petals 12-20 x 4-10mm, thick-textured, concave; labellum narrower than other segments. Column 5-8 x 2.3-4.5mm, same colour as perianth, 3-lobed; post-anther lobe not hooding anther, 2-3 x 1-1.5mm, strap-like, narrowed upwards, incurved, reddish-brown with purplish collar, apex yellow, irregularly toothed; auxiliary lobes strap-like, 1-1.7mm long, incurved and often interlocking, apex yellow, irregularly toothed; column arms converging, porrect to obliquely erect, c.1.5mm long; hair tufts toothbrush-like, dense, hairs white, 1-2mm long. Anther at base of column. Widely distributed but now restricted to isolated populations that range from coastal districts, where it grows in grassland, heathland, sedgeland and shrubby forest in seasonally wet sandy soils, to inland areas in drier forest and mallee communities, usually in freely draining sandy soil. Notes Long-lasting, sweetly but lightly fragrant, colourful, insect-pollinated flowers open freely on hot sunny days. This orchid is commonest in open situations growing among low vegetation, but it also occurs in taller shrubby habitats. It responds strongly to summer fires, especially in overgrown habitats and studies suggest that this orchid may disappear from dense habitats that remain unburnt (Calder et al. 1989, SWIFFT (2007). These studies also report that nearly all seedlings of this orchid were found in open sites where disturbance, such as digging by animals, had occurred. The plants were also found to be highly palatable to grazing animals. Poll. Pollinated by native bees in genera Nomia and Lasioglossum (Halictidae) and a species of blow fly, Calliphora stygia, lured into visiting nectarless flowers by floral colours and fragrance (Cropper & Calder 1990). Sep-Nov.

fire: flowering enhanced by summer fires, mowing and slashing.
description: leaf 100-300 x 6-12mm, leathery, dark green, base purplish. flower stem 150-500 x 2-3.5mm, 1-8-flowered. sterile bracts usually two. flowers 30-40mm across (rarely as small as 15mm across), interior blue to purplish blue or pink with darker longitudinal veins, exterior dusky purple. sepals and petals 8-18 x 4-10mm, labellum widest. column 5-6.5 x 2.5-4mm, broadly winged, white or pale blue with brown or bluish apical collar; post-anther lobe short, slightly hooding anther, 1-2.5 x 1.5-2.8mm, reddish-brown to black with yellow apex, dorsal surface rough or bumpy with  knobs; column arms parallel, projecting forwards, more or less parallel, white or yellow, 1.5-2.5mm long, irregularly and deeply lobed. anther near column apex. locally common in moist to wet sites in heathy forest, heathland and on swamp margins, growing in peaty soil; also colonises roadsides and other disturbed sites. notes variable in degree of striping on perianth segments; some specimens have no stripes, others are faintly striped whereas most are strongly striped. self-pollinating flowers open freely on warm to hot days. flowering enhanced by summer fires, mowing and slashing. late oct-dec. ;
original_text: Leaf 100-300 x 6-12mm, leathery, dark green, base purplish. Flower stem 150-500 x 2-3.5mm, 1-8-flowered. Sterile bracts usually two. Flowers 30-40mm across (rarely as small as 15mm across), interior blue to purplish blue or pink with darker longitudinal veins, exterior dusky purple. Sepals and petals 8-18 x 4-10mm, labellum widest. Column 5-6.5 x 2.5-4mm, broadly winged, white or pale blue with brown or bluish apical collar; post-anther lobe short, slightly hooding anther, 1-2.5 x 1.5-2.8mm, reddish-brown to black with yellow apex, dorsal surface rough or bumpy with wart-like knobs; column arms parallel, projecting forwards, more or less parallel, white or yellow, 1.5-2.5mm long, irregularly and deeply lobed. Anther near column apex. Locally common in moist to wet sites in heathy forest, heathland and on swamp margins, growing in peaty soil; also colonises roadsides and other disturbed sites. Notes Variable in degree of striping on perianth segments; some specimens have no stripes, others are faintly striped whereas most are strongly striped. Self-pollinating flowers open freely on warm to hot days. Flowering enhanced by summer fires, mowing and slashing. Late Oct-Dec.

fire: flowering enhanced by summer fires.
description: leaf terete, 60-200 x 0.5-1mm, wiry. flower stem flexuose, 100-300 x 1-1.5mm, reddish, wiry, 1-4-flowered (usually 2). sterile bracts several, small. flowers 10-15mm across, cream to pale yellow. sepals and petals 5.5-9 x 3.5-4mm (labellum shortest and narrowest), externally brownish-yellow. column 3.5-4.5 x 2.5mm, white to cream, four lines of short hairs on dorsal surface from base to apex; post-anther lobe very short, not hooded, sometimes notched, few brown papillae on dorsal side; column arms reduced to small bumps or rounded lobes. anther large, bright yellow to orange, covered with short hairs or papillae. widespread and common, growing among low shrubs and sedges in depressions, swamp margins, heathland and other seasonally moist to wet sites in sandy and peaty soil, sometimes in shallow water. notes an inconspicuous orchid that occasionally grows in vegetative tufts but is easily overlooked even when in flower. short-lived, self-pollinating flowers open tardily only on hot humid days, and in cool cloudy weather may not open at all. on very hot days sepals and petals can reflex strongly leaving column protruding conspicuously. flowering enhanced by summer fires. sep-nov. ;
original_text: Leaf terete, 60-200 x 0.5-1mm, wiry. Flower stem flexuose, 100-300 x 1-1.5mm, reddish, wiry, 1-4-flowered (usually 2). Sterile bracts several, small. Flowers 10-15mm across, cream to pale yellow. Sepals and petals 5.5-9 x 3.5-4mm (labellum shortest and narrowest), externally brownish-yellow. Column 3.5-4.5 x 2.5mm, white to cream, four lines of short hairs on dorsal surface from base to apex; post-anther lobe very short, not hooded, sometimes notched, few brown papillae on dorsal side; column arms reduced to small bumps or rounded lobes. Anther large, bright yellow to orange, covered with short hairs or papillae. Widespread and common, growing among low shrubs and sedges in depressions, swamp margins, heathland and other seasonally moist to wet sites in sandy and peaty soil, sometimes in shallow water. Notes An inconspicuous orchid that occasionally grows in vegetative tufts but is easily overlooked even when in flower. Short-lived, self-pollinating flowers open tardily only on hot humid days, and in cool cloudy weather may not open at all. On very hot days sepals and petals can reflex strongly leaving column protruding conspicuously. Flowering enhanced by summer fires. Sep-Nov.

fire: flowering enhanced by summer fires.
description: leaf ovate to ovate-lanceolate, 50-150 x 10-30mm, leathery, bright green to yellowish-green, often withered at flowering time. flower stem 150-450 x 3-5mm, green, 2-25-flowered. sterile bracts two or three. flowers 20-40mm across, brown or purplish-brown with irregular greenish or yellowish streaks, spots and blotches, externally brown with a green median line. sepals and petals 8-20 x 3-6mm, labellum narrowest. column 6-9 x 4-6mm, pale yellow or whitish, often spotted or blotched, very broadly winged, wings spreading like mantle, pale yellow, margins deeply fringed or toothed (teeth to 2mm long); post-anther lobe with dense dorsal patch of globose to linear white papillae; supra-anther lobe 2-3.5 x 1mm, cream to whitish, with narrow projecting ch apex; lateral lobes 1.5-2mm long, fi, cream. anther near column base, with curved  bulbous appendage 2-3mm long. localised, mainly growing in seasonally wet soil in depressions and along swamp margins, often in dense shrubby coastal heath and forests; also in drier open habitats growing in freely draining soils. notes insect-pollinated flowers open freely on warm to hot days. flowering enhanced by summer fires. nov-feb. ;
original_text: Leaf ovate to ovate-lanceolate, 50-150 x 10-30mm, leathery, bright green to yellowish-green, often withered at flowering time. Flower stem 150-450 x 3-5mm, green, 2-25-flowered. Sterile bracts two or three. Flowers 20-40mm across, brown or purplish-brown with irregular greenish or yellowish streaks, spots and blotches, externally brown with a green median line. Sepals and petals 8-20 x 3-6mm, labellum narrowest. Column 6-9 x 4-6mm, pale yellow or whitish, often spotted or blotched, very broadly winged, wings spreading like mantle, pale yellow, margins deeply fringed or toothed (teeth to 2mm long); post-anther lobe with dense dorsal patch of globose to linear white papillae; supra-anther lobe 2-3.5 x 1mm, cream to whitish, with narrow projecting chisel-like apex; lateral lobes 1.5-2mm long, finger-like, cream. Anther near column base, with curved beak-like bulbous appendage 2-3mm long. Localised, mainly growing in seasonally wet soil in depressions and along swamp margins, often in dense shrubby coastal heath and forests; also in drier open habitats growing in freely draining soils. Notes Insect-pollinated flowers open freely on warm to hot days. Flowering enhanced by summer fires. Nov-Feb.

fire: notes flowering plants produce spectacular display, especially on burnt ground.
description: leaf 100-400 x 10-30mm, very thick, fleshy, dark green, often glaucous, base green or purplish. flower stem 200-1000 x 4-8mm, 2-30-flowered. sterile bracts two to four, large, lowest bract . flowers 20-40mm across, crowded, internally blue to dark metallic blue, mauve, lilac, pale purple or greenish blue with darker veins, externally greenish or brownish. sepals and petals 8-20 x 4-10mm, concave. column 5-8 x 2-3.5mm, cream, pale yellow, mauve or greenish; post-anther lobe not hooding anther, 4.5-5.5 x 2-3mm, s, pale brown with yellow apex, strongly incurved, prominently notched, irregularly toothed; column arms converging, 1.5-2.5mm long, obliquely erect; hair-tufts toothb, moderately dense, white, hairs 1-1.5mm long. anther at base of column. locally common, growing in open forest, shrubland and heathland, often on rocky slopes and ridges in hard clay or freely draining gravelly soil. notes flowering plants produce spectacular display, especially on burnt ground. insect-pollinated sweetly scented flowers open freely in warm weather. var: bates (2014) named grandiflora subsp exposa from plants growing in wirrabarra nfr in flinders ra., sa, based on following differences: smaller plants (less than 500mm tall), more slender and colourful (leaf pink to purplish, flower stem purple to purple-black or brown, sterile bracts pink, buds bluish-black), smaller deep blue flowers (10-30mm across) and dark post-anther lobe deeply notched and decurved. subsequent morphological and molecular studies show this taxon nests within normal variation of grandiflora (mark clements pers. comm.). sep-dec. ;
original_text: Leaf 100-400 x 10-30mm, very thick, fleshy, dark green, often glaucous, base green or purplish. Flower stem 200-1000 x 4-8mm, 2-30-flowered. Sterile bracts two to four, large, lowest bract leaf-like. Flowers 20-40mm across, crowded, internally blue to dark metallic blue, mauve, lilac, pale purple or greenish blue with darker veins, externally greenish or brownish. Sepals and petals 8-20 x 4-10mm, concave. Column 5-8 x 2-3.5mm, cream, pale yellow, mauve or greenish; post-anther lobe not hooding anther, 4.5-5.5 x 2-3mm, strap-like, pale brown with yellow apex, strongly incurved, prominently notched, irregularly toothed; column arms converging, 1.5-2.5mm long, obliquely erect; hair-tufts toothbrush-like, moderately dense, white, hairs 1-1.5mm long. Anther at base of column. Locally common, growing in open forest, shrubland and heathland, often on rocky slopes and ridges in hard clay or freely draining gravelly soil. Notes Flowering plants produce spectacular display, especially on burnt ground. Insect-pollinated sweetly scented flowers open freely in warm weather. Var.: Bates (2014) named T. grandiflora subsp. exposa from plants growing in Wirrabarra NFR in Flinders Ra., SA, based on following differences: smaller plants (less than 500mm tall), more slender and colourful (leaf pink to purplish, flower stem purple to purple-black or brown, sterile bracts pink, buds bluish-black), smaller deep blue flowers (10-30mm across) and dark post-anther lobe deeply notched and decurved. Subsequent morphological and molecular studies show this taxon nests within normal variation of T. grandiflora (Mark Clements pers. comm.). Sep-Dec.

fire: flowering enhanced by summer fires.
description: leaf 70-350 x 3-10mm, fleshy, ribbed, light green or dark green, base purplish. flower stem 200-750 x 1-2.5mm, 1-12-flowered. sterile bracts usually two. flowers 15-30mm across, dark purplish blue or mauve. sepals and petals 6-15 x 3.5-8mm, concave. column 4.5-6.5 x 2.5-3.5mm, pale blue, dark mauve or pink; post-anther lobe 2.5-3.5 x 1.5-2.5mm, dark purple to black with yellow apex, tubular, inflated, hooded, curved through 90º, deeply notched; column arms 1-1.5mm long, curved gently upwards; hair-tufts toothb, sparse, cream or pale yellow (sometimes pinkish), hairs 1.2-1.8mm long, erect and embracing front of midlobe. widely distributed but generally uncommon, growing in winter-wet sites such as swamps, swamp margins, seepage areas or low-lying flats in open forest, woodland, heathy forest and heathland in moist to wet clay or clay loam; plants sometimes grow in standing water. notes self-pollinating flowers open tardily only on hot humid days and in cool weather do not open at all. flowering enhanced by summer fires. late oct-dec. ;

Widely distributed but generally uncommon, growing in winter-wet sites such as swamps, swamp margins, seepage areas or low-lying flats in open forest, woodland, heathy forest and heathland in moist to wet clay or clay loam; plants sometimes grow in standing water. Notes Self-pollinating flowers open tardily only on hot humid days and in cool weather do not open at all. Flowering enhanced by summer fires. Late Oct-Dec.

fire: flowering enhanced by summer fires.
description: leaf 100-200 x 8-10mm. flower stem 150-250 x 2-3mm, 1-8-flowered. sterile bracts two or three. flowers 20-25mm across, pale blue to bright blue, externally blue or mauve. sepals and petals 12-15 x 5.5-8mm (labellum narrowest). column 5-6 x 2.5-3mm, white or bluish with pale yellow apex and dark apical collar; post-anther lobe short, dorsal surface with few irregular bumps, yellow-tipped, deeply and irregularly lobed; auxiliary lobes short, not much higher than post-anther lobe, deeply toothed; column arms obliquely erect, 1-2mm long; hair-tufts elongated, mop-like, somewhat sparse, white, hairs circa1mm long. highly localised, growing in coastal and near-coastal heathland and heathy forest in low-lying sites that are seasonally moist; also on disturbed sites such as gravel scrapes and old quarries. the discovery of this species in se nsw is possible as it extends to genoa and shipwreck creek in far e gippsland, vic. notes self-pollinating flowers open tardily on hot days. flowering enhanced by summer fires. oct-dec. ;
original_text: Leaf 100-200 x 8-10mm. Flower stem 150-250 x 2-3mm, 1-8-flowered. Sterile bracts two or three. Flowers 20-25mm across, pale blue to bright blue, externally blue or mauve. Sepals and petals 12-15 x 5.5-8mm (labellum narrowest). Column 5-6 x 2.5-3mm, white or bluish with pale yellow apex and dark apical collar; post-anther lobe short, dorsal surface with few irregular bumps, yellow-tipped, deeply and irregularly lobed; auxiliary lobes short, not much higher than post-anther lobe, deeply toothed; column arms obliquely erect, 1-2mm long; hair-tufts elongated, mop-like, somewhat sparse, white, hairs c.1mm long. Highly localised, growing in coastal and near-coastal heathland and heathy forest in low-lying sites that are seasonally moist; also on disturbed sites such as gravel scrapes and old quarries. The discovery of this species in SE NSW is possible as it extends to Genoa and Shipwreck Creek in far E Gippsland, Vic. Notes Self-pollinating flowers open tardily on hot days. Flowering enhanced by summer fires. Oct-Dec.

fire: flowering enhanced by summer fires.
description: leaf ovate to ovate-lanceolate, 60-120 x 10-20mm, leathery, bright green to yellowish-green. flower stem 200-350 x 1.5-2mm, green, 2-12-flowered. sterile bracts usually two. flowers often crowded, 45-55mm across, rich brown to dark golden-brown with large orange or yellow blotches and streaks, externally similar. sepals and petals 16-27 x 4-8mm, labellum narrowest. column 9-12 x 5-7mm, base brown, apex orange, very broadly winged, wings spreading like mantle, pale yellow or tan, deeply and stiffly fringed or toothed (teeth to 2.5mm long); dorsal surface of post-anther lobe covered by dense mass of orange papillae; supra-anther lobe 3-4mm long, rod-like, yellow or tan, with projecting clubbed apex that resembles head of mudskipper; lateral lobes 2-2.5mm long, fi, fleshy, orange. anther near column base, with curved  appendage 3-4mm long. highly restricted, growing among shrubs in moist sandy clay loam close to low-lying areas that become waterlogged in winter. notes insect-pollinated sweetly cinnamon-scented flowers open freely on warm to hot days. flowering enhanced by summer fires. dec-jan. ;
original_text: Leaf ovate to ovate-lanceolate, 60-120 x 10-20mm, leathery, bright green to yellowish-green. Flower stem 200-350 x 1.5-2mm, green, 2-12-flowered. Sterile bracts usually two. Flowers often crowded, 45-55mm across, rich brown to dark golden-brown with large orange or yellow blotches and streaks, externally similar. Sepals and petals 16-27 x 4-8mm, labellum narrowest. Column 9-12 x 5-7mm, base brown, apex orange, very broadly winged, wings spreading like mantle, pale yellow or tan, deeply and stiffly fringed or toothed (teeth to 2.5mm long); dorsal surface of post-anther lobe covered by dense mass of orange papillae; supra-anther lobe 3-4mm long, rod-like, yellow or tan, with projecting clubbed apex that resembles head of mudskipper; lateral lobes 2-2.5mm long, finger-like, fleshy, orange.
